--- layout: new_default title: The Wings of the Dove - Volume I ---

The Wings of the Dove

Bilingual Edition — Volume I

    {% for i in (1..16) %}
  • {{ i }}
    • {% endfor %}

Chapter I

Listen to Chapter I

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

Kate Croy waits for her father in a room. While she waits, she looks at her reflection in a mirror, moves from a sofa to an armchair, examines prints on the wall, and stands on a small balcony looking at the street. She later returns to the mirror, where she adjusts her hat and hair.

Her father, Lionel Croy, arrives. Kate tells him she is glad he is better. He replies that he is unwell and has been to the chemist. She tells him he looks lovely. He assesses her appearance. She asks him how long he has been at his current lodging. She then tells him she is willing to go with him and stay with him, even there. She takes off her gloves and sits down.

He asks where she would go with him, then says he cannot consent to her staying. She asks what he will do. He says he is thinking. She asks if he has considered that she is ready to stay. He says he has not. He asks if she truly expects him to believe she has decided to do this.

She replies that she doesn't care what he believes and that she doesn't know him. He asks if she thinks she can "make that up," and she says no. She says she doesn't understand how he gets on. He replies that he doesn't. She says that he flourishes. He asks if she is again bringing up that he has not killed himself. She tells him about her mother's will, which provides two hundred pounds a year for her sister Marian and two hundred for herself, but that she gives one hundred of her share to Marian.

He calls her a "weak thing." She says the remaining hundred would help them both together and asks if he can do anything. He looks at her, then turns and stands by the window. He asks what has "wound her up." She explains that her Aunt Maud has made her a proposal with a condition: that Kate must sever all relations with him.

He agrees that this is the condition and asks if she supposes he can support her. She says yes. He calls her a fool. She says she offers to accept his life and will do everything she can for him. He asks what she can do and says she cannot afford to give up her aunt. She rises, goes back to the mirror, and adjusts her hat. He tells her she is "all right" and not to get involved with him. She turns to him and details the condition: she must never see, speak to, write, or communicate with him in any way.

He calls the requirement proper and asks what her aunt promises in return. He tells Kate her opportunity and duty is to "use" him. He asks if she has decided to give half her inheritance to her sister. She laughs and says no. He asks if she plans to let her sister have it. She asks if he wants her to give him everything. He says he refuses what she came to offer.

She says if she signs the agreement with her aunt, she will honor it. He tells her to "marry properly," and then he will resume relations with her. She picks up her parasol and asks if this is because he fears her aunt more than a potential husband. He says he trusts her aunt's judgment completely for any man she selects.

Kate says goodbye and states that it may be for a long time. He suggests it be forever. She looks at him for a long time. She says she wishes a witness were there to confirm her offer to stay. He asks if she wants him to call the landlady. She says there is only one word he needs to speak. He turns his back to her and says he has already spoken it. She offers to give up her aunt for him. He turns around, says she makes him sick, and opens the door.

He says the real issue is that she is in love, and her aunt disapproves. He tells her to go. Standing in the doorway, Kate says her aunt is not the person she pities most. He asks if she is deceiving two people. She shakes her head and says if he fails her, she will go her own way. He asks if that means marrying a poor man. He demands to know who the man is. She replies that the man wants to be kind to him.

He calls the man an ass and says he will not hear of anyone her aunt disapproves of. He warns that if she defies them both, he will make her regret it. She says if she doesn't defy them, it will not be out of fear of him. She asks if he can do nothing for her. He replies that he has given his advice and tells her to go to her sister Marian for consolation.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

This extended passage, the opening of Henry James's *The Wings of the Dove*, is a masterclass in psychological realism and narrative setup. Through a tense and protracted meeting between Kate Croy and her father, Lionel, James establishes the novel's core thematic concerns, delves deep into the consciousness of his protagonist, and introduces the major literary ideas that will drive the narrative forward. The analysis reveals a world of moral decay, transactional relationships, and the desperate struggle for agency within suffocating social constraints.

### Themes

**1. Appearance Versus Reality:** This is the most pervasive theme in the passage. It is embodied by Lionel Croy, a man whose physical presentation is a complete contradiction of his moral character. He is described as the quintessential "English gentleman," with a "perfect look," "pink and silver as to skin and hair," and "kind, safe eyes." His appearance suggests fortune, stability, and integrity. Yet, the narrative voice and Kate’s consciousness reveal him to be a liar, a manipulator, and a moral void. He "dealt out lies as he might the cards from the greasy old pack," and his "plausibility had been the heaviest of her mother's crosses." This chasm between his immaculate surface and his internal corruption is the central tragedy of the Croy family. Kate herself is acutely aware of this theme, using the "tarnished glass" of the mirror not just for vanity, but to compose her own appearance, recognizing it as a necessary tool for navigating a world that judges by surfaces.

**2. Moral and Financial Decay:** The setting is a powerful symbol of this theme. The "vulgar little room" in Chirk Street is described in painstaking detail: the "shabby sofa," the "slippery and sticky" armchair, the "sallow prints," and the "lonely magazine, a year old." Every object emanates "the failure of fortune and of honour." This physical squalor is a direct reflection of the Croy family's social and moral collapse. Kate tastes the "faint, flat emanation of things," a sensory experience of her family's decline. The family history itself is described as a "fine florid, voluminous phrase... that dropped... into no words, no notes at all," a metaphor for grand potential that has dissolved into meaningless failure.

**3. The Commodification of Human Relationships:** In the world Kate inhabits, people are not valued for their intrinsic worth but for their utility. Lionel Croy is the chief practitioner of this worldview. He appraises his daughter's "happy aspect as a sensible value" and an "asset." His advice regarding Aunt Maud's proposal is not paternal but strategic: Kate's duty, he argues, is to "use me" by abandoning him to secure a financially advantageous marriage. He sees her potential marriage not as a source of happiness, but as a transaction that might eventually benefit him. "There's in fact, my dear," he concludes, "a coach-and-four to be got out of me." This reduces family bonds to a cynical game of profit and loss.

**4. The Constraints of Gender:** Kate’s consciousness is painfully aware of her limited agency as a woman in this society. In a moment of intense frustration, she "lost herself in the thought of the way she might still pull things round had she only been a man." As a "penniless girl," her primary path to security is through a strategic marriage, orchestrated by her powerful aunt. Her beauty is her main currency, a fact she acknowledges as she studies her reflection. Her father’s plan for her revolves entirely around her marrying a "proper one" selected by her aunt, highlighting how her fate is to be determined by others.

### Character Development

**Kate Croy:** The passage is a deep dive into Kate’s complex and conflicted character. She is not a simple victim. * **Resilience and Pragmatism:** Despite being steeped in the "shames" of her family, Kate is a fighter. She is described as not judging herself "cheap" and not making for "misery." She possesses an inner strength and a clear-sighted understanding of her predicament. Her repeated self-examinations in the mirror are acts of composing herself for battle, of solidifying the one "asset" she truly controls. * **Internal Conflict:** Kate is torn between a lingering, desperate hope for familial connection and a bitter, clear-eyed realism. She offers to stay with her father, a final test of his character, which he spectacularly fails. Her anger is potent: "She tried to be sad, so as not to be angry; but it made her angry that she couldn't be sad." This reveals a profound disillusionment; she knows she should mourn her family's state, but her father’s character only provokes fury. * **Developing Resolve:** By the end of the scene, Kate has moved from waiting and impatience to a state of grim resolution. His father’s self-serving advice, culminating in the "inspiration" that she abandon him "for ever," solidifies her understanding that she is utterly alone. Her final departure, after having her last, sincere appeal for solidarity rejected, marks a turning point. She will now "go my way—as I see my way," suggesting a move toward the calculated pragmatism her world demands.

**Lionel Croy:** Lionel does not develop; rather, he is *revealed* in all his monstrous complexity. * **The Performer:** He is a man who exists only on the surface. His charm, his "perfect look," and his ability to "turn the tables" are performance arts honed over a lifetime. He meets Kate’s serious emotional crisis with a performance of paternal sacrifice, reframing his own abandonment as a noble gesture for her benefit. * **Moral Emptiness:** The narrator states he has "ceased to be amusing—he was really too inhuman." He is incapable of authentic emotion, extinguishing both tragic and comic feeling with his presence. He cannot comprehend Kate’s offer of loyalty except through a transactional lens, immediately asking what her aunt will "engage to do." * **Master of Inversion and Manipulation:** His genius lies in his ability to twist language and morality. He lectures Kate on the "deplorably superficial morality of the age" and the decline of "family sentiment" while simultaneously advising her to sell herself to the highest bidder. His argument that she has an "admirable opportunity" to "use me" is a breathtaking act of moral jujitsu, turning his own parasitic nature into a paternal duty she owes him. His true motivation is revealed in the end: his anger stems from her giving her meager inheritance to her sister instead of him, grounding all his lofty performance in petty greed.

### Major Literary Ideas

* **Psychological Realism:** The narrative prioritizes Kate’s internal consciousness above all else. The long, complex sentences with their many subordinate clauses mirror the intricate and often contradictory process of human thought. We experience the shabby room, the frustrating wait, and the manipulative dialogue not as objective facts, but as they are filtered through Kate's perceptions, memories, and emotions. * **Symbolism of Setting:** The room in Chirk Street is a powerful "objective correlative"—an external manifestation of an internal state. Its ugliness is "positive and palpable," its textures "slippery and of the sticky." It is a physical embodiment of the moral decay and entrapment that Kate feels, making the abstract concepts of honor, fortune, and family tangible and oppressive. * **The Power of Subtext:** The dialogue is a masterwork of subtext. The true meaning of the conversation lies beneath the polished, often evasive words the characters use. When Lionel says, "I can never consent to that," he means the opposite. When Kate offers to stay, she is demanding a proof of love that she knows he cannot provide. James forces the reader to act as an interpreter, to decode the vast difference between what is said and what is meant, which is central to the novel's exploration of social artifice.

She waited, Kate Croy, for her father to come in, but he kept her unconscionably, and there were moments at which she showed herself, in the glass over the mantel, a face positively pale with the irritation that had brought her to the point of going away without sight of him. It was at this point, however, that she remained; changing her place, moving from the shabby sofa to the armchair upholstered in a glazed cloth that gave at once—she had tried it—the sense of the slippery and of the sticky. She had looked at the sallow prints on the walls and at the lonely magazine, a year old, that combined, with a small lamp in coloured glass and a knitted white centre-piece wanting in freshness, to enhance the effect of the purplish cloth on the principal table; she had above all, from time to time, taken a brief stand on the small balcony to which the pair of long windows gave access. The vulgar little street, in this view, offered scant relief from the vulgar little room; its main office was to suggest to her that the narrow black house-fronts, adjusted to a standard that would have been low even for backs, constituted quite the publicity implied by such privacies.

Translation

Kate Croy waited for her father to arrive, but he made her wait an inexcusable length of time. At certain points, reflected in the mirror over the mantelpiece, her face appeared genuinely pale with the frustration that had almost caused her to leave without seeing him. Yet, she persevered, changing her position, moving from the worn sofa to the armchair covered in a glazed fabric that, upon testing, felt simultaneously slippery and sticky. She examined the sickly prints on the walls and the outdated magazine, a year old, which, along with a small, colored-glass lamp and a knitted white doily that was no longer fresh, amplified the effect of the purplish tablecloth on the main table. Above all, she occasionally stepped onto the tiny balcony, accessible through the long windows. The unremarkable street outside offered little escape from the unremarkable room; its primary function was to remind her that the narrow, black facades, built to a standard that would have been poor even for rear elevations, provided all the visibility that these private spaces could possibly require.

One felt them in the room exactly as one felt the room—the hundred like it or worse—in the street. Each time she turned in again, each time, in her impatience, she gave him up, it was to sound to a deeper depth, while she tasted the faint, flat emanation of things, the failure of fortune and of honour. If she continued to wait it was really, in a manner, that she might not add the shame of fear, of individual, personal collapse, to all the other shames. To feel the street, to feel the room, to feel the table-cloth and the centre-piece and the lamp, gave her a small, salutary sense, at least, of neither shirking nor lying.

Translation

One felt the room's atmosphere, just as one felt the other hundred rooms like it, or worse, out on the street. Each time she turned back inside, each time her impatience led her to abandon him, it was to sink further into a deeper despair, as she experienced the faint, lifeless essence of everything: the failure of fortune and of honor. If she continued to wait, it was really so that she might not compound the shame of fear, of personal ruin, with all the other shames. To feel the street, to feel the room, to feel the tablecloth and the centerpiece and the lamp, provided her with a small, helpful sensation, at least, that she was neither avoiding nor deceiving.

This whole vision was the worst thing yet—as including, in particular, the interview for which she had prepared herself; and for what had she come but for the worst? She tried to be sad, so as not to be angry; but it made her angry that she couldn't be sad. And yet where was misery, misery too beaten for blame and chalk-marked by fate like a "lot" at a common auction, if not in these merciless signs of mere mean, stale feelings? Kate Croy waited for her father to arrive, but he was taking an unreasonable amount of time.

Translation

This whole vision was the worst thing yet—especially the interview she had prepared for. And why else had she come, if not for the worst? She tried to be sad, so she wouldn't be angry, but it angered her that she couldn't feel sad. And yet, where was true misery—misery too battered to blame, and chalked by fate like a "lot" at a public auction—if not in these merciless signs of petty, stale feelings? Kate Croy waited for her father to arrive, but he was taking an unreasonable amount of time.

There were moments when she glanced at her reflection in the mirror above the fireplace and saw a face visibly pale with the frustration that had brought her to the point of leaving without seeing him. However, she stayed put, shifting from the worn sofa to the armchair, which was covered in a slick, glazed fabric that felt both slippery and sticky. She examined the faded prints on the walls, and the lonely, year-old magazine, which, along with a small lamp with colored glass and a knitted white doily that was no longer fresh, amplified the effect of the purplish tablecloth on the main table. Most of all, she occasionally stepped onto the tiny balcony accessible through the long windows.

Translation

There were instances when she would catch her reflection in the mirror above the fireplace and observe a face blanched with the exasperation that had almost driven her to depart without seeing him. Nevertheless, she remained, oscillating between the worn sofa and the armchair, draped in a smooth, glossy fabric that felt both slick and tacky. She scrutinized the faded prints adorning the walls, and the solitary, year-old magazine which, alongside a small lamp with colored glass and a knitted white doily that had lost its freshness, amplified the effect of the purplish tablecloth on the main table. Most frequently, she would step out onto the tiny balcony accessed through the long windows.

The unremarkable little street offered little respite from the unremarkable little room; its primary function was to remind her that the narrow, black house fronts, built to a standard that was low even for the backs of buildings, represented the kind of public exposure implied by such private spaces. One felt them in the room just as one felt the room—and the hundreds like it, or worse—in the street. Each time she turned back inside, each time, in her impatience, she gave up on him, she sank into a deeper despair as she experienced the faint, lifeless atmosphere of things, the failure of fortune and of honor. If she continued to wait, it was really, in a way, to avoid adding the shame of fear, of personal collapse, to all the other shames.

Translation

The plain street offered no escape from the plain little room; it mostly served to remind her that the narrow, black facades, constructed to a standard even lower than the backs of buildings, mirrored the public exposure inherent in her private space. She felt them in the room, just as she felt the room—and the hundreds like it, or worse—out on the street. Each time she returned inside, each time, in her impatience, she gave up on him, she sank into a deeper despair as she sensed the faint, lifeless atmosphere of things, the failure of fortune and honor. If she continued to wait, it was really, in a way, to avoid adding the shame of fear, of personal collapse, to all the other shames.

To feel the street, to feel the room, to feel the tablecloth, the doily, and the lamp, at least gave her a small, beneficial sense of neither evading nor lying. This entire scene was the worst thing yet, particularly the meeting for which she had prepared herself. Why had she come but for the worst? She tried to be sad so as not to be angry, but it made her angry that she couldn't be sad.

Translation

Feeling the street, the room, the tablecloth, the doily, and the lamp provided a small, helpful sensation of not running away or pretending. This whole situation was the worst, especially the meeting she’d readied herself for. Why had she come if not for the worst? She tried to be sad to avoid anger, but her inability to feel sadness only made her angry.

And yet, where was true misery, misery too defeated to assign blame and marked by fate like a "lot" at a public auction, if not in these relentless signs of mere petty, worn-out feelings? Her father's life, her sister's, her own, that of her two lost brothers—the whole history of their house had the effect of some fine florid, voluminous phrase, say even a musical, that dropped first into words, into notes, without sense, and then, hanging unfinished, into no words, no notes at all. Why should a set of people have been put in motion, on such a scale and with such an air of being equipped for a profitable journey, only to break down without an accident, to stretch themselves in the wayside dust without a reason? The answer to these questions was not in Chirk Street, but the questions themselves bristled there, and the girl's repeated pause before the mirror and the chimney-place might have represented her nearest approach to an escape from them.

Translation

And yet, where was real suffering, suffering too worn down to accuse anyone and stamped by destiny like a “lot” at a public auction, if not in these relentless signs of small, tired emotions? Her father’s life, her sister’s, her own, that of her two lost brothers—the entire history of their home resembled a beautiful, ornate, sprawling statement, maybe even a musical, that first fell into words, into notes, without meaning, and then, unfinished, fell into no words, no notes at all. Why should a group of people have been set in motion, on such a scale and with such an appearance of being prepared for a worthwhile journey, only to fail without a crash, to lie down in the dust of the roadside for no reason? The answer to these questions wasn’t on Chirk Street, but the questions themselves were everywhere there, and the girl’s constant hesitation before the mirror and the fireplace might have been her closest attempt to escape them.

Was it not in fact the partial escape from this "worst" in which she was steeped to be able to make herself out again as agreeable to see? She stared into the tarnished glass too hard indeed to be staring at her beauty alone. She readjusted the poise of her black, closely-feathered hat; retouched, beneath it, the thick fall of her dusky hair; kept her eyes, aslant, no less on her beautiful averted than on her beautiful presented oval. She was dressed altogether in black, which gave an even tone, by contrast, to her clear face and made her hair more harmoniously dark.

Translation

Wasn't it a partial escape from the "worst" she was immersed in to make herself appear presentable again? She scrutinized the tarnished glass too intensely to be simply admiring her beauty. She adjusted the angle of her black, tightly-feathered hat; retouched the thick cascade of her dark hair beneath it; kept her eyes, angled, fixed as much on her beautiful profile as on her beautiful, forward-facing oval face. She was entirely dressed in black, which, by contrast, lent an even tone to her clear complexion and made her hair appear more harmoniously dark.

Outside, on the balcony, her eyes showed as blue; within, at the mirror, they showed almost as black. She was handsome, but the degree of it was not sustained by items and aids; a circumstance moreover playing its part at almost any time in the impression she produced. The impression was one that remained, but as regards the sources of it no sum in addition would have made up the total. She had stature without height, grace without motion, presence without mass.

Translation

Outside, on the balcony, her eyes appeared blue; inside, at the mirror, they appeared almost black. She was attractive, but the extent of her attractiveness wasn't enhanced by any accessories or techniques; a factor that also influenced the impression she made on nearly everyone. The impression lingered, yet no combination of additional elements could account for it. She possessed poise without actual height, elegance without movement, and an undeniable presence without physical bulk.

Slender and simple, frequently soundless, she was somehow always in the line of the eye—she counted singularly for its pleasure. More "dressed," often, with fewer accessories, than other women, or less dressed, should occasion require, with more, she probably could not have given the key to these felicities. They were mysteries of which her friends were conscious—those friends whose general explanation was to say that she was clever, whether or no it were taken by the world as the cause or as the effect of her charm. If she saw more things than her fine face in the dull glass of her father's lodgings, she might have seen that, after all, she was not herself a fact in the collapse.

Translation

Slender and simple, often silent, she was somehow always in one's line of sight—she mattered uniquely for the pleasure she gave. More "dressed" than other women, often, with fewer accessories, or less dressed, as the occasion demanded, with more, she likely couldn't have explained the secret to these graces. They were mysteries that her friends were aware of—those friends whose typical explanation was to say that she was clever, regardless of whether the world considered this the cause or the effect of her charm. If she saw more than her beautiful face in the dull mirror of her father's lodgings, she might have seen that, in the end, she wasn't actually a factor in the decline.

She didn't judge herself cheap, she didn't make for misery. Personally, at least, she was not chalk-marked for the auction. She hadn't given up yet, and the broken sentence, if she was the last word, would end with a sort of meaning. There was a minute during which, though her eyes were fixed, she quite visibly lost herself in the thought of the way she might still pull things round had she only been a man.

Translation

She didn't consider herself worthless, nor did she court unhappiness. Personally, at least, she wasn't destined for ruin. She hadn't surrendered, and the unfinished story, if she were the final sentence, would conclude with some kind of purpose. There was a moment when, though her gaze remained fixed, she visibly lost herself in the thought of how she could have salvaged everything if only she had been a man.

It was the name, above all, she would take in hand—the precious name she so liked and that, in spite of the harm her wretched father had done it, was not yet past praying for. She loved it in fact the more tenderly for that bleeding wound. But what could a penniless girl do with it but let it go? Her father's life, her sister's, her own, and that of her two deceased brothers—the entire history of their family resembled a grand, elaborate composition, perhaps even a musical one.

Translation

It was the name, above all, that she would seize—the treasured name she loved, and which, despite the damage her wretched father had inflicted, was not beyond redemption. She actually loved it more tenderly because of that bleeding wound. But what could a penniless girl do with it except let it go? Her father's life, her sister's, her own, and that of her two deceased brothers—the whole history of their family resembled a grand, complex composition, perhaps even a musical one.

It began with words, then notes, devoid of meaning, only to halt abruptly, dissolving into silence. Why would a family have been set in motion, on such a grand scale and appearing so well-prepared for a successful journey, only to fail without any discernible reason, to collapse in the dust without cause? The answer to these questions wasn't found in Chirk Street, but the questions themselves lingered there. The girl's repeated pauses before the mirror and fireplace might have been her closest attempt to escape them.

Translation

It began with words, then notes, meaningless sounds that abruptly stopped, fading into silence. Why had a family launched itself, seemingly prepared for a successful journey on such a grand scale, only to fail without reason, to collapse into dust without cause? The answer to these questions wasn’t found on Chirk Street, but the questions themselves remained there. The girl’s repeated pauses before the mirror and the fireplace might have been her closest attempt at evading them.

Wasn't it a partial escape from this "worst" reality, in which she was immersed, to be able to make herself presentable? She stared into the clouded glass, focusing too intently to be simply admiring her beauty. She adjusted the angle of her black, feathered hat; smoothed the thick cascade of her dark hair beneath it; and kept her gaze, angled, on both her beautiful profile and her face. She was entirely dressed in black, which gave a uniform tone, emphasizing her fair complexion and enhancing the darkness of her hair.

Translation

Wasn't presenting a polished appearance a temporary reprieve from the "worst" of her reality? She peered into the smudged glass, her focus exceeding mere vanity. She repositioned her black, feathered hat; smoothed the thick fall of dark hair underneath; and held her gaze, at an angle, on both her attractive profile and her face. She was entirely in black, creating a monochrome effect that accentuated her pale skin and intensified the darkness of her hair.

Outside, on the balcony, her eyes appeared blue; inside, reflected in the mirror, they seemed almost black. She was attractive, but the extent of it wasn't due to specific features or enhancements; this quality played a role in the overall impression she created. The impression was lasting, but the sources of it couldn't be quantified. She possessed poise without height, grace without movement, and presence without weight.

Translation

On the balcony, her eyes appeared blue; inside, in the mirror, they were almost black. She was attractive, but it wasn't a matter of particular features or added embellishments; it was a factor of the overall effect she produced. This effect was striking, but its origins were unmeasurable. She possessed poise despite her lack of height, grace without movement, and presence without mass.

Slim and understated, often quiet, she somehow always drew the eye—she was a source of undeniable pleasure to observe. More "dressed" than other women, with fewer accessories, or less dressed, as the occasion demanded, with more, she couldn't explain how she achieved this effect. They were mysteries her friends recognized—friends who generally attributed it to her intelligence, regardless of whether the world saw it as the cause or the result of her charm. If she saw more than her attractive face in the dull mirror of her father's lodgings, she might have realized that she herself wasn't a casualty of their family's decline.

Translation

Lean and modest, frequently reserved, she nonetheless always caught your attention—she was a uniquely enjoyable sight. She was either more formally attired than other women, with minimal ornamentation, or less so, as circumstances dictated, with an abundance; she couldn't explain how she achieved this. Her friends, who usually chalked it up to her intelligence, regardless of whether the world considered it the origin or the outcome of her charisma, understood these mysteries. If she could see more than her pretty face in the dreary mirror of her father's home, she might have realized she wasn't a victim of her family's downfall.

She didn't consider herself insignificant, and she wasn't succumbing to despair. At least personally, she wasn't marked for ruin. She hadn't given up, and the broken narrative, if she were the final character, would conclude with a sense of significance. For a moment, her eyes fixed, she visibly lost herself in the thought of how she could still salvage things if only she were a man.

Translation

She didn't feel small, and she wasn't sinking into hopelessness. At least, not in her own life. She wasn't doomed. She hadn't surrendered, and if she was the last one standing, the story wouldn't end meaninglessly. For a second, her gaze sharpened, and she seemed to vanish inside herself as she considered how she could fix everything if she were a man.

It was the family name, above all, she would address—the cherished name she adored and which, despite the damage her unfortunate father had caused, was not beyond redemption. In fact, she loved it even more tenderly because of its wounded state. But what could a penniless girl do with it except relinquish it? When her father at last appeared she became, as usual, instantly aware of the futility of any effort to hold him to anything.

Translation

Above all else, she would protect the family name—the name she treasured and loved, which, despite her father’s mistakes, could still be saved. If anything, she loved it even more because of its damaged state. But what could a poor girl do with it except give it up? When her father finally arrived, she was, as always, instantly aware of the pointlessness of trying to make him accountable for anything.

He had written her that he was ill, too ill to leave his room, and that he must see her without delay; and if this had been, as was probable, the sketch of a design, he was indifferent even to the moderate finish required for deception. He had clearly wanted, for perversities that he called reasons, to see her, just as she herself had sharpened for a talk; but she now again felt, in the inevitability of the freedom he used with her, all the old ache, her poor mother's very own, that he couldn't touch you ever so lightly without setting up. No relation with him could be so short or so superficial as not to be somehow to your hurt; and this, in the strangest way in the world, not because he desired it to be—feeling often, as he surely must, the profit for him of its not being—but because there was never a mistake for you that he could leave unmade or a conviction of his impossibility in you that he could approach you without strengthening. He might have awaited her on the sofa in his sitting-room, or might have stayed in bed and received her in that situation.

Translation

He had written to her that he was sick, too sick to leave his room, and that he had to see her immediately. If this was, as was likely, a deliberate fabrication, he didn't even bother with the level of detail necessary to make the lie convincing. He clearly wanted, for reasons he insisted on calling valid, to see her, just as she herself was primed for a conversation. But she now felt again, in the inescapable freedom he exercised with her, all the old pain, her poor mother's own, which he couldn't even touch gently without provoking. No interaction with him could be so brief or insignificant as to avoid causing her some pain. This was strange, not because he intended it—he must often have realized the advantage of things being different—but because there was never a mistake he could avoid making for her, or a belief in his own inadequacy in her that he couldn't reinforce by being present. He might have waited for her on the sofa in his sitting room, or he might have stayed in bed and received her there.

She was glad to be spared the sight of such penetralia, but it would have reminded her a little less that there was no truth in him. This was the weariness of every fresh meeting; he dealt out lies as he might the cards from the greasy old pack for the game of diplomacy to which you were to sit down with him. The inconvenience—as always happens in such cases—was not that you minded what was false, but that you missed what was true. He might be ill, and it might suit you to know it, but no contact with him, for this, could ever be straight enough.

Translation

She was glad to avoid seeing such private spaces, though it would have perhaps reminded her less of his untruthfulness. This was the exhaustion of every new encounter; he dealt out lies as he might deal cards from a greasy old deck for a game of diplomacy they were to play together. The problem—as always in these situations—was not that she minded the lies, but that she missed the truth. He might be ill, and she might want to know, but no interaction with him, even for this, could ever be direct enough.

Just so he even might die, but Kate fairly wondered on what evidence of his own she would some day have to believe it. When her father finally showed up, she immediately understood how useless it was to try to pin him down on anything. He had written to her that he was sick, too sick to leave his room, and that he had to see her immediately. If this was a fabrication—which it probably was—he didn't bother with the minor details necessary for a convincing lie.

Translation

Just so he even might die, but Kate truly wondered what proof of his own she would one day have to accept. When her father finally arrived, she understood instantly how futile it was to try and get him to commit to anything. He had written to her that he was sick, too sick to leave his room, and that he had to see her immediately. If this was a lie—which it likely was—he didn't bother with the little details needed for a believable fabrication.

Clearly, he wanted to see her for reasons he called his own, just as she had been eager to talk to him. But now, she felt that familiar pain, inherited from her mother, in the freedom with which he treated her. He couldn't interact with her, no matter how briefly or superficially, without causing her some kind of harm. Strangely, this wasn't because he intended to hurt her, since he must have realized the advantage of things being otherwise.

Translation

It was plain he wanted to see her for his own reasons, just as she'd been eager to speak with him. But now, she felt that familiar pain, inherited from her mother, in the casual way he treated her. He couldn't interact with her, even briefly or superficially, without causing her some kind of harm. Oddly, this wasn't because he meant to hurt her, since he must have understood the benefit of things being different.

Instead, he couldn't help but make mistakes and strengthen her belief in his untrustworthiness. He could have waited for her on the sofa in his living room or stayed in bed and received her there. She was relieved to avoid such an intimate view, but it would have reminded her less that he was dishonest. This was the burden of every meeting: he would deal out lies like cards from a worn-out deck, inviting her to play a game of diplomacy.

Translation

Instead, he invariably stumbled, reinforcing her conviction that he was unreliable. He could have waited for her on the living room sofa, or even remained in bed and received her there. She was glad to avoid such an intimate encounter, but it would have been less of a reminder of his deceit. That was the weight of every meeting: he would deal out lies as though from a worn deck, inviting her to play a game of calculated deception.

The problem, as always, wasn't that she cared about the falsehoods, but that she missed the truth. He might be sick, and it might be useful to know, but no interaction with him could ever be honest enough to confirm it. He might even die, and Kate wondered what proof she'd ever have to believe that. He had not at present come down from his room, which she knew to be above the one they were in: he had already been out of the house, though he would either, should she challenge him, deny it or present it as a proof of his extremity.

Translation

The issue, as always, wasn't that she was bothered by the lies, but that she longed for the truth. He might be ill, and it might be helpful to know, but no interaction with him could ever be honest enough to confirm it. He might even die, and Kate wondered what evidence she'd ever have to believe that. He hadn't yet come down from his room, which she knew was above the one they were in: he had already left the house, though he would either deny it if she confronted him, or offer it as proof of his dire condition.

She had, however, by this time, quite ceased to challenge him; not only, face to face with him, vain irritation dropped, but he breathed upon the tragic consciousness in such a way that after a moment nothing of it was left. The difficulty was not less that he breathed in the same way upon the comic: she almost believed that with this latter she might still have found a foothold for clinging to him. He had ceased to be amusing—he was really too inhuman. His perfect look, which had floated him so long, was practically perfect still; but one had long since for every occasion taken it for granted.

Translation

However, by this point, she'd completely stopped confronting him. Not only did the fruitless frustration vanish when they were face to face, but he also had a way of affecting her tragic awareness, so that after a moment, it would disappear entirely. The problem was that he also had this effect on the comic. She almost thought that with the latter, she could still have found a way to hold on to him. He was no longer amusing—he was actually too inhuman. His flawless appearance, which had served him so well for so long, was still practically flawless, but she'd long since accepted it for every occasion.

Nothing could have better shown than the actual how right one had been. He looked exactly as much as usual—all pink and silver as to skin and hair, all straitness and starch as to figure and dress—the man in the world least connected with anything unpleasant. He was so particularly the English gentleman and the fortunate, settled, normal person. Seen at a foreign table d'hôte, he suggested but one thing: "In what perfection England produces them!" He had kind, safe eyes, and a voice which, for all its clean fulness, told, in a manner, the happy history of its having never had once to raise itself.

Translation

Nothing could have better illustrated how correct one had been. He looked exactly the same as always—all pink and silver in his skin and hair, all rigid and starched in his figure and clothing—the man in the world least associated with anything unpleasant. He was so quintessentially the English gentleman and the fortunate, settled, normal person. Seen at a foreign table d'hôte, he suggested only one thing: "In what perfection England produces them!" He had kind, safe eyes, and a voice which, for all its clear fullness, communicated, in its way, the happy history of never having once had to raise itself.

Life had met him so, half-way, and had turned round so to walk with him, placing a hand in his arm and fondly leaving him to choose the pace. Those who knew him a little said, "How he does dress!"—those who knew him better said, "How does he?" The one stray gleam of comedy just now in his daughter's eyes was the funny feeling he momentarily made her have of being herself "looked up" by him in sordid lodgings. For a minute after he came in it was as if the place were her own and he the visitor with susceptibilities. He gave you funny feelings, he had indescribable arts, that quite turned the tables: that had been always how he came to see her mother so long as her mother would see him.

Translation

Life had gone to meet him, halfway, and had turned around to walk with him, offering him an arm and happily letting him decide the speed. Those who knew him casually remarked, "Look at his clothes!"—those who knew him better asked, "How does he do it?"

The only hint of humor in his daughter's eyes was the momentary feeling that he was somehow "visiting" her in a cheap boarding house. For a moment after he entered, it was as if the place was hers and he was the visitor, the one with delicate sensibilities. He gave you odd feelings; he had strange ways of turning the tables, which was how he always managed to see her mother, as long as her mother allowed it.

He came from places they had often not known about, but he patronised Lexham Gardens. Kate's only actual expression of impatience, however, was "I'm glad you're so much better!" He hadn't come downstairs from his room yet. She knew it was above the room they were in.

Translation

He originated from locations they were often unfamiliar with, yet he frequented Lexham Gardens. Kate's sole display of impatience, however, consisted of, "I'm glad you're feeling better!" He hadn't yet come downstairs from his room. She knew it was located above the room they were currently in.

He had already left the house, though if she confronted him, he would deny it or claim it proved how desperate he was. However, by this point, she had stopped challenging him. Not only did her irritation disappear when she was with him, but he also had a way of influencing her tragic thoughts, so that they vanished in an instant. The problem was that he used the same method on the comical.

Translation

He was gone, but if she called him on it, he'd lie or say it showed how hard he was trying. She’d stopped arguing with him, though. Her annoyance evaporated when they were together, and he could redirect her darkest thoughts, making them disappear instantly. The problem was, he did the same thing with anything funny.

She almost believed that with the comical, she might still have found a way to hold onto him. He was no longer amusing; he was truly inhuman. His perfect appearance, which had served him so well, was practically still perfect, but she had long since taken it for granted on every occasion. Nothing could have better illustrated how right she had been than the reality.

Translation

She almost thought that if he still had a sense of humor, she might have been able to keep him. He wasn't funny anymore; he was utterly devoid of humanity. His flawless appearance, which had worked so well for him, was still nearly perfect, but she'd stopped noticing it a long time ago. The truth was the best possible proof that she'd been right.

He looked exactly as he always did: all pink and silver in his skin and hair, all stiffness and formality in his figure and clothes, the person in the world least associated with anything unpleasant. He was the quintessential English gentleman, the fortunate, settled, and normal person. Seen at a foreign restaurant, he suggested only one thing: "How perfectly England produces them!" He had kind, safe eyes and a voice that, despite its clear fullness, communicated the happy history of never having had to raise itself. Life had met him halfway, turned to walk with him, placed a hand in his arm, and lovingly allowed him to set the pace.

Translation

He looked exactly the same as always: his skin and hair were all pink and silver, his posture and clothes were all stiffness and formality, the person in the world least likely to be associated with anything unpleasant. He was the quintessential English gentleman, the fortunate, settled, and normal person. If you saw him in a foreign restaurant, he only suggested one thing: "How perfectly England produces them!" He had kind, safe eyes and a voice that, despite its clear fullness, communicated the happy history of never having to raise itself. Life had met him halfway, turned to walk with him, placed a hand in his arm, and lovingly allowed him to set the pace.

Those who knew him slightly said, "How well he dresses!" Those who knew him better said, "How does he dress?" The one glimmer of comedy in his daughter's eyes at that moment was the amusing sensation he momentarily gave her of being "looked up" by him in the rundown lodgings. For a minute after he came in, it was as if the place were hers and he was the visitor with delicate sensibilities. He gave you odd feelings; he had indescribable skills that completely reversed the roles.

Translation

Those who barely knew him would say, "He's so well-dressed!" Those who knew him better would wonder, "How does he dress?" The only flicker of amusement in his daughter's eyes at that moment was the strange feeling he momentarily gave her of being the one visited, in that dilapidated lodging. For a minute after he arrived, it was as if the place belonged to her, and he was the delicate visitor. He made you feel odd things; he had an indescribable talent for turning everything upside down.

That had always been how he saw her mother, as long as her mother would see him. He came from places they often didn't know about, but he patronized Lexham Gardens. Kate's only display of impatience, however, was, "I'm glad you're feeling better!" Croy showed he could qualify the humble hand that assuaged him. "I'm taking something he has made up for me. It's just why I've sent for you—that you may see me as I really am." "Oh papa, it's long since I've ceased to see you otherwise than as you really are!

Translation

Croy demonstrated he could appreciate the simple gesture that comforted him. "I'm taking a medicine he prepared for me. That’s why I asked you to come—so you can see me as I truly am." "Oh, Papa, I haven't seen you any other way in ages!"

I think we've all arrived by this time at the right word for that: 'You're beautiful—n'en parlons plus.' You're as beautiful as ever—you look lovely." He judged meanwhile her own appearance, as she knew she could always trust him to do; recognising, estimating, sometimes disapproving, what she wore, showing her the interest he continued to take in her. He might really take none at all, yet she virtually knew herself the creature in the world to whom he was least indifferent. She had often enough wondered what on earth, at the pass he had reached, could give him pleasure, and she had come back, on these occasions, to that. It gave him pleasure that she was handsome, that she was, in her way, a sensible value.

Translation

I think we've all arrived at the right word for that: 'You're beautiful—enough said.' You're as beautiful as ever—you look lovely." Meanwhile, he assessed her appearance, as she knew she could always trust him to do; recognizing, estimating, sometimes disapproving of what she wore, showing her the interest he continued to take in her. He might really take none at all, yet she virtually knew herself to be the person in the world to whom he was least indifferent. She had often wondered what on earth, at the point he had reached, could give him pleasure, and she had come back, on those occasions, to that. It gave him pleasure that she was handsome, that she was, in her way, a sensible asset.

It was at least as marked, nevertheless, that he derived none from similar conditions, so far as they were similar, in his other child. Poor Marian might be handsome, but he certainly didn't care. The hitch here, of course, was that, with whatever beauty, her sister, widowed and almost in want, with four bouncing children, was not a sensible value. She asked him, the next thing, how long he had been in his actual quarters, though aware of how little it mattered, how little any answer he might make would probably have in common with the truth.

Translation

It was equally obvious, however, that he felt no satisfaction from similar circumstances in his other child, to the extent that they were similar. Poor Marian might be attractive, but he clearly didn't care. The problem, of course, was that, despite whatever beauty she possessed, her sister, a widow nearly in poverty, with four lively children, wasn't a practical asset. The next thing she did was ask him how long he'd been in his current residence, though she knew it hardly mattered, how little truth any answer he might give would likely contain.

She failed in fact to notice his answer, truthful or not, already occupied as she was with what she had on her own side to say to him. This was really what had made her wait—what superseded the small remainder of her resentment at his constant practical impertinence; the result of all of which was that, within a minute, she had brought it out. "Yes—even now I'm willing to go with you. I don't know what you may have wished to say to me, and even if you hadn't written you would within a day or two have heard from me.

Translation

She didn't, in fact, register his response, whether it was truthful or not, since she was already focused on what she had to tell him. This was truly the reason she had waited—it overshadowed the remnants of her annoyance at his persistent practical rudeness; the culmination of which was that, within a minute, she had said it. "Yes—I'm still willing to go with you. I don't know what you wanted to tell me, and even if you hadn't written, you would have heard from me within a day or two."

Things have happened, and I've only waited, for seeing you, till I should be quite sure. I am quite sure. I'll go with you." "I'm not much better, dear—I feel terribly unwell.

Translation

"Things have changed, and I've only been waiting to see you until I was absolutely certain. I am certain. I'll go with you." "I'm not doing much better, dear—I feel terribly unwell."

The proof is that I just went to the pharmacy—that awful man on the corner." Mr. Croy thus demonstrated his capacity to soften the harshness of the medicine that was helping him. "I'm taking something he concocted for me. That's why I sent for you—so you can see me as I truly am."

Translation

The evidence? I just went to the pharmacy—that dreadful man on the corner. Mr. Croy used this to blunt the edges of the medication he was on. I'm taking something he whipped up for me. That's why I sent for you—so you can see what I'm really like.

"Oh, Dad, I stopped seeing you as anything other than who you are a long time ago! I think we've all agreed on the best way to put it: 'You're wonderful—let's not talk about it.' You're still as wonderful as ever—you look lovely." Meanwhile, she gauged his opinion of her own appearance, as she always knew she could trust him to do. He noticed, assessed, sometimes disapproved of her clothing, showing her that he still cared. He might not actually care at all, yet she essentially knew that she was the person in the world he was least indifferent to.

She often wondered what, at his age, could possibly give him pleasure, and she'd always concluded that it was this. It gave him pleasure that she was beautiful, that she was, in her own way, a worthwhile asset. However, it was equally clear that he got no pleasure from the same qualities, to the degree that they existed, in his other child. Poor Marian might be beautiful, but he certainly didn't care.

Translation

She often wondered what could possibly bring him joy at his age, and she'd always decided it was this. It gave him pleasure that she was beautiful, that she was, in her own way, a valuable asset. However, it was equally obvious that he derived no pleasure from the same qualities, to the degree that they existed, in his other child. Poor Marian might be beautiful, but he definitely didn't care.

The problem, of course, was that, however beautiful, her sister, a widow almost in poverty, with four lively children, wasn't a worthwhile asset. She asked him next how long he'd been staying in his current home, though she knew it hardly mattered, that his answer would probably bear little resemblance to the truth. She didn't, in fact, even hear his answer, true or not, as she was already focused on what she had to say to him. This was the real reason she'd waited—what replaced the last bit of her annoyance at his persistent practical rudeness.

Translation

The issue, naturally, was that her sister, a widow nearly destitute with four energetic children, was no kind of asset, regardless of her beauty. She then asked him how long he'd been living in his current residence, though she knew it was irrelevant, that his response would likely be a fabrication. In truth, she didn't even register his reply, accurate or not, because she was already concentrating on what she needed to tell him. This was the actual reason she'd waited—the thing that superseded her lingering irritation at his constant, callous lack of manners.

As a result, within a minute, she'd revealed it. "Yes—even now I'm willing to go with you. I don't know what you wanted to tell me, and even if you hadn't written, you would have heard from me in a day or two. Things have happened, and I only waited to see you until I was completely certain.

Translation

Therefore, within a minute, she divulged it. "Yes—I'm willing to go with you, even now. I don't know what you were going to say, and I would have contacted you in a day or two anyway, even if you hadn't written. Things have changed, and I only waited to meet with you until I was completely sure."

And I am certain. I'll go with you." It produced an effect. "Go with me where?"

Translation

"And I am certain. I'll go with you." The declaration had an impact. "Go with you where?"

"Anywhere. I'll stay with you. Even here." She had taken off her gloves and, as if she had arrived with her plan, she sat down. Lionel Croy hung about in his disengaged way—hovered there as if, in consequence of her words, looking for a pretext to back out easily: on which she immediately saw she had discounted, as it might be called, what he had himself been preparing.

Translation

"Anywhere. I'll stay with you. Even here."

She removed her gloves and, as if she'd had a plan all along, sat down. Lionel Croy lingered, somehow detached—hovering as if, because of her statement, he was seeking a reason to withdraw: which she realized at once she had underestimated, in a sense, what he himself had been preparing.

He wished her not to come to him, still less to settle with him, and had sent for her to give her up with some style and state; a part of the beauty of which, however, was to have been his sacrifice to her own detachment. There was no style, no state, unless she wished to forsake him. His idea had accordingly been to surrender her to her wish with all nobleness; it had by no means been to have positively to keep her off. She cared, however, not a straw for his embarrassment—feeling how little, on her own part, she was moved by charity.

Translation

He didn’t want her to come to him, and certainly not to stay with him. He had summoned her with the intention of letting her go with a certain grace and dignity. The elegance of his plan, however, was predicated on his sacrifice being matched by her own indifference. There would be no grace, no dignity, unless she chose to leave him. His intention, therefore, had been to yield to her desire with magnanimity. It was not his intention to have to actively push her away. However, she didn’t care a whit about his awkwardness, feeling how little she herself was motivated by compassion.

She had seen him, first and last, in so many attitudes that she could now deprive him quite without compunction of the luxury of a new one. Yet she felt the disconcerted gasp in his tone as he said: "Oh my child, I can never consent to that!" Her words had an impact. "Go with you where?"

Translation

She had witnessed him in countless moods, from start to finish, and she could easily deny him the satisfaction of a fresh one. However, she registered the flustered intake of breath in his voice as he said, "Oh my child, I can never consent to that!" Her words had landed. "Go with you where?"

"Anywhere. I'll stay with you. Even here." She removed her gloves and, as if her plan was already in motion, she sat down. Lionel Croy remained nearby, aimlessly—lingering as though, as a result of her declaration, he was searching for an easy escape.

Translation

"Anywhere. I'll stay with you. Even here." She took off her gloves and sat down as though she had set her plan in motion. Lionel Croy stayed close, aimless, lingering as if he was looking for a quick exit in response to her words.

Immediately, she recognized that she had, in a sense, miscalculated what he himself was preparing. He didn't want her to join him, much less live with him, and he had summoned her to end the relationship with a certain flair and dignity. Part of the appeal of that plan, however, was that he would appear to be sacrificing himself for her independence. There would be no style, no drama, unless she was willing to leave him.

Translation

Instantly, she understood she'd misjudged what he was about to do. He didn't want her with him, certainly not living with him. He'd called her there to end things, with a certain level of style and grace. Part of the appeal of his plan, however, was that he would appear to be sacrificing himself for her freedom. There would be no style, no drama, unless she was willing to leave.

His intention, therefore, had been to surrender her to her desire with noble grace. It was not at all to actively push her away. However, she was completely indifferent to his discomfort—aware of how little she herself was motivated by compassion. She had observed him in so many different ways over time that she could now deprive him of a new posture without any hesitation.

Translation

His plan, then, was to give in to her wishes with a show of noble character. He hadn't intended to actively push her away at all. But she was entirely unmoved by his discomfort—knowing that she herself was rarely swayed by compassion. She'd watched him closely over the years, and now she could strip him of a new persona without a second thought.

Yet she sensed the breathless shock in his voice as he exclaimed, "Oh my dear, I can never agree to that!" "What then are you going to do?" "I'm turning it over," said Lionel Croy. "You may imagine if I'm not thinking."

Translation

She detected the stunned disbelief in his voice as he blurted out, "Oh, my dear, I can never agree to that!"

"So, what are you going to do?"

"I'm considering it," Lionel Croy said. "You can imagine I'm giving it a lot of thought."

"Haven't you thought then," his daughter asked, "of what I speak of? I mean of my being ready." Standing before her with his hands behind him and his legs a little apart, he swayed slightly to and fro, inclined toward her as if rising on his toes. It had an effect of conscientious deliberation.

Translation

"Haven't you considered," his daughter asked, "what I'm talking about? I mean, that I'm ready." Standing before her with his hands clasped behind his back and his legs slightly apart, he subtly swayed, leaning toward her as if he were on his tiptoes. It gave the impression of careful thought.

"No. I haven't. I couldn't. I wouldn't." It was so respectable, a show that she felt afresh, and with the memory of their old despair, the despair at home, how little his appearance ever by any chance told about him.

Translation

"No. I haven't. I couldn't. I wouldn't." It was all so proper, a performance that she felt all over again, and with the memory of their old hopelessness, the hopelessness at home, how rarely his outward self ever revealed anything about the man.

His plausibility had been the heaviest of her mother's crosses; inevitably so much more present to the world than whatever it was that was horrid—thank God they didn't really know!—that he had done. He had positively been, in his way, by the force of his particular type, a terrible husband not to live with; his type reflecting so invidiously on the woman who had found him distasteful. Had this thereby not kept directly present to Kate herself that it might, on some sides, prove no light thing for her to leave uncompanioned a parent with such a face and such a manner? Yet if there was much she neither knew nor dreamed of, it passed between them at this very moment that he was quite familiar with himself as the subject of such quandaries.

Translation

His ability to seem believable was the worst burden for her mother. He was always present to the world, much more so than the horrible things—thank God they didn't really know!—that he'd done. He was, in his own way, by the force of his personality, a terrible husband to live with. His very nature reflected poorly on the woman who found him repulsive. Didn't this keep Kate keenly aware that it might be difficult to leave a parent with such a face and such a manner alone? Yet if there was much she didn't know or dream of, it was understood between them right then that he was completely familiar with being the subject of such questions.

If he recognised his younger daughter's happy aspect as a sensible value, he had from the first still more exactly appraised his own. The great wonder was not that in spite of everything his own had helped him; the great wonder was that it hadn't helped him more. However, it was, to its old, eternal, recurrent tune, helping him all the while; her drop into patience with him showed how it was helping him at this moment. She saw the next instant precisely the line he would take.

Translation

If he recognized his younger daughter's cheerful demeanor as something valuable, he had from the start been even more precise in his assessment of himself. The real surprise wasn't that his own qualities had assisted him, despite everything; the real surprise was that they hadn't assisted him more. However, they were, in their old, eternal, recurring pattern, helping him all along; her descent into tolerance toward him showed how they were helping him at that very moment. In the next instant, she knew exactly what argument he would make.

"Do you really ask me to believe you've been making up your mind to that?" "So, what are you going to do?" "I'm considering it," Lionel Croy said. "You can imagine I'm thinking about it."

Translation

"Do you really expect me to believe you've been deciding about that?" "So, what's your plan?" "I'm thinking about it," Lionel Croy said. "You can imagine I'm considering it."

"Haven't you considered," his daughter asked, "what I'm talking about? I mean, about me being ready." He stood before her, hands clasped behind his back, legs slightly apart, swaying gently. He leaned toward her as if rising on his toes.

"Have you even thought about," his daughter asked, "what I'm saying? About me being ready?" He stood in front of her, hands clasped behind his back, feet slightly apart, gently rocking. He leaned toward her as if he were rising up on his toes.

It gave the impression of careful thought. "No. I haven't. I couldn't.

"Not really. I couldn't."

I won't." It was all so respectable, a performance that she felt all over again, and with the memory of their old despair, the despair at home, how little his appearance ever revealed about him. His charm had been her mother's biggest burden; inevitably, it was so much more apparent to the world than whatever awful things he had done—thank God they didn't really know! Translation

"I won't." It was all so proper, a performance she felt again, remembering their old despair, the despair at home, and how little he ever showed of himself. His charm had been her mother's biggest problem; it was always so much more obvious to everyone than whatever terrible things he'd done—thank God they didn't really know! He'd been awful to live with in his way, because of his personality; it reflected so poorly on the woman who didn't like him. This made Kate realize that it might, in some ways, be hard to abandon a parent with that face and those manners.

Yet, though there was much she neither knew nor imagined, it was clear between them at that moment that he was very familiar with being the subject of such dilemmas. If he acknowledged his younger daughter's happiness as a positive attribute, he had, from the beginning, assessed his own with even greater precision. The real surprise wasn't that his personality had helped him despite everything; the real surprise was that it hadn't helped him more. Nevertheless, it was, playing its old, constant, familiar tune, helping him all along; her surrender to patience with him showed how it was helping him at this moment.

Translation

Even though there was a lot she didn't understand or anticipate, it was obvious to both of them in that moment that he was used to being the center of these kinds of conflicts. If he recognized his younger daughter's happiness as something good, he'd been even more exact in evaluating himself from the start. The real shock wasn't that his personality had been an asset, despite everything; the real shock was that it hadn't been an even bigger asset. Still, it was there, playing its same old, familiar song, helping him all along; her willingness to be patient with him was proof of how it was helping him right then.

She saw immediately the course he would take. "Do you truly expect me to believe you've been deciding to do that?" She had to consider her own line. "I don't think I care, papa, what you believe.

Translation

She understood his plan right away. "Do you honestly think I'll buy that you've been planning this?" She needed to think about her own response. "I don't think I care, Father, what you believe."

I never, for that matter, think of you as believing anything; hardly more," she permitted herself to add, "than I ever think of you as yourself believed. I don't know you, father, you see." "And it's your idea that you may make that up?" "Oh dear, no; not at all.

Translation

I, for my part, never think of you as having any beliefs. Barely more," she allowed herself to say, "than I think of you as actually believing in anything yourself. I don't know you, Father, you see." "And you think you can fix that?" "Oh no, not at all."

That's no part of the question. If I haven't understood you by this time, I never shall, and it doesn't matter. It has seemed to me that you may be lived with, but not that you may be understood. Of course I've not the least idea how you get on."

Translation

That's not what we're talking about. If I haven't understood you by now, I never will, and it doesn't really matter. It's seemed to me that you can be lived with, but not understood. Of course, I have no idea how you actually manage.

"I don't get on," Mr. Croy almost gaily replied. She needed to figure out her own approach. "I don't care, Dad, what you think.

Translation

"I don't connect with people," Mr. Croy responded, almost cheerfully. She needed to find her own way. "I don't care what you think, Dad."

I don't really think of you as having any beliefs. I don't think you believe anything any more than I think you actually believe in yourself. I don't know you, Father, you see." "And you think you can fix that?"

Translation

"I don't think you have any beliefs. I don't think you believe in anything, and I don't think you even believe in yourself. I don't know you, Father."

"And you think you can fix that?"

"Oh, no, not at all. That's not the point. If I haven't understood you by now, I never will, and it doesn't matter. It seems to me that you can be around, but not truly understood.

Translation

Oh, no, not at all. That's not the point. If I haven't understood you by now, I never will, and it doesn't matter. It seems to me that you can exist in my orbit, but not be truly understood.

Of course, I have no idea how you manage." "I don't manage," Mr. Croy replied almost cheerfully. His daughter took in the place again, and it might well have seemed odd that in so little to meet the eye there should be so much to show.

Translation

"I have no idea how you do it, of course." Mr. Croy replied with almost a cheerful tone. His daughter looked around, taking in the space, and it must have seemed strange that so little visible to the eye could reveal so much.

What showed was the ugliness—so positive and palpable that it was somehow sustaining. It was a medium, a setting, and to that extent, after all, a dreadful sign of life; so that it fairly put a point into her answer. "Oh, I beg your pardon. You flourish."

Translation

What was visible was the ugliness—so real and tangible it was almost supportive. It was a context, a stage, and therefore, a terrible indication of life; which gave a sharp edge to her reply. "Oh, I'm sorry. You thrive."

"Do you throw it up at me again," he pleasantly inquired, "that I've not made away with myself?" She treated the question as needing no reply; she sat there for real things. "You know how all our anxieties, under mamma's will, have come out. She had still less to leave than she feared.

Translation

"Are you going to bring up again," he asked, with a casual tone, "that I haven't killed myself?" She acted as if the question didn't require an answer; she was preoccupied with the actual state of affairs. "You know how all of our concerns, because of mother's will, have become known. She had even less to give than we thought."

We don't know how we lived. It all makes up about two hundred a year for Marian, and two for me, but I give up a hundred to Marian." His daughter looked around the room, and it was strange that such a small space contained so much to observe. What was most apparent was the ugliness—so undeniable and real that it was oddly comforting.

Translation

"We don't know how we managed to live. It amounts to around two hundred a year for Marian, and two for me, though I give a hundred to Marian." His daughter glanced around the room, and it was odd that such a small space held so much to see. What stood out most was the ugliness—so undeniable and real that it was strangely comforting.

It served as a framework, a context, and in that sense, it was a terrible indication of existence; thus, it sharpened her response. "Oh, I'm sorry. You're doing well." "Are you accusing me again," he asked cheerfully, "of not having killed myself?"

Translation

It acted as a structure, a background. In that sense, it was a wretched symbol of life, and therefore it intensified her reaction. "Oh, I'm sorry. You're doing okay." "Are you accusing me again," he asked, sounding cheerful, "of not killing myself?"

She didn't respond to the question; instead, she focused on the real matters. "You know how all our worries have come to light because of Mother's will. She had less to leave behind than she thought. We're unsure how we managed to survive.

Translation

She ignored the question, turning her attention to the actual issues at hand. "You know how all this turmoil has erupted because of Mother's will. She had fewer assets than she believed. We barely scraped by, we're not sure how we made it."

In total, it comes to roughly two hundred pounds a year for Marian, and two for me, but I give a hundred to Marian." "Oh, you weak thing!" her father kindly sighed. "For you and me together," she went on, "the other hundred would do something." "And what would do the rest?"

Translation

"All told, that's about two hundred pounds a year for Marian, and two for me, but I give a hundred to Marian." "Oh, you poor thing!" her father said, his voice soft with sympathy. "For you and me together," she continued, "the other hundred would be useful." "And what about the rest?"

"Can you yourself do nothing?" He gave her a look; then, slipping his hands into his pockets and turning away, stood for a little at the window she had left open. She said nothing more—she had placed him there with that question, and the silence lasted a minute, broken by the call of an appealing costermonger, which came in with the mild March air, with the shabby sunshine, fearfully unbecoming to the room, and with the small homely hum of Chirk Street. Presently he moved nearer, but as if her question had quite dropped. "I don't see what has so suddenly wound you up."

Translation

"Can't you do anything yourself?"

He gave her a look, then shoved his hands in his pockets, turned away, and stood for a moment by the window she'd opened. "Oh, you poor thing," her father said with a sigh. "For you and me," she continued, "the other hundred could make a difference." "And what about the rest?" "Can't you do anything?"

He gestured to show he understood perfectly; then, in a few seconds, he completely changed the dynamic. "Do you honestly think I'm in a position to let you depend on me?" She paused, but when she spoke, she was decisive. "Yes."

Translation

He made a gesture to show he understood perfectly. In a few seconds, he completely altered the tone of their exchange. "Do you truly believe I'm in a place where I can allow you to rely on me?" She hesitated. But when she replied, her tone was resolute. "Yes."

"Well then, you're a bigger idiot than I thought you were." "Why so? You live. You flourish.

"In that case, you're a bigger idiot than I took you for." "Why do you say that? You're alive. You're thriving."

You bloom." "Ah, how you've all always hated me!" he murmured with a pensive gaze again at the window. "No one could be less of a mere cherished memory," she declared as if she had not heard him. "You're an actual person, if there ever was one.

Don't put it to me therefore as monstrous that the fact that we are, after all, parent and child should at present in some manner count for us. My idea has been that it should have some effect for each of us.

Translation
