She believed she had already gauged the extent of this burden in the past, back when, as the second-born, she had considered no one in the world as lovely as Marian, no one as charming, as clever, or as certain of happiness and success.

The view was different now, but her attitude had been obliged, for many reasons, to show as the same. The subject of this estimate was no longer pretty, as the reason for thinking her clever was no longer plain; yet, bereaved, disappointed, demoralised, querulous, she was all the more sharply and insistently Kate's elder and Kate's own. Kate's most constant feeling about her was that she would make her, Kate, do things; and always, in comfortless Chelsea, at the door of the small house the small rent of which she couldn't help having on her mind, she fatalistically asked herself, before going in, which thing it would probably be this time. She noticed with profundity that disappointment made people selfish; she marvelled at the serenity—it was the poor woman's only one—of what Marian took for granted: her own state of abasement as the second-born, her life reduced to mere inexhaustible sisterhood.

Translation

The view had changed now, but her behavior was forced to appear unchanged for many reasons. The object of this assessment was no longer attractive, as the reason for considering her clever was no longer clear. Yet, bereaved, disappointed, demoralized, and querulous, she was all the more sharply and insistently Kate’s elder and Kate’s own. Kate’s most constant feeling about her was that she would make her, Kate, do things; and always, in comfortless Chelsea, at the door of the small house, the small rent of which she couldn't help having on her mind, she fatalistically asked herself, before going in, which thing it would probably be this time. She noticed with profundity that disappointment made people selfish; she marveled at the serenity—it was the poor woman's only one—of what Marian took for granted: her own state of abasement as the second-born, her life reduced to mere inexhaustible sisterhood.

She existed, in that view, wholly for the small house in Chelsea; the moral of which moreover, of course, was that the more one gave oneself the less of one was left. There were always people to snatch at one, and it would never occur to them that they were eating one up. They did that without tasting. Aunt Maud’s room was her personal space, her office, her place for business, her battleground.

Translation

In that assessment, her existence was entirely for the Chelsea house; the moral of which, naturally, was that the more one gave, the less of oneself remained. People were always trying to take from her, and it would never occur to them that they were consuming her. They did so without even noticing. Aunt Maud's room was her private domain, her office, her place of business, her battleground.

It was her primary place of activity. Located on the ground floor and opening into the main hall, it felt to our young woman like a guardhouse or a toll booth whenever she entered or exited. The lioness was waiting – the young woman was aware of this, and of the proximity of something she expected to be vulnerable. Meanwhile, she would have made a wonderful lioness in a show, an extraordinary figure anywhere; regal, beautiful, vibrant, with shiny, perpetual satin, sparkling bugles and flashing jewels, with bright, agate-like eyes, flowing raven hair, and a smooth complexion like fine china.

Translation

It was the center of her world. Situated on the ground floor and opening onto the main hall, it felt to our young woman like a guard post or a collection point every time she came and went. The lioness was waiting – the young woman knew it, and knew she was near something she expected to be defenseless. Meanwhile, she would have made a spectacular lioness in a show, an outstanding presence anywhere; queenly, beautiful, alive, with lustrous, always-on satin, glittering sequins and flashing gems, with bright, agate-colored eyes, flowing black hair, and skin as smooth as porcelain.

It seemed that her skin was too tight, especially around her curves and corners. Her niece had a quiet name for her – she kept it quiet; when she thought of her, with free imagination, as typically British, she called her "Britannia of the Market Place" – Britannia, unmistakable, but with a pen behind her ear. Kate felt she would not be happy until she could add to the rest of the display a helmet, a shield, a trident and a ledger. In truth, though, the forces Kate felt she would have to deal with were not those suggested by that simple and general image.

Translation

It felt like her skin constricted her, particularly where her body curved and angled. Her niece had a secret nickname for her, only whispered in her thoughts: "Britannia of the Market Place"—a familiar figure, but with a pen tucked behind her ear. Kate imagined she wouldn't be content until she could add a helmet, a shield, a trident, and a ledger to her usual attire. But the truth was that the battles Kate braced herself for were far different from the ones that image suggested.

She was learning to understand her companion every day, and what she had already realized was the mistake of relying on simple comparisons. There was a whole side of Britannia – the side of her excessive materialism, her ornate decorations, her fancy furnishings, her heaving bosom, the false idols of her taste and the dishonesty of her speech – a side whose contemplation alone would be dangerously misleading. She was a complex and subtle Britannia, as passionate as she was practical, with a collection of prejudices as deep as the pocket filled with coins bearing her image, which the world knew her by. She was, in short, behind her aggressive and defensive front, conducting operations dictated by her intelligence.

Translation

Each day, she understood her companion more. She'd already learned the error of easy comparisons. There was a whole side to Britannia—her excessive materialism, her ornate decorations, her fancy furnishings, her heaving bosom, the false idols of her taste, and the dishonesty of her speech—a side that, if focused on, would mislead dangerously. She was a complex, subtle Britannia, as passionate as she was pragmatic. She possessed a collection of prejudices, as profound as the coin-filled pocket bearing her image, by which the world knew her. In short, behind her aggressive and defensive façade, she was conducting operations dictated by her intellect.

As a young lady in a fortified citadel, our young woman saw her aunt as a besieger, and what made her formidable in this role was that she was ruthless and immoral. That’s how Kate, in private and with a youthful casualness, conveniently pictured her, implying that her aunt presented certain dangers, which, as we’ve seen, caused the younger woman to hesitate and stay above while the elder, below, both aggressive and strategic, covered as much ground as possible. Yet, what were the dangers, after all, but simply the dangers of life and of London? Mrs.

Translation

As a young woman in a fortress, our heroine saw her aunt as an aggressor, and what made her so in this role was that she was merciless and amoral. That’s how Kate, privately and with youthful ease, readily imagined her, implying that her aunt presented certain threats, which, as we’ve seen, caused the younger woman to hesitate and remain aloof while the elder, below, both assertive and calculating, advanced as far as possible. And yet, what were the threats, after all, but simply the dangers of life and of London? Mrs.

Lowder was London, was life – the noise of the siege and the intensity of the struggle. There were some things, after all, that Britannia was afraid of; but Aunt Maud was afraid of nothing – not even, it seemed, of serious thought. Kate kept these impressions to herself so completely that she barely shared them with poor Marian, whose frequent visits were supposedly for the purpose of discussing everything. One of Kate's reasons for avoiding the final concession to Aunt Maud was so that she could be freer to commit to her much closer and less fortunate relative, with whom Aunt Maud would have almost nothing to do.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder was London, was life – the clamor of the siege and the fervor of the battle. There were, after all, some things that even Britannia feared; but Aunt Maud feared nothing – not even, it seemed, serious reflection. Kate kept these impressions so private that she rarely shared them with poor Marian, whose regular visits were ostensibly meant for shared discussion. One of Kate's reasons for resisting Aunt Maud's final demands was to be freer to commit to her much closer and less fortunate relative, with whom Aunt Maud would scarcely deign to interact.

The most difficult part of her situation was that any contact with her sister had the effect of destroying her courage and holding her back, increasing her sense of the part that blood ties could play in one's life, which wasn’t always uplifting or pleasant. She was now facing this blood tie; the awareness of it was what she seemed to have most clearly gained from her mother's death, much of that awareness having been absorbed and carried away by her mother. Her troubling, harassing father, her menacing, uncompromising aunt, her poor little nephews and nieces were figures that caused the chord of natural devotion to strongly vibrate. She put it to herself – especially in relation to Marian – that she saw what one might become through the cultivation of family ties.

Translation

The hardest part was that any interaction with her sister undermined Kate’s resolve, holding her back and emphasizing the significance of kinship, which wasn’t always positive. She was now confronting this blood tie; the recognition of it was what she seemed to have most clearly gleaned from her mother’s death, much of that awareness having been absorbed and lost with her mother. Her irritating, burdensome father, her intimidating, unyielding aunt, her unfortunate young nephews and nieces were figures that strongly activated the feeling of natural devotion. She told herself—particularly regarding Marian—that she saw what someone could become through an emphasis on familial connections.

She had, in the past, she believed, understood this responsibility, in the days when, as the second-born, she had thought no one in the world was as pretty as Marian, as charming, as clever, or as certain of happiness and success. That view was different now, but her behavior had had to appear the same for many reasons. The subject of this estimation was no longer pretty, and the reason for thinking her clever was no longer clear, but, bereaved, disappointed, demoralized, and irritable, she was all the more sharply and insistently Kate's elder sister and Kate's own. Kate's most constant feeling about her was that she would make her, Kate, do things.

Translation

She believed she had understood this responsibility in the past, back when, as the second-born, she thought no one in the world was as beautiful as Marian, as charming, as clever, or as assured of happiness and success. That view had changed, but her behavior had to remain consistent for several reasons. The object of this assessment was no longer beautiful, and the basis for considering her clever was no longer evident, but, grief-stricken, disappointed, demoralized, and irritable, she was all the more emphatically Kate's elder sister and Kate's own. Kate's most consistent feeling about her was that she would force Kate to do things.

Always in their uncomfortable Chelsea neighborhood, at the door of the small house whose rent she couldn’t help but worry about, Kate would fatalistically ask herself before going in which thing it would probably be this time. She noticed deeply that disappointment made people selfish. She was amazed by the serenity – which was the poor woman's only one – of what Marian took for granted: her own state of humility as the second-born, her life reduced to mere endless sisterhood. In that view, Marian existed solely for the small house in Chelsea, whose moral was, of course, that the more one gave oneself, the less of oneself remained.

There were always people to take advantage of one, and it would never occur to them that they were consuming one. They did that without tasting. There was no such misfortune, or at any rate no such discomfort, she further reasoned, as to be formed at once for being and for seeing. You always saw, in this case, something else than what you were, and you got, in consequence, none of the peace of your condition.

Translation

People would always exploit you, and it wouldn't even cross their minds that they were doing so. They did it without a second thought. There was no misfortune, or at least no hardship, she continued, like being created both to be and to observe. In that scenario, you always saw something other than yourself, and as a result, you found no solace in your own existence.

However, as she never really let Marian see what she was, Marian might well not have been aware that she herself saw. Kate was accordingly, to her own vision, not a hypocrite of virtue, for she gave herself up; but she was a hypocrite of stupidity, for she kept to herself everything that was not herself. What she most kept was the particular sentiment with which she watched her sister instinctively neglect nothing that would make for her submission to their aunt; a state of the spirit that perhaps marked most sharply how poor you might become when you minded so much the absence of wealth. It was through Kate that Aunt Maud should be worked, and nothing mattered less than what might become of Kate in the process.

Translation

However, because Kate never truly revealed herself to Marian, Marian might not have even realized that she possessed any insight of her own. Therefore, in her own eyes, Kate wasn't a hypocrite of virtue, as she yielded herself; instead, she was a hypocrite of stupidity, as she kept everything that wasn't her own self hidden. The thing she kept most private was the specific feeling with which she observed her sister instinctively take every step to ensure her submission to their aunt; a state of mind that perhaps most clearly revealed how impoverished one could become when one cared so deeply about the lack of wealth. Aunt Maud was to be manipulated through Kate, and what might happen to Kate in the process mattered least of all.

Kate was to burn her ships, in short, so that Marian should profit; and Marian's desire to profit was quite oblivious of a dignity that had, after all, its reasons—if it had only cared for them—for keeping itself a little stiff. Kate, to be properly stiff for both of them, would therefore have had to be selfish, have had to prefer an ideal of behaviour—than which nothing, ever, was more selfish—to the possibility of stray crumbs for the four small creatures. The tale of Mrs. Lowder's disgust at her elder niece's marriage to Mr.

Translation

Kate was essentially going to destroy everything for herself so that Marian would benefit. Yet, Marian's ambition to gain an advantage didn't acknowledge a certain sense of pride. This pride had its own valid reasons for maintaining a degree of distance—if only it had chosen to acknowledge them. To be properly proud for both of them, Kate would have had to act selfishly. She would have had to prioritize an ideal of behavior—a deeply self-centered act—over the chance of small advantages for the four children. The story of Mrs. Lowder's disgust at her elder niece's marriage to Mr.

Condrip had lost little of its point; the incredibly fatuous behaviour of Mr. Condrip, the parson of a dull suburban parish, with a saintly profile which was always in evidence, being so distinctly on record to keep criticism consistent. He had presented his profile on system, having, goodness knew, nothing else to present—nothing at all to full-face the world with, no imagination of the propriety of living and minding his business. Criticism had remained on Aunt Maud's part consistent enough; she was not a person to regard such proceedings as less of a mistake for having acquired more of the privilege of pathos.

Translation

The relevance of Mrs. Lowder's condemnation of Mr. Condrip's marriage hadn't diminished. Mr. Condrip, the pastor of a boring suburban parish, was an incredibly foolish man, with his saintly profile constantly on display. This behavior was well-documented, ensuring that criticism remained consistent. He strategically presented his profile, since, heaven knows, he had nothing else to offer—nothing to face the world with, no understanding of how to live and mind his own affairs. Aunt Maud's criticism had remained consistent; she wasn't the kind of person to see such actions as less of a mistake simply because she felt more empathy for the situation.

She had not been forgiving, and the only approach she made to overlooking them was by overlooking—with the surviving delinquent—the solid little phalanx that now represented them. Of the two sinister ceremonies that she lumped together, the marriage and the interment, she had been present at the former, just as she had sent Marian, before it, a liberal cheque; but this had not been for her more than the shadow of an admitted link with Mrs. Condrip's course. She disapproved of clamorous children for whom there was no prospect; she disapproved of weeping widows who couldn't make their errors good; and she had thus put within Marian's reach one of the few luxuries left when so much else had gone, an easy pretext for a constant grievance.

Kate Croy remembered well what their mother, in a different quarter, had made of it; and it was Marian's marked failure to pluck the fruit of resentment that committed them, as sisters, to an almost equal fellowship in abjection. If the theory was that, yes, alas, one of the pair had ceased to be noticed, but that the other was noticed enough to make up for it, who would fail to see that Kate couldn't separate herself without a cruel pride? That lesson became sharp for our young lady the day after her interview with her father. Kate reasoned that the worst part of her situation was being simultaneously someone and an observer.

Translation

Kate Croy recalled vividly her mother's reaction to it all, in another context entirely. Marian's inability to extract satisfaction from her own resentment bound the sisters together, almost equally, in a state of degradation. The idea may have been that, yes, unfortunately, one of them was no longer being acknowledged, but the other was being acknowledged enough to compensate for it. But who wouldn't see that Kate couldn't simply separate herself without appearing cruelly proud? The lesson became clear to our young lady the day after her meeting with her father. Kate concluded that the worst part of her predicament was simultaneously being a participant and an observer.

In this case, you always saw something other than who you were, and you never felt content. However, since she never let Marian know her true self, Marian may not have realized Kate was observing. Therefore, Kate didn't see herself as a hypocrite of virtue, because she abandoned herself. Instead, she was a hypocrite of stupidity, because she kept her real thoughts hidden.

Translation

In this scenario, one was perpetually perceiving something other than one’s authentic self, a state that fostered perpetual discontent. Nevertheless, because Kate concealed her true nature from Marian, the latter may have remained oblivious to Kate’s observational role. Consequently, Kate didn't perceive herself as a hypocrite of virtue, given her self-abandonment. Instead, she was a hypocrite of foolishness, because she kept her genuine thoughts concealed.

What she concealed most was the way she watched her sister instinctively do everything possible to win over their aunt. This attitude showed how poor you could become when you worried so much about not having money. Kate was supposed to manipulate Aunt Maud, and what happened to Kate in the process was unimportant. Kate was, in short, to sacrifice everything so that Marian could benefit.

Translation

The thing Kate concealed most was how she observed her sister instinctively doing everything imaginable to ingratiate herself with their aunt. This behavior revealed the depths of impoverishment one could reach when consumed by the fear of lacking funds. Kate’s role was to manipulate Aunt Maud, and Kate’s own well-being was inconsequential. In short, Kate was expected to sacrifice everything for Marian’s gain.

Marian's desire to benefit disregarded a sense of dignity that had every reason—if she'd cared—to remain a little aloof. Kate, to be properly aloof for both of them, would have had to be selfish, to value an idea of how to behave—which is the most selfish thing of all—over the possibility of a few meager advantages for the four small children. The story of Mrs. Lowder's disgust at her older niece's marriage to Mr.

Translation

Marian's pursuit of advantage ignored a sense of self-respect that, if she'd valued it, could have kept her somewhat distant. For Kate to truly maintain that distance for both of them, she would have had to be self-serving, to prioritize an image of proper conduct—which is the ultimate form of selfishness—over the chance for even a few small benefits for the four young children. The tale of Mrs. Lowder's disapproval of her older niece's marriage to Mr.

Condrip had lost none of its impact. Mr. Condrip, the pastor of a boring suburban parish, was incredibly foolish, and his saintly profile, which he always displayed, was well-known, allowing for consistent criticism. He had presented his profile by habit, because he had, goodness knows, nothing else to offer—nothing to present to the world head-on, no understanding of how to live properly and mind his own business.

Translation

The story of Mrs. Lowder's disapproval of her older niece's marriage to Mr. Condrip still resonated. Mr. Condrip, the pastor of a dull, suburban parish, was a complete fool, and his sanctimonious facade, which he constantly presented, was a source of widespread mockery. He exhibited this profile out of habit, because he possessed, heaven knows, nothing else to offer—nothing to present to the world directly, no comprehension of how to behave appropriately and mind his own affairs.

Aunt Maud's criticism remained consistent; she wasn't the sort of person to see such events as less of a mistake just because they had acquired more emotional weight. She hadn't been forgiving, and the only way she came close to overlooking them was to overlook—with the surviving offender—the small family that now represented them. Of the two unfortunate events she grouped together, the marriage and the death, she had been present at the first, and she had sent Marian a generous check beforehand; but this hadn't been more than the appearance of acknowledging a connection to Mrs. Condrip's path.

Translation

Aunt Maud’s disapproval persisted; she wasn’t the type to diminish the significance of past mistakes simply because they had become more emotionally charged. She was not a forgiving person, and the only way she came close to overlooking things was to overlook—along with the surviving party—the small family that now represented them. Of the two tragic events she considered together, the marriage and the death, she had attended the former, and she had sent Marian a generous check beforehand; but this did nothing more than superficially acknowledge a connection to Mrs. Condrip's life.

She disapproved of noisy children with no future; she disapproved of grieving widows who couldn't fix their mistakes; and she had thus given Marian one of the few luxuries left when so much else was gone, a convenient excuse for constant resentment. Kate Croy clearly remembered how their mother had handled it in a different situation, and it was Marian's noticeable failure to embrace resentment that bound them, as sisters, in a shared state of degradation. If the idea was that, yes, alas, one of the pair had ceased to be noticed, but that the other was noticed enough to compensate for it, who wouldn't see that Kate couldn't separate herself without being cruelly proud? That lesson became clear to our young lady the day after her meeting with her father.

Translation

She disapproved of unruly children without prospects; she disapproved of grieving widows who couldn't rectify their errors; and so she had provided Marian with one of the few consolations remaining when so much else was lost, a convenient pretext for perpetual bitterness. Kate Croy vividly recalled how their mother had addressed this in a different context, and it was Marian's conspicuous inability to embrace resentment that united them, as sisters, in a shared sense of decline. If the implication was that, yes, alas, one of them was no longer noticed, but the other was noticed sufficiently to make up for it, who couldn't see that Kate couldn't distance herself without being cruelly arrogant? That lesson became clear to our young lady the day after her meeting with her father.

"I can't imagine," Marian on this occasion said to her, "how you can think of anything else in the world but the horrid way we're situated." "And, pray, how do you know," Kate inquired in reply, "anything about my thoughts? It seems to me I give you sufficient proof of how much I think of you. I don't, really, my dear, know what else you've to do with!"

Translation

"I can't imagine," Marian said to her, "how you can think of anything else in the world but this horrible situation we're in."

"And, pray tell, how do you know anything about my thoughts?" Kate asked back. "It seems to me I give you enough proof of how much I think of you. I really don't know, my dear, what else you have to do with!"

Marian's retort, on this, was a stroke as to which she had supplied herself with several kinds of preparation, but there was, none the less, something of an unexpected note in its promptitude. She had foreseen her sister's general fear; but here, ominously, was the special one. "Well, your own business is of course your own business, and you may say there's no one less in a position than I to preach to you. But, all the same, if you wash your hands of me for ever for it, I won't, for this once, keep back that I don't consider you've a right, as we all stand, to throw yourself away."

Translation

Marian's response, for which she'd rehearsed various approaches, was delivered with a speed that still caught her off guard. She'd anticipated her sister's general anxieties, but here, ominously, was the specific fear. "Fine, your personal affairs are your own, and you could certainly argue that I'm the last person who should lecture you. But even if you cut me out of your life completely for this, I won't conceal, just this once, that I don't believe you have the right, given our circumstances, to ruin your life."

"I can't understand," Marian said to her, "how you can think about anything other than the terrible situation we're in." "And, tell me, how do you know anything about what I'm thinking?" Kate replied. "It seems like I show you often enough how much I think of you. I really don't know what else you expect!"

Translation

"I don't get it," Marian said to her, "how you can think about anything other than the terrible situation we're in." "And, tell me, how do you know anything about what I'm thinking?" Kate replied. "It seems like I show you often enough how much I care about you. I really don't know what else you expect!"

Marian's response was something she'd prepared for in several ways, yet its quickness still had an element of surprise. She had anticipated her sister's usual worries, but here, ominously, was the specific one. "Well, what you do is your own business, and you could easily say I'm the last person who should lecture you. But even so, if you cut me out of your life for it, I won't, this one time, hide the fact that I don't think you have the right, given our circumstances, to ruin your life."

Translation

Marian had rehearsed her reply in multiple scenarios, but its rapid delivery still took her aback. She'd expected her sister's typical anxieties, but this, ominously, was the exact one. "Look, what you do is your own affair, and you could argue I'm the least qualified person to be lecturing you. But regardless, if you shut me out of your life because of it, I won't, just this once, pretend I don't believe you're not entitled, given our situation, to destroy your life."

It was after the children's dinner, which was also their mother's, but which their aunt mostly contrived to keep from ever becoming her own luncheon; and the two young women were still in the presence of the crumpled table-cloth, the dispersed pinafores, the scraped dishes, the lingering odour of boiled food. Kate had asked, with ceremony, if she might put up a window a little, and Mrs. Condrip had replied without it that she might do as she liked. She often received such inquiries as if they reflected in a manner on the pure essence of her little ones.

Translation

It was after the children had eaten dinner, which was also their mother's, though their aunt generally managed to avoid making it her own meal. The two young women were still surrounded by the rumpled tablecloth, the scattered pinafores, the scraped dishes, and the lingering smell of cooked food. Kate had formally asked if she could open the window a bit, and Mrs. Condrip had replied, without addressing the question, that she could do as she pleased. She often took such requests as if they were a commentary on the pure nature of her children.

The four had retired, with much movement and noise, under imperfect control of the small Irish governess whom their aunt had hunted out for them and whose brooding resolve not to prolong so uncrowned a martyrdom she already more than suspected. Their mother had become for Kate—who took it just for the effect of being their mother—quite a different thing from the mild Marian of the past: Mr. Condrip's widow expansively obscured that image. She was little more than a ragged relic, a plain, prosaic result of him, as if she had somehow been pulled through him as through an obstinate funnel, only to be left crumpled and useless and with nothing in her but what he accounted for.

Translation

The four children had gone upstairs, creating a great commotion, with little help from the small Irish governess their aunt had found for them. Kate already suspected the governess was determined not to stay in this job, a situation she saw as a form of suffering. For Kate, their mother had changed, her role defined by the fact that she was their mother. She was no longer the gentle Marian of before. Mr. Condrip’s widow had erased that memory. She was now a damaged remnant, a plain, unromantic consequence of him, as if she'd been forced through him like a narrow opening, only to be left ruined and worthless, containing nothing but what he had given her.

She had grown red and almost fat, which were not happy signs of mourning; less and less like any Croy, particularly a Croy in trouble, and sensibly like her husband's two unmarried sisters, who came to see her, in Kate's view, much too often and stayed too long, with the consequence of inroads upon the tea and bread-and-butter—matters as to which Kate, not unconcerned with the tradesmen's books, had feelings. About them, moreover, Marian was touchy, and her nearer relative, who observed and weighed things, noted as an oddity that she would have taken any reflection on them as a reflection on herself. If that was what marriage necessarily did to you, Kate Croy would have questioned marriage. It was a grave example, at any rate, of what a man—and such a man!—might make of a woman.

Translation

She had become flushed and nearly plump, which were not signs of healthy grieving. She resembled the Croys less and less, especially a Croy experiencing hardship. She more closely resembled her husband's unmarried sisters, who visited her—in Kate's opinion—far too often and stayed too long. This led to a depletion of the tea and bread-and-butter—a matter about which Kate, mindful of the tradesmen's accounts, had strong feelings. Moreover, Marian was sensitive about the sisters. Her close relative, who observed and considered things, noted it was peculiar that Marian would have perceived any criticism of them as a criticism of herself. If that was what marriage inevitably did to you, Kate Croy would have questioned the institution. It was, at the very least, a serious example of what a man—and such a man at that!—could make of a woman.

She could see how the Condrip pair pressed their brother's widow on the subject of Aunt Maud—who wasn't, after all, their aunt; made her, over their interminable cups, chatter and even swagger about Lancaster Gate, made her more vulgar than it had seemed written that any Croy could possibly become on such a subject. They laid it down, they rubbed it in, that Lancaster Gate was to be kept in sight, and that she, Kate, was to keep it; so that, curiously, or at all events sadly, our young woman was sure of being, in her own person, more permitted to them as an object of comment than they would in turn ever be permitted to herself. The beauty of which, too, was that Marian didn't love them. But they were Condrips—they had grown near the rose; they were almost like Bertie and Maudie, like Kitty and Guy.

Translation

She could see how the Condrip sisters pressured their brother's widow regarding Aunt Maud—who wasn't actually their aunt. They made her, during their endless tea sessions, ramble and even boast about Lancaster Gate. They made her more vulgar than any Croy should ever become on that topic. They insisted, they hammered it home, that Lancaster Gate had to be kept in sight, and that she, Kate, was to maintain it. It was strange, or at least sad, that our young woman was more of a subject of comment for them than they would ever be allowed to be for her. The amazing thing was that Marian didn't love them. But they were Condrips—they'd grown up close to the family; they were almost like Bertie and Maudie, like Kitty and Guy.

They talked of the dead to her, which Kate never did; it being a relation in which Kate could but mutely listen. She couldn't indeed too often say to herself that if that was what marriage did to you——! It may easily be guessed, therefore, that the ironic light of such reserves fell straight across the field of Marian's warning. "I don't quite see," she answered, "where, in particular, it strikes you that my danger lies.

Translation

They spoke of the deceased to her, a subject on which Kate remained silent, the role she was forced to play. Indeed, she often had to remind herself that if that was what marriage did to you——! Therefore, it's easy to see how the ironic light of such constraints fell directly onto Marian's warning. "I don't quite understand," she responded, "in what specific way you believe my danger presents itself."

I'm not conscious, I assure you, of the least 'disposition' to throw myself anywhere. I feel as if, for the present, I have been quite sufficiently thrown." It was after the children's dinner—which was also their mother's, but which their aunt largely avoided—and the two young women remained at the table, surrounded by the crumpled tablecloth, scattered children's aprons, empty dishes, and the lingering smell of cooked food. Kate had formally asked if she could open a window, and Mrs.

Translation

I can honestly say I'm not in the mood to throw myself anywhere, I assure you. I feel as if I've been thrown enough, for the moment." This was after the children's dinner, which was also their mother's, though their aunt mostly skipped it. The two young women stayed at the table, surrounded by the wrinkled tablecloth, scattered children's aprons, empty dishes, and the lingering smell of food. Kate had formally asked if she could open a window, and Mrs.

Condrip had responded—without it—that she could do as she pleased. She often reacted to such inquiries as if they questioned the very nature of her children. The four children had retreated, with much commotion, under the somewhat shaky control of the young Irish governess. The governess's determined resolve to end her thankless job was already more than Kate suspected.

Translation

Condrip had replied—without explicitly answering—that she was free to do as she wished. She frequently treated such questions as challenges to her children's character. The four children had withdrawn, noisily, under the tenuous supervision of the young Irish governess. Kate already suspected that the governess was determined to quit her thankless position.

For Kate, their mother—who she thought acted that way only because she was a mother—had become entirely different from the gentle Marian of the past. Mr. Condrip's widow had completely obscured that image. She was little more than a worn-out remnant, a plain, unromantic product of him.

Translation

For Kate, their mother—who she believed behaved that way solely because she was a mother—had transformed into someone entirely unlike the kind Marian of yesteryear. Mr. Condrip's widow had completely erased that memory. She was now little more than a faded relic, a plain, unromantic consequence of his influence.

It was as if she had been forced through him, like being squeezed through a tight funnel, only to be left crumpled and useless, with nothing left in her but what he had caused. She had become red and almost fat, which were not good signs of grief. She was less and less like a Croy, especially a Croy in trouble, and instead, resembled her husband's two unmarried sisters, who, in Kate's opinion, visited too often and stayed too long. The consequence of these visits were raids on the tea and bread-and-butter—matters about which Kate, who was somewhat involved with the household finances, had strong feelings.

Translation

It was as if she'd been forced through him, like being squeezed through a tight funnel, only to be left crumpled and useless. Everything that was left of her was a product of his influence. She'd become flushed and almost heavy, which weren't good indicators of grief. She resembled a Croy less and less, especially a Croy in distress. Instead, she was starting to look like her husband's two unmarried sisters, who, according to Kate, came around too much and lingered far too long. The outcome of these visits was a drain on the tea and bread-and-butter—issues about which Kate, who had some involvement in the household budget, felt very strongly.

Moreover, Marian was sensitive about these things, and Kate, who observed and assessed situations, found it strange that Marian would perceive any criticism of her sisters-in-law as a personal attack. If marriage inevitably did that to you, Kate Croy would reconsider the idea. It was a serious example, at any rate, of what a man—and such a man!—could make of a woman. She could see how the Condrip sisters pressured their brother's widow regarding Aunt Maud—who wasn't actually their aunt.

Translation

Furthermore, Marian was touchy about these matters, and Kate, who was observant and analytical, thought it odd that Marian would interpret any criticism of her sisters-in-law as a personal affront. If marriage inevitably had that effect on someone, Kate Croy would have to rethink the whole concept. It was a clear illustration, in any case, of what a man—and such a man at that!—could do to a woman. She could see how the Condrip sisters were pressuring their brother's widow about Aunt Maud—who wasn't actually their aunt.

They made her, during their endless cups of tea, chat and even boast about Lancaster Gate. They made her more vulgar than any Croy should ever have been on such a subject. They insisted that Lancaster Gate should remain in her sights, and that Kate should make sure it did. So, surprisingly, or at least sadly, Kate was sure that she was more a subject of their commentary than they would ever be to her.

Translation

The sisters, over endless cups of tea, forced her to talk, even brag, about Lancaster Gate. They made her more crass than any Croy should ever be on such a topic. They insisted Lancaster Gate remain her goal, and that Kate make sure it did. So, surprisingly, or at least sadly, Kate realized she was more the subject of their discussions than they would ever be to her.

The funny thing was, Marian didn't even like them. But they were Condrips—they had grown close to the rose; they were almost like Bertie and Maudie, like Kitty and Guy. They talked about the deceased to her, which Kate never did; a subject on which Kate could only listen silently. She couldn't help but frequently tell herself, if that was what marriage did to you—!

Translation

The strange part was, Marian didn't even care for them. But they were Condrips—they were connected to the family like a vine to a rose; they were almost like Bertie and Maudie, like Kitty and Guy. They spoke to her of the dead, something Kate never did; a subject that left Kate silent. She couldn't help but frequently think, if that's what marriage did to you—!

Therefore, it's easy to guess that the ironic perspective of these reservations directly contradicted Marian's warning. "I don't quite understand," she responded, "where, specifically, you think my danger lies. I assure you, I'm not aware of any urge to throw myself at anything. I feel as if, for the moment, I've been thrown quite enough."

Translation

Thus, it's simple to see that the sardonic nature of these doubts completely undermined Marian's caution. "I'm not quite sure," she replied, "what, precisely, you think I'm in danger of. I can promise you, I feel no impulse to throw myself at anything. I feel as though I've already been thrown quite enough, for the time being."

"You don't feel"—Marian brought it all out—"as if you would like to marry Merton Densher?" Kate took a moment to meet this inquiry. "Is it your idea that if I should feel so I would be bound to give you notice, so that you might step in and head me off? Is that your idea?" the girl asked.

Translation

"You don't feel"—Marian brought it all out—"as if you would like to marry Merton Densher?" Kate took a moment to meet this inquiry. "Is it your idea that if I should feel that way, I would be bound to give you notice, so that you might step in and head me off? Is that your idea?" the girl asked.

Then, as her sister also had a pause, "I don't know what makes you talk of Mr. Densher," she observed. "I talk of him just because you don't. That you never do, in spite of what I know—that's what makes me think of him.

Translation

Marian paused as well. "I don't know why you bring up Mr. Densher," she said.

"I bring him up precisely because you don't. The fact that you never do, despite what I know—that's what makes me think about him."

Or rather perhaps it's what makes me think of you. If you don't know by this time what I hope for you, what I dream of—my attachment being what it is—it's no use my attempting to tell you." But Marian had in fact warmed to her work, and Kate was sure she had discussed Mr. Densher with the Miss Condrips. "If I name that person I suppose it's because I'm so afraid of him.

Translation

Or perhaps it’s what makes me think of you. If you don't already know what I hope for you, what I dream of—given my attachment—it's pointless for me to try and tell you." But Marian had, in fact, become more involved in her work, and Kate was sure she had discussed Mr. Densher with the Miss Condrips. "If I bring up that person, I suppose it's because I'm so afraid of him.

If you want really to know, he fills me with terror. If you want really to know, in fact, I dislike him as much as I dread him." "You don't feel," Marian revealed, "as if you'd want to marry Merton Densher?" Kate took a moment to consider the question.

Translation

"If you truly want to know, he terrifies me. If you really want to know, I actually dislike him as much as I fear him."

"You don't feel," Marian revealed, "like you'd want to marry Merton Densher?"

Kate took a moment to consider the question.

"Do you believe that if I did feel that way, I'd have to inform you, so you could interfere? Is that what you think?" she asked. Then, after her sister hesitated, "I'm unsure why you're bringing up Mr. Densher," she added.

Translation

"Do you think if I felt that way, I'd have to tell you, so you could meddle? Is that what you're implying?" she asked. Then, after her sister paused, "I don't know why you're bringing up Mr. Densher," she added.

"I bring him up precisely because you don't. The fact that you never do, despite what I know, is what makes me think of him. Or perhaps, it's what makes me think of you. If you still don't understand what I want for you, what I hope for, given our connection, there's no point in me explaining it." However, Marian had become quite animated, and Kate was certain she'd been discussing Mr.

Translation

"I mention him because you don't. The fact that you never do, in spite of what I know, is what makes me think of him. Or maybe, it's what makes me think of you. If you still don't grasp what I want for you, what I wish for, considering our relationship, there's no reason for me to say anything." But Marian had become quite worked up, and Kate was sure she had been talking about Mr.

Densher with the Miss Condrips. "If I mention that man, it's likely because I'm so afraid of him. To be honest, he terrifies me. In truth, I dislike him as much as I fear him."

Translation

Densher and the Miss Condrip sisters. "If I bring him up, it's probably because I'm scared of him. Honestly, he frightens me. The truth is, I dislike him as much as I fear him."

"And yet don't think it dangerous to abuse him to me?" "Yes," Mrs. Condrip confessed, "I do think it dangerous; but how can I speak of him otherwise? I dare say, I admit, that I shouldn't speak of him at all.

Translation

"And still, you don't think it's risky to speak ill of him to me?" "Yes," Mrs. Condrip admitted, "I do think it's dangerous; but how else can I talk about him? I suppose, I concede, I shouldn't be talking about him at all."

Only I do want you for once, as I said just now, to know." "To know what, my dear?" "That I should regard it," Marian promptly returned, "as far and away the worst thing that has happened to us yet." "Do you mean because he hasn't money?"

Translation

"But I do want you, just this once, as I said, to know." "Know what, darling?" "That I would consider it," Marian replied immediately, "by far the worst thing that's happened to us." "You mean because he's broke?"

"Yes, for one thing. And because I don't believe in him." Kate was civil, but perfunctory. "What do you mean by not believing in him?"

Translation

"That's part of it. And because I don't trust him." Kate was polite, but dismissive. "What do you mean, you don't trust him?"

"Well, being sure he'll never get it. And you must have it. You shall have it." "And yet, you don't think it's risky to criticize him to me?"

Translation

"I'm certain he'll never understand. But you have to. You will have to." "And still, you don't think it's risky to criticize him to me?"

"Yes," Mrs. Condrip admitted, "I do think it's risky; but how else can I talk about him? I suppose, I realize, that I shouldn't talk about him at all. But I really want you, just this once, like I said, to understand."

Translation

"Yes," Mrs. Condrip conceded, "I do think it's risky. But how else can I discuss him? I guess, I understand, that I shouldn't talk about him at all. But I truly want you, just this once, like I said, to understand."

"Understand what, darling?" "That I consider it," Marian immediately replied, "by far the worst thing that's happened to us." "You mean because he's broke?" "Yes, partly.

Translation

"Understand what, dear?" Marian asked at once, "That I think it's the worst thing that's ever happened to us." "You mean because he's broke?" "Yes, partly.

And because I don't trust him." Kate was polite, but uninterested. "What do you mean by not trusting him?" "Well, that I'm certain he'll never succeed.

Translation

And because I don't trust him." Kate was polite, but uninterested. "What do you mean by not trusting him?" "Well, I'm certain he'll never succeed.

And you need to. You will have to." "To give it to you?" Marian met her with a readiness that was practically pert.

Translation

"And you need to. You will have to." "To give it to you?" Marian met her with a readiness that was practically pert.

"To have it, first. Not, at any rate, to go on not having it. Then we should see." "We should indeed!" said Kate Croy.

Translation

"To possess it, initially. At the very least, to stop not possessing it. Then we'll assess." "We certainly shall!" Kate Croy responded.

It was talk of a kind she loathed, but if Marian chose to be vulgar what was one to do? It made her think of the Miss Condrips with renewed aversion. "I like the way you arrange things—I like what you take for granted. If it's so easy for us to marry men who want us to scatter gold, I wonder we any of us do anything else.

Translation

It was the kind of conversation she detested, but what could she do if Marian chose to be vulgar? It made her think of the Miss Condrips with renewed aversion. "I like the way you arrange things—I like what you take for granted. If it's so easy for us to marry men who want us to shower them with gold, I wonder we ever do anything else."

I don't see so many of them about, nor what interest I might ever have for them. You live, my dear," she presently added, "in a world of vain thoughts." "Give it to you?" Marian was quick to reply, almost cheekily, "To have it, first.

Translation

"I don't encounter many of those types, nor do I understand what appeal I could possibly have for them. You, my dear," she added after a moment, "live in a world of frivolous ideas." "Hand it over to you?" Marian retorted promptly, almost impudently, "You'd have to actually possess it first."

Not, at any rate, to keep not having it. Then we'll see." "We certainly will!" Kate Croy responded. She detested this type of conversation, but what could she do if Marian chose to be so common?

Translation

Not, at any rate, to go on lacking it. Then we'll see." "We certainly will!" Kate Croy responded. She detested this kind of conversation, but what could she do if Marian chose to be so vulgar?

It reminded her of the Miss Condrips, and her dislike for them intensified. "I admire your methods—the assumptions you make. If marrying men who want us to spend their money were so simple, I'm surprised we don't all do it. I don't see so many of them around, and I can't imagine what would attract them to me.

Translation

The thought of it reminded her of the Miss Condrips, and her disdain for them grew stronger. "I find your approach—the way you just assume things—fascinating. If marrying men just for their money were as easy as you make it sound, I'm surprised we're not all doing it. I don't see so many of those kinds of men, and I can't imagine what would make me attractive to them."

You, my dear," she added after a pause, "live in a world of fantasies." "Not so much as you, Kate; for I see what I see, and you can't turn it off that way." The elder sister paused long enough for the younger's face to show, in spite of superiority, an apprehension. "I'm not talking of any man but Aunt Maud's man, nor of any money, even, if you like, but Aunt Maud's money. I'm not talking of anything but your doing what she wants.

Translation

"You, my dear," she added after a pause, "live in a world of fantasies." "Not as much as you, Kate; because I see what's real, and you can't just ignore it." The older sister paused long enough for the younger's face to betray apprehension, despite her air of superiority. "I'm not talking about any man, only Aunt Maud's man, and not even about money, if you prefer, but Aunt Maud's money. I'm talking about you doing whatever she wants."

You're wrong if you speak of anything that I want of you; I want nothing but what she does. That's good enough for me!"—and Marian's tone struck her companion as dreadful. "If I don't believe in Merton Densher, I do at least in Mrs. Lowder."

Translation

"You're mistaken if you think I want anything from you. I only want what she wants. That's enough for me!" Marian's tone sounded dreadful to her companion. "Even if I don't believe in Merton Densher, at least I believe in Mrs. Lowder."

"Your ideas are the more striking," Kate returned, "that they're the same as papa's. I had them from him, you may be interested to know—and with all the brilliancy you may imagine—yesterday." "Not even as much as you, Kate; I see clearly, and you can't dismiss it so easily." The older sister waited, allowing her younger sister's face to reveal a flicker of worry, despite her air of superiority. "I'm not discussing any man besides Aunt Maud's man, nor even the money, if you prefer, but rather Aunt Maud's money.

Translation

"The more compelling your ideas are," Kate replied, "the more they resemble my father's. You might be interested to learn that I heard them from him yesterday, and with all the brilliance you can imagine."

"Not even as much as you, Kate. I see the situation clearly, and you can't just brush it aside." Translation

"I'm only concerned with you doing her bidding. You're wrong if you think I want anything from you personally; I only want what she wants. That's all that matters to me!" Marian's voice grated on her sister's ears. "Even if I don't trust Merton Densher, I certainly trust Mrs.

Lowder." "Your opinions are all the more remarkable," Kate replied, "because they're identical to Papa's. I heard them from him, you might be interested to know—and with all the dramatic flair you can imagine—yesterday." Marian clearly was interested to know.

Translation

"I only care that you do as she asks. You're mistaken if you think I want anything from you; I only want what she wants. That's all that matters to me!" Marian's voice grated on her sister's ears. "He has been to see you?" "No, I went to him." "Really?" Marian wondered. "For what purpose?"

Translation

"He's come to see you then?" "No, I went to see him." "Oh?" Marian considered this. "Why?"

"To tell him I'm ready to go to him." Marian stared. "To leave Aunt Maud——?" "For my father, yes."

She had fairly flushed, poor Mrs. Condrip, with horror. "You're ready——?" "So I told him.

Translation

"What does he have to do with us? Why would you even bring this up?" They just stared at each other, and tears sprang up in Marian's eyes. Kate watched her for a moment, then said, "I've thought it all through, again and again."

But you don't need to be upset. I'm not going. He doesn't want me." Her companion still panted—it took time to subside.

Translation

"But there's no need to be upset. I'm not going. He doesn't want me." Her friend was still breathless—it took a moment for her to calm down.

"Well, I wouldn't have you—wouldn't receive you at all, I can assure you—if he had made you any other answer. I do feel injured—at your having been willing. If you were to go to papa, my dear, you would have to stop coming to me." Marian put it thus, indefinably, as a picture of privation from which her companion might shrink. Such were the threats she could complacently make, could think herself masterful for making.

Translation

"Well, I wouldn't want you here, wouldn't accept you at all, I can assure you, if he had given you any other response. I do feel offended that you were even willing. If you were to go to Papa, my dear, you would have to stop seeing me."

Marian phrased it this way, vaguely, as a vision of loss that her friend might recoil from. Those were the threats she could make with satisfaction, could consider herself powerful for making.

"But if he won't take you," she continued, "he shows at least his sharpness." Marian had always her views of sharpness; she was, as her sister privately commented, great on it. But Kate had her refuge from irritation. "He won't take me," she simply repeated.

Translation

"But if he won't accept you," she continued, "at least he's showing some intelligence." Marian always had her own opinion of intelligence; as her sister privately observed, she was obsessed with it. But Kate had a way of avoiding irritation. "He won't accept me," she simply repeated.

"But he believes, like you, in Aunt Maud. He threatens me with his curse if I leave her." Her friend was still catching her breath—it took a while for her to calm down. "Well, I wouldn't have you—I wouldn't let you come here at all, I assure you—if he had given you any other response.

Translation

"However, he, like you, believes in Aunt Maud. He's threatened to curse me if I leave her." Her friend was still trying to catch her breath, taking a moment to calm down. "Well, I wouldn't want you to—I wouldn't let you come here at all, I assure you—if he had given you any other answer."

I do feel hurt—that you were even considering it. If you went to your father, dear, you'd have to stop seeing me." Marian put it that way, in an unsettling way, as if painting a bleak picture that might scare her friend. Those were the kinds of threats she could make without a second thought; she even felt powerful when she made them.

Translation

I am hurt that you were even thinking about it. If you went to your father, dear, you couldn't see me anymore." Marian phrased it like that, disturbingly, as if she were sketching a grim scenario to frighten her friend. She could issue those kinds of threats without hesitation; they even made her feel strong.

"But if he won't take you," she went on, "at least it shows he's smart." Marian always had her own ideas about what it meant to be clever; as her sister said in private, she was obsessed with it. But Kate had a way to escape her annoyance. "He won't take me," she simply repeated.

Translation

"Even if he refuses," Marian continued, "it proves he's got some sense." Marian had her own unique definition of intelligence, which, as her sister had once whispered, bordered on obsession. But Kate had a trick to deflect the irritation. "He won't take me," she repeated, simply.

"But he believes, like you, in Aunt Maud. He threatens to curse me if I leave her." "So you won't?" As the girl at first said nothing her companion caught at it. "You won't, of course?

Translation

"But he believes in Aunt Maud, just like you. He's threatened to curse me if I leave her." "So you won't?" The girl didn't say anything at first, and her companion seized on the silence. "You won't, of course?"

I see you won't. But I don't see why, nevertheless, I shouldn't insist to you once for all on the plain truth of the whole matter. The truth, my dear, of your duty. Do you ever think about that?

Translation

I see you won't. But even so, I don't understand why I shouldn't tell you the simple truth of the matter. The truth, my dear, about your obligations. Do you ever consider that?

It's the greatest duty of all." "There you are again," Kate laughed. "Papa's also immense on my duty." "Oh, I don't pretend to be immense, but I pretend to know more than you do of life; more even perhaps than papa." Marian seemed to see that personage at this moment, nevertheless, in the light of a kinder irony.

Translation

It's the greatest duty of all." "There you go again," Kate laughed. "Papa's also immense on my duty." "Oh, I don't pretend to be immense, but I pretend to know more than you do of life; more even perhaps than papa." Marian seemed to see that figure at this moment, nevertheless, in the light of a kinder irony.

"Poor old papa!" She sighed it with as many condonations as her sister's ear had more than once caught in her "Dear old Aunt Maud!" These were things that made Kate, for the time, turn sharply away, and she gathered herself now to go. They were the note again of the abject; it was hard to say which of the persons in question had most shown how little they liked her. The younger woman proposed, at any rate, to let discussion rest, and she believed that, for herself, she had done so during the ten minutes that, thanks to her wish not to break off short, elapsed before she could gracefully withdraw.

Translation

"Poor old papa!" She sighed with the same understanding her sister's ear had often heard in her "Dear old Aunt Maud!" These were things that made Kate, for the time, turn sharply away, and she gathered herself to leave. They were the mark again of the downtrodden; it was difficult to say which of the people in question had shown the least affection for her. The younger woman proposed, at any rate, to let the discussion end, and she believed that, for herself, she had done so during the ten minutes that, thanks to her wish not to abruptly end the conversation, passed before she could gracefully leave.

It then appeared, however, that Marian had been discussing still, and there was something that, at the last, Kate had to take up. "Whom do you mean by Aunt Maud's young man?" "So you won't do it?" When the girl didn't respond at first, her friend pressed the issue. "You won't, right?

Translation

It then became apparent that Marian was still talking, and there was something that Kate had to address finally. "Who is this young man of Aunt Maud's you're talking about?" "So you won't do it?" When the girl didn't answer right away, her friend pressed her. "You won't, will you?"

I understand. But I still think I should explain the complete truth to you, once and for all. The truth about your obligations, my dear. Do you ever consider that?

Translation

I understand. However, I believe I must finally tell you everything, once and for all. The truth about your responsibilities, my dear. Do you ever think about that?

It's the most important thing." "There you go again," Kate laughed. "Dad also emphasizes my duty constantly." "Oh, I'm not claiming to be as extreme as that, but I do claim to know more about life than you do; perhaps even more than your father." Marian seemed to picture her father at that moment, with a touch of gentle mockery.

Translation

It's the most important thing." "There you go again," Kate laughed. "Dad's always on me about my duty, too." "Oh, I'm not saying I'm as intense as him. But I do think I know more about life than you do; maybe even more than your father." Marian seemed to be picturing her father then, a hint of gentle amusement on her face.

"Poor old Dad!" She sighed it with the same understanding her sister often expressed when saying, "Dear old Aunt Maud!" These were the kind of remarks that usually made Kate recoil, and she prepared to leave. They were a sign of disrespect, and it was hard to say who, of the people involved, disliked her more. The younger woman, in any case, decided to end the conversation, believing she'd already done so during the ten minutes that passed, thanks to her desire to avoid a sudden exit, before she could gracefully leave.

Translation

"Poor old Dad!" She sighed, the same way her sister would say, "Dear old Aunt Maud!" Those kinds of comments usually made Kate cringe, and she got ready to go. They showed a lack of respect, and it was hard to say who, of the people involved, disliked her more. The younger woman, in any case, decided to end the conversation, thinking it had already been over for ten minutes, thanks to her wanting to avoid a sudden exit, before she could gracefully leave.

However, it then became clear that Marian was still talking, and Kate had to address something at the end. "Who do you mean by Aunt Maud's boyfriend?" "Whom should I mean but Lord Mark?" "And where do you pick up such vulgar twaddle?" Kate demanded with her clear face.

Translation

However, it then became clear that Marian was still talking, and Kate had to respond. "Who are you talking about, calling him Aunt Maud's boyfriend?" "Who else would I mean but Lord Mark?" "And where did you hear such nonsense?" Kate demanded, her face showing her displeasure.

"How does such stuff, in this hole, get to you?" She had no sooner spoken than she asked herself what had become of the grace to which she had sacrificed. Marian certainly did little to save it, and nothing indeed was so inconsequent as her ground of complaint. She desired her to "work" Lancaster Gate as she believed that scene of abundance could be worked; but she now didn't see why advantage should be taken of the bloated connection to put an affront on her own poor home.

Translation

"How does this even get to you in this dump?" No sooner had she said the words than she wondered what had happened to the poise she'd sacrificed for the sake of appearances. Marian certainly wasn't helping matters, and the grounds for her grievance were entirely ridiculous. She wanted Kate to "work" Lancaster Gate, believing that its wealth could be exploited, but now she couldn't understand why they should take advantage of that affluent connection to insult her own humble home.

She appeared in fact for the moment to take the position that Kate kept her in her "hole" and then heartlessly reflected on her being in it. Yet she didn't explain how she had picked up the report on which her sister had challenged her—so that it was thus left to her sister to see in it, once more, a sign of the creeping curiosity of the Miss Condrips. They lived in a deeper hole than Marian, but they kept their ear to the ground, they spent their days in prowling, whereas Marian, in garments and shoes that seemed steadily to grow looser and larger, never prowled. There were times when Kate wondered if the Miss Condrips were offered her by fate as a warning for her own future—to be taken as showing her what she herself might become at forty if she let things too recklessly go.

Translation

For the moment, it seemed that Marian thought Kate was the reason she was stuck in this "hole," and that Kate was cruelly judging her situation. She didn't explain how she'd gotten the report that her sister had challenged, leaving Kate to see it as another sign of the Miss Condrips' creeping curiosity. They lived in an even deeper hole than Marian, but they kept their ear to the ground and spent their days prowling, while Marian, in clothes and shoes that seemed to get steadily looser and larger, never prowled. There were times when Kate wondered if the Miss Condrips were a warning from fate about her own future—a sign of what she might become at forty if she let things get too reckless.

What was expected of her by others—and by so many of them—could, all the same, on occasion, present itself as beyond a joke; and this was just now the aspect it particularly wore. She was not only to quarrel with Merton Densher to oblige her five spectators—with the Miss Condrips there were five; she was to set forth in pursuit of Lord Mark on some preposterous theory of the premium attached to success. Mrs. Lowder's hand had attached it, and it figured at the end of the course as a bell that would ring, break out into public clamour, as soon as touched.

Translation

What was expected of her by others—and by so many of them—could, even so, occasionally appear as something past a joke; and that was exactly how it seemed at the moment. She wasn't simply supposed to argue with Merton Densher to appease her five observers—the Miss Condrips brought the total to five; she was to chase after Lord Mark based on some absurd theory about the reward for winning. Mrs. Lowder had devised it, and it was displayed at the finish line like a bell that would ring and burst into public outcry as soon as it was struck.

Kate reflected sharply enough on the weak points of this fond fiction, with the result at last of a certain chill for her sister's confidence; though Mrs. Condrip still took refuge in the plea—which was after all the great point—that their aunt would be munificent when their aunt should be pleased. The exact identity of her candidate was a detail; what was of the essence was her conception of the kind of match it was open to her niece to make with her aid. Marian always spoke of marriages as "matches," but that was again a detail.

Translation

Kate considered the flaws in this cherished fantasy quite acutely, which eventually cooled her sister's confidence, though Mrs. Condrip continued to cling to the argument—which was, after all, the main point—that their aunt would be generous when she was satisfied. The exact identity of the man was inconsequential; what truly mattered was her aunt's vision of the kind of marriage her niece could achieve with her assistance. Marian always referred to marriages as "matches," but that was just another minor detail.

Mrs. Lowder's "aid" meanwhile awaited them—if not to light the way to Lord Mark, then to somebody better. Marian would put up, in fine, with somebody better; she only wouldn't put up with somebody so much worse. Kate had, once more, to go through all this before a graceful issue was reached.

Translation

Meanwhile, Mrs. Lowder's "aid" was waiting for them—even if it didn't lead to Lord Mark, then to someone better. Marian would settle, in short, for someone better; she just wouldn't settle for someone much worse. Kate once again had to endure all of this before a suitable outcome could be reached.

It was reached by her paying with the sacrifice of Mr. Densher for her reduction of Lord Mark to the absurd. So they separated softly enough. She was to be let off hearing about Lord Mark so long as she made it good that she wasn't underhand about anybody else.

Translation

She achieved this by sacrificing Mr. Densher, rendering Lord Mark ridiculous in the process. They parted ways quietly. She would be spared further discussion of Lord Mark, provided she proved she wasn't being deceitful with anyone else.

She had denied everything and every one, she reflected as she went away—and that was a relief; but it also made rather a clean sweep of the future. The prospect put on a bareness that already gave her something in common with the Miss Condrips. "Who else would I be talking about but Lord Mark?" "And where did you hear such trash?" Kate asked, her face clear.

Translation

She had denied everything and everyone, she reflected as she left—and that was a relief; but it also made a clean sweep of the future. The prospect took on a bareness that already gave her something in common with the Miss Condrips. "Who else would I be talking about but Lord Mark?" "And where did you hear such trash?" Kate asked, her face clear.

"How does that kind of gossip reach you here?" She had hardly spoken when she wondered what had happened to the tact she had sacrificed for. Marian certainly did little to preserve it, and her complaint was quite illogical. Marian wanted her to "work" Lancaster Gate, believing that location of wealth could be exploited.

Translation

"How does gossip like that get to you, here?" She had barely finished the question when she thought about the tact she had given up. Marian certainly didn't do much to keep it going, and her complaint was quite illogical. Marian wanted her to "work" Lancaster Gate, believing that its wealthy location could be exploited.

But now, Marian didn't understand why they should take advantage of their wealthy connections to insult their own humble home. In fact, Marian seemed to be suggesting that Kate kept her in this "hole" and then cruelly judged her for being there. However, she didn't explain how she'd gotten the information that made her question her sister, so Kate was left to recognize it as another example of the Miss Condrips' constant prying. They lived in a more miserable state than Marian, but they kept their ears open, spending their days investigating things.

Translation

But now, Marian couldn't fathom why they should leverage their affluent acquaintances to denigrate their own modest dwelling. Indeed, Marian appeared to imply that Kate was keeping her in this "dump," and then callously judging her for it. Still, she didn't reveal the source of the information that caused her to question her sister, so Kate was left to recognize it as another instance of the Miss Condrips' endless nosiness. They were living in a more wretched situation than Marian, but they kept their ears open, spending their days digging for dirt.

Marian, however, in clothes that always seemed too loose and too big, never poked around. Sometimes Kate wondered if the Miss Condrips were a warning from fate about her own future, showing her what she might become at forty if she let things go too carelessly. What was expected of her by others, and by so many of them, could sometimes become unbearable. That was the situation at the moment.

Translation

Marian, always draped in garments that hung loosely, never snooped. Kate sometimes wondered if the Miss Condrips were a grim premonition of her own future, a glimpse of what she might turn into at forty if she didn't take better care. The expectations of others, and there were so many, could occasionally become too much to bear. That was how things stood at that moment.

She wasn't just supposed to argue with Merton Densher to please her five observers—there were five Miss Condrips; she was supposed to pursue Lord Mark based on some ridiculous idea about the reward for success. Mrs. Lowder had set it up, and it was like a bell at the end of the race that would ring, bursting into public notice, as soon as it was touched. Kate thought critically about the weaknesses of this silly story, which ended up making her feel cold about her sister's confidence.

Translation

She wasn't merely meant to spar with Merton Densher to entertain her five scrutinizers—those five Miss Condrips; she was meant to court Lord Mark based on a ludicrous notion of the prize for winning. Mrs. Lowder had arranged it all, and it was like a finish-line bell poised to clang, erupting into public view, the instant it was struck. Kate considered the flaws in this absurd arrangement, and as she did, she found herself feeling a chill toward her sister's convictions.

However, Mrs. Condrip still held onto the excuse—which was, after all, the most important part—that their aunt would be generous when she was pleased. The exact identity of the chosen man was a detail; the essential thing was the aunt's idea of the kind of marriage her niece could have with her help. Marian always called marriages "matches," but that was just another detail.

Translation

Nevertheless, Mrs. Condrip continued to cling to the rationale—which was, when all was said and done, the crucial element—that their aunt would be magnanimous when satisfied. The specific identity of the prospective husband was of little consequence; the fundamental aspect was the aunt's vision of the kind of marriage her niece could attain with her assistance. Marian invariably referred to marriages as "matches," but that was simply another insignificant detail.

Mrs. Lowder's "aid" awaited them—if not to guide them to Lord Mark, then to someone better. Marian would settle for someone better; she just wouldn't settle for someone worse. Kate had to go through all this again before reaching a graceful resolution.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder’s “aid” was waiting for them—if not to get them to Lord Mark, then to someone better. Marian would be fine with someone better; she just wouldn’t settle for someone worse. Kate had to go through all of this again before arriving at an elegant conclusion.

This was achieved when she sacrificed Mr. Densher to make Lord Mark seem absurd. So they parted calmly enough. Kate wouldn't have to hear about Lord Mark as long as she could prove she wasn't secretly involved with anyone else.

Translation

This was accomplished when she used Mr. Densher to make Lord Mark appear ridiculous. And so, they separated with relative ease. Kate wouldn't have to hear about Lord Mark again, as long as she could demonstrate she wasn't secretly involved with another man.

She had denied everything and everyone, she thought as she left—and that was a relief, but it also erased much of the future. The possibilities seemed bleak, and she already felt a kinship with the Miss Condrips.

Translation

She had denied everything and everyone, Kate thought as she left, and that was a relief. But it also erased much of the future. The possibilities seemed bleak, and she already felt a kinship with the Miss Condrips.

Chapter 3

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

Merton Densher, a newspaper writer, often loiters in Kensington Gardens, where Kate Croy leaves her aunt's house to meet him. They walk and talk together. They first met a year earlier at a party and reconnected six months later by chance on an Underground train, after which Densher followed Kate off the train and walked with her.

Densher asked to visit Kate, and she agreed after getting permission from her aunt, Mrs. Lowder. Densher visited, was invited to dinner by Mrs. Lowder, and visited several more times.

During a later walk in the gardens, Kate tells Densher that her aunt plans to write to him to express her disapproval. Kate then recounts her family's history of misfortune, including her father's unspecified disgrace, the deaths of her brothers, and her sister's unhappy marriage. She explains that she recently offered to live with her father, but he refused, insisting, along with her sister, that she can only help them by staying with her wealthy aunt.

Densher proposes they get married the next day. Kate postpones the decision, telling him to wait until after he has seen her aunt. She suggests they can manage the situation with her aunt to their benefit. When Densher asks what he is supposed to do, Kate tells him to see her aunt. He asks if he should grovel, and she tells him to do what he likes and walks away.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

This is an excellent excerpt for literary analysis, drawn from the opening of Book Two of Henry James's masterpiece, *The Wings of the Dove*. The text is a dense, psychologically rich introduction to the central characters and the complex web of social and moral pressures that defines their world.

### Literary Analysis

#### Themes

Several major themes are immediately apparent and begin to intertwine in this passage:

1. **The Dichotomy of Thought vs. Life:** The primary conflict is established through the character of Merton Densher. He is a man whose "strength [is] merely for thought," while he feels a "weakness... for life." He recognizes that thought alone "only went on in the void" and needs to be grounded in the "immediate air of life" to have meaning. This positions him as an intellectual, an observer, who desires to become a participant. Kate Croy, in contrast, represents this tangible "life." She comes from a world of visceral, "dark disasters"—disgrace, poverty, death—and is drawn to Densher because he makes the world of "the mind" real for her. Their relationship is thus built on the "famous law of contraries," where each possesses what the other lacks and desperately needs.

2. **The Corrupting Influence of Society and Money:** This is the central engine of the novel's plot, and its foundations are laid bare here. The love between Kate and Densher, pure in its own intellectual and emotional space, is rendered impossible by the material world. Densher's poverty is described as the "great ugliness," a fundamental barrier to their union.
