Her intelligence sometimes kept her still—too still—but her lack of it made her restless. So, it seemed, she gained the disadvantages of both extremes.

Translation

They envisioned the possibilities for Kate. Kate understood her own capacity to make an impression; she considered herself attractive but also resilient, finding herself intelligent but detached. Moreover, she wasn't ambitious enough, which was a pity because, for the sake of a tranquil existence, she couldn't bring herself to choose graceful indifference or, indeed, simpleminded indifference. Her intellect occasionally kept her stagnant—excessively stagnant—while the absence of it made her unsettled. Thus, it appeared, she acquired the drawbacks of both extremes.

She saw herself in a situation, nonetheless, and even her sad, disillusioned mother, dying, but with Aunt Maud interviewing the nurse on the stairs, had reminded her that situations, by their nature, needed to be managed. The dear woman had died believing that she was actually managing the one that had arisen. Kate took one of her walks with Densher just after her visit to Mr. Croy; but most of it went, as usual, to their sitting in talk.

Translation

Despite everything, she recognized her position, and even her mother, in her dying disillusionment—with Aunt Maud interrogating the nurse on the stairs—had impressed upon her that situations, by definition, needed to be navigated. The poor woman had passed away believing she had successfully managed the situation at hand. Kate took one of her walks with Densher shortly after her visit to Mr. Croy; but, as was customary, most of the time was spent simply talking.

They had, under the trees, by the lake, the air of old friends—phases of apparent earnestness, in particular, in which they might have been settling every question in their vast young world; and periods of silence, side by side, perhaps even more, when "a long engagement!" would have been the final reading of the signs on the part of a passer struck with them, as it was so easy to be. They would have presented themselves thus as very old friends rather than as young persons who had met for the first time but a year before and had spent most of the interval without contact. It was indeed for each, already, as if they were older friends; and though the succession of their meetings might, between them, have been straightened out, they only had a confused sense of a good many, very much alike, and a confused intention of a good many more, as little different as possible. The desire to keep them just as they were had perhaps to do with the fact that in spite of the presumed diagnosis of the stranger there had been for them as yet no formal, no final understanding.

Translation

Beneath the trees, beside the lake, they had the air of old friends. They shared moments of apparent sincerity, during which they might have been resolving every question in their immense young world. And there were periods of silence, side by side, which perhaps spoke even louder. A passerby, struck by their presence, would easily have concluded, "A long engagement!" They would have appeared as very old friends rather than young people who had only met a year ago and had spent most of that time apart. For each of them, it felt as though they were already older friends. Though the sequence of their meetings might have been straightened out between them, they only held a vague sense of many similar meetings, and a confused intention to repeat them, with as little variation as possible. Their desire to keep things as they were might have been connected to the fact that, despite the stranger's assumed diagnosis, there had been no formal, final understanding between them.

Densher had at the very first pressed the question, but that, it had been easy to reply, was too soon; so that a singular thing had afterwards happened. They had accepted their acquaintance as too short for an engagement, but they had treated it as long enough for almost anything else, and marriage was somehow before them like a temple without an avenue. They belonged to the temple and they met in the grounds; they were in the stage at which grounds in general offered much scattered refreshment. But Kate had meanwhile had so few confidants that she wondered at the source of her father's suspicions.

Translation

Densher had pressed the question at the start, but it was easy to reply that it was too soon. Then a strange thing happened. They had considered their acquaintance too brief for an engagement, but they treated it as long enough for almost anything else. Marriage was somehow before them like a temple without an avenue. They belonged to the temple and they met in its grounds. They were at the stage where grounds in general offered much scattered refreshment. But Kate had meanwhile had so few confidants that she wondered at the source of her father's suspicions.

The diffusion of rumour was of course, in London, remarkable, and for Marian not less—as Aunt Maud touched neither directly—the mystery had worked. No doubt she had been seen. Of course she had been seen. She had taken no trouble not to be seen, and it was a thing, clearly, she was incapable of taking.

Translation

The spread of gossip in London was, naturally, extraordinary, and it was no less remarkable for Marian—as Aunt Maud never directly mentioned it—the mystery had worked. No doubt she had been seen. Of course she had been seen. She had made no effort to avoid being seen, and it was, plainly, something she was incapable of doing.

But she had been seen how?—and what was there to see? She was in love—she knew that: but it was wholly her own business, and she had the sense of having conducted herself, of still so doing, with almost violent conformity. Kate took a walk with Densher after she visited Mr. Croy, but most of their time was spent, as usual, talking.

Translation

But how exactly had she been seen, and what was there to see anyway? She was in love—she knew that. But it was entirely her own affair, and she felt as though she’d behaved, and was still behaving, with almost aggressive propriety. Kate went for a walk with Densher after she visited Mr. Croy, but most of their time, as always, was spent talking.

They seemed like old friends as they sat under the trees by the lake, showing moments of deep sincerity, as if they were discussing every important issue in their young lives. There were also periods of silence, side by side, which might have led an observer to conclude, "a long engagement!" as the ultimate interpretation of their behavior. They presented themselves as very old friends rather than young people who had met only a year before and had spent most of that time apart. It felt as though they had been friends for much longer.

Translation

They looked like they'd known each other forever as they sat by the lake, beneath the trees. There were moments of genuine connection between them, like they were hashing out all the big questions of their youth. Then there were the silent stretches, side-by-side. An onlooker might have thought, "a long engagement!" as the only explanation for it all. They presented themselves as if they were very old friends, not young people who'd only met a year ago and, for most of that year, had lived apart. It felt like their friendship had existed for much longer.

Although their meetings could have been clearly traced, they had only a vague sense of a great many encounters, all very similar, and an equally vague intention of having many more, as much alike as possible. Their wish to keep things as they were might have been connected to the fact that, despite the stranger's assumptions, they had not yet reached a formal, binding agreement. Densher had initially proposed the question, but it was easy to respond that it was premature. A strange thing had then happened.

Translation

Their meetings, though documented, felt like a blur of nearly identical experiences. They anticipated more of the same, with a shared desire to maintain their current dynamic. This reticence, despite the observer's expectations, was likely linked to the absence of a formal commitment. Densher had broached the subject, but it was easily dismissed as premature. Then, an unusual event transpired.

They considered their relationship too new for an engagement, but they treated it as though it was old enough for almost anything else. Marriage was before them, like a temple without a path. They belonged to the temple and met in the surrounding grounds; they were at a stage where the grounds offered many enjoyable diversions. Kate, however, had so few confidants that she was puzzled by her father's suspicions.

Translation

They thought their relationship was too fresh for an engagement, yet they behaved as though it was seasoned enough for nearly every other aspect of life. Marriage loomed, a temple without a road leading to it. They were part of the temple, meeting in the gardens nearby; they were at a point where the gardens presented plenty of pleasant distractions. Kate, however, had so few people she could confide in that her father's doubts confused her.

Gossip in London was, of course, widespread, and the mystery, which Aunt Maud had not directly addressed, had affected Marian as well. No doubt she had been seen. Of course, she had been seen. She hadn't bothered to avoid being seen, and it was something she clearly couldn't do.

Translation

Gossip spread rapidly through London, and the mystery, which Aunt Maud had not explicitly acknowledged, had also impacted Marian. Undoubtedly, she had been observed. Indeed, she had been observed. She hadn't made an effort to remain unseen, and it was a feat she clearly couldn't accomplish.

But how had she been seen, and what was there to see? She was in love—she knew that, but it was entirely her own affair, and she felt as if she had behaved, and was still behaving, with almost extreme propriety. "I've an idea—in fact I feel sure—that Aunt Maud means to write to you; and I think you had better know it." So much as this she said to him as soon as they met, but immediately adding to it: "So as to make up your mind how to take her. I know pretty well what she'll say to you."

Translation

But how had she been seen, and what was there to see? She was in love—she knew that, but it was entirely her own business, and she felt as if she had behaved, and was still behaving, with almost perfect decorum. "I have a feeling—in fact I'm certain—that Aunt Maud intends to write to you; and I think you should know." This much she said to him as soon as they met, but immediately added: "So you can decide how to respond to her. I have a good idea of what she'll say to you."

"Then will you kindly tell me?" She thought a little. "I can't do that. I should spoil it.

Translation

"Then will you kindly tell me?" She considered for a moment. "I can't do that. I'd ruin it."

She'll do the best for her own idea." "Her idea, you mean, that I'm a sort of a scoundrel; or, at the best, not good enough for you?" They were side by side again in their penny chairs, and Kate had another pause. "Not good enough for her."

Translation

"She'll do what she thinks is best for her own idea." "Her idea, you mean, that I'm a sort of a scoundrel; or, at the best, not good enough for you?" They were side by side again in their penny chairs, and Kate had another pause. "Not good enough for her."

"I suspect—I'm actually certain—that Aunt Maud plans to write to you, and I thought you should be aware of it." She told him this as soon as they met, and then quickly added, "So you can decide how to respond to her. I have a pretty good idea of what she'll say." "Then would you mind telling me?" She paused for a moment.

Translation

"I suspect—in fact, I'm sure—that Aunt Maud intends to write to you, and I wanted you to know." She said it right away when they saw each other, and then added quickly, "So you can decide how to answer her. I have a pretty good idea of what she'll say." "Would you mind telling me, then?" She hesitated.

"I can't. I'd ruin it. She'll present her own point of view most effectively." "Her point of view being that I'm some kind of villain?

Translation

"I can't. If I did, I'd mess it up. She'll get her ideas across much better than I could."

"Her ideas being that I'm the bad guy?"

Or, at best, not worthy of you?" They were sitting together again in their inexpensive chairs, and Kate paused again. "Not worthy of her." "Oh, I see.

Translation

Or, at best, not worthy of you?" They were sitting together again in their inexpensive chairs, and Kate paused again. "Not worthy of her." "Oh, I see.

And that's necessary." He put it as a truth rather more than as a question; but there had been plenty of truths between them that each had contradicted. Kate, however, let this one sufficiently pass, only saying the next moment: "She has behaved extraordinarily." "And so have we," Densher declared.

Translation

"And that's necessary." He phrased it more as a statement than a question, although they'd shared many truths that they'd both denied. Kate, however, let that one slide, and simply said a moment later, "She's behaved extraordinarily." "And so have we," Densher declared.

"I think, you know, we've been awfully decent." "For ourselves, for each other, for people in general, yes. But not for her. For her," said Kate, "we've been monstrous.

Translation

"I think, you know, we've been awfully decent." "For ourselves, for each other, for people in general, yes. But not for her. For her," said Kate, "we've been monstrous."

She has been giving us rope. So if she does send for you," the girl repeated, "you must know where you are." "That I always know. It's where you are that concerns me."

Translation

She's been letting us have our way. So if she does send for you," the girl repeated, "you need to understand your situation." "I always understand mine. It's yours that worries me."

"Well," said Kate after an instant, "her idea of that is what you'll have from her." He gave her a long look, and whatever else people who wouldn't let her alone might have wished, for her advancement, his long looks were the thing in the world she could never have enough of. What she felt was that, whatever might happen, she must keep them, must make them most completely her possession; and it was already strange enough that she reasoned, or at all events began to act, as if she might work them in with other and alien things, privately cherish them, and yet, as regards the rigour of it, pay no price. She looked it well in the face, she took it intensely home, that they were lovers; she rejoiced to herself and, frankly, to him, in their wearing of the name; but, distinguished creature that, in her way, she was, she took a view of this character that scarce squared with the conventional. The character itself she insisted on as their right, taking that so for granted that it didn't seem even bold; but Densher, though he agreed with her, found himself moved to wonder at her simplifications, her values.

Translation

"Well," Kate said after a moment, "you'll get from her what she thinks of as that." He looked at her closely, and whatever else people who wouldn't leave her alone might have wanted for her, for her success, his long looks were the one thing in the world she could never get enough of. What she felt was that, no matter what happened, she must keep them, must make them entirely her own; and it was already odd enough that she reasoned, or at least started to act, as if she could blend them with other, foreign things, secretly value them, and yet, as far as the seriousness of it went, pay nothing for them. She faced it squarely, she internalized it completely, that they were lovers; she reveled in it privately, and, frankly, to him, in their use of the word; but, in her own way, being a remarkable person, she had a view of this relationship that didn't quite match the usual one. She insisted on the relationship itself as their right, taking that so for granted that it didn't even seem daring; but Densher, though he agreed with her, found himself surprised by her simplifications, her values.

Life might prove difficult—was evidently going to; but meanwhile they had each other, and that was everything. This was her reasoning, but meanwhile, for him, each other was what they didn't have, and it was just the point. Repeatedly, however, it was a point that, in the face of strange and special things, he judged it rather awkwardly gross to urge. It was impossible to keep Mrs.

Translation

Stringham out of it; it was impossible, with her, not to have to do with her. He was by that time—he felt it as a sort of doom—far enough gone to find his position perfectly familiar and to realize with what a different view of the case he should have met her, in the first instance, if he had seen from the beginning what he was coming to. He had, in other words, to live with the fact that he was already living with it, and this, inevitably, involved a certain amount of the practical. It involved, above all, the sense of his own participation, and, by the time he had been at Matcham a week, he had given up the attempt to blink that.

Lowder out of their scheme. She stood there too close to it and too solidly; it had to open a gate, at a given point, do what they would to take her in. And she came in, always, while they sat together rather helplessly watching her, as in a coach-in-four; she drove round their prospect as the principal lady at the circus drives round the ring, and she stopped the coach in the middle to alight with majesty. It was our young man's sense that she was magnificently vulgar, but yet, quite, that this wasn't all.

Translation

Lowder was outside of their plan. She was too close to it, too solid; it had to open a gate, no matter what they did to include her. And she always entered, while they sat together, watching her rather helplessly, as if in a coach-and-four. She drove around their expectations like the main woman in a circus drives around the ring, and she stopped the coach in the middle to dismount with grandeur. It was our young man’s feeling that she was magnificently vulgar, yet, also, that this wasn’t the whole truth.

It wasn't with her vulgarity that she felt his want of means, though that might have helped her richly to embroider it; nor was it with the same infirmity that she was strong, original, dangerous. "Oh, I understand. And that's essential." He stated this more as a fact than a question.

Translation

It wasn't her vulgarity that made her aware of his poverty, though that might have helped her to emphasize it. Nor did her strength, originality, and danger stem from the same weakness. "Oh, I understand. And that's essential." He stated this more as a fact than a question.

But they'd already contradicted plenty of truths between them. Kate, however, let that comment go, saying a moment later, "She's behaved in an extraordinary way." "And so have we," Densher said. "I think we've been extremely reasonable."

Translation

But they had already contradicted a multitude of truths between them. Kate, nonetheless, ignored that comment, stating a moment later, "Her behavior has been quite extraordinary." "And so have we," Densher said. "I believe we've been exceedingly rational."

"For ourselves, for each other, for people in general, yes. But not for her. For her," Kate said, "we've been terrible. She's given us freedom.

Translation

"For ourselves, for each other, for people in general, yes. But not for her. For her," Kate said, "we've been terrible. She's given us freedom."

So if she does call for you," she repeated, "you need to know where you stand." "I always know that. It's where you stand that concerns me." "Well," Kate said after a moment, "her idea of that is what you'll get from her." He gave her a long look, and whatever anyone else who didn't leave her alone might have desired for her success, his long looks were what she wanted more than anything.

Translation

"So if she does call for you," she repeated, "you need to understand your position." "I always understand mine. It's yours that worries me." "Well," Kate said after a pause, "her version of it is the one you'll be getting from her." He gave her a long look, and whatever anyone else who wouldn't leave her alone might have wished for her, her success, those long looks were what she wanted most.

What she felt was that, no matter what happened, she had to keep them, had to completely possess them. And it was already strange enough that she reasoned, or at least started acting, as if she could integrate them with other, unrelated things, privately cherish them, and yet, regarding how difficult it all was, pay no price. She acknowledged it, she took it seriously, that they were lovers. She reveled in it privately and, honestly, with him.

Translation

What she felt was that she had to keep them, no matter what. She had to completely own them. It was already a strange notion to her, that she thought, or at least started behaving, as if she could merge them with other, unrelated things, privately treasure them, and, despite how difficult it all was, pay nothing for it. She acknowledged it. She took it seriously that they were lovers. She reveled in it privately, and, honestly, with him.

However, despite being a remarkable person in her own way, she had a particular view of this situation that didn't align with tradition. She insisted on the label itself as their right, taking it so for granted that it didn't seem even daring. But Densher, although he agreed with her, was surprised by her simplifying and her values. Life might become difficult—it obviously would—but in the meantime they had each other, and that was everything.

Translation

Yet, as extraordinary as she was in her own right, her perspective on this matter deviated from conventional wisdom. She embraced their designation as their inherent entitlement, viewing it so matter-of-factly that it lacked any sense of audacity. However, Densher, despite his agreement, was taken aback by her simplification and her priorities. Life might present challenges—indeed, it inevitably would—but for now, they had each other, and that was all that mattered.

This was her reasoning, but in the meantime, for him, what they didn't have was each other, and that was the core issue. However, he felt it was awkward and insensitive to constantly bring up this point in light of strange and complex matters. It was impossible to exclude Mrs. Lowder from their plan.

Translation

That was her logic, but in his case, what they lacked was each other, and that was the fundamental problem. Yet, he found it clumsy and tactless to keep harping on this detail, given the odd and complicated circumstances. It was impossible to leave Mrs. Lowder out of their plans.

She was too close to it and too entrenched. It had to open a door, at some point, no matter what they did, to include her. And she always entered, while they sat together rather helplessly watching her, like in a horse-drawn carriage. She circled their situation the way the main lady in the circus circles the ring, and she stopped the carriage in the middle to get out with regal flair.

Translation

She was too involved, too deeply embedded in it all. No matter their actions, their plans would inevitably have to accommodate her. And she would always insert herself into the situation, while they remained, helpless, observing her, much like passengers in a carriage. She surveyed their predicament as a ringmaster surveys a circus ring, and with theatrical grace, she would halt the carriage in the center and dismount.

Our young man felt she was magnificently vulgar, but also realized that wasn't the whole story. It wasn't because of her vulgarity that she recognized his lack of money, though that might have helped her embellish it. Nor was it because of this vulnerability that she was strong, original, and dangerous. His want of means—of means sufficient for anyone but himself—was really the great ugliness, and was, moreover, at no time more ugly for him than when it rose there, as it did seem to rise, shameless, face to face with the elements in Kate's life colloquially and conveniently classed by both of them as funny.

Translation

Our young man found her magnificently vulgar, but understood there was more to it than that. It wasn't because of her vulgarity that she saw his lack of money, though it may have helped her highlight it. Nor was it through this vulnerability that she was strong, original, and dangerous. His lack of funds—lacking enough for anyone but himself—was the real ugliness, and, furthermore, it was never uglier to him than when it arose, as it seemed to, shamelessly, confronting the elements of Kate's life, which they both casually and conveniently categorized as funny.

He sometimes indeed, for that matter, asked himself if these elements were as funny as the innermost fact, so often vivid to him, of his own consciousness—his private inability to believe he should ever be rich. His conviction on this head was in truth quite positive and a thing by itself; he failed, after analysis, to understand it, though he had naturally more lights on it than any one else. He knew how it subsisted in spite of an equal consciousness of his being neither mentally nor physically quite helpless, neither a dunce nor a cripple; he knew it to be absolute, though secret, and also, strange to say, about common undertakings, not discouraging, not prohibitive. Only now was he having to think if it were prohibitive in respect to marriage; only now, for the first time, had he to weigh his case in scales.

Translation

He sometimes, for that matter, actually wondered if those elements were as humorous as the core fact, so often clear to him, of his own awareness—his personal inability to believe he would ever be rich. His conviction on this point was truly certain and a thing unto itself; he couldn’t understand it after examining it, though he naturally understood it better than anyone else. He knew it persisted despite also being aware that he wasn’t helpless in mind or body, neither unintelligent nor crippled; he knew it to be absolute, though hidden, and also, oddly, with everyday endeavors, not disheartening, not restrictive. Only now did he have to consider if it would be restrictive regarding marriage; only now, for the first time, did he have to assess his situation.

The scales, as he sat with Kate, often dangled in the line of his vision; he saw them, large and black, while he talked or listened, take, in the bright air, singular positions. Sometimes the right was down and sometimes the left; never a happy equipoise—one or the other always kicking the beam. Thus was kept before him the question of whether it were more ignoble to ask a woman to take her chance with you, or to accept it from one's conscience that her chance could be at the best but one of the degrees of privation; whether, too, otherwise, marrying for money mightn't after all be a smaller cause of shame than the mere dread of marrying without. Through these variations of mood and view, all the same, the mark on his forehead stood clear; he saw himself remain without whether he married or not.

Translation

The scales, as he sat with Kate, often swayed in his sightline; he saw them, enormous and black, as he spoke or listened, assume distinct positions in the bright air. Sometimes the right side was down, and sometimes the left; never a pleasant balance—one or the other always tipping the beam. Thus, the question of whether it was more dishonorable to ask a woman to risk her future with him, or to concede to his conscience that her prospects could only be, at best, a series of deprivations was ever-present. He also considered whether, alternatively, marrying for money might, in the end, be a lesser source of shame than the mere fear of marrying without it. Across these fluctuations of mood and perspective, the mark on his forehead remained clear; he saw himself remaining alone, regardless of whether he married or not.

It was a line on which his fancy could be admirably active; the innumerable ways of making money were beautifully present to him; he could have handled them, for his newspaper, as easily as he handled everything. He was quite aware how he handled everything; it was another mark on his forehead; the pair of smudges from the thumb of fortune, the brand on the passive fleece, dated from the primal hour and kept each other company. He wrote, as for print, with deplorable ease; since there had been nothing to stop him even at the age of ten, so there was as little at twenty; it was part of his fate in the first place and part of the wretched public's in the second. The innumerable ways of making money were, no doubt, at all events, what his imagination often was busy with after he had tilted his chair and thrown back his head with his hands clasped behind it.

Translation

This was a line that really sparked his imagination. The countless ways to make money were vividly clear to him. He could have written about them for his newspaper as easily as he wrote about anything else. He was very conscious of how he did things; it was another mark on his forehead, paired with the other mark, a kind of branding from the start. They were like two smudges from fate's thumb, a mark upon his passive self. It began at the very beginning and was always there. He wrote with terrible ease, as if it was meant for print. Nothing had ever stopped him, not even when he was ten, and nothing stopped him now. It was simply his destiny, and, in a way, the wretched public's, too. The many paths to wealth were, undoubtedly, what his imagination often dwelt on, especially after he'd leaned back in his chair with his hands clasped behind his head.

What would most have prolonged that attitude, moreover, was the reflection that the ways were ways only for others. Within the minute, now—however this might be—he was aware of a nearer view than he had yet quite had of those circumstances on his companion's part that made least for simplicity of relation. He saw above all how she saw them herself, for she spoke of them at present with the last frankness, telling him of her visit to her father and giving him, in an account of her subsequent scene with her sister, an instance of how she was perpetually reduced to patching up, in one way or another, that unfortunate woman's hopes. His lack of money—not enough for anyone except himself—was the real problem, and it seemed most obvious when it confronted him directly, brazenly facing the aspects of Kate's life they jokingly referred to as "funny." He sometimes wondered if those things were as humorous as his deepest awareness of his own situation—his private belief that he would never be rich.

Translation

What most perpetuated that stance, furthermore, was the realization that those avenues were only accessible to others. In that very moment—however it might be—he grasped a closer understanding of the conditions his companion faced, the ones that complicated their relationship. Above all, he understood how she perceived those conditions herself, as she discussed them with complete candor, describing her visit to her father and detailing, through her later confrontation with her sister, how she was constantly forced to mend, in one way or another, that unfortunate woman's aspirations. His poverty—not enough for anyone, including himself—was the central issue, and it was most apparent when it directly confronted him, boldly facing the elements of Kate's life they jokingly called "funny." He sometimes questioned whether those matters were as amusing as his deepest understanding of his own circumstances—his private conviction that he would never be wealthy.

This conviction was very strong and unique to him. He couldn't understand it, even though he knew more about it than anyone else. He knew it persisted despite his understanding that he wasn't completely helpless, either mentally or physically, and that he was neither stupid nor disabled. He knew it was absolute, though hidden, and surprisingly, it didn't discourage him from regular tasks.

Translation

This conviction was potent and singular to him. It baffled him, despite the fact that he possessed a greater familiarity with it than anyone else. He knew it endured even though he understood he wasn't entirely without resources, both mentally and physically, and that he was neither unintelligent nor incapacitated. He knew it was unwavering, though concealed, and unexpectedly, it didn't dissuade him from his daily routines.

Only now did he have to consider if it would prevent him from marrying; only now, for the first time, did he have to weigh the pros and cons. As he sat with Kate, the scales of this decision often appeared before him; he saw them, large and dark, as he spoke or listened, hanging in strange positions in the bright air. Sometimes the right side was down, sometimes the left; there was never a balance—one side always outweighed the other. This forced him to consider whether it was more shameful to ask a woman to risk her future with him or to accept the fact that her future with him would likely involve some level of financial hardship.

Translation

Only now did he have to wonder if it would stop him from getting married; only now, for the first time, did he have to think through the advantages and disadvantages. As he sat with Kate, the components of this decision often materialized; he saw them, large and ominous, as he talked or listened, suspended in peculiar ways in the clear atmosphere. Sometimes the right side was heavy, sometimes the left; there was never equilibrium—one side consistently carried more weight. This compelled him to ask himself whether it was more disgraceful to ask a woman to gamble her future with him or to accept that her future with him would probably involve some degree of financial difficulty.

He also wondered if marrying for money might be less shameful than the fear of marrying without it. Despite these shifting feelings and perspectives, one thing remained clear: his fate was sealed; he saw himself remaining without, regardless of whether he married or not. His imagination worked wonders on this idea; he could easily picture the many ways to make money, and he could have written about them for his newspaper as easily as he wrote about everything else. He was very aware of how easily he wrote; it was another mark on his forehead, a pair of smudges left by luck, a mark on his passive nature, there since the beginning and always together.

Translation

He also considered whether marrying for money might be less shameful than the fear of marrying without it. Despite these fluctuating emotions and viewpoints, one thing was certain: his destiny was fixed; he envisioned himself remaining without, irrespective of whether he married or remained single. His imagination had a field day with this notion; he could readily envision the many methods to acquire wealth, and he could have documented them for his newspaper as effortlessly as he wrote about everything else. He was acutely conscious of his facility for writing; it was another blemish, a set of marks left by fortune, an imprint upon his acquiescent nature, present from the start and inseparable.

He wrote with regrettable ease, since nothing had stopped him even at age ten, so there was little to stop him at twenty; it was partly his destiny and partly the public's misfortune. The many ways to make money were undoubtedly what his imagination often focused on after he leaned back in his chair with his hands clasped behind his head. What would have most prolonged that posture was the thought that these methods were only useful for others. At this moment, however, he became more aware of the circumstances of his companion's life that complicated their relationship.

Translation

He wrote with an unfortunate facility, since nothing had curbed him even at ten years old, so there was little to stop him at twenty; this was in part his fate, and in part the public's misfortune. The myriad ways to acquire money were, without a doubt, what his imagination often dwelt upon once he leaned back in his chair, hands clasped behind his head. What would have extended that pose the longest was the thought that these methods were only useful to others. At this moment, however, he became more aware of the realities of his companion’s life that complicated their relationship.

He saw, above all, how she saw them herself, because she spoke about them openly, telling him about her visit to her father and describing a later argument with her sister, providing an example of how she was constantly trying to mend her unfortunate sister's hopes. "The tune," she exclaimed, "to which we're a failure as a family!" With which he had it again all from her—and this time, as it seemed to him, more than all: the dishonour her father had brought them, his folly and cruelty and wickedness; the wounded state of her mother, abandoned, despoiled and helpless, yet, for the management of such a home as remained to them, dreadfully unreasonable too; the extinction of her two young brothers—one, at nineteen, the eldest of the house, by typhoid fever, contracted at a poisonous little place, as they had afterwards found out, that they had taken for a summer; the other, the flower of the flock, a middy on the Britannia, dreadfully drowned, and not even by an accident at sea, but by cramp, unrescued, while bathing, too late in the autumn, in a wretched little river during a holiday visit to the home of a shipmate. Then Marian's unnatural marriage, in itself a kind of spiritless turning of the other cheek to fortune: her actual wretchedness and plaintiveness, her greasy children, her impossible claims, her odious visitors—these things completed the proof of the heaviness, for them all, of the hand of fate. Kate confessedly described them with an excess of impatience; it was much of her charm for Densher that she gave in general that turn to her descriptions, partly as if to amuse him by free and humorous colour, partly—and that charm was the greatest—as if to work off, for her own relief, her constant perception of the incongruity of things.

Translation

He saw, above all, how she saw them herself, because she spoke openly about these things. She told him about visiting her father, describing a subsequent argument with her sister, offering an example of how she was always trying to mend her sister's broken hopes. "The tune," she exclaimed, "to which we're a failure as a family!" With that, he had it again, all of it from her—and this time, it seemed to him, more than everything: the disgrace her father had brought on them, his foolishness, cruelty, and wickedness; the suffering of her mother, abandoned, stripped bare and helpless, yet, for managing what remained of their home, dreadfully unreasonable as well; the deaths of her two young brothers—one, at nineteen, the eldest of the house, by typhoid fever, contracted at a poisonous little place, as they had later discovered, that they had taken for the summer; the other, the darling of the family, a midshipman on the Britannia, drowned horribly, not even by a sea accident, but by a cramp, unrescued, while bathing, too late in the autumn, in a wretched little river during a holiday visit to a shipmate's home. Then Marian's unnatural marriage, in itself a kind of meek acceptance of misfortune: her actual wretchedness and plaintiveness, her greasy children, her impossible demands, her odious visitors—these things completed the proof of the heavy hand of fate for them all. Kate confessed to describing these things with an excess of impatience. It was a large part of her charm for Densher that she gave that general turn to her descriptions, partly as if to amuse him with colorful and humorous language, partly—and that charm was the greatest—as if to work off, for her own relief, her constant perception of the incongruity of things.

She had seen the general show too early and too sharply, and she was so intelligent that she knew it and allowed for that misfortune; therefore when, in talk with him, she was violent and almost unfeminine, it was almost as if they had settled, for intercourse, on the short cut of the fantastic and the happy language of exaggeration. It had come to be definite between them at a primary stage that, if they could have no other straight way, the realm of thought at least was open to them. They could think whatever they liked about whatever they would—or, in other words, they could say it. Saying it for each other, for each other alone, only of course added to the taste.

Translation

She had grasped the whole picture too soon and too clearly, and she was intelligent enough to be aware of this, making allowances for her misfortune. Consequently, when she became intense and nearly unfeminine in their conversations, it was almost as if they had agreed to use the shortcut of the fantastical and the joyful language of exaggeration as the basis for their communication. It had been established between them early on that, if no other straightforward path was available, at least the realm of thought was open to them. They were free to think whatever they wished about whatever they pleased—or, in other words, they were free to speak their minds. Saying it to each other, and only to each other, naturally heightened the pleasure.

The implication was thereby constant that what they said when not together had no taste for them at all, and nothing could have served more to launch them, at special hours, on their small floating island than such an assumption that they were only making believe everywhere else. Our young man, it must be added, was conscious enough that it was Kate who profited most by this particular play of the fact of intimacy. It always seemed to him that she had more life than he to react from, and when she recounted the dark disasters of her house and glanced at the hard, odd offset of her present exaltation—since as exaltation it was apparently to be considered—he felt his own grey domestic annals to make little show. It was naturally, in all such reference, the question of her father's character that engaged him most, but her picture of her adventure in Chirk Street gave him a sense of how little as yet that character was clear to him.

Translation

The constant unspoken agreement was that their words, when uttered apart, held no appeal for them. This understanding served to launch them, during those special hours, onto their own secluded haven. They assumed they were merely pretending everywhere else. Our young man, it should be noted, was well aware that Kate benefited most from this particular performance of intimacy. It seemed to him that she possessed more vitality to draw from. When she recounted the dark tragedies of her family and alluded to the peculiar, stark contrast of her present joy—for that is what it seemed to be—he felt his own mundane domestic history pale in comparison. Naturally, in all such discussions, the nature of her father fascinated him most, but her account of her experiences in Chirk Street revealed how little he truly understood that man.

What was it, to speak plainly, that Mr. Croy had originally done? "The tune," she exclaimed, "that describes our family's failure!" With that, she told him everything again—and this time, it seemed to him, even more than before: the disgrace her father had brought on them, his foolishness, cruelty, and wickedness; her mother's wounded state, abandoned, robbed, and helpless, yet, in managing the home that remained, also terribly unreasonable; the deaths of her two young brothers—one, at nineteen, the eldest, by typhoid fever, caught at a disgusting little place they'd taken for the summer; the other, the favorite, a naval cadet on the Britannia, dreadfully drowned, not by an accident at sea, but by a cramp, unrescued, while bathing too late in the autumn, in a terrible little river during a holiday visit to a shipmate's home. Then Marian's unnatural marriage, a kind of passive acceptance of fate: her actual misery and complaints, her grubby children, her impossible demands, her awful visitors—these things proved how heavy fate's hand had been on them all.

Translation

To put it bluntly, what had Mr. Croy done in the first place? "The tune," she cried, "that tells the story of our family's downfall!" And then she told him everything all over again—and it seemed to him, this time, even more than before: the shame her father had brought on them, his foolishness, his cruelty, and his wickedness; her mother's wounded state, abandoned, robbed, and helpless, and yet, in running the household that remained, also terribly difficult; the deaths of her two young brothers—one, the eldest, at nineteen, dead from typhoid fever contracted at a disgusting little place they'd rented for the summer; the other, the favorite, a naval cadet on the Britannia, who had drowned horribly, not in an accident at sea, but from a cramp, left to drown while swimming too late in the autumn, in a terrible little river during a holiday visit to a friend's house. Then there was Marian's unnatural marriage, a kind of passive surrender to fate: her actual misery and complaints, her dirty children, her impossible demands, her awful visitors—all of this proved how heavily fate had burdened them.

Kate described these things with impatience; it was part of her charm for Densher that she gave her descriptions that quality, partly to entertain him with lively, humorous language, partly—and that charm was the greatest—to relieve herself by constantly pointing out how absurd things were. She'd seen the general situation too early and too clearly, and she was intelligent enough to know it and allow for that misfortune; so when she was harsh and almost unfeminine in conversation with him, it was almost as if they'd agreed to communicate using the shortcut of exaggeration and fantasy. It had become clear between them early on that, if they couldn't have anything else, at least they had the realm of thought. They could think whatever they wanted about whatever they wanted—or, in other words, they could say it.

Translation

Kate described these things with impatience. For Densher, this was part of her appeal. She flavored her descriptions with that quality, partly to amuse him with vivid, witty language, and partly—and this was the greatest charm of all—to unburden herself by continually highlighting the absurdity of everything. She had understood the overall situation too early and too well, and she was intelligent enough to be aware of that misfortune and account for it. Therefore, when she spoke to him with a harshness that bordered on the unfeminine, it was almost as if they had agreed to communicate using the shorthand of hyperbole and imagination. Early on, they had established that, if they could have nothing else, they had the realm of thought. They could think whatever they wanted, about whatever they wanted—or, in other words, they could say it.

Saying it for each other, and only for each other, of course, made it better. The unspoken agreement was that what they said when they weren't together had no appeal at all, and nothing could have launched them on their own little island more than the idea that they were only pretending everywhere else. Our young man, it must be said, was aware that Kate benefited most from their intimate conversations. He always felt she had more life than he did to react against, and when she described her family's dark tragedies and looked at the strange, stark contrast of her present happiness—because that's what it seemed to be—he felt his own dull domestic life to be insignificant.

Translation

Sharing these things, and only with each other, made it easier. They understood that what they said when apart held no value, and nothing cemented their private world like the idea that they were playacting everywhere else. It should be said that Kate gained the most from their private talks. He always felt she had a greater zest for life to push against, and when she recounted her family's awful dramas and observed the bizarre, sharp contrast with her current happiness—because that's what it seemed to be—he felt his own bland, ordinary life to be meaningless.

Naturally, in all such discussions, her father's character interested him most, but her account of her experience in Chirk Street made him realize how unclear that character still was to him. What, to be specific, had Mr. Croy done in the first place? "I don't know—and I don't want to.

Translation

Inevitably, during these conversations, he was most intrigued by her father, though her tales of Chirk Street made him realize how little he truly knew about the man. What, specifically, had Mr. Croy done in the first place? "I don't know—and I don't want to."

I only know that years and years ago—when I was about fifteen—something or other happened that made him impossible. I mean impossible for the world at large first, and then, little by little, for mother. We of course didn't know it at the time," Kate explained, "but we knew it later; and it was, oddly enough, my sister who first made out that he had done something. I can hear her now—the way, one cold, black Sunday morning when, on account of an extraordinary fog, we had not gone to church, she broke it to me by the school-room fire.

Translation

"I only know that years and years ago—when I was about fifteen—something or other happened that made him impossible. I mean, impossible for the world at large first, and then, little by little, for mother. We of course didn't know it at the time," Kate explained, "but we knew it later; and it was, oddly enough, my sister who first figured out that he had done something. I can hear her now—the way, one cold, black Sunday morning when, on account of an extraordinary fog, we had not gone to church, she broke it to me by the school-room fire."

I was reading a history-book by the lamp—when we didn't go to church we had to read history-books—and I suddenly heard her say, out of the fog, which was in the room, and apropos of nothing: 'Papa has done something wicked.' And the curious thing was that I believed it on the spot and have believed it ever since, though she could tell me nothing more—neither what was the wickedness, nor how she knew, nor what would happen to him, nor anything else about it. We had our sense, always, that all sorts of things had happened, were all the while happening, to him; so that when Marian only said she was sure, tremendously sure, that she had made it out for herself, but that that was enough, I took her word for it—it seemed somehow so natural. We were not, however, to ask mother—which made it more natural still, and I said never a word. But mother, strangely enough, spoke of it to me, in time, of her own accord very much later on.

Translation

I was reading a history book by the lamp—we had to read history books when we didn't go to church—and I suddenly heard her say, out of the fog, which was in the room, apropos of nothing: "Papa has done something wicked." The curious thing was that I believed her instantly and have believed it ever since, though she couldn't tell me anything more—neither what the wickedness was, nor how she knew, nor what would happen to him, nor anything else about it. We always sensed that all sorts of things had happened and were happening to him; so when Marian just said she was sure, tremendously sure, that she'd figured it out herself, but that that was enough, I took her word for it—it seemed so natural somehow. We weren't to ask mother, however, which made it even more natural, and I didn't say a word. But mother, strangely enough, spoke of it to me, in time, of her own accord, much later on.

He hadn't been with us for ever so long, but we were used to that. She must have had some fear, some conviction that I had an idea, some idea of her own that it was the best thing to do. She came out as abruptly as Marian had done: 'If you hear anything against your father—anything I mean, except that he's odious and vile—remember it's perfectly false.' That was the way I knew—it was true, though I recall that I said to her then that I of course knew it wasn't. She might have told me it was true, and yet have trusted me to contradict fiercely enough any accusation of him that I should meet—to contradict it much more fiercely and effectively, I think, than she would have done herself.

Translation

He hadn't been around for ages, but we were used to it. She must have been afraid, convinced I knew something, or had some idea of her own that this was the best thing to do. She spoke as abruptly as Marian had. "If you hear anything bad about your father—anything, I mean, except that he's hateful and disgusting—remember it's completely untrue." That was how I knew—it was true, even though I remember telling her then that of course I knew it wasn't. She could have told me it was true and still trusted me to fiercely deny any accusations against him that I might hear—to deny them more fiercely and effectively, I think, than she would have done herself.

As it happens, however," the girl went on, "I've never had occasion, and I've been conscious of it with a sort of surprise. It has made the world, at times, seem more decent. No one has so much as breathed to me. That has been a part of the silence, the silence that surrounds him, the silence that, for the world, has washed him out.

Translation

As it happens, however," the girl went on, "I've never had occasion, and I've been conscious of it with a sort of surprise. It has made the world, at times, seem more decent. No one has so much as breathed a word to me. That has been a part of the silence, the silence that surrounds him, the silence that, for the world, has washed him away.

He doesn't exist for people. And yet I'm as sure as ever. In fact, though I know no more than I did then, I'm more sure. And that," she wound up, "is what I sit here and tell you about my own father.

Translation

He doesn't exist for anyone. And still, I'm as certain as I've always been. Actually, even though I know no more than I did back then, I'm even more certain. And that," she concluded, "is what I sit here and tell you about my own father.

If you don't call it a proof of confidence I don't know what will satisfy you." "I don't know—and I don't want to. I only know that years ago—when I was about fifteen—something happened that made him unacceptable. I mean, unacceptable to the world first, and then, gradually, to mother.

Translation

If you don't call that proof of confidence, then I don't know what would. "I don't know—and I don't want to. I only know that years ago—when I was about fifteen—something happened that made him unacceptable. I mean, unacceptable to the world first, and then, gradually, to mother.

Of course, we didn't know it at the time," Kate explained, "but we found out later; and, strangely, it was my sister who first realized he had done something wrong. I can still hear her—that cold, dark Sunday morning when, due to an extraordinary fog, we hadn't gone to church—when she told me by the schoolroom fire. I was reading a history book by the lamp—when we didn't go to church we had to read history books—and I suddenly heard her say, coming out of the fog that filled the room, and apropos of nothing: 'Papa has done something wicked.' And the odd thing was that I believed it instantly and have believed it ever since, though she couldn't tell me more—neither what the wickedness was, nor how she knew, nor what would happen to him, nor anything else about it. We always sensed that all sorts of things had happened, were constantly happening, to him; so when Marian just said she was sure, absolutely sure, that she'd figured it out herself, but that was enough, I took her word for it—it seemed somehow so natural.

Translation

"Of course, we didn't know it at the time," Kate explained, "but we found out later; and, strangely, it was my sister who first realized he had done something wrong. I can still hear her—that cold, dark Sunday morning when, due to an extraordinary fog, we hadn't gone to church—when she told me by the schoolroom fire. I was reading a history book by the lamp—when we didn't go to church we had to read history books—and I suddenly heard her say, coming out of the fog that filled the room, and apropos of nothing: 'Papa has done something wicked.' And the odd thing was that I believed it instantly and have believed it ever since, though she couldn't tell me more—neither what the wickedness was, nor how she knew, nor what would happen to him, nor anything else about it. We always sensed that all sorts of things had happened, were constantly happening, to him; so when Marian just said she was sure, absolutely sure, that she'd figured it out herself, but that was enough, I took her word for it—it seemed somehow so natural.

However, we weren't supposed to ask mother—which made it even more natural, and I didn't say a word. But mother, strangely enough, spoke to me about it, on her own accord, much later on. He hadn't been with us for a long time, but we were used to that. She must have had some fear, some conviction that I knew something, some idea of her own that this was the best thing to do.

Translation

We weren't supposed to ask Mother about it, which made it even easier to accept, and I didn't say a word. But Mother, strangely enough, spoke to me about it herself, much later. He hadn't been with us for a long time, but we were used to that. She must have had some fear, some certainty that I knew something, some idea of her own that this was the right thing to do.

She came out just as abruptly as Marian had: 'If you hear anything against your father—anything, I mean, except that he's hateful and disgusting—remember it's completely false.' That's how I knew—it was true, though I remember telling her then that of course I knew it wasn't. She might have told me it was true, and still trusted me to fiercely deny any accusation against him that I might hear—to deny it much more fiercely and effectively, I think, than she would have done herself. But as it happens," the girl continued, "I've never had to, and I've been aware of this with a kind of surprise. It has, at times, made the world seem more decent.

Translation

She spoke as abruptly as Marian had: "If you hear anything said against your father—anything beyond the fact that he's hateful and disgusting—remember it's completely false." That’s how I knew it was true, though I recall telling her then that of course I knew it wasn't. She might have told me it was true and still trusted me to fiercely deny any accusation against him that I might hear—to deny it much more fiercely and effectively, I think, than she would have done herself. But as it happens," the girl continued, "I've never had to, and I've been aware of this with a kind of surprise. It has, at times, made the world seem more decent.

No one has even hinted anything to me. That has been part of the silence, the silence that surrounds him, the silence that, for the world, has erased him. He doesn't exist for people. And yet I'm as sure as ever.

Translation

No one has ever hinted anything to me. That's part of the silence, the silence around him, the silence that has erased him from the world. He doesn't exist for people. And yet I'm as sure as ever.

In fact, though I know no more than I did then, I'm more sure. And that," she concluded, "is what I'm telling you about my own father. If you don't call that a show of trust, I don't know what will satisfy you." "It satisfies me beautifully," Densher declared, "but it doesn't, my dear child, very greatly enlighten me.

Translation

Indeed, even though my knowledge hasn't grown, my certainty has. And that," she finished, "is the story of my father. If that isn't trust, then I don't know what you want from me." "It's perfect," Densher said. "But it doesn't, my dear, illuminate me very much."

You don't, you know, really tell me anything. It's so vague that what am I to think but that you may very well be mistaken? What has he done, if no one can name it?" "He has done everything."

Translation

You really don't tell me anything, you know. It's so vague that all I can think is that you might be wrong. What has he actually done, if no one can say?" "He's done everything.

"Oh—everything! Everything's nothing." "Well then," said Kate, "he has done some particular thing. It's known—only, thank God, not to us.

Translation

"Oh—everything! Everything amounts to nothing." "Well then," said Kate, "he's done some specific thing. It's known—only, thank God, not to us."

But it has been the end of him. You could doubtless find out with a little trouble. You can ask about." Densher for a moment said nothing; but the next moment he made it up.

Translation

But it has finished him. You could probably discover with a bit of effort. You can make inquiries." Densher remained silent for a beat; but the next second he made up his mind.

"I wouldn't find out for the world, and I'd rather lose my tongue than put a question." "I find this perfectly satisfactory," Densher announced, "but, my dear, it doesn't really clarify anything for me. You aren't actually giving me any specific information. It's so unclear that I can only assume you might be wrong.

Translation

"I wouldn't want to know, no matter what. I'd sooner be mute than ask a question." "I'm content with this," Densher said, "but, darling, it doesn't really explain anything to me. You aren't offering me any actual details. It's so vague that I can only assume you might be mistaken."

What exactly has he done, if no one can say?" "He's done everything." "Oh—everything! That's the same as nothing."

Translation

"If no one can specify, what has he actually done?" "He's done it all." "Oh, everything! That's the same as saying he's done nothing at all."

"Well then," Kate replied, "he's done something specific. It's known—thankfully, not to us. But it's ruined him. You could probably discover what it is with a bit of effort.

Translation

"So," Kate answered, "he did something specific. It's known—thank God, not by us. But it's ruined him. You could probably find out what it is with a little digging."

You could ask around." Densher remained silent for a moment, but then made his decision. "I wouldn't want to know for anything in the world, and I would sooner lose my ability to speak than ask a question." "And yet it's a part of me," said Kate.

Translation

"You could try asking around." Densher was quiet for a beat, then he made up his mind. "I wouldn't want to know, no matter what, and I'd sooner lose my tongue than ask a question." "And yet, it's a part of me," Kate said.

"A part of you?" "My father's dishonour." Then she sounded for him, but more deeply than ever yet, her note of proud, still pessimism. "How can such a thing as that not be the great thing in one's life?" She had to take from him again, on this, one of his long looks, and she took it to its deepest, its headiest dregs.

Translation

"A part of you?" "My father's disgrace." Then her voice took on a tone, for him, deeper than he'd heard before, a note of proud, unwavering pessimism. "How could something like that not be the most important thing in a person's life?" She needed to take from him, again, one of his long looks, and she took it to its deepest, most intoxicating depths.

"I shall ask you, for the great thing in your life," he said, "to depend on me a little more." After which, just hesitating, "Doesn't he belong to some club?" he inquired. She had a grave headshake. "He used to—to many." "But he has dropped them?"

Translation

"I want to ask you," he said, "to let yourself rely on me a little more, for the most important thing in your life." Then, after a pause, he asked, "Doesn't he belong to a club?" She shook her head solemnly. "He used to, many clubs." "But he doesn't anymore?"

"They've dropped him. Of that I'm sure. It ought to do for you. I offered him," the girl immediately continued—"and it was for that I went to him—to come and be with him, make a home for him so far as is possible.

Translation

"They've kicked him out. I'm certain of it. That should satisfy you. I offered him," the girl said right away, "and that's why I went to him—to come and be with him, to create a home for him, as much as that's possible."

But he won't hear of it." "And yet it's a part of me," Kate said. "A part of you?" "My father's disgrace." Then her voice took on, more profoundly than before, a tone of proud, quiet pessimism.

Translation

"But he won't allow it." "And yet, it's a part of me," Kate said. "A part of you?" "My father's shame." Then her voice grew, more intensely than before, a tone of proud, quiet pessimism.

"How could something like that not be the most significant thing in one's life?" She had to endure, once again, one of his long, searching glances, and she absorbed it completely, every last bit. "I'm going to ask the most important thing in your life to depend on me a little more," he said. Then, after a slight pause, "Doesn't he belong to a club?" he asked.

Translation

"How could something like that not be the most important thing in one's life?" She braced herself, yet again, under his long, piercing gaze, taking it all in, every last detail. "I'm going to ask the most important thing in your life to depend on me a little more," he said. Then, a beat of silence, "Doesn't he belong to a club?" he asked.

She shook her head solemnly. "He used to belong to many." "But he's been removed from them?" "They've removed themselves from him.

Translation

She nodded gravely. "He was in quite a few, at one point." "But he's been expelled?" "They've all distanced themselves."

Of that, I'm certain. It should be enough for you. I offered him," the girl continued at once—"and that was why I went to him—to come and be with him, to create a home for him, as much as possible. But he refuses to consider it."

Translation

I know that much. It ought to suffice. I offered him, the girl went on without pause—and that’s why I went to him—to come and stay, to make a home for him, to the best of my ability. But he won’t even think about it.

Densher took this in with visible, but generous, wonder. "You offered him—'impossible' as you describe him to me—to live with him and share his disadvantages?" The young man saw for the moment but the high beauty of it. "You are gallant!" "Because it strikes you as being brave for him?" She wouldn't in the least have this.

Translation

Densher absorbed this with visible but generous wonder. "You offered him—'impossible' as you describe him to me—to live with him and share his disadvantages?" In that moment, the young man saw only its high beauty. "You are gallant!" "Because it strikes you as being brave for him?" She would not concede this at all.

"It wasn't courage—it was the opposite. I did it to save myself—to escape." He had his air, so constant at this stage, as of her giving him finer things than any one to think about. "Escape from what?"

Translation

"It wasn't courage—it was the opposite. I did it to save myself—to escape." He had that look, so common with him now, as if she were giving him superior things to ponder. "Escape from what?"

"From everything." "Do you by any chance mean from me?" "No; I spoke to him of you, told him—or what amounted to it—that I would bring you, if he would allow it, with me." Densher absorbed this with obvious but sincere amazement.

Translation

"From everything." "Are you suggesting you were trying to escape me?" "No. I mentioned you to him. I told him—or something like it—that I would bring you along if he'd let me." Densher listened, clearly astonished, but also genuinely so.

"You offered him—a man you find 'impossible'—to live with him and accept his limitations?" For a moment, the young man was struck only by the profound beauty of her gesture. "That was incredibly noble of you!" "You think it was brave of him?" She firmly rejected that idea. "It wasn't courage—it was the reverse.

Translation

"You offered him—a man you find 'impossible'—to live with him and accept his limitations?" For a moment, the young man was struck only by the profound beauty of her gesture. "That was incredibly noble of you!" "You think it was brave of him?" She firmly rejected that idea. "It wasn't courage—it was the reverse.

I did it to save myself—to get away." He adopted his familiar expression, as if she were providing him with the most stimulating food for thought. "Escape from what?" "From everything."

Translation

"I did it to save myself—to get away." A familiar look came over him, as if she'd just presented him with some delicious puzzle to solve. "Escape from what?" "From everything."

"Are you suggesting you were escaping from me?" "No; I spoke to him about you, told him—or essentially implied—that I would bring you with me, if he would permit it." "But he won't allow it," said Densher. "Won't hear of it on any terms.

Translation

"Are you saying you were running from me?" "No; I spoke to him about you, told him—or at least suggested—that I'd take you with me, if he'd let me." "But he won't," said Densher. "Won't even consider it."

He won't help me, won't save me, won't hold out a finger to me," Kate went on; "he simply wriggles away, in his inimitable manner, and throws me back." "Back then, after all, thank goodness," Densher concurred, "on me." But she spoke again as with the sole vision of the whole scene she had evoked. "It's a pity, because you'd like him.

Translation

He won't help me, won't save me, won't lift a finger for me," Kate continued. "He just squirms away, in that way he has, and abandons me." "Back, then, thank God," Densher agreed, "to me." But she spoke again as if the whole scene she had described was all she could see. "It's a shame, because you'd like him."

He's wonderful—he's charming." Her companion gave one of the laughs that marked in him, again, his feeling in her tone, inveterately, something that banished the talk of other women, so far as he knew other women, to the dull desert of the conventional, and she had already continued. "He would make himself delightful to you." "But he won't allow it," Densher said. "He won't even consider it, no matter what," Kate continued.

Translation

"He's wonderful—he's charming."

Her companion gave one of the laughs that revealed, once again, his reaction to her tone. He always felt this way, as if the things other women said, if he even knew any other women, were relegated to the boring wasteland of the mundane. And she had already continued: "He would make himself delightful to you."

"But he won't allow it," Densher said.

"He won't even consider it, no matter what," Kate continued.

"He won't help me, he won't save me, he won't lift a finger," Kate went on. "He simply evades the issue, in his own unique way, and rejects me." "So, after all, thank goodness," Densher agreed, "I get you." But she spoke again as if the whole scene she had described was all she could see.

Translation

"He won't help me, he won't save me, he won't do anything," Kate continued. "He just avoids it all, in his own special way, and dismisses me." "So, in the end, thank God," Densher agreed, "I get you." But she spoke again as if the entire scene she'd described was all she could see.

"It's a shame, because you'd like him. He's amazing—he's charming." Her companion laughed in a way that always indicated his feelings about her tone. It always banished the subject of other women, as far as he knew other women, to the boring wasteland of the mundane, and she had already continued.

Translation

"That's the pity of it, because you would really warm to him. He's incredible—he's got that undeniable charm." Her friend's laughter revealed what he thought of the way she was speaking. It reliably pushed the topic of other women, or as far as he understood other women, into that dull, everyday place, and she'd already started on.

"He would make himself delightful to you." "Even while objecting to me?" "Well, he likes to please," the girl explained—"personally. He would appreciate you and be clever with you.

Translation

"He'd charm you." "Even though he's criticizing me?" "He just wants to make people happy," the girl said, "in private. He'd find you interesting and be witty around you."

It's to me he objects—that is as to my liking you." "Heaven be praised then," Densher exclaimed, "that you like me enough for the objection!" But she met it after an instant with some inconsequence. "I don't.

Translation

"He's the one with the problem—that is, the fact that I like you." "Thank God," Densher exclaimed, "that you like me enough for him to object!" But she responded, a beat later, with a non sequitur. "I don't."

I offered to give you up, if necessary, to go to him. But it made no difference, and that's what I mean," she pursued, "by his declining me on any terms. The point is, you see, that I don't escape." Densher wondered.

Translation

I offered to give you up, if necessary, to go to him. But it didn't change anything, and that's what I mean when I say he turned me down completely. The point is, you see, that I can't get away. Densher was puzzled.

"But if you didn't wish to escape me?" "I wished to escape Aunt Maud. But he insists that it's through her and through her only that I may help him; just as Marian insists that it's through her, and through her only, that I can help her. That's what I mean," she again explained, "by their turning me back."

Translation

"But if you didn't want to leave me?" "I wanted to get away from Aunt Maud. But he insists that I can only help him through her; just like Marian insists that I can only help her through her. That's what I mean," she explained again, "when I say they turned me back."

"Even while disliking me?" "Well, he enjoys being agreeable," the girl said, "in person. He would find you charming and know how to be witty with you. It's me he dislikes—specifically, me liking you."

Translation

"Even if he didn't like me?" "Well, he likes to be pleasant," the girl said, "when you're right there with him. He'd find you charming and know how to make you laugh. It's me he doesn't like—specifically, that I like you."

"Thank goodness then," Densher exclaimed, "that you like me enough for him to disapprove!" But she responded after a moment with something irrelevant. "I don't. I offered to give you up, if I had to, and go to him.

Translation

"Thank God," Densher exclaimed, "that you like me enough to make him disapprove!" But she answered after a moment with something that didn't relate. "I don't. I offered to give you up, if I had to, and go to him."

But it made no difference, and that's what I mean," she continued, "by his rejecting me no matter what. The point is, you see, that I can't leave." Densher was puzzled. "But if you didn't want to leave me?"

Translation

"It didn't change anything, and that's the whole point," she said. "He'd refuse me no matter what I did. The fact is, I can't go." Densher was confused. "But if you didn't want to leave me?"

"I wanted to escape Aunt Maud. But he insists that it's only through her that I can help him; just as Marian insists that it's only through her that I can help her. That's what I mean," she explained again, "by their refusing to let me go." The young man thought.

Translation

"I wanted to get away from Aunt Maud. But he insists that I can only help him through her; just as Marian insists that I can only help her through her. That's what I mean," she explained again, "by their not letting me go." The young man thought.

"Your sister turns you back too?" "Oh, with a push!" "But have you offered to live with your sister?" "I would in a moment if she'd have me.

Translation

"So, your sister is holding you back, too?"

"Oh, with a shove!"

"But have you offered to live with your sister?"

"I'd do it in a heartbeat if she'd let me."

That's all my virtue—a narrow little family feeling. I've a small stupid piety—I don't know what to call it." Kate bravely sustained it; she made it out. "Sometimes, alone, I've to smother my shrieks when I think of my poor mother. She went through things—they pulled her down; I know what they were now—I didn't then, for I was a pig; and my position, compared with hers, is an insolence of success.

Translation

That's the extent of my virtue—a small, limited sense of family. I possess a simple, foolish devotion—I don't know what else to call it." Kate bravely endured her feelings; she forced them out. "Sometimes, when I'm alone, I have to stifle my screams when I think of my poor mother. She endured hardships—they wore her down; I understand what they were now—I didn't then, because I was a thoughtless fool; and my situation, compared to hers, is an act of insulting triumph.

That's what Marian keeps before me; that's what papa himself, as I say, so inimitably does. My position's a value, a great value, for them both"—she followed and followed. Lucid and ironic, she knew no merciful muddle. "It's the value—the only one they have."

Translation

That's what Marian reminds me of, and it's what Papa does so well, as I said, in a way that's impossible to imitate. My position has value, a great deal of value, for both of them," she continued, pushing forward. Clear-sighted and ironic, she didn't allow for any kind of comforting confusion. "It's the value, the only one they have."

The young man considered. "So your sister also rejects you?" "Oh, with a forceful shove!" "But have you proposed living with your sister?"

Translation

The young man thought for a moment. "So, your sister rejects you, too?" "Oh, with a resounding push!" "But have you suggested living with your sister?"

"I would accept in an instant if she'd allow it. That's my defining characteristic—a limited, almost provincial sense of familial duty. I have a small, foolish devotion—I'm not sure what to call it." Kate persevered courageously; she understood her motivations. "At times, alone, I have to stifle my screams when I remember my poor mother.

Translation

"I'd move in with her in a heartbeat if she'd let me. That's really the core of who I am—a narrow, almost small-town understanding of what family means. I have this little, silly loyalty—I don't know what else to call it." Kate kept going, even though it was hard; she knew why she felt this way. "Sometimes, when I'm by myself, I have to bite back the urge to scream when I think about my poor mother."

She endured terrible things—they ruined her; I understand what they were now—I didn't then, because I was ignorant; and my situation, compared to hers, is an insulting example of good fortune. That's what Marian reminds me of constantly; that's what Papa himself, as I've mentioned, does so flawlessly. My position is valuable, greatly valuable, to them both"—she continued to elaborate. Clear-sighted and sarcastic, she did not allow herself any comforting confusion.

Translation

She suffered through awful things—they destroyed her. I know what they were now. I didn't back then, because I was clueless. And my circumstances, compared to hers, are an insulting display of luck. That's what Marian is always reminding me; that's what Papa, as I said before, does so perfectly. My place is precious, extremely precious, to them both—she went on, elaborating. Sharp and cutting, she allowed herself no misleading sentimentality.
