"It's the value—the only one they possess." Everything between our young couple moved today, in spite of their pauses, their margin, to a quicker measure—the quickness and anxiety playing lightning-like in the sultriness. Densher watched, decidedly, as he had never done before. "And the fact you speak of holds you!"

Translation

"It's their value—the only thing they have." Everything between our young couple quickened today, despite their pauses and hesitations. The quickness and anxiety played like lightning in the sultriness. Densher watched, intensely, as he never had before. "And the fact you speak of holds you!"

"Of course, it holds me. It's a perpetual sound in my ears. It makes me ask myself if I've any right to personal happiness, any right to anything but to be as rich and overflowing, as smart and shining, as I can be made." Densher had a pause.

Translation

"Of course, it holds me. It's a constant sound in my ears. It makes me wonder if I even have a right to personal happiness, if I have a right to anything other than to be as rich and overflowing, as clever and dazzling, as I can possibly become." Densher paused.

"Oh, you might, with good luck, have the personal happiness too." Her immediate answer to this was a silence like his own; after which she gave him straight in the face, but quite simply and quietly: "Darling!" Despite their hesitations and the space they allowed themselves, everything between our young couple advanced at a quicker pace today—a sense of speed and worry crackling like electricity in the heavy air. Densher observed them closely, as he'd never done before.

Translation

"Oh, with a bit of luck, you might get personal happiness as well." Her immediate response was silence, mirroring his; then she said to him directly, but simply and quietly, "Darling!" Despite their hesitations and the space they allowed themselves, everything between our young couple progressed at a quicker pace today—a sense of speed and worry crackling like electricity in the heavy air. Densher observed them closely, as he'd never done before.

"And the thing you mentioned still affects you!" "Of course, it does. It's constantly on my mind. It makes me question whether I deserve personal happiness, whether I have any right to anything other than being as wealthy and generous, as clever and impressive, as I can possibly become."

Translation

"And that thing you mentioned still bothers you!" "Of course, it does. It's always in my thoughts. It makes me wonder if I deserve to be happy, if I'm entitled to anything beyond being as rich and generous, as smart and impressive, as I can possibly manage."

Densher hesitated. "Well, with a bit of luck, you might have personal happiness as well." Her immediate response was a silence like his own; after which, she looked directly at him, but in a simple and quiet way: "Darling!" It took him another moment; then he was also quiet and simple.

Translation

Densher paused. "Well, with a bit of luck, you might find personal happiness too." Her immediate response was a silence mirroring his own; after which, she looked directly at him, but with a simple, quiet demeanor: "Darling!" It took him another moment; then he was also quiet and simple.

"Will you settle it by our being married to-morrow—as we can, with perfect ease, civilly?" "Let us wait to arrange it," Kate presently replied, "till after you've seen her." "Do you call that adoring me?" Densher demanded. They were talking, for the time, with the strangest mixture of deliberation and directness, and nothing could have been more in the tone of it than the way she at last said: "You're afraid of her yourself."

Translation

"Will you solve this by marrying me tomorrow—which we can do, easily, legally?" "Let's postpone making that decision," Kate replied after a moment, "until after you've seen her." "Do you call that loving me?" Densher asked. For the time being, they spoke with a peculiar blend of calculation and candor, and nothing could have been more perfect than the way she finally said, "You're afraid of her yourself."

He gave a smile a trifle glassy. "For young persons of a great distinction and a very high spirit, we're a caution!" "Yes," she took it straight up; "we're hideously intelligent. But there's fun in it too.

Translation

His smile was a little strained. "For young people who are exceptionally distinguished and very spirited, we're a warning!" "Yes," she agreed immediately; "we're horribly intelligent. But there's also fun in it."

We must get our fun where we can. I think," she added, and for that matter, not without courage, "our relation's beautiful. It's not a bit vulgar. I cling to some saving romance in things."

Translation

We must find our fun where we can. I think," she added, and not without a certain bravery, "our relationship is beautiful. It isn't the least bit crass. I hold onto some saving romance in things.

He needed another moment, then he was also calm and straightforward. "Will you resolve this by us getting married tomorrow—which we can do, without any problem, legally?" "Let's wait to decide," Kate responded after a moment, "until after you've seen her." "Do you think that means you love me?" Densher asked.

Translation

He needed a moment to collect himself, and then he, too, was composed and direct. “Will you resolve this by us getting married tomorrow—which we can do, legally, without any issue?”

“Let’s hold off on deciding,” Kate replied after a pause, “until after you’ve seen her.”

“Do you think that means you love me?” Densher asked.

For the moment, they were speaking with a bizarre combination of thoughtful consideration and frankness, and her next words were perfectly in keeping with that: "You're afraid of her yourself." He forced a somewhat strained smile. "For people who are both very refined and exceptionally spirited, we're a disaster!" "Yes," she agreed immediately, "we're terribly clever.

Translation

At the moment, their conversation was an odd mixture of careful thought and bluntness, and her next words fit right in: "You're afraid of her, too." He managed a somewhat strained smile. "For people who are both very refined and exceptionally spirited, we're a disaster!" "Yes," she agreed at once, "we're terribly clever."

But there's also something enjoyable about it. We have to find our enjoyment where we can. I think," she added, and in a way that took some courage, "our relationship is beautiful. It isn't at all crass.

Translation

But there's also a certain pleasure in it. We have to seek out our pleasures when we can. I think," she added, with a touch of bravery, "that our relationship is lovely. It's not at all vulgar.

I hold onto the romantic aspects of things." It made him break into a laugh which had more freedom than his smile. "How you must be afraid you'll chuck me!" "No, no, that would be vulgar.

Translation

"I cling to the romantic side of life." This prompted a laugh from him, more unrestrained than his smile. "You must be terrified you'll get rid of me!" "No, no, that would be vulgar."

But, of course, I do see my danger," she admitted, "of doing something base." "Then what can be so base as sacrificing me?" "I shan't sacrifice you; don't cry out till you're hurt. I shall sacrifice nobody and nothing, and that's just my situation, that I want and that I shall try for everything.

Translation

"But, of course, I recognize my risk," she conceded, "of acting despicably." "Then what could be more despicable than sacrificing me?" "I won't sacrifice you; don't complain until you're harmed. I won't sacrifice anyone or anything, and that's precisely my predicament, what I desire, and what I will strive for, everything."

That," she wound up, "is how I see myself, and how I see you quite as much, acting for them." "For 'them'?" and the young man strongly, extravagantly marked his coldness. "Thank you!" "Don't you care for them?"

Translation

"That," she finished, "is how I see myself, and how I see you, as well, acting on their behalf." "On 'their' behalf?" and the young man strongly, extravagantly emphasized his lack of warmth. "Thank you!" "Don't you care about them?"

He burst out laughing, a sound freer than his smile. "You must be terrified you'll get rid of me!" "No, no, that would be crude. But, of course, I recognize the risk," she conceded, "of behaving badly."

Translation

He laughed, the sound more unrestrained than his smile. "You must be terrified you'll lose me!" "No, no, that would be uncouth. But of course, I acknowledge the peril," she admitted, "of misbehaving."

"Then what could be more reprehensible than abandoning me?" "I won't abandon you; don't complain until you're actually hurt. I'll sacrifice no one and nothing, and that's precisely the position I desire and will strive for—everything. That," she concluded, "is how I perceive myself, and how I see you as well, acting on their behalf."

Translation

"So, what could be worse than leaving me?" "I won't leave you. Don't start complaining until something actually happens. I won't sacrifice anyone or anything, and that's exactly the situation I want and will fight for—everything. That," she said finally, "is how I see myself, and how I see you, as well, acting in their interest."

"On *their* behalf?" the young man responded, his coldness sharply and emphatically evident. "Thank you!" "Don't you care about them?" "Why should I?

Translation

"On *their* behalf?" the young man responded, his coldness sharply and emphatically evident. "Thank you!" "Don't you care about them?" "Why should I?

What are they to me but a serious nuisance?" As soon as he had permitted himself this qualification of the unfortunate persons she so perversely cherished, he repented of his roughness—and partly because he expected a flash from her. But it was one of her finest sides that she sometimes flashed with a mere mild glow. "I don't see why you don't make out a little more that if we avoid stupidity we may do all.

Translation

"What are they to me but a serious nuisance?" As soon as he allowed himself this description of the unfortunate people she so stubbornly cared for, he regretted his harshness—and partly because he anticipated an outburst from her. But one of her best qualities was that she sometimes responded with only a gentle warmth. "I don't see why you don't realize more that if we avoid foolishness we can do anything."

We may keep her." He stared. "Make her pension us?" "Well, wait at least till we have seen."

Translation

"We can keep her." He was taken aback. "Make her support us?" "Well, let's at least wait and see."

He thought. "Seen what can be got out of her?" Kate for a moment said nothing. "After all I never asked her; never, when our troubles were at the worst, appealed to her nor went near her.

Translation

He considered. "Seen what we can get out of her?" Kate was silent for a moment. "After all, I never asked her. Never, when our troubles were at their worst, did I appeal to her or go near her."

She fixed upon me herself, settled on me with her wonderful gilded claws." "Why should I? They're nothing but a major pain." As soon as he allowed himself to speak so harshly about the people she was so stubbornly fond of, he regretted his bluntness—partly because he anticipated an angry reaction from her.

Translation

She turned her focus to me, locked onto me with those incredible, golden claws. "Why would I? They're nothing but a colossal headache." The moment he allowed himself to speak so harshly about the people she adored so stubbornly, he regretted his frankness—in part because he expected she'd be angry.

But one of her best qualities was that she sometimes responded with only a gentle warmth. "I don't understand why you don't consider the possibility that if we're smart about this, we can achieve everything. We can keep her." He was stunned.

Translation

But one of her best qualities was that she sometimes responded with only a gentle warmth. "I don't understand why you don't consider the possibility that if we're smart about this, we can achieve everything. We can keep her." He was stunned.

"Make her support us?" "Well, let's at least wait until we've seen what happens." He paused to think. "Seen what we can get from her?"

Translation

"Make her support us?" "Well, let's at least wait until we've seen what happens." He paused to think. "Seen what we can get from her?"

Kate said nothing for a moment. "I never actually asked her for anything; never, even when we were in the worst trouble, did I appeal to her or even go near her. She chose me herself, attached herself to me with her amazing, alluring power." "You speak," Densher observed, "as if she were a vulture."

Translation

Kate remained silent for a beat. "I never actually asked her for anything. Not once, even when we were in the direst straits, did I appeal to her or even go near her. She chose me herself, attached herself to me with her amazing, alluring power." "You speak," Densher observed, "as if she were a vulture."

"Call it an eagle—with a gilded beak as well, and with wings for great flights. If she's a thing of the air, in short—say at once a balloon—I never myself got into her car. I was her choice." It had really, her sketch of the affair, a high colour and a great style; at all of which he gazed a minute as at a picture by a master.

Translation

"Call her an eagle—with a gilded beak, and

wings for grand flights. If she's an aerial

creature, in short—say a hot air balloon—I never

myself climbed aboard. I was her choice." Her rendering

of the situation truly possessed a vibrancy, a bold flair;

he contemplated it for a moment, as though it were a masterpiece.

"What she must see in you!" "Wonders!" And, speaking it loud, she stood straight up. "Everything. There it is."

Translation

"What does she possibly see in you?" "Marvels!" And, with a loud declaration, she stood tall. "Everything. That's it."

Yes, there it was, and as she remained before him he continued to face it. "So that what you mean is that I'm to do my part in somehow squaring her?" "You're talking," Densher noted, "as if she were a vulture." "Think of it as an eagle—with a gold beak, too, and capable of soaring to great heights.

Translation

Yes, it was there, and as she stood before him, he kept facing it. "So what you're saying is that I'm supposed to play my role in, somehow, straightening her out?" "You're talking," Densher observed, "as if she were a vulture." "Consider it an eagle—with a golden beak, too, and capable of soaring to great heights."

If she's a creature of the sky, a balloon, to be blunt—I never got inside her basket, so to speak. I was her choice." Her description of the situation had a vividness and style; he stared at it for a moment as if it were a painting by a master artist. "What must she see in you!"

Translation

"If she's a creature of the sky, a balloon, to be blunt—I never got inside her basket, so to speak. I was her choice." Her description of the situation was so vivid and stylish; he stared at it for a moment, as though it were a painting by a master artist. "What must she see in you!"

"Miracles!" And, saying it out loud, she stood up straight. "Everything. That's the truth of it." Yes, the truth was plain, and as she stood before him, he kept looking at it.

Translation

"Miracles!" she declared aloud, then straightened. "Everything. The whole truth." It was a simple truth, and he continued to gaze at it as she stood before him.

"So you're saying I need to do something to make things right with her?" "See her, see her," Kate said with impatience. "And grovel to her?" "Ah, do what you like!" And she walked in her impatience away.

Translation

"So you're saying I need to fix things with her?" "See her, see her," Kate said impatiently. "And beg her forgiveness?" "Oh, whatever!" And she stormed off in her frustration.

Chapter 4

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

A man follows and then overtakes a woman, Kate. He decides to do as she wishes. He goes to Mrs. Lowder's house at her telegraphed request and waits for a long time in her drawing room, pacing back and forth.

When Mrs. Lowder appears, she tells him that she wants Kate to marry a great man and that he is not her choice. She says she will not banish him and will allow him to continue seeing Kate.

Later, the man tells Kate about his meeting with Mrs. Lowder. He also informs her that his newspaper has offered him a work assignment in America for fifteen to twenty weeks, which he feels he must accept. Kate encourages him to go. He then explains his foreign upbringing to her.

After this conversation, while in a garden, Kate pledges herself to him forever. They move to a more secluded spot, exchange vows and tokens, and become secretly engaged. They agree to keep their engagement private for the time being. They discuss the potential difficulty of Mrs. Lowder finding another suitor for Kate.

They talk about exchanging letters while he is away. Kate says she will post her own letters. He asks if he should send his to another address, but she tells him to send them to the house, saying she will be proud to have it known that he writes to her. She says that if her aunt asks about their relationship, she will say that she loves him. The man says that he believes Mrs. Lowder will not ask him directly, so he will not have to lie. Kate then tells him he does not understand her reasons for posting her own letters.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

This is an excellent excerpt, dense with the hallmarks of psychological realism, likely from a writer like Henry James. The prose is intricate, focusing less on external action and more on the internal machinations of its protagonist's mind. The analysis below will explore the text's major themes, character developments, and literary ideas.

### Literary Analysis

#### **Themes**

The text is built around a powerful collision of several major themes:

1. **Love vs. Social and Economic Power:** This is the central conflict. The protagonist, Merton Densher, and his love, Kate Croy, are bound by genuine affection, but their union is obstructed by a formidable external force: Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud). Her power is not just personal but institutional, rooted in wealth and social standing. Her "vast drawing-room" and "massive, florid furniture" are not mere backdrops; they are symbols of a world that operates on "morality and money, a good conscience and a big balance." Densher's only weapon in this house is that he loves Kate, an argument he himself knows is "painfully cheap" in such a context. The entire narrative is a strategic negotiation between the intangible asset of love and the very tangible power of wealth.

2. **The Nature of Deception and Strategy:** The characters are engaged in a sophisticated game of psychological warfare. Open conflict is avoided in favor of diplomacy, patience, and strategic maneuvering. Mrs. Lowder’s plan is a masterpiece of passive aggression: she doesn't banish Densher but gives him enough rope to hang himself, believing that "he may be safely left to kill his own cause." She bets that time and exposure to high society will erode Kate's affection for him. In response, Kate and Densher forge their own counter-strategy: a secret engagement. Their victory is not in defeating Mrs. Lowder, but in "gaining time" and preserving their bond in secret, turning her own weapon against her.

3. **Consciousness and Perception:** The narrative is deeply embedded in Densher's consciousness. We experience the world through his observations, interpretations, and anxieties. He is constantly "reading" the environment and the people within it. Mrs. Lowder’s house speaks a "language" to him, syllabifying her story through its "gregariously ugly" and "cruel" objects. He analyzes her facial expressions ("like a lighted window at night" that becomes a "drawn curtain" in silence) and deconstructs her motives with intellectual precision. This focus on interiority highlights how the central battles are fought not on a physical stage, but within the minds of the characters.

#### **Character Developments**

1. **Merton Densher:** Densher is presented as an intelligent, sensitive, but socially and economically marginal figure. He is acutely aware of his own inadequacy in Mrs. Lowder's world, describing his own position as a "desert of his poverty." Initially, he is prepared to be "abject," "ridiculous," and "unreasonable" to win Kate. His primary development in this passage is his shift from a position of reactive fear to one of proactive strategy. He begins by "wincing" at the thought of opposing Mrs. Lowder but ends by using his "fatal intelligence" to resist her. He becomes a co-conspirator with Kate, analyzing his opponent and helping to craft a plan. His foreign upbringing, initially a mark of his otherness and a point of criticism from Mrs. Lowder, is reframed by Kate as a source of his unique appeal, making him "complicated and brilliant."

2. **Kate Croy:** Though seen largely through Densher’s eyes, Kate emerges as a formidable and clear-sighted strategist. She is the "inspiration" for Densher's actions, but she is no passive prize. She understands her aunt’s psychology perfectly and orchestrates Densher's meeting with her. Her interpretation of the outcome is crucial: where Densher might see a conditional defeat, she sees a tactical victory ("we shall have gained time"). Her sudden, beautiful pledge—"I engage myself to you for ever"—is both a moment of profound emotional honesty and a brilliant strategic move, sealing their alliance just as Densher is set to depart. She demonstrates a capacity for managing appearances while remaining fiercely loyal to their private pact.

3. **Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud):** Mrs. Lowder is the central antagonist, an embodiment of the oppressive social order. She is characterized through potent metaphors: she is the "lioness in her cage," and her influence is like the unstoppable "car of Juggernaut." Yet, she is not a one-dimensional villain. Densher perceives her "colossal vulgarity" as having a "freshness, almost with beauty." Her power lies in her subtlety; she fights "with one hand," leaving her "weapons of defence... untouched." Her unexpected "good-nature" and her personal liking for Densher make her more complex and dangerous. She doesn't need to crush him; she believes she can simply out-wait and out-maneuver him, making his own perceived inadequacies do the work for her.

#### **Major Literary Ideas and Techniques**

1. **Psychological Realism:** The text is a prime example of psychological realism, where the character's internal life—their thoughts, feelings, and perceptions—is the primary subject. The long, complex sentences with multiple clauses mirror the intricate, unfolding process of human thought. The plot advances not through dramatic events, but through shifts in understanding and strategic realignments between the characters.

2. **Symbolism of Setting:** The description of Mrs. Lowder's house at Lancaster Gate is a masterclass in symbolism. The "prodigious extent" of the rooms reflects the scale of the challenge Densher faces. The furniture is "massive," "florid," "aggressively erect," and "splendidly" British. It represents a world of inherited wealth, rigid social codes, and a materialism that is a "portentous negation of his own world of thought." The house is not just a place; it is the physical manifestation of Mrs. Lowder's power and the values that threaten to crush Densher and Kate's love.

3. **Figurative Language:** The author uses vivid and powerful metaphors to convey abstract emotional and power dynamics: * **Kate’s injunction is "like the crack of a great whip,"** signifying its sharp, commanding authority. * **Densher is "in the cage of the lioness without his whip,"** perfectly capturing his feeling of powerlessness before Mrs. Lowder. * **Mrs. Lowder is a "car of Juggernaut,"** an image of immense, impersonal, and destructive force. * **Densher shaking his cleverness "as he sometimes shook his poor, dear, shabby, old watch, to start it up again"** is a poignant image of his intellectual resources, which feel old and inadequate but are all he has.

In conclusion, this text masterfully explores a complex social and psychological drama. Through its deep dive into the protagonist's consciousness, its rich symbolism, and its nuanced portrayal of a strategic battle for love against overwhelming social power, it creates a tense and intellectually stimulating narrative where the most significant action happens beneath the surface of polite conversation. The "victory" achieved by Densher and Kate is not a final one, but the establishment of a precarious secret alliance, setting the stage for a long and difficult campaign.

His eyes had followed her at this time quite long enough, before he overtook her, to make out more than ever, in the poise of her head, the pride of her step—he didn't know what best to call it—a part, at least, of Mrs. Lowder's reasons. He consciously winced while he figured his presenting himself as a reason opposed to these; though, at the same moment, with the source of Aunt Maud's inspiration thus before him, he was prepared to conform, by almost any abject attitude or profitable compromise, to his companion's easy injunction. He would do as she liked—his own liking might come off as it would.

Translation

His eyes had followed her for quite a while before he caught up to her, long enough to fully appreciate, in the way she held her head and the confidence in her stride – he wasn’t sure how to describe it – some of Mrs. Lowder’s motivations. He inwardly recoiled at the thought of himself as a reason to oppose them. Even so, with the origin of Aunt Maud’s influence right in front of him, he was ready to comply, through almost any humiliating pose or advantageous concession, with his companion's simple command. He would do as she wished; his own desires could take their chances.

He would help her to the utmost of his power; for, all the rest of that day and the next, her easy injunction, tossed off that way as she turned her beautiful back, was like the crack of a great whip in the blue air, the high element in which Mrs. Lowder hung. He wouldn't grovel perhaps—he wasn't quite ready for that; but he would be patient, ridiculous, reasonable, unreasonable, and above all deeply diplomatic. He would be clever, with all his cleverness—which he now shook hard, as he sometimes shook his poor, dear, shabby, old watch, to start it up again.

Translation

He would assist her to the fullest extent of his ability. For the rest of that day and the following one, her casual instruction, delivered as she turned away, was like a whip cracking in the clear air, the lofty sphere where Mrs. Lowder resided. He wouldn't debase himself, not yet; he wasn't quite there. But he would be patient, absurd, logical, illogical, and above all, deeply diplomatic. He would utilize his intellect, which he now summoned, much as he occasionally shook his worn, beloved old watch to get it working again.

It wasn't, thank goodness, as if there weren't plenty of that, and with what they could muster between them it would be little to the credit of their star, however pale, that defeat and surrender—surrender so early, so immediate—should have to ensue. It was not indeed that he thought of that disaster as, at the worst, a direct sacrifice of their possibilities: he imaged—it which was enough as some proved vanity, some exposed fatuity, in the idea of bringing Mrs. Lowder round. When, shortly afterwards, in this lady's vast drawing-room—the apartments at Lancaster Gate had struck him from the first as of prodigious extent—he awaited her, at her request, conveyed in a "reply-paid" telegram, his theory was that of their still clinging to their idea, though with a sense of the difficulty of it really enlarged to the scale of the place.

Translation

Thankfully, it wasn’t as if they lacked resources, and considering their combined capabilities, their reputations, however faint, would suffer if they were forced to concede so early and completely. He didn't see it as a direct sacrifice of their goals, at worst. He imagined—and this was enough—a certain vanity, a certain foolishness in the thought of convincing Mrs. Lowder. When, soon after, he waited for her in her immense drawing-room—the rooms in Lancaster Gate had seemed enormous from the start—at her request, conveyed via a "reply-paid" telegram, his assumption was that they were still clinging to their plan, though they now grasped the challenge with a sense of it truly enlarged to the scale of the place.

"See her, see her," Kate said impatiently. "And debase myself for her?" "Do whatever you want!" And she walked away in her frustration. IV

Translation

"Go see her, just go see her," Kate said impatiently. "And humiliate myself for her?" "Do whatever you want!" And with that, she walked away, utterly frustrated. IV

He watched her long enough before catching up to her, noticing even more than before the way she held her head, the confident way she walked – he wasn’t sure what to call it. It gave him an understanding of at least some of Mrs. Lowder’s motivations. He consciously cringed at the idea of presenting himself as a counter-argument to these motivations.

Translation

He observed her for a while before catching up, taking in the way she carried herself, the assured way she moved—he couldn't quite put his finger on it. It provided him insight into at least some of Mrs. Lowder’s reasoning. He visibly recoiled at the prospect of attempting to challenge that reasoning.

Even as he stood there, with Aunt Maud’s inspiration right in front of him, he was ready to comply with his companion's simple instructions. He would do as she liked, regardless of his own preferences. He would assist her as much as he could; because her easy command, tossed out as she turned away, was like the crack of a whip in the air. He wasn't quite ready to debase himself, but he would be patient, ridiculous, reasonable, unreasonable, and above all, deeply strategic.

Translation

Even with Aunt Maud's influence right there, he was ready to do what his companion asked. He'd do what she wanted, no matter what he preferred. He would help her as much as possible, because her casual order, issued as she walked away, had the force of a whip. He wasn't ready to humiliate himself, but he would be patient, absurd, logical, illogical, and, above all, calculating.

He would use all his intelligence, which he now focused intensely, like shaking an old watch to get it working again. Thankfully, they had plenty of it. With what they could gather between them, it would be a disgrace to their cause, however weak, if they had to surrender so early. It wasn't that he viewed that defeat as a direct loss of their goals.

Translation

He would deploy all his wits, concentrating with a newfound intensity, as if jumpstarting a dormant machine. Fortunately, they had an abundance of intellect to draw upon. Considering their combined resources, it would be a shameful blow to their cause, however fragile, to concede so soon. It wasn't that he saw defeat as a direct negation of their ambitions.

Instead, he saw it as an exposed vanity, an example of foolishness, in the idea of persuading Mrs. Lowder. When, shortly after, in her enormous drawing-room – the Lancaster Gate apartments had always seemed vast to him – he waited for her, as she had requested in a "reply-paid" telegram, his assumption was that they were still clinging to their idea, though the challenge of it had truly expanded to match the scale of the place. He had the place for a long time—it seemed to him a quarter of an hour—to himself; and while Aunt Maud kept him and kept him, while observation and reflection crowded on him, he asked himself what was to be expected of a person who could treat one like that.

Translation

He didn't see defeat as a setback to their goals, but as a demonstration of vanity, a showcase of their foolishness in trying to win over Mrs. Lowder. Shortly after, he was kept waiting in her immense drawing-room—the Lancaster Gate apartments had always seemed cavernous to him—as she'd requested in a "reply-paid" telegram. He assumed they were still pursuing their idea, though the difficulty of it had grown to match the scale of the surroundings. He had the room to himself for a long time—it seemed like a quarter of an hour—and while Aunt Maud kept him waiting, while observations and reflections flooded his mind, he wondered what could be expected of someone who treated people so dismissively.

The visit, the hour were of her own proposing, so that her delay, no doubt, was but part of a general plan of putting him to inconvenience. As he walked to and fro, however, taking in the message of her massive, florid furniture, the immense expression of her signs and symbols, he had as little doubt of the inconvenience he was prepared to suffer. He found himself even facing the thought that he had nothing to fall back on, and that that was as great a humiliation in a good cause as a proud man could desire. It had not yet been so distinct to him that he made no show—literally not the smallest; so complete a show seemed made there all about him; so almost abnormally affirmative, so aggressively erect, were the huge, heavy objects that syllabled his hostess story.

Translation

The visit, the arranged time, it was all her idea. So her tardiness was undoubtedly part of a larger plan to make things difficult for him. As he paced, taking in the statement made by the large, ornate furniture, the vast message of her signs and symbols, he had little doubt of the suffering he was prepared to endure. He even confronted the idea that he had nothing to fall back on, and that this was as great a humiliation in a worthy cause as a proud man could hope for. It hadn't yet been so clear to him that he made no impression at all—literally none. Such a complete spectacle seemed to exist all around him. The huge, heavy objects that told the story of his hostess were almost abnormally assertive, aggressively upright.

"When all's said and done, you know, she's colossally vulgar"—he had once all but said that of Mrs. Lowder to her niece; only just keeping it back at the last, keeping it to himself with all its danger about it. It mattered because it bore so directly, and he at all events quite felt it a thing that Kate herself would some day bring out to him. It bore directly at present, and really all the more that somehow, strangely, it didn't in the least imply that Aunt Maud was dull or stale.

Translation

"At the end of the day, you know, she's incredibly vulgar"—he'd practically said that about Mrs. Lowder to her niece once. He'd barely stopped himself, holding it back, knowing the risks involved. It mattered because it was so relevant, and he felt certain that Kate would eventually tell him. It was especially relevant right now, and oddly, strangely, it didn't imply that Aunt Maud was boring or uninteresting.

She was vulgar with freshness, almost with beauty, since there was beauty, to a degree, in the play of so big and bold a temperament. She was in fine quite the largest possible quantity to deal with; and he was in the cage of the lioness without his whip—the whip, in a word, of a supply of proper retorts. He had no retort but that he loved the girl—which in such a house as that was painfully cheap. Kate had mentioned to him more than once that her aunt was Passionate, speaking of it as a kind of offset and uttering it as with a capital P, marking it as something that he might, that he in fact ought to, turn about in some way to their advantage.

Translation

She was vulgar in a way that was new, almost beautiful, because there was a certain beauty in the display of such a large and daring personality. She was, in short, a huge amount to handle; and he was in the lioness's den without his whip—the whip, that is, of a supply of witty replies. He had no reply except that he loved the girl—which in a house like that was painfully cliché. Kate had mentioned to him more than once that her aunt was Passionate, describing it as a kind of counterweight and saying it with a capital P, emphasizing it as something that he could, that he should in fact, turn to their advantage.

He wondered at this hour to what advantage he could turn it; but the case grew less simple the longer he waited. Decidedly there was something he hadn't enough of. He stood as one fast. He was alone in the room for a long time—or so it felt; perhaps only fifteen minutes—and while his Aunt Maud kept him waiting, observation and contemplation filled his mind.

Translation

He wondered what advantage he could take of it at this moment, but the situation became less clear the longer he waited. There was definitely something he lacked. He was stuck. He was alone in the room for a long time—or so it seemed; maybe only fifteen minutes—and while his Aunt Maud kept him waiting, observation and contemplation filled his mind.

He wondered what he could expect from someone who treated him this way. She had requested this meeting, this visit, and her lateness was undoubtedly part of a plan to inconvenience him. As he paced back and forth, absorbing the atmosphere of her grand, ornate furniture, the overwhelming message of her possessions, he realized he was prepared to endure the inconvenience. He even faced the possibility that he had no other option, and that such a situation was the ultimate humiliation for a man of pride who was fighting for something important.

Translation

He considered what to anticipate from a person who treated him so dismissively. She’d asked for this meeting, this visit, and her tardiness was no doubt a calculated tactic to put him out. As he walked back and forth, taking in the room, the lavish, elaborate furniture, the loud statement of her wealth, he understood he was willing to put up with the annoyance. He even admitted the possibility that he had no choice, that this situation was the final indignity for a man of principle, fighting for something significant.

He was acutely aware that he was putting on no pretense—not even the slightest one—while the room itself made a grand display. The massive, imposing objects seemed to speak his hostess's story, so confidently, so aggressively. "When all is said and done, she's incredibly vulgar"—he had almost said that about Mrs. Lowder to her niece, but held back at the last moment, keeping the thought to himself, aware of the potential danger.

Translation

He knew he wasn't feigning anything, not even a little, even as the room itself put on a show. The huge, overbearing items seemed to tell his hostess's story, so assuredly, so boldly. "In the end, she's incredibly vulgar"—he'd almost said that about Mrs. Lowder to her niece, but stopped himself at the last second, keeping the thought private, conscious of the risk.

It mattered because it was so relevant, and he felt certain that Kate would eventually bring this up to him. It was especially pertinent now, because, strangely, it didn't imply that Aunt Maud was boring or predictable. Her vulgarity was fresh, almost beautiful, because there was a certain beauty in such a large and bold personality. She was, in short, a huge presence to contend with, and he felt like he was in the lioness's den without a way to defend himself—without a witty comeback.

Translation

It mattered because it was so relevant, and he was sure Kate would bring it up. It was especially pertinent now, because, oddly, it didn't mean Aunt Maud was boring or predictable. Her vulgarity was new, almost beautiful, because there was a certain beauty in such a large and bold personality. She was, in short, a huge presence to contend with, and he felt like he was in the lioness's den without a way to defend himself—without a witty comeback.

The only thing he had was his love for the girl, which felt inadequate in a house like this. Kate had told him more than once that her aunt was Passionate, pronouncing it with a capital "P," highlighting it as something that he could—and should—somehow use to their advantage. He wondered now how he could do that, but the longer he waited, the more complex the situation became. He definitely lacked something.

Translation

The only thing he had was his love for the girl, which felt insufficient in this setting. Kate had emphasized more than once that her aunt was Passionate, as in, with a capital "P," as if he should somehow leverage it to their benefit. He wondered how, and the longer he waited, the more convoluted the situation became. He was missing something crucial.

He was trapped. His slow march to and fro seemed to give him the very measure; as he paced and paced the distance it became the desert of his poverty; at the sight of which expanse moreover he could pretend to himself as little as before that the desert looked redeemable. Lancaster Gate looked rich—that was all the effect; which it was unthinkable that any state of his own should ever remotely resemble. He read more vividly, more critically, as has been hinted, the appearances about him; and they did nothing so much as make him wonder at his aesthetic reaction.

Translation

He was trapped. His monotonous pacing seemed to define his predicament; as he walked back and forth, the space transformed into the vast emptiness of his own destitution. Looking at this expanse, he could no longer pretend, as he had before, that the desert held any promise of salvation. Lancaster Gate appeared opulent—that was the sole impression it made; an impression which, in his current state, seemed utterly unattainable. As hinted at earlier, he observed and judged the world around him with greater intensity and scrutiny; yet, this only served to amplify his wonder at his own aesthetic sensibilities.

He hadn't known—and in spite of Kate's repeated reference to her own rebellions of taste—that he should "mind" so much how an independent lady might decorate her house. It was the language of the house itself that spoke to him, writing out for him, with surpassing breadth and freedom, the associations and conceptions, the ideals and possibilities of the mistress. Never, he flattered himself, had he seen anything so gregariously ugly—operatively, ominously so cruel. He was glad to have found this last name for the whole character; "cruel" somehow played into the subject for an article—that his impression put straight into his mind.

Translation

He hadn't realized—despite Kate's frequent mentions of her own defiant tastes—that he'd care so much about how a self-sufficient woman decorated her home. It was the house's inherent language that resonated with him, articulating, with remarkable scope and liberty, the associations, concepts, ideals, and potentials of its owner. He fancied he'd never seen anything so flagrantly ugly—functionally, menacingly, brutally so. He was pleased to have discovered that final term for the overall aesthetic; "cruel" somehow fit the article he was mentally composing.

He would write about the heavy horrors that could still flourish, that lifted their undiminished heads, in an age so proud of its short way with false gods; and it would be funny if what he should have got from Mrs. Lowder were to prove, after all, but a small amount of copy. Yet the great thing, really the dark thing, was that, even while he thought of the quick column he might add up, he felt it less easy to laugh at the heavy horrors than to quail before them. He couldn't describe and dismiss them collectively, call them either Mid-Victorian or Early; not being at all sure they were rangeable under one rubric.

Translation

He would write about the oppressive horrors that still thrived, that defiantly presented themselves, in an era so certain of its swift takedown of false idols; and it would be ironic if what he'd gleaned from Mrs. Lowder amounted to only a small piece for his article. And yet the significant thing, the unsettling thing, was that, even as he considered the snappy article he could put together, he found it less easy to laugh at these oppressive horrors than to feel fear in their presence. He couldn't describe and dismiss them as a whole, labeling them either Mid-Victorian or Early; he wasn't at all sure they could be categorized under a single heading.

It was only manifest they were splendid and were furthermore conclusively British. They constituted an order and they abounded in rare material—precious woods, metals, stuffs, stones. He had never dreamed of anything so fringed and scalloped, so buttoned and corded, drawn everywhere so tight, and curled everywhere so thick. He had never dreamed of so much gilt and glass, so much satin and plush, so much rosewood and marble and malachite.

Translation

It was clear they were magnificent, and unequivocally British. They represented a specific style, and they were filled with luxurious materials—precious woods, metals, fabrics, and stones. He had never imagined anything so fringed and scalloped, so buttoned and corded, so tautly drawn, and so thickly curled. He had never imagined so much gilding and glass, so much satin and plush, so much rosewood and marble and malachite.

But it was, above all, the solid forms, the wasted finish, the misguided cost, the general attestation of morality and money, a good conscience and a big balance. These things finally represented for him a portentous negation of his own world of thought—of which, for that matter, in the presence of them, he became as for the first time hopelessly aware. They revealed it to him by their merciless difference. His interview with Aunt Maud, none the less, took by no means the turn he had expected.

Translation

But it was, above all, the solid forms, the extravagant finishes, the misplaced expense, the overall declaration of morality and wealth, of a clear conscience and a large bank account. These things ultimately represented for him a significant rejection of his own way of thinking—of which, for that matter, in their presence, he became hopelessly aware for the first time. They revealed it to him through their relentless contrast. His meeting with Aunt Maud, nonetheless, did not go as he had anticipated.

Passionate though her nature, no doubt Mrs. Lowder, on this occasion, neither threatened nor appealed. Her arms of aggression, her weapons of defence, were presumably close at hand, but she left them untouched and unmentioned, and was in fact so bland that he properly perceived only afterwards how adroit she had been. He properly perceived something else as well, which complicated his case; he shouldn't have known what to call it if he hadn't called it her really imprudent good-nature.

Translation

Though passionate by nature, Mrs. Lowder, without a doubt, neither threatened nor pleaded on this occasion. Her instruments of aggression, her weapons of defense, were presumably close at hand, but she left them untouched and unmentioned, and was in fact so bland that he only properly perceived afterward how adroit she had been. He also properly perceived something else, which complicated his situation; he wouldn't have known what to call it if he hadn't called it her truly imprudent good nature.

Her blandness, in other words, was not mere policy—he wasn't dangerous enough for policy; it was the result, he could see, of her fairly liking him a little. From the moment she did that she herself became more interesting; and who knew what might happen should he take to liking her? Well, it was a risk he naturally must face. She fought him, at any rate, but with one hand, with a few loose grains of stray powder.

Translation

In other words, her affability wasn't just a strategy—he wasn't significant enough to warrant one. It stemmed, he realized, from the fact that she genuinely had some fondness for him. From the moment that was true, she became more intriguing; and who knew what might occur if he were to reciprocate her feelings? It was a risk he would inevitably have to take. At the very least, she was fighting him, albeit half-heartedly, using only a sprinkling of scattered ammunition.

He recognised at the end of ten minutes, and even without her explaining it, that if she had made him wait it had not been to wound him; they had by that time almost directly met on the fact of her intention. She had wanted him to think for himself of what she proposed to say to him—not having otherwise announced it; wanted to let it come home to him on the spot, as she had shrewdly believed it would. Her first question, on appearing, had practically been as to whether he hadn't taken her hint, and this inquiry assumed so many things that it made discussion, immediately, frank and large. He knew, with the question put, that the hint was just what he had taken; knew that she had made him quickly forgive her the display of her power; knew that if he didn't take care he should understand her, and the strength of her purpose, to say nothing of that of her imagination, nothing of the length of her purse, only too well.

Translation

He realized, after ten minutes, without her even having to explain, that the wait hadn’t been intended to hurt him. By then, they’d practically arrived at the same understanding of her intentions. She wanted him to figure out for himself what she was about to tell him, without her explicitly stating it. She wanted him to understand it in the moment, as she’d accurately predicted he would. Her first question, upon arriving, was essentially whether he’d understood her hint, and this question implied so much that it immediately opened up a straightforward and expansive conversation. He knew, with that question, that he had understood the hint exactly. He knew that she’d made him quickly forgive her display of power. He knew that if he wasn’t careful, he’d understand her, the strength of her purpose, not to mention the power of her imagination, and the depth of her resources, only too well.

Yet he pulled himself up with the thought, too, that he was not going to be afraid of understanding her; he was just going to understand and understand without detriment to the feeblest, even, of his passions. The play of one's mind let one in, at the best, dreadfully, in action, in the need of action, where simplicity was all; but when one couldn't prevent it the thing was to make it complete. There would never be mistakes but for the original fun of mistakes. What he must use his fatal intelligence for was to resist.

Translation

Yet he also steeled himself with the thought that he wouldn't be afraid of understanding her. He would simply understand, and keep understanding, without harming even his faintest passions. Overthinking could be terribly risky, particularly when it came to action and the need for simplicity. But since he couldn't stop it, he had to make the understanding complete. Mistakes wouldn't exist without the original allure of making them. What he had to use his dangerous intelligence for was resistance.

Mrs. Lowder, meanwhile, might use it for whatever she liked. His slow pacing gave him a sense of the situation. As he walked back and forth, the distance became like a barren wasteland representing his lack of money.

Translation

Meanwhile, Mrs. Lowder could do with it as she pleased. His deliberate steps helped him grasp the situation. The space he traversed, measured by his steps, became a desolate expanse, a symbol of his poverty.

Looking at this emptiness, he found it as impossible as before to believe that this desert could ever be transformed. Lancaster Gate looked wealthy—that was the only effect it had. It was impossible that his own circumstances would ever remotely resemble it. He observed his surroundings more closely and critically, as he had hinted he might.

Translation

He stared at the desolate landscape, still unable to believe it could change. Lancaster Gate appeared affluent, and that was all it signified. There was no way his own situation would ever come close. He examined his surroundings with a renewed focus and a critical eye, just as he'd suggested.

It made him question his aesthetic reactions. He hadn't realized—despite Kate's repeated references to her own taste rebellions—that he would care so much about how a wealthy woman might decorate her house. The house itself seemed to speak to him. It described, with great freedom, the mistress's values, ideas, and aspirations.

Translation

It made him question his aesthetic responses. He hadn't realized—despite Kate's repeated mentions of her own taste rebellions—that he would care so much about how a wealthy woman might decorate her house. The house itself seemed to speak to him. It described, with great freedom, the mistress's values, ideas, and aspirations.

He thought he'd never seen anything so overwhelmingly ugly, so clearly and cruelly designed. He was glad to have found that word for the overall impression. "Cruel" seemed relevant to an article he might write. This idea immediately came to mind.

Translation

He decided he'd never encountered anything so thoroughly ugly, so obviously and deliberately awful. He was pleased to have found the word for the general effect. "Cruel" seemed relevant to the article he was considering. The thought popped into his head immediately.

He would write about the heavy horrors that could still thrive, that proudly stood, in an era that prided itself on discarding false gods. It would be ironic if Mrs. Lowder provided him with only a small amount of material for his article. Yet, the major issue, the troubling one, was that even while considering the quick article he could create, he found it harder to laugh at the heavy horrors than to feel intimidated by them.

Translation

He would write about the oppressive terrors that persisted, that brazenly endured, in an age that celebrated the rejection of deceitful idols. It would be ironic if Mrs. Lowder provided him with only a paltry amount of material for his article. Still, the primary issue, the concerning one, was that even while contemplating the article he could quickly produce, he found it more difficult to mock the oppressive terrors than to feel intimidated by them.

He couldn't describe and dismiss them as a group, calling them either Mid-Victorian or Early; he wasn't sure they fit neatly into one category. It was obvious they were impressive and certainly British. They represented a way of life, and they were filled with luxurious materials—precious woods, metals, fabrics, and stones. He had never imagined so many fringes and scallops, buttons and cords, everything tightly drawn and thickly curled.

Translation

He couldn't simply label them and move on, calling them Mid-Victorian or Early Victorian. He wasn't convinced they could be so easily classified. Clearly, they were striking, undeniably British. They embodied a specific lifestyle and were constructed with lavish materials: fine woods, metals, textiles, and gems. He'd never conceived of so many fringes and scallops, buttons and cords, all meticulously arranged and elaborately ornamented.

He had never imagined so much gold and glass, satin and plush, rosewood, marble, and malachite. But, above all, it was the solid forms, the wasted effort, the misapplied expense, the general indication of morality and wealth, a clear conscience, and a large bank balance. These things ultimately represented a significant rejection of his own way of thinking, of which, in their presence, he became, for the first time, painfully aware. They revealed his world by their distinct differences.

Translation

He'd never envisioned such quantities of gold and glass, satin and plush, rosewood, marble, and malachite. However, it was, above all, the solidity of the forms, the wasted effort, the misapplied expenditure, the general display of morality and wealth, a clear conscience, and a substantial bank account. These elements fundamentally represented a rejection of his own perspective, which, in their presence, he became, for the first time, painfully aware of. They exposed his world through their stark contrasts.

His meeting with Aunt Maud did not go as he expected. Though passionate, Mrs. Lowder neither threatened nor pleaded. Her tools of aggression and defense were presumably close at hand, but she left them untouched and unmentioned.

Translation

His encounter with Aunt Maud diverged from his expectations. Despite her intensity, Mrs. Lowder issued no threats and offered no entreaties. Her customary means of attack and self-preservation were likely within reach, yet she neither employed them nor alluded to their existence.

She was, in fact, so pleasant that only later did he realize how skillfully she had acted. He also recognized something else that complicated his situation. He wouldn't have known what to call it if he hadn't called it her imprudent good nature. Her pleasantness wasn't just a strategy—he wasn't important enough for a strategy.

Translation

In retrospect, he understood how adroitly she'd played the scene. Something else, too, became clear, something that made his position all the more precarious. He could only define it as her imprudent amiability. Her niceness wasn't a calculated move—he wasn't significant enough to merit one.

It was the result, he could see, of her actually liking him a little. From that moment, she herself became more interesting; and who knew what might happen if he started to like her? Well, it was a risk he obviously had to face. She fought him, but with only one hand, a few scattered grains of powder.

Translation

He saw it now: the consequence of her genuinely feeling some affection for him. From that point on, she became more intriguing; and who knew what might occur if he reciprocated? It was a risk he'd clearly have to take. She resisted, though her efforts were feeble, a scattering of dust.

He realized within ten minutes, without her even explaining it, that she had made him wait not to hurt him. They had almost directly reached an agreement on her intentions. She wanted him to figure out for himself what she was going to say, without announcing it. She wanted him to understand it immediately, as she correctly believed he would.

Translation

He understood in under ten minutes, without her saying a word, that she'd kept him waiting out of consideration for him. They'd essentially reached an understanding about her intentions. She wanted him to deduce what she was going to say, without her having to spell it out. She wanted him to grasp it right away, correctly assuming he would.

Her first question, on seeing him, was whether he had understood her hint. This question assumed so much that the conversation became immediately open and broad. He knew that the hint was exactly what he had understood. He knew that she had made him quickly forgive her display of power.

Translation

Upon seeing him, her first question was whether he'd understood the hint. This question’s presumptuous nature opened the conversation immediately, allowing it to become wide-ranging. He knew that the hint was precisely what he’d understood. He knew that she’d quickly forced him to forgive her exercise of power.

He knew that if he wasn't careful, he would fully understand her, the strength of her purpose, her imagination, and her financial resources. However, he also realized he wouldn't be afraid to understand her. He was simply going to understand, without damaging even his weakest passions. Using one's mind often leads to problems when it comes to action, where simplicity is essential.

Translation

He knew that he risked a complete comprehension of her—the force driving her, her capacity for invention, and her wealth. Still, he understood that this wouldn't frighten him. He would simply understand, without jeopardizing even his most trivial inclinations. Employing the intellect frequently complicates action, where purity of purpose is paramount.

But, when you can't prevent it, the thing to do is to complete it. Mistakes would never happen without the original pleasure of making them. What he had to use his intelligence for was to resist. Mrs.

Translation

But, when you can't prevent it, the thing to do is to complete it. Mistakes would never happen without the original pleasure of making them. What he had to use his intelligence for was to resist. Mrs.

Lowder could use her intelligence for whatever she wanted. It was after she had begun her statement of her own idea about Kate that he began, on his side, to reflect that—with her manner of offering it as really sufficient if he would take the trouble to embrace—it she couldn't half hate him. That was all, positively, she seemed to show herself for the time as attempting; clearly, if she did her intention justice, she would have nothing more disagreeable to do. "If I hadn't been ready to go very much further, you understand, I wouldn't have gone so far.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder could use her intelligence however she pleased. It was after she'd begun to state her own idea about Kate that he, in turn, began to reflect that—with her way of presenting it as truly sufficient if he'd just take the trouble to accept—she couldn't possibly hate him enough. That was all, definitely, that she appeared to be trying to convey at the moment; clearly, if she were doing her intention justice, she'd have nothing more unpleasant to do. "If I hadn't been prepared to go much further, you understand, I wouldn't have gone this far."

I don't care what you repeat to her—the more you repeat to her, perhaps the better; and, at any rate, there's nothing she doesn't already know. I don't say it for her; I say it for you—when I want to reach my niece I know how to do it straight." So Aunt Maud delivered herself—as with homely benevolence, in the simplest, but the clearest terms; virtually conveying that, though a word to the wise was, doubtless, in spite of the advantage, not always enough, a word to the good could never fail to be. The sense our young man read into her words was that she liked him because he was good—was really, by her measure, good enough: good enough, that is, to give up her niece for her and go his way in peace. But was he good enough—by his own measure?

Translation

"I don't care what you tell her—the more, the better, perhaps. In any case, there's nothing she doesn't already know. I'm not saying this for her; I'm saying it for you. When I want to reach my niece, I know how to do it directly."

Aunt Maud spoke with a folksy kindness, using the simplest but clearest language. Essentially, she was saying that while a word to the wise might not always be enough, a word to the good was guaranteed to work. The young man understood her to mean that she liked him because he was good—good enough, in her estimation. Good enough, that is, to give up her niece for her and leave in peace. But was he good enough, according to his own standards?

He fairly wondered, while she more fully expressed herself, if it might be his doom to prove so. "She's the finest possible creature—of course you flatter yourself that you know it. But I know it, quite as well as you possibly can—by which I mean a good deal better yet; and the tune to which I'm ready to prove my faith compares favourably enough, I think, with anything you can do. I don't say it because she's my niece—that's nothing to me: I might have had fifty nieces, and I wouldn't have brought one of them to this place if I hadn't found her to my taste.

Translation

He was frankly unsure, as she continued to explain herself, if his fate would be to find out. "She's the best possible person—of course you think you already know that. But I know it, and I know it much better than you do; and the degree to which I'm prepared to prove my belief is, I think, much greater than anything you can do. I'm not saying this because she's my niece—that doesn't matter to me: I could have had fifty nieces, and I wouldn't have brought a single one of them here if I hadn't liked her."

I don't say I wouldn't have done something else, but I wouldn't have put up with her presence. Kate's presence, by good fortune, I marked early; Kate's presence—unluckily for you—is everything I could possibly wish; Kate's presence is, in short, as fine as you know, and I've been keeping it for the comfort of my declining years. I've watched it long; I've been saving it up and letting it, as you say of investments, appreciate, and you may judge whether, now it has begun to pay so, I'm likely to consent to treat for it with any but a high bidder. I can do the best with her, and I've my idea of the best."

Translation

I'm not saying I wouldn't have done something else, but I wouldn't have tolerated her being here. Kate's being here, luckily, I noticed early on; Kate's being here—unfortunately for you—is everything I could possibly want. Kate's being here is, in short, as wonderful as you realize, and I've been keeping it for the comfort of my old age. I've watched it for a long time; I've been saving it up and letting it, as you say about investments, appreciate in value, and you can imagine whether, now that it's starting to pay off, I'm likely to consider giving it up to anyone but the highest bidder. I know how to make the most of her, and I have my own idea of what that is.

After she'd started explaining her thoughts about Kate, he began to realize, as she presented her idea as if it were enough if he would just accept it, that she must really dislike him. That's all she seemed to be trying to convey at the moment. It was clear that, if she truly meant what she said, she wouldn't have to do anything more unpleasant. "If I hadn't been willing to go much further, you understand, I wouldn't have gone this far.

Translation

As she laid out her thoughts on Kate, and the way she presented her idea as though all he needed to do was accept it, he started to understand that she must genuinely hate him. That seemed to be the only thing she was trying to communicate. It was obvious that if she actually believed what she was saying, she wouldn't need to do anything else to make things unpleasant. "If I hadn't been willing to go much further, you understand, I wouldn't have gone this far."

I don't care what you tell her—the more you tell her, perhaps the better; and, anyway, she already knows everything. I'm not saying this for her; I'm saying it for you—when I want to reach my niece, I know how to do it directly." That's how Aunt Maud spoke, with a simple, almost motherly kindness, but in the clearest terms. She was essentially saying that, although a wise person doesn't always appreciate advice, a good person always will.

Translation

"It doesn't matter what you say to her—in fact, the more the better. She already knows everything anyway. I'm not saying this for her benefit. I'm telling you this because when I need to reach my niece, I know how to do it without going through you." Aunt Maud spoke with a straightforwardness that was almost gentle, but her words were perfectly clear. What she meant was that, while a clever person might not value guidance, a good person always would.

What the young man understood from her words was that she liked him because he was good—good enough, in her opinion: good enough, that is, to give up her niece for her and go away peacefully. But was he good enough, according to his own standards? He seriously wondered, as she spoke further, if he was destined to be that way. "She's the most wonderful person—of course you think you know that.

Translation

The young man took her meaning as an indication that she approved of him for his decency—that, in her estimation, he was decent enough to hand her niece over to him and then disappear quietly. But did he measure up to his own ideals? He began to question this as she continued, wondering if he was fated to be that kind of person. "She is the most remarkable individual—you no doubt already realize that."

But I know it just as well as you do—which means even better; and the faith I'm willing to demonstrate is comparable, I think, to anything you can offer. I'm not saying this because she's my niece—that means nothing to me. I could have had fifty nieces, and I wouldn't have brought a single one of them here if I hadn't found her appealing. I'm not saying I wouldn't have done something else, but I wouldn't have put up with her being here.

Translation

But I understand her just as well, if not better than you do, and the faith I'm willing to show is, I believe, as great as yours. I'm not saying this because she's my niece—that doesn't matter to me. I could have had fifty nieces, and I wouldn't have brought any of them here unless I found her to be interesting. I'm not saying I wouldn't have done something else, but I wouldn't have tolerated her being here.

Kate's presence, fortunately, I noticed early; Kate's presence—unfortunately for you—is everything I could possibly want; Kate's presence is, in short, as wonderful as you know, and I've been saving it for the comfort of my old age. I've watched her for a long time; I've been saving her and letting her, as you say about investments, appreciate in value, and you can imagine whether, now that it's starting to pay off, I'm likely to consider negotiating for it with anyone other than the highest bidder. I can do the best with her, and I know what the best is." "Oh, I quite conceive," said Densher, "that your idea of the best isn't me."

Translation

Fortunately, I saw Kate's potential early on; her presence, unfortunately for you, is exactly what I want. In short, Kate's presence is as wonderful as you realize, and I've been keeping it safe, just for the comfort of my old age. I've been observing her for a long time. I've nurtured her, allowing her—like you would with investments—to increase in value. You can imagine whether I'm now inclined to negotiate her, with anyone other than the highest bidder, now that things are starting to pay off. I'm the one who can make the most of her, and I know what that "most" is." "Oh, I understand," Densher said. "Your idea of the best certainly doesn't include me."

It was an oddity of Mrs. Lowder's that her face in speech was like a lighted window at night, but that silence immediately drew the curtain. The occasion for reply allowed by her silence was never easy to take; yet she was still less easy to interrupt. The great glaze of her surface, at all events, gave her visitor no present help.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder had a peculiar habit: when she spoke, her face was like a window brightly lit at night. But silence instantly drew the curtain. It was never simple to respond to the pauses she created, and it was even harder to interrupt her. Her visitor certainly received no immediate assistance from the blank, impenetrable surface she presented.

"I didn't ask you to come to hear what it isn't—I asked you to come to hear what it is." "Of course," Densher laughed, "it's very great indeed." His hostess went on as if his contribution to the subject were barely relevant. "I want to see her high, high up—high up and in the light."

Translation

"I didn't ask you to come and hear what it isn't—I asked you to come and hear what it is." "Of course," Densher laughed, "it's very great indeed." His hostess continued, as if his input was almost beside the point. "I want to see her high, high up—high up and in the light."

"Oh, I understand," Densher said. "I know I'm not your idea of the perfect man." Mrs. Lowder had a peculiar habit of lighting up when she spoke, like a window illuminated at night.

Translation

"Oh, I understand," Densher said. "I know I'm not who you'd ideally choose." Mrs. Lowder had a strange way of brightening when she talked, like a window suddenly lit up after dark.

But silence immediately drew the curtain. The pause she created never made it easy to respond, though interrupting her was even more difficult. The composed expression on her face offered no immediate assistance to her visitor. "I didn't invite you here to hear what you aren't.

Translation

But the silence fell like a curtain. The pauses she took made it hard to reply, even though interrupting her was harder still. The calm look on her face offered no help to her visitor. "I didn't ask you here to tell me what you aren't."

I wanted you to hear what you are." "Of course," Densher laughed, "it's quite significant." His hostess continued as if his comment held little relevance. "I want to see her successful, very successful—achieving everything and in the public eye."

Translation

"I wanted you to understand what you are." Densher laughed, "Of course, that's important." His hostess continued as though his remark was immaterial. "I want to see her succeed, to really succeed—achieving everything and in the public eye."

"Ah, you naturally want to marry her to a duke, and are eager to smooth away any hitch." She gave him so, on this, the mere effect of the drawn blind that it quite forced him, at first, into the sense, possibly just, of having affected her as flippant, perhaps even as low. He had been looked at so, in blighted moments of presumptuous youth, by big cold public men, but never, so far as he could recall, by any private lady. More than anything yet it gave him the measure of his companion's subtlety, and thereby of Kate's possible career.

Translation

"Oh, you want to marry her off to a duke, and you're anxious to fix any problems." She treated him that way, with the drawn blankness of a window shade, which made him feel, just for a moment, that she thought him flippant, maybe even vulgar. He'd been looked at that way, in his arrogant youth, by important, cold public figures, but never, as far as he could remember, by a private woman. More than anything, it showed him how subtle his companion was, and therefore, how Kate's career might unfold.

"Don't be too impossible!"—he feared from his friend, for a moment, some such answer as that; and then felt, as she spoke otherwise, as if she were letting him off easily. "I want her to marry a great man." That was all; but, more and more, it was enough; and if it hadn't been her next words would have made it so. "And I think of her what I think. There you are."

Translation

"Don't be too difficult!"—he braced himself for some reply like that from his friend. When she didn't say it, he felt as if she was letting him off the hook. "I want her to marry a great man." That was it, but it was becoming more and more significant, and if it wasn't already, her next words would have sealed the deal. "And I think of her what I think. There you have it."

Oh, I understand. You want to marry her to a duke, and you're determined to remove any obstacles. Her reaction, the way she looked at him, made him feel as though he'd been seen as shallow, perhaps even vulgar. He'd been judged that way before, in his youth, by stern, important men, but never, he thought, by a woman.

Translation

I see. You want her to marry a duke, and you're set on clearing the way. The look on her face made him feel like he was being seen as superficial, maybe even crude. He'd been judged like that before, when he was young, by serious, powerful men, but never, he thought, by a woman.

More than anything, it revealed her own intelligence, and consequently, the potential path for Kate. He feared, for a moment, that she might say something like, "Don't be ridiculous!" But she didn't, and he felt relieved, as if she were letting him off easily. "I want her to marry a significant man." That was it, but it was enough, and if it hadn't been, her next words would have sealed it. "And I think of her as I think.

Translation

More than anything, her reaction betrayed her intelligence, and as a result, the options available to Kate. For a second, he was worried she might say something like, "That's ridiculous!" But she didn't, and he was relieved, as if she was giving him an easy out. "I want her to marry a man of importance." That was it, but it was enough, and if it hadn't been, her next words would have finalized it. "And I think of her as myself."

That's all there is to it." They sat for a little face to face upon it, and he was conscious of something deeper still, of something she wished him to understand if he only would. To that extent she did appeal—appealed to the intelligence she desired to show she believed him to possess. He was meanwhile, at all events, not the man wholly to fail of comprehension.

Translation

"That's the whole story." They sat facing each other in silence for a moment, and he was aware of something deeper, of something she wanted him to grasp if he only would. To that degree, she appealed—appealed to the intelligence she wanted to demonstrate she believed he had. He was, in the meantime, at any rate, not the kind of man to entirely miss the point.

"Of course I'm aware how little I can answer to any fond, proud dream. You've a view—a magnificent one; into which I perfectly enter. I thoroughly understand what I'm not, and I'm much obliged to you for not reminding me of it in any rougher way." She said nothing—she kept that up; it might even have been to let him go further, if he was capable of it, in the way of poorness of spirit. It was one of those cases in which a man couldn't show, if he showed at all, save for poor; unless indeed he preferred to show for asinine.

Translation

"Of course I know how much I fail to live up to any cherished, hopeful fantasy. You have an ideal—a truly impressive one; I completely get that. I fully grasp what I'm not, and I appreciate you not pointing it out more harshly." She didn't respond—she kept that up; perhaps it was to allow him to delve further, if he could, into his own despondency. It was one of those situations where a person couldn't be anything but pathetic, unless they chose to be an ass.

It was the plain truth: he was—on Mrs. Lowder's basis, the only one in question—a very small quantity, and he did know, damnably, what made quantities large. He desired to be perfectly simple; yet in the midst of that effort a deeper apprehension throbbed. Aunt Maud clearly conveyed it, though he couldn't later on have said how.

Translation

It was the simple truth: according to Mrs. Lowder, and really, she was the only one that mattered, he was a nobody. And he knew, goddamn it, what made people important. He wanted to be straightforward, but even in that effort, a deeper anxiety throbbed. Aunt Maud conveyed it, though afterward, he wouldn't be able to say exactly how.

"You don't really matter, I believe, so much as you think, and I'm not going to make you a martyr by banishing you. Your performances with Kate in the Park are ridiculous so far as they're meant as consideration for me; and I had much rather see you myself—since you're, in your way, my dear young man, delightful—and arrange with you, count with you, as I easily, as I perfectly should. Do you suppose me so stupid as to quarrel with you if it's not really necessary? It won't—it would be too absurd!—be necessary.

Translation

"I don't think you're as important as you believe, and I won't turn you into a martyr by kicking you out. Your little shows with Kate in the Park are ridiculous, especially if you think they're for my benefit. I'd much rather see you myself—since you're, in your own way, my dear young man, quite charming—and work things out with you, count on you, as I easily and perfectly could. Do you think I'm so stupid that I'd argue with you if it wasn't truly necessary? It won't be—it would be ridiculous!—necessary."
