I can bite your head off any day, any day I really open my mouth; and I'm dealing with you now, see—and successfully judge—without opening it. I do things handsomely all round—I place you in the presence of the plan with which, from the moment it's a case of taking you seriously, you're incompatible. Come then as near it as you like, walk all round it—don't be afraid you'll hurt it!—and live on with it before you." They sat facing each other for a while, and he was aware of something more profound, something she wanted him to understand, if he would.

Translation

I could obliterate you any time, any day. I don’t even have to say anything. I'm dealing with you right now, and successfully assessing you without saying a word. I handle everything with finesse. I'm presenting you with the plan, which you're fundamentally at odds with the moment it becomes serious. So, come as close as you like, examine it from every angle, don't worry about damaging it, and live with it. They sat facing each other for a moment, and he sensed something deeper, something she wanted him to comprehend, if he was capable.

She was, to a certain degree, appealing—appealing to the intelligence she wanted to show she believed he had. He, for his part, wasn't the kind of man to entirely miss the point. "Of course, I know how little I can fulfill any idealistic, proud expectation. You have a vision—a magnificent one; which I completely understand.

Translation

She possessed a certain allure—an allure directed at the intelligence she hoped to demonstrate she believed he possessed. He, for his part, wasn't the sort to completely miss the point. "Of course, I understand how little I can live up to any idealistic, proud expectation. You have a vision—a magnificent one; which I completely understand."

I fully realize what I am not, and I'm grateful to you for not pointing it out to me more harshly." She didn't speak—she kept that up; it might even have been to encourage him to go further, if he could, in self-deprecation. It was one of those situations where a man could only come across as inadequate if he tried to express himself; unless, of course, he wanted to come across as foolish. It was the simple truth: he was—according to Mrs. Lowder's standards, which were the only ones that mattered—a very small figure, and he knew, damn it, what made figures significant.

Translation

"I know exactly what I'm not, and I appreciate you not being too blunt about it." She stayed silent, and it might have been to get him to dig deeper, if he could, in putting himself down. It was one of those moments when a man would just sound lame trying to explain himself, unless he wanted to sound like an idiot. The plain fact was that he was, by Mrs. Lowder's standards—the only ones that counted—a nobody, and he knew, goddamn it, what made people important.

He wanted to be completely straightforward; yet even while trying, a deeper sense of understanding pulsed. Aunt Maud made it clear, though later he wouldn't have been able to say how. "I don't believe you're as important as you think you are, and I'm not going to make you suffer by cutting you off. Your interactions with Kate in the Park are ridiculous, as far as they're meant to consider me; and I'd much rather see you myself—since, in your own way, my dear young man, you're charming—and work things out with you, count on you, as I easily and completely could.

Translation

He wanted to be utterly honest, but even in the attempt, a deeper level of comprehension throbbed. Aunt Maud had made herself clear, though later he wouldn't be able to recall the how. "I don't believe you're as significant as you fancy yourself, and I won't make you miserable by shutting you out. Your encounters with Kate in the Park are absurd, as far as they're meant to concern me; and I'd much prefer to see you myself—since, in your own way, my dear boy, you're quite appealing—and hash things out with you, rely on you, as I easily and completely could.

Do you think me so foolish as to quarrel with you if it's not absolutely necessary? It won't be—it would be too absurd!—necessary. I can dismiss you any day, any time I actually speak my mind; and I'm dealing with you now, see—and judging you successfully—without saying a word. I handle things gracefully overall—I show you the plan which, from the moment I start taking you seriously, you can't be a part of.

Translation

Do you imagine I'm so idiotic that I'd argue with you unless I absolutely had to? It won't be—it would be ridiculous!—necessary. I can get rid of you any day, any time I actually say what I think; and I'm dealing with you now, see—and judging you effectively—without uttering a word. Generally, I manage things with finesse—I'm showing you the blueprint that, from the moment I start to regard you seriously, you can't be involved in.

So come as close to it as you like, examine it thoroughly—don't worry about damaging it!—and live alongside it." He afterwards felt that if she hadn't absolutely phrased all this it was because she so soon made him out as going with her far enough. He was so pleasantly affected by her asking no promise of him, her not proposing he should pay for her indulgence by his word of honour not to interfere, that he gave her a kind of general assurance of esteem. Immediately afterwards, then, he spoke of these things to Kate, and what then came back to him first of all was the way he had said to her—he mentioned it to the girl—very much as one of a pair of lovers says in a rupture by mutual consent: "I hope immensely, of course, that you'll always regard me as a friend." This had perhaps been going far—he submitted it all to Kate; but really there had been so much in it that it was to be looked at, as they might say, wholly in its own light.

Translation

So, come as close as you like, scrutinize it carefully—don't worry about hurting it!—and live with it.” Afterwards, he felt that the reason she hadn't explicitly said all this was because she quickly realized he would go along with her. He was so pleased that she didn't ask for any promise from him, that she didn't expect him to guarantee his cooperation with a pledge, that he gave her a sort of general assurance of his respect. Immediately afterwards, he talked about these things to Kate, and what came back to him first was the way he'd said to her—he mentioned it to the girl—much like two lovers say in a mutual breakup: "I certainly hope that you'll always consider me a friend." Perhaps that was going too far—he put it all to Kate; but truly, there was so much to consider in it that it had to be viewed, so to speak, in its own context.

Other things than those we have presented had come up before the close of his scene with Aunt Maud, but this matter of her not treating him as a peril of the first order easily predominated. There was moreover plenty to talk about on the occasion of his subsequent passage with our young woman, it having been put to him abruptly, the night before, that he might give himself a lift and do his newspaper a service—so flatteringly was the case expressed—by going, for fifteen or twenty weeks, to America. The idea of a series of letters from the United States from the strictly social point of view had for some time been nursed in the inner sanctuary at whose door he sat, and the moment was now deemed happy for letting it loose. The imprisoned thought had, in a word, on the opening of the door, flown straight out into Densher's face, or perched at least on his shoulder, making him look up in surprise from his mere inky office-table.

Translation

Other things had arisen before the close of his conversation with Aunt Maud, but her failure to treat him as an immediate threat was the most significant. Additionally, there was much to discuss during his subsequent encounter with our young woman. The night before, he had been asked, quite suddenly, if he might boost his own prospects and benefit his newspaper—the proposition was framed with considerable flattery—by traveling to America for fifteen or twenty weeks. The notion of a series of letters from the United States, focused exclusively on social matters, had been under consideration for some time within the inner circle of which he was a part. The timing now seemed right to put it into action. The previously suppressed idea, upon the opening of its conceptual door, had burst forth directly into Densher’s face, or at least had landed upon his shoulder, causing him to look up from his inky office desk in surprise.

His account of the matter to Kate was that he couldn't refuse—not being in a position, as yet, to refuse anything; but that his being chosen for such an errand confounded his sense of proportion. He was definite as to his scarce knowing how to measure the honour, which struck him as equivocal; he had not quite supposed himself the man for the class of job. This confused consciousness, he intimated, he had promptly enough betrayed to his manager; with the effect, however, of seeing the question surprisingly clear up. What it came to was that the sort of twaddle that was not in his chords was, unexpectedly, just what they happened this time not to want.

Translation

He told Kate he couldn't refuse—he wasn't in a position to refuse anything, not yet. But the fact that he was chosen for this assignment baffled him. He was clear that he barely knew how to gauge the honor of it, which seemed questionable to him; he hadn't imagined himself suited for this kind of work. He confessed this confused feeling to his manager, but the effect was that the situation became surprisingly clear. Essentially, the kind of trivial nonsense that wasn't his forte was, unexpectedly, exactly what they didn't want this time.

They wanted his letters, for queer reasons, about as good as he could let them come; he was to play his own little tune and not be afraid; that was the whole point. Later, he realized that if she hadn't explicitly said everything, it was because she quickly realized he was going along with her plan. He was so pleased that she didn't ask him to promise anything, that she didn't demand he guarantee his good behavior, that he offered her a general expression of admiration. Immediately after that, he discussed these matters with Kate, and the first thing that came to mind was how he'd said to her—he recounted it to the girl—much like a couple says during a breakup by mutual agreement: "I certainly hope you'll always think of me as a friend." Perhaps that was too much—he explained everything to Kate—but there was so much involved that it had to be viewed, so to speak, in its own context.

Translation

They wanted his letters, for reasons they didn't specify, as good as he could make them; he should do his own thing and not worry about it, that was the idea. He later understood that she didn't spell it all out because she saw he was going along with it. He was glad she didn't ask for a commitment, that she didn't need any assurances, and he gave her some general praise. Afterward, he talked it over with Kate, and the first thing that occurred to him was what he'd told her—he told Kate—like a couple breaking up amicably: "I hope we can still be friends." Maybe he'd said too much—he explained to Kate—but there was a lot to consider, and it needed to be understood within its own framework.

Other things had been said before the end of his discussion with Aunt Maud, but her not treating him as a serious threat was what stood out. Translation

What stuck with him most from the conversation with Aunt Maud was that she hadn't taken him seriously. He also had a lot to process regarding his talk with the young woman. The night before, she'd unexpectedly proposed that he could do himself and his newspaper a favor—it was rather flattering—by spending fifteen or twenty weeks in America. The plan for a series of society-focused letters from the United States had been brewing for a while, and the moment was ripe to move forward. In short, the proposal, upon the opening of the door, had hit Densher square in the face, or at least landed on his shoulder, making him look up from his cluttered desk in surprise.

His explanation to Kate was that he couldn't refuse—not being in a position to refuse anything yet; but that being chosen for such a task surprised him. He was clear about not knowing how to judge the honor, which seemed questionable; he hadn't thought he was suited for the job. This uncertain feeling, he implied, he had quickly revealed to his manager; but the effect was to make the issue surprisingly clear. What it came down to was that the kind of fluff that wasn't his style was, unexpectedly, exactly what they didn't want this time.

Translation

Densher told Kate he couldn't turn the assignment down; he wasn't in a place to refuse anything at the moment. But he was still surprised they'd picked him. He didn't know how to assess this honor—if that's what it was—which seemed dubious. He hadn't thought he was the right man for the job. He'd admitted his reservations to his editor. The result, though, was that everything became surprisingly clear. What it came down to was that the kind of trivial, lighthearted material that wasn't his usual thing was, unexpectedly, precisely what they didn't want this time around.

They wanted his letters, for strange reasons, to be as good as he could make them; he should do his own thing and not be afraid; that was the whole idea. It would have been the whole, that is, had there not been a sharper one still in the circumstance that he was to start at once. His mission, as they called it at the office, would probably be over by the end of June, which was desirable; but to bring that about he must now not lose a week; his inquiries, he understood, were to cover the whole ground, and there were reasons of State—reasons operating at the seat of empire in Fleet Street—why the nail should be struck on the head. Densher made no secret to Kate of his having asked for a day to decide; and his account of that matter was that he felt he owed it to her to speak to her first.

Translation

They wanted him to make the letters as good as possible, for reasons he didn't quite understand. He should do what he did best and not worry about it; that was the whole point. Well, that would have been the point, except for the fact that he had to begin immediately. His mission, as they called it, would hopefully be over by the end of June, which was ideal. But to make that happen, he couldn't waste any time. His investigation, he was told, needed to cover every angle. There were sensitive issues at play—issues at the heart of the empire, in Fleet Street—which meant he had to get to the core of the matter. Densher didn't hide from Kate that he'd asked for a day to think things over. He explained that he felt he owed it to her to tell her first.

She assured him on this that nothing so much as that scruple had yet shown her how they were bound together; she was clearly proud of his letting a thing of such importance depend on her; but she was clearer still as to his instant duty. She rejoiced in his prospect and urged him to his task; she should miss him intensely—of course she should miss him; but she made so little of it that she spoke with jubilation of what he would see and would do. She made so much of this last quantity that he laughed at her innocence, though also with scarce the heart to give her the real size of his drop in the daily bucket. He was struck at the same time with her happy grasp of what had really occurred in Fleet Street—all the more that it was his own final reading.

Translation

She assured him that nothing had demonstrated their bond more than this hesitation of his. She was clearly pleased that he let something so important hinge on her, but she was even clearer about what he needed to do immediately. She was thrilled about his opportunity and pushed him to get started. She would miss him terribly—of course, she would—but she made so little of it that she spoke with glee about what he would see and what he would do. She made so much of this that he laughed at her naivete, though he also barely had the heart to tell her how much of a setback this would be for him. He was struck by her joyful understanding of what had actually happened in Fleet Street—especially since it was his own final interpretation.

He was to pull the subject up—that was just what they wanted; and it would take more than all the United States together, visit them each as he might, to let him down. It was just because he didn't nose about and wasn't the usual gossipmonger that they had picked him out; it was a branch of their correspondence with which they evidently wished a new tone associated, such a tone as, from now on, it would have always to take from his example. The entirety of it would have been the focus, that is, if it weren't for an even sharper consideration: he was scheduled to leave immediately. His assignment, as they termed it at the office, would likely conclude by the end of June, which was considered ideal.

Translation

They wanted him to confront the subject head-on; that was the point. No amount of travel, even if he visited every corner of the United States, would undermine his position. They’d chosen him precisely because he wasn't a busybody or a gossip. He was meant to bring a new sensibility to their communications, a tone that would become the standard, based on his own. The whole endeavor would have been his sole focus, had it not been for the impending reality: he was leaving immediately. His project, as they called it at the office, was slated to wrap up by the end of June, which was considered the best-case scenario.

To achieve this, he couldn't afford to waste a single week. He understood his investigations were to be comprehensive. There were matters of significant importance – matters originating from the central offices in Fleet Street – that required immediate attention. Densher was open with Kate about having requested a day to consider the offer, explaining that he felt he needed to consult with her first.

Translation

To make this happen, he couldn't afford any delays. He knew his research had to be thorough. There were crucial issues – ones coming directly from the main offices on Fleet Street – that demanded his immediate action. Densher had been upfront with Kate, telling her he'd asked for a day to think about it, because he wanted to discuss it with her first.

She responded that nothing had revealed the depth of their connection as clearly as that hesitation. She was evidently pleased that he would allow something of such importance to hinge on her. However, she was even more emphatic about his immediate responsibility. She was happy for him and encouraged him to accept the task.

Kate said nothing had demonstrated their closeness as plainly as his pause. It clearly thrilled her that he would let something so vital depend on her. But she was more forceful about his immediate obligations. She was happy for him and urged him to accept the task.

She would miss him intensely, of course she would miss him, but she downplayed it so much that she spoke with great enthusiasm about what he would experience and accomplish. She focused so much on this aspect that he laughed at her naiveté, though he struggled to convey the true extent of his own diminished enthusiasm. He was also impressed by her accurate understanding of the situation in Fleet Street, especially since it matched his own interpretation. He was expected to thoroughly investigate the matter – that was precisely what they desired.

Translation

She would miss him terribly, naturally she would, but she minimized it so much that she spoke with great excitement about what he would encounter and achieve. She was so focused on this that he laughed at her innocence, though he found it hard to show how little enthusiasm he actually had. He was also impressed by her sharp understanding of the situation at Fleet Street, especially since it mirrored his own understanding. He was supposed to investigate the matter thoroughly – that was exactly what they wanted.

He knew that the United States, even if he visited every part of it, wouldn't be enough to detract him from this. They had chosen him precisely because he wasn't inclined to pry or engage in casual gossip. They clearly desired a fresh approach to their dealings, a tone that would become standard based on his performance. "How you ought indeed, when you understand so well, to be a journalist's wife!" Densher exclaimed in admiration, even while she struck him as fairly hurrying him off.

Translation

He knew that even a tour of the entire United States wouldn't be enough to distract him. They had selected him because he wasn't one to pry or participate in idle chatter. It was clear they wanted a new way of doing things, and his work would set the tone. "You should be a journalist's wife!" Densher declared admiringly, even though it seemed she was pushing him away.

But she was almost impatient of the praise. "What do you expect one not to understand when one cares for you?" "Ah then, I'll put it otherwise and say 'How much you care for me!'" "Yes," she assented; "it fairly redeems my stupidity.

Translation

But she was almost annoyed by the compliment. "What did you expect I wouldn't understand, considering I care about you?" "Ah, then, I'll put it differently and say, 'How much you care about me!'" "Yes," she agreed, "it almost makes up for my foolishness."

I shall, with a chance to show it," she added, "have some imagination for you." She spoke of the future this time as so little contingent, that he felt a queerness of conscience in making her the report that he presently arrived at on what had passed for him with the real arbiter of their destiny. The way for that had been blocked a little by his news from Fleet Street; but in the crucible of their happy discussion this element soon melted into the other, and in the mixture that ensued the parts were not to be distinguished. The young man moreover, before taking his leave, was to see why Kate had just spoken of the future as if they now really possessed it, and was to come to the vision by a devious way that deepened the final cheer.

Translation

"I'll have a chance to prove it," she added, "I'll use some imagination on your behalf." She spoke of the future as though it was a sure thing. This made him feel a pang of guilt about the report he was about to give her about his encounter with the person who really decided their fate. The path to that news had been partially blocked by what he'd heard from Fleet Street, but that was soon dissolved in the crucible of their happy conversation. The parts were indistinguishable in the mixture that followed. Before leaving, the young man would understand why Kate had spoken of the future as though they truly controlled it, and he would come to that understanding by a circuitous route that enhanced the final joy.

Their faces were turned to the illumined quarter as soon as he had answered her question in respect to the appearance of their being able to play a waiting game with success. It was for the possibility of that appearance that she had, a few days before, so earnestly pressed him to see her aunt; and if after his hour with that lady it had not struck Densher that he had seen her to the happiest purpose the poor facts flushed with a better meaning as Kate, one by one, took them up. "You should really be a journalist's wife, considering how well you understand things!" Densher exclaimed admiringly, even though she seemed to be rushing him. But she was almost annoyed by the compliment.

Translation

As soon as he answered her question about whether they seemed capable of waiting things out successfully, they turned their faces toward the light. It was for the sake of that appearance that she'd urged him so hard to visit her aunt a few days earlier. If Densher hadn't realized that the meeting had served the best possible purpose, the pitiful facts would have taken on a more positive cast as Kate, one by one, took them up. "You really should be a journalist's wife, the way you understand things!" Densher exclaimed admiringly, though it seemed like she was rushing him. But she was almost irritated by the compliment.

"What do you expect? That I *wouldn't* understand when I care about you?" "Well then, let me put it this way: 'How much you care about me!'" "Yes," she agreed.

Translation

"What did you think? That I wouldn't understand, when I care about you?"

"Well, put it like this then: 'How much you care about me!'"

"Yes," she conceded.

"It makes up for my lack of intelligence. I will, given the opportunity to show it, have some imagination for you." This time, she spoke of the future as if it were inevitable. He felt a pang of guilt as he prepared to tell her what had happened with the person who really controlled their fate.

Translation

"It compensates for my intellectual shortcomings. I will, when the chance arises, be imaginative for your sake." She spoke of the future as though it were a certainty. He felt a sharp stab of guilt as he readied himself to tell her about the events involving the person who truly dictated their destiny.

His news from his work had briefly complicated things, but in the heat of their conversation, it quickly faded, and the two elements blended together indistinguishably. Before he left, the young man was going to understand why Kate had spoken of the future as if they actually had it, and he would reach that understanding through a circuitous route that enhanced the overall joy. Their faces turned towards the hopeful outlook as soon as he had answered her question about whether they could appear successful in waiting. It was to create the *impression* of a successful waiting game that she had, a few days earlier, urged him to visit her aunt.

Translation

His work update had briefly muddied the waters, but the issue evaporated in the intensity of their exchange, the two components merging seamlessly. Before he departed, the young man would understand why Kate had spoken of the future with such conviction, and he would arrive at this understanding by a roundabout path that amplified their shared happiness. Their faces brightened at the optimistic prospect the moment he had answered her question about whether they could appear successful while waiting. It was to cultivate the *impression* of a successful waiting game that, a few days prior, she had pressed him to visit her aunt.

And if Densher hadn't realized after meeting the woman how successfully he had played his part, the dull facts suddenly took on a new, better meaning as Kate, one by one, picked them up and examined them. "If she consents to your coming, why isn't that everything?" "It is everything; everything she thinks it. It's the probability—I mean as Mrs.

Translation

And if Densher hadn't understood how well he'd performed his role after meeting the woman, the mundane details unexpectedly took on a new and improved significance as Kate, one by one, considered them. "If she agrees to your visit, why isn't that everything?" "It is everything; everything she believes it to be. It's the likelihood—I mean, as Mrs.

Lowder measures probability—that I may be prevented from becoming a complication for her by some arrangement, any arrangement, through which you shall see me often and easily. She's sure of my want of money, and that gives her time. She believes in my having a certain amount of delicacy, in my wishing to better my state before I put the pistol to your head in respect to sharing it. The time that will take figures for her as the time that will help her if she doesn't spoil her chance by treating me badly.

Translation

Lowder assesses probability—that I might be kept from being a problem for her through some deal, any deal, by which you will see me regularly and without difficulty. She's sure I need money, and that buys her time. She believes I possess a certain degree of sensitivity, that I want to improve my situation before demanding a share. The time that will be required for that she sees as the time that will aid her, provided she doesn't ruin her chances by treating me poorly.

She doesn't at all wish moreover," Densher went on, "to treat me badly, for I believe, upon my honour, funny as it may sound to you, that she personally rather likes me, and that if you weren't in question I might almost become her pet young man. She doesn't disparage intellect and culture—quite the contrary; she wants them to adorn her board and be named in her programme; and I'm sure it has sometimes cost her a real pang that I should be so desirable, at once, and so impossible." He paused a moment, and his companion then saw that a strange smile was in his face—a smile as strange even as the adjunct, in her own, of this informing vision. "I quite suspect her of believing that, if the truth were known, she likes me literally better than—deep down—you yourself do: wherefore she does me the honour to think that I may be safely left to kill my own cause. There, as I say, comes in her margin.

Translation

"Furthermore, she doesn't want to mistreat me at all," Densher continued. "Because, believe me, though it may sound strange, I think she actually likes me. If you weren't involved, I might almost be her favorite young man. She doesn't dislike intelligence and sophistication—quite the opposite; she wants them to be part of her social circle, to be included in her plans. And I'm sure it's occasionally painful for her that I'm so appealing, and yet unavailable." He hesitated, and his companion noticed a peculiar smile on his face—a smile as unsettling as the additional insight in her own. "I wouldn't be surprised if she believes that, if the truth were known, she likes me literally more than—deep down—you do. That's why she honors me by thinking I can be left to ruin my own prospects. That's, as I said, where her wiggle room comes in."

I'm not the sort of stuff of romance that wears, that washes, that survives use, that resists familiarity. Once in any degree admit that, and your pride and prejudice will take care of the rest! the pride fed full, meanwhile, by the system she means to practise with you, and the prejudice excited by the comparison she'll enable you to make, from which I shall come off badly. She likes me, but she'll never like me so much as when she succeeded a little better in making me look wretched.

Translation

I'm not the romantic type—the kind that endures, that stands up to wear and tear, that stays appealing. Once you concede that, your pride and prejudice will handle the rest! Her pride will be inflated by the plan she's enacting with you, and your prejudice will be stoked by the comparison she'll make you draw, from which I won't come out looking good. She does like me, but she'll never like me as much as when she's managed to make me look a little miserable.

For then you'll like me less." "If she agrees to your visit, isn't that all that matters?" "It is everything; at least, everything she believes it is. It's the likelihood – from Mrs.

Translation

Then you'll like me even less." "If she approves of your visit, isn't that the only thing that counts?" "It's absolutely everything; or, at least, everything she thinks it is. It's the probability—based on Mrs.

Lowder's point of view – that she can prevent me from complicating things for her through some plan, any plan, that lets you see me often and easily. She's certain I'm broke, and that buys her time. She believes I have enough sense of propriety to try and improve my financial situation before I demand to share your life. The time that will take appears to her as time that will help her, provided she doesn't ruin her chances by treating me poorly.

Translation

Then you'll like me even less." "If she approves of your visit, isn't that the only thing that counts?" "It's absolutely everything; or, at least, everything she thinks it is. It's the probability—based on Mrs. Lowder's point of view – that she can prevent me from complicating things for her through some plan, any plan, that lets you see me often and easily. She's certain I'm broke, and that buys her time. She believes I have enough sense of propriety to try and improve my financial situation before I demand to share your life. The time that will take appears to her as time that will help her, provided she doesn't ruin her chances by treating me poorly.

Furthermore," Densher continued, "she doesn't want to treat me poorly. I honestly believe, though it may sound strange, that she actually likes me, and if you weren't involved, I might almost be her favorite young man. She values intellect and culture – quite the opposite; she wants them to enhance her social circle and be part of her image. I'm sure it sometimes pains her that I'm so appealing, yet simultaneously, so out of reach." He paused, and his companion noticed a peculiar smile on his face, as unusual as the vision itself that was dawning on her.

Translation

Furthermore," Densher continued, "she doesn't want to treat me poorly. I honestly believe, though it may sound strange, that she actually likes me, and if you weren't involved, I might almost be her favorite young man. She values intellect and culture – quite the opposite; she wants them to enhance her social circle and be part of her image. I'm sure it sometimes pains her that I'm so appealing, yet simultaneously, so out of reach." He paused, and his companion noticed a peculiar smile on his face, as unusual as the vision itself that was dawning on her.

"I strongly suspect she believes that, if the truth were known, she actually likes me more than – deep down – you do. Therefore, she does me the honor of thinking I can be left to ruin my own chances. That's where her leeway lies, as I said. I'm not the kind of romantic material that endures, that lasts, that survives familiarity.

Translation

"I have a feeling she thinks she likes me, secretly, more than she likes you. So, she gives me the 'honor' of letting me mess things up for myself. That's the extent of her tolerance, as I mentioned. I'm not the type of romantic interest who sticks around, who lasts, who can handle being known."

Once she admits that, your pride and biases will handle the rest! Your pride will be inflated by the strategy she intends to use with you, and your prejudices will be fueled by the comparison she'll encourage you to make, in which I'll fare poorly. She likes me, but she'll like me even more when she's managed to make me appear somewhat miserable. Because then, you'll like me less."

Translation

Once she says that, your ego and prejudices will do the rest. Your pride will be bolstered by the plan she has for you, and your biases will be strengthened by the comparison she'll push you to make, where I'll come out looking bad. She likes me, but she'll like me even more once she's succeeded in making me look a little unhappy. Because then, you'll like me less."

Kate showed for this evocation a due interest, but no alarm; and it was a little as if to pay his tender cynicism back in kind that she after an instant replied: "I see, I see; what an immense affair she must think me! One was aware, but you deepen the impression." "I think you'll make no mistake," said Densher, "in letting it go as deep as it will." He had given her indeed, she made no scruple of showing, plenty to consider.

Translation

Kate displayed the appropriate level of interest, but no sign of alarm. After a moment, as if to return his affectionate cynicism in kind, she said, "I see, I see; she must think I'm a huge deal! One knew that, but you're really driving the point home." "I don't think you'll make a mistake," Densher said, "in letting it get as deep as it's going to." He had given her plenty to think about, a fact that she didn't hesitate to reveal.

"Her facing the music, her making you boldly as welcome as you say—that's an awfully big theory, you know, and worthy of all the other big things that, in one's acquaintance with people, give her a place so apart." Kate displayed the appropriate level of interest in his story, but she wasn't alarmed. Almost as if to match his gentle cynicism, she responded after a moment: "I understand. I see.

Translation

"Her willingness to face the consequences, her eagerness to make you feel comfortable—that's a pretty grand idea, you know, and fits right in with the other grand things that, in my experience with people, make her so unique." Kate showed the right amount of interest in his story, but she wasn't concerned. Almost mimicking his subtle cynicism, she replied after a beat: "I get it. I see."

She must think I'm a huge deal! I knew, but you're really emphasizing it." "I don't think you'll go wrong," Densher said, "by allowing it to become as significant as it wants to be." He had truly given her a lot to think about, as she readily admitted.

Translation

"She must think I'm a big shot! I knew it, but you're really driving the point home." "I don't think you'll regret it," Densher said, "by letting it become as important as it wants to be." He had certainly given her a lot to consider, as she readily conceded.

"The way she's facing the music, welcoming you so openly like you say—that's a really enormous idea, you know, and fits in with all the other big aspects of her that set her apart from everyone else I know." "Oh, she's grand," the young man conceded; "she's on the scale, altogether, of the car of Juggernaut which was a kind of image that came to me yesterday while I waited for her at Lancaster Gate. The things in your drawing-room there were like the forms of the strange idols, the mystic excrescences, with which one may suppose the front of the car to bristle." "Yes, aren't they?" the girl returned; and they had, over all that aspect of their wonderful lady, one of those deep and free interchanges that made everything but confidence a false note for them.

Translation

"The way she's handling all of this, embracing you so readily—it's a truly remarkable thing, you know, and it aligns with all the other big qualities about her that make her unlike anyone else I've ever known." "Oh, she's magnificent," the young man agreed; "she's on a scale, completely, like the car of Juggernaut—which was an image that occurred to me yesterday while I was waiting for her at Lancaster Gate. The things in your drawing-room there were like the forms of those strange idols, the mystical outgrowths, that I imagine the front of the car bristling with." "Yes, aren't they?" the girl replied; and, regarding all the aspects of their incredible lady, they shared one of those deep and open exchanges that made anything less than complete trust seem wrong to them.

There were complications, there were questions; but they were so much more together than they were anything else. Kate uttered for a while no word of refutation of Aunt Maud's "big" diplomacy, and they left it there, as they would have left any other fine product, for a monument to her powers. But, Densher related further, he had had in other respects too the car of Juggernaut to face; he omitted nothing from his account of his visit, least of all the way Aunt Maud had frankly at last—though indeed only under artful pressure—fallen foul of his very type, his want of the right marks, his foreign accidents, his queer antecedents. She had told him he was but half a Briton, which, he granted Kate, would have been dreadful if he hadn't so let himself in for it.

Translation

There were difficulties, there were uncertainties; but above all, they were a unified front. For a time, Kate didn't challenge Aunt Maud's "grand" diplomacy, and they let it rest, as if it were a testament to her abilities. But, Densher went on, he'd also had to contend with the car of Juggernaut in other ways. He left nothing out of his account of the visit, especially how Aunt Maud had finally, though only after some skillful coaxing, attacked his very essence—his lack of the right credentials, his foreign background, his odd history. She'd said he was only half-British, which, he admitted to Kate, would have been terrible if he hadn't practically asked for it.

"Oh, she's impressive," the young man admitted. "She's huge, just like the car of Juggernaut. That image came to me yesterday while I was waiting for her at Lancaster Gate. The things in your drawing-room were like the strange idols, the mystical projections, that I imagine adorn the front of that car."

Translation

"Oh, she's impressive," the young man admitted. "She's massive, just like the car of Juggernaut. That image came to me yesterday while I was waiting for her at Lancaster Gate. There were challenges, there were questions, but they were much more aligned with each other than anything else. Kate didn't challenge Aunt Maud's "bold" approach, and they left it at that, as a testament to her abilities.

"Yes, they are," the girl replied. They shared a comfortable understanding about their amazing aunt, which made anything less than complete trust feel wrong. There were challenges, there were questions, but they were much more aligned than anything else. Kate didn't challenge Aunt Maud's "bold" approach, and they left it at that, as a testament to her abilities.

But, Densher continued, he'd also had to contend with the car of Juggernaut in other ways. He left nothing out of his account of his visit, especially how Aunt Maud had finally, though only after some skillful prodding, directly criticized his very nature: his lack of the right qualities, his foreign traits, his odd background. She'd told him he was only half British, which, he admitted to Kate, would have been terrible if he hadn't invited it. "I was really curious, you see," he explained, "to find out from her what sort of queer creature, what sort of social anomaly, in the light of such conventions as hers, such an education as mine makes one pass for."

Translation

But, Densher continued, he'd had to deal with the overwhelming power of Aunt Maud in other ways, too. He didn't omit a single detail of his visit, especially how Aunt Maud, after some skillful coaxing, had directly criticized his core being: his lacking the right qualities, his foreign characteristics, his strange background. She'd told him he was only half British, which, he conceded to Kate, would have been awful if he hadn't asked for it. "I was really curious, you see," he explained, "to hear from her just what sort of strange creature, what sort of social misfit, my upbringing and my education, in the face of her rules, make me out to be."

Kate said nothing for a little; but then, "Why should you care?" she asked. "Oh," he laughed, "I like her so much; and then, for a man of my trade, her views, her spirit, are essentially a thing to get hold of; they belong to the great public mind that we meet at every turn and that we must keep setting up 'codes' with. Besides," he added, "I want to please her personally." "Ah, yes, we must please her personally!" his companion echoed; and the words may represent all their definite recognition, at the time, of Densher's politic gain.

Translation

Kate was silent for a moment. Then, "Why do you care?" she asked.

"Oh," he laughed, "I like her so much. And then, for a man in my line of work, her views, her spirit, are something to grasp onto. They're part of the prevailing public mindset we encounter constantly, and we have to constantly create 'codes' to deal with it. Besides," he added, "I want to please her personally."

"Ah, yes, we must please her personally!" his companion echoed. And those words might represent their full understanding, at the time, of Densher's strategic advantage.

They had in fact between this and his start for New York many matters to handle, and the question he now touched upon came up for Kate above all. She looked at him as if he had really told her aunt more of his immediate personal story than he had ever told herself. That, if it were so, was an accident, and it put him, for half an hour, on as much of the picture of his early years abroad, his migratory parents, his Swiss schools, his German university, as she had easy attention for. A man, he intimated, a man of their world, would have spotted him straight as to many of these points; a man of their world, so far as they had a world, would have been through the English mill.

Translation

Between this moment and his departure for New York, they had much to sort out, and the issue he raised now was foremost for Kate. She stared at him, as though he’d confided more of his personal history to her aunt than he ever had to her. If that was the case, it was accidental, and it led him to present, for half an hour, a portrait of his early years abroad, his nomadic parents, his Swiss schooling, his German university, and she listened without difficulty. He suggested that a man of their circle would have instantly grasped many of these details; a man of their world, insofar as they possessed one, would have been molded by the English system.

But it was none the less charming to make his confession to a woman; women had, in fact, for such differences, so much more imagination. Kate showed at present all his case could require; when she had had it from beginning to end she declared that she now made out more than ever yet of what she loved him for. She had herself, as a child, lived with some continuity in the world across the Channel, coming home again still a child; and had participated after that, in her teens, in her mother's brief but repeated retreats to Dresden, to Florence, to Biarritz, weak and expensive attempts at economy from which there stuck to her—though in general coldly expressed, through the instinctive avoidance of cheap raptures—the religion of foreign things. When it was revealed to her how many more foreign things were in Merton Densher than he had hitherto taken the trouble to catalogue, she almost faced him as if he were a map of the continent or a handsome present of a delightful new "Murray." He hadn't meant to swagger, he had rather meant to plead, though with Mrs.

Translation

But it was nonetheless charming to make his confession to a woman; women had, in fact, for such differences, so much more imagination. Kate showed at present all his case could require; when she had heard it from beginning to end she declared that she now understood more than ever what she loved him for. She had herself, as a child, lived with some continuity in the world across the Channel, returning home still a child; and had participated after that, in her teens, in her mother's brief but repeated retreats to Dresden, to Florence, to Biarritz, weak and expensive attempts at economy from which there stuck to her—though in general coldly expressed, through the instinctive avoidance of cheap raptures—the religion of foreign things. When it was revealed to her how many more foreign things were in Merton Densher than he had hitherto taken the trouble to catalogue, she almost faced him as if he were a map of the continent or a handsome present of a delightful new "Murray." He hadn't meant to swagger, he had rather meant to plead, though with Mrs.

Lowder he had meant also a little to explain. His father had been, in strange countries, in twenty settlements of the English, British chaplain, resident or occasional, and had had for years the unusual luck of never wanting a billet. His career abroad had therefore been unbroken, and, as his stipend had never been great, he had educated his children at the smallest cost, in the schools nearest; which was also a saving of railway fares. Densher's mother, it further appeared, had practised on her side a distinguished industry, to the success of which—so far as success ever crowned it—this period of exile had much contributed: she copied, patient lady, famous pictures in great museums, having begun with a happy natural gift and taking in betimes the scale of her opportunity.

Translation

He had wanted, in Mrs. Lowder's presence, to clarify his position as well. His father, a British chaplain, either resident or occasional, had served in strange countries and twenty English settlements, enjoying for years the unusual fortune of never being without a post. His career overseas had thus been uninterrupted, and, given his modest salary, he had educated his children in the nearest, and therefore cheapest, schools—a measure that also saved on travel costs. Furthermore, it turned out that Densher's mother had pursued a distinguished career of her own, to which this period of exile had significantly contributed, at least as far as any career could be considered a success: a patient woman, she copied famous paintings in major museums, having started with a natural talent and swiftly grasping the scope of her opportunity.

Copyists abroad of course swarmed, but Mrs. Densher had had a sense and a hand of her own, had arrived at a perfection that persuaded, that even deceived, and that made the disposal of her work blissfully usual. Her son, who had lost her, held her image sacred, and the effect of his telling Kate all about her, as well as about other matters until then mixed and dim, was to render his history rich, his sources full, his outline anything but common. He had come round, he had come back, he insisted abundantly, to being a Briton: his Cambridge years, his happy connection, as it had proved, with his father's college, amply certified to that, to say nothing of his subsequent plunge into London, which filled up the measure.

Translation

Copyists were, of course, everywhere, but Mrs. Densher had had a certain sensibility and skill of her own, achieving a level of perfection that was convincing, even deceptive, making the sale of her work a remarkably regular occurrence. Her son, who had lost her, held her memory sacred. Telling Kate all about her, along with other previously vague and obscure matters, had the effect of enriching his history, filling his sources, and making his profile anything but ordinary. He had come around, he had returned, he insisted frequently, to being British: his years at Cambridge, his fortunate connection, as it turned out, with his father's college, fully attested to that, not to mention his subsequent immersion in London, which completed the picture.

But brave enough though his descent to English earth, he had passed, by the way, through zones of air that had left their ruffle on his wings, had been exposed to initiations ineffaceable. Something had happened to him that could never be undone. "You see," he explained, "I was genuinely curious to find out from her what kind of unusual person, what kind of social misfit, I seemed to her, given her standards and my kind of background." Kate was silent for a moment.

Translation

Despite his bold arrival back in England, he had, in the interim, journeyed through experiences that had undeniably altered him, leaving a lasting mark. He had undergone changes he could never reverse. "You see," he explained, "I was genuinely eager to understand what kind of unusual person, what kind of social outcast, I appeared to her, considering her values and my upbringing." Kate was silent for a moment.

Then she asked, "Why do you care?" "Well," he laughed, "I like her a lot. And for someone in my line of work, her perspectives and her personality are essential to understand. They represent the broad public opinion we always encounter, the one we have to constantly try to relate to.

Translation

"Why do you care, then?" she asked.

He laughed. "Because I really like her. And for someone in my position, understanding her viewpoints and her character is crucial. She embodies the general public's opinions, the ones we're always dealing with, the ones we're constantly trying to connect with."

Besides," he added, "I want to make her happy." "Oh yes, we must make her happy!" his companion repeated. These words perhaps represented their clear understanding of Densher's strategic advantage. They had many things to discuss between then and his trip to New York, and the question he'd raised was especially important to Kate.

Translation

"Also," he added, "I want to make her happy." "Of course, we must make her happy!" his companion echoed. Perhaps these words signaled their comprehension of Densher's strategic advantage. They had much to discuss before his trip to New York, and the question he'd posed was particularly important to Kate.

She looked at him as if he had revealed more to her aunt about his personal life than he had ever revealed to her. If that was the case, it was unplanned, and for half an hour, he described his early years abroad, his constantly moving parents, his Swiss schools, his German university, as much as she could easily pay attention to. He implied that anyone familiar with their world would immediately recognize these details; anyone who understood their social circles would have already experienced the established English ways. But it was still delightful to confide in a woman; women, in fact, possessed more imagination when it came to understanding these differences.

Translation

She stared at him, as if he'd told her aunt things about himself that he'd never told her. If that was true, it was accidental. For thirty minutes, he described his childhood overseas, his parents' constant travels, his Swiss schools, his German university, as much as she could focus on. He hinted that anyone familiar with their world would instantly understand these details; anyone who knew their social set would be familiar with English traditions. But it was still wonderful to confide in a woman; women, in fact, were better at imagining these differences.

Kate displayed all the concern he could want; after she had heard his whole story, she said she now understood more than ever why she loved him. She, as a child, had lived for some time in Europe, returning home while still young; and then, as a teenager, she'd been part of her mother's brief but repeated trips to Dresden, Florence, and Biarritz, attempts at cost-cutting that were both weak and expensive. Yet, despite generally avoiding passionate displays, she had retained a deep appreciation for European culture. When it became apparent to her just how many European influences shaped Merton Densher, more than he had previously detailed, she practically regarded him as if he were a map of the continent or a wonderful new "Murray" travel guide.

Translation

Kate showed all the interest he could have hoped for. After she'd heard his story, she said she understood more than ever why she loved him. She herself had spent time in Europe as a child, before coming back to the States young. And as a teen, she'd gone with her mother on her frequent, fleeting trips to Dresden, Florence, and Biarritz. These were cheap efforts that ended up being both unsuccessful and costly. Even though she wasn't usually one for passionate shows of emotion, she still had a profound fondness for European culture. When she realized how many European influences had formed Merton Densher, more than he'd let on before, she basically looked at him like he was a map of the continent or a great new "Murray" guidebook.

He hadn't meant to boast; he'd wanted to make a case for himself, though with Mrs. Lowder, he'd also wanted to clarify things a bit. His father had been a British chaplain, either permanently or occasionally, in various foreign countries and English communities, and had been fortunate enough to always have work. His career abroad had therefore been continuous, and since his salary had never been substantial, he had educated his children at the lowest possible cost, in the nearest schools, which also saved on travel expenses.

Translation

He hadn't intended to brag; he'd just wanted to plead his case, although with Mrs. Lowder, he'd also hoped to clear up some confusion. His father, a British chaplain, had served either full-time or intermittently in different foreign countries and English communities, and he'd always been able to find employment. His career overseas had thus been uninterrupted, and since his income had never been high, he'd educated his children as cheaply as possible, at the closest schools, which also kept down the cost of travel.

It also turned out that Densher's mother had been a talented artist, and this period of exile had significantly contributed to her success. She was a dedicated copyist of famous paintings in major museums, having started with a natural gift and recognized her opportunity early on. Copyists were common abroad, but Mrs. Densher had unique talent and skill, achieving a level of perfection that was persuasive, even deceptive, making the sale of her work easy.

Translation

It also happened that Densher’s mother had been a gifted artist, and this time away from England was key to her accomplishments. She had diligently copied famous paintings in prominent museums, building on a natural talent and seeing an opportunity early on. Though copyists were common overseas, Mrs. Densher was unusually talented and skilled, reaching a level of perfection that was convincing, even misleading, which made selling her work easy.

Her son, who had lost her, cherished her memory. Describing her to Kate, along with other previously obscure details, made his past richer, his roots more complex, and his character anything but ordinary. He had, he insisted repeatedly, become a true Briton: his years at Cambridge, his positive connection, as it turned out, with his father's college, confirmed that, not to mention his subsequent move to London, which completed the picture. However, even with his firm grounding in English life, he had journeyed through experiences that had changed him forever.

Translation

Her son, who mourned her passing, treasured her memory. Recounting her to Kate, along with previously unknown facts, deepened his past, complicated his origins, and made his personality anything but simple. He had, he continually stressed, become a true Englishman: his time at Cambridge, his unexpected affinity for his father's college, confirmed this, not to mention his later move to London, which completed the picture. However, despite his solid foundation in English life, he had undergone experiences that had irrevocably altered him.

Something had happened to him that he could never reverse. When Kate Croy said to him as much he besought her not to insist, declaring that this indeed was what was too much the matter with him, that he had been but too probably spoiled for native, for insular use. On which, not unnaturally, she insisted the more, assuring him, without mitigation, that if he was complicated and brilliant she wouldn't for the world have had him any thing less; so that he was reduced in the end to accusing her of putting the dreadful truth to him in the hollow guise of flattery. She was making out how abnormal he was in order that she might eventually find him impossible; and, as she could fully make it out but with his aid, she had to bribe him by feigned delight to help her.

Translation

Something had happened to him, something he could never undo. When Kate Croy said as much to him, he begged her not to dwell on it, saying that was precisely his problem, that he had probably been ruined for a normal, insular life. Naturally, she pressed him further, assuring him, without qualification, that if he was complicated and brilliant, she wouldn't change a thing. In the end, he accused her of disguising the awful truth as flattery. She was highlighting his abnormality so that she could ultimately declare him impossible. And since she could only fully establish it with his help, she had to bribe him with pretended admiration to cooperate.

If her last word for him, in the connection, was that the way he saw himself was just a precious proof the more of his having tasted of the tree and being thereby prepared to assist her to eat, this gives the happy tone of their whole talk, the measure of the flight of time in the near presence of his settled departure. Kate showed, however, that she was to be more literally taken when she spoke of the relief Aunt Maud would draw from the prospect of his absence. When Kate Croy told him that, he begged her not to dwell on it, saying that was exactly the problem: he'd likely been ruined for his home country, for living on an island. Unsurprisingly, she pushed harder, assuring him directly that if he was complicated and brilliant, she wouldn't have him any other way.

Translation

If her final assessment of him, in this context, was that his self-perception was just further, precious proof that he had tasted the forbidden fruit and was thus prepared to help her eat it too, then this describes the overall mood of their conversation, the sense of time passing quickly with his impending departure looming. Kate, however, demonstrated that she was to be taken more literally when she mentioned the relief Aunt Maud would feel at the prospect of his absence. When Kate Croy said this to him, he begged her not to dwell on it, saying that was precisely the problem: he was probably ruined for his homeland, for an insular existence. Unsurprisingly, she pressed him further, assuring him without hesitation that if he was complicated and brilliant, she wouldn't change a thing.

Finally, he accused her of using flattery to disguise the awful truth. She was portraying him as abnormal so she could ultimately declare him unsuitable. Since she needed his help to fully succeed, she was bribing him with feigned pleasure to cooperate. If her final assessment was that his self-perception was just another piece of evidence that he'd eaten from the tree of knowledge and was therefore ready to help her do the same, it captured the joyful spirit of their entire conversation, the rapid passage of time while he prepared to leave.

Translation

At last, he accused her of using flattery to hide the awful truth. She was painting him as abnormal, so she could ultimately declare him unacceptable. Since she needed his help to fully succeed, she was bribing him with feigned pleasure to cooperate. If her ultimate judgment was that his self-perception was just further proof that he had tasted the fruit of knowledge and was thus prepared to help her do the same, then this captured the joyful spirit of their entire conversation, the rapid passage of time while he prepared to leave.

However, Kate proved she was also being literal when she mentioned the relief Aunt Maud would feel about his departure. "Yet one can scarcely see why," he replied, "when she fears me so little." His friend weighed his objection. "Your idea is that she likes you so much that she'll even go so far as to regret losing you?"

Translation

But Kate showed that she also meant what she said when she spoke of Aunt Maud's relief at his leaving. "Still, it's hard to see why," he answered, "given how little she fears me." His friend considered his point. "You're suggesting she likes you so much that she'll even miss you?"

Well, he saw it in their constant comprehensive way. "Since what she builds on is the gradual process of your alienation, she may take the view that the process constantly requires me. Mustn't I be there to keep it going? It's in my exile that it may languish."

Translation

He understood the reasoning behind their constant, all-encompassing strategy. "Considering her foundation rests on your growing estrangement, she might believe that I'm perpetually necessary. Wouldn't I have to be present to sustain it? It's in my absence that it could falter."

He went on with that fantasy, but at this point Kate ceased to attend. He saw after a little that she had been following some thought of her own, and he had been feeling the growth of something determinant even through the extravagance of much of the pleasantry, the warm, transparent irony, into which their livelier intimacy kept plunging like a confident swimmer. Suddenly she said to him with extraordinary beauty: "I engage myself to you for ever." "I don't understand," he responded, "since she doesn't seem to be afraid of me."

Translation

He continued with his imagined scenario, but Kate had stopped paying attention. After a moment, he realized she'd become lost in her own thoughts, and he'd felt something concrete developing, even through the abundance of charm, the warm, clear irony, into which their deepening closeness repeatedly plunged like a self-assured swimmer. Abruptly, she said to him, her beauty striking, "I commit myself to you, eternally." "I don't understand," he replied, "given that she doesn't appear to fear me."

His friend considered his point. "You think she likes you so much that she'll be upset if she loses you?" He understood her perspective within their ongoing dynamic. "Because she's banking on you pushing me away, she might believe she needs me to keep that going.

Translation

His friend pondered his statement. "You think she's so into you that she'd be unhappy to lose you?" He saw her angle in their complicated dance. "Since she's betting on you pushing me away, she might think she needs me to keep that up."

My absence could undermine her plan." He continued with that thought, but Kate lost interest. He realized she'd been occupied by her own thoughts. He'd sensed something significant developing beneath the surface of their playful banter, their warm, clear irony, which their deepening connection embraced with ease.

Translation

"My being gone could mess up her strategy." He went on, but Kate's attention had drifted. He saw she was caught up in something of her own. He had felt something important stirring underneath their lighthearted back-and-forth, their easy, affectionate sarcasm, which their growing bond absorbed effortlessly.

Suddenly, she declared to him with stunning beauty, "I commit myself to you forever." The beauty was in everything, and he could have separated nothing—couldn't have thought of her face as distinct from the whole joy. Yet her face had a new light. "And I pledge you—I call God to witness!—every spark of my faith; I give you every drop of my life." That was all, for the moment, but it was enough, and it was almost as quiet as if it were nothing.

Translation

Suddenly, she told him, stunningly beautiful, "I commit myself to you forever." The beauty was everywhere, and he couldn't have separated anything—couldn't have thought of her face as distinct from the joy. Yet her face had a new light. "And I pledge you—I call God to witness!—every spark of my faith; I give you every drop of my life." That was all, for the moment, but it was enough, and it was almost as quiet as if it were nothing.

They were in the open air, in an alley of the Gardens; the great space, which seemed to arch just then higher and spread wider for them, threw them back into deep concentration. They moved by a common instinct to a spot, within sight, that struck them as fairly sequestered, and there, before their time together was spent, they had extorted from concentration every advance it could make them. They had exchanged vows and tokens, sealed their rich compact, solemnized, so far as breathed words and murmured sounds and lighted eyes and clasped hands could do it, their agreement to belong only, and to belong tremendously, to each other. They were to leave the place accordingly an affianced couple; but before they left it other things still had passed.

Translation

They were outside, in a garden alley. The expanse seemed to swell above them, to widen for them, and this brought them to a profound focus. They went, as if by mutual understanding, to a place that felt somewhat secluded. There, before their time was up, they had taken from their concentration all the progress it could offer. They had exchanged promises and keepsakes, solidified their significant agreement, and made solemn, as best as words and murmurs and shining eyes and clasped hands could, their commitment to each other, and to each other entirely. They would leave as an engaged couple, but before they left, other things had occurred.

Densher had declared his horror of bringing to a premature end her happy relation with her aunt; and they had worked round together to a high level of wisdom and patience. Kate's free profession was that she wished not to deprive him of Mrs. Lowder's countenance, which, in the long run, she was convinced he would continue to enjoy; and as, by a blessed turn, Aunt Maud had demanded of him no promise that would tie his hands, they should be able to cultivate their destiny in their own way and yet remain loyal. One difficulty alone stood out, which Densher named.

Translation

Densher had declared his horror of ending prematurely her happy relationship with her aunt, and together they had navigated their way to a place of wisdom and patience. Kate's freely stated wish was that she didn't want to deprive him of Mrs. Lowder's good opinion, which, in the long run, she was sure he would continue to enjoy. And because, by a stroke of luck, Aunt Maud had asked nothing of him that would bind him, they would be able to pursue their destiny as they wished and still remain loyal. Only one difficulty remained, which Densher pointed out.

The beauty was everywhere, and he couldn't separate anything—couldn't think of her face as separate from all the joy. Yet her face had a new light. "And I promise you—I call God to witness!—every bit of my faith; I give you my entire life." That was all, for now, but it was enough, and it was almost as quiet as if it were nothing. They were outside, in a path in the Gardens; the wide space, which seemed to arch higher and spread wider just for them, made them deeply focused.

Translation

Beauty surrounded him, and he couldn't isolate anything. He couldn't consider her face separate from the joy. But her face now held a new radiance. "I promise you—and I call God as my witness!—every ounce of my faith. I give you my whole life." That was all, for the moment, but it was sufficient. It was almost as silent as if nothing was said. They were outside, on a path in the Gardens. The vast expanse, which seemed to swell and open just for them, intensified their focus.

They moved together by instinct to a spot, within sight, that seemed secluded, and there, before their time together was over, they had taken from their concentration every advantage it could give them. They had exchanged vows and tokens, sealed their rich agreement, and confirmed, as much as words, murmurs, bright eyes, and clasped hands could, their promise to belong only, and completely, to each other. They were to leave the place as an engaged couple; but before they left, more had happened. Densher had expressed his fear of ending her happy relationship with her aunt too soon; and they had come to a wise and patient understanding.

Translation

They instinctively gravitated to a nearby, secluded spot, and there, before their time ran out, they capitalized on their shared focus. They exchanged promises and gifts, solidifying their profound agreement, and confirming, as much as words, whispers, bright gazes, and intertwined hands could, their commitment to each other, exclusively and entirely. They would depart as an engaged couple; but before they left, more had occurred. Densher had voiced his concern about abruptly disrupting her contentment with her aunt, and they had reached a sensible and tolerant understanding.

Kate freely admitted that she didn't want to prevent him from maintaining a good relationship with Mrs. Lowder, which she believed he would continue to enjoy; and because, fortunately, Aunt Maud hadn't asked him for a promise that would limit him, they could pursue their destiny in their own way and still remain loyal. Only one difficulty remained, which Densher mentioned. "Of course it will never do—we must remember that—from the moment you allow her to found hopes of you for any one else in particular.

Translation

Kate readily conceded that she wouldn't stand in the way of his continuing a good relationship with Mrs. Lowder, which she assumed he would want to keep; and because, luckily, Aunt Maud hadn't demanded a commitment from him that would tie him down, they could follow their own path and remain true to her. Only one hurdle persisted, which Densher brought up. "Obviously it won't work—we have to remember that—from the moment you let her begin to have expectations of you for anyone else."

So long as her view is content to remain as general as at present appears, I don't see that we deceive her. At a given moment, you see, she must be undeceived: the only thing therefore is to be ready for the moment and to face it. Only, after all, in that case," the young man observed, "one doesn't quite make out what we shall have got from her." "What she'll have got from us?" Kate inquired with a smile.

Translation

"As long as her view is content to stay as broad as it seems to be now, I don't think we're deceiving her. At some point, you see, she'll have to be disillusioned: so the only thing is to be ready for the moment and to face it. Though, in that case," the young man observed, "it's not quite clear what we'll have gotten from her." "What she'll have gotten from us?" Kate asked with a smile.

"What she'll have got from us," the girl went on, "is her own affair—it's for her to measure. I asked her for nothing," she added; "I never put myself upon her. She must take her risks, and she surely understands them. What we shall have got from her is what we've already spoken of," Kate further explained; "it's that we shall have gained time.

Translation

"What she'll have gotten from us," the girl continued, "is her own business—it's up to her to decide. I didn't ask her for anything," she added; "I never imposed myself on her. She has to take her chances, and she certainly understands them. What we'll have gotten from her is what we've already discussed," Kate further explained; "it's that we'll have gained time."

And so, for that matter, will she." We can't let this continue – we need to remember that – from the moment you let her believe that you might be interested in someone else. As long as her expectations are as vague as they seem to be now, I don't think we're misleading her. Eventually, you see, she will need to be told the truth; the only thing to do is to be prepared for that moment and face it.

Translation

And she will too. We can't let this go on – we have to remember that – from the moment you let her believe you might be interested in someone else. As long as her expectations are as undefined as they are now, I don't think we're being dishonest with her. Ultimately, you see, she will need to be told the truth; the only thing to do is be ready for that moment and confront it.

But, in that case," the young man said, "I'm not sure what we'll get out of her." "What she'll get from us?" Kate asked with a smile. "What she'll get from us," the girl continued, "is her own business – she can decide that. I didn't ask her for anything," she added; "I never took advantage of her.

Translation

"But in that case," the young man said, "I don't see what we gain from her."

"What she gains from us?" Kate asked with a smile.

"What she gains from us," the girl continued, "is her own concern – she can figure that out. I didn't ask her for anything," she added; "I never took advantage of her."

She has to accept the risks, and I'm sure she understands them. What we'll get from her is what we've already discussed," Kate explained; "it's that we'll have bought ourselves some time. And so, for that matter, will she." Densher gazed a little at all this clearness; his gaze was not at the present hour into romantic obscurity.

Translation

She has to take the chances, and I'm sure she knows that. What we get from her is what we already talked about," Kate said, "which is that we've bought ourselves some time. And, for that matter, so has she." Densher stared at the obviousness of it all; his gaze wasn't lost in romantic fog at the moment.

"Yes; no doubt, in our particular situation, time's everything. And then there's the joy of it." She hesitated. "Of our secret?"

Translation

"Yes, undoubtedly, in our specific circumstances, time is of the essence. And then there's the pleasure of it." She paused. "Of our secret?"

"Not so much perhaps of our secret in itself, but of what's represented and, as we must somehow feel, protected and made deeper and closer by it." And his fine face, relaxed into happiness, covered her with all his meaning. "Our being as we are." It was as if for a moment she let the meaning sink into her. "So gone?"

Translation

"Perhaps not so much the secret itself, but what it symbolizes. What it protects, deepens, and makes more intimate." His handsome face, softened with joy, conveyed his entire meaning. "Our existence, as we are." As if she allowed the significance to settle within her for a moment. "So, vanished?"

"So gone. So extremely gone. However," he smiled, "we shall go a good deal further." Her answer to which was only the softness of her silence—a silence that looked out for them both at the far reach of their prospect. This was immense, and they thus took final possession of it.

Translation

"Gone, then. Utterly gone. Though," he smiled, "we have further to go." Her response was simply the yielding of her silence—a silence that observed their shared future from its furthest point. The scope of their future was immense, and they claimed it then and there.

They were practically united and they were splendidly strong; but there were other things—things they were precisely strong enough to be able successfully to count with and safely to allow for; in consequence of which they would, for the present, subject to some better reason, keep their understanding to themselves. It was not indeed, however, till after one more observation of Densher's that they felt the question completely straightened out. "The only thing of course is that she may any day absolutely put it to you." Densher considered the situation, fully aware of its implications.

Translation

They were virtually a single entity and possessed a magnificent strength. But certain other factors existed—factors they were just powerful enough to acknowledge and account for without endangering themselves. Therefore, barring compelling reason to the contrary, they would keep their agreement private, for now. It wasn't until Densher made one final observation that the matter felt fully resolved. "The only real possibility, of course, is that she could ask you directly, at any moment." Densher considered the situation, fully aware of its implications.

He wasn't interested in any romantic fantasies at the moment. "Yes, time is crucial given our circumstances. And there's also the pleasure of it." She paused.

Translation

He had no interest in romantic notions. "Yes, the clock is ticking, considering the situation. And the fun of it, too." She stopped speaking.

"Of our secret?" "Not necessarily the secret itself, but what it represents, what it shields and intensifies, as we both realize. Our connection, how we are together." His handsome features softened with happiness, conveying his feelings completely. "Our relationship, exactly as it is."

Translation

"About what we're hiding?" "Not just the secret, but what it means, what it protects and makes stronger, as we both know. Our bond, how we're together." His attractive face lit up, and his feelings were obvious. "Our relationship, precisely as it is."
