She seemed to absorb the idea for a moment. "So, that's it?" "It's finished. Utterly finished.

Translation

She appeared to consider the thought for a beat. "Is that the end, then?" "It's over. Completely over."

But," he smiled, "we're going to keep going, moving forward." Her only response was a gentle silence, anticipating the future they envisioned. The possibilities were endless, and they embraced them fully. They were essentially together and incredibly resilient. However, there were other factors—things they were strong enough to acknowledge and account for.

Translation

"But," he said with a smile, "we're going to keep moving, keep going." Her only answer was a soft silence, a silent expectation of the future they were building. The possibilities were infinite, and they welcomed them wholeheartedly. They were fundamentally together and incredibly strong. However, there were other considerations—things they were strong enough to accept and manage.

Therefore, unless they had a compelling reason to change, they would keep their understanding private for now. It wasn't until Densher made one final point that the issue was truly settled. "The only real concern is that she might confront you about it any day now." Kate considered.

Translation

So, unless there was a good reason to do otherwise, they’d keep their arrangement a secret, at least for the time being. The matter was finally settled when Densher made a concluding remark. "The only thing is, she could ask you about it at any moment.” Kate pondered this.

"Ask me where, on my honour, we are? She may, naturally; but I doubt if in fact she will. While you're away she'll make the most of it. She'll leave me alone."

Translation

"Ask me where, on my word of honor, we are? She might, of course; but I doubt she actually will. While you're gone she'll enjoy the situation. She'll leave me to my own devices."

"But there'll be my letters." The girl faced his letters. "Very, very many?" "Very, very, very many—more than ever; and you know what that is!

Translation

"But there will be my letters." The girl's gaze fell on his letters. "A great many?" "A great, great, great many—more than you can possibly imagine; and you know what that means!"

And then," Densher added, "there'll be yours." "Oh, I shan't leave mine on the hall-table. I shall post them myself." He looked at her a moment.

Translation

"And then," Densher added, "there'll be yours."

"Oh, I won't leave mine on the hall table. I'll mail them myself."

He looked at her for a moment.

"Do you think then I had best address you elsewhere?" After which, before she could quite answer, he added with some emphasis: "I'd rather not, you know. It's straighter." She might again have just waited. "Of course it's straighter.

Translation

"Do you think, then, I should send them somewhere else?" After which, before she could quite respond, he added with some emphasis: "I'd really prefer not to, you know. It's more direct." She might have just waited again. "Of course, it's more direct."

Don't be afraid I shan't be straight. Address me," she continued, "where you like. I shall be proud enough of its being known you write to me." Kate paused to think.

Translation

Don't worry, I won't be evasive. Write to me," she continued, "wherever you want. I'll be thrilled that people know you're writing to me." Kate paused, considering.

"She might ask me, on my word of honor, where we are. It's possible; though I don't think she will. While you're gone, she'll take full advantage. She'll leave me alone."

Translation

"She could ask me, on my word, about our location. It's a possibility, though I doubt she will. While you're away, she'll exploit the situation. She'll leave me to myself."

"But there will be my letters." The girl considered his letters. "A great many?" "A great, great many—more than ever; and you understand what that means!

Translation

"But there will be my letters." The girl pondered his letters. "A substantial number?" "An enormous number—more than ever before; and you grasp the significance of that!"

And then," Densher added, "there will be yours." "Oh, I won't leave mine lying around. I'll mail them myself." He looked at her for a moment.

Translation

"And then," Densher added, "there will be yours." "Oh, I won't leave mine lying around. I'll mail them myself." He looked at her for a moment.

"Do you think I should send them somewhere else?" Then, before she could reply, he added emphatically, "I'd prefer not to. It's more direct." She could have hesitated again. "Of course it's more direct.

Translation

"Do you think I should send them somewhere else?" Then, before she could respond, he said firmly, "I'd rather not. It's more straightforward." She could have paused again. "Of course it's more straightforward.

Don't worry, I'll be honest. Send them wherever you like. I'll be proud to have it known that you're writing to me." He turned it over for the last clearness.

Translation

Don't worry, I'll be upfront. Send them anywhere you want. I'll be glad to have it known that you're writing to me." He considered this for the final time.

"Even at the risk of its really bringing down the inquisition?" Well, the last clearness now filled her. "I'm not afraid of the inquisition. If she asks if there's anything definite between us, I know perfectly what I shall say."

Translation

"Even if it means really incurring the inquisition's wrath?" Well, understanding finally dawned on her. "I'm not afraid of the inquisition. If she asks if anything concrete has happened between us, I know exactly what I'll say."

"That I am, of course, 'gone' for you?" "That I love you as I shall never in my life love any one else, and that she can make what she likes of that." She said it out so splendidly that it was like a new profession of faith, the fulness of a tide breaking through; and the effect of that, in turn, was to make her companion meet her with such eyes that she had time again before he could otherwise speak. "Besides, she's just as likely to ask you." He considered it one last time, trying to be absolutely certain.

Translation

"That I am, of course, 'gone' for you?" "That I love you as I shall never in my life love anyone else, and that she can make what she likes of that." She said it with such confidence it was like a new profession of faith, the fullness of a tide breaking through; and the effect of that, in turn, was to make her companion meet her with such eyes that she had time again before he could otherwise speak. "Besides, she's just as likely to ask you." He considered it one last time, trying to be absolutely certain.

"Even if it provokes a huge scandal?" Well, she now understood everything perfectly. "I'm not worried about a scandal. If she asks if there's anything serious between us, I know exactly what I'll say."

Translation

"Even if it causes a massive scandal?" She finally understood everything clearly. "I'm not concerned about a scandal. If she asks if there's anything serious between us, I know precisely what I'll say."

"That I'm completely devoted to you, of course?" "That I love you more than I'll ever love anyone, and she can interpret that however she wants." She declared it so beautifully that it was like a fresh statement of belief, a surging wave breaking through; and the effect was such that her companion responded with such a look that she had time to react before he could speak. "Besides, she's just as likely to ask you." "Not while I'm away."

Translation

"That I'm completely devoted to you, of course?" "That I love you more than I'll ever love anyone, and she can interpret that however she wants." She spoke with such beauty that it was like a renewed oath, a surging wave breaking; and the effect was such that her companion responded with a look that gave her time to react before he could speak. "Besides, she's just as likely to ask you." "Not while I'm away."

"Then when you come back." "Well then," said Densher, "we shall have had our particular joy. But what I feel is," he candidly added, "that, by an idea of her own, her superior policy, she won't ask me. She'll let me off.

Translation

"Then when you come back." "Well then," said Densher, "we shall have had our own private joy. But what I feel is," he honestly added, "that, thanks to an idea of her own, her superior strategy, she won't ask me. She'll let me off."

I shan't have to lie to her." "It will be left all to me?" asked Kate. "All to you!" he tenderly laughed. But it was, oddly, the very next moment as if he had perhaps been a shade too candid.

Translation

"I won't have to lie to her." "It's all left to me then?" Kate asked. "All to you!" he laughed tenderly. But it was, oddly enough, the very next moment as if he had perhaps been a bit too candid.

His discrimination seemed to mark a possible, a natural reality, a reality not wholly disallowed by the account the girl had just given of her own intention. There was a difference in the air—even if none other than the supposedly usual difference in truth between man and woman; and it was almost as if the sense of this provoked her. She seemed to cast about an instant, and then she went back a little resentfully to something she had suffered to pass a minute before. She appeared to take up rather more seriously than she need the joke about her freedom to deceive.

Translation

His judgment seemed to indicate a potential, an inherent truth, a reality not entirely contradicted by the account the girl had just given of her intention. There was a shift in the atmosphere—even if it was nothing more than the typical difference in truth between men and women; and it was almost as if the awareness of this irritated her. She seemed to hesitate for a moment, and then she went back a little resentfully to something she had ignored a minute before. She appeared to take more seriously than necessary the joke about her freedom to deceive.

Yet she did this too in a beautiful way. "Men are too stupid—even you. You didn't understand just now why, if I post my letters myself, it won't be for any thing so vulgar as to hide them." "Not while I'm gone."

Translation

And she did it beautifully, too. "Men are so stupid—even you. You didn't get it a second ago, how posting my own letters wouldn't be about something as vulgar as hiding them." "Not while I'm away."

"Then when you return." "Well," Densher said, "we'll have had our special pleasure. But what I feel is," he admitted openly, "that, because of something she's decided, her clever strategy, she won't ask me. She'll let me off the hook.

Translation

"Then when you get back." "Well," Densher said, "we'll have had our fun. But what I feel is," he admitted frankly, "that, because of something she's decided, her clever strategy, she won't ask me. She'll let me off the hook."

I won't have to lie to her." "It'll all be left to me?" Kate asked. "All to you!" he laughed affectionately. But it was, strangely, the very next second as if he might have been a bit too honest.

Translation

"I won't have to lie to her." "It will all be left to me?" Kate asked. "All to you!" he laughed affectionately. But, strangely, the very next second, it was as if he might have been a bit too honest.

His assessment seemed to suggest a possible, likely truth, a truth not entirely contradicted by what the girl had just said about her own plan. There was a subtle shift in the atmosphere—even if it was nothing more than the usual difference in honesty between men and women; and it was almost as if this realization annoyed her. She seemed to pause for a moment, and then she returned a little resentfully to something she'd let slide a moment earlier. She appeared to take the joke about her freedom to deceive more seriously than she needed to.

Translation

His judgment seemed to imply a possible, likely truth, one that wasn't completely disproven by what the girl had just said about her own plan. The atmosphere subtly changed—even if it was nothing more than the usual disparity in candor between men and women; and it was almost as if this realization bothered her. She seemed to hesitate, and then she returned, a little resentfully, to something she'd glossed over a moment before. She seemed to take the joke about her freedom to deceive more seriously than she should have.

Yet she did this beautifully too. "Men are too clueless—even you. You didn't understand just now why, if I mail my letters myself, it won't be for something as simple as hiding them." "Oh, you said—for the pleasure."

Translation

And she managed this perfectly as well. "Men are incredibly dense—even you are. You didn't realize a moment ago that if I'm the one mailing the letters, it's not simply to hide them." "Oh, you said—for the pleasure."

"Yes; but you didn't, you don't understand what the pleasure may be. There are refinements——!" she more patiently dropped. "I mean of consciousness, of sensation, of appreciation," she went on. "No," she sadly insisted—"men don't know.

Translation

"Yes; but you don't understand, you don't grasp what the pleasure can be. There are subtleties—!" she said, more patiently. "I mean of consciousness, of sensation, of appreciation," she continued. "No," she sadly insisted—"men don't know."

They know, in such matters, almost nothing but what women show them." This was one of the speeches, frequent in her, that, liberally, joyfully, intensely adopted and, in itself, as might be, embraced, drew him again as close to her, and held him as long, as their conditions permitted. "Then that's exactly why we've such an abysmal need of you!"

Translation

"They know, in these things, almost nothing except what women reveal to them." This was one of her frequent pronouncements, one that she generously, joyfully, and intensely seized upon, and which, as though it were a separate entity, drew him close to her again and kept him there as long as circumstances allowed. "Then that's precisely why we depend on you so completely!"

Chapter 5

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

Two women are traveling together through the Brünig Pass in Switzerland. They stop for lunch and decide to extend their stay. The elder woman, Mrs. Stringham, makes the arrangements. The younger woman, Milly Theale, wanders off alone.

After an hour, Mrs. Stringham goes to find Milly. She follows a footpath up a hillside and asks an old woman at some chalets for directions. Continuing on, she finds a book Milly had been carrying left on a rock. Mrs. Stringham then sees Milly sitting on a slab of rock at the edge of a steep precipice.

Mrs. Stringham watches her from a distance without being seen. After a time, she quietly withdraws, returning the way she came. She stops at the book, writes "à bientôt!" on the cover, and leaves it there. Mrs. Stringham returns to their inn to wait. Late in the afternoon, Milly reappears.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

This collection of texts, seemingly fragments from a larger work (strongly resembling Henry James's *The Wings of the Dove*), provides a rich ground for literary analysis. Through the intricate consciousness of an observer, Mrs. Susan Stringham, the narrative explores profound themes of perception, identity, and the chasm between American innocence and European experience. The character of Milly Theale emerges not through direct action, but as a powerful, enigmatic presence refracted through the lens of her companion's devoted and analytical mind.

### Themes

**1. Perception vs. Reality: The Observer and the Observed** The central theme is the nature of perception itself. The narrative is overwhelmingly focalized through Mrs. Stringham, whose "fine cloud of observation and suspicion" colors every scene. Milly Theale is less a character we know directly and more a phenomenon to be interpreted. The text acknowledges this, stating, "we shall really ourselves scarce otherwise come closer to her than by feeling their impression and sharing, if need be, their confusion."

Mrs. Stringham's role evolves from that of a curious acquaintance to an almost scientific analyst, a "spy" who is "applying tests, laying traps, concealing signs." Her mission is to unlock the "key of knowledge" to Milly's essence. This dynamic raises questions about the reliability of her vision. Is the "greatness" she perceives in Milly an objective reality, or is it a projection of her own desires for a life more profound than her own "prosaically usual" existence? The text suggests both are true; Milly possesses an inherent power, but it is Mrs. Stringham's refined consciousness that gives it a name and a narrative.

**2. The "Real Thing" versus Representation** A key tension exists between lived experience and its artistic or intellectual representation. Mrs. Stringham is a writer, a woman who has made a name for herself by contributing "short stories to the best magazines" and consciously curating her literary tastes. Her life is one of order, intellect, and representation. However, she recognizes in Milly "the real thing, the romantic life itself," a force so potent it makes her "hand a while tremble too much for the pen."

Milly's life story is described as a "New York legend" and a "poetry" and "history" finer than that of esteemed authors. Mrs. Stringham’s carefully constructed world of literature and Bostonian probity pales in comparison to the raw, unwritten drama that Milly embodies. This theme culminates in Mrs. Stringham’s realization that her own life is over; she has "renounced that character" to become a vessel for leading "Milly's own." Art and intellect, in this context, are not the peak of existence but a preparation for recognizing and serving life at its most intense.

**3. American Identity and the European Experience** The text is steeped in the classic Jamesian theme of the encounter between the New World and the Old. Milly is the quintessential American product: an heiress of immense, almost mythical, wealth born from "wild cosmopolite backward generations." She is defined by her "New York mourning, New York hair, a New York history," signifying a scale of tragedy and possibility that requires a "greater stage" than even Boston can provide.

Paradoxically, this "heiress of all the ages" is "starved for culture." She comes to Europe, the "great American sedative," not for rest but with a "high restlessness." The journey through Switzerland and Italy is a pilgrimage where her American "intensity" is set against the backdrop of European history and landscape. Mrs. Stringham, having had her own European education, acts as the cultural guide, the bridge between Milly’s raw potential and the Old World’s deep-seated knowledge.

**4. Freedom, Fate, and the Burden of Being** Milly possesses "boundless freedom, the freedom of the wind in the desert," a liberty underwritten by her immense wealth. Yet, this freedom is also a profound burden. Her money is not a tool but an inescapable part of her identity: "She couldn't have lost it if she had tried—that was what it was to be really rich. It had to be the thing you were."

This paradox is powerfully symbolized in the scene on the Brünig pass. Seated on the "dizzy edge" of a precipice, Milly has the ultimate freedom to choose her fate. Mrs. Stringham’s initial fear is of suicide, a "sharp or simple release." However, her deeper perception reveals the opposite: Milly is not contemplating escape but is in a state of "uplifted and unlimited possession," looking down on the "kingdoms of the earth." The revelation is that her destiny is not to leap away from life, but "of taking full in the face the whole assault of life." Her freedom does not exempt her from the human predicament; it amplifies it.

### Character Development

**Susan Shepherd Stringham:** Mrs. Stringham undergoes a profound internal transformation. Initially, she is a woman defined by her past—her respectable widowhood, her European schooling, her modest literary career. Her life is "small," contained, and prides itself on its "Boston probity." The arrival of Milly is a "revelation" that shatters this containment. She finds in Milly an object worthy of complete devotion, a purpose that eclipses her own identity. Her development is a journey of surrender: she gives up her life to vicariously experience Milly's, becoming the ultimate confidant whose own emotions are subsumed by the "princess" she serves. She moves from intellectual analysis to a state of awe-filled, protective love.

**Milly Theale:** Milly’s development is one of deepening mystery and emerging power. She is first introduced as a "striking apparition," a collection of tragic and romantic attributes: an orphan, immensely rich, strangely beautiful, and marked by sorrow. As the narrative progresses, these external markers give way to an indefinable inner force. Her "restlessness" and "vagueness" are not signs of weakness but of a spirit too large for conventional expression. The climactic scene on the precipice is not an action but a state of being, revealing her essential character. She is not a passive victim of her tragic history but an active, sovereign consciousness preparing to engage with a complex and challenging destiny. She is a force that "draws feet of water" like a great steamer, pulling others into her powerful wake.

### Major Literary Ideas

**Focalization and Psychological Realism:** The text is a masterclass in psychological realism, achieved through a tightly controlled third-person limited point of view. By remaining almost exclusively within Mrs. Stringham's consciousness, the author immerses the reader in the process of interpretation. The long, subordinate clauses and intricate sentences mirror the complex, unfolding nature of thought and perception. This technique makes Milly a captivating enigma, as we are forced to piece her together from Mrs. Stringham's impressions, suspicions, and revelations.

**Symbolism:** The narrative is rich with symbolism that elevates the personal drama to a universal level. * **Milly as a "Princess":** This metaphor establishes a social and existential hierarchy. Milly is not bound by ordinary rules; she lives in a realm of "court life without the hardships," where practical difficulties do not exist. This makes her both magnificent and tragically isolated. * **The Precipice:** The most potent symbol in the text, it represents the intersection of ultimate freedom and unavoidable fate. It is a place of sublime perspective and mortal danger, where Milly’s true character is revealed not by what she does, but by the sheer force of her presence and contemplation. * **The Mine:** Mrs. Stringham’s final thought of Milly as a "mine of something precious" that "but needed working" encapsulates her entire project. Milly is a source of immense, untapped value (and "she was not thinking, either, of Milly's gold"), and Mrs. Stringham sees it as her life’s work to excavate that spiritual and existential treasure.

In conclusion, these texts construct a powerful and nuanced psychological drama. Through the devoted eyes of Mrs. Stringham, we witness the emergence of Milly Theale as a figure of tragic grandeur—a modern princess whose vast freedom only serves to deepen her engagement with a formidable destiny. The literary genius lies in making this profound human story unfold almost entirely within the quiet, observant, and ever-deepening consciousness of a friend.

The air was still, thick with the scent of late summer: dust, dry grass, and something else, something indefinable that hung in the air like a promise. The sun beat down, turning the cobblestones of the main street to a shimmering heat.

The two ladies who, in advance of the Swiss season, had been warned that their design was unconsidered, that the passes would not be clear, nor the air mild, nor the inns open—the two ladies who, characteristically, had braved a good deal of possibly interested remonstrance were finding themselves, as their adventure turned out, wonderfully sustained. It was the judgment of the head-waiters and other functionaries on the Italian lakes that approved itself now as interested; they themselves had been conscious of impatiences, of bolder dreams—at least the younger had; so that one of the things they made out together—making out as they did an endless variety—was that in those operatic palaces of the Villa d'Este, of Cadenabbia, of Pallanza and Stresa, lone women, however reinforced by a travelling-library of instructive volumes, were apt to be beguiled and undone. Their flights of fancy moreover had been modest; they had for instance risked nothing vital in hoping to make their way by the Brünig. They were making it in fact happily enough as we meet them, and were only wishing that, for the wondrous beauty of the early high-climbing spring, it might have been longer and the places to pause and rest more numerous.

Translation

The two women, having been cautioned before the Swiss season that their plan was ill-considered, that the mountain passes would not be passable, nor the weather gentle, nor the inns open—the two women, who, true to form, had ignored a great deal of potentially concerned protestations, were finding themselves, as their adventure unfolded, wonderfully vindicated. The opinions of head-waiters and other functionaries on the Italian lakes, it now seemed, were self-serving. The women themselves had been aware of their own impatience, their more daring aspirations—at least the younger one had; so that one of the things they understood together—as they discussed an endless variety of topics—was that in those operatic palaces of the Villa d'Este, of Cadenabbia, of Pallanza and Stresa, lone women, however fortified by a traveling library of instructive books, were likely to be deceived and ruined. Their ambitions, moreover, had been modest; they had, for example, risked nothing crucial in hoping to travel by the Brünig Pass. They were, in fact, traveling quite happily as we find them, and only wished that, for the exquisite beauty of the early spring in the high mountains, their journey could have lasted longer and that there had been more places to stop and rest.

"Oh, you said—for enjoyment." "Yes; but you don't understand what enjoyment can be. There are complexities," she said more patiently. "I mean of awareness, of feeling, of understanding," she continued.

Translation

"Oh, you said—for enjoyment." "Yes; but you don't understand what enjoyment can be. There are complexities," she said, more patiently. "I mean of awareness, of feeling, of understanding," she continued.

"No," she sadly insisted, "men don't know. They know almost nothing about these things except what women show them." This was one of those statements, typical of her, that he wholeheartedly, joyfully, intensely accepted and, in itself, as it were, embraced, drawing him closer to her and holding him there as long as their situation allowed. "Then that's exactly why we need you so desperately!"

Translation

"No," she said, her voice heavy with sadness, "men just don't get it. They barely understand any of this, except what women reveal to them." It was a declaration, characteristic of her, that he received with complete, elated, and profound agreement, and, in its own right, as it were, it embraced him, pulling him closer and holding him there for the duration that their circumstances would permit. "Then that's precisely why we depend on you so completely!"

BOOK THREE V The two women who, before the Swiss tourist season, had been told that their plan was foolish, that the mountain passes wouldn't be clear, nor the weather pleasant, nor the hotels open—the two women who, as was their nature, had disregarded a great deal of possibly self-serving advice, were now finding themselves remarkably supported by their experience. The headwaiters and other staff at the Italian lakes had their own reasons for disapproving; the women had been aware of impatience, of bolder fantasies—at least the younger one had.

Translation

BOOK THREE V

The two women, having been warned before the Swiss tourist season that their plan was foolish, that the mountain passes wouldn't be passable, the weather unpleasant, and the hotels closed—the two women who, as was their way, had ignored a great deal of possibly self-serving advice, were now finding their experience surprisingly validating. The headwaiters and staff at the Italian lakes had their own reasons for disapproval; the women had sensed impatience, bolder fantasies—at least the younger one had.

So, one of the things they realized together—and they realized an endless variety of things—was that in those theatrical settings of the Villa d'Este, Cadenabbia, Pallanza, and Stresa, single women, even with a travelling library of educational books, were likely to be deceived and ruined. Their ambitions had been rather restrained; they hadn't, for example, risked anything serious in hoping to travel by the Brünig Pass. In fact, they were doing quite well as we find them, and they only wished that, due to the amazing beauty of the early spring high in the mountains, the journey could have been longer and that there were more places to stop and rest. Such at least had been the intimated attitude of Mrs.

Translation

So, one of the things they understood together—and they understood a great many things—was that in the theatrical environments of the Villa d'Este, Cadenabbia, Pallanza, and Stresa, single women, even with a travelling library of intellectual books, were likely to be deceived and ruined. Their ambitions had been quite modest; they hadn't, for instance, risked anything significant in the hope of travelling by the Brünig Pass. Indeed, they were faring rather well as we see them, and they only wished that, due to the stunning beauty of the early spring high in the mountains, the journey could have been longer and that there were more places to stop and rest. Such, at least, had been the implied sentiment of Mrs.

Stringham, the elder of the companions, who had her own view of the impatiences of the younger, to which, however, she offered an opposition but of the most circuitous. She moved, the admirable Mrs. Stringham, in a fine cloud of observation and suspicion; she was in the position, as she believed, of knowing much more about Milly Theale than Milly herself knew, and yet of having to darken her knowledge as well as make it active. The woman in the world least formed by nature, as she was quite aware, for duplicities and labyrinths, she found herself dedicated to personal subtlety by a new set of circumstances, above all by a new personal relation; had now in fact to recognise that an education in the occult—she could scarce say what to call it—had begun for her the day she left New York with Mildred.

Translation

Stringham, the elder of the two companions, held her own perspective on the younger woman's impatience. Her resistance, however, was of the most indirect kind. The admirable Mrs. Stringham operated within a delicate cloud of observation and suspicion. She believed she understood Milly Theale far better than Milly understood herself, yet she was compelled to keep her knowledge both concealed and in play. Though nature had least equipped her—as she fully acknowledged—for deceit and complexity, she now found herself committed to personal subtlety by a new set of circumstances, especially a new personal relationship. Indeed, she had to admit that an education in the occult—she could barely find the right words for it—had commenced for her the day she departed New York with Mildred.

She had come on from Boston for that purpose; had seen little of the girl—or rather had seen her but briefly, for Mrs. Stringham, when she saw anything at all, saw much, saw everything—before accepting her proposal; and had accordingly placed herself, by her act, in a boat that she more and more estimated as, humanly speaking, of the biggest, though likewise, no doubt, in many ways, by reason of its size, of the safest. In Boston, the winter before, the young lady in whom we are interested had, on the spot, deeply, yet almost tacitly, appealed to her, dropped into her mind the shy conceit of some assistance, some devotion to render. Mrs.

Translation

Stringham had felt the appeal, the intimation, as a gentle touch, an appeal to her innermost instincts, and she had responded. She was now, at the moment, steering the craft. She had taken the helm in the boat of Milly’s life, and she was not turning back.

Stringham's little life had often been visited by shy conceits—secret dreams that had fluttered their hour between its narrow walls without, for any great part, so much as mustering courage to look out of its rather dim windows. But this imagination—the fancy of a possible link with the remarkable young thing from New York—had mustered courage: had perched, on the instant, at the clearest look-out it could find, and might be said to have remained there till, only a few months later, it had caught, in surprise and joy, the unmistakable flash of a signal. At least, that was the unspoken understanding with Mrs. Stringham, the older of the two women.

Translation

Stringham’s small life had frequently been visited by timid fantasies—private dreams that had briefly surfaced in her mind without, for the most part, even gathering the confidence to peer out of its rather dim windows. But this particular fantasy—the idea of a possible connection with the extraordinary young woman from New York—had found courage: had, immediately, taken up residence in the most prominent position it could find, and could be said to have remained there until, just a few months later, it had perceived, with surprise and joy, the unmistakable sign of a response. Or so it was silently agreed between Mrs. Stringham and the other woman.

She had her own opinions about the younger woman's impatience, but she resisted it only in subtle ways. Mrs. Stringham was an exceptional observer, always watchful. She believed she knew more about Milly Theale than Milly knew herself, yet she had to keep her knowledge hidden while also putting it to use.

Translation

Stringham held her own views on the younger woman’s impatience, but she only countered it subtly. Mrs. Stringham was an astute observer, perpetually vigilant. She felt she understood Milly Theale better than Milly understood herself, but she had to conceal her understanding while simultaneously employing it.

She knew she wasn't naturally inclined towards deceit or complicated plots. However, a new set of circumstances, especially a new personal relationship, had thrust her into a position where she needed to be subtle. She had to acknowledge that she'd begun to learn something mysterious – she wasn’t sure what to call it – the day she left New York with Mildred. She'd come from Boston for that reason.

Translation

Stringham understood she was not inclined towards deceit or complex schemes. Yet, new conditions, particularly a recent personal relationship, had forced her to be subtle. She was obliged to accept that she’d begun to understand something enigmatic – she didn’t know how else to describe it – the day she left New York with Mildred. She had come from Boston for that reason.

Before agreeing to Milly's proposal, she had seen little of her—or rather, she had seen her only briefly, because Mrs. Stringham, when she noticed something, noticed a great deal, in fact, she noticed everything. Consequently, she'd placed herself in a situation she increasingly recognized as immense, even though, due to its scale, it was also probably quite safe. In Boston, the previous winter, the young woman we're interested in had, at once, profoundly, yet almost silently, reached out to her, planting in her mind the hesitant idea of offering assistance and devotion.

Translation

Prior to accepting Milly’s offer, she’d scarcely seen her – or, rather, their encounters were fleeting, because Mrs. Stringham, when she did observe something, was an exceptionally astute observer, noticing virtually everything. As a result, she’d put herself in a position that she understood was significant, though, due to its very magnitude, probably also quite secure. In Boston, the winter before, the young woman in question had, simultaneously, and with little fanfare, made an overture to her, initiating a nascent desire to provide support and loyalty.

Mrs. Stringham's quiet life had often been visited by these shy thoughts—secret aspirations that had briefly flourished in her limited world without ever mustering the courage to look beyond its rather dull boundaries. But this particular thought—the idea of a possible connection with the extraordinary young woman from New York—had found courage. It had immediately taken up the clearest position it could find, and could be said to have remained there until, only a few months later, it had been surprised and delighted by the unmistakable flash of a signal.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham’s peaceful existence had frequently been visited by these timid reflections—private longings that had briefly bloomed in her restricted world, without ever gathering the nerve to look past its somewhat uninteresting limits. But this particular thought—the idea of a possible connection with the remarkable young woman from New York—had found its bravery. It had immediately taken hold of the most obvious position it could find, and it could be said to have remained there until, only a few months later, it was surprised and overjoyed by the unmistakable flicker of a sign.

Milly Theale had Boston friends, such as they were, and of recent making; and it was understood that her visit to them—a visit that was not to be meagre—had been undertaken, after a series of bereavements, in the interest of the particular peace that New York could not give. It was recognised, liberally enough, that there were many things—perhaps even too many—New York could give; but this was felt to make no difference in the constant fact that what you had most to do, under the discipline of life, or of death, was really to feel your situation as grave. Boston could help you to that as nothing else could, and it had extended to Milly, by every presumption, some such measure of assistance. Mrs.

Translation

Milly Theale had made Boston friends, though they were a recent development; and it was generally understood that her visit to them—a visit of some length—had been arranged, following a string of losses, in order to find the kind of peace that New York couldn’t provide. It was widely accepted, rather tolerantly, that New York offered many things—perhaps too many things, even—but this didn’t change the fundamental reality that the most important thing to do, whether facing life or death, was to fully acknowledge the gravity of your situation. Boston could facilitate that better than anything else, and it seemed Milly had, by all accounts, received some measure of support in that regard. Mrs.

Stringham was never to forget—for the moment had not faded, nor the infinitely fine vibration it set up in any degree ceased—her own first sight of the striking apparition, then unheralded and unexplained: the slim, constantly pale, delicately haggard, anomalously, agreeably angular young person, of not more than two-and-twenty in spite of her marks, whose hair was some how exceptionally red even for the real thing, which it innocently confessed to being, and whose clothes were remarkably black even for robes of mourning, which was the meaning they expressed. It was New York mourning, it was New York hair, it was a New York history, confused as yet, but multitudinous, of the loss of parents, brothers, sisters, almost every human appendage, all on a scale and with a sweep that had required the greater stage; it was a New York legend of affecting, of romantic isolation, and, beyond everything, it was by most accounts, in respect to the mass of money so piled on the girl's back, a set of New York possibilities. She was alone, she was stricken, she was rich, and, in particular, she was strange—a combination in itself of a nature to engage Mrs. Stringham's attention.

Translation

Stringham would never forget—the moment hadn’t faded, nor had the incredibly subtle impact it had initiated in any way subsided—her first sight of the astonishing figure, then unannounced and unexplained: the slender, perpetually pale, delicately worn, oddly and yet appealingly angular young woman, not older than twenty-two despite her visible troubles, whose hair was somehow exceptionally red even for the real thing, which it innocently admitted to being, and whose clothes were remarkably black even for garments of mourning, which was what they signified. It was New York mourning, it was New York hair, it was a New York story, still unclear, but extensive, of losing parents, siblings, almost every close relative, all on a scale and with a scope that demanded the larger stage; it was a New York myth of touching, romantic isolation, and, above all else, it was by most accounts, considering the vast fortune amassed by the girl, a set of New York opportunities. She was alone, she was devastated, she was rich, and, particularly, she was odd—a combination that, in itself, was bound to capture Mrs. Stringham’s interest.

But it was the strangeness that most determined our good lady's sympathy, convinced as she was that it was much greater than any one else—any one but the sole Susan Stringham—supposed. Susan privately settled it that Boston was not in the least seeing her, was only occupied with her seeing Boston, and that any assumed affinity between the two characters was delusive and vain. She was seeing her, and she had quite the deepest moment of her life in now obeying the instinct to conceal the vision. She couldn't explain it—no one would understand.

Translation

But it was the strangeness that most captivated our dear lady’s sympathy, as she was certain that she saw much more than anyone else did—anyone but Susan Stringham herself. Privately, Susan concluded that Boston wasn’t seeing her at all; it was preoccupied with her seeing Boston, and any assumed connection between the two was illusory and pointless. She was seeing her, and she experienced the most profound moment of her life in following the impulse to hide the vision. She couldn’t explain it—no one would understand.

They would say clever Boston things—Mrs. Stringham was from Burlington, Vermont, which she boldly upheld as the real heart of New England, Boston being "too far south"—but they would only darken counsel. Milly Theale had some Boston friends, recently made, and it was understood that her visit to them—a visit meant to be substantial—had been undertaken after a series of tragedies, with the intention of finding the kind of peace that New York couldn't offer. It was generally accepted that New York offered many things—perhaps even too many things—but this didn't change the fact that the most important thing to do, in the face of life or death, was to recognize the seriousness of your situation.

Translation

They would make clever Boston remarks—Mrs. Stringham came from Burlington, Vermont, which she bravely declared was the true heart of New England, as Boston was "too far south"—but they only muddied the waters. Milly Theale had some recently acquired Boston friends, and it was understood that her visit to them—a visit intended to be significant—had been arranged after a string of tragedies, with the goal of discovering the kind of serenity that New York couldn't provide. It was widely agreed that New York offered a great deal—maybe even too much—but this didn't alter the fact that the most important thing to do, when faced with life or death, was to acknowledge the gravity of your circumstances.

Boston could help with this like nothing else, and it seemed to have offered Milly some assistance. Mrs. Stringham would never forget the moment she first saw the striking, unannounced, and unexplained young woman: slim, consistently pale, delicately worn, unusually yet attractively angular, not older than twenty-two despite her hardship. Her hair was somehow exceptionally red, even for real red hair, which it plainly was, and her clothes were remarkably black, even for mourning attire, which was what they were.

Translation

Boston was uniquely suited to this, and it seemed to have already been of some service to Milly. Mrs. Stringham would never forget the first time she saw the unexpected, enigmatic young woman: slender, always pale, a little fragile, possessing a striking, attractive angularity, and appearing no older than twenty-two, though she had clearly suffered. Her hair was extraordinarily red, even for real red hair, which it undoubtedly was, and her clothes were unusually black, even for mourning clothes, which was what they were.

It was New York mourning, New York hair, a New York story of loss—parents, siblings, almost every relative, all gone on a scale and with a scope that required a larger stage. It was a New York legend of moving, romantic isolation, and, above all, it was, according to most accounts, given the vast wealth the girl possessed, a collection of New York possibilities. She was alone, grieving, wealthy, and, in particular, strange—a combination that immediately drew Mrs. Stringham's interest.

Translation

It was New York's mourning, New York's hair, a New York tale of loss—parents, siblings, nearly every relative, all vanished with a scale and scope that demanded a larger stage. It was a New York myth of moving, romantic solitude, and, most of all, it was, according to most, given the girl's immense wealth, a catalog of New York possibilities. She was alone, grieving, rich, and, particularly, peculiar—a combination that immediately captivated Mrs. Stringham's attention.

But it was the strangeness that most captivated Mrs. Stringham, who believed it was more pronounced than anyone else—except for Susan Stringham—realized. Susan privately decided that Boston wasn't truly seeing her; it was only concerned with being seen by her, and any assumed connection between the two was false. She, however, *was* seeing her, and had the most profound moment of her life in following her instinct to hide what she saw.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham was most intrigued by the girl’s oddness, believing it was more obvious than everyone—except for Susan Stringham—understood. Susan, in her private thoughts, concluded that Boston wasn’t really perceiving the girl; it was only focused on being perceived *by* her, and any supposed bond between them was fabricated. Susan, however, *was* truly seeing her, and experienced the most significant moment of her life when she followed her impulse to conceal what she perceived.

She couldn't explain it; no one would understand. They would say clever Boston things—Mrs. Stringham was from Burlington, Vermont, which she proudly declared was the true heart of New England, as Boston was "too far south"—but they would only complicate the matter. There could be no better proof, than this quick intellectual split, of the impression made on our friend, who shone, herself, she was well aware, with but the reflected light of the admirable city.

Translation

She couldn't articulate it, and no one would grasp it. They'd offer their usual, witty Boston pronouncements—Mrs. Stringham, hailing from Burlington, Vermont, a place she avowed was the genuine essence of New England, claiming Boston was "too far south"—but those comments would only cloud the issue. This sudden, intellectual division was definitive proof of the impact on our friend, who, she knew, radiated solely with the reflected glory of that remarkable city.

She too had had her discipline, but it had not made her striking; it had been prosaically usual, though doubtless a decent dose; and had only made her usual to match it—usual, that is, as Boston went. She had lost first her husband, and then her mother, with whom, on her husband's death, she had lived again; so that now, childless, she was but more sharply single than before. But she sat rather coldly light, having, as she called it, enough to live on—so far, that is, as she lived by bread alone: how little indeed she was regularly content with that diet appeared from the name she had made—Susan Shepherd Stringham—as a contributor to the best magazines. She wrote short stories, and she fondly believed she had her "note," the art of showing New England without showing it wholly in the kitchen.

Translation

She, too, had had her discipline, but it hadn’t made her remarkable. It had been mundanely ordinary, albeit a respectable amount, and had only made her ordinary to match it—ordinary, that is, as Boston went. She had lost her husband first, then her mother, with whom she had lived again after her husband’s death. So now, childless, she was only more distinctly alone than before. But she remained rather coldly detached, having, as she put it, enough to live on—insofar, that is, as she lived on bread alone. Just how little she was genuinely satisfied with that regimen was apparent from the name she had adopted—Susan Shepherd Stringham—as a contributor to the leading magazines. She wrote short stories and fondly believed she possessed her “voice,” the skill of depicting New England without depicting it entirely in the kitchen.

She had not herself been brought up in the kitchen; she knew others who had not; and to speak for them had thus become with her a literary mission. To be in truth literary had ever been her dearest thought, the thought that kept her bright little nippers perpetually in position. There were masters, models, celebrities, mainly foreign, whom she finely accounted so and in whose light she ingeniously laboured; there were others whom, however chattered about, she ranked with the inane, for she was full of discrimination; but all categories failed her—they ceased at least to signify—as soon as she found herself in presence of the real thing, the romantic life itself. That was what she saw in Mildred—what positively made her hand a while tremble too much for the pen.

Translation

She hadn't grown up in the kitchen herself; she knew others who hadn't either. To speak for them had become her literary mission. To be truly literary had always been her deepest desire, the thought that kept her mind sharp and focused. There were masters, models, celebrities, mostly foreign, whom she highly esteemed and whose work she studied. There were others, however much they were discussed, whom she considered vapid, as she was full of discernment. But all these categories failed her—they ceased to matter—as soon as she found herself in the presence of the real thing, the romantic life itself. That was what she saw in Mildred—what made her hand tremble too much to write for a while.

She had had, it seemed to her, a revelation—such as even New England refined and grammatical couldn't give; and, all made up as she was of small neat memories and ingenuities, little industries and ambitions, mixed with something moral, personal, that was still more intensely responsive, she felt her new friend would have done her an ill turn if their friendship shouldn't develop, and yet that nothing would be left of anything else if it should. It was for the surrender of everything else that she was, however, quite prepared, and while she went about her usual Boston business with her usual Boston probity she was really all the while holding herself. She wore her "handsome" felt hat, so Tyrolese, yet some how, though feathered from the eagle's wing, so truly domestic, with the same straightness and security; she attached her fur boa with the same honest precautions; she preserved her balance on the ice-slopes with the same practised skill; she opened, each evening, her "Transcript" with the same interfusion of suspense and resignation; she attended her almost daily concert with the same expenditure of patience and the same economy of passion; she flitted in and out of the Public Library with the air of conscientiously returning or bravely carrying off in her pocket the key of knowledge itself; and finally—it was what she most did—she watched the thin trickle of a fictive "love-interest" through that somewhat serpentine channel, in the magazines, which she mainly managed to keep clear for it. But the real thing, all the while, was elsewhere; the real thing had gone back to New York, leaving behind it the two unsolved questions, quite distinct, of why it was real, and whether she should ever be so near it again.

Translation

It seemed to her that she'd had a revelation—something even New England, with its refinement and grammar, couldn't provide. And though she was composed of neat little memories and cleverness, of tiny efforts and ambitions, mixed with a personal moral core that was even more receptive, she felt that her new friend would have wronged her if their friendship didn't deepen. Yet, she also knew that everything else would be lost if it did. She was ready to surrender everything else, however. While she went about her usual Boston routine with her usual Boston integrity, she was really holding herself back. She wore her "handsome" felt hat, so Tyrolean, but somehow, despite the eagle's feather, so truly domestic, with the same composure and confidence. She fastened her fur boa with the same honest care. She kept her balance on the icy slopes with the same practiced skill. Each evening, she opened her "Transcript" with the same blend of anticipation and resignation. She attended her almost daily concerts with the same patience and restraint. She drifted in and out of the Public Library with the air of conscientiously returning or bravely carrying off in her pocket the key to knowledge itself. And finally—which was what she did most—she followed the thin stream of a fictional "love-interest" through the somewhat winding path of the magazines, which she largely kept open for that. But the real thing was elsewhere the whole time. The real thing had gone back to New York, leaving behind two distinct, unanswered questions: why it was real, and whether she would ever be so close to it again.

The rapid intellectual shift perfectly demonstrated the impact made on our friend, who knew she shone with the reflected glory of the remarkable city. She, too, had followed a specific path, but it hadn’t made her stand out; it was ordinary and expected, though undoubtedly adequate, which only made her a typical Bostonian. She’d lost her husband and then her mother, with whom she'd lived after her husband's death. Now, childless, she was more alone than ever.

Translation

This quick mental transition precisely illustrated the effect that the remarkable city was having on our friend, who knew she radiated in its reflected brilliance. She, too, had followed a particular path, but it hadn’t distinguished her; it was commonplace and predictable, although perfectly acceptable, which only made her a quintessential Bostonian. She'd lost her husband, and then her mother, with whom she'd lived after her husband died. Now, without children, she was more isolated than ever before.

However, she lived a somewhat detached life, having, as she put it, enough money to get by, at least as far as surviving on basic necessities went. How little she was truly satisfied with that existence was evident in her pen name—Susan Shepherd Stringham—used for her contributions to prestigious magazines. She wrote short stories and believed she had found her "voice," the ability to depict New England without portraying it solely through the lens of the kitchen. She herself hadn't grown up in a kitchen; she knew others who hadn't, and speaking for them had become her literary purpose.

Translation

However, her life was somewhat separate, as she put it, with enough money to get by, at least to cover the basics of survival. How little she was truly satisfied with that existence was obvious in her pen name—Susan Shepherd Stringham—used for her contributions to prestigious magazines. She wrote short stories and believed she had found her "voice," the ability to depict New England without portraying it solely through the lens of the kitchen. She herself hadn't grown up in a kitchen; she knew others who hadn't, and speaking for them had become her literary purpose.

To be a true writer had always been her greatest desire, the aspiration that kept her keen observations constantly at the ready. There were literary masters, role models, and celebrities, primarily foreign, whom she deeply admired and whose work she studied with care. There were others, however much they were discussed, whom she considered superficial, for she possessed a keen sense of judgment. But all categories and classifications failed her—or at least became irrelevant—once she encountered the genuine article, the romantic life itself.

Translation

Her deepest yearning had always been to be a real writer, a dream that kept her sharp, her powers of observation perpetually switched on. She held in high regard, and carefully studied the works of, literary giants, role models, and celebrities—mostly from other countries. But others, no matter how much they were lauded, she saw as shallow, for she had a discerning eye. Yet all categorization, all labels, failed her—or at least lost their meaning—when she came face-to-face with the real thing, with the drama and romance of life itself.

That’s what she saw in Mildred—what, for a time, made her hand tremble too much to write. She felt she’d had a revelation—something even refined, grammatically precise New England couldn't provide. Despite her being made up of small, tidy memories, clever ideas, modest ambitions, and a blend of moral and personal qualities that made her intensely responsive, she felt her new friend would harm her if their friendship didn’t develop, yet that everything else would disappear if it did. However, she was fully prepared to give up everything else, and while she went about her ordinary Boston routine with her usual Boston integrity, she was constantly holding herself in check.

Translation

That was the quality she recognized in Mildred—the quality that, for a time, made it difficult for her to write. She felt she’d discovered something, something even the elegance and precision of New England couldn’t offer. Though she was defined by small, neat memories, clever thoughts, modest goals, and a mix of moral and personal traits that made her exquisitely sensitive, she sensed her new friend would be a threat if their relationship didn’t deepen, and that everything else would vanish if it did. Yet she was ready to sacrifice everything else, and though she went about her normal, Boston life with her typical Bostonian rectitude, she was always exercising self-control.

She wore her "handsome" Tyrolean-style felt hat, which, though adorned with feathers from an eagle's wing, seemed so homely, with the same composure and confidence. She fastened her fur boa with the same careful attention. She navigated the icy sidewalks with the same practiced skill. Each evening, she opened her "Transcript" newspaper with the same mix of anticipation and resignation.

Translation

She wore her "handsome" Tyrolean-style felt hat, which, despite the eagle feather accents, looked utterly ordinary, all with the same poised confidence. She secured her fur boa with the same meticulous care. She moved along the slick sidewalks with the same practiced expertise. Each evening, she opened her "Transcript" newspaper with the same combination of excitement and weary acceptance.

She attended her almost daily concert with the same display of patience and the same restraint of emotion. She went in and out of the Public Library with the air of conscientiously returning or bravely carrying off in her pocket the key to knowledge itself. And finally—which was her primary focus—she followed the slender thread of a fictional "love-interest" through the somewhat winding path in the magazines, which she mostly managed to keep open for it. But the real thing, all the while, was elsewhere; the real thing had returned to New York, leaving behind the two distinct, unanswered questions of why it was real and whether she would ever again get so close to it.

Translation

She attended her almost daily concert with the same display of patience and the same restraint of emotion. She entered and exited the Public Library as though she were conscientiously returning, or bravely pocketing, the very key to knowledge. And finally—which was her primary focus—she followed the slender thread of a fictional "love-interest" through the somewhat winding path in the magazines, which she mostly managed to keep open for it. But the real thing, all the while, was elsewhere; the real thing had returned to New York, leaving behind the two distinct, unanswered questions of why it was real and whether she would ever again get so close to it.

For the figure to which these questions attached themselves she had found a convenient description—she thought of it for herself, always, as that of a girl with a background. The great reality was in the fact that, very soon, after but two or three meetings, the girl with the background, the girl with the crown of old gold and the mourning that was not as the mourning of Boston, but at once more rebellious in its gloom and more frivolous in its frills, had told her she had never seen any one like her. They had met thus as opposed curiosities, and that simple remark of Milly's—if simple it was—became the most important thing that had ever happened to her; it deprived the love-interest, for the time, of actuality and even of pertinence; it moved her first, in short, in a high degree, to gratitude, and then to no small compassion. Yet in respect to this relation at least it was what did prove the key of knowledge; it lighted up as nothing else could do the poor young woman's history.

Translation

For the person these questions concerned, she'd developed a convenient label: she always thought of her as the girl with a background. The great reality was that very soon, after only two or three encounters, the girl with the background, the girl with the crown of old gold and the mourning that was not the Boston kind, but both more rebellious in its darkness and more frivolous in its frills, had told her she’d never seen anyone like her. They had met as opposing curiosities, and Milly’s simple remark – if it was simple – became the most important thing that had ever happened to her; for the time, it took away the love-interest’s reality and even its relevance; it moved her first to a high degree of gratitude, and then to no small amount of compassion. Yet in this relationship, at least, it proved to be the key to knowledge; it illuminated the young woman’s history like nothing else could.

That the potential heiress of all the ages should never have seen any one like a mere typical subscriber, after all, to the "Transcript" was a truth that—in especial as announced with modesty, with humility, with regret—described a situation. It laid upon the elder woman, as to the void to be filled, a weight of responsibility; but in particular it led her to ask whom poor Mildred had then seen, and what range of contacts it had taken to produce such queer surprises. That was really the inquiry that had ended by clearing the air: the key of knowledge was felt to click in the lock from the moment it flashed upon Mrs. Stringham that her friend had been starved for culture.

Translation

That the prospective inheritor of all time should never have seen anyone like a mere typical reader of the "Transcript" was a truth that—especially as announced with modesty, with humility, with regret—defined the situation. It placed a heavy responsibility on the elder woman regarding what was lacking; but in particular, it led her to wonder whom poor Mildred had encountered and what sort of social circle had produced such strange surprises. This was really the question that ended up clarifying everything: the key to knowledge clicked into place the moment Mrs. Stringham realized her friend had been starved for culture.

Culture was what she herself represented for her, and it was living up to that principle that would surely prove the great business. She knew, the clever lady, what the principle itself represented, and the limits of her own store; and a certain alarm would have grown upon her if something else hadn't grown faster. Concerning the person to whom these questions were directed, she had found a fitting descriptor—she always thought of her as a girl with a background. The crucial fact was that, shortly after only two or three encounters, the girl with the background, the girl with the crown of antique gold and mourning attire that wasn't like the mourning of Boston, but was simultaneously more defiant in its somberness and more flamboyant in its details, had stated that she had never met anyone like her.

Translation

Culture was what she herself embodied, and adhering to that ideal would be the true challenge. The perceptive woman understood the principle and the boundaries of her own knowledge. A sense of unease would have overtaken her if something else hadn't also intensified. Regarding the person to whom these questions were directed, she'd found a suitable description—she always thought of her as a girl with a background. The crucial detail was that, after only a few meetings, the girl with the background, the girl with the antique gold crown and mourning attire that differed from Bostonian black—defiant in its solemnity yet flamboyant in its details—had declared she'd never met anyone like her.

They had come together as contrasting interests, and that simple comment of Milly's—if it was simple—became the most significant thing that had ever happened to her; it temporarily diminished the relevance of any romantic interest; it first, in short, caused her immense gratitude, and then considerable compassion. Nevertheless, with regard to this relationship, it indeed proved to be the gateway to understanding; it illuminated the young woman's past unlike anything else could. That the prospective heiress of all time had never encountered someone like a mere average subscriber to the "Transcript" was a truth that—especially when stated with modesty, humility, and regret—revealed a situation. It placed a sense of duty on the older woman, as though there was a void to be filled; but in particular, it prompted her to wonder who poor Mildred had met before, and what series of encounters had led to such strange surprises.

Translation

Their connection had been born of opposing sensibilities, and that offhand remark of Milly's—assuming it was offhand—became the single most important event in her life. It temporarily eclipsed any other potential romantic attachments. Initially, it engendered tremendous gratitude, followed by a substantial degree of empathy. Moreover, it proved to be a critical pathway to understanding their dynamic. It shed light on the younger woman's history in a way nothing else could. The fact that this future heiress had never encountered someone like a regular reader of the "Transcript" was a revelation—especially when conveyed with such modesty, humility, and regret—that spoke volumes. It instilled in the older woman a sense of obligation, as if there were a void to be filled. But more specifically, it compelled her to consider who poor Mildred had known before, and what prior experiences had resulted in such astonishment.

That was the core inquiry that ultimately clarified everything: the key to knowledge was felt to turn in the lock the moment it struck Mrs. Stringham that her friend had been deprived of cultural experiences. Culture was what she herself embodied for her, and living up to that ideal would undoubtedly prove to be the most important task. She knew, the intelligent woman, what the principle itself represented, and the limitations of her own knowledge; and a certain apprehension would have increased within her if something else hadn't grown more rapidly.

Translation

That was the central question that ultimately explained everything. The key to understanding seemed to click into place the moment Mrs. Stringham realized her friend had been deprived of cultural experiences. Culture was what she herself represented to Milly, and living up to that ideal would undoubtedly become her most important mission. Mrs. Stringham, being intelligent, understood what the concept of culture meant and the limits of her own knowledge. A sense of unease might have intensified within her, had something else not simultaneously grown stronger.

This was, fortunately for her—and we give it in her own words—the sense of a harrowing pathos. That, primarily, was what appealed to her, what seemed to open the door of romance for her still wider than any, than a still more reckless, connection with the "picture-papers." For such was essentially the point: it was rich, romantic, abysmal, to have, as was evident, thousands and thousands a year, to have youth and intelligence and if not beauty, at least, in equal measure, a high, dim, charming, ambiguous oddity, which was even better, and then on top of all to enjoy boundless freedom, the freedom of the wind in the desert—it was unspeakably touching to be so equipped and yet to have been reduced by fortune to little humble-minded mistakes. Luckily for her—and we'll use her own words—she felt a deep, heartbreaking sadness. That, above all, is what moved her, what seemed to open the door to romance even wider than before, more so than any daring involvement with the "illustrated magazines." That was the main point: it was thrilling, romantic, and profound to possess, as it was obvious she did, vast wealth; to have youth, intelligence, and if not beauty, then at least an equally valuable quality—a certain strange, alluring, and enigmatic charm, which was even better; and then, on top of all that, to possess unlimited freedom, as limitless as the wind in the desert.

Translation

This, fortunately for her—and we give it in her own words—was the feeling of a harrowing pathos. That, primarily, was what appealed to her, what seemed to open the door of romance for her still wider than any, than a still more reckless, connection with the "picture-papers." For such was essentially the point: it was rich, romantic, abysmal, to have, as was evident, thousands and thousands a year, to have youth and intelligence and if not beauty, at least, in equal measure, a high, dim, charming, ambiguous oddity, which was even better, and then on top of all to enjoy boundless freedom, the freedom of the wind in the desert—it was unspeakably touching to be so equipped and yet to have been reduced by fortune to little humble-minded mistakes.

Luckily for her—and we'll use her own words—she felt a deep, heartbreaking sadness. That, above all, is what moved her, what seemed to open the door to romance even wider than before, more so than any daring involvement with the "illustrated magazines." That was the main point: it was thrilling, romantic, and profound to possess, as it was obvious she did, vast wealth; to have youth, intelligence, and if not beauty, then at least an equally valuable quality—a certain strange, alluring, and enigmatic charm, which was even better; and then, on top of all that, to possess unlimited freedom, as limitless as the wind in the desert.

It was unbelievably poignant to have all those advantages and yet to be brought down by fate to small, self-effacing errors. It brought our friend's imagination back again to New York, where aberrations were so possible in the intellectual sphere, and it in fact caused a visit she presently paid there to overflow with interest. As Milly had beautifully invited her, so she would hold out if she could against the strain of so much confidence in her mind; and the remarkable thing was that even at the end of three weeks she had held out. But by this time her mind had grown comparatively bold and free; it was dealing with new quantities, a different proportion altogether—and that had made for refreshment: she had accordingly gone home in convenient possession of her subject.

Translation

It was incredibly sad to have all those advantages and still be brought low by fate because of small, humble mistakes. It brought our friend's imagination back to New York, where intellectual deviations were so common, and it made the visit she subsequently paid there overflow with interest. As Milly had so kindly invited her, she would hold on if she could against the pressure of so much faith in her mind; and the remarkable thing was that even after three weeks, she had. But by this time, her mind had become comparatively bold and free; it was dealing with new concepts, a completely different scale—and that had been refreshing: accordingly, she had gone home conveniently in possession of her subject.

New York was vast, New York was startling, with strange histories, with wild cosmopolite backward generations that accounted for anything; and to have got nearer the luxuriant tribe of which the rare creature was the final flower, the immense, extravagant, unregulated cluster, with free-living ancestors, handsome dead cousins, lurid uncles, beautiful vanished aunts, persons all busts and curls, preserved, though so exposed, in the marble of famous French chisels—all this, to say nothing of the effect of closer growths of the stem, was to have had one's small world-space both crowded and enlarged. Our couple had at all events effected an exchange; the elder friend had been as consciously intellectual as possible, and the younger, abounding in personal revelation, had been as unconsciously distinguished. This was poetry—it was also history—Mrs. Stringham thought, to a finer tune even than Maeterlink and Pater, than Marbot and Gregorovius.

Translation

New York was immense, New York was shocking, filled with bizarre stories, with chaotic, cosmopolitan, backward generations that explained everything. To have gotten closer to the extravagant group of which the unique person was the ultimate product, the enormous, excessive, uncontrolled collection, with free-spirited ancestors, attractive deceased cousins, shocking uncles, beautiful, deceased aunts, people composed of busts and curls, preserved, though so exposed, in the marble of famous French sculptors—all this, not to mention the effect of closer associations with the family, was to have had one’s small world both overcrowded and expanded. Our pair had at least achieved an exchange; the older friend had been as deliberately intellectual as possible, and the younger, overflowing with personal revelations, had been as naturally distinguished. This was poetry—it was also history—Mrs. Stringham thought, to a higher degree than even Maeterlinck and Pater, than Marbot and Gregorovius.

She appointed occasions for the reading of these authors with her hostess, rather perhaps than actually achieved great spans; but what they managed and what they missed speedily sank for her into the dim depths of the merely relative, so quickly, so strongly had she clutched her central clue. All her scruples and hesitations, all her anxious enthusiasms, had reduced themselves to a single alarm—the fear that she really might act on her companion clumsily and coarsely. She was positively afraid of what she might do to her, and to avoid that, to avoid it with piety and passion, to do, rather, nothing at all, to leave her untouched because no touch one could apply, however light, however just, however earnest and anxious, would be half good enough, would be anything but an ugly smutch upon perfection—this now imposed itself as a consistent, an inspiring thought. It revived our friend's interest in New York, a place where unconventional ideas flourished, and it made her subsequent visit there exceptionally interesting.

Translation

She arranged times to read these authors with her hostess, perhaps more as a formality than as an actual accomplishment; but what they achieved and what they didn't quickly faded for her into the hazy realm of the merely subjective, so quickly, so strongly had she grasped her core understanding. All her doubts and uncertainties, all her passionate excitements, had condensed into a single worry—the fear that she might treat her companion clumsily and crudely. She was genuinely afraid of what she could do to her, and to avoid that, to avoid it with reverence and ardor, to do, instead, nothing at all, to leave her untouched because no touch one could make, however delicate, however fair, however sincere and concerned, would be good enough, would be anything but a wretched stain upon perfection—this now presented itself as a consistent, an uplifting idea. It rekindled our friend's interest in New York, a place where unorthodox ideas thrived, and it made her later visit there extraordinarily engaging.

Milly had extended a beautiful invitation, and she resolved to maintain her composure despite the overwhelming trust placed in her. Remarkably, after three weeks, she had succeeded. By then, her mind had become relatively confident and uninhibited; it was processing new information, an entirely different perspective, which was refreshing. Consequently, she returned home with a solid grasp of her subject.

Translation

Milly had offered a beautiful invitation, and she resolved to remain composed despite the enormous trust placed in her. Remarkably, after three weeks, she had succeeded. By then, her mind had become relatively confident and uninhibited; it was processing new information, an entirely different perspective, which was refreshing. Consequently, she returned home with a solid grasp of her subject.

New York was vast and surprising, with intriguing histories and a diverse population, including eccentric, old-fashioned families that could explain anything. Getting closer to the luxurious group, of which the rare individual was the culmination—the vast, extravagant, unconstrained collection, with free-spirited ancestors, attractive deceased cousins, scandalous uncles, and beautiful departed aunts, all immortalized in marble by famous French sculptors—this, not to mention the influence of closer familial connections, both overwhelmed and broadened her own limited understanding. Our pair had, in any case, exchanged something valuable. The older friend had been as intellectual as possible, while the younger, overflowing with personal revelations, had been effortlessly remarkable.

Translation

New York sprawled, a city of wonders, boasting captivating histories and a varied populace, even including peculiar, antiquated families who knew the answers to everything. Getting acquainted with that privileged circle, where the exceptional individual was the ultimate prize—the sprawling, lavish, unrestrained assembly, with unconventional forebears, alluring dead cousins, scandalous uncles, and beautiful deceased aunts, all forever captured in marble by celebrated French sculptors—and not forgetting the influence of closer family ties, both stunned and expanded her limited perspective. The two of them had, in any case, shared something meaningful. The older friend had been as erudite as could be, while the younger, brimming with personal insights, had been effortlessly captivating.

This, Mrs. Stringham believed, was poetry—it was also history—expressed with a depth surpassing even Maeterlinck and Pater, Marbot and Gregorovius.
