She arranged for readings of these authors with her hostess, though perhaps they didn't cover much material; but what they managed to read and what they skipped quickly faded for her into the hazy realm of the irrelevant, so rapidly and firmly had she grasped her central understanding. All her doubts and hesitations, all her enthusiastic worries, had distilled into a single concern: the fear that she might act awkwardly or rudely towards her companion.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham considered this to be poetry—and history as well—rendered with a profundity that exceeded even Maeterlinck and Pater, Marbot and Gregorovius. She organized readings of these writers with her hostess, though they may not have covered much ground; the parts they did read, along with what they omitted, quickly blurred into a hazy background of unimportance, so quickly and completely had her primary understanding taken hold. All her uncertainties and self-consciousness, all her excited anxieties, had crystallized into a singular preoccupation: the worry that she might offend or mistreat her companion.

She was genuinely afraid of what she might do to her, and to avoid that, to avoid it with utmost care and affection, to do nothing at all, to leave her untouched because no gesture, no matter how gentle, how fair, how sincere and concerned, would be good enough, would be anything other than a blemish on perfection—this now presented itself as a consistent, inspiring idea. Less than a month after the event that had so determined Mrs. Stringham's attitude—close upon the heels, that is, of her return from New York—she was reached by a proposal that brought up for her the kind of question her delicacy might have to contend with. Would she start for Europe with her young friend at the earliest possible date, and should she be willing to do so without making conditions?

Translation

She was truly afraid of what she might do to her. To avoid that, to avoid it with the greatest possible care and affection—to do nothing at all, to leave her untouched because no gesture, no matter how gentle, fair, sincere, or concerned, would be good enough, would be anything other than a blemish on perfection—this was now a consistent, inspiring idea for her. Less than a month after the event that had so determined Mrs. Stringham's attitude—that is, soon after her return from New York—she received a proposal that raised the kind of question her sensitivity might have to deal with. Would she depart for Europe with her young friend as soon as possible, and would she be willing to do so without stipulations?

The inquiry was launched by wire; explanations, in sufficiency, were promised; extreme urgency was suggested, and a general surrender invited. It was to the honour of her sincerity that she made the surrender on the spot, though it was not perhaps altogether to that of her logic. She had wanted, very consciously, from the first, to give something up for her new acquaintance, but she had now no doubt that she was practically giving up all. What settled this was the fulness of a particular impression, the impression that had throughout more and more supported her and which she would have uttered so far as she might by saying that the charm of the creature was positively in the creature's greatness.

Translation

The inquiry came by wire; explanations would follow, they promised; extreme urgency was implied, and a complete surrender was requested. It was to her credit that she agreed immediately, though perhaps it wasn’t entirely logical. She had wanted, from the beginning, to sacrifice something for her new friend, but now she was sure she was giving up everything. What decided her was the strength of a certain impression, the impression that had always sustained her and which she would have described, had she been able, as the creature’s charm residing in her greatness.

She would have been content so to leave it; unless indeed she had said, more familiarly, that Mildred was the biggest impression of her life. That was at all events the biggest account of her, and none but a big, clearly, would do. Her situation, as such things were called, was on the grand scale; but it still was not that. It was her nature, once for all—a nature that reminded Mrs.

Translation

She would have been happy to just let it go; unless she could have said, more casually, that Mildred was the biggest impression of her life. That, in any case, was the biggest thing about her, and only something big would have sufficed. Her circumstances, as they were called, were on the grand scale; but they still weren't it. It was her nature, once and for all—a nature that reminded Mrs.

Stringham of the term always used in the newspapers about the great new steamers, the inordinate number of "feet of water" they drew; so that if, in your little boat, you had chosen to hover and approach, you had but yourself to thank, when once motion was started, for the way the draught pulled you. Milly drew the feet of water, and odd though it might seem that a lonely girl, who was not robust and who hated sound and show, should stir the stream like a leviathan, her companion floated off with the sense of rocking violently at her side. More than prepared, however, for that excitement, Mrs. Stringham mainly failed of ease in respect to her own consistency.

Translation

Stringham of the phrase the newspapers always used to describe the biggest new ships, the excessive “feet of water” they needed; so that if you, in your small boat, had elected to linger nearby and get close, you had no one to blame but yourself when the current began to pull you. Milly drew the feet of water, and strange as it seemed that a solitary girl, who wasn’t strong and disliked noise and display, should churn the water like a whale, her friend was tossed about with the sensation of being violently rocked. However, more than ready for that agitation, Mrs. Stringham mostly lacked composure regarding her own steadfastness.

To attach herself for an indefinite time seemed a roundabout way of holding her hands off. If she wished to be sure of neither touching nor smutching, the straighter plan would doubtless have been not to keep her friend within reach. This in fact she fully recognised, and with it the degree to which she desired that the girl should lead her life, a life certain to be so much finer than that of anybody else. The difficulty, however, by good fortune, cleared away as soon as she had further recognised, as she was speedily able to do, that she, Susan Shepherd—the name with which Milly for the most part amused herself—was not anybody else.

Translation

To commit to a relationship

for an unspecified amount of time felt like a convoluted

way of keeping her distance. If she wanted to

make certain she wouldn’t touch or be tainted, the

simpler solution would have been to not

keep her friend close. In fact, she fully

understood this, and with it, the extent to which

she wanted the girl to live her life, a life destined

to be so much better than anyone else’s. However, by some luck, the problem

disappeared as soon as she further realized, as she

quickly was able to do, that she, Susan Shepherd—the

name Milly mostly used to

tease herself—was not anyone else.

She had renounced that character; she had now no life to lead; and she honestly believed that she was thus supremely equipped for leading Milly's own. No other person whatever, she was sure, had to an equal degree this qualification, and it was really to assert it that she fondly embarked. Less than a month after the event that had so greatly influenced Mrs. Stringham's perspective—that is, shortly after her return from New York—she received a proposal that raised a question her sense of propriety might struggle with.

Translation

She had abandoned that persona. She no longer had a life of her own to live. She truly believed that this made her uniquely suited to direct Milly’s. She was certain that no one else was as well-equipped for this, and it was to prove it that she enthusiastically began. Less than a month after the incident that had so greatly changed Mrs. Stringham’s perspective—meaning, shortly after her return from New York—she received a proposal that made her wonder if her sense of what was right would be challenged.

Would she leave for Europe with her young friend as soon as possible, and would she be willing to do so without any conditions? The inquiry arrived by telegram; detailed explanations were promised, the situation was presented as extremely urgent, and a general agreement was requested. To her credit, she agreed immediately, although perhaps not entirely because of logic. She had consciously wanted, from the very beginning, to sacrifice something for her new friend, but she now felt she was essentially sacrificing everything.

Translation

The question was whether she would leave for Europe with her young friend as soon as possible, and whether she would be willing to do so unconditionally. The message arrived by telegram; it promised a full explanation, portrayed the situation as highly pressing, and asked for a simple yes or no. To her credit, she agreed at once, though perhaps not entirely for rational reasons. From the start, she had consciously wanted to sacrifice something for her new friend, but now she felt she was sacrificing everything.

What cemented this was the strength of a particular feeling, the feeling that had increasingly sustained her, which she would have expressed by saying that the girl's charm was fundamentally tied to her extraordinary nature. She would have been happy to leave it at that; unless, perhaps, she had said, more colloquially, that Mildred was the most significant presence in her life. That, at any rate, was the most significant way to describe her, and only something significant would suffice. Her situation, as these things are described, was on a grand scale; but it still wasn't that.

Translation

What made it real was the power of a specific feeling, the one that had become her bedrock. She might have put it like this: the girl's appeal was rooted in her unique essence. She would have been content to leave it there, unless she had added, in more casual terms, that Mildred was the most important person in her world. That, at any rate, was the most accurate way to characterize her, and only something substantial would do. Her circumstances, as these things are usually portrayed, were of epic proportions; but even that wasn't quite it.

It was her nature, plain and simple—a nature that reminded Mrs. Stringham of the phrase often used in the newspapers about the huge new ships, the excessive "depth of water" they required; so that if, in your small boat, you had chosen to get close and approach, you had only yourself to blame, once the ship began to move, for the way the current pulled you along. Milly drew the water, and although it might seem odd that a lonely girl, who wasn't strong and who disliked noise and display, should stir the waters like a giant whale, her companion found herself tossed about violently at her side. However, despite being prepared for that intensity, Mrs.

Translation

Stringham was still taken by surprise.

Stringham mainly felt uneasy about her own consistency. To commit herself for an indefinite period seemed a roundabout way of keeping her distance. If she wanted to ensure she neither touched nor tarnished, the most straightforward approach would undoubtedly have been to keep her friend out of reach. In fact, she fully realized this, and she also realized the extent to which she wanted the girl to live her life, a life certain to be far more extraordinary than anyone else's.

Translation

Stringham was mainly unsettled by her own principles. Agreeing to something open-ended felt like a convoluted way of maintaining space. If she was trying to avoid any connection or damage, the simplest move would have been to keep her friend completely at arm's length. In truth, she understood this perfectly, and she also knew the degree to which she hoped the girl would fully experience her life, a life destined to be far more remarkable than anyone else's.

The difficulty, however, fortunately disappeared as soon as she further acknowledged, which she was soon able to do, that she, Susan Shepherd—the name Milly often playfully used for her—was not anyone else. She had relinquished that identity; she no longer had a life of her own to lead; and she genuinely believed that this made her perfectly suited to lead Milly's. No other person, she was certain, possessed this qualification to the same degree, and it was truly to assert this that she eagerly set off. Many things, though not in many weeks, had come and gone since then, and one of the best of them, doubtless, had been the voyage itself, by the happy southern course, to the succession of Mediterranean ports, with the dazzled wind-up at Naples.

Translation

The problem, however, thankfully vanished the moment she further acknowledged—which she quickly did—that she, Susan Shepherd, the name Milly often playfully used for her, was not anyone else. She had given up that identity; she no longer had a life of her own to live; and she truly believed this made her perfectly suited to lead Milly's. No other person, she was sure, had this qualification to the same degree, and it was to confirm this that she enthusiastically set off. Many things, though not in many weeks, had come and gone since then, and one of the best of them, undoubtedly, had been the voyage itself, by the pleasant southern route, to the succession of Mediterranean ports, culminating in the dazzling finale in Naples.

Two or three others had preceded this; incidents, indeed rather lively marks, of their last fortnight at home, and one of which had determined on Mrs. Stringham's part a rush to New York, forty-eight breathless hours there, previous to her final rally. But the great sustained sea-light had drunk up the rest of the picture, so that for many days other questions and other possibilities sounded with as little effect as a trio of penny whistles might sound in a Wagner overture. It was the Wagner overture that practically prevailed, up through Italy, where Milly had already been, still further up and across the Alps, which were also partly known to Mrs.

Translation

Two or three other experiences had come before this one. These were lively reminders of their last two weeks at home. One of these experiences had prompted Mrs. Stringham to rush to New York for a breathless forty-eight hours before she finally left. But the continuous, brilliant light of the sea had obscured the rest of the picture. For many days, other questions and possibilities had as little impact as a trio of penny whistles in a Wagner overture. It was the Wagner overture that practically dominated, throughout Italy, where Milly had already been, and further up and across the Alps, which Mrs. Stringham also knew in part.

Stringham; only perhaps "taken" to a time not wholly congruous, hurried in fact on account of the girl's high restlessness. She had been expected, she had frankly promised, to be restless—that was partly why she was "great"—or was a consequence, at any rate, if not a cause; yet she had not perhaps altogether announced herself as straining so hard at the cord. It was familiar, it was beautiful to Mrs. Stringham that she had arrears to make up, the chances that had lapsed for her through the wanton ways of forefathers fond of Paris, but not of its higher sides, and fond almost of nothing else; but the vagueness, the openness, the eagerness without point and the interest without pause—all a part of the charm of her oddity as at first presented—had become more striking in proportion as they triumphed over movement and change.

Translation

Stringham; only perhaps brought to a time not entirely fitting, rushed, in fact, because of the girl's extreme restlessness. She had been expected, she had frankly promised, to be restless—that was partly why she was "great"—or was a result, at any rate, if not a cause; yet she had not perhaps entirely revealed herself as straining so hard against the limits. It was familiar, it was beautiful to Mrs. Stringham that she had lost opportunities to catch up, the chances that had slipped away from her through the careless ways of ancestors who loved Paris, but not its finer aspects, and loved almost nothing else; but the uncertainty, the openness, the eagerness without direction and the interest without end—all a part of the charm of her eccentricity as first observed—had become more noticeable as they overcame movement and change.

She had arts and idiosyncrasies of which no great account could have been given, but which were a daily grace if you lived with them; such as the art of being almost tragically impatient and yet making it as light as air; of being inexplicably sad and yet making it as clear as noon; of being unmistakably gay, and yet making it as soft as dusk. Mrs. Stringham by this time understood everything, was more than ever confirmed in wonder and admiration, in her view that it was life enough simply to feel her companion's feelings; but there were special keys she had not yet added to her bunch, impressions that, of a sudden, were apt to affect her as new. A lot had happened since then, though not a long time had passed.

Translation

She possessed talents and quirks that weren't easily explained, but which, if you lived with them, were a daily source of beauty. These included the skill of being almost tragically impatient yet making it seem effortless; of being inexplicably sad yet making it as bright as midday; of being unmistakably happy, yet making it as gentle as twilight. By this point, Mrs. Stringham understood everything, and was more than ever filled with wonder and admiration, believing that simply feeling her companion's feelings was enough to sustain a life. Yet there were still certain nuances she hadn't yet grasped, impressions that suddenly struck her as fresh. A great deal had changed since then, though it hadn't been long.

One of the best things, undoubtedly, was the voyage itself. They had sailed south, enjoying the Mediterranean ports, and the delightful ending in Naples. There had been two or three other significant events beforehand. These were lively episodes from their last two weeks at home.

Translation

Without a doubt, one of the best parts was the trip itself. They'd sailed south, enjoying the ports along the Mediterranean, culminating in the joy of Naples. Before that, there were a couple of other significant events. These were lively episodes from their final two weeks at home.

One of them had prompted Mrs. Stringham to rush to New York. She spent forty-eight breathless hours there, just before they finally left. But the continuous bright sea had erased the rest of the memories.

Translation

That event had caused Mrs. Stringham to rush off to New York. She was there for a frantic two days right before they left. However, the constantly sunny sea had washed away the other recollections.

For many days, other problems and possibilities seemed insignificant. They were as ineffective as a cheap trio of whistles playing during a Wagner overture. It was the Wagner overture that truly dominated their trip. This continued as they traveled through Italy, where Milly had already been.

Translation

For many days, other problems and possibilities seemed insignificant, as ineffectual as a cheap trio of whistles piping during a Wagner overture. It was the Wagner overture that truly dominated their trip. This continued as they traveled through Italy, where Milly had already been.

It went on as they went further up into the Alps, which Mrs. Stringham also partly knew. Perhaps, the trip was arranged to fit the timeframe of a hurried visit. This was caused by the girl's strong restlessness.

Translation

It continued as they ascended into the Alps, a region Mrs. Stringham had also partially explored. Perhaps the itinerary was structured to accommodate a fleeting visit, a schedule dictated by the girl's pronounced unease.

It was expected and promised that she would be restless. That was partly why she was "great." It was a consequence of her personality. However, she perhaps hadn't expressed how much she was struggling. It was familiar and beautiful to Mrs.

Translation

Stringham to witness the girl's anguish. It was, after all, a large part of her charm.

Stringham that Milly had things to catch up on. She needed to experience the opportunities that had passed her by. This was due to her ancestors, who loved Paris, but not its finer aspects, and didn't seem to love much else. But the vagueness, openness, eagerness without a specific purpose, and the constant interest – all part of the charm of her oddity as first perceived – had become more striking as they were amplified by movement and change.

Translation

Stringham realized that Milly had some lost ground to cover. She needed to seize the experiences that she'd missed. This was a consequence of her forebears, who adored Paris, but not its more sophisticated elements, and who didn't appear to have cared for much else. However, the imprecision, the receptiveness, the ambition without a clear objective, and the perpetual curiosity—all aspects of the charm she had initially projected—became more pronounced as they were enhanced by travel and evolution.

She had skills and quirks that were hard to explain. But if you lived with them, they brought daily grace. These included the skill of being almost tragically impatient, yet making it seem lighthearted. She could be inexplicably sad, yet make it as clear as noon.

Translation

She possessed abilities and eccentricities that defied easy description. However, when you shared her life, they brought a daily elegance. This included the talent for being nearly devastatingly impatient, while making it appear playful. She could be inexplicably melancholic, and yet make her sadness as clear as daylight.

She could be undeniably happy, and yet make it as soft as dusk. By now, Mrs. Stringham understood everything. She was even more confirmed in her wonder and admiration.

Translation

She could be undeniably happy, and yet make it as soft as dusk. By now, Mrs. Stringham understood everything. She was even more confirmed in her wonder and admiration.

She felt it was enough to simply experience her companion's feelings. But there were special insights she hadn't yet grasped, impressions that suddenly affected her as something new. This particular day on the great Swiss road had been, for some reason, full of them, and they referred themselves, provisionally, to some deeper depth than she had touched—though into two or three such depths, it must be added, she had peeped long enough to find herself suddenly draw back. It was not Milly's unpacified state, in short, that now troubled her—though certainly, as Europe was the great American sedative, the failure was to some extent to be noted: it was the suspected presence of something behind it—which, however, could scarcely have taken its place there since their departure.

Translation

She felt that it was enough just to share her friend's emotions. Yet, there were particular understandings that eluded her, impressions that suddenly struck her as novel. This specific day on the expansive Swiss road had been, for reasons she couldn't articulate, filled with them, and they seemed to originate from a greater depth than she had previously explored—though it must be said that she had peered into two or three such depths for a period long enough to abruptly retreat. Ultimately, it wasn't Milly's unsettled condition that now concerned her—although, undoubtedly, as Europe was meant to soothe Americans, the lack of improvement was somewhat noteworthy: instead, it was the suspected presence of something hidden—something, however, that could hardly have appeared since their journey began.

What any fresh motive of unrest could suddenly have sprung from was, in short, not to be divined. It was but half an explanation to say that excitement, for each of them, had naturally dropped, and that what they had left behind, or tried to—the great serious facts of life, as Mrs. Stringham liked to call them—was once more coming into sight as objects loom through smoke when smoke begins to clear; for these were general appearances from which the girl's own aspect, her really larger vagueness, seemed rather to disconnect itself. The nearest approach to a personal anxiety indulged in as yet by the elder lady was on her taking occasion to wonder if what she had more than anything else got hold of mightn't be one of the finer, one of the finest, one of the rarest—as she called it so that she might call it nothing worse—cases of American intensity.

Translation

The source of any new disquiet was, in short, impossible to guess. It was only a partial explanation to say that their initial excitement had naturally waned, and that what they had left behind, or attempted to—the significant, serious realities of life, as Mrs. Stringham was fond of saying—were once again becoming visible, like objects emerging from smoke as it dissipates. However, these were general observations, and the girl's own demeanor, her considerable and pervasive ambiguity, seemed somewhat separate from them. The closest the elder woman had come to expressing personal concern was when she wondered if what she had primarily grasped might not be one of the subtler, one of the most subtle, one of the rarest—as she phrased it to avoid a harsher description—cases of American intensity.

She had just had a moment of alarm—asked herself if her young friend were merely going to treat her to some complicated drama of nerves. At the end of a week, however, with their further progress, her young friend had effectively answered the question and given her the impression, indistinct indeed as yet, of something that had a reality compared with which the nervous explanation would have been coarse. Mrs. Stringham found herself from that hour, in other words, in presence of an explanation that remained a muffled and intangible form, but that, assuredly, should it take on sharpness, would explain everything and more than everything, would become instantly the light in which Milly was to be read.

Translation

She had just been startled for a moment—had wondered if her young friend might simply perform some elaborate display of nerves for her. But at the end of a week, as they continued on, her young friend had effectively answered the question, giving her the impression, still hazy, of something real, beside which the nervous explanation would have seemed crude. From that moment on, Mrs. Stringham realized, she was in the presence of an explanation that remained muffled and indistinct, but which, if it were to become clear, would explain everything and more than everything, becoming instantly the light in which Milly was to be understood.

That particular day on the grand Swiss road was, for some reason, filled with these feelings, and they seemed to connect to a deeper level than she had previously understood—although, it should be noted, she had glanced into two or three of these depths, only to quickly withdraw. In short, it wasn't Milly's unsettled condition that was bothering her now—even though the failure of Europe to calm her, as it was supposed to do for Americans, was noticeable to some degree. What was troubling was the suspected presence of something hidden beneath the surface—something that couldn't possibly have appeared since they had left. What new cause for anxiety could have suddenly arisen was, in short, impossible to guess.

Translation

That day on the grand Swiss road was, for some reason, saturated with these feelings. They seemed to tap into something deeper than she'd previously realized, though she had, it must be said, glanced into a few of these depths, only to immediately pull back. In short, it wasn't Milly's unease that preoccupied her now—though the failure of Europe to soothe her, as it was supposed to do for Americans, was evident to a degree. What was troubling was the suspected presence of something concealed beneath the surface—something that couldn't possibly have emerged since they'd departed. The source of this new anxiety was, in short, impossible to fathom.

It was a weak explanation to say that excitement had naturally faded for both of them and that the significant issues they had left behind, or tried to, as Mrs. Stringham liked to call them, were once again becoming visible, like objects emerging from smoke as it dissipates. This was because these were general observations, and the girl's own condition, her greater sense of uncertainty, seemed to be separate from them. The closest the older woman came to expressing a personal concern was when she wondered if what she was observing might be a particularly intense, one of the most intense, one of the rarest—as she put it to avoid using a harsher term—cases of American intensity.

Translation

It was a flimsy explanation to say their initial excitement had simply worn off, that the significant issues they'd tried to escape, as Mrs. Stringham put it, were now reappearing, like objects resolving out of smoke. This was because these were general observations, and the girl's own state, her heightened anxiety, seemed unrelated. The older woman's closest approach to a personal concern was her speculation about whether what she was witnessing was a particularly intense, even the most intense, one of the rarest—she chose the phrase to avoid a harsher term—cases of American intensity.

She had been momentarily alarmed, wondering if her young friend was about to subject her to some complex display of nerves. However, after a week and further travels, her young friend had effectively answered the question, giving her the impression, though still unclear, of something real, compared to which the nervous explanation would have been crude. In other words, Mrs. Stringham found herself from that moment facing an explanation that remained vague and undefined.

Translation

She had felt a flicker of alarm, fearing her young companion was about to launch into some elaborate nervous performance. But a week and more travel passed, and her young friend seemed to have provided an answer, offering the impression, however unclear, of something genuine, making the anxious explanation seem clumsy by comparison. In other words, from that moment on, Mrs. Stringham found herself confronting an explanation that remained indefinite and indistinct.

Still, should it become clearer, it would explain everything and more, instantly becoming the key to understanding Milly. Such a matter as this may at all events speak of the style in which our young woman could affect those who were near her, may testify to the sort of interest she could inspire. She worked—and seemingly quite without design—upon the sympathy, the curiosity, the fancy of her associates, and we shall really ourselves scarce otherwise come closer to her than by feeling their impression and sharing, if need be, their confusion. She reduced them, Mrs.

Translation

Stringham knew, to the necessity of their being, for the most part, as vague as she was, and the effect of it was naturally to make her feel the less vague.

However, if it should become clearer, it would explain everything and more, instantly becoming the key to understanding Milly. Such a matter as this may at all events speak of the style in which our young woman could affect those who were near her, may testify to the sort of interest she could inspire. She worked—and seemingly quite without design—upon the sympathy, the curiosity, the fancy of her associates, and we shall really ourselves scarce otherwise come closer to her than by feeling their impression and sharing, if need be, their confusion. She reduced them, Mrs. Stringham knew, to the necessity of their being, for the most part, as vague as she was, and the effect of it was naturally to make her feel the less vague.

Stringham would have said, reduced them to a consenting bewilderment; which was precisely, for that good lady, on a last analysis, what was most in harmony with her greatness. She exceeded, escaped measure, was surprising only because they were so far from great. Thus it was that on this wondrous day on the Brünig the spell of watching her had grown more than ever irresistible; a proof of what—or of a part of what—Mrs. Stringham had, with all the rest, been reduced to.

Translation

Stringham would have said she reduced them to consenting bewilderment; which was, precisely, for that good lady, on a final analysis, what was most in harmony with her greatness. She was exceptional, defied measure, was only surprising because they were so far from great. Thus it was that on this wondrous day on the Brünig the spell of watching her had grown more than ever irresistible; a proof of what—or of a part of what—Mrs. Stringham had, with everyone else, been reduced to.

She had almost the sense of tracking her young friend as if at a given moment to pounce. She knew she shouldn't pounce, she hadn't come out to pounce; yet she felt her attention secretive, all the same, and her observation scientific. She struck herself as hovering like a spy, applying tests, laying traps, concealing signs. This would last, however, only till she should fairly know what was the matter; and to watch was, after all, meanwhile, a way of clinging to the girl, not less than an occupation, a satisfaction in itself.

Translation

She almost felt as if she were tracking her young friend, ready to pounce at any moment. She knew she shouldn't pounce; she hadn't set out to do so. Still, she sensed her own attention was furtive, and her observation, scientific. She appeared to herself like a spy, hovering, conducting tests, setting traps, hiding her intentions. However, this would last only until she understood the problem. And, in the meantime, watching was a way of clinging to the girl, as much an activity as a source of satisfaction.

The pleasure of watching, moreover, if a reason were needed, came from a sense of her beauty. Her beauty hadn't at all originally seemed a part of the situation, and Mrs. Stringham had, even in the first flush of friendship, not named it, grossly, to any one; having seen early that, for stupid people—and who, she sometimes secretly asked herself, wasn't stupid?—it would take a great deal of explaining. She had learned not to mention it till it was mentioned first—which occasionally happened, but not too often; and then she was there in force.

Translation

The enjoyment of observation, if a justification was required, stemmed from a perception of the girl's beauty. Her beauty hadn't initially seemed relevant, and Mrs. Stringham, even during the first stages of their friendship, hadn't explicitly mentioned it to anyone. She'd realized early on that, for the foolish—and who, she sometimes wondered privately, wasn't foolish?—it would require extensive explanation. She'd learned to avoid bringing it up until someone else did—which occurred sometimes, but not often; and then she was ready to engage.

Then she both warmed to the perception that met her own perception, and disputed it, suspiciously, as to special items; while, in general, she had learned to refine even to the point of herself employing the word that most people employed. She employed it to pretend that she was also stupid and so have done with the matter; spoke of her friend as plain, as ugly even, in a case of especially dense insistence; but as, in appearance, so "awfully full of things." This was her own way of describing a face that, thanks, doubtless, to rather too much forehead, too much nose and too much mouth, together with too little mere conventional colour and conventional line, was expressive, irregular, exquisite, both for speech and for silence. When Milly smiled it was a public event—when she didn't it was a chapter of history. They had stopped, on the Brünig, for luncheon, and there had come up for them under the charm of the place the question of a longer stay.

Translation

Then she both embraced the perception that mirrored her own, and, suspiciously, challenged it, focusing on specific details. In general, she had learned to refine her understanding to the point of using the word most people used. She employed it to feign stupidity and thus be done with the subject, referring to her friend as plain, even ugly, when faced with especially persistent scrutiny; but, in terms of her appearance, "awfully full of things." This was her own way of describing a face that, owing no doubt to a rather prominent forehead, nose, and mouth, coupled with a lack of conventional color and line, was expressive, irregular, and exquisite, both in moments of speech and silence. When Milly smiled it was a public event—when she didn't, it was a chapter of history. They had stopped on the Brünig for lunch, and under the spell of the location, the idea of staying longer had arisen.

This situation demonstrates how this young woman could affect those around her, revealing the kind of interest she could generate. She effortlessly influenced the sympathy, curiosity, and imagination of those close to her. To understand her, we must experience their impressions and, if necessary, share their confusion. She reduced them, as Mrs.

Translation

This situation demonstrates how this young woman could affect those around her, revealing the kind of interest she could generate. She effortlessly influenced the sympathy, curiosity, and imagination of those close to her. To understand her, we must experience their impressions and, if necessary, share their confusion. She reduced them, as Mrs.

Stringham would say, to a state of willing bewilderment. For that good woman, this was precisely what aligned with her greatness. The young woman exceeded expectations, defying measurement. Her surprising nature was only because they were not great.

Translation

Stringham would say, to a state of willing bewilderment. For that good woman, this was precisely what aligned with her greatness. The young woman exceeded expectations, defying measurement. Her surprising nature was only because they were not great.

Thus, on that remarkable day on the Brünig, the fascination of observing her grew stronger than ever. This proved what—or a portion of what—Mrs. Stringham, along with everyone else, had been reduced to. She felt as though she was tracking her young friend, ready to pounce at any moment.

Translation

So, on that extraordinary day on the Brünig, the captivating experience of watching her intensified. This demonstrated what—or at least some of what—Mrs. Stringham, along with everyone else, had become. She felt as though she was stalking her young friend, prepared to spring into action at any instant.

She knew she wouldn't pounce; she didn't come to do that. Yet, her attention felt secretive, and her observation felt scientific. She thought of herself as a hovering spy, conducting tests, setting traps, and concealing her true intentions. This would only last until she fully understood what was happening.

Translation

She understood she wouldn't attack; that wasn't why she was there. Still, her focus felt clandestine, and her study felt clinical. She imagined herself as a watchful observer, running experiments, laying snares, and masking her real motivations. This would continue only until she had a complete grasp of the situation.

Watching was, after all, a way of staying connected to the girl, an occupation, and a source of satisfaction in itself. The pleasure of watching also came from appreciating her beauty. Her beauty hadn't initially seemed relevant to the situation, and Mrs. Stringham, even early in their friendship, hadn't openly mentioned it to anyone.

Translation

Watching was, after all, a way to stay connected to the girl, a pastime, and a source of personal fulfillment. The satisfaction of watching also derived from appreciating her beauty. Her beauty hadn't initially seemed pertinent to the situation, and Mrs. Stringham, even early in their friendship, hadn't openly discussed it with anyone.

She had quickly realized that for those who weren't intelligent—and who, she sometimes wondered privately, wasn't?—it would require extensive explanation. She had learned not to bring it up until someone else did, which occurred occasionally, but not too often. Then she would strongly agree with the perception that mirrored her own, while still disputing specific aspects of it. In general, she had learned to refine her perception to the point of using the same word that most people used.

Translation

She soon understood that explaining it would take a lot of work for those who weren’t smart – and who, she sometimes wondered, actually were? She’d learned not to bring it up unless someone else did, which happened now and then, but not frequently. Then she would strongly agree with their understanding, which was also hers, while still disagreeing with some of the details. Overall, she had learned to shape her understanding to the point that she used the same language as everyone else.

She used it to pretend she was also unintelligent and to be done with the matter. She would describe her friend as plain, even ugly, when faced with particularly dense insistence. But, in appearance, she was "awfully full of things." This was her way of describing a face that, perhaps due to a large forehead, a prominent nose, and a wide mouth, along with a lack of conventional color and shape, was expressive, unconventional, and exquisite in both speech and silence. When Milly smiled, it was a public event; when she didn't, it was a significant event.

Translation

She used this to pretend she was also unintelligent and be done with it. She would call her friend plain, even ugly, when someone was being particularly dense. But, in reality, she was "awfully full of things." This was how she described a face that, maybe because of a large forehead, a prominent nose, and a wide mouth, along with a lack of typical color and shape, was expressive, unconventional, and exquisite in both speech and silence. When Milly smiled, it was a public event; when she didn't, it was a significant event.

They had stopped for lunch on the Brünig, and the question of staying longer arose because of the charming atmosphere. Mrs. Stringham was now on the ground of thrilled recognitions, small sharp echoes of a past which she kept in a well-thumbed case, but which, on pressure of a spring and exposure to the air, still showed itself ticking as hard as an honest old watch. The embalmed "Europe" of her younger time had partly stood for three years of Switzerland, a term of continuous school at Vevey, with rewards of merit in the form of silver medals tied by blue ribbons and mild mountain-passes attacked with alpenstocks.

Translation

They’d stopped for lunch on the Brünig Pass, and the idea of staying longer came up because of the appealing ambiance. Mrs. Stringham was now on the terrain of excited recollections, faint but definite echoes of a past she kept in a much-handled case, which, when triggered and exposed, still revealed itself ticking as reliably as an authentic antique watch. The preserved “Europe” of her youth had partly represented three years in Switzerland, a period of uninterrupted schooling in Vevey, with honors of achievement in the form of silver medals tied with blue ribbons and gentle mountain passes conquered with walking sticks.

It was the good girls who, in the holidays, were taken highest, and our friend could now judge, from what she supposed her familiarity with the minor peaks, that she had been one of the best. These reminiscences, sacred to-day because prepared in the hushed chambers of the past, had been part of the general train laid for the pair of sisters, daughters early fatherless, by their brave Vermont mother, who struck her at present as having apparently, almost like Columbus, worked out, all unassisted, a conception of the other side of the globe. She had focussed Vevey, by the light of nature, and with extraordinary completeness, at Burlington; after which she had embarked, sailed, landed, explored and, above all, made good her presence. She had given her daughters the five years in Switzerland and Germany that were to leave them ever afterwards a standard of comparison for all cycles of Cathay, and to stamp the younger in especial—Susan was the younger—with a character that, as Mrs.

Translation

It was the well-behaved girls who were taken to the highest places during school holidays, and our friend could now see, judging from her supposed familiarity with the lesser mountains, that she must have been one of the best. These recollections, sacred now because they were prepared in the quiet chambers of the past, had been part of the overall plan laid out for the two sisters, daughters who had lost their father early, by their brave Vermont mother, who, at the moment, seemed to have worked out, almost like Columbus, a conception of the other side of the world, entirely on her own. She had brought Vevey into focus, using her own intuition, with remarkable thoroughness, in Burlington; after which she had embarked, sailed, landed, explored and, above all, ensured her presence. She had given her daughters the five years in Switzerland and Germany that would forevermore leave them with a standard of comparison for all kinds of faraway places, and to imprint the younger one, in particular—Susan was the younger—with a character that, as Mrs.

Stringham had often had occasion, through life, to say to herself, made all the difference. It made all the difference for Mrs. Stringham, over and over again and in the most remote connections, that, thanks to her parent's lonely, thrifty, hardy faith, she was a woman of the world. There were plenty of women who were all sorts of things that she wasn't, but who, on the other hand, were not that, and who didn't know she was (which she liked—it relegated them still further) and didn't know, either, how it enabled her to judge them.

Translation

Stringham often had reason to tell herself throughout her life, “it made all the difference.” It made all the difference for Mrs. Stringham, repeatedly and in the most unexpected ways, that, thanks to her parents’ solitary, frugal, resolute belief, she was a woman of the world. There were plenty of women who were all sorts of things that she wasn't, but who, conversely, were not that, and who didn’t know she was (which she appreciated—it distanced them further) and didn’t know, either, how it allowed her to assess them.

She had never seen herself so much in this light as during the actual phase of her associated, if slightly undirected, pilgrimage; and the consciousness gave perhaps to her plea for a pause more intensity than she knew. The irrecoverable days had come back to her from far off; they were part of the sense of the cool upper air and of everything else that hung like an indestructible scent to the torn garment of youth—the taste of honey and the luxury of milk, the sound of cattle-bells and the rush of streams, the fragrance of trodden balms and the dizziness of deep gorges. Mrs. Stringham was now in a realm of excited memories, small, sharp echoes of a past she kept in a well-worn box.

Translation

She hadn't seen herself so clearly until she was in the thick of her wandering, though it was somewhat aimless. This awareness might have made her request for a break more urgent than she realized. Those lost days had returned from a distant place. They were part of the sensation of crisp, high air, and of everything else that clung to the tattered remnants of youth like an everlasting fragrance—the taste of honey and the richness of milk, the ringing of cowbells and the roar of rushing water, the scent of crushed plants and the vertigo of deep ravines. Mrs. Stringham was now in a world of lively memories, small, distinct echoes of a past she kept stored in a well-used box.

When she pressed a hidden button and let it breathe, the past still ticked away like a reliable old watch. The "Europe" of her youth had partly been shaped by three years in Switzerland, a period of schooling in Vevey. She'd won merit awards—silver medals with blue ribbons—and she'd hiked through gentle mountain passes with alpenstocks. The girls who were considered "good" would be taken on the highest climbs during the holidays.

Translation

When she activated the hidden mechanism and allowed it to run, the past continued to measure time, a dependable old timepiece. The "Europe" of her younger years was partially formed by three years in Switzerland, a time of education in Vevey. She had earned honors—silver medals with blue ribbons—and she'd trekked through easy mountain trails with walking sticks. The girls who were deemed "well-behaved" were permitted on the most elevated climbs during the breaks.

Now, Mrs. Stringham could guess, based on her supposed familiarity with the lesser peaks, that she had been one of the best. These memories, precious because they were carefully stored in the quiet rooms of the past, had been part of a plan prepared for the two sisters. Their courageous mother, from Vermont, had lost their father early in their lives.

Translation

Based on her supposed familiarity with the lesser peaks, Mrs. Stringham could now guess she’d been one of the best. These memories, precious because they were carefully stored in the quiet rooms of the past, had been part of a plan prepared for the two sisters. Their courageous mother, from Vermont, had lost their father early in their lives.

Mrs. Stringham now thought her mother had, almost like Columbus, worked out her own idea of the other side of the world, all by herself. She had focused on Vevey with remarkable precision in Burlington, relying only on her own intuition. After that, she had set sail, arrived, explored, and, most importantly, made sure they were seen.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham now believed her mother had, much like Columbus, conceived her own vision of the world's other side, entirely on her own. She had pinpointed Vevey with astounding accuracy while still in Burlington, guided solely by her instincts. Following this, she had embarked, arrived, explored, and, most crucially, ensured they were noticed.

She had given her daughters five years in Switzerland and Germany. Those years would forever give them a basis for comparing all of life's experiences. They especially shaped the younger sister, Susan, giving her a character that, as Mrs. Stringham had often said to herself throughout her life, made all the difference.

Translation

She'd given her daughters five years in Switzerland and Germany. Those years would permanently provide a framework for evaluating all of life. They particularly defined the younger sister, Susan, imbuing her with a character that, as Mrs. Stringham had often reflected, made all the difference.

It made all the difference for Mrs. Stringham, repeatedly and in unexpected ways, that because of her parent's solitary, economical, and strong belief, she was a woman of the world. There were many women who were other things she wasn't, but who, on the other hand, weren't that, and who didn't know she was (which she liked—it put them at a greater distance). They also didn't know how her experiences enabled her to judge them.

Translation

That she was a woman of the world made all the difference to Mrs. Stringham, over and over, and in ways she couldn't have anticipated. This was a consequence of her parents' self-sufficient, frugal, and unwavering convictions. There were plenty of women who possessed qualities she lacked, but who, conversely, did not have that one, and who were unaware that she did (which she enjoyed—it put them at a greater remove). They also didn't realize how her experiences enabled her to assess them.

She had never seen herself in this light as much as during this phase of her journey, even though it lacked a clear direction. This awareness gave her request for a break more urgency than she realized. Those days she could never get back had returned to her from afar. They were part of the feeling of cool, fresh air, and everything else that clung like an everlasting fragrance to the tattered clothes of youth: the taste of honey and the pleasure of milk, the sound of cowbells and the roar of streams, the scent of crushed herbs and the vertigo of deep ravines.

Translation

More than ever, she was seeing herself this way, even though she wasn't sure where she was going. This realization made her need for a pause more pressing than she understood. The days she couldn't recover had come back to her from a distance. They were part of the sensation of cool, clean air and everything else that clung like a permanent scent to the worn clothes of her youth: the taste of honey and the pleasure of milk, the sound of cowbells and the roar of streams, the fragrance of crushed herbs and the vertigo of deep ravines.

Milly clearly felt these things too, but they affected her companion at moments—that was quite the way Mrs. Stringham would have expressed it—as the princess in a conventional tragedy might have affected the confidant if a personal emotion had ever been permitted to the latter. That a princess could only be a princess was a truth with which, essentially, a confidant, however responsive, had to live. Mrs.

Translation

Milly evidently felt them as well, though at times they impacted her companion—as Mrs. Stringham would surely have put it—much like a princess in a conventional tragedy might impact the confidante, assuming the confidante were ever allowed to feel a personal emotion. That a princess could only be a princess was a truth with which a confidante, however sympathetic, had to contend. Mrs.

Stringham was a woman of the world, but Milly Theale was a princess, the only one she had yet had to deal with, and this in its way, too, made all the difference. It was a perfectly definite doom for the wearer—it was for every one else a perfectly palpable quality. It might have been, possibly, with its involved loneliness and other mysteries, the weight under which she fancied her companion's admirable head occasionally, and ever so submissively, bowed. Milly had quite assented at luncheon to their staying over, and had left her to look at rooms, settle questions, arrange about their keeping on their carriage and horses; cares that had now moreover fallen to Mrs.

Translation

Stringham was worldly-wise, but Milly Theale was a princess, the only one she'd had to manage, and this, in its own way, changed everything. It was a clear-cut fate for the one who bore it—and it was a tangible quality for everyone else. Perhaps, with its inherent loneliness and other secrets, it was the weight that, she imagined, occasionally bowed her companion's admirable head, ever so submissively. Milly had readily agreed at luncheon to remain, and had left her to view the rooms, resolve issues, and make arrangements for keeping their carriage and horses; concerns that had now, furthermore, fallen to Mrs.

Stringham as a matter of course and that yet for some reason, on this occasion particularly, brought home to her—all agreeably, richly, almost grandly—what it was to live with the great. Her young friend had, in a sublime degree, a sense closed to the general question of difficulty, which she got rid of, furthermore, not in the least as one had seen many charming persons do, by merely passing it on to others. She kept it completely at a distance: it never entered the circle; the most plaintive confidant couldn't have dragged it in; and to tread the path of a confidant was accordingly to live exempt. Service was in other words so easy to render that the whole thing was like court life without the hardships.

Translation

Stringham, as a matter of course, and yet for some reason, on this occasion particularly, it brought home to her—agreeably, richly, almost grandly—what it was to live with the great. Her young friend had, in a sublime degree, a sense closed off to the general question of difficulty, which she got rid of, furthermore, not in the least as one had seen many charming people do, by merely passing it on to others. She kept it completely at a distance: it never entered the circle; the most plaintive confidant couldn't have dragged it in; and to tread the path of a confidant was accordingly to live exempt. Service was, in other words, so easy to render that the whole thing was like court life without the hardships.

It came back of course to the question of money, and our observant lady had by this time repeatedly reflected that if one were talking of the "difference," it was just this, this incomparably and nothing else, that when all was said and done most made it. A less vulgarly, a less obviously purchasing or parading person she couldn't have imagined; but it was, all the same, the truth of truths that the girl couldn't get away from her wealth. She might leave her conscientious companion as freely alone with it as possible and never ask a question, scarce even tolerate a reference; but it was in the fine folds of the helplessly expensive little black frock that she drew over the grass as she now strolled vaguely off; it was in the curious and splendid coils of hair, "done" with no eye whatever to the mode du jour, that peeped from under the corresponding indifference of her hat, the merely personal tradition that suggested a sort of noble inelegance; it lurked between the leaves of the uncut but antiquated Tauchnitz volume of which, before going out, she had mechanically possessed herself. She couldn't dress it away, nor walk it away, nor read it away, nor think it away; she could neither smile it away in any dreamy absence nor blow it away in any softened sigh.

Translation

It always came back to money, and our observant lady had, by this point, repeatedly considered that if one were discussing "the difference," it was specifically this, and nothing else, that made it most of all. She couldn't have imagined a less vulgar, a less ostentatious person. But the inescapable truth was that the girl couldn't escape her wealth. She might leave her conscientious companion alone with it as much as possible, never asking a question, scarcely even acknowledging it. But it was there in the elegant folds of the helplessly expensive little black frock she wore as she aimlessly strolled away. It was in the curious, splendid hairstyle, "done" without any regard for current fashion, peeking from under the hat, whose indifference also suggested a kind of noble lack of elegance. It was present between the pages of the uncut but antiquated Tauchnitz volume that she had mechanically picked up before leaving. She couldn't dress it away, walk it away, read it away, or think it away. She could neither smile it away in any dreamy absence nor blow it away in any soft sigh.

She couldn't have lost it if she had tried—that was what it was to be really rich. It had to be the thing you were. When at the end of an hour she had not returned to the house Mrs. Stringham, though the bright afternoon was yet young, took, with precautions, the same direction, went to join her in case of her caring for a walk.

Translation

She couldn't have lost it even if she'd wanted to—that's what being truly rich meant. It was something you simply were. When the girl hadn't returned to the house after an hour, though the bright afternoon was still early, Mrs. Stringham, with certain precautions, went in the same direction, deciding to join her in case she felt like a walk.

But the purpose of joining her was in truth less distinct than that of a due regard for a possibly preferred detachment: so that, once more, the good lady proceeded with a quietness that made her slightly "underhand" even in her own eyes. She couldn't help that, however, and she didn't care, sure as she was that what she really wanted was not to overstep, but to stop in time. It was to be able to stop in time that she went softly, but she had on this occasion further to go than ever yet, for she followed in vain, and at last with some anxiety, the footpath she believed Milly to have taken. It wound up a hillside and into the higher Alpine meadows in which, all these last days, they had so often wanted, as they passed above or below, to stray; and then it obscured itself in a wood, but always going up, up, and with a small cluster of brown old high-perched chalets evidently for its goal.

Translation

However, the reason for joining her was actually less clear than a proper respect for a potential desire to be alone. So, once again, the good lady continued forward with a quietness that seemed a bit "sneaky" even to herself. She couldn't help it, though, and didn't really care, as sure as she was that what she truly wanted was not to overstep, but to stop in time. It was to be able to stop in time that she walked softly, but on this occasion she had further to go than ever before, for she followed in vain, and at last with some anxiety, the footpath she believed Milly had taken. It wound up a hillside and into the higher Alpine meadows where, all these last days, they had so often wanted, as they passed above or below, to wander; and then it disappeared into a wood, but always going up, up, and with a small group of brown, old, high-perched chalets clearly as its destination.

Mrs. Stringham reached in due course the chalets, and there received from a bewildered old woman, a very fearful person to behold, an indication that sufficiently guided her. The young lady had been seen not long before passing further on, over a crest and to a place where the way would drop again, as our unappeased inquirer found it, in fact, a quarter of an hour later, markedly and almost alarmingly to do. It led somewhere, yet apparently quite into space, for the great side of the mountain appeared, from where she pulled up, to fall away altogether, though probably but to some issue below and out of sight.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham arrived at the chalets eventually and, from a bewildered old woman—a truly frightening figure—obtained directions that were helpful enough. The young lady had been seen not long before, heading beyond the crest and toward a spot where the path descended. Our still-unsatisfied seeker discovered this to be the case a quarter of an hour later, quite clearly, and almost alarmingly so. It led somewhere, though seemingly into nothingness, as from where she stopped, the vast mountainside appeared to simply fall away. Though it likely only led to somewhere below, out of view.

Her uncertainty moreover was brief, for she next became aware of the presence on a fragment of rock, twenty yards off, of the Tauchnitz volume that the girl had brought out, and that therefore pointed to her shortly previous passage. She had rid herself of the book, which was an encumbrance, and meant of course to pick it up on her return; but as she hadn't yet picked it up what on earth had become of her? Mrs. Stringham, I hasten to add, was within a few moments to see; but it was quite an accident that she had not, before they were over, betrayed by her deeper agitation the fact of her own nearness.

Translation

Her hesitation didn’t last long, for she then noticed, lying on a small rock twenty yards away, the Tauchnitz edition the girl had carried. It indicated the girl had passed by there recently. The girl had gotten rid of the book, since it was cumbersome, intending to retrieve it later. But if she hadn’t yet picked it up, where could she have gone? Mrs. Stringham was, I should add, about to find out, but it was just luck that her extreme distress hadn't already revealed her presence.

Milly obviously felt things deeply too, but they seemed to affect her companion at times—that was exactly how Mrs. Stringham would have put it—much like a princess in a traditional play might affect a confidant, if personal feelings were ever allowed for the confidant. A princess could only be a princess, and that was a truth a confidant, no matter how understanding, had to accept. Mrs.

Translation

Milly was sensitive, no doubt, but her sensitivities seemed to impact her friend at certain moments—that was, in Mrs. Stringham's view, the way a princess's moods might affect a confidante in a play, assuming the confidante were allowed any genuine personal feelings at all. A princess was simply a princess, a fact her most empathetic confidante must acknowledge. Mrs.

Stringham was worldly, but Milly Theale was a princess, the only one she'd ever had to deal with, and that, too, made all the difference. It was a definite fate for the one who lived it—but for everyone else, it was a very obvious characteristic. Perhaps it was the burden of her isolation and other mysteries that, Mrs. Stringham imagined, sometimes made her companion's admirable head bow, ever so humbly.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham was experienced, but Milly Theale was a princess, the only one she'd ever known, and that changed everything. It was a fixed destiny for the person living it, but for everyone else, it was simply a clear trait. Maybe it was the weight of her loneliness and other secrets that, Mrs. Stringham thought, sometimes made her friend's impressive head drop in a posture of humility.

Milly had agreed at lunch to stay longer and had let her look at rooms, sort out arrangements, and take care of the carriage and horses. These were tasks that had naturally fallen to Mrs. Stringham, but, for some reason, on this particular occasion, they brought home to her—agreeably, richly, almost grandly—what it was like to live with someone so important. Her young friend had a sublime ability to avoid the general problem of hardship, and she didn't simply pass it on to others, as many charming people did.

Translation

Milly had agreed at lunch to stay longer and had allowed her to look at rooms, sort out arrangements, and take care of the carriage and horses. These were tasks that had naturally fallen to Mrs. Stringham, but, for some reason, on this particular occasion, they brought home to her—agreeably, richly, almost grandly—what it was like to live with someone so important. Her young friend had a sublime ability to avoid the general problem of hardship, and she didn't simply pass it on to others, as many charming people did.

She kept it completely separate: it never entered their circle; the most desperate confidant couldn't have dragged it in. So, being a confidant meant living without such worries. Service was so easy to provide that it felt like court life without the difficulties. It came back to the matter of money, and our observant lady had repeatedly realized that if one were talking about the "difference," it was exactly this—nothing else—that ultimately made the biggest difference.

Translation

Milly kept it entirely apart; it never touched their world. Even the most desperate friend couldn’t have brought it in. Thus, being her friend meant living without those anxieties. Service was so effortless that it felt like royal life, but without the burdens. It came down to the issue of money, and our perceptive woman had repeatedly understood that if one were to speak of the “difference,” it was precisely this—nothing else—that ultimately made the greatest difference.

She couldn't imagine anyone less interested in buying or showing off, but it was still undeniably true that the girl couldn't escape her wealth. She could let her conscientious companion be alone with it as much as possible, never asking questions or even tolerating mentions of it, but it was present in the elegant folds of the simple black dress she trailed across the grass as she strolled away. It was in the curious and beautiful way her hair was styled, without any regard for current fashion, that peeked out from under the casual style of her hat. It was a personal style that suggested a kind of elegant informality.

Translation

She couldn’t imagine anyone less interested in buying or showing off, but it was still undeniably true that the girl couldn’t escape her wealth. She could let her conscientious companion be alone with it as much as possible, never asking questions or even tolerating mentions of it, but it was present in the elegant folds of the simple black dress she trailed across the grass as she strolled away. It was in the curious and beautiful way her hair was styled, without any regard for current fashion, that peeked out from under the casual style of her hat. It was a personal style that suggested a kind of elegant informality.

It was there between the pages of the uncut, old-fashioned Tauchnitz volume that she'd mechanically picked up before going out. She couldn't dress it away, walk it away, read it away, or think it away. She couldn't smile it away in any dreamy distraction, nor could she sigh it away. She couldn't have lost it if she tried—that's what it meant to be truly rich.

Translation

It was there, nestled between the pages of the un-clipped, old-fashioned Tauchnitz volume she'd picked up without thinking before leaving the house. She couldn't dress it away, couldn't walk it away, read it away, or think it away. She couldn't smile it away in any dreamy distraction, nor could she sigh it away. She couldn't have lost it if she tried—that's what it meant to be truly rich.

It was a part of who she was. After an hour, when she hadn't returned to the house, Mrs. Stringham, although the afternoon was still young, took the same path, with caution, to join her, in case she wanted company. But the purpose of joining her was less about companionship and more about respecting a possible desire to be alone.

Translation

It was ingrained within her being. After an hour had passed and she hadn't come back to the house, Mrs. Stringham, even though it was still early in the afternoon, cautiously followed the same route, intending to find her in case she wanted someone with her. However, the intention wasn't so much to offer company as it was to honor a potential need to be by herself.

So, once again, the good lady proceeded quietly, which made her feel a little deceitful, even to herself. She couldn't help it, and she didn't care because she was sure that what she really wanted was not to intrude but to know when to stop. Wanting to be able to stop in time, she went softly, but on this occasion, she had farther to go than ever before. She followed the path she believed Milly had taken, but it was in vain.

Translation

The woman set off again, moving with a quietness that made her feel slightly dishonest, even to herself. She couldn't help it, and she didn't mind, because she was certain that her true desire wasn't to intrude but to know when to retreat. Hoping to recognize the right moment, she walked softly, though this time she had a longer distance to cover than before. She traced the route she thought Milly had followed, but it was useless.

At last, with some worry, she followed the path that wound up the hillside and into the high Alpine meadows, where they'd often wanted to wander, as they passed above or below. Then the path disappeared into a wood, but it always went upward, toward a small cluster of old brown chalets that were clearly the goal. Mrs. Stringham reached the chalets and was told by a bewildered old woman, a very frightening sight, which direction the young lady had gone.

Translation

Finally, after some worrying, she followed the path as it snaked up the hillside and into the high Alpine meadows. They'd often wanted to walk there, passing above or below. The path then vanished into a wood, but it continued to climb toward a small collection of old, brown chalets, which were obviously the destination. Mrs. Stringham reached the chalets and, after being told by a bewildered old woman—a truly frightening figure—which way the young lady had gone, continued on.

She had been seen not long before passing over a crest and toward a place where the path would descend again, as our still-searching woman soon found it did, a quarter of an hour later, noticeably and almost alarmingly. It led somewhere, yet seemed to lead into nothingness. From where she stopped, the side of the mountain appeared to fall away completely, though probably only to an area below and out of sight. Her uncertainty was brief.

Translation

She’d been spotted not long ago going over a ridge and toward a place where the trail would drop again, as our still-searching woman quickly discovered it did, a quarter of an hour later, noticeably and almost alarmingly. It led somewhere, yet seemed to lead into nothingness. From where she stood, the mountainside appeared to fall away completely, though probably only to an area below and out of view. Her hesitation was short-lived.

Then, she saw the Tauchnitz volume, which the girl had brought, lying on a rock twenty yards away. It indicated she'd passed by there recently. She'd gotten rid of the book, which was a burden, and meant to pick it up on her way back. But since she hadn't yet picked it up, what on earth had become of her?

Translation

Then she saw the Tauchnitz volume, which the girl had been carrying, lying on a rock twenty yards away. It showed she'd been there recently. She’d ditched the book, which was a nuisance, intending to retrieve it on her return. But since she hadn't, what in the world had happened to her?

Mrs. Stringham, I must add, was about to find out, but it was a matter of luck that her own nearness hadn't been revealed by her growing agitation. The whole place, with the descent of the path and as a sequel to a sharp turn that was masked by rocks and shrubs, appeared to fall precipitously and to become a "view" pure and simple, a view of great extent and beauty, but thrown forward and vertiginous. Milly, with the promise of it from just above, had gone straight down to it, not stopping till it was all before her; and here, on what struck her friend as the dizzy edge of it, she was seated at her ease.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham, I should say, was about to discover the truth. It was only by chance that her own presence hadn't already been exposed by her rising anxiety. The entire scene, with its downward-sloping path and the sharp bend obscured by rocks and bushes, seemed to plunge downward, transforming into a pure, uninterrupted "view." This vista was vast and beautiful, yet also unsettlingly steep. Milly, having caught a glimpse of this from just above, had gone straight down, not stopping until she reached the bottom. And there, on what seemed to her friend like the dizzying edge, she was now sitting comfortably.

The path somehow took care of itself and its final business, but the girl's seat was a slab of rock at the end of a short promontory or excrescence that merely pointed off to the right into gulfs of air and that was so placed by good fortune, if not by the worst, as to be at last completely visible. For Mrs. Stringham stifled a cry on taking in what she believed to be the danger of such a perch for a mere maiden; her liability to slip, to slide, to leap, to be precipitated by a single false movement, by a turn of the head—how could one tell? into whatever was beneath.

Translation

The path, as if by its own volition, completed its course. The girl’s chosen seat was a rock slab, at the tip of a short projection, a jut of land that pointed off toward the right and into an expanse of open space. By luck, or perhaps the worst kind of fate, the girl was now entirely visible. Mrs. Stringham suppressed a cry upon perceiving the peril of such a perch for a young woman. The risk of her slipping, sliding, leaping—being thrown off by a single wrong move, a turn of the head—who knew what could happen? Into the space below.

A thousand thoughts, for the minute, roared in the poor lady's ears, but without reaching, as happened, Milly's. It was a commotion that left our observer intensely still and holding her breath. What had first been offered her was the possibility of a latent intention—however wild the idea—in such a posture; of some betrayed accordance of Milly's caprice with a horrible hidden obsession. But since Mrs.

Translation

Stringham could never really credit a mere fancy as the basis for the girl's actions, she rejected that. She ended up with the truth, which was that Milly was sitting out there from a simple impulse.

Stringham stood as motionless as if a sound, a syllable, must have produced the start that would be fatal, so even the lapse of a few seconds had a partly reassuring effect. It gave her time to receive the impression which, when she some minutes later softly retraced her steps, was to be the sharpest she carried away. This was the impression that if the girl was deeply and recklessly meditating there, she was not meditating a jump; she was on the contrary, as she sat, much more in a state of uplifted and unlimited possession that had nothing to gain from violence. She was looking down on the kingdoms of the earth, and though indeed that of itself might well go to the brain, it wouldn't be with a view of renouncing them.

Translation

Stringham stood as still as if a sound, a single word, would have triggered a disastrous reaction. The passing of a few seconds had a partially calming effect. It allowed her to absorb the impression that, when she quietly retraced her steps some minutes later, would be the most vivid she took with her. This impression was that if the girl was lost in deep, reckless thought, she wasn't contemplating a jump. On the contrary, as she sat there, she was in a state of elevated and limitless possession, a state that had nothing to gain from violence. She was looking down on the kingdoms of the earth, and while that alone might be overwhelming, it wasn’t with any intention of giving them up.

Was she choosing among them, or did she want them all? This question, before Mrs. Stringham had decided what to do, made others vain; in accordance with which she saw, or believed she did, that if it might be dangerous to call out, to sound in any way a surprise, it would probably be safe enough to withdraw as she had come. She watched a while longer, she held her breath, and she never knew afterwards what time had elapsed.

Translation

Was she making a selection among them, or did she desire them all? Before Mrs. Stringham could decide what to do, this question rendered other possibilities irrelevant. As a result, she observed, or thought she did, that if it could be dangerous to call out, to create any kind of sudden disruption, it would likely be safe enough to leave as she had entered. She observed a bit longer, she held her breath, and she never knew afterward how much time had passed.

The entire area, following the path down and after a sharp turn hidden by rocks and bushes, seemed to plunge downward and become simply a "view." It was a view of remarkable scale and beauty, but also steep and dizzying. Milly, having been promised this view from the high point, had gone directly down to it, not stopping until it was completely before her. And here, on what seemed to her friend like the precarious edge of it, she sat comfortably. The path managed to lead itself to its final destination, but the girl's seat was a rock slab at the tip of a small outcropping.

Translation

The entire area, following the path downward and after a sharp turn hidden by rocks and bushes, seemed to plummet and become merely a "view." It was a view of tremendous scale and beauty, but also precipitous and disorienting.
