Milly, having been promised this view from the high point, had gone directly toward it, not stopping until it was completely before her. And here, on what seemed to her friend like the precarious edge of it, she sat at ease. The path managed to lead itself to its ultimate destination, but the girl's seat was a rock slab at the very end of a small outcropping.

This jutted out to the right, over an abyss of open air, and by luck, or perhaps ill fortune, it was fully visible. Mrs. Stringham almost cried out, thinking of the danger for a young woman in such a perch. The possibility of her slipping, sliding, or even leaping – of being thrown over by a sudden move or a turn of her head - who knew?

Translation

This rock formation extended to the right, over an open chasm, and by chance, or perhaps bad luck, it was completely exposed. Mrs. Stringham nearly gasped, considering the danger for a young woman in such a position. The thought of her slipping, sliding, or even jumping—of being thrown over by a sudden movement or a turn of her head—who could say?

– into whatever was below, it seemed endless. A thousand thoughts raced through the poor woman's mind, but Milly did not seem to notice. The sight left our observer perfectly still and breathless. Her first thought was of a hidden intention in such a posture, however wild – some secret agreement between Milly's whim and a terrible, hidden obsession.

Translation

...into an abyss that appeared to have no bottom. A torrent of thoughts flooded the unfortunate woman's mind, but Milly appeared oblivious. The scene rendered our observer immobile, breathless. Her initial thought was that there was a hidden purpose to this pose, no matter how outlandish—some clandestine pact between Milly's capricious nature and a dreadful, concealed fixation.

But since Mrs. Stringham stood so still, as if any sound would be fatal, the passing seconds had a somewhat reassuring effect. It gave her time to receive the impression which, as she softly retraced her steps a few minutes later, would be the most striking thing she carried away. This impression was that if the girl were deeply and recklessly lost in thought there, she was not contemplating a jump.

Translation

But because Mrs. Stringham remained frozen, as if the slightest noise might prove catastrophic, the slow passage of time had a calming effect. It allowed her to absorb an impression that, when she quietly retraced her steps a few minutes later, would be the most vivid detail she retained. That impression was that if the girl was profoundly and carelessly lost in thought, she wasn't considering leaping.

On the contrary, she seemed to be in a state of uplifted and limitless possession, a state that had nothing to gain from violence. She was looking down on the kingdoms of the earth, and though that could be overwhelming, it was not with any intention of giving them up. Was she choosing among them, or did she want them all? Before Mrs.

Translation

Stringham could decide, the girl turned away from the precipice and began to walk back towards the building.

Stringham could decide what to do, this question made others irrelevant. Consequently, she saw, or believed she saw, that while it might be dangerous to call out or make any sound that might surprise her, it would probably be safe enough to leave as she had come. She watched a while longer, held her breath, and never knew afterward how much time had passed. Not many minutes probably, yet they had not seemed few, and they had given her so much to think of, not only while creeping home, but while waiting afterwards at the inn, that she was still busy with them when, late in the afternoon, Milly reappeared.

Translation

Stringham could decide what to do; this question rendered all others unimportant. As a result, she observed, or thought she observed, that while it could be risky to call out or make any noise that might startle her, it would likely be safe enough to depart as she had arrived. She watched for a while longer, holding her breath, and afterward never knew how much time had elapsed. Probably not many minutes, and yet they hadn't seemed few, and they had given her so much to consider, not only while moving cautiously back, but while waiting afterward at the inn, that she was still preoccupied with them when, late in the afternoon, Milly reappeared.

She had stopped at the point of the path where the Tauchnitz lay, had taken it up and, with the pencil attached to her watch-guard, had scrawled a word—à bientôt!—across the cover; then, even under the girl's continued delay, had measured time without a return of alarm. For she now saw that the great thing she had brought away was precisely a conviction that the future was not to exist for her princess in the form of any sharp or simple release from the human predicament. It wouldn't be for her a question of a flying leap and thereby of a quick escape. It would be a question of taking full in the face the whole assault of life, to the general muster of which indeed her face might have been directly presented as she sat there on her rock.

Translation

She had stopped at the place on the path where the Tauchnitz edition lay. She had picked it up and, with the pencil attached to her watch chain, had scrawled a word—*à bientôt!*—across the cover. Then, even with the girl's continued absence, she had measured time without becoming alarmed again. For she now understood that the most important thing she had taken away was the certainty that the future would not exist for her princess as a sharp or easy release from the human condition. It wouldn’t be a matter of a flying leap and a quick escape for her. It would be a matter of facing the full assault of life head-on, an assault to which her own face might have been directly presented as she sat there on the rock.

Mrs. Stringham was thus able to say to herself, even after another interval of some length, that if her young friend still continued absent it wouldn't be because—whatever the opportunity—she had cut short the thread. She wouldn't have committed suicide; she knew herself unmistakably reserved for some more complicated passage; this was the very vision in which she had, with no little awe, been discovered. The image that thus remained with the elder lady kept the character of revelation.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham was therefore able to tell herself, even after another considerable stretch of time, that if her young friend remained gone, it wouldn't be because—whatever the chance—she had ended things prematurely. She wouldn't have killed herself; she knew she was unmistakably destined for a more complex journey; this was the precise understanding in which she had been, with considerable awe, discovered. The image that then remained with the older woman had the quality of a revelation.

During the breathless minutes of her watch she had seen her companion afresh; the latter's type, aspect, marks, her history, her state, her beauty, her mystery, all unconsciously betrayed themselves to the Alpine air, and all had been gathered in again to feed Mrs. Stringham's flame. They are things that will more distinctly appear for us, and they are meanwhile briefly represented by the enthusiasm that was stronger on our friend's part than any doubt. It was a consciousness she was scarce yet used to carrying, but she had as beneath her feet a mine of something precious.

Translation

During the nerve-wracking minutes she spent waiting, she had seen her friend anew. The friend's type, her features, her defining traits, her past, her condition, her beauty, her mystery, all unconsciously revealed themselves to the mountain air, and all had been absorbed once more to fuel Mrs. Stringham's passion. These are things that will become clearer to us later. For now, they can be summed up by the enthusiasm that was stronger in our friend than any uncertainty. It was a realization she was still getting used to, but she felt as though she had a precious mine beneath her feet.

She seemed to herself to stand near the mouth, not yet quite cleared. The mine but needed working and would certainly yield a treasure. She was not thinking, either, of Milly's gold. It likely wasn't many minutes, but they felt long, and they'd given her so much to consider.

Translation

She felt as if she were standing at the entrance, which wasn't fully open yet. The mine just needed to be worked, and it would definitely produce a treasure. She wasn't thinking about Milly's fortune, either. It probably wasn't many minutes, but they felt long, and they had given her so much to think about.

Not just on her walk back, but while waiting at the inn, she was still preoccupied when Milly finally returned late in the afternoon. She had stopped where she'd left the Tauchnitz book, picked it up, and scribbled "à bientôt!" on the cover with the pencil attached to her watch chain. Despite the girl's continued absence, she had measured the time without growing alarmed. She realized she had gained a firm belief that the future wouldn't offer her princess a quick or easy escape from life's struggles.

Translation

Not only on her walk back, but while waiting at the inn, she remained preoccupied when Milly finally returned late in the afternoon. She had gone back to where she'd left the Tauchnitz book, picked it up, and scribbled "à bientôt!" on the cover with the pencil attached to her watch chain. Despite the girl's continued absence, she had measured the time without growing alarmed. She realized she had gained a firm belief that the future wouldn't offer her princess a quick or easy escape from life's struggles.

It wouldn't be a matter of a sudden leap and a quick release. It would be about facing the full force of life's challenges, to which her face could have been directly presented as she sat on her rock. Mrs. Stringham could say to herself, even after a longer wait, that if her young friend was still gone, it wasn't because she'd ended it all, whatever the opportunity.

Translation

It wouldn't be a matter of a sudden leap and a quick release. Instead, it would be about facing the full force of life's challenges, challenges to which her face could have been directly presented as she sat on her rock. Mrs. Stringham could say to herself, even after a longer wait, that if her young friend was still gone, it wasn't because she'd ended it all, whatever the opportunity.

She wouldn't have committed suicide; she knew she was destined for something more complex. This was the exact image she had seen, with no small amount of awe. The image that remained with the older woman had the quality of a revelation. During the tense minutes of her watch, she had seen her companion anew.

Translation

She wouldn't have killed herself; she knew she was meant for something more intricate. This was the precise vision she'd had, not without a sense of wonder. The image that stayed with the older woman possessed the nature of a profound insight. During the anxious minutes of her vigil, she'd seen her friend in a new light.

The girl's type, her appearance, her characteristics, her story, her condition, her beauty, her mystery – all unconsciously revealed themselves in the Alpine air, and all served to fuel Mrs. Stringham's passion. These things will become clearer to us later, but for now, they are represented by the enthusiasm that outweighed any doubt in her friend's mind. It was a feeling she wasn't used to carrying, but she felt like she had a mine of something precious beneath her feet.

Translation

The girl's essence, her looks, her personality, her background, her situation, her charm, her enigmatic aura – all of it seemed to effortlessly unfurl in the mountain air, intensifying Mrs. Stringham's fascination. These elements will become more apparent to us later on, but for the moment, they're embodied by the fervor that completely eclipsed any hesitation her friend might have had. It was an emotion she didn't typically experience, yet it felt as if a treasure lay buried just beneath her.

She felt like she was standing near the entrance, not yet fully cleared. The mine only needed to be worked, and it would certainly yield a treasure. She wasn't thinking about Milly's money, either.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham felt as if she were poised at the threshold, the passage not entirely open. The potential was there, awaiting exploitation; the mine merely needed to be worked, and it would undoubtedly produce wealth. The idea of Milly's financial resources didn't even factor into her thoughts.

Chapter 6

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

When Mrs. Stringham and a girl named Milly meet, Mrs. Stringham notices Milly does not have her book and decides not to mention that she had followed her. Milly asks to leave their current location and continue their journey, and Mrs. Stringham agrees. They plan to depart the next morning.

Later, Milly abruptly asks Mrs. Stringham what a Dr. Finch said during a private meeting in New York. Mrs. Stringham recalls the meeting and tells Milly nothing significant was discussed. Milly admits she had only guessed about the meeting. Mrs. Stringham asks if Milly is feeling unwell. Milly says she is not but then wonders aloud how long she will "have everything." She declines the offer of a doctor and says she will tell Mrs. Stringham their destination at supper, then leaves the room.

At supper, Milly announces she wants to go to London to be around "people." Mrs. Stringham mentions a Mr. Densher, whom Milly met in New York and could contact in London. Milly replies that he is still in America.

Mrs. Stringham then tells Milly about her own potential London contact, a former school friend named Maud Lowder (née Manningham), with whom she has lost touch. She proposes trying to reconnect with her. Milly encourages her to "Risk everything!"

After Milly goes to bed, Mrs. Stringham stays up, opens her portfolio, and writes a letter to begin her search for Maud Lowder.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

Excellent. This is a rich and complex passage, characteristic of the dense, psychological prose of Henry James, from which it is taken (*The Wings of the Dove*). The analysis will explore the interplay between the two central characters, the pervasive themes of mortality and perception, and the literary techniques James employs to create a scene of immense psychological weight.

### Literary Analysis

This passage captures a pivotal moment of decision and revelation between two travelling companions: the enigmatic, wealthy young American Milly Theale, and her older, more conventional friend and chaperone, Mrs. Susan Stringham. Through a carefully orchestrated conversation and a deep dive into Mrs. Stringham’s consciousness, the text establishes the central themes of the narrative: the weight of an unspoken fate, the contrast between American innocence and European experience, and the complex, often self-serving nature of human relationships.

---

#### **Themes**

**1. The Unspoken and the Shadow of Mortality:**

The most powerful theme in the passage is that which is never explicitly stated: Milly’s illness and impending death. The entire scene is governed by this unspoken truth. Milly’s preoccupation is introduced immediately with the forgotten "Tauchnitz" book, a symbol of a mind burdened by something far more significant than the details of a European tour.

Her dialogue is a masterful exercise in evasion and metaphor. When she abruptly asks about Dr. Finch, she is probing the secret of her own condition, a secret she suspects Mrs. Stringham shares with the doctor. Her later, seemingly paradoxical statements—wondering if she will have her life "for long" and her claim that her only problem is "the power to resist the bliss of what I have!"—are deeply ironic. She veils her profound fear and existential questioning in witty, almost mocking language. This creates a powerful dramatic irony, as the reader, along with Mrs. Stringham, senses the tragic reality beneath the sophisticated surface. Her sudden, urgent desire to go to London, to experience "people," is not a frivolous whim but a conscious decision to seize what life she has left.

**2. Perception versus Reality:**

The narrative is filtered almost entirely through Mrs. Stringham’s perspective. She is constantly trying to interpret Milly, to "read the meanings" of her actions and words. This makes the theme of perception central. Mrs. Stringham’s analysis of Milly’s mood is a telling example: she concludes that Milly's "complaint was in fact but the excess of the joy of life." This is a comforting, romantic interpretation that allows her to reframe a terrifying possibility as something positive. She prefers to see Milly's restlessness not as a symptom of dread, but as an inability to "stop for the joy."

However, the text subtly undermines Mrs. Stringham’s perception. Milly’s "inscrutable comment" on her friend's "notion of freedom" and the "mocking light" in her eyes suggest that Milly’s understanding of her situation is far more stark and less romantic than Mrs. Stringham imagines. The reader is positioned with Mrs. Stringham, sharing her limited view, and must also work to decipher the truth of Milly’s condition and state of mind.

**3. The American Quest in Europe:**

The passage is a classic exploration of the Jamesian theme of the American experience in the Old World. For Milly and Mrs. Stringham, Europe is not just a place but an idea, a "world imagined always in what one had read and dreamed." Their desire for "lighted candles at wayside inns" and the romance of the "great Alpine road" reveals a literary, almost fanciful approach to their journey.

Milly’s decision to seek out "people" in London marks a crucial shift. She is turning away from the passive consumption of scenery and art ("museums and churches") toward an active engagement with the human drama of European society. London is positioned as the "crown," the ultimate stage for this engagement. This quest is imbued with a sense of urgency, as Milly feels she has a limited "remainder" of time to experience it.

---

#### **Character Development**

**Milly Theale:**

Milly is developed as a figure of immense grace, intelligence, and tragic depth. She is not a passive victim of her fate but an active agent in shaping her remaining days. She controls the conversation, first by demanding they leave their current location and then by suddenly interrogating Mrs. Stringham about the doctor. Her verbal dexterity allows her to simultaneously reveal and conceal her inner turmoil. Her final, decisive command to her friend, "Risk everything!", is both an encouragement for Mrs. Stringham's social venture and a declaration of her own philosophy in the face of her mortality. She is a "princess," as Mrs. Stringham sees her, but one whose royalty is defined by her wealth, her freedom, and the profound, isolating knowledge of her own fragility.

**Mrs. Susan Stringham:**

Mrs. Stringham undergoes a significant development in this passage. She begins as a sensitive, caring, and slightly "fanciful" companion, wholly devoted to understanding and protecting Milly. However, the prospect of going to London awakens her own dormant past and ambitions. Her decision to contact her old schoolmate, Maud Manningham (now the formidable Mrs. Lowder), is not purely for Milly’s benefit.

The narrative reveals her deep-seated feelings of having been "shunted" and "pitied" by the more socially successful Maud. In a moment of startling psychological honesty, she realizes that Milly is her "trophy"—a beautiful, wealthy, and unique individual whom she can produce as a form of "poetic justice" and "generous revenge." Her affection for Milly is genuine, but it becomes intertwined with a personal desire for social vindication. She is no longer just a passive observer but an active participant with her own complex stakes in the drama to come.

---

#### **Major Literary Ideas**

**Psychological Realism:** The external action of the passage is minimal. The true drama is internal, located within the consciousness of Mrs. Stringham and the subtext of Milly’s speech. James uses long, intricate sentences to mirror the complex, unfolding process of thought, memory, and interpretation.

**Focalization:** The use of Mrs. Stringham as the focalizing consciousness is the passage's key technical achievement. It creates suspense and ambiguity by limiting the reader’s access to Milly’s true thoughts. We experience Milly as Mrs. Stringham does: as a beautiful, brilliant, and ultimately inscrutable puzzle. This technique forces the reader into an active role, piecing together clues from dialogue, gesture, and expression.

**Symbolism:** * **The Journey/Motion:** For Milly, movement represents life. Halts and pauses precipitate her anxieties, while the "renewed promise of motion" restores her to her "great spaces" and gives her a sense of purpose. * **London:** Represents the pinnacle of social and human experience—the dense, rich, and potentially dangerous "human picture" that Milly craves before her time runs out. * **Milly as a "Trophy":** This powerful metaphor reveals the complex blending of affection and ambition in Mrs. Stringham's character, objectifying Milly even as she cherishes her.

In conclusion, this passage functions as a brilliant microcosm of the larger novel. It establishes the central characters in all their complexity, introduces the haunting theme of a life lived in the shadow of death, and sets the stage for the social and psychological drama that will unfold in London. With its focus on the unspoken and the intricate dance of perception, it is a masterclass in psychological realism.

The girl said nothing, when they met, about the words scrawled on the Tauchnitz, and Mrs. Stringham then noticed that she had not the book with her. She had left it lying and probably would never remember it at all. Her comrade's decision was therefore quickly made not to speak of having followed her; and within five minutes of her return, wonderfully enough, the preoccupation denoted by her forgetfulness further declared itself.

Translation

The girl didn't mention the words written in the Tauchnitz when they met, and Mrs. Stringham realized she didn't have the book. She'd left it behind and likely wouldn't think of it again. Her companion quickly decided not to say anything about following her; and, remarkably, within five minutes of her return, the absentmindedness that explained her forgetfulness was again apparent.

"Should you think me quite abominable if I were to say that after all——?" Mrs. Stringham had already thought, with the first sound of the question, everything she was capable of thinking, and had immediately made such a sign that Milly's words gave place to visible relief at her assent. "You don't care for our stop here—you'd rather go straight on?

Translation

"Would you think me absolutely awful if I were to say that after all—?" Mrs. Stringham had already considered, the moment the question began, everything she was capable of considering, and had immediately made a gesture that allowed Milly's words to be replaced by visible relief at her agreement. "You don't want to stop here—you'd rather keep going?"

We'll start then with the peep of to-morrow's dawn—or as early as you like; it's only rather late now to take the road again." And she smiled to show how she meant it for a joke that an instant onward rush was what the girl would have wished. "I bullied you into stopping," she added; "so it serves me right." Translation

"Alright, then, we'll start with the first light of dawn tomorrow—or whenever you'd like. It's just that it's getting rather late to start traveling again." She smiled, indicating that she understood Milly might have preferred to leave immediately. "I forced you to stop here," she added. "So I deserved that." When they met, the girl didn't mention the writing in the Tauchnitz book, and Mrs.

Stringham realized she didn't have it with her. She had left it behind, and likely wouldn't remember it. Her companion quickly decided not to say she had followed her. Within five minutes of her return, the distraction that caused her forgetfulness became even more apparent.

Translation

Stringham knew she didn't have the book. She'd left it somewhere, and it was unlikely she'd think of it again. Her companion decided not to reveal that she'd been following her. Within five minutes of her reappearance, the thing that had made her forget became clear.

"Would you think I'm awful if I said I—?" Mrs. Stringham had anticipated everything possible the moment the question began, and immediately signaled her agreement. Milly's words ceased as she visibly relaxed, relieved.

Translation

"Would you think I'm awful if I said I—?" Mrs. Stringham had foreseen every possibility the instant the question started, and immediately signaled her agreement. Milly's words stopped as she visibly relaxed, relieved.

"You don't want to stay here—you'd prefer to go on? We'll leave at dawn tomorrow—or as early as you'd like; it's just rather late now to travel again." She smiled, intending to convey that a sudden departure was exactly what the girl desired. "I forced you to stop," she added; "so I deserved this." Milly made in general the most of her good friend's jokes; but she humoured this one a little absently.

Translation

"You don't want to stay here—you'd rather keep going? We can leave at dawn tomorrow—or even earlier, if you like; it's just too late to travel again now." She smiled, hoping to imply that a sudden departure was exactly what the girl wanted. "I made you stop," she added; "so I deserve this." Milly usually enjoyed her friend's jokes; but she indulged this one a little absentmindedly.

"Oh yes, you do bully me." And it was thus arranged between them, with no discussion at all, that they would resume their journey in the morning. The younger tourist's interest in the detail of the matter—in spite of a declaration from the elder that she would consent to be dragged anywhere—appeared almost immediately afterwards quite to lose itself; she promised, however, to think till supper of where, with the world all before them, they might go—supper having been ordered for such time as permitted of lighted candles. It had been agreed between them that lighted candles at wayside inns, in strange countries, amid mountain scenery, gave the evening meal a peculiar poetry—such being the mild adventures, the refinements of impression, that they, as they would have said, went in for. It was now as if, before this repast, Milly had designed to "lie down"; but at the end of three minutes more she was not lying down, she was saying instead, abruptly, with a transition that was like a jump of four thousand miles: "What was it that, in New York, on the ninth, when you saw him alone, Dr.

Translation

"Oh yes, you do bully me." And that was that. Without any further discussion, they agreed to continue their journey in the morning. The younger tourist, despite having just declared that she would go anywhere her companion wished, seemed to lose interest in the specifics of their destination. She did, however, promise to ponder where they might go for the rest of the day, before supper. Supper, it had been decided, would be served at a time that allowed for lit candles. They had agreed that candles at wayside inns in foreign lands, surrounded by mountains, lent a certain romance to the evening meal—a mild adventure and a refined experience that was, as they might have put it, exactly what they were looking for. Milly had seemed about to "lie down" before the meal, but three minutes later, she wasn't lying down. Instead, she said abruptly, as if she had jumped four thousand miles in a single bound: "What was it that, in New York, on the ninth, when you saw him alone, Dr.

Finch said to you?" Milly usually enjoyed her friend's teasing, but she wasn't fully engaged this time. "Oh yes, you do pick on me," she replied, a little distantly. And so, without any argument, they settled that they would continue their travels the next day.

Translation

"Oh yes, you do pick on me," she replied, a little distantly. And so, without any argument, they settled that they would continue their travels the next day.

The younger traveler's curiosity about the specifics of their plans—despite the older one's claim that she'd go anywhere—seemed to vanish almost immediately. However, she promised to consider their options before dinner, which was scheduled for whenever the candles could be lit. They had both decided that the presence of lit candles in roadside inns, in unfamiliar countries, surrounded by mountains, added a special beauty to the evening meal. These were the simple pleasures and delicate nuances they particularly valued.

Translation

The younger traveler's interest in the details of their itinerary—despite the older woman's insistence that she was game for anything—seemed to evaporate instantly. Still, she vowed to think about their options before dinner, which was set for whenever the candles could be lit. They had both agreed that the presence of lit candles in roadside inns, in unknown countries, surrounded by mountains, gave a special beauty to the evening meal. These were the simple pleasures and subtle details they cherished most.

It seemed as though Milly had initially planned to "rest" before dinner, but after only a few minutes, she abruptly changed course, with a sudden shift in topic that felt like a huge leap: "What did Dr. Finch say to you in New York on the ninth, when you spoke with him privately?" It was not till later that Mrs. Stringham fully knew why the question had startled her still more than its suddenness explained; though the effect of it even at the moment was almost to frighten her into a false answer.

Translation

Milly seemed to have wanted a break before dinner. But after a few minutes, she abruptly changed her mind, the conversation veering off on a tangent that felt like a huge jump. "What did Dr. Finch say to you in New York on the ninth, when you spoke with him privately?" It was only later that Mrs. Stringham fully understood why the question had shocked her even more than its suddenness could explain. The question's effect, even in that moment, was almost enough to frighten her into lying.

She had to think, to remember the occasion, the "ninth," in New York, the time she had seen Dr. Finch alone, and to recall what he had then said to her; and when everything had come back it was quite, at first, for a moment, as if he had said something that immensely mattered. He hadn't, however, in fact; it was only as if he might perhaps after all have been going to. It was on the sixth—within ten days of their sailing—that she had hurried from Boston under the alarm, a small but a sufficient shock, of hearing that Mildred had suddenly been taken ill, had had, from some obscure cause, such an upset as threatened to stay their journey.

Translation

She had to think, to remember the occasion, the "ninth," in New York, the time she had seen Dr. Finch alone, and to recall what he had said to her then. When everything came back, it was, at first, for a moment, as if he had said something that immensely mattered. He hadn't, however, in fact; it was only as if he might perhaps, after all, have been going to. It was on the sixth—within ten days of their sailing—that she had hurried from Boston under the alarm, a small but a sufficient shock, of hearing that Mildred had suddenly been taken ill, had had, from some obscure cause, such an upset as threatened to stay their journey.

The bearing of the accident had happily soon announced itself as slight, and there had been, in the event, but a few hours of anxiety; the journey had been pronounced again not only possible, but, as representing "change," highly advisable; and if the zealous guest had had five minutes by herself with the doctor, that was, clearly, no more at his instance than at her own. Almost nothing had passed between them but an easy exchange of enthusiasms in respect to the remedial properties of "Europe"; and this assurance, as the facts came back to her, she was now able to give. "Nothing whatever, on my word of honour, that you mayn't know or mightn't then have known. I've no secret with him about you.

Translation

The accident had thankfully revealed itself to be minor, and there had been, in the end, only a few hours of worry. The trip had been declared not only possible, but, given it represented "change," highly advisable. If the eager guest had had five minutes alone with the doctor, it was clearly no more at his urging than hers. Almost nothing had transpired between them except an easy exchange of enthusiasms regarding the healing properties of "Europe," and she was now able to confirm this as the facts returned to her. "Nothing at all, on my word of honor, that you can't know or couldn't have known then. I have no secrets with him about you."

What makes you suspect it? I don't quite make out how you know I did see him alone." It wasn't until later that Mrs. Stringham fully understood why the question had startled her more than its abruptness explained.

Translation

"What makes you suspect it? I don't quite understand how you know I saw him alone." It wasn't until later that Mrs. Stringham fully understood why the question had startled her more than its abruptness explained.

Even at the time, the question almost frightened her into giving a dishonest answer. She had to pause, to remember the event, the "ninth" in New York, the time she had seen Dr. Finch alone, and to recall what he had said to her. When everything came back to her, it was as if he had, for a moment, said something of great importance.

Translation

Even then, the question nearly scared her into lying. She had to stop, to think back on the occasion, the "ninth" in New York, the time she had seen Dr. Finch by himself, and to remember what he had said. When it all came back to her, it felt as if he had, just for a second, said something incredibly significant.

However, in reality, he hadn't. It was only as if he might have been about to. It was on the sixth – within ten days of their departure – that she had rushed from Boston, alarmed and slightly shaken by the news that Mildred had suddenly fallen ill, suffering some unexplained ailment that threatened to delay their trip. The illness thankfully proved to be minor, and there were only a few hours of worry.

Translation

In truth, he hadn’t. It was more like he was on the verge of it. It was on the sixth – within ten days of their leaving – that she'd hurried from Boston, alarmed and slightly unnerved by the news that Mildred had suddenly taken ill, suffering from some mysterious illness that threatened to postpone their trip. Fortunately, the illness proved to be minor, and there were only a few hours of concern.

The journey was declared not only possible, but highly recommended as a "change" of scenery. If the eager guest had managed to have five minutes alone with the doctor, it was clear that it was at her request as much as his. Almost nothing had passed between them except a casual discussion about the healing benefits of "Europe." Recalling these facts, she was now able to assure him, "Nothing at all, I swear, that you don't know or might not have known then. I have no secrets with him about you.

Translation

The trip was not only deemed feasible, but highly encouraged as a refreshing "change" of pace. If the eager guest had managed to speak with the doctor for even five minutes, it was obvious that it was as much at her behest as his. Hardly anything had transpired between them aside from a brief conversation about the curative properties of "Europe." Recalling this, she could now reassure him, "I swear, there's nothing you don't already know, or couldn't have figured out back then. I have no secrets with him concerning you."

Why do you suspect it? I don't understand how you know I saw him alone." "No—you never told me," said Milly. "And I don't mean," she went on, "during the twenty-four hours while I was bad, when your putting your heads together was natural enough.

Translation

Why do you think that? I don't get how you know I met with him by myself." "No—you never said anything," Milly replied. "And I don't mean," she continued, "during the twenty-four hours when I was ill, when you two conferring made perfect sense."

I mean after I was better—the last thing before you went home." Mrs. Stringham continued to wonder. "Who told you I saw him then?"

Translation

"I mean after I was better—the last thing before you went home." Mrs. Stringham continued to wonder. "Who told you I saw him then?"

"He didn't himself—nor did you write me it afterwards. We speak of it now for the first time. That's exactly why!" Milly declared—with something in her face and voice that, the next moment, betrayed for her companion that she had really known nothing, had only conjectured and, chancing her charge, made a hit. Yet why had her mind been busy with the question?

Translation

"He didn't tell me, and you didn't write me about it later. We're talking about it now for the first time. That's the whole point!" Milly announced, with something in her expression and tone that immediately revealed to her companion that she hadn't actually known anything, she'd only guessed and, taking a gamble, gotten lucky. But why had she been preoccupied with the question?

"But if you're not, as you now assure me, in his confidence," she smiled, "it's no matter." "No—you never told me," Milly said. "And I don't mean," she continued, "during the twenty-four

Translation

hours, or whatever, you may have had with him, after his accident, after his disaster, or whatever it was, in the hospital, and all that. It's not of that I speak. I speak of the period before. The period of the spring, of the long days—"

hours when I was sick, when you would have naturally conferred. I mean after I recovered—the last time before you went home."

Translation

Hours when I was ill, when you would have normally consulted me. I'm referring to after I got better—the final time before you left for home.

Mrs. Stringham continued to be puzzled. "Who told you I saw him then?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham remained perplexed. "Who told you I saw him at that point?"

"He didn't—nor did you write and tell me afterwards. We're talking about it for the first time now.

Translation

"He didn't. And you didn't write to tell me about it later, either. We're only discussing this now, for the first time."

That's precisely why!" Milly declared—with something in her face and voice that immediately revealed to her friend that she truly knew nothing, had only guessed and, taking a chance,

Translation

"That's exactly it!" Milly declared, her expression and tone instantly showing her friend that she was completely clueless, had only been guessing, and, taking a gamble,

had gotten lucky. Still, why had she been thinking about it? "But if you aren't, as you now assure

Translation

me, you aren't, then why were you?" she asked, her voice laced with a playful curiosity that suggested she already knew the answer.

me, his confidante," she smiled, "it doesn't matter." "I'm not in his confidence, and he had nothing to confide. But are you feeling unwell?"

Translation

"Me, his confidante," she smiled, "it doesn't matter." "I'm not privy to his secrets, and he had nothing to reveal. But are you feeling unwell?"

The elder woman was earnest for the truth, though the possibility she named was not at all the one that seemed to fit—witness the long climb Milly had just indulged in. The girl showed her constant white face, but that her friends had all learned to discount, and it was often brightest when superficially not bravest. She continued for a little mysteriously to smile. "I don't know—haven't really the least idea.

Translation

The older woman sought the truth, even though the possibility she suggested didn't seem to make sense, given the long walk Milly had just taken. The girl's face was always pale, but her friends had learned to ignore it; the pallor was often most pronounced when she was putting on a brave face. She kept smiling mysteriously. "I don't know—I really haven't a clue."

But it might be well to find out." Mrs. Stringham, at this, flared into sympathy. "Are you in trouble—in pain?"

Translation

"But it might be well to find out." Mrs. Stringham, at this, flared into sympathy. "Are you in trouble—in pain?"

"Not the least little bit. But I sometimes wonder——!" "Yes"—she pressed: "wonder what?" I don't know his secrets, and he didn't have any to tell.

Translation

"Not a bit. But sometimes I wonder—!" "Yes," she urged, "wonder what?" I don't know what he's hiding, and he's never told me a thing.

But, are you feeling sick? The older woman was genuinely concerned, even though the idea she suggested wasn't the right one—considering the steep climb Milly had just finished. The girl's face was always pale, but her friends had gotten used to that. Her face often looked best when she was putting on a brave face.

Translation

"Are you sick?" the older woman asked, truly worried, even though her guess didn't make much sense after Milly had just climbed that hill. The girl's face was always pale, but her friends were used to it. She looked her best when she was trying to be brave.

She kept smiling mysteriously. "I don't know—I really haven't a clue. But maybe it's best to find out." At this, Mrs.

Translation

Mrs. Bloom, for that was her name, decided she'd had enough of the girl's riddles.

Stringham became very sympathetic. "Are you in trouble—are you hurting?" "Not even a little bit. But I sometimes wonder——!"

Translation

Stringham's demeanor shifted to one of intense sympathy. "Are you in some kind of difficulty—are you in pain?" "Not even a tiny bit. But sometimes I wonder——!"

"Yes," she urged, "wonder what?" "Well, if I shall have much of it." Mrs. Stringham stared.

Translation

"Yes," she urged, "wonder what?" "Well, if I shall have much of it." Mrs. Stringham stared.

"Much of what? Not of pain?" "Of everything. Of everything I have."

Translation

"Much of what? Not of pain?" Mrs. Stringham asked.

"Of everything. Of everything I possess."

Anxiously again, tenderly, our friend cast about. "You 'have' everything; so that when you say 'much' of it——" "I only mean," the girl broke in, "shall I have it for long? That is if I have got it."

Translation

Again with anxiety, then with tenderness, our friend searched for the right words. "You 'have' everything; so that when you say 'much' of it—" "I only mean," the girl interrupted, "will I have it for long? That is, if I actually possess it at all."

She had at present the effect, a little, of confounding, or at least of perplexing her comrade, who was touched, who was always touched, by something helpless in her grace and abrupt in her turns, and yet actually half made out in her a sort of mocking light. "If you've got an ailment?" "If I've got everything," Milly laughed. "Well, I wonder if I'll get to enjoy much of it."

Translation

Right now, she seemed to be confusing, or at least frustrating, her friend. He was moved, always moved, by the vulnerability in her elegance, the sudden shifts in her mood. But he also sensed a mocking undertone in her. "If you're sick?" Milly laughed. "If I have everything? Well, I wonder if I'll get to enjoy much of it."

Mrs. Stringham was taken aback. "Much of what? Not suffering, I hope?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham was surprised. "Much of what? Not suffering, I trust?"

"Of everything. Of everything I possess." Our friend looked concerned, and spoke gently. "You *have* everything.

Translation

"Of everything. Of everything I own." Our friend looked concerned and spoke gently. "You *do* have everything."

So, when you say 'much' of it..." "I only mean," the girl interrupted, "will I have it for long? Assuming I actually *do* have it, that is." She was, at the moment, a little confusing, or at least baffling, to her friend.

Translation

"So, when you say 'much' of it..." "I only mean," the girl cut in, "will I get to keep it for a while? If I even *have* it to begin with." She was, at this moment, a little confusing, or at least bewildering, to her friend.

Mrs. Stringham was always moved by the young woman's vulnerable, graceful manner, by her sudden changes of mood. Yet, she also saw in her a hint of something mocking. "If you're sick?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham was often touched by the young woman's delicate, vulnerable bearing, by her abrupt shifts in temperament. However, she also detected in her an undercurrent of irony. "If you're ill?"

"If I have everything," Milly laughed. "Ah, that—like almost nobody else." "Then for how long?" Mrs.

Translation

"If I have everything," Milly laughed. "Ah, that—like almost nobody else." "Then for how long?" Mrs.

Stringham's eyes entreated her; she had gone close to her, half enclosed her with urgent arms. "Do you want to see some one?" And then as the girl only met it with a slow headshake, though looking perhaps a shade more conscious: "We'll go straight to the best near doctor." This too, however, produced but a gaze of qualified assent and a silence, sweet and vague, that left everything open. Our friend decidedly lost herself. "Tell me, for God's sake, if you're in distress."

Translation

Stringham's eyes pleaded with her. She had moved close, almost enveloping her with pressing arms. "Do you want to see someone?" Then, as the girl only responded with a slow shake of her head, though perhaps looking a little more aware, "We'll go straight to the best doctor nearby." However, this also only produced a look of hesitant agreement and a silence, sweet and indefinite, that left everything unresolved. Our friend was truly at a loss. "Tell me, for God's sake, if you're in distress."

"I don't think I've really everything," Milly said as if to explain—and as if also to put it pleasantly. "But what on earth can I do for you?" The girl hesitated, then seemed on the point of being able to say; but suddenly changed and expressed herself otherwise. "Dear, dear thing—I'm only too happy!" "Ah, that's something that almost nobody else does."

Translation

"I don't think I've really got everything," Milly said, as if trying to explain—and also as if trying to make it sound nice. "But what on earth can I do for you?"

The girl hesitated, as if she were about to say something. But then she changed her mind and expressed herself differently. "Oh, my dear—I'm only too happy!" "Ah, that's something almost no one else does."

"So, for how long?" Mrs. Stringham's eyes pleaded with her. She had moved closer, almost embracing her with her arms, as if to urge her on.

Translation

"So, for how long?" Mrs. Stringham's eyes were practically begging. She had drawn near, almost putting her arms around her, as if trying to push her forward.

"Do you want to see someone?" And then, as the girl only shook her head slowly, though she seemed to become a bit more aware: "We'll go straight to the best doctor nearby." This, however, only resulted in a look of partial agreement and a silence, sweet and vague, that left everything uncertain. Our friend was clearly at a loss. "Tell me, for the love of God, if you're in trouble." "I don't think I have everything, really," Milly said, as if to explain—and also to make it sound nice.

Translation

"Is there someone you want to see?" The girl just slowly shook her head, though she seemed to become a little more present. "We'll go right to the best doctor around here." This only got a halfhearted nod and a silence that was soft and unclear, leaving everything up in the air. Our friend was obviously stumped. "Tell me, for God's sake, if you're in trouble." "I don't think I really have it all," Milly said, like she was trying to explain—and also to soften the blow.

"But what on earth can I do for you?" The girl hesitated, then seemed about to speak, but suddenly changed her mind and expressed herself differently. "Oh, my dear—I'm so happy!" It brought them closer, but it rather confirmed Mrs.

Translation

"But what in the world can I do for you?" The girl hesitated, then seemed to open her mouth, but thought better of it and changed tack. "Oh, my dear—I'm so happy!" It drew them together, but it seemed to confirm Mrs.

Stringham's doubt. "Then what's the matter?" "That's the matter—that I can scarcely bear it." "But what is it you think you haven't got?"

Translation

Stringham's skepticism. "So what's wrong?" "That's the problem—I can hardly handle it." "But what do you think you're missing?"

Milly waited another moment; then she found it, and found for it a dim show of joy. "The power to resist the bliss of what I have!" Mrs. Stringham took it in—her sense of being "put off" with it, the possible, probable irony of it—and her tenderness renewed itself in the positive grimness of a long murmur.

Translation

Milly hesitated, and then at last she located it, summoning a faint display of happiness. "The strength to refuse the joy of what I possess!" Mrs. Stringham considered this – her sense of being "distanced" by it, the inherent, likely irony of it – and her affection revived in the resolute severity of a long, soft utterance.

"Whom will you see?"—for it was as if they looked down from their height at a continent of doctors. "Where will you first go?" Milly had for the third time her air of consideration; but she came back with it to her plea of some minutes before. "I'll tell you at supper—good-bye till then." And she left the room with a lightness that testified for her companion to something that again particularly pleased her in the renewed promise of motion.

Translation

"Whom will you see?" – because it was as if they were looking down from their position at a whole continent of doctors. "Where will you go first?" For the third time, Milly adopted her thoughtful expression; but she returned with it to the request she'd made a few minutes before. "I'll tell you at supper – goodbye until then." And she left the room with a lightness that demonstrated to her companion something that again particularly pleased her in the renewed prospect of movement.

The odd passage just concluded, Mrs. Stringham mused as she once more sat alone with a hooked needle and a ball of silk, the "fine" work with which she was always provided—this mystifying mood had simply been precipitated, no doubt, by their prolonged halt, with which the girl hadn't really been in sympathy. One had only to admit that her complaint was in fact but the excess of the joy of life, and everything did then fit. She couldn't stop for the joy, but she could go on for it, and with the sense of going on she floated again, was restored to her great spaces.

Translation

That strange exchange had just finished, Mrs. Stringham thought as she sat alone once more, a hooked needle and ball of silk in her hands, the "delicate" work she always had with her. This puzzling behavior had simply been brought on, no doubt, by their extended stop, which the girl hadn't truly approved of. One only had to accept that her issue was really just an excess of the joy of life, and then everything made sense. She couldn't pause for the joy, but she could keep going for it, and with the feeling of continuing, she floated again, was returned to her vast expanses.

There was no evasion of any truth—so at least Susan Shepherd hoped—in one's sitting there while the twilight deepened and feeling still more finely that the position of this young lady was magnificent. The evening at that height had naturally turned to cold, and the travellers had bespoken a fire with their meal; the great Alpine road asserted its brave presence through the small panes of the low, clean windows, with incidents at the inn-door, the yellow diligence, the great waggons, the hurrying, hooded, private conveyances, reminders, for our fanciful friend, of old stories, old pictures, historic flights, escapes, pursuits, things that had happened, things indeed that by a sort of strange congruity helped her to read the meanings of the greatest interest into the relation in which she was now so deeply involved. It was natural that this record of the magnificence of her companion's position should strike her as, after all, the best meaning she could extract; for she herself was seated in the magnificence as in a court-carriage—she came back to that, and such a method of progression, such a view from crimson cushions, would evidently have a great deal more to give. By the time the candles were lighted for supper and the short, white curtains were drawn, Milly had reappeared, and the little scenic room had then all its romance.

Translation

Susan Shepherd hoped there was no dodging of any truth in her sitting there as twilight deepened, feeling even more keenly that the young woman's circumstances were magnificent. At that altitude, the evening had naturally grown cold, and the travelers had ordered a fire with their meal. The grand Alpine road made its bold presence known through the small panes of the low, clean windows, with activity at the inn door: the yellow stagecoach, the large wagons, the hurrying, hooded private carriages. These were reminders for our imaginative friend of old stories, old pictures, historical flights, escapes, pursuits—things that had happened, things, in fact, that by a strange sort of harmony, helped her to read the most compelling meanings into the relationship in which she was now so deeply involved. It was natural that this record of her companion's magnificent position should strike her as the best meaning she could extract, after all. She herself was seated in the magnificence as in a court carriage—she returned to that thought. Such a mode of transport, such a view from crimson cushions, would evidently have a great deal more to offer. By the time the candles were lit for supper and the short, white curtains were drawn, Milly had reappeared, and the little scenic room was then entirely romantic.

That charm moreover was far from broken by the words in which she, without further loss of time, satisfied her patient mate. "I want to go straight to London." Their closeness didn't dispel Mrs. Stringham's doubts.

Translation

That charm was not diminished by the words with which she immediately satisfied her patient companion. "I want to go straight to London." Their intimacy didn't ease Mrs. Stringham's doubts.

"So, what's wrong?" "That's the problem—I can hardly stand it." "But what do you feel you lack?" Milly hesitated, then found the words, and a glimmer of happiness.

Translation

"What's the matter, then?" "That's just it—I can barely cope with it." "But what do you think you're missing?" Milly paused, and then found the right words, a hint of joy in her expression.

"The ability to withstand the overwhelming joy of what I have!" Mrs. Stringham considered this – the feeling of being brushed aside, the likely irony of it – and her tenderness deepened into a long, quiet sigh. "Who will you see?" she asked, as if surveying a vast continent of doctors from a high vantage point.

Translation

"The strength to bear the incredible happiness of my life!" Mrs. Stringham absorbed this, the sensation of being dismissed, the probable absurdity of it all, and her affection matured into a deep, silent exhalation. "Who are you planning to visit?" she inquired, as if appraising an immense landscape of physicians from a great height.

"Where will you go first?" Milly paused, lost in thought for the third time, but returned to her earlier promise. "I'll tell you at supper—goodbye until then." She left the room with a lightness that told her companion that something had again particularly pleased her in the renewed prospect of travel. Mrs.

Translation

"Where will you go first?" Milly hesitated, distracted yet again, but then resumed her previous commitment. "I'll tell you at supper—goodbye until then." She left the room with an air of buoyancy, indicating to her companion that she was once more excited by the prospect of travel. Mrs.

Stringham, sitting alone again with her needle and silk, lost in her needlework, thought that this confusing mood had simply been brought on by their extended pause, which the girl hadn't really liked. You just had to accept that her ailment was an overabundance of joy, and everything made sense. She couldn't pause for the joy, but she could continue because of it, and the prospect of continuing restored her, returning her to her great freedom. There was no avoiding any truth – or so Susan Shepherd hoped – as she sat there while twilight deepened, feeling even more acutely that this young woman's circumstances were remarkable.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham, alone with her needle and thread, engrossed in her embroidery, decided that this perplexing state of mind was nothing more than a reaction to their prolonged break, a break the girl hadn’t truly enjoyed. You simply had to accept that her condition was an excess of happiness, and everything clicked into place. She couldn't pause *for* the joy, but she could continue *because* of it, and the anticipation of continuation revived her, returning her to a feeling of utter liberty. No truth was avoidable – or so Susan Shepherd hoped – as she sat there in the deepening twilight, feeling even more keenly that this young woman’s situation was extraordinary.

The air at that altitude had naturally become cold, and the travelers had ordered a fire for their meal. The grand Alpine road was visible through the small, clean windows, with the happenings at the inn's entrance – the yellow stagecoach, the large wagons, the hurried, cloaked private carriages – reminding our imaginative friend of old tales, old images, historic escapes, pursuits, events that had taken place, things that, by a strange connection, helped her to read the deepest meanings into the situation she was now deeply involved in. It was natural that this record of her companion's remarkable position should strike her as the most significant meaning she could derive; for she herself was seated in this remarkable situation as if in a royal carriage—she returned to that thought, and this method of moving, this view from crimson cushions, would obviously have a great deal more to offer. By the time the candles were lit for supper and the short white curtains were drawn, Milly had returned, and the small, picturesque room was then filled with romance.

Translation

The higher elevation had, of course, brought a chill, so the travelers had requested a fire to accompany their meal. Through the small, sparkling windows, the sweeping Alpine road was visible, as was the activity at the inn’s entrance: the yellow stagecoach, the large wagons, the hurried, cloaked private carriages. All of this reminded our imaginative friend of old stories, of old imagery, of historical escapes and chases, of occurrences that, by some strange link, allowed her to interpret the profoundest significance of the situation she was now fully involved in. It was only natural that this documentation of her companion’s exceptional circumstances would appear to her as the most important meaning she could take away from it; for she herself was situated within this remarkable scenario, as if in a royal carriage—she returned to that thought, and this mode of transport, this view from crimson cushions, would obviously have a great deal more to offer. By the time the candles had been lit for supper and the small white curtains had been drawn, Milly had returned, and the small, picturesque room was then saturated with romance.

That charm was in no way diminished by the words in which she, without delay, satisfied her attentive friend. "I want to go straight to London." It was unexpected, corresponding with no view positively taken at their departure; when England had appeared, on the contrary, rather relegated and postponed—seen for the moment, as who should say, at the end of an avenue of preparations and introductions. London, in short, might have been supposed to be the crown, and to be achieved like a siege by gradual approaches.

Translation

That enchantment wasn't lessened by the words with which she immediately addressed her attentive friend. "I want to go straight to London." It was unexpected, not in keeping with any plan formulated when they departed; England had seemed, on the contrary, rather set aside and put off—envisioned, for the time being, as being at the end of a series of preparations and introductions. London, in short, might have been assumed to be the grand prize, to be attained like a military objective by stages.

Milly's actual fine stride was therefore the more exciting, as any simplification almost always was to Mrs. Stringham; who, besides, was afterwards to recall as the very beginning of a drama the terms in which, between their smoky candles, the girl had put her preference and in which still other things had come up, come while the clank of waggon-chains in the sharp air reached their ears, with the stamp of hoofs, the rattle of buckets and the foreign questions, foreign answers, that were all alike a part of the cheery converse of the road. The girl brought it out in truth as she might have brought a huge confession, something she admitted herself shy about and that would seem to show her as frivolous; it had rolled over her that what she wanted of Europe was "people," so far as they were to be had, and that if her friend really wished to know, the vision of this same equivocal quantity was what had haunted her during their previous days, in museums and churches, and what was again spoiling for her the pure taste of scenery. She was all for scenery—yes; but she wanted it human and personal, and all she could say was that there would be in London—wouldn't there?

Translation

Milly's decisive move was all the more thrilling, a simplification that always appealed to Mrs. Stringham. Mrs. Stringham would later recall the exact words, spoken in the dim light of their candles, in which the girl had declared her preference. This was the true beginning of the drama. Even then, other things had surfaced, while the clatter of wagon chains echoed in the crisp air. The sounds of hooves, the clanging of buckets, and the foreign questions and answers—all part of the cheerful chatter of the journey—reached their ears.

Milly delivered her statement as if it were a major confession, something she was shy about, something that might make her seem frivolous. It had dawned on her that what she truly desired from Europe was "people," as many as she could find. She confessed to her friend that the vision of these elusive figures had been haunting her in the museums and churches, spoiling the pleasure of the landscapes. She loved the scenery, yes, but she wanted it to be human and personal. All she could say was that London—wouldn't it?—would have them.

more of that kind than anywhere else. She came back to her idea that if it wasn't for long—if nothing should happen to be so for her—why, the particular thing she spoke of would probably have most to give her in the time, would probably be less than anything else a waste of her remainder. She produced this last consideration indeed with such gaiety that Mrs. Stringham was not again disconcerted by it, was in fact quite ready—if talk of early dying was in order—to match it from her own future.

Translation

more of those kinds of people than anywhere else. Milly returned to her idea that if it wasn't for long—if nothing should happen to be that way for her—the particular thing she spoke of would likely give her the most in the time she had, would probably be the least wasteful of her remaining time. She delivered this final thought with such glee that Mrs. Stringham was no longer worried by it, and was actually ready—if talk of dying young was appropriate—to match it with one from her own future.

Good, then; they would, eat and drink because of what might happen to-morrow; and they would direct their course from that moment with a view to such eating and drinking. They ate and drank that night, in truth, as if in the spirit of this decision; whereby the air, before they separated, felt itself the clearer. It was an unexpected development, contradicting the plans they had when they left. England had seemed to be put off, postponed, something to be addressed after a long series of preparations and introductions.

Translation

Fine, then; they would eat and drink because of what might happen tomorrow; and they would plan accordingly from that moment forward with those meals in mind. They ate and drank that night, in truth, as if they were acting on this resolution; and the atmosphere, before they parted, felt itself lighter. It was an unexpected turn of events, going against their original plans. England had seemed to be put off, postponed, something to be addressed after a long series of preparations and introductions.

In short, London was supposed to be the final goal, to be reached gradually, like a military campaign. Milly’s sudden shift of direction was therefore all the more exciting, as simplification usually was to Mrs. Stringham. She would later remember this as the very beginning of a story.

Translation

In essence, London was meant to be the ultimate destination, approached methodically, akin to a military operation. Milly’s abrupt change of course, therefore, was all the more thrilling, as such a streamlining typically was for Mrs. Stringham. She would later recall this as the true commencement of a narrative.

Milly, between their smoky candles, had expressed her preference, and other issues came up while the sound of wagon chains filled the sharp air, the stamp of hooves, the clatter of buckets, and the foreign questions and answers that were all part of the cheerful conversation of the road. Milly revealed this, as if making a huge confession, something she felt embarrassed about. It seemed she wanted "people" from Europe, if she could get them. If her friend really wanted to know, the image of this uncertain group of people had haunted her during their earlier days in museums and churches.

Translation

Milly, seated across from her companion, amidst the flickering candlelight, had spoken of her wishes. Other matters arose amid the sounds of wagon chains in the crisp air, the thud of hooves, the clatter of buckets, and the foreign exchanges that constituted the vibrant chatter of travel. Milly divulged this as though making a significant confession, a fact that caused her some discomfort. It appeared she desired "people" from Europe, if she could find them. If her friend truly wished to know, the thought of this indefinite assembly of individuals had lingered with her during their previous days spent in museums and churches.

It was now spoiling her appreciation of the scenery. She did love the scenery—yes; but she wanted it to involve people, and all she could say was that London—wouldn’t it?—would offer more of that kind of experience than anywhere else. She returned to her idea that if their time was limited—if something were to happen to her—then the thing she spoke of would probably give her the most in the time she had, would probably be the least wasteful way for her to spend her remaining days. She presented this last point with such joy that Mrs.

Translation

It was ruining her enjoyment of the landscape. She did love the scenery, it was true; but she wanted it to include people, and all she could say was that London—wouldn’t it?—would provide more of that kind of experience than anywhere else. She returned to her idea that if their time was limited—if something were to happen to her—then the thing she spoke of would likely give her the most in the time she had, would probably be the least wasteful way for her to spend her remaining days. She presented this final point with such happiness that Mrs.

Stringham was no longer bothered. In fact, she was ready—if talk of dying young was in order—to share similar sentiments about her own future. Fine, then; they would eat and drink because of what might happen tomorrow. From that moment, they would direct their course with that intention.

Translation

Stringham wasn't upset anymore. Actually, if they were going to talk about dying young, she was prepared to agree about her own future. Alright, then; they would eat and drink because of what might happen tomorrow. From that moment on, they would act with that goal in mind.

They ate and drank that night, as if in the spirit of this decision, and the air felt clearer before they parted. It had cleared perhaps to a view only too extensive—extensive, that is, in proportion to the signs of life presented. The idea of "people" was not so entertained on Milly's part as to connect itself with particular persons, and the fact remained for each of the ladies that they would, completely unknown, disembark at Dover amid the completely unknowing. They had no relation already formed; this plea Mrs.

Translation

They ate and drank that night, as if embracing this decision. The air seemed clearer before they separated. Perhaps the air had cleared to an extent that was excessive, especially considering the few signs of life present. The thought of "people" didn't engage Milly enough to connect it with any specific individuals. The reality was that each of the women would disembark at Dover, utterly unknown, amidst those who knew them not at all. They had no established connections. This was Mrs.

Stringham put forward to see what it would produce. It produced nothing at first but the observation on the girl's side that what she had in mind was no thought of society nor of scraping acquaintance; nothing was further from her than to desire the opportunities represented for the compatriot in general by a trunkful of "letters." It wasn't a question, in short, of the people the compatriot was after; it was the human, the English picture itself, as they might see it in their own way—the world imagined always in what one had read and dreamed. Mrs. Stringham did every justice to this world, but when later on an occasion chanced to present itself, she made a point of not omitting to remark that it might be a comfort to know in advance even an individual.

Translation

Stringham ventured forth to see what the proposal would yield. Initially, it produced nothing beyond the girl's observation that she wasn't seeking out society or trying to make acquaintances; nothing was further from her mind than to desire the opportunities that a trunk full of "letters" might represent to the average compatriot. In short, it wasn't about the people the compatriot was after; it was the human, the English picture itself, as they might see it in their own way—the world always imagined from what one had read and dreamed. Mrs. Stringham acknowledged this world fully, but later, when an opportunity arose, she made a point of noting that it could be comforting to know even a single individual beforehand.

This still, however, failed in vulgar parlance, to "fetch" Milly, so that she had presently to go all the way. "Haven't I understood from you, for that matter, that you gave Mr. Densher something of a promise?" The sky had cleared, revealing a landscape that was perhaps too vast—vast, at least, considering the lack of activity.

Translation

This, however, didn't "fetch" Milly, to use the common expression, and she had to pursue it further. "Didn't I understand from you, for that matter, that you gave Mr. Densher a kind of promise?" The sky had cleared, exposing a landscape that was perhaps too vast—vast, at least, given the lack of any activity.

Milly didn't really think of "people" as specific individuals. The reality was that, completely unknown, the ladies would arrive at Dover, greeted by those who also didn't know them. They had no existing connections. Mrs.

Translation

Milly didn't really think of "people" as specific individuals. The reality was that, completely unknown, the ladies would arrive at Dover, greeted by those who also didn't know them. They had no existing connections. Mrs.

Stringham brought this up to see what Milly would say. Initially, it produced nothing except Milly's statement that she wasn't interested in socializing or making new acquaintances. She had no desire for the opportunities that a trunk full of "letters" represented for the typical American abroad. In short, it wasn't about the people that other Americans sought.

Translation

Stringham mentioned this to gauge Milly's reaction. At first, it elicited only Milly's declaration that she had no interest in social engagements or in meeting new people. She wasn't seeking the advantages that a trunk full of "letters" promised to the average American traveling overseas. In essence, it wasn't about the people that other Americans pursued.

It was about the human, the English experience itself, as they would perceive it—the world one had always imagined from books and dreams. Mrs. Stringham appreciated this perspective, but when a chance arose later, she made it a point to say that it might be helpful to know even a single person in advance. However, this didn't sway Milly.

Translation

It was about the experience, the English one, as they would see it—the world one had always envisioned from books and dreams. Mrs. Stringham appreciated this point of view, but later, when an opportunity presented itself, she took the chance to say that it might be beneficial to know even a single person beforehand. Still, this didn't change Milly's mind.

So, Mrs. Stringham had to clarify further. "Haven't I understood that you may have made Mr. Densher a sort of promise?"

Translation

Thus, Mrs. Stringham was obliged to further elucidate. "Haven't I gathered that you might have made Mr. Densher a certain pledge?"

There was a moment, on this, when Milly's look had to be taken as representing one of two things—either that she was completely vague about the promise or that Mr. Densher's name itself started no train. But she really couldn't be so vague about the promise, her interlocutress quickly saw, without attaching it to something; it had to be a promise to somebody in particular to be so repudiated. In the event, accordingly, she acknowledged Mr.

Translation

Densher, but only to put him off. "Oh, yes—Mr. Densher," she said, with an air of merely just remembering. "Of course, he too. I promised him something, I believe."

Merton Densher, the so unusually clever young Englishman who had made his appearance in New York on some special literary business—wasn't it?—shortly before their departure, and who had been three or four times in her house during the brief period between her visit to Boston and her companion's subsequent stay with her; but she required much reminding before it came back to her that she had mentioned to this companion just afterwards the confidence expressed by the personage in question in her never doing so dire a thing as to come to London without, as the phrase was, looking a fellow up. She had left him the enjoyment of his confidence, the form of which might have appeared a trifle free—that she now reasserted; she had done nothing either to impair or to enhance it; but she had also left Mrs. Stringham, in the connection and at the time, rather sorry to have missed Mr. Densher.

Translation

Merton.

Densher, the remarkably intelligent young Englishman who had turned up in New York on some literary errand—wasn't that it?—shortly before they left, and who had been to her house three or four times during the short time between her trip to Boston and her companion's subsequent stay with her; but she needed a great deal of prompting before it came back to her that she had mentioned to this companion just afterward the confidence expressed by the man in question about her never doing such a terrible thing as coming to London without, as the saying went, looking him up. She had left him with his confidence, the form of which might have seemed a little forward—she now stated again; she had done nothing to either hurt or improve it; but she had also left Mrs. Stringham, at the time and in that context, rather sorry to have missed Mr. Densher.

She had thought of him again after that, the elder woman; she had likewise gone so far as to notice that Milly appeared not to have done so—which the girl might easily have betrayed; and, interested as she was in everything that concerned her, she had made out for herself, for herself only and rather idly, that, but for interruptions, the young Englishman might have become a better acquaintance. His being an acquaintance at all was one of the signs that in the first days had helped to place Milly, as a young person with the world before her, for sympathy and wonder. Isolated, unmothered, unguarded, but with her other strong marks, her big house, her big fortune, her big freedom, she had lately begun to "receive," for all her few years, as an older woman might have done—as was done, precisely, by princesses who had public considerations to observe and who came of age very early. If it was thus distinct to Mrs.

Translation

Stringham that Densher had been a pleasant feature, the latter had not, it seemed, made a similar impression on her companion. Milly's own impressions were not yet, however, much of a subject for discussion between them.

Stringham then that Mr. Densher had gone off somewhere else in connection with his errand before her visit to New York, it had been also not undiscoverable that he had come back for a day or two later on, that is after her own second excursion—that he had in fine reappeared on a single occasion on his way to the West: his way from Washington as she believed, though he was out of sight at the time of her joining her friend for their departure. It had not occurred to her before to exaggerate—it had not occurred to her that she could; but she seemed to become aware to-night that there had been just enough in this relation to meet, to provoke, the free conception of a little more. In this moment, Milly's expression could be interpreted in one of two ways: either she didn't remember the promise at all, or the name "Mr.

Translation

Stringham noted that Mr. Densher had traveled elsewhere due to his assignment before her visit to New York. It was also not hard to discover that he had returned for a day or two later, after her second trip. He had, in short, reappeared only once on his way West, presumably from Washington, though she hadn't seen him when she met her friend to leave. She hadn't thought to elaborate before, nor had it occurred to her that she could. But tonight, she seemed to realize that there had been just enough to this relationship to encourage a little more. In that moment, Milly's expression could be interpreted two ways: either she didn't recall the promise at all, or the name "Mr.

Densher" didn't trigger any thoughts. But her companion quickly realized that Milly couldn't be that oblivious to the promise without it being connected to something specific. For her to deny the promise, it must have been a promise made to someone in particular. As it turned out, Milly acknowledged Mr.

Translation

Densher’s name, and Stringham was able to read her response. She then, however, followed with the caveat that she couldn't see how it had anything to do with anything. She had heard of him, of course, as someone who might perhaps be a very good person. Yet she'd never properly connected him to anyone or anything specific.
