Those words expressed her first complete understanding of a truly romantic situation. She and her friend were already at dinner in Lancaster Gate, surrounded, it seemed, by every English tradition. Her awareness of Mrs.

Translation

Milly spoke with perfect honesty when she told the man on her right—who also happened to be the man on her hostess’s left—that she barely knew where she was. Those words captured her first full comprehension of a genuinely romantic situation. She and her friend were already at dinner in Lancaster Gate, immersed, it seemed, in every English tradition. Her awareness of Mrs.

Lowder’s existence, and even more so of her remarkable personality, had only recently and suddenly come to her. Susie, as she often called her companion to be informal, had merely needed to use a small, elegant gesture, and the fairy tale had started instantly. As a result, Susie was now radiant—because that was the result of Mrs. Stringham’s new sense of success—in the role of a fairy godmother.

Translation

Milly was being completely truthful when she confessed to the man on her right—who was also seated to the left of their hostess—that she was rather disoriented. Those words marked her initial, complete understanding of an authentic romantic context. She and her friend were already at dinner in Lancaster Gate, apparently surrounded by every British custom imaginable. Her knowledge of Mrs. Lowder, and especially of her extraordinary character, had only recently and unexpectedly dawned on her. Susie, as she often familiarly called her friend, had only needed to make a simple, graceful gesture, and the fantasy had begun immediately. Consequently, Susie was now beaming—a result of Mrs. Stringham’s newfound sense of accomplishment—in her role as a fairy godmother.

Milly had almost insisted on dressing her for this occasion as one. It was no fault of the girl’s if the good lady wasn't now wearing a pointed hat, a short petticoat, and diamond shoe buckles, while brandishing a magic crutch. In truth, the good lady behaved as contentedly as if those symbols represented her work. Milly’s observation to Lord Mark had surely been the result of an exchange of glances, which even the great length of the table hadn’t prevented.

Translation

Milly had nearly insisted on outfitting her like one. It wasn't the girl’s fault that the good lady wasn't presently wearing a pointed hat, a short petticoat, and diamond shoe buckles, while brandishing a magic crutch. In fact, the good lady acted as though those symbols perfectly represented her work. Milly’s observation to Lord Mark had surely resulted from a shared look, which not even the vast length of the table had prevented.

Twenty people were between them, but this sustained communication was the most intense result yet of their earlier discussion during the pause on the Swiss pass. It almost seemed to Milly that their fate had been unreasonably rushed—as if they had, in reality, made a small joke and received a disproportionately serious response. She couldn't have said at that moment, with her heightened awareness, whether she was more excited or burdened. The situation might have been serious if she hadn't, by good fortune, decided from the moment the situation appeared that the most important thing was neither to seek nor to avoid.

Translation

Twenty people separated them, but this ongoing connection was the most profound outcome of their prior conversation during the break on the Swiss pass. It felt to Milly as if their destiny had been unreasonably accelerated—as though they had, in actuality, offered a small jest and received an excessively grave reaction. She was unable to say at that moment, with her heightened senses, whether she was more exhilarated or weighed down. The circumstances could have been dire had she not, by sheer luck, decided from the moment the situation arose that the most crucial thing was neither to pursue nor to evade.

It wasn't even to wonder too much, but to let things happen as they would, since there was little doubt how they would turn out. Lord Mark had been brought to her before dinner—not by Mrs. Lowder, but by the handsome girl, that lady's niece, who was now at the other end and on the same side as Susie; he had taken her in, and she meant presently to ask him about Miss Croy, the handsome girl, actually offered to her sight—though now in a splendid way—but for the second time. The first time had been the occasion—only three days before—of her calling at their hotel with her aunt and then making, for our other two heroines, a great impression of beauty and eminence.

Translation

It wasn't even a matter of overthinking, but of letting things unfold as they would, since there was little doubt how they'd resolve. Lord Mark had been brought to her before dinner—not by Mrs. Lowder, but by the attractive girl, that lady's niece, who was now at the other end of the table and seated next to Susie. He'd escorted her in, and she intended to question him about Miss Croy, the attractive girl actually presented to her—though now in a magnificent manner—for the second time. The first time had been the occasion—only three days prior—of her visiting their hotel with her aunt and then making, for our two other heroines, a strong impression of beauty and importance.

This impression had remained so with Milly that, at present, and although her attention was aware at the same time of everything else, her eyes were mainly engaged with Kate Croy when not engaged with Susie. That wonderful creature's eyes moreover readily met them—she ranked now as a wonderful creature; and it seemed a part of the swift prosperity of the American visitors that, so little in the original reckoning, she should yet appear conscious, charmingly, frankly conscious, of possibilities of friendship for them. Milly had easily and, as a guest, gracefully generalised: English girls had a special, strong beauty, and it particularly showed in evening dress—above all when, as was strikingly the case with this one, the dress itself was what it should be. That observation she had all ready for Lord Mark when they should, after a little, get round to it.

Translation

This impression had lingered for Milly to the point that, even though she was aware of everything else happening, her gaze was primarily fixed on Kate Croy, except when it landed on Susie. Furthermore, those magnificent eyes readily met Milly's—she was considered a magnificent creature now; and it seemed to be part of the American visitors' sudden good fortune that she, who had been such a small factor at first, now appeared to be aware—charmingly and frankly so—of the potential for friendship with them. Milly had easily, and with the grace of a guest, generalized: English girls possessed a unique, strong beauty, especially in evening dress—most notably when, as was certainly the case with this one, the dress itself was perfect. She had this observation ready for Lord Mark, once they circled back to it.

She seemed even now to see that there might be a good deal they would get round to; the indication being that, taken up once for all with her other neighbour, their hostess would leave them much to themselves. Mrs. Lowder's other neighbour was the Bishop of Murrum—a real bishop, such as Milly had never seen, with a complicated costume, a voice like an old-fashioned wind instrument, and a face all the portrait of a prelate; while the gentleman on our young lady's left, a gentleman thick-necked, large and literal, who looked straight before him and as if he were not to be diverted by vain words from that pursuit, clearly counted as an offset to the possession of Lord Mark. As Milly made out these things—with a shade of exhilaration at the way she already fell in—she saw how she was justified of her plea for people and her love of life.

Translation

Milly seemed to understand that they might have time to get to know each other; the implication was that their hostess, preoccupied with her other guest, would leave them largely alone. Mrs. Lowder’s other guest was the Bishop of Murrum—a real bishop, unlike any Milly had encountered, complete with elaborate vestments, a voice like an antiquated brass instrument, and a countenance perfectly suited to a religious portrait. Meanwhile, the man on Milly’s left, a thick-necked, literal-minded gentleman who stared straight ahead, as if impervious to frivolous conversation, clearly served to balance out Lord Mark’s presence. As Milly grasped these nuances—a touch of excitement coloring her realization that she fit in so easily—she saw how her fondness for people and her love of life were vindicated.

It wasn't then, as the prospect seemed to show, so difficult to get into the current, or to stand, at any rate, on the bank. It was easy to get near—if they were near; and yet the elements were different enough from any of her old elements, and positively rich and strange. Lord Mark had been introduced to her before dinner—not by Mrs. Lowder, but by the beautiful girl, Mrs.

Translation

It wasn’t as hard as it seemed to insert herself, or at least, to remain on the periphery. It was easy to get close—if they were close; and yet, the components were different from what she was used to, and positively opulent and unusual. Lord Mark had been introduced to her before dinner—not by Mrs. Lowder, but by the beautiful girl, Mrs.

Lowder's niece, who was seated at the other end of the table on the same side as Susie. Lord Mark had escorted the girl in, and Milly intended to ask him about Miss Croy, the beautiful girl who had been presented to her, though now with a stunning display, for the second time. The first time had been just three days before when Miss Croy, with her aunt, had visited their hotel, making a strong impression of beauty and importance on Milly and her friend. This impression remained so vivid that, even though Milly was aware of everything else around her, her attention was primarily focused on Kate Croy when she wasn't occupied with Susie.

Translation

It hadn’t been difficult to insert herself, or at least, to stay on the edge. Getting close was simple enough, assuming they were close; but their makeup was different from what she was accustomed to—positively lavish and strange. Lord Mark had been introduced to her before dinner—not by Mrs. Lowder, but by the beautiful girl, Mrs. Lowder’s niece, who sat at the opposite end of the table on the same side as Susie. Lord Mark had brought the girl in, and Milly planned to ask him about Miss Croy, the beautiful girl who’d been introduced to her, though now, spectacularly, for a second time. The first time had been just three days before, when Miss Croy and her aunt had visited their hotel, making a strong impression of beauty and importance on Milly and her friend. This impression remained so vivid that, even though Milly was aware of everything else around her, her attention was mostly fixed on Kate Croy when she wasn’t occupied with Susie.

Furthermore, Miss Croy's amazing eyes readily met Milly's—she was now considered an amazing creature. It seemed part of the American visitors' quick success that, though hardly anticipated, Miss Croy appeared conscious, charmingly and openly aware, of the possibility of friendship with them. Milly had easily and gracefully generalized: English girls possessed a special, powerful beauty, which was particularly evident in evening gowns—especially when, as was remarkably the case with Miss Croy, the dress itself was perfect. Milly had that observation ready to share with Lord Mark when they eventually had the opportunity.

Translation

Moreover, Miss Croy's striking eyes readily met Milly's—she was now considered a striking person. It seemed part of the American visitors' quick success that, though hardly anticipated, Miss Croy appeared conscious, charmingly and openly aware, of the possibility of friendship with them. Milly had easily and gracefully generalized: English girls possessed a special, powerful beauty, which was particularly evident in evening gowns—especially when, as was remarkably the case with Miss Croy, the dress itself was perfect. Milly had that observation ready to share with Lord Mark when they eventually had the opportunity.

She sensed that they would have plenty to talk about; the indication was that their hostess, absorbed by her other neighbor, would leave them largely to themselves. Mrs. Lowder's other neighbor was the Bishop of Murrum—a real bishop, the likes of which Milly had never seen, with an elaborate outfit, a voice like an old-fashioned wind instrument, and a face straight out of a portrait of a prelate. Meanwhile, the gentleman on Milly's left, a thick-necked, large, and literal man who stared straight ahead as if unwilling to be distracted by trivial conversation from his purpose, clearly served to balance the presence of Lord Mark.

Translation

Milly felt certain that there would be ample conversation between them. Her impression was that their hostess, preoccupied with the other person seated next to her, would leave them largely alone. Mrs. Lowder's other neighbor was the Bishop of Murrum—a genuine bishop, a type Milly had never encountered before, resplendent in elaborate attire, with a voice reminiscent of a bygone era's wind instruments, and a face that could have been lifted straight from a prelate's portrait. Meanwhile, the gentleman to Milly's left, a man of considerable build with a thick neck and a literal demeanor, who gazed fixedly forward as if unwilling to be diverted by minor chatter from his objective, clearly served as a counterweight to Lord Mark's presence.

As Milly understood these things—with a hint of excitement at how easily she was fitting in—she realized that her faith in people and her love of life were justified. It wasn't as difficult as it seemed to get involved or, at the very least, to be on the edge of it. It was easy to get close—if they were close; and yet, the components were different from any of her previous experiences, and positively rich and strange. She asked herself if her right-hand neighbour would understand what she meant by such a description of them, should she throw it off; but another of the things to which, precisely, her sense was awakened was that no, decidedly, he wouldn't.

Translation

Milly, assessing the situation with a thrill at her own adaptability, found her belief in humanity and her appreciation for existence validated. Participation, or at least a position on the periphery, proved less daunting than anticipated. Closeness was attainable—provided they were close; still, the elements composing this reality were unlike anything she'd known, undeniably vibrant and perplexing. She considered whether her immediate neighbor would comprehend her assessment of their circumstances if she were to articulate it; however, the burgeoning acuity of her senses confirmed that, unequivocally, he would not.

It was nevertheless by this time open to her that his line would be to be clever; and indeed, evidently, no little of the interest was going to be in the fresh reference and fresh effect both of people's cleverness and of their simplicity. She thrilled, she consciously flushed, and turned pale with the certitude—it had never been so present—that she should find herself completely involved: the very air of the place, the pitch of the occasion, had for her so positive a taste and so deep an undertone. The smallest things, the faces, the hands, the jewels of the women, the sound of words, especially of names, across the table, the shape of the forks, the arrangement of the flowers, the attitude of the servants, the walls of the room, were all touches in a picture and denotements in a play; and they marked for her, moreover, her alertness of vision. She had never, she might well believe, been in such a state of vibration; her sensibility was almost too sharp for her comfort: there were, for example, more indications than she could reduce to order in the manner of the friendly niece, who struck her as distinguished and interesting, as in fact surprisingly genial.

Translation

Nonetheless, it became clear to her that he would rely on his intelligence. Indeed, it was evident that a significant portion of the intrigue would arise from the novel interplay of people's cleverness and their naiveté. She was exhilarated; she felt a conscious flush, followed by a pallor, with the absolute certainty—more present than ever before—that she would be entirely consumed. The very atmosphere, the tenor of the event, possessed for her such a distinct flavor and profound resonance. The smallest details—the faces, the hands, the women's jewelry, the sound of words, especially names, spoken across the table, the shape of the forks, the arrangement of the flowers, the demeanor of the servants, the walls of the room—all contributed to a picture and were clues in a drama. Furthermore, these details emphasized her heightened perception. She had never, she believed, been in such a state of heightened awareness; her sensitivity was almost too acute for her comfort. There were, for example, more hints than she could organize regarding the manner of the friendly niece, who struck her as both distinguished and intriguing, even surprisingly amiable.

This young woman's type had, visibly, other possibilities; yet here, of its own free movement, it had already sketched a relation. Were they, Miss Croy and she, to take up the tale where their two elders had left it off so many years before?—were they to find they liked each other and to try for themselves if a scheme of constancy on more modern lines could be worked? She had doubted, as they came to England, of Maud Manningham, had believed her a broken reed and a vague resource, had seen their dependence on her as a state of mind that would have been shamefully silly—so far as it was dependence—had they wished to do any thing so inane as "get into society." To have made their pilgrimage all for the sake of such society as Mrs. Lowder might have in reserve for them—that didn't bear thinking of at all, and she herself had quite chosen her course for curiosity about other matters.

Translation

This young woman's type, plainly, had other options. Yet here, of its own accord, it had already begun to form a connection. Were they, Miss Croy and she, to continue the story where their elders had left off so many years ago? Would they discover they liked each other and attempt to see if a plan of commitment, updated for the times, could succeed? She'd had her doubts about Maud Manningham as they came to England, believing her unreliable and a hazy option. She'd viewed their reliance on her as a mindset that would have been embarrassingly foolish—if they'd wanted something as pointless as "getting into society." To have undertaken their journey solely for the sake of whatever society Mrs. Lowder might have to offer—that was unbearable to consider. And she, for her part, had chosen her path out of a curiosity for other matters.

She would have described this curiosity as a desire to see the places she had read about, and that description of her motive she was prepared to give her neighbour—even though, as a consequence of it, he should find how little she had read. It was almost at present as if her poor prevision had been rebuked by the majesty—she could scarcely call it less—of the event, or at all events by the commanding character of the two figures—she could scarcely call that less either—mainly presented. Mrs. Lowder and her niece, however dissimilar, had at least in common that each was a great reality.

Translation

She would have framed this curiosity as a longing to see the places she had read about. She was prepared to offer this explanation to her neighbor, even though it might reveal how little she'd actually read. Right now, it was as if her limited foresight had been rebuked by the majesty—she could barely call it anything less—of the situation, or at least by the dominating nature of the two figures—and she could hardly call that less, either—they predominantly represented. Mrs. Lowder and her niece, though vastly different, shared the common trait of being undeniably substantial.

That was true, primarily, of the aunt—so true that Milly wondered how her own companion had arrived, in other days, at so odd an alliance; yet she none the less felt Mrs. Lowder as a person of whom the mind might in two or three days roughly make the circuit. She would sit there massive, at least, while one attempted it; whereas Miss Croy, the handsome girl, would indulge in incalculable movements that might interfere with one's tour. She was real, none the less, and everything and everybody were real; and it served them right, no doubt, the pair of them, for having rushed into their adventure.

Translation

That was particularly true of the aunt. It was so true that Milly wondered how her own friend had ended up in such an odd relationship in the past. Still, she felt that she could roughly understand Mrs. Lowder's personality in a few days. She would sit there, enormous, while one attempted to do so. In contrast, Miss Croy, the attractive girl, would be prone to unpredictable behavior, which could disrupt one's exploration. She was real, nonetheless, and everything and everyone were real. It served them right, no doubt, the two of them, for rushing into their adventure.

She wondered if the person sitting beside her would understand what she meant if she explained what she thought of the other guests. But she realized that, no, he definitely wouldn't. She was now aware that his approach would be to appear intelligent. And indeed, a great deal of the interest would come from seeing both the intelligence and the simplicity of the people around her.

Translation

She doubted the man beside her would grasp her meaning if she voiced her opinions on the other guests. She concluded, however, that he wouldn't. She understood now that his strategy was to project intelligence. And, in fact, much of the fascination for him stemmed from observing the intelligence and the naiveté of those present.

She felt a thrill, she blushed and then paled, with the certainty—it had never felt so real—that she would become completely involved. The atmosphere of the place, the significance of the occasion, had a very strong and deep impact on her. The smallest details—the faces, the hands, the jewels of the women, the sound of words, especially names, spoken across the table, the shape of the forks, the arrangement of the flowers, the way the servants behaved, the walls of the room—all contributed to a picture and were clues in a play. They showed how perceptive she was.

Translation

She felt a rush of excitement, she blushed and then went pale, with the certainty—it had never felt so tangible—that she would become fully immersed. The ambience of the place, the gravity of the event, had a profound and deep effect on her. The tiniest details—the faces, the hands, the jewelry of the women, the cadence of words, especially names, uttered across the table, the form of the forks, the placement of the flowers, the conduct of the servants, the walls of the room—all contributed to a tableau and were clues in a drama. They demonstrated how observant she was.

She had never, she believed, been so sensitive; her awareness was almost too intense for her comfort. For instance, there were more signs than she could process regarding the friendly niece, who seemed distinguished and interesting, and surprisingly warm. This young woman’s type seemed to have other possibilities, and yet, on its own, it had already begun to form a connection with her. Would she and Miss Croy continue the story that their elders had begun so many years before?

Translation

She felt more acutely than ever, she thought, her senses heightened almost to the point of discomfort. Take, for example, the friendly niece. There were countless signals to interpret about her—she was elegant, engaging, and unexpectedly kind. This young woman’s profile hinted at untold possibilities, and yet, even now, a bond was forming. Would she and Miss Croy pick up where their forebears had left off, all those years ago?

Would they discover they liked each other and try to create a new kind of long-term relationship based on modern ideas? As they came to England, she had doubted Maud Manningham, believing her to be unreliable and a vague hope. She had seen their reliance on her as a foolish state of mind—as far as it was dependence—if they wanted to do something as pointless as “get into society.” To have made their journey only for the sake of the social circle that Mrs. Lowder might offer them was not something she wanted to think about.

Translation

Would they find that they genuinely liked each other and attempt to build a new, lasting relationship based on contemporary values? Upon arriving in England, she had been skeptical of Maud Manningham, considering her untrustworthy and a rather slim prospect. She had viewed their reliance on her as naive—an almost foolish dependency—particularly if they were pursuing something as trivial as “entering society.” To have undertaken this journey solely for the social connections Mrs. Lowder might provide was a thought she actively avoided.

She had chosen her own path, driven by curiosity about other things. She would have described this curiosity as a desire to see the places she had read about, and she was prepared to tell her neighbor this, even if he realized how little she had actually read. It was as if her limited expectations had been challenged by the importance—she could hardly call it less—of the event, or at least by the commanding presence of the two main figures. Mrs.

Translation

She had made her own choices, motivated by a longing to experience new things. She would have told her neighbor that this was a desire to see the places she had read about, and she was ready to admit it, even if he knew she hadn't read very much. It was as if the significance of the event—she could hardly call it anything less—had altered her limited expectations, or at least the compelling presence of the two main figures. Mrs.

Lowder and her niece, though very different, shared the quality of being utterly real. This was especially true of the aunt—so true that Milly wondered how her own companion had formed such a strange alliance in the past. Still, she felt that Mrs. Lowder was a person she could understand in a couple of days.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder and her niece, though very different, shared a quality of complete authenticity. This was especially apparent with the aunt—so much so that Milly wondered how her own friend had formed such a strange alliance in the past. Even so, she felt that Mrs. Lowder was someone she could understand within a couple of days.

She would sit there, substantial, while one tried to figure her out. In contrast, Miss Croy, the attractive girl, would be unpredictable, which might disrupt one’s observations. However, she was real. Everything and everyone was real, and they deserved it, no doubt, for having embarked on this adventure.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder would remain in place, a solid presence, while you attempted to decipher her. In contrast, the appealing Miss Croy was unpredictable, a trait that could throw off your perceptions. Despite this, she possessed authenticity. Everything and everyone was real, and they deserved it, no question, having taken part in this experience.

Lord Mark's intelligence meanwhile, however, had met her own quite sufficiently to enable him to tell her how little he could clear up her situation. He explained, for that matter—or at least he hinted—that there was no such thing, to-day in London, as saying where any one was. Every one was everywhere—nobody was anywhere. He should be put to it—yes, frankly—to give a name of any sort or kind to their hostess's "set." Was it a set at all, or wasn't it, and were there not really no such things as sets, in the place, any more?—was there any thing but the senseless shifting tumble, like that of some great greasy sea in mid-Channel, of an overwhelming melted mixture?

Translation

Lord Mark, however, with his own intelligence, was quite capable of understanding her, and could tell her how little he could resolve her predicament. He explained, in fact—or at least, he implied—that in London nowadays, it was impossible to pinpoint anyone's location. Everyone was everywhere, and nobody was anywhere. He would find it difficult—frankly—to categorize their hostess's circle. Was it even a circle, or wasn't it? Were there even circles anymore, in the city? Was there anything but a senseless, shifting tumble, like a vast, greasy sea in the middle of the Channel, an overwhelming, melted mixture?

He threw out the question, which seemed large; Milly felt that at the end of five minutes he had thrown out a great many, though he followed none more than a step or two; perhaps he would prove suggestive, but he helped her as yet to no discriminations: he spoke as if he had given them up from too much knowledge. He was thus at the opposite extreme from herself, but, as a consequence of it, also wandering and lost; and he was furthermore, for all his temporary incoherence, to which she guessed there would be some key, as great a reality as either Mrs. Lowder or Kate. The only light in which he placed the former of these ladies was that of an extraordinary woman—a most extraordinary woman, and "the more extraordinary the more one knows her," while of the latter he said nothing, for the moment, but that she was tremendously, yes, quite tremendously, good-looking.

Translation

He posed the question, which felt momentous. Milly sensed that in the span of five minutes he had presented many questions, even though he pursued none for more than a brief time. Perhaps he would be a source of ideas, but he wasn't aiding her in making any distinctions. He spoke as if he had abandoned them due to excessive understanding. Thus, he was at the opposite end of the spectrum from her, but as a result, he was also adrift and lost. Despite his temporary lack of clarity, for which she believed there was a reason, he was as real as Mrs. Lowder or Kate. The only perspective he offered on the former woman was that she was extraordinary—a most extraordinary woman, and "the more extraordinary the more one knows her." Of the latter, he said nothing, for the time being, except that she was tremendously, yes, quite tremendously, good-looking.

It was some time, she thought, before his talk showed his cleverness, and yet each minute she believed in it more, quite apart from what her hostess had told her on first naming him. Perhaps he was one of the cases she had heard of at home—those characteristic cases of people in England who concealed their play of mind so much more than they showed it. Even Mr. Densher a little did that.

Translation

She considered that it took a while for his conversation to reveal his intelligence, but with each passing minute, she believed in it more. This was separate from what her hostess had initially said when introducing him. Maybe he was one of those types she'd heard about back home—the typical English, who were more inclined to hide their intellectual agility than display it. Even Mr. Densher did that, to some extent.

And what made Lord Mark, at any rate, so real either, when this was a thing he so definitely insisted on? His type some how, as by a life, a need, an intention of its own, insisted for him; but that was all. It was difficult to guess his age—whether he were a young man who looked old or an old man who looked young; it seemed to prove nothing, as against other things, that he was bald and, as might have been said, slightly stale, or, more delicately perhaps, dry: there was such a fine little fidget of preoccupied life in him, and his eyes, at moments—though it was an appearance they could suddenly lose—were as candid and clear as those of a pleasant boy. Very neat, very light, and so fair that there was little other indication of his moustache than his constantly feeling it—which was again boyish—he would have affected her as the most intellectual person present if he had not affected her as the most frivolous.

Translation

And what, in any case, made Lord Mark feel authentic, when that was something he insisted on so strongly? His persona, in a way, as if by its own life, its own need, its own purpose, was what insisted on him; but that was all. It was hard to guess his age—whether he was a young man who looked old or an old man who looked young; it didn’t seem to mean anything, compared to other things, that he was bald and, you might say, slightly stale, or, to be more delicate perhaps, dry: there was such a subtle little restlessness of absorbed life in him, and his eyes, at times—though they could suddenly lose this look—were as open and clear as those of a charming boy. Very tidy, very slight, and so fair that the main evidence of his mustache was his constant touching of it—which was also boyish—he would have struck her as the most intellectual person there if he hadn't struck her as the most superficial.

The latter quality was rather in his look than in anything else, though he constantly wore his double eyeglass, which was, much more, Bostonian and thoughtful. Meanwhile, Lord Mark's understanding was sharp enough to tell her he couldn't clarify her situation. In fact—or at least he suggested—he implied that in London nowadays, it was impossible to know anyone's whereabouts. Everyone was everywhere, and nobody was anywhere.

Translation

That sense of superficiality was more apparent than anything else, though he constantly wore his double eyeglass, which was, if anything, more Bostonian and thoughtful. Meanwhile, Lord Mark's understanding was sharp enough to tell her he couldn't clarify her situation. In fact—or at least he suggested—he implied that in London nowadays, it was impossible to know anyone's whereabouts. Everyone was everywhere, and nobody was anywhere.

He would struggle—frankly—to categorize their hostess's circle. Was it even a circle, or were social circles, in the traditional sense, nonexistent anymore? Was there anything besides the chaotic, shifting crowd, like an overwhelming, shapeless mix swirling in the middle of the English Channel? He posed the question, which seemed profound.

Translation

He found it difficult, to be honest, to define the social connections of their hostess. Could it even be considered a circle, or were social circles, as they used to be, a thing of the past? Was there anything beyond the disordered, constantly changing mass, like a formless, all-encompassing blend churning in the English Channel? He asked himself the question, which felt like a significant one.

Milly felt he'd posed many questions in five minutes, though he didn't pursue any of them very far. Perhaps he would inspire thought, but he wasn't helping her make any distinctions. He spoke as if he'd given up on understanding things, presumably because he knew too much. In that way, he was the opposite of her, but as a result, he was also adrift and lost.

Translation

Milly felt he'd asked a lot of questions in just five minutes, even though he didn't follow up on any of them. Maybe he sparked ideas, but he wasn't helping her figure anything out. He talked like he'd given up on understanding, probably because he knew too much. In that way, he was the opposite of her, but it also meant he was lost and adrift.

Despite his temporary, confusing way of speaking, which she sensed had an underlying logic, he was just as real as Mrs. Lowder or Kate. The only perspective he offered on Mrs. Lowder was that she was an extraordinary woman, and "the more one knew her, the more extraordinary she was." He said nothing about Kate at the moment, except that she was incredibly, undeniably attractive.

Translation

Though his speech was currently perplexing and erratic, and though she sensed an underlying reason for it, he was as tangible as Mrs. Lowder or Kate. His only assessment of Mrs. Lowder was that she was remarkable, and that "the better one knew her, the more remarkable she became." He made no comment on Kate at the moment, save for observing that she was remarkably, indisputably alluring.

Milly thought it took a while for his intelligence to become apparent in his conversation, yet she believed in it more with each passing minute, regardless of what her hostess had initially told her about him. Perhaps he was one of those people she'd heard about back home—those characteristic English types who concealed their mental agility more than they revealed it. Even Mr. Densher did that, to some extent.

Translation

Milly found that his intelligence took a while to surface in their conversations, but with every minute, she had more faith in it, despite what her hostess had said about him. Maybe he was one of those people she’d heard about back home—those quintessential English types who hid their mental acuity more than they showed it. Even Mr. Densher did that, to a certain degree.

And what made Lord Mark seem so real, anyway, given that he insisted so much on that very point? His very type, as if driven by its own life, need, or purpose, asserted itself through him; but that was all. It was hard to guess his age—whether he was a young man who appeared old or an old man who seemed young. His baldness and slightly faded appearance—perhaps it was more accurate to say he seemed dry—didn't really mean anything.

Translation

And what, really, made Lord Mark seem so tangible, considering how much he stressed the point? The man's entire persona, as if animated by its own force, desire, or objective, expressed itself through him; but that was the extent of it. His age was difficult to place—was he a young man who looked old, or an old man who seemed young? His bald head and slightly washed-out appearance—or perhaps it was better to say he seemed desiccated—didn't really signify anything.

He had a nervous energy, a constant hum of inner activity, and his eyes, though they could suddenly lose this quality, were sometimes as clear and innocent as a pleasant boy's. Immaculately dressed, slender, and so fair-haired that his moustache was barely visible, though he constantly touched it—which was another boyish trait—he would have struck her as the most intellectual person present if he hadn't also seemed the most frivolous. This last quality was more evident in his appearance than anything else, even though he frequently wore his double eyeglass, which gave him a much more studious, thoughtful air. The idea of his frivolity had, no doubt, to do with his personal designation, which represented—as yet, for our young woman, a little confusedly—a connection with an historic patriciate, a class that, in turn, also confusedly, represented an affinity with a social element that she had never heard otherwise described than as "fashion." The supreme social element in New York had never known itself but as reduced to that category, and though Milly was aware that, as applied to a territorial and political aristocracy, the label was probably too simple, she had for the time none other at hand.

Translation

He possessed a nervous energy, a constant buzz of inner activity, and his eyes, though they could suddenly lose this quality, were sometimes as clear and innocent as a pleasant boy's. Immaculately dressed, slender, and so fair-haired that his mustache was barely visible, though he constantly touched it—which was another boyish trait—he would have struck her as the most intellectual person present if he hadn't also seemed the most frivolous. This latter quality was more evident in his appearance than anything else, even though he frequently wore his double eyeglass, which gave him a much more studious, thoughtful air. The idea of his frivolity was, no doubt, connected to his personal designation, which represented—as yet, for our young woman, a little confusedly—a link to an historic patriciate, a class that, in turn, also confusedly, represented an affinity with a social element that she had never heard described otherwise than as "fashion." The supreme social element in New York had never known itself except as reduced to that category, and though Milly was aware that, as applied to a territorial and political aristocracy, the label was probably too simple, she had for the time none other at hand.

She presently, it is true, enriched her idea with the perception that her interlocutor was indifferent; yet this, indifferent as aristocracies notoriously were, saw her but little further, inasmuch as she felt that, in the first place, he would much rather get on with her than not, and in the second was only thinking of too many matters of his own. If he kept her in view on the one hand and kept so much else on the other—the way he crumbed up his bread was a proof—why did he hover before her as a potentially insolent noble? She couldn't have answered the question, and it was precisely one of those that swarmed. They were complicated, she might fairly have said, by his visibly knowing, having known from afar off, that she was a stranger and an American, and by his none the less making no more of it than if she and her like were the chief of his diet.

Translation

She did, it was true, eventually revise her understanding by recognizing that her conversation partner was detached. But this detachment, characteristic as it was of aristocrats, didn't provide much clarity. She sensed, first, that he preferred speaking to her over not speaking to her, and second, that he was preoccupied with a multitude of other things. The way he crumbled his bread was evidence of this. Why then did he present himself to her as a potentially arrogant nobleman? She couldn't answer the question, and it was precisely one of the many that troubled her. These questions were complicated, she might fairly have said, by his obvious awareness—having known from the outset—that she was a foreigner and an American, and yet by his acting as though her kind was his primary concern.

He took her, kindly enough, but imperturbably, irreclaimably, for granted, and it wouldn't in the least help that she herself knew him, as quickly, for having been in her country and threshed it out. There would be nothing for her to explain or attenuate or brag about; she could neither escape nor prevail by her strangeness; he would have, for that matter, on such a subject, more to tell her than to learn from her. She might learn from him why she was so different from the handsome girl—which she didn't know, being merely able to feel it; or at any rate might learn from him why the handsome girl was so different from her. The notion of his superficiality was likely linked to his identity, which, in Milly's somewhat hazy understanding, signified a connection to a long-standing upper class.

Translation

He accepted her, graciously enough, but with unwavering indifference. It wouldn't help in the slightest that she already knew him, having come from her country and already figured him out. She wouldn't have to explain anything, or downplay anything, or boast. She couldn't escape or succeed because of her foreignness. On that subject, for that matter, he would have more to tell her than to learn from her. She might learn from him why she was so unlike the beautiful girl—something she didn't understand, only felt. Or, at the very least, she might learn from him why the beautiful girl was so unlike her. His superficiality was likely linked to his identity, which, in Milly's somewhat vague understanding, meant a connection to a longstanding upper class.

This class, she also vaguely understood, represented an association with a social sphere she knew only as "high society." New York's elite had always been defined by this term. While Milly realized it might be an oversimplification when applied to a titled aristocracy, she couldn't think of a better word. Eventually, she added to her understanding the fact that her companion seemed detached. However, this didn't clarify matters much, given aristocrats were known for detachment.

Translation

This class, she also vaguely understood, represented an association with a social sphere she only knew as "high society." New York's elite had always been defined by this term. Though Milly knew it might be an oversimplification when applied to a titled aristocracy, she couldn't think of a better word. Eventually, she added to her understanding the fact that her companion seemed detached. But this didn't clarify matters much, since aristocrats were known for detachment.

She felt he would rather engage with her than not, and also seemed preoccupied with his own concerns. If he was paying attention to her while also considering many other things—as proven by the way he crumbled his bread—why did he present himself as a potential, insolent aristocrat? She couldn't answer that question, and it was one of many buzzing around her. These questions were complicated, she might fairly have said, by his obvious awareness—his having known from afar—that she was a foreigner and an American.

Translation

She sensed he'd prefer their interaction to silence, yet he seemed absorbed in his own thoughts. He was clearly observing her, despite the other matters occupying him—evident in how he absentmindedly crumbled his bread—so why the deliberate pose of a possibly rude aristocrat? She couldn't unravel it, and the question joined the many swirling in her mind. These questions, she might have admitted, were made more complex by his apparent knowledge—his prior awareness—that she was foreign, an American.

Despite this, he acted as if she and others like her were commonplace. He accepted her, kindly enough, but with unwavering ease, as if she were a given, and it wouldn't help in the least that she, in turn, recognized he had been to her country and understood it. She couldn't explain, downplay, or boast about anything; her being different wouldn't help her escape or succeed; on that topic, he likely knew more than she did. She might learn from him why she was so unlike the beautiful girl—which she didn't understand, only feeling it; or at least she might learn why the beautiful girl was so different from her.

Translation

Nevertheless, he behaved as if she and people like her were utterly ordinary. He accommodated her, in a pleasant way, but with total composure, as if her presence was a foregone conclusion. It wouldn't do any good that she, for her part, realized he’d been to her country and understood it. She couldn’t try to rationalize, minimize, or boast about anything; her otherness wouldn’t help her get away with anything or make her successful. On that score, he probably knew more than she did. Perhaps she could find out from him why she was so unlike the beautiful girl—something she didn’t comprehend, only felt; or, at the very least, she might understand why the beautiful girl was so unlike her.

On these lines, however, they would move later; the lines immediately laid down were, in spite of his vagueness for his own convenience, definite enough. She was already, he observed to her, thinking what she should say on her other side—which was what Americans were always doing. She needn't in conscience say anything at all; but Americans never knew that, nor ever, poor creatures, yes (she had interposed the "poor creatures!") what not to do. The burdens they took on—the things, positively, they made an affair of!

Translation

However, they would address that later. The immediate conditions, despite his deliberate vagueness, were clear. He observed that she was already contemplating her response—the typical American tendency. She had no obligation to say anything at all. But Americans, the poor things (she had interjected, "poor things!"), never understood that, nor what *not* to do. The burdens they shouldered—the things they turned into such a fuss!

This easy and, after all, friendly jibe at her race was really for her, on her new friend's part, the note of personal recognition so far as she required it; and she gave him a prompt and conscious example of morbid anxiety by insisting that her desire to be, herself, "lovely" all round was justly founded on the lovely way Mrs. Lowder had met her. He was directly interested in that, and it was not till afterwards that she fully knew how much more information about their friend he had taken than given. Here again, for instance, was a pertinent note for her: she had, on the spot, with her first plunge into the obscure depths of a society constituted from far back, encountered the interesting phenomenon of complicated, of possibly sinister motive.

Translation

This casual, ultimately harmless dig at her background was, for her new acquaintance, a sign of personal acknowledgement, tailored to her needs. She quickly demonstrated her own capacity for overwrought concern by maintaining that her wish to be universally "lovely" was entirely justified by Mrs. Lowder's own graciousness towards her. He was immediately intrigued by this, and only later did she fully realize how much more information about their friend he had gleaned than he had offered. Here, too, was a note of significance for her: at her first foray into the hidden complexities of a long-established society, she had already encountered the fascinating phenomenon of layered, perhaps even malicious, intentions.

However, Maud Manningham (her name, even in her presence, somehow still fed the fancy) had, all the same, been lovely, and one was going to meet her now quite as far on as one had one's self been met. She had been with them at their hotel—they were a pair—before even they had supposed she could have got their letter. Of course indeed they had written in advance, but they had followed that up very fast. She had thus engaged them to dine but two days later, and on the morrow again, without waiting for a return visit, waiting for anything, she had called with her niece.

Translation

Nevertheless, Maud Manningham—her name, even when she was right there, still tickling the imagination—had, all the same, been lovely, and now they were going to meet her on as friendly terms as they had been met themselves. She'd been at their hotel with them—they were a pair—before they even thought she could have received their letter. Of course they had written ahead, but they'd followed up quickly. She had then invited them to dinner two days later, and the next day, without waiting for a return visit, without waiting for anything, she had called on them with her niece.

It was as if she really cared for them, and it was magnificent fidelity—fidelity to Mrs. Stringham, her own companion and Mrs. Lowder's former schoolmate, the lady with the charming face and the rather high dress down there at the end. They would address those matters later; the initial matters, despite his deliberately vague approach, were quite clear.

Translation

It was as if she genuinely liked them, and it was a magnificent loyalty—loyalty to Mrs. Stringham, her own companion and Mrs. Lowder's former school friend, the woman with the charming face and the rather high-waisted dress down there at the end. They would get to those details later; the preliminary matters, despite his deliberately vague approach, were quite clear.

He observed that she was already contemplating what she would say next, which was typical of Americans. She didn't have to say anything at all, but Americans never understood that, nor did they, poor things (she had interjected the "poor things!"), know what not to do. The burdens they took on, the things they made such a big deal of! This lighthearted and friendly jab at her nationality was, for her, a sign of personal connection from her new friend.

Translation

He noticed she was already planning her next words, a common trait among Americans. She didn't need to say anything, but Americans never grasped that. Nor did they, poor dears (she added the "poor dears!"), understand what to avoid. The obligations they took on, the things they exaggerated! This playful, amicable teasing of her nationality signaled to her a personal connection from her new acquaintance.

She promptly and deliberately showed her own tendency toward worry by insisting that her desire to be "lovely" in every way was justified by how graciously Mrs. Lowder had treated her. He was immediately interested in that, and she didn't realize until later how much more he had learned about their friend than he had revealed. Another important point for her: she had immediately, upon entering the mysterious world of a society that had existed for a long time, encountered the intriguing phenomenon of complex, possibly suspicious, motives.

Translation

She immediately and intentionally displayed her own propensity for anxiety by asserting that her ambition to be "charming" in every aspect was validated by Mrs. Lowder's graciousness. He was instantly intrigued, and she didn't understand until later how much more he'd learned about their friend than he'd let on. Another critical point for her: upon entering the perplexing world of a long-established society, she'd immediately encountered the fascinating phenomenon of complicated, potentially dubious, intentions.

Still, Maud Manningham (the name itself, even when she was present, still captured the imagination) had been lovely, and one would reciprocate her welcome as warmly. She had visited them at their hotel—they were a pair—before they even thought she could have received their letter. Of course, they had written ahead, but they had also followed up very quickly. She had invited them to dinner just two days later, and then the next day, without waiting for a return visit or anything else, she had called with her niece.

Translation

Even now, thinking of Maud Manningham—the name itself seemed to stir the imagination—she had been delightful, and one would gladly return her kindness. She had come to their hotel—they were a couple—before they even expected she'd received their letter. They had written in advance, naturally, but they'd also followed up right away. She'd invited them to dinner just two days later, and then the following day, without waiting for a reciprocal visit or anything, she'd called with her niece.

It was as though she genuinely cared about them, and it was a remarkable dedication—loyalty to Mrs. Stringham, her own companion and Mrs. Lowder's former schoolmate, the woman with the charming face and the rather formal attire over there. Lord Mark took in through his nippers these balanced attributes of Susie.

Translation

It was as though she truly cared, a remarkable dedication, a loyalty to Mrs. Stringham, her companion, formerly Mrs. Lowder’s schoolmate—the woman with the charming face and the rather formal attire. Lord Mark absorbed Susie’s balanced attributes with his keen eyes.

"But isn't Mrs. Stringham's fidelity then equally magnificent?" "Well, it's a beautiful sentiment; but it isn't as if she had anything to give." "Hasn't she got you?" Lord Mark presently asked.

Translation

"But isn't Mrs. Stringham's loyalty just as impressive?" "Well, it's a lovely sentiment, but it's not like she has anything to offer." "Doesn't she have you?" Lord Mark asked after a moment.

"Me—to give Mrs. Lowder?" Milly had clearly not yet seen herself in the light of such an offering. "Oh, I'm rather a poor present; and I don't feel as if, even at that, I've as yet quite been given." "You've been shown, and if our friend has jumped at you it comes to the same thing." He made his jokes, Lord Mark, without amusement for himself; yet it wasn't that he was grim.

Translation

"Me—to give to Mrs. Lowder?" Milly obviously hadn't considered herself in that role before. "Oh, I'm not much of a gift; and I don't feel like I've actually been given yet, even at that." "You've been presented, and if our friend has accepted you, it's essentially the same thing." Lord Mark made his jokes, not enjoying them himself, though it wasn't that he was unhappy.

"To be seen you must recognise, is, for you, to be jumped at; and, if it's a question of being shown, here you are again. Only it has now been taken out of your friend's hands; it's Mrs. Lowder, already, who's getting the benefit. Look round the table and you'll make out, I think, that you're being, from top to bottom, jumped at."

Translation

"To be seen, you must realize, means to be pounced upon in your case; and if we're talking about being put on display, well, here you are again. Only now it's been taken out of your friend's hands; Mrs. Lowder is already reaping the rewards. Look around the table, and I think you'll see that you're being, from head to toe, pounced upon."

Lord Mark observed Susie's qualities, carefully considering them. "But isn't Mrs. Stringham's loyalty just as impressive?" "Well, it's a lovely idea; but she doesn't actually have anything to offer."

Translation

Lord Mark assessed Susie's attributes, giving them thoughtful consideration. "But isn't Mrs. Stringham's devotion equally noteworthy?" "Yes, it sounds nice; however, she's fundamentally useless."

"Doesn't she have you?" Lord Mark asked after a moment. "Me—to offer to Mrs. Lowder?" Milly didn't seem to see herself as something to be given away. "Oh, I'm not much of a gift; and I don't feel like I've actually been given away yet."

Translation

"Isn't she relying on you?" Lord Mark asked after a moment. "Me—as an offering to Mrs. Lowder?" Milly didn't seem to view herself as something to be handed over. "Oh, I'm not much of a prize; and I don't feel I've actually been given away, not yet."

"You've been presented, and if our friend has enthusiastically accepted you, it's the same thing." Lord Mark made his jokes without finding them amusing; it wasn't that he was unpleasant. "For you, being presented means being eagerly pursued; and, since we're talking about presentation, here you are again. Only now it's no longer your friend's doing; Mrs. Lowder is already benefiting.

Translation

"You've been introduced, and if our friend is excited about you, it's essentially the same thing." Lord Mark made his jokes without a hint of a smile; it wasn't that he was being mean. "For you, being introduced means being enthusiastically courted; and, since we're discussing introductions, here you are again. Except now, it's no longer your friend's doing; Mrs. Lowder is already profiting."

Look around the table, and you'll probably realize you're being aggressively pursued by everyone." "Well, then," said Milly, "I seem also to feel that I like it better than being made fun of." It was one of the things she afterwards saw—Milly was for ever seeing things afterwards—that her companion had here had some way of his own, quite unlike any one's else, of assuring her of his consideration. She wondered how he had done it, for he had neither apologised nor protested.

Translation

"Look around the table," he said, "and you'll probably realize you're being aggressively pursued by everyone." "Well, then," said Milly, "I seem to feel that I like it better than being made fun of." It was one of the things she realized later—Milly was always realizing things later—that her companion had used a method, unlike anyone else's, of assuring her of his consideration. She wondered how he'd done it, because he'd neither apologized nor protested.

She said to herself, at any rate, that he had led her on; and what was most odd was the question by which he had done so. "Does she know much about you?" "No, she just likes us." Even for this his travelled lordship, seasoned and saturated, had no laugh.

Translation

She told herself, at least, that he'd been stringing her along. The strangest part was the question he'd used to do it. "Does she know much about you?" "No, she just likes us." Even this—his lordship, the worldly and experienced man, didn't find funny.

"I mean you particularly. Has that lady with the charming face, which is charming, told her?" "Well," Milly said, "I think I prefer this to being ridiculed." Later, Milly would recognize—she often understood things later—that her companion had a unique way of showing his respect, unlike anyone else.

Translation

"I'm talking about you specifically. Has that lady with the lovely face—and it *is* lovely—told her?" "Well," Milly said, "I think this is better than being laughed at." Later, Milly would realize—she often took a while to understand things—that her companion had a singular way of showing respect, unlike anyone else's.

She puzzled over how he'd managed it, because he hadn't apologized or defended himself. She decided he'd manipulated her, and the most peculiar part was the question that had led her to that conclusion. "Does she know much about you?" "No, she just likes us."

Translation

She couldn't understand how he'd pulled it off, because he hadn't said he was sorry or tried to justify his actions. She decided he'd been manipulating her, and what was most strange was the question that had made her think so. "Does she know a lot about you?" "No, she just likes us."

Even this seasoned and worldly gentleman didn't laugh. "I mean, you specifically. Has that woman with the lovely, charming face told her?" Milly hesitated.

Translation

Even a man as experienced and sophisticated as he was didn't crack a smile. "I'm asking about you, specifically. Has that woman, the one with the pretty, captivating face, spoken to her?" Milly paused.

"Told her what?" "Everything." This, with the way he dropped it, again considerably moved her—made her feel for a moment that, as a matter of course, she was a subject for disclosures. But she quickly found her answer.

Translation

"Told her what?" "Everything." The way he said it, he really got to her. For a second, she felt like she was just there to be gossiped about. But then she figured it out.

"Oh, as for that, you must ask her." "Your clever companion?" "Mrs. Lowder."

Translation

"Oh, you'll have to ask her about that," he said. "Your clever friend?" "Mrs. Lowder."

He replied to this that their hostess was a person with whom there were certain liberties one never took, but that he was none the less fairly upheld, inasmuch as she was for the most part kind to him and as, should he be very good for a while, she would probably herself tell him. "And I shall have, at any rate, in the meantime, the interest of seeing what she does with you. That will teach me more or less, you see, how much she knows." Milly paused.

Translation

He answered that their hostess was someone with whom you never took certain liberties, but that he was still fairly confident because she was generally kind to him and, if he behaved himself for a while, she would likely tell him herself. "And at least, in the meantime, I'll be interested in watching what she does with you. That will show me, more or less, how much she knows." Milly hesitated.

"Told her what?" "Everything." His simple statement, and the way he delivered it, unsettled her—for a moment, she felt as if her life was a topic of discussion. But she quickly composed herself.

Translation

"Told her what?" "Everything." His matter-of-fact declaration, and the manner in which he presented it, disquieted her—for an instant, she felt as though her existence had become a subject of scrutiny. However, she swiftly regained her composure.

"You'll have to ask her." "Your brilliant friend?" "Mrs. Lowder."

Translation

"You'll need to ask her," he said. "Your clever friend?" "Mrs. Lowder."

He responded that their hostess was someone with whom he couldn't be too familiar, but he felt somewhat assured, since she was generally nice to him, and if he behaved himself, she would probably fill him in. "And at the very least, I'll be interested to see what she does with you. That will tell me, more or less, how much she knows." Milly followed this—it was lucid; but it suggested something apart.

Translation

He replied that he couldn't get too close to their hostess, but he was somewhat reassured by her general friendliness. If he was on his best behavior, she would likely explain things to him. "And at the very least, I'll be interested to see how she treats you. That will tell me, more or less, how much she knows." Milly understood this—it was clear; but it hinted at something separate.

"How much does she know about you?" "Nothing," said Lord Mark serenely. "But that doesn't matter—for what she does with me." And then, as to anticipate Milly's question about the nature of such doing: "This, for instance—turning me straight on for you." The girl thought.

Translation

"How much does she know about you?" "Nothing," Lord Mark said calmly. "But that doesn't matter—it's what she does with me that counts."

And then, as if anticipating Milly's question about what he meant by "doing": "This, for instance—putting me right in front of you."

The girl considered this.

"And you mean she wouldn't if she did know——?" He met it as if it were really a point. "No. I believe, to do her justice, she still would.

Translation

"And you mean she wouldn't if she knew—?" He treated this as a genuine point. "No. I believe, to be fair to her, she still would."

So you can be easy." Milly had the next instant, then, acted on the permission. "Because you're even at the worst the best thing she has?" With this he was at last amused.

Translation

"So you can relax." Milly had the next second, then, acted on the permission. "Because even at your worst, you're the best thing she has?" This finally amused him.

"I was till you came. You're the best now." Milly understood this—it was clear, but it hinted at something else. "How much does she know about you?"

Translation

"I was, until you arrived. You're the best now." Milly understood this—it was plain, but it implied something more. "How much does she know about you?"

"Nothing," Lord Mark said calmly. "But that's not important—because of what she does with me." And then, as though to answer Milly's question about the nature of this "doing": "Like this, for example—directing me to you." The girl considered. "And you mean she wouldn't do that if she did know—?"

Translation

"Nothing," Lord Mark replied, his voice even. "But it doesn't matter, because of what she does with me." And then, as though explaining the nature of this "doing": "Like this, for instance—she sent me to you." The girl thought for a moment. "And you're suggesting she wouldn't do that if she knew—?"

He addressed the matter as if it were a significant point. "No. I believe, to be fair to her, she still would. So you don't need to worry."

Translation

He treated the issue as if it were of great importance. "No. To be fair to her, I think she'd still do it. So you needn't be concerned."

Milly immediately took advantage of this reassurance. "Because, even at your worst, you're the best thing she has?" At this he was finally amused. "I was, until you arrived.

Translation

Milly seized upon the reassurance. "Because, even at your worst, you're the best she's got?" He was finally amused. "I was, until you showed up."

You're the best now." It was strange his words should have given her the sense of his knowing, but it was positive that they did so, and to the extent of making her believe them, though still with wonder. That, really, from this first of their meetings, was what was most to abide with her: she accepted almost helplessly, she surrendered to the inevitability of being the sort of thing, as he might have said, that he at least thoroughly believed he had, in going about, seen here enough of for all practical purposes. Her submission was naturally, moreover, not to be impaired by her learning later on that he had paid at short intervals, though at a time apparently just previous to her own emergence from the obscurity of extreme youth, three separate visits to New York, where his nameable friends and his contrasted contacts had been numerous.

Translation

"You're the best now." It was odd that his words should have given her the feeling that he understood, but they did, absolutely, and to the point that she believed them, though she was still astonished. That, really, from their first meeting, was what would stay with her most: she accepted almost helplessly, she surrendered to the certainty of being the kind of person, as he might have said, that he believed he'd seen enough of, in his travels, for all intents and purposes. Her surrender, furthermore, wasn't going to be damaged by her later learning that he had made three separate trips to New York at short intervals, though at a time that seemed just before her own emergence from the obscurity of her extreme youth, where his named friends and his contrasting acquaintances had been numerous.

His impression, his recollection of the whole mixed quantity, was still visibly rich. It had helped him to place her, and she was more and more sharply conscious of having—as with the door sharply slammed upon her and the guard's hand raised in signal to the train—been popped into the compartment in which she was to travel for him. It was a use of her that many a girl would have been doubtless quick to resent; and the kind of mind that thus, in our young lady, made all for mere seeing and taking is precisely one of the charms of our subject. Milly had practically just learned from him, had made out, as it were, from her rumbling compartment, that he gave her the highest place among their friend's actual properties.

Translation

His impression, his memory of the entire complex picture, was still vividly rich. It had helped him to understand her, and she was increasingly aware that she had been—as if a door slammed shut on her and the guard signaled the train—thrust into the compartment in which she was to travel with him. Many a girl would likely have been quick to resent being used in this way; and the kind of mind that, in our young lady, was entirely geared towards seeing and receiving is precisely one of the charms of our subject. Milly had practically just learned from him, had, so to speak, gathered from her rumbling compartment, that he considered her the most valuable of their friend's actual possessions.

She was a success, that was what it came to, he presently assured her, and that was what it was to be a success: it always happened before one could know it. One's ignorance was in fact often the greatest part of it. "You haven't had time yet," he said; "this is nothing. But you'll see.

Translation

She had succeeded, that’s what it amounted to, he assured her now, and that's what being a success was: it always happened before one could realize it. One’s ignorance was, in fact, often the greatest part of it. “You haven’t had time yet,” he said; “this is nothing. But you’ll see.”

You'll see everything. You can, you know—everything you dream of."
