That, truly, from this first meeting, was what would stay with her most: she accepted almost without resistance, she yielded to the inevitability of being the type of person—as he might have put it—that he certainly believed he had seen enough of in his travels for practical purposes.

Translation

You'll see everything. You can, you know—everything you dream of." It was strange how his words gave her the impression that he knew her, but they did, and to the point that she believed him, though still with a sense of wonder. That, truly, from this first meeting, was what would stay with her the most: she accepted almost without resistance, she gave in to the inevitability of being the type of person—as he might have put it—that he certainly believed he had seen enough of in his travels for practical purposes.

Her acceptance, furthermore, would not be lessened by her later learning that he had, at brief intervals, though seemingly just before she emerged from her extremely young and obscure beginnings, made three separate trips to New York, where he had numerous friends and contacts of different types. His impression, his memory of the whole mixed collection, was still noticeably vivid. It had helped him to understand her, and she became increasingly aware that she had been—as if the door had been slammed on her and the guard signaled the train—thrust into the compartment in which she was to travel for him. It was a way of using her that many a girl would likely have resented quickly; and the kind of mind that, in our young woman, was entirely focused on observing and taking in is precisely one of the most appealing aspects of our subject.

Translation

Moreover, her acceptance wouldn't be diminished by the later revelation that, at scattered points in time, and apparently just before she emerged from her extremely early and unknown phase, he had made three separate trips to New York, where he had various friends and contacts. His impression, his memory of the whole mixed group, remained strikingly clear. It had helped him to understand her, and she realized more and more that she'd been—as if the door had slammed on her and the guard had signaled the train—pushed into the compartment in which she was to travel for him. It was a means of using her that many a girl would likely have quickly resented; and the type of mind that, in our young woman, was completely focused on observing and absorbing is exactly one of the most appealing features of our subject.

Milly had just learned from him, had, in a sense, gathered from her moving compartment, that he considered her to be the most valuable of their friend's possessions. She was a success, that was the long and short of it, he assured her presently, and that was what being a success entailed: it always happened before one realized it. One's ignorance was often the greatest part of it. "You haven't had time yet," he said; "this is nothing.

Translation

Milly had just heard from him, had, in a way, picked it up from her moving compartment, that he thought she was the most valuable thing their friend owned. She was a success, he told her now, and that was the whole point: it always happened before you knew it. Your own cluelessness was often the biggest part of it. "You haven't had time yet," he said; "this is nothing.

But you'll see. You'll see everything. You can, you know—everything you dream of." He made her more and more wonder; she almost felt as if he were showing her visions while he spoke; and strangely enough, though it was visions that had drawn her on, she hadn't seen them in connection—that is in such preliminary and necessary connection—with such a face as Lord Mark's, such eyes and such a voice, such a tone and such a manner.

Translation

But you will. You'll see it all. You can—everything you've ever wanted." He made her more and more curious; she almost felt like he was showing her visions while he spoke. And strangely, though visions were what had drawn her, she hadn't connected them—that is, in such a preliminary and essential way—with a face like Lord Mark's, such eyes and voice, such a tone and manner.

He had for an instant the effect of making her ask herself if she were after all going to be afraid; so distinct was it for fifty seconds that a fear passed over her. There they were again—yes, certainly: Susie's overture to Mrs. Lowder had been their joke, but they had pressed in that gaiety an electric bell that continued to sound. Positively, while she sat there, she had the loud rattle in her ears, and she wondered, during these moments, why the others didn't hear it.

Translation

For an instant, he made her wonder if she was, in fact, going to be afraid. The sensation was so clear, for a brief moment, that fear washed over her. There they were again, yes: Susie's offer to Mrs. Lowder had been their joke, but in that moment of levity, they had pressed an electric bell that continued to ring. Truly, as she sat there, she heard the loud rattle in her ears, and she wondered, for those few seconds, why the others couldn't hear it.

They didn't stare, they didn't smile, and the fear in her that I speak of was but her own desire to stop it. That dropped, however, as if the alarm itself had ceased; she seemed to have seen in a quick, though tempered glare that there were two courses for her, one to leave London again the first thing in the morning, the other to do nothing at all. Well, she would do nothing at all; she was already doing it; more than that, she had already done it, and her chance was gone. She gave herself up—she had the strangest sense, on the spot, of so deciding; for she had turned a corner before she went on again with Lord Mark.

Translation

They didn't stare, they didn't smile, and the fear I mentioned was just her own wish to end it. That vanished, though, as if the alarm itself had been silenced; it seemed she had realized, in a quick, though controlled flash, that she had two options: to leave London again first thing in the morning, or to do nothing at all. Well, she would do nothing at all; she was already doing it; even more than that, she had already done it, and her chance was gone. She gave in—she had the strangest feeling, right then, of having made that decision; because she had turned a corner before she continued on with Lord Mark.

Inexpressive, but intensely significant, he met as no one else could have done the very question she had suddenly put to Mrs. Stringham on the Brünig. Should she have it, whatever she did have, that question had been, for long? "Ah, so possibly not," her neighbour appeared to reply; "therefore, don't you see?

Translation

He was inscrutable, but his presence was deeply meaningful. He responded in a way that no one else could have managed, perfectly addressing the exact query she'd unexpectedly posed to Mrs. Stringham on the Brünig. Had she possessed it, whatever *it* was, that question had lingered for some time? "Ah, perhaps not," her companion seemed to answer. "Consequently, you understand?"

I'm the way." It was vivid that he might be, in spite of his absence of flourish; the way being doubtless just in that absence. The handsome girl, whom she didn't lose sight of and who, she felt, kept her also in view—Mrs. Lowder's striking niece would, perhaps, be the way as well, for in her too was the absence of flourish, though she had little else, so far as one could tell, in common with Lord Mark. Yet how indeed could one tell, what did one understand, and of what was one, for that matter, provisionally conscious but of their being somehow together in what they represented?

Translation

"I am the way." It was evident that he could be, despite his lack of ostentation; the way, undoubtedly, lay precisely in that absence. The beautiful girl, whom she kept in sight and who, she sensed, kept her in view as well—Mrs. Lowder's remarkable niece—could possibly also be the way, for in her, too, was the absence of ostentation, though, as far as one could tell, she had little else in common with Lord Mark. Yet, in truth, how could one tell, what did one understand, and of what, for that matter, was one provisionally conscious but of their being somehow bound together in what they embodied?

Kate Croy, fine but friendly, looked over at her as really with a guess at Lord Mark's effect on her. If she could guess this effect what then did she know about it and in what degree had she felt it herself? Did that represent, as between them, anything particular, and should she have to count with them as duplicating, as intensifying by a mutual intelligence, the relation into which she was sinking? Nothing was so odd as that she should have to recognise so quickly in each of these glimpses of an instant the various signs of a relation; and this anomaly itself, had she had more time to give to it, might well, might almost terribly have suggested to her that her doom was to live fast.

Translation

Kate Croy, lovely but approachable, glanced at the girl, trying to imagine how Lord Mark impacted her. If she could imagine the impact, what then did she truly know about it, and to what extent had she experienced it herself? Did this represent something specific between them, and should she have to consider them as mirroring, as amplifying through shared understanding, the relationship she was entering? Nothing was so strange as having to so quickly recognize the various indicators of a relationship in these brief glimpses; and this strangeness itself, if she had more time to consider it, might very well, might almost alarmingly have indicated to her that her fate was to live intensely.

It was queerly a question of the short run and the consciousness proportionately crowded. He made her increasingly curious. She almost felt as though he were showing her visions while he spoke. Strangely enough, even though visions had drawn her in, she hadn't connected them—specifically, hadn't connected them in the necessary way—with a face like Lord Mark's, eyes and voice like his, his tone and manner.

Translation

It was an odd situation, focused on the immediate and with an overabundance of awareness. He piqued her curiosity more and more. It was almost as though he were showing her visions as he talked. Curiously, even though these visions had captivated her, she hadn't associated them—specifically, hadn't connected them in the required way—with a face like Lord Mark's, his eyes and voice, his overall demeanor.

For a moment, he made her wonder if she was going to be afraid; for a full minute, she distinctly felt fear wash over her. There they were again, certainly: Susie's introduction to Mrs. Lowder had been their inside joke, but in that gaiety, they had pressed an electric bell that continued to ring. While she sat there, she actually heard the loud ringing in her ears, and she wondered why the others didn't notice it.

Translation

For a moment, he made her question whether she would be afraid; for a full minute, she distinctly felt fear wash over her. There they were again, certainly: Susie's introduction to Mrs. Lowder had been their private joke, but in that gaiety, they had pressed an electric bell that continued to ring. While she sat there, she actually heard the loud ringing in her ears, and she wondered why the others didn't notice it.

They didn't stare, they didn't smile, and the fear she felt was just her own wish to stop it. That fear subsided, as if the alarm itself had ceased. She seemed to see, in a quick, though controlled flash, that she had two options: to leave London first thing in the morning, or to do nothing at all. Well, she would do nothing at all; she was already doing it; even more, she had already done it, and her opportunity was lost.

Translation

They didn't stare, they didn't smile, and the fear she felt was just her own desire to end it. The fear lessened, as though the alarm had been turned off. In a swift, controlled burst, she seemed to realize she had two choices: leave London first thing in the morning, or do absolutely nothing. She would do nothing; she was already doing it; in fact, she'd already done it, and her chance was gone.

She gave up – she had the strangest feeling of making that decision right then and there. She had turned a corner before she spoke again with Lord Mark. Without expression, but intensely significant, he answered the very question she'd suddenly put to Mrs. Stringham on the Brünig, in a way that no one else could have.

Translation

She surrendered. She had this uncanny sense that she was making that decision in that very moment. She had changed direction before she spoke with Lord Mark again. Without showing anything, but full of meaning, he responded to the exact question she'd suddenly put to Mrs. Stringham on the Brünig, in a way that only he could have.

Should she have it, whatever "it" was, she had wondered for a long time. "Ah, perhaps not," her neighbor seemed to reply; "therefore, don't you see? I'm the way." It was clear that he might be, despite his lack of flamboyance; the "way" was probably in that absence. The attractive young woman, whom she kept an eye on and who, she sensed, was also watching her—Mrs.

Translation

Should she accept it, whatever “it” might be? She’d been wondering that for a while. “Ah, probably not,” her neighbor seemed to be saying. “So, don’t you see? I’m the path.” It was obvious he could be, despite his lack of flash; the “path” was likely in that restraint. The appealing young woman, whom she observed and who, she felt, was also observing her—Mrs.

Lowder's striking niece—might also be the way, since she too lacked flamboyance, although they seemed to have little else in common, as far as one could tell. Yet how could one truly tell? What did one understand? And, for that matter, of what was she provisionally aware other than their being somehow connected in what they represented?

Translation

Mrs. Lowder's beautiful niece could be the way forward as well. She wasn't flashy either, even if they didn't seem to share much else. But how could anyone really know? What did she actually understand? And, considering everything, what did she tentatively grasp, aside from their shared connection through what they symbolized?

Kate Croy, refined but friendly, glanced at her as if she understood Lord Mark's effect on her. Would she have to consider them as duplicating, as intensifying by a shared understanding, the relationship she was entering?

Translation

Kate Croy, elegant but approachable, offered a look that seemed to acknowledge the impact Lord Mark had on her. If Kate understood this impact, what did she truly know about it, and to what degree had she experienced it herself? Did this suggest a particular dynamic between them? Would she be forced to view them as mirroring, amplifying through mutual comprehension, the relationship she was about to embrace?

Nothing was so strange as having to recognize, so quickly, in each of those momentary glimpses, the various signs of a relationship. And this unusual aspect itself, if she'd had more time to think about it, might well, might almost terrifyingly have suggested to her that her fate was to live life at a rapid pace. Oddly, it was a matter of the short term, with a correspondingly crowded awareness. These were immense excursions for the spirit of a young person at Mrs.

Translation

Nothing was as unsettling as having to register the signs of a relationship so rapidly, in each fleeting glance. If she'd had the luxury of contemplation, this unusual experience could have, perhaps frighteningly, suggested that her destiny was to live life at a breakneck speed. Curiously, it was about the immediate, creating a correspondingly dense awareness. These were vast expeditions for the spirit of a young person at Mrs.

Lowder's mere dinner-party; but what was so significant and so admonitory as the fact of their being possible? What could they have been but just a part, already, of the crowded consciousness? And it was just a part, likewise, that while plates were changed and dishes presented and periods in the banquet marked; while appearances insisted and phenomena multiplied and words reached her from here and there like plashes of a slow, thick tide; while Mrs. Lowder grew somehow more stout and more instituted and Susie, at her distance and in comparison, more thinly improvised and more different—different, that is, from every one and everything: it was just a part that while this process went forward our young lady alighted, came back, taking up her destiny again as if she had been able by a wave or two of her wings to place herself briefly in sight of an alternative to it.

Translation

Lowder's dinner party; but what was so telling, so instructive, as the very fact that this was happening at all? They could only be, already, a component of her teeming awareness. And it was just a component, too, that while plates were changed and courses served and the dinner progressed; while the spectacle of it all unfolded, details accumulating and words reached her from all sides like the lapping of a slow, viscous tide; while Mrs. Lowder became, somehow, more imposing and established and Susie, at a distance and by comparison, more tentatively formed, more unlike everyone and everything—it was just a component that while this was happening, our young woman returned to herself, embracing her destiny anew as though she'd briefly managed to glimpse an alternative, a different life, by a flutter of her wings.

Whatever it was it had showed in this brief interval as better than the alternative; and it now presented itself altogether in the image and in the place in which she had left it. The image was that of her being, as Lord Mark had declared, a success. This depended more or less of course on his idea of the thing—into which at present, however, she wouldn't go. But, renewing soon, she had asked him what he meant then that Mrs.

Translation

Whatever it was, it had appeared in this short time as preferable to the other option; and now it presented itself fully, in the image and the location where she'd left it. The image was that of her, as Lord Mark had said, being a success. This depended, of course, more or less on his definition of the term—which, for now, she'd avoid. But, remembering what she'd soon asked him, she wondered what he'd meant when Mrs.

Lowder would do with her, and he had replied that this might safely be left. "She'll get back," he pleasantly said, "her money." He could say it too—which was singular—without affecting her either as vulgar or as "nasty "; and he had soon explained himself by adding: "Nobody here, you know, does anything for nothing." These were extraordinary experiences for a young woman at Mrs. Lowder’s dinner party.

Translation

What Mrs. Lowder would do with her was a question, and he had responded that it could be safely disregarded. "She'll get back her money," he'd said with a pleasantness that was singular. He could say it without it sounding vulgar or "nasty," and he'd explained this by adding, "Nobody here, you know, does anything for nothing." These were strange experiences for a young woman at Mrs. Lowder's dinner party.

What was more telling than their possibility? They were clearly already a part of her complex thoughts. It was also true that as the courses changed and the meal progressed, as the social scene intensified, as events multiplied, and as conversations drifted to her like the slow rise of a dense tide—while Mrs. Lowder became increasingly imposing and established, and Susie, in comparison, seemed more provisional and different from everyone and everything—it was also true that during this process, our young lady had paused, returned, and resumed her life as if she had briefly glimpsed a different path.

Translation

What was more significant than the mere possibility of those thoughts? They were undeniably already woven into the fabric of her intricate thinking. As the dinner moved from course to course, as the social dynamics became more charged, as the evening's events unfolded, and as the various conversations flowed towards her like a slowly rising, weighty current—and as Mrs. Lowder's presence grew more and more commanding, established, and permanent, while Susie, by contrast, seemed more tentative and alien to her surroundings—during all of this, our young woman had, at some point, paused, retreated, and then recommenced her life as if she'd caught a fleeting glimpse of an alternate course.

Whatever that alternative was, it had appeared, in this brief moment, superior to her current circumstances, and now it returned, exactly as she had left it. This vision was of her being, as Lord Mark had said, a success. This depended on his definition, which she currently chose to ignore. But, soon after, she had asked him what Mrs.

Translation

Whatever that alternative was, it had, in this fleeting instant, seemed better than her present situation, and now it reappeared, exactly as before. This vision depicted her as a success, according to Lord Mark’s assessment. This assessment, she chose to disregard at the moment. But, shortly thereafter, she had asked him what Mrs.

Lowder would do with her, and he had replied that she shouldn't worry. "She'll get back her money," he said pleasantly. He could say it, oddly enough, without seeming vulgar or unpleasant. He then clarified, "No one here, you know, does anything for free."

Translation

Whatever Mrs. Lowder planned, he said she shouldn't fret. "She'll get her money back," he said, sounding quite agreeable. He managed this, strangely, without appearing crass or off-putting. He added, "You understand, no one here works without being compensated."

"Ah, if you mean that we shall reward her as hard as ever we can, nothing is more certain. But she's an idealist," Milly continued, "and idealists, in the long run, I think, don't feel that they lose." Lord Mark seemed, within the limits of his enthusiasm, to find this charming. "Ah, she strikes you as an idealist?"

Translation

"Ah, if you mean that we'll reward her as handsomely as possible, nothing is more certain. But she's an idealist," Milly continued, "and idealists, in the long run, I think, don't feel that they lose." Lord Mark seemed, within the limits of his enthusiasm, to find this charming. "Ah, she strikes you as an idealist?"

"She idealises us, my friend and me, absolutely. She sees us in a light," said Milly. "That's all I've got to hold on by. So don't deprive me of it."

Translation

"She idealizes us, absolutely, my friend and me. She sees us in a certain light," Milly said. "That's the only thing I have to hold onto. So, please, don't take it away from me."

"I wouldn't for the world. But do you think," he continued as if it were suddenly important for him—"do you think she sees me in a light?" She neglected his question for a little, partly because her attention attached itself more and more to the handsome girl, partly because, placed so near their hostess, she wished not to show as discussing her too freely. Mrs.

Translation

"I wouldn't dream of it. But do you think," he went on, as if this had just become crucial to him, "do you think she sees me a certain way?" She didn't respond to his question for a moment, in part because her focus was increasingly on the attractive girl, and in part because, positioned so close to their hostess, she didn't want to seem as though she was gossiping about her. Mrs.

Lowder, it was true, steering in the other quarter a course in which she called at subjects as if they were islets in an archipelago, continued to allow them their ease, and Kate Croy, at the same time, steadily revealed herself as interesting. Milly in fact found, of a sudden, her ease—found it all—as she bethought herself that what Mrs. Lowder was really arranging for was a report on her quality and, as perhaps might be said, her value from Lord Mark. She wished him, the wonderful lady, to have no pretext for not knowing what he thought of Miss Theale.

Translation

Translation

"She sees us a certain way," Milly said. "That's all I have left to cling to. So please, don't take it from me." "I wouldn't dream of it."

But do you think," he continued, as if it suddenly became crucial to know—"do you think she sees me in a favorable light?" She set aside his question for a moment, partly because her attention was increasingly focused on the beautiful girl, and partly because, being so close to their hostess, she didn't want to seem as though she was gossiping about her. Mrs. Lowder, it was true, was navigating the conversation in a way that she brought up subjects as though they were islands in a chain, and continued to allow them to converse freely.

Translation

"But do you think," he went on, as if this was suddenly vital, "do you think she actually likes me?" She paused, partly because she was distracted by the pretty girl, and partly because she didn't want to appear to be talking behind the hostess's back, being so close to her. Mrs. Lowder, it was true, was managing the conversation in such a way that she'd introduce topics like islands in a chain, while letting them talk freely.

Kate Croy, at the same time, was steadily revealing herself to be intriguing. In fact, Milly suddenly felt at ease—understood everything—as she realized that what Mrs. Lowder was truly orchestrating was a report on her character and, perhaps, her worth, from Lord Mark. She wanted him, the extraordinary woman, to have no excuse for not knowing what he thought of Miss Theale.

Translation

At the same time, Kate Croy was steadily proving herself to be an enigma. In fact, Milly suddenly felt at ease—everything clicked into place—as she realized that Mrs. Lowder was actually engineering a character assessment, and perhaps a valuation, from Lord Mark. The remarkable woman wanted him to have no excuse for remaining ignorant of his opinion of Miss Theale.

Why his opinion was so important remained to be seen; but it was this understanding, in any case, that now determined Milly's response. "No. She knows you. She probably has good reason to.

Translation

The reason his opinion mattered wasn't yet clear, but this realization, in any case, shaped Milly's reaction. "No. She knows you. She probably has good reason to."

And all of you, here, know each other—I can see that—to the extent that you know anything. You know what you're accustomed to, and it's your being accustomed to it—that, and that alone—that defines you. But there are things you don't know." He took it in as if it might fairly, to do him justice, be a point.

Translation

And you all know each other—I can see that—to the extent that anyone knows anything. You're familiar with what you're used to, and it's that familiarity, and that alone, that defines you. But there are things you don't know." He considered that, as if that might be, to be fair, a valid point.

"Things that I don't—with all the pains I take and the way I've run about the world to leave nothing unlearned?" Milly thought, and it was perhaps the very truth of his claim—its not being negligible—that sharpened her impatience and thereby her wit. "You're blasé, but you're not enlightened. You're familiar with everything, but conscious, really of nothing.

Translation

"Things I don't—with all the effort I expend and the way I've traveled the world, leaving no stone unturned?" Milly wondered, and perhaps the very truth of his statement—that it couldn't be dismissed—was what heightened her agitation and, consequently, her sharp tongue. "You're jaded, but you're not enlightened. You know everything, but you're truly aware of nothing."

What I mean is that you've no imagination." Lord Mark, at this, threw back his head, ranging with his eyes the opposite side of the room and showing himself at last so much more completely as diverted that it fairly attracted their hostess's notice. Mrs. Lowder, however, only smiled on Milly for a sign that something racy was what she had expected, and resumed, with a splash of her screw, her cruise among the islands.

Translation

"What I'm saying is, you lack imagination." At this, Lord Mark threw back his head, his gaze sweeping across the room. He seemed so amused, it actually caught the attention of their hostess. Mrs. Lowder simply smiled at Milly, as if to indicate she'd anticipated some sort of playful remark, and then, with a flourish of her pen, continued her perusal of the islands.

"Oh, I've heard that," the young man replied, "before!" He considered her statement as if it might, in fairness, be a valid point. "Things that I don't—despite all my efforts and the journeys I've taken across the world to learn everything?" Milly pondered this, and it was likely the truth of his statement—its undeniable nature—that fueled her irritation and her sharp intellect.

Translation

"Oh, I've heard that one before," the young man said. He paused, as if considering her words were a fair point. "Things that I don't—despite my best efforts and the journeys I've made across the world to learn everything?" Milly thought about this, and it was likely the truth in his statement—the way it couldn't be denied—that made her feel annoyed and sharpened her mind.

"You're jaded, but you're not insightful. You're acquainted with everything, but truly aware of nothing. What I mean is, you lack imagination." Lord Mark reacted by tilting his head back, his gaze sweeping across the far side of the room.

Translation

"You're cynical, but you're not perceptive. You know about everything, but understand nothing. What I'm saying is, you have no imagination." Lord Mark responded by throwing his head back, his eyes moving across the opposite side of the room.

He appeared so thoroughly amused that it finally caught their hostess's attention. Mrs. Lowder merely smiled at Milly, as if confirming her expectation of something amusing, and resumed her perusal of the room. "Oh, I've heard that before," the young man replied.

Translation

He seemed so thoroughly amused that it finally caught their hostess's attention. Mrs. Lowder simply smiled at Milly, as if confirming her expectation of something amusing, and resumed her perusal of the room. "Oh, I've heard that before," the young man replied.

"There it is then. You've heard everything before. You've heard me of course before, in my country, often enough." "Oh, never too often," he protested; "I'm sure I hope I shall still hear you again and again."

Translation

"So there it is. You've heard it all before. You've certainly heard me before, in my country, often enough."

"Oh, never too often," he protested. "I hope I'll keep hearing you over and over."

"But what good then has it done you?" the girl went on as if now frankly to amuse him. "Oh, you'll see when you know me." "But, most assuredly, I shall never know you." "Then that will be exactly," he laughed, "the good!"

Translation

"But what good has it done you, then?" the girl continued, as if simply to amuse him. "Oh, you'll see when you know me." "But, most certainly, I will never know you." "Then that will be exactly," he laughed, "the good!"

If it established thus that they couldn't, or Wouldn't, mix, why, none the less, did Milly feel, through it, a perverse quickening of the relation to which she had been, in spite of herself, appointed? What queerer consequence of their not mixing than their talking—for it was what they had arrived at—almost intimately? She wished to get away from him, or indeed, much rather, away from herself so far as she was present to him. She saw already—wonderful creature, after all, herself too—that there would be a good deal more of him to come for her, and that the special sign of their intercourse would be to keep herself out of the question.

Translation

If it was confirmed that they couldn't, or wouldn't, get involved, then why did Milly still feel a strange intensification of the connection that she'd been assigned to, despite herself? What was more odd than their not mixing, except that they were talking—which was what they'd gotten to—in a manner that was almost intimate? She wanted to escape him, or rather, to escape herself insofar as she was in his presence. She saw already—a wonderful creature, herself, after all—that there would be a lot more of him to come for her, and that the unique feature of their interactions would be to leave herself out of the equation.

Everything else might come in—only never that; and with such an arrangement they might even go far. This in fact might quite have begun, on the spot, with her returning again to the topic of the handsome girl. If she was to keep herself out she could naturally best do so by putting in somebody else. She accordingly put in Kate Croy, being ready to that extent—as she was not at all afraid for her—to sacrifice her if necessary.

Translation

Everything else could enter the picture—except that. With such an arrangement, they could potentially go far. Indeed, this might have begun right then and there, with her returning to the subject of the handsome girl. If she was to exclude herself, she could best do so by introducing someone else. Accordingly, she introduced Kate Croy, prepared to that extent—as she had no fear for her—to sacrifice her if necessary.

Lord Mark himself, for that matter, had made it easy by saying a little while before that no one among them did anything for nothing. "What then"—she was aware of being abrupt—"does Miss Croy, if she's so interested, do it for? What has she to gain by her lovely welcome? Look at her now!" Milly broke out with characteristic freedom of praise, though pulling herself up also with a compunctious "Oh!" as the direction thus given to their eyes happened to coincide with a turn of Kate's face to them.

Translation

Lord Mark himself, by the way, had made things simple when he'd mentioned just a little earlier that nobody in their circle did anything without some personal gain. "So then"—she knew she was being blunt—"what does Miss Croy, if she's so interested, do it for? What's she hoping to get from her gracious hospitality? Just look at her now!" Milly burst out in a moment of unrestrained admiration, though she immediately checked herself with a guilty "Oh!" as the direction of their gaze happened to land on Kate's face at that very instant.

All she had meant to do was to insist that this face was fine; but what she had in fact done was to renew again her effect of showing herself to its possessor as conjoined with Lord Mark for some interested view of it. He had, however, promptly met her question. So, there it is. You've heard this all before.

She'd only intended to say that Kate's face was beautiful. Instead, she'd inadvertently reinforced the impression that she and Lord Mark were somehow in league, each with their own ulterior motives for appreciating it. "You've heard me, naturally, in my own country, many times."

"You'll see when you get to know me."

"But, absolutely, I'll never know you."

If it was established that they couldn't, or wouldn't, connect, then, despite that, why did Milly feel a strange, rapid intensification of their relationship, a relationship she'd been assigned to despite herself?

What stranger result of their not connecting than their talking—because that's what it had become—almost intimately? She wanted to escape from him, or, really, much more, away from herself, so far as she was present for him. Translation

What more peculiar outcome of their disconnection than their conversations, which was essentially what it had become, almost intimate? She wanted to get away from him, or, truthfully, even more, away from herself, so far as she was present in his perception. She already saw—a remarkable person, she was, after all—that he would be a more permanent fixture in her life, and that the fundamental aspect of their dynamic would be her own absence from it. Everything else could be allowed—except herself; and with that agreement, they might even go far.

This, in fact, might have already begun, right there, with her returning to the topic of the beautiful girl. If she was to exclude herself, she could best do so by bringing someone else in. Accordingly, she introduced Kate Croy, being willing to that extent—as she wasn't at all concerned about her—to sacrifice her if necessary. Lord Mark himself, for that matter, had made it easy by saying a little while before that no one among them did anything for nothing.

Translation

This might have already started, in fact, right then and there, with her circling back to the subject of the beautiful girl. If she was to remove herself, the best way to do so would be by introducing someone else. So, she brought up Kate Croy, prepared to go that far—since she didn't care about Kate at all—and sacrifice her if needed. Lord Mark, for that matter, had made it easier by saying not long before that nobody among them did anything for free.

"So then,"—she knew she was being blunt—"what does Miss Croy do it for, if she's so interested? What does she gain from her lovely welcome? Look at her now!" Milly exclaimed with her usual open enthusiasm, though she also stopped herself with a quick "Oh!" as the direction of their gaze happened to align with Kate's turning her face toward them. All she'd meant to do was emphasize that this face was lovely; but what she'd actually done was reinforce her own effect of appearing to its owner as being linked with Lord Mark for some selfish purpose.

Translation

"So," she said, aware she was being direct, "what's Miss Croy getting out of this, if she's so interested? What's she getting out of being so welcoming? Look at her!" Milly said, her usual openness on display. She quickly caught herself with an "Oh!" as their eyes happened to meet Kate's, who was turning her face toward them. She'd simply meant to highlight how beautiful Kate's face was, but instead, she'd only reinforced the impression that she, Milly, was somehow connected with Lord Mark and his self-serving motives, as far as Kate was concerned.

He, however, had immediately addressed her question. "To gain? Why, your acquaintance." "Well, what's my acquaintance to her?

Translation

He answered her question without hesitation. "To gain? Why, your friendship." "But what good is my friendship to her?"

She can care for me—she must feel that—only by being sorry for me; and that's why she's lovely: to be already willing to take the trouble to be. It's the height of the disinterested." There were more things in this than one that Lord Mark might have taken up; but in a minute he had made his choice. "Ah then, I'm nowhere, for I'm afraid I'm not sorry for you in the least.

Translation

"She can care about me, she has to—only through pity. That's what makes her so wonderful: she's already prepared to put herself out. It's the purest form of selflessness." Lord Mark could have responded to any number of things he said, but he picked one right away.

She gets it," Milly said, "she's better than all of you. She's beautiful." He finally seemed taken aback by this—by the point the girl was making; which she returned to even after a distraction created by a dish brought between them. "Beautiful in character, I see.

"Is she, though? Tell me about her." Milly thought. "But you've known her longer than I have, haven't you?"

Translation

"You haven't seen her? I can't figure her out. It's hopeless. I've already failed."

And I assure you I really should like to." His assurance had in fact for his companion a positive suggestion of sincerity; he affected her as now saying something that he felt; and she was the more struck with it as she was still conscious of the failure even of curiosity he had just shown in respect to herself. She had meant something—though indeed for herself almost only—in speaking of their friend's natural pity; it had been a note, doubtless, of questionable taste, but it had quavered out in spite of her; and he had not so much as cared to inquire "Why 'natural'?" Not that it wasn't really much better for her that he shouldn't: explanations would in truth have taken her much too far. Only she now perceived that, in comparison, her word about this other person really "drew" him; and there were things in that, probably, many things, as to which she would learn more and which glimmered there already as part and parcel of that larger "real" with which, in her new situation, she was to be beguiled. It was in fact at the very moment, this element, not absent from what Lord Mark was further saying.

Translation

"And I assure you I really should like to," he said. His affirmation actually seemed sincere to her, and his words made her believe that he truly meant what he was saying. She was particularly affected by this because she was still aware of his lack of interest in her. She had tried to say something, mostly to herself, when she spoke of their friend's inherent compassion. It was a questionable choice of words, but she couldn't help it. He hadn't even bothered to ask, "Why 'inherent'?" Not that it was better if he had. Explanations would have taken her too far. She realized that, in contrast, her mention of this other person really captivated him, and there were probably many things to be learned from that. They were already becoming part of the "real" world that would entice her in her new circumstances. In fact, this element was present in what Lord Mark was saying.

"So you're wrong, you see, as to our knowing all about each other. There are cases where we break down. I at any rate give her up—up, that is, to you. You must do her for me—tell me, I mean, when you know more.

Translation

"So, you're mistaken, you see, in thinking we know everything about each other. There are times when we fail. I, for one, surrender her—surrender her, that is, to you. You must deal with her for me—tell me, I mean, when you find out more."

You'll notice," he pleasantly wound up, "that I've confidence in you." He seemed surprised, finally, by what the girl said. She returned to it, even after they were distracted by a dish being served. "Beautiful character, I see.

Translation

"You'll observe," he concluded amiably, "that I trust you." He appeared, at last, surprised by her words. She returned to the topic, even after they were interrupted by the arrival of a dish. "A beautiful character, I see."

Translation

"You haven't met her?" "No. I've messed it up with her. It's hopeless. I don't get her."

Translation

"And I promise, I really do." Milly saw he meant it; he was being sincere. She noticed it even more because, just before, he hadn't seemed interested in her at all. When she mentioned their friend's natural compassion, she'd mostly been talking to herself; it was an inappropriate comment, maybe, but she couldn't help it. He hadn't even asked, "Why 'natural'?" Translation

Now she understood her comments regarding their mutual acquaintance had caught his interest; this likely signified something, multiple things, which she would eventually understand, already suggesting the greater "reality" meant to captivate her in this new life. Indeed, this aspect was evident in Lord Mark's words. "Therefore, you're incorrect to presume we possess complete knowledge of each other. There are occasions when we fall short."

I, for one, give up on her—hand her over to you. You must describe her to me—tell me, when you know more. You'll notice," he concluded pleasantly, "that I trust you." "Why shouldn't you have?" Milly asked, observing in this, as she thought, a fine, though, for such a man, a surprisingly artless, fatuity.

Translation

I, for one, am done with her—I hand her over to you. You must describe her to me—tell me what you learn. You'll see," he concluded amiably, "that I trust you." "Why wouldn't you?" Milly asked, perceiving in this, she thought, a fine, though, for such a man, a surprisingly naive, complacency.

It was as if there might have been a question of her falsifying for the sake of her own show—that is of her honesty not being proof against her desire to keep well with him herself. She didn't, none the less, otherwise protest against his remark; there was something else she was occupied in seeing. It was the handsome girl alone, one of his own species and his own society, who had made him feel uncertain; of his certainties about a mere little American, a cheap exotic, imported almost wholesale, and whose habitat, with its conditions of climate, growth, and cultivation, its immense profusion, but its few varieties and thin development, he was perfectly satisfied. The marvel was, too, that Milly understood his satisfaction—feeling that she expressed the truth in presently saying: "Of course; I make out that she must be difficult; just as I see that I myself must be easy." And that was what, for all the rest of this occasion, remained with her—as the most interesting thing that could remain.

Translation

It was as if there could have been a suspicion that she might be dishonest just to put on a good show—that is, that her integrity wasn't strong enough to resist the temptation to stay on his good side. Nevertheless, she didn't otherwise object to his comment; she was busy observing something else. It was the beautiful young woman alone, someone of his own kind and social circle, who had made him feel unsure; he had no doubts about a mere little American, a cheap, foreign import, almost mass-produced, whose environment—its climate, conditions for growth, and development—with its immense abundance but limited variety and thinness, he was completely content with. The surprising thing was that Milly understood his satisfaction—feeling that she was stating the truth when she said, "Of course; I can see that she must be difficult, just as I see that I myself must be easy." And that was what stayed with her, for the rest of this conversation—as the most compelling thing to contemplate.

She was more and more content herself to be easy; she would have been resigned, even had it been brought straighter home to her, to passing for a cheap exotic. Provisionally, at any rate, that protected her wish to keep herself, with Lord Mark, in abeyance. They had all affected her as inevitably knowing each other, and if the handsome girl's place among them was something even their initiation couldn't deal with—why, then, she would indeed be a quantity. "Why shouldn't you have?" Milly asked.

Translation

She was increasingly satisfied to be the "easy" one; she would have accepted it, even if it had been made explicitly clear to her, to be perceived as a cheap foreigner. At least for the time being, that protected her desire to remain uncommitted with Lord Mark. They had all seemed to know each other intimately, and if the beautiful girl's place among them was something that even their connections couldn't resolve—well, then she would be something indeed. "Why shouldn't you have?" Milly asked.

She detected, what she thought was a charmingly naive vanity in him, surprising for a man like him. It was as if there was a possibility she would have lied to maintain her image—that her integrity wouldn't withstand her desire to stay on his good side. Nevertheless, she didn't object to his comment; she was busy noticing something else. It was the beautiful woman, a member of his own social circle, who had made him feel unsure.

Translation

She sensed a touch of charming, almost childlike vanity in him, which seemed odd for a man of his standing. It was as though he suspected she might lie to protect her own reputation—that her principles weren't strong enough to resist the urge to stay in his good graces. However, she didn't challenge his statement, her attention fixed on something else entirely. It was the beautiful woman, a familiar face from his own world, who had clearly rattled him.

He was confident when it came to a simple American like herself, a cheap import, almost mass-produced. He was completely satisfied with her environment, its climate, how she developed, her vast numbers, her limited varieties, and her underdeveloped nature. The amazing thing was, Milly understood his satisfaction. She expressed the truth by saying, "Of course; I gather that she must be difficult; while I know I'm easy." That was what she focused on for the rest of their time together—it was the most intriguing aspect.

Translation

He was certain of himself with a woman like her, an American, easily acquired, practically a product of a factory. He approved of her world, its weather, her growth, her abundance, her lack of variation, and her simplicity. What was remarkable was that Milly understood his satisfaction. She spoke the truth when she said, "Naturally; I assume she's complicated; whereas I am simple." This became her primary interest for the remainder of their time together, the most captivating element of it all.

She grew more comfortable being the "easy" one; she would have accepted, even if she had been told directly, that she was seen as a cheap exotic. At least for now, that protected her desire to keep her feelings about Lord Mark hidden. They all seemed to know each other, and if the beautiful woman's role was something even their inner circle couldn't grasp—then she would indeed be significant.

Translation

She grew accustomed to being the "easy" one. She would have accepted, even if told outright, that she was viewed as a cheap, foreign novelty. At least for the time being, that protected her wish to conceal her feelings for Lord Mark. They all seemed to know one another, and if the beautiful woman's role was something even their inner circle couldn't decipher, then she would indeed be of importance.

Chapter 8

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

An American pair, Milly Theale and her companion Mrs. Stringham (Susie), frequently remark to each other that they have only themselves to thank for their situation. Mrs. Stringham enjoys the success of her appeal to her old schoolmate, Mrs. Lowder (Maud Manningham), while Milly spends time with Mrs. Lowder's niece, Kate Croy.

For the week following a dinner party, Milly and Kate explore London's shops, museums, and sights together, while their older companions, Mrs. Stringham and Mrs. Lowder, also spend time together. Kate tells Milly about her difficult family situation. Milly tells Mrs. Stringham she believes Kate has a secret trouble and is using their new friendship as a distraction. During their outings, Milly gives Kate several valuable gifts, prompting Kate to say she must avoid shops to prevent Milly from buying her everything.

By the end of the week, Milly asks Kate for information about a man named Lord Mark and requests to be taken to visit a Mrs. Condrip. Kate explains that Lord Mark's reputation rests on his future potential, which her Aunt Maud believes in, though he has few actual accomplishments. Kate describes London society as a system where people use one another but can still be friends. She tells Milly that she, too, is part of her aunt's system and is trying to figure out what her aunt expects from her. Milly expresses her delight at being taken in hand by Mrs. Lowder.

Later, Milly observes to Kate that Mrs. Stringham should have bored Mrs. Lowder. Kate agrees, and Milly notices that Kate herself finds Mrs. Stringham boring. This bothers Milly until she concludes that Kate has a brutal quality, which she finds new and intriguing.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

This is an excellent and complex piece of text, characteristic of the prose of Henry James, likely from his novel *The Wings of the Dove*. The writing is dense, psychologically intricate, and deeply focused on the interior lives of its characters. A literary analysis reveals a rich tapestry of themes, nuanced character development, and sophisticated literary techniques.

### **Major Themes**

#### 1. The Old World vs. The New World: European Experience and American Innocence This classic Jamesian theme is immediately apparent. The "slightly gasping American pair," Milly Theale and her companion Mrs. Susan Shepherd Stringham, are thrust into the labyrinthine social world of London. This world is described as a force of nature—an "incalculable strength of a wave that was actually holding them aloft and that would naturally dash them wherever it liked."

* **American Perspective:** The Americans perceive London with a mixture of awe, confusion, and romanticism. Mrs. Stringham sees it as "vast, obscure, lurid," representing a "world" that "had never yet boldly crossed to Boston." They are "pilgrims," suggesting a naive quest in a land of ancient, complex codes. * **European Reality:** London society, as embodied by Mrs. Lowder and Kate Croy, operates on a different logic. It is a transactional, pragmatic, and potentially dangerous system. Kate explains that everyone "made the sharpest possible bargain," where "the worker in one connection was the worked in another." This is a world of "precautions" and "dangers" that the Americans are only beginning to comprehend.

#### 2. Appearance vs. Reality and the Nature of Perception The narrative is obsessed with how characters perceive, or "take," one another. Reality is filtered through layers of interpretation, imagination, and social performance.

* **The "Harmonising Blur":** The initial impression of London society is softened by a "fine floating gold-dust," a beautiful haze that obscures the "strong and deep" forms and colours behind it. This metaphor suggests that the surface charm of this world conceals a more formidable and perhaps darker reality. * **Literary Imagination:** Milly and Mrs. Stringham constantly frame their experiences in literary or fantastical terms. Milly is the "wandering princess," and Kate is the "heroine" of a "strong story." This act of framing is a way of making sense of an overwhelming reality, but it also risks misinterpretation. Milly imagines the "London girl" from *Punch* and popular fiction, only to find Kate is "nicer" but no less complex. * **Unspoken Knowledge:** Much of the tension comes from what is unsaid. Kate has a "secret, some smothered trouble," and a "latent impression" that Milly is "not, after all, a person to change places...with." This hints at a fundamental, perhaps tragic, difference between them that lies beneath their friendly surface.

#### 3. Power, Wealth, and Social Transaction The text subtly but insistently explores the mechanics of social power, which is inextricably linked to money and status.

* **Milly's Power:** Milly's immense wealth gives her an "immense" range and a "high happiness of her companion's liberty." She has "to ask nobody for anything." This financial power is the source of her princess-like status, but it also makes her an object of interest in London's transactional society. Kate notes that Milly would "pay a hundred per cent.—and even to the end, doubtless, through the nose." * **The London System:** Kate's description of London as a place of "working and of being worked" is a central thesis of the excerpt. Relationships are bargains. Mrs. Lowder "takes up" people like Lord Mark and Kate herself, expecting a return on her social investment. This pragmatic view contrasts sharply with the Americans' more sentimental understanding of relationships.

### **Character Developments**

#### Milly Theale Milly is presented as the archetypal American heiress: immensely rich, innocent, and imaginative, but also marked by a subtle fragility ("her white face"). Her key development in this passage is her dawning awareness of the world she has entered. She moves from seeing Kate as a fictional "heroine" to suspecting her "secret" and sensing the complex web of obligations she lives within. She begins to see herself through Kate’s eyes, borrowing Kate’s "view of her state" and accepting her role as a "practical princess." This suggests a passive quality, a willingness to be defined by others, which could be a source of vulnerability.

#### Susan Shepherd Stringham (Susie) As Milly's chaperone, Mrs. Stringham acts as a primary narrative consciousness. She is the romantic intellectual, initially seeing the trip as a source of "literary material." However, the reality of Mrs. Lowder's world overwhelms her; the sense of it as a story "quite dropped from her." She is both "carried away" by the thrill and burdened by a "bad conscience," recognizing the moral complexities she is facing for the first time. Her perception of Mrs. Lowder as a "projectile" or "fortress"—spacious because she is "full"—is a brilliant psychological insight that contrasts European substance with a perceived American emptiness.

#### Kate Croy Kate is the sophisticated, worldly "London girl." She is described as handsome and charming, but her defining characteristic is a pragmatic and defensive nature. Her dismissal of Susie reveals a hardness; Milly perceives her as "the least bit brutal." This brutality is not aggressive but a "habit of anticipation," a survival instinct learned in a world of "dangers." She understands the transactional nature of her society perfectly and is trying to figure out what she has "to give" in order to get what she needs. Her fascination with Milly is genuine, yet it is also analytical and colored by her awareness of Milly's immense financial power and freedom.

#### Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud) Mrs. Lowder is a force of nature. Described in metaphors of immense size and contained power ("capacious receptacle," "great slumbering fortress"), she is a woman of action, not introspection. For her, the "why" of an action is unimportant, like "vanilla or the nutmeg" in a pudding. She is the master manipulator of the London social system, expertly "working" people and situations to her advantage. Yet, her genuine affection for the seemingly insignificant Susie is a "marvel" that mystifies Milly, suggesting a hidden depth of sentiment beneath her formidable exterior.

### **Major Literary Ideas and Techniques**

* **Psychological Realism:** The drama is almost entirely internal. The narrative prioritizes the characters' thoughts, interpretations, and shifting perceptions over external events. The plot advances through dialogue and observation, revealing the complex inner machinery of each character. * **Dense, Intricate Prose:** The author's style is a crucial part of the novel's meaning. The long, winding sentences, full of qualifying clauses and abstract nouns, mirror the complexity of the social and psychological landscape the characters are navigating. The prose forces the reader to slow down and untangle meaning, just as the characters must do in their interactions. * **Shifting Point of View:** The narrative consciousness flows between characters, primarily resting with Mrs. Stringham and Milly. This limited third-person perspective immerses the reader in their American point of view, making the discoveries about London society feel immediate and profound. We learn about Kate and Mrs. Lowder through the Americans' attempts to understand them. * **Metaphor and Symbolism:** The text is rich with figurative language that gives abstract social dynamics a concrete form. The "wave," the "gold-dust," Milly as a "princess," and Mrs. Lowder as a "fortress" are not mere decorations but essential tools for understanding the characters' experiences and the thematic core of the work.

In conclusion, this passage is a masterful introduction to a world of immense social and psychological complexity. Through the juxtaposition of American innocence and European experience, it establishes the central conflicts and relationships that will drive the narrative, all while showcasing a literary style that is as challenging as it is rewarding.

That sense of quantities, separate or mixed, was indeed doubtless what most prevailed at first for our slightly gasping American pair; it found utterance for them in their frequent remark to each other that they had no one but themselves to thank. It dropped from Milly more than once that if she had ever known it was so easy—! though her exclamation mostly ended without completing her idea. This, however, was a trifle to Mrs.

Translation

That awareness of quantities, whether separate or combined, was certainly the dominant feeling at first for our slightly bewildered American pair; it manifested itself in their frequent remark to each other that they had only themselves to blame. Milly let slip more than once that if she had only known it was so easy—! though her exclamation usually trailed off unfinished. However, this was a minor issue for Mrs.

Stringham, who cared little whether she meant that in this case she would have come sooner. She couldn't have come sooner, and she perhaps, on the contrary, meant—for it would have been like her—that she wouldn't have come at all; why it was so easy being at any rate a matter as to which her companion had begun quickly to pick up views. Susie kept some of these lights for the present to herself, since, freely communicated, they might have been a little disturbing; with which, moreover, the quantities that we speak of as surrounding the two ladies were, in many cases, quantities of things—and of other things—to talk about. Their immediate lesson, accordingly, was that they just had been caught up by the incalculable strength of a wave that was actually holding them aloft and that would naturally dash them wherever it liked.

Translation

Stringham didn't care much whether Milly meant she would have arrived earlier. She couldn't have, and in fact she might have meant—as was typical for her—that she wouldn't have come at all. How easy it was was something her friend was starting to form opinions about. Susie kept some of these opinions to herself for the time being, because sharing them might be unsettling. Additionally, the things that surrounded the two women were, in many cases, things—and other things—to discuss. Their immediate lesson, therefore, was that they'd simply been caught by the immense power of a wave that was currently holding them up and would naturally carry them wherever it wanted.

They meanwhile, we hasten to add, make the best of their precarious position, and if Milly had had no other help for it she would have found not a little in the sight of Susan Shepherd's state. The girl had had nothing to say to her, for three days, about the "success" announced by Lord Mark—which they saw, besides, otherwise established; she was too taken up, too touched, by Susie's own exaltation. Susie glowed in the light of her justified faith; everything had happened that she had been acute enough to think least probable; she had appealed to a possible delicacy in Maud Manningham—a delicacy, mind you, but barely possible—and her appeal had been met in a way that was an honour to human nature. This proved sensibility of the lady of Lancaster Gate performed verily, for both our friends, during these first days, the office of a fine floating gold-dust, something that threw over the prospect a harmonising blur.

Translation

They, meanwhile, we must add, are making the best of their precarious situation, and if Milly had no other option, she would have found a great deal in the sight of Susan Shepherd’s condition. The girl hadn’t mentioned the “success” Lord Mark announced to her for three days—a success they saw as dubious, anyway; she was too preoccupied, too moved by Susie’s own elation. Susie was radiant, alight with her vindicated faith; everything had occurred that she’d been astute enough to deem the least likely; she’d appealed to a potential sensitivity in Maud Manningham—a sensitivity, mark you, though barely plausible—and her appeal had been answered in a manner that honored human nature. This demonstrated sensitivity from the woman of Lancaster Gate truly acted, for our two friends, during those first few days, as a kind of fine, floating gold dust, something that cast a harmonizing haze over the landscape.

The forms, the colours behind it were strong and deep—we have seen how they already stood out for Milly; but nothing, comparatively, had had so much of the dignity of truth as the fact of Maud's fidelity to a sentiment. That was what Susie was proud of, much more than of her great place in the world, which she was moreover conscious of not as yet wholly measuring. That was what was more vivid even than her being—in senses more worldly and in fact almost in the degree of a revelation—English and distinct and positive, with almost no inward, but with the finest outward resonance. That sense of vastness, whether in separate parts or as a whole, was undoubtedly what overwhelmed our slightly breathless American friends at first.

Translation

The shapes, the colors behind it were powerful and profound—we know how much they already meant to Milly; but nothing, in comparison, possessed as much of the dignity of truth as Maud's loyalty to a feeling. That was what Susie was proud of, more than her high status in the world, which she knew she hadn’t fully grasped yet. That was what was more real than her own self—in a way that was more worldly and nearly like a revelation—English and clear and certain, with almost no inner life, but with the most exquisite outward harmony. That sense of immensity, whether in individual aspects or as a whole, was surely what initially overwhelmed our slightly anxious American friends.

It found expression in their frequent comment to each other that they had only themselves to blame. Milly mentioned more than once that if she'd known it would be so easy—! though her exclamation usually trailed off before she finished her thought. This, however, was less significant to Mrs.

Translation

It manifested itself in their repeated assertions that they had only themselves to hold accountable. Milly remarked more than once that if she had known it would be so simple—! though her exclamation typically trailed off before she could complete the sentence. This, however, was less critical to Mrs.

Stringham, who didn't much care whether Milly meant she would have come sooner. She couldn't have come sooner, and she perhaps, on the contrary, meant—because it would be like her—that she wouldn't have come at all. As for why it was so easy, that was something her companion had begun to quickly understand. Susie kept some of these insights to herself for the moment, since, if freely shared, they might have been a bit unsettling.

Translation

Stringham wasn't overly concerned with whether Milly meant she would have arrived earlier. She couldn't have arrived earlier, and it was possible, conversely, that Milly meant—because it was in character—that she wouldn't have come at all. As for why things were so straightforward, that was something her companion was rapidly starting to grasp. Susie was keeping some of these insights to herself for the time being, because if she shared them openly, they might be a little disturbing.

Moreover, the vastness we're speaking of as surrounding the two ladies was, in many instances, a vastness of things—and of other matters—to discuss. Consequently, their immediate lesson was that they'd simply been caught up by the overwhelming force of a wave that was actually holding them aloft and would naturally carry them wherever it pleased. Meanwhile, we hasten to add, they made the most of their precarious situation, and if Milly had had nothing else to help her, she would have found plenty in the sight of Susan Shepherd's state. The girl hadn't mentioned the "success" announced by Lord Mark—which they also saw confirmed elsewhere—for three days.

Translation

Furthermore, the sense of vastness enveloping the two women was, in many cases, a vastness of topics and other things needing discussion. Hence, their immediate takeaway was that they'd been seized by a powerful wave that was actually buoying them, and would, naturally, take them wherever it wanted. In the meantime, we should add, they made the best of their precarious circumstances, and if Milly had nothing else to buoy her spirits, she would have found plenty in the sight of Susan Shepherd's condition. The girl hadn't mentioned the "success" announced by Lord Mark—which they'd also seen confirmed elsewhere—for three days.

She was too absorbed, too touched, by Susie's own elation. Susie glowed in the light of her vindicated belief; everything had happened that she'd been sharp enough to consider least likely; she had appealed to a possible sense of decency in Maud Manningham—a decency, mind you, that was barely possible—and her appeal had been answered in a way that honored human nature. This demonstrated sensitivity of the lady of Lancaster Gate truly acted, for both our friends, during these first days, like a beautiful, floating golden dust, something that cast a harmonizing blur over the landscape. The shapes, the colors behind it were strong and deep—we've seen how they already stood out for Milly; but nothing, comparatively, possessed as much of the dignity of truth as the fact of Maud's loyalty to a sentiment.

Translation

She was too consumed, too moved, by Susie's own joy. Susie shone with the light of her vindicated faith; everything had happened that she'd been astute enough to deem improbable; she'd appealed to a potential sense of decency in Maud Manningham—a decency, remember, that was barely plausible—and her appeal had been answered in a way that gave credit to human nature. This displayed sensitivity of the woman from Lancaster Gate actually functioned, for both of our friends, during these first few days, like a beautiful, floating golden dust, something that cast a harmonizing haze over the scenery. The forms, the colors behind it were powerful and profound—we've seen how they already stood out for Milly; but nothing, comparatively, possessed as much of the nobility of truth as the fact of Maud's devotion to a feeling.

That was what Susie was proud of, much more than of her high standing in the world, which she also realized she didn't yet fully grasp. That was what was more vivid, even than her being—in more worldly terms and almost as a revelation—English and clear and certain, with almost no internal complexities, but with the finest outward expression. Susan Shepherd's word for her, again and again, was that she was "large"; yet it was not exactly a case, as to the soul, of echoing chambers: she might have been likened rather to a capacious receptacle, originally perhaps loose, but now drawn as tightly as possible over its accumulated contents—a packed mass, for her American admirer, of curious detail. When the latter good lady, at home, had handsomely figured her friends as not small—which was the way she mostly figured them—there was a certain implication that they were spacious because they were empty.

Translation

That was what Susie was proud of, more than of her high status in the world, which she also realized she didn't yet completely understand. That was more vivid, even than her being—in more practical terms and almost as a revelation—English and clear and certain, with almost no internal complexities, but with the finest outward expression. Susan Shepherd's word for her, again and again, was that she was "large"; yet it was not exactly a case, as far as the soul was concerned, of echoing chambers: she might have been compared instead to a capacious receptacle, originally perhaps loose, but now drawn as tightly as possible over its accumulated contents—a packed mass, for her American admirer, of curious detail. When the latter good lady, at home, had generously pictured her friends as not small—which was how she usually pictured them—there was an implication that they were spacious because they were empty.

Mrs. Lowder, by a different law, was spacious because she was full, because she had something in common, even in repose, with a projectile, of great size, loaded and ready for use. That indeed, to Susie's romantic mind, announced itself as half the charm of their renewal—a charm as of sitting in springtime, during a long peace, on the daisied, grassy bank of some great slumbering fortress. True to her psychological instincts, certainly, Mrs.

Translation

Lowder was at the same time a presence, in the sense

that her image was perpetually renewed and

restored—she was, in other words, a force. It was in

this connection, and for the joy of it, that she had

made up her mind to "take" Susie.

Stringham had noted that the "sentiment" she rejoiced in on her old schoolmate's part was all a matter of action and movement, was not, save for the interweaving of a more frequent plump "dearest" than she would herself perhaps have used, a matter of much other embroidery. She brooded, with interest, on this further remark of race, feeling in her own spirit a different economy. The joy, for her, was to know why she acted—the reason was half the business; whereas with Mrs. Lowder there might have been no reason: "why" was the trivial seasoning-substance, the vanilla or the nutmeg, omittable from the nutritive pudding without spoiling it.

Translation

Stringham observed that the "sentiment" Mrs. Lowder found so delightful in her old schoolmate was entirely about action and momentum. Aside from an increased use of the word "dearest," a word she might not use herself, it lacked embellishment. Stringham pondered this distinction in their personalities with interest, sensing a different approach within herself. For Stringham, the pleasure was in understanding why she acted—the reason was half the equation. With Mrs. Lowder, there may have been no reason at all: "why" was a trivial addition, like vanilla or nutmeg, easily omitted from a nourishing pudding without ruining it.

Mrs. Lowder's desire was clearly sharp that their young companions should also prosper together; and Mrs. Stringham's account of it all to Milly, during the first days, was that when, at Lancaster Gate, she was not occupied in telling, as it were, about her, she was occupied in hearing much of the history of her hostess's brilliant niece. Susan Shepherd repeatedly described her as "large," but it wasn't as if her soul was hollow.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder clearly wanted her young friends to thrive together. Mrs. Stringham's description to Milly, in those first few days, was that when she wasn't occupied with, so to speak, sharing details about herself, she was hearing all about her hostess's brilliant niece. Susan Shepherd kept calling her "large," but it wasn't as if her soul was empty.

Instead, she resembled a vast container. Initially perhaps loose, it was now stretched taut over everything inside—a packed collection of intriguing details for her American admirer. When that woman at home complimented her friends by saying they weren't "small"—which was how she usually described them—it implied they were spacious because they were empty. Mrs.

Translation

Instead, she seemed like a massive vessel. It might have been somewhat yielding at first, but now it was stretched tight over everything within—a packed assortment of captivating details for her American admirer. When that woman back home praised her friends by saying they weren't "small"—which was her usual way of characterizing them—it meant they were roomy precisely because they were vacant. Mrs.

Lowder, however, was spacious in a different way: she was full. Even when she was still, she had something in common with a projectile, huge, loaded, and ready to be launched. That, in fact, seemed to Susie's romantic imagination to be half the appeal of their reunion—like sitting in springtime on the grassy, flower-covered bank of a massive fortress while it slumbered. True to her understanding of people, Mrs.

Translation

Lowder, however, was spacious in a different way: she was full. Even when she was still, she had something in common with a projectile, huge, loaded, and ready to be launched. That, in fact, seemed to Susie's romantic imagination to be half the appeal of their reunion—like sitting in springtime on the grassy, flower-covered bank of a massive fortress while it slumbered. True to her understanding of people, Mrs.

Stringham had noticed that the "feeling" her old friend displayed was all about doing things and being active. Except for the repeated use of the affectionate term "dearest," a term she herself wouldn't use as often, it wasn't about expressing much emotion. She considered this further difference between them with interest, feeling she was different. For her, the pleasure was in understanding the reasons behind her actions—knowing why was half the point.

Translation

Stringham had observed that her old friend's "feeling" was entirely focused on action and activity. Aside from the frequent use of the term "dearest," which Stringham herself wouldn't use as often, there wasn't much emotional expression. She contemplated this additional distinction between them with curiosity, feeling a sense of her own difference. For Stringham, the pleasure was in understanding the reasons behind her actions; knowing the "why" was half the battle.

With Mrs. Lowder, though, there might not be a reason: the "why" was just a small detail, like the vanilla or nutmeg in a pudding, not essential to its nourishment. Mrs. Lowder clearly wanted their young friends to do well together.

Translation

With Mrs. Lowder, however, the "why" might not even exist. The reasoning was a trivial thing, like the vanilla or nutmeg in a pudding, not a necessary part of the sustenance. Mrs. Lowder's desire was clearly for their young friends to succeed in their relationship.

Mrs. Stringham's explanation to Milly in the early days was that when Mrs. Lowder wasn't talking about her, she was listening to a great deal about her hostess's brilliant niece. They had plenty, on these lines, the two elder women, to give and to take, and it was even not quite clear to the pilgrim from Boston that what she should mainly have arranged for in London was not a series of thrills for herself.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham explained to Milly early on that when Mrs. Lowder wasn't talking about her, she was listening to a great deal about her hostess's brilliant niece. The two older women had plenty to share and exchange along those lines. In fact, it wasn't even quite clear to the visitor from Boston that she shouldn't have been arranging a series of thrilling experiences for herself during her time in London.

She had a bad conscience, indeed almost a sense of immorality, in having to recognise that she was, as she said, carried away. She laughed to Milly when she also said that she didn't know where it would end; and the principal of her uneasiness was that Mrs. Lowder's life bristled for her with elements that she was really having to look at for the first time. They represented, she believed, the world, the world that, as a consequence of the cold shoulder turned to it by the Pilgrim Fathers, had never yet boldly crossed to Boston—it would surely have sunk the stoutest Cunarder—and she couldn't pretend that she faced the prospect simply because Milly had had a caprice.

Translation

She felt guilty, almost as if she were behaving immorally, because she realized she was, as she put it, being swept away. She laughed to Milly when she added that she didn't know where it would stop. The main cause of her unease was that Mrs. Lowder's life was full of things she was genuinely forced to confront for the first time. She believed those things represented the world. That was the world that, as a result of the cold shoulder given to it by the Pilgrim Fathers, had never boldly sailed to Boston—it would have sunk even the most sturdy ship—and she couldn't pretend she was facing that prospect simply because Milly had a whim.
