She was in the act herself of having one, directed precisely to their present spectacle. She could but seek strength in the thought that she had never had one—or had never yielded to one, which came to the same thing—before. The sustaining sense of it all, moreover, as literary material—that quite dropped from her. She must wait, at any rate, she should see: it struck her, so far as she had got, as vast, obscure, lurid.

Translation

She was currently entertaining one herself, directed specifically at the scene before them. She could only find solace in the thought that she'd never had one—or had never surrendered to one, which amounted to the same thing—before. The sustaining sense of it all, moreover, as a potential literary subject, completely deserted her. She must wait, at any rate, she would see: it struck her, so far as she had progressed, as vast, obscure, and lurid.

She reflected in the watches of the night that she was probably just going to love it for itself—that is for itself and Milly. The odd thing was that she could think of Milly's loving it without dread—or with dread, at least not on the score of conscience, only on the score of peace. It was a mercy, at all events, for the hour, that their fancies jumped together. The two older women had so much to share, so much to discuss, that the visitor from Boston wasn't even certain that her main purpose in London was to experience excitement.

Translation

She thought during the night that she would probably just love it for itself—that is, for its own sake and for Milly. The strange thing was that she could imagine Milly loving it without fear—or with fear, at least not because of her conscience, only because of her peace of mind. It was a relief, in any case, for the moment, that their imaginations aligned. The two older women had so much to share, so much to talk about, that the visitor from Boston wasn't even sure that her main reason for being in London was to experience excitement.

In fact, she felt guilty, almost immoral, to admit that she was, as she put it, swept away. She laughed to Milly when she confessed she didn't know how it would all end. Her primary concern was that Mrs. Lowder's life was filled with aspects she was encountering for the first time.

Translation

In truth, she felt guilty, almost as if she were doing something wrong, to confess that she was, as she put it, completely captivated. She laughed with Milly when she admitted she had no idea how things would resolve themselves. Her main concern was that Mrs. Lowder's life was full of elements she was only now beginning to discover.

She believed these elements represented the world, the world that, because of the cold shoulder given to it by the Pilgrim Fathers, had never dared to cross over to Boston – it would likely sink even the strongest ship. She couldn't claim she was facing this situation solely because Milly had a whim. She herself was currently having a whim, directly related to their current situation. She could only find strength in the thought that she had never had one before—or had never given in to one, which amounted to the same thing.

Translation

She felt that these elements comprised the world. It was a world that, having been shunned by the Pilgrim Fathers, had never dared to reach Boston—it would probably sink any vessel, no matter how sturdy. She couldn’t pretend she was dealing with this just because Milly wanted to. She, too, was currently following a whim, which was directly connected to their circumstances. Her only reassurance was that she’d never had one before—or had never indulged one, which was essentially the same thing.

The idea of using it all as literary material, as a story to be written, completely left her. She would have to wait, she should wait, to see. It seemed to her, so far, as vast, unclear, and dark. She considered, in the stillness of the night, that she was probably going to love it for its own sake—that is, for its own sake and for Milly.

Translation

The notion of transforming everything into literary material, into a story to be written, vanished entirely. She would have to wait, she knew she should wait, to see how it unfolded. At this point, it appeared immense, undefined, and obscure. Contemplating it in the quiet of the night, she realized she was likely going to embrace it for its own sake—that is, for its own sake and for Milly.

The strange thing was that she could imagine Milly loving it without fear—or, at least, with fear but not because of her conscience, only because of her peace of mind. It was a blessing, at least for now, that their desires aligned. While, for this first week that followed their dinner, she drank deep at Lancaster Gate, her companion was no less happily, appeared to be indeed on the whole quite as romantically, provided for. The handsome English girl from the heavy English house had been as a figure in a picture stepping by magic out of its frame: it was a case, in truth, for which Mrs.

Translation

The odd part was that she could picture Milly adoring it without being afraid, or at least, with fear, but not because of her morals, only because of her sense of well-being. It was fortunate, at least for the time being, that their wishes were the same. During that first week after their dinner, while she was enjoying herself at Lancaster Gate, her friend was no less content, indeed seemed generally to be just as romantically fulfilled. The attractive English girl from the imposing English house had been like a painted figure magically stepping out of its frame: it was a situation for which Mrs.

Stringham presently found the perfect image. She had lost none of her grasp, but quite the contrary, of that other conceit in virtue of which Milly was the wandering princess: so what could be more in harmony now than to see the princess waited upon at the city gate by the worthiest maiden, the chosen daughter of the burgesses? It was the real again, evidently, the amusement of the meeting for the princess too; princesses living for the most part, in such an appeased way, on the plane of mere elegant representation. That was why they pounced, at city gates, on deputed flower-strewing damsels; that was why, after effigies, processions, and other stately games, frank human company was pleasant to them.

Translation

Stringham quickly found the perfect image. She hadn’t lost any of her grip on, quite the opposite, that other idea about virtue, by which Milly was the wandering princess. So what could be more harmonious now than to see the princess served at the city gate by the most worthy maiden, the chosen daughter of the townspeople? It was real again, clearly, the amusement of the meeting for the princess, too. Princesses lived, for the most part, in such a placid way, on the level of mere elegant display. That was why they pounced, at city gates, on appointed flower-strewing girls; that was why, after effigies, processions, and other stately games, genuine human companionship was pleasant to them.

Kate Croy really presented herself to Milly—the latter abounded for Mrs. Stringham in accounts of it—as the wondrous London girl in person, by what she had conceived, from far back, of the London girl; conceived from the tales of travellers and the anecdotes of New York, from old porings over Punch and a liberal acquaintance with the fiction of the day. The only thing was that she was nicer, for the creature in question had rather been, to our young woman, an image of dread. She had thought of her, at her best, as handsome just as Kate was, with turns of head and tones of voice, felicities of stature and attitude, things "put on" and, for that matter, put off, all the marks of the product of a packed society who should be at the same time the heroine of a strong story.

Translation

Kate Croy appeared to Milly as the quintessential London girl. Mrs. Stringham heard all about it. Kate embodied Milly's idea of the London girl, a concept she'd formed long ago. It came from travelers' stories, New York gossip, old issues of *Punch*, and a familiarity with contemporary fiction. The only difference was that Kate was actually *nicer* than the image Milly had held, which had once seemed frightening. Milly had pictured her, at her best, as handsome like Kate, with similar gestures, vocal inflections, and perfect posture. She imagined her as a product of a crowded society, both polished and artificial. The sort of woman who would be the main character in a compelling narrative.

She placed this striking young person from the first in a story, saw her, by a necessity of the imagination, for a heroine, felt it the only character in which she wouldn't be wasted; and this in spite of the heroine's pleasant abruptness, her forbearance from gush, her umbrellas and jackets and shoes—as these things sketched themselves to Milly—and something rather of a breezy boy in the carriage of her arms and the occasional freedom of her slang. For the week following their dinner, while Milly thrived in Lancaster Gate, her friend seemed equally content, perhaps even more romantically fulfilled. The beautiful English girl from the imposing English home had emerged from her world as if stepping out of a painting. Mrs.

Translation

Stringham was thrilled by Milly's descriptions of Kate's allure. Milly had immediately cast this captivating young woman in a narrative, visualizing her as a heroine by necessity. She sensed that this role was the only one that wouldn't diminish her. This was despite the heroine's agreeable directness, her avoidance of excessive sentimentality, her umbrellas, jackets, and shoes—all of which Milly vividly pictured—and the somewhat boyish quality in her bearing and occasional use of slang. In the week after their dinner, while Milly flourished in Lancaster Gate, her friend appeared equally content, perhaps even more romantically fulfilled. The stunning English girl, from her distinguished English home, had stepped out into the world as if emerging from a painting. Mrs. Stringham was delighted.

Stringham found the perfect metaphor for this. Milly retained her identity as a wandering princess, so it was appropriate that the worthiest maiden, the chosen daughter of the city, should now attend to the princess. It was real again, the joy of this reunion for the princess, too; princesses generally existed, in a peaceful state, in the realm of mere stylish appearances. That was why they embraced the flower-bearing young women at the city gates.

Translation

Stringham hit upon the perfect image. Milly, still a princess in exile, needed a champion, and who better than the city's darling, its most worthy daughter? The reunion felt authentic, a genuine delight for the princess as well. After all, princesses typically existed in the realm of appearances, content in their elegant displays. That's why they loved the girls who brought them flowers at the city gates.

After the statues, processions, and formal rituals, genuine human interaction was pleasant. Kate Croy revealed herself to Milly, as Milly's descriptions to Mrs. Stringham showed, as the wondrous London girl in person, just as Milly had imagined her, based on the accounts of travelers and the stories of New York, from old copies of Punch and her extensive reading of the popular novels. The only difference was that Kate was even nicer.

Translation

Genuine human interaction was a welcome change after the statues, the processions, and the formal rituals. Kate Croy proved to Milly, in the way Milly's descriptions had already shown Mrs. Stringham, to be the remarkable London girl she was in person. Milly had pictured her this way, based on what travelers said, what she knew of New York, from old copies of *Punch*, and from her extensive reading of popular novels. The only surprise was that Kate was even lovelier.

Milly had previously imagined the London girl as a source of fear. At her best, she had envisioned her as handsome, like Kate, with similar gestures, voices, grace, posture, both the performed and the discarded, all the markers of a product of a crowded society who should simultaneously be the protagonist of a powerful narrative. Milly immediately placed this striking young woman within a story, seeing her, inevitably, as a heroine, feeling it was the only role in which she wouldn't be wasted. This was despite the heroine's pleasant directness, her lack of sentimentality, her umbrellas, jackets, and shoes, which Milly had observed, and a certain boyish energy in her posture, and her occasional use of slang.

Translation

Milly had once feared the London girl. At her most optimistic, she saw her as beautiful, like Kate, with similar gestures, voices, grace, posture—both the practiced and the unconsidered—all the hallmarks of someone born into a teeming society, someone who would command a compelling story. Milly immediately cast this captivating young woman in a narrative, seeing her, inevitably, as a heroine, feeling it was the only role that wouldn't diminish her. This was despite the heroine's pleasant candor, her lack of sentimentality, her umbrellas, jackets, and shoes, which Milly had noticed, as well as a certain boyish energy in her posture, and her occasional use of slang.

When Milly had settled that the extent of her goodwill itself made her shy, she had found for the moment quite a sufficient key, and they were by that time thoroughly afloat together. This might well have been the happiest hour they were to know, attacking in friendly independence their great London—the London of shops and streets and suburbs oddly interesting to Milly, as well as of museums, monuments, "sights" oddly unfamiliar to Kate, while their elders pursued a separate course, both rejoicing in their intimacy and each thinking the other's young woman a great acquisition for her own. Milly expressed to Susan Shepherd more than once that Kate had some secret, some smothered trouble, besides all the rest of her history; and that if she had so good-naturedly helped Mrs. Lowder to meet them this was exactly to create a diversion, to give herself something else to think about.

Translation

When Milly decided that her own inherent kindness was the source of her shyness, she found a sufficient explanation, at least for the time being, and they were, at that point, fully comfortable with each other. This might well have been the happiest hour they would share, as they happily and independently explored their vast London—the London of stores, avenues, and suburbs, which Milly found surprisingly captivating, as well as the museums, landmarks, and "sights," which were oddly foreign to Kate, while their elders followed their own separate paths, both delighted by their close relationship and each believing that the other's young woman was a wonderful addition to her own life. Milly told Susan Shepherd more than once that Kate had a secret, some hidden problem, beyond her known past; and that if she had so generously helped Mrs. Lowder to meet them, it was precisely to create a distraction, to give herself something else to think about.

But on the case thus postulated our young American had as yet had no light: she only felt that when the light should come it would greatly deepen the colour; and she liked to think she was prepared for anything. What she already knew, moreover, was full to her vision, of English, of eccentric, of Thackerayan character, Kate Croy having gradually become not a little explicit on the subject of her situation, her past, her present, her general predicament, her small success, up to the present hour, in contenting at the same time her father, her sister, her aunt and herself. It was Milly's subtle guess, imparted to her Susie, that the girl had somebody else as well, as yet unnamed, to content, it being manifest that such a creature couldn't help having; a creature not perhaps, if one would, exactly formed to inspire passions, since that always implied a certain silliness, but essentially seen, by the admiring eye of friendship, under the clear shadow of some probably eminent male interest. The clear shadow, from whatever source projected, hung, at any rate, over Milly's companion the whole week, and Kate Croy's handsome face smiled out of it, under bland skylights, in the presence alike of old masters passive in their glory and of thoroughly new ones, the newest, who bristled restlessly with pins and brandished snipping shears.

Translation

But in this imagined scenario, our young American remained in the dark. She only felt that when the truth emerged, it would intensify everything. She liked to believe she was ready for anything. Everything she already knew was saturated with Englishness, with eccentricity, with a distinctly Thackerayan quality, as Kate Croy had become increasingly forthcoming about her circumstances—her past, her present, her general troubles, and her limited success in satisfying her father, her sister, her aunt, and herself, all at once. Milly subtly guessed, sharing her theory with her Susie, that Kate also had someone else to please, someone as yet unnamed, since such a person inevitably would; someone perhaps not designed to inspire great passions, as that always suggested a degree of foolishness, but who was, at least in the eyes of a sympathetic friend, clearly under the influence of some likely important male figure. This definite influence, no matter its source, surrounded Milly’s companion all week, and Kate Croy’s beautiful face smiled out from within it, beneath gentle skylights, surrounded by both the old masters, passively basking in their glory, and the brand-new ones, the most recent of whom bristled with pins and wielded snipping shears.

Once Milly decided her shyness stemmed from her genuine kindness, she found a reasonable explanation, and they were, at that point, truly connected. This might have been the best time they ever experienced, exploring London with their own freedom—the London of stores, streets, and suburbs that strangely fascinated Milly, and of museums, monuments, and "sights" that seemed odd and unfamiliar to Kate. Meanwhile, their older companions went their separate ways, both appreciating their close friendship and each thinking the other's young friend was a wonderful addition to their lives. Milly told Susan Shepherd more than once that Kate had a secret, some hidden trouble, in addition to everything else in her past.

Translation

Once Milly decided her reticence was rooted in her inherent goodness, she found a rationale, and at that moment, they truly bonded. This might have been the zenith of their time together, discovering London with complete liberty—the London of shops, roads, and neighborhoods, which strangely captivated Milly, and of galleries, landmarks, and "sights," which seemed peculiar and alien to Kate. Simultaneously, their older associates pursued their own affairs, each acknowledging their close camaraderie and each considering the other's young friend a delightful addition to their world. Milly informed Susan Shepherd more than once that Kate possessed a secret, some concealed difficulty, adding to everything else in her history.

Milly thought that if Kate had so generously helped Mrs. Lowder meet them, it was exactly to distract herself, to give herself something else to focus on. But regarding this theory, our young American still knew nothing for certain. She only felt that when the truth did come out, it would bring with it great intensity, and she liked to think she was prepared for anything.

Translation

Milly reasoned that Kate's role in introducing them to Mrs. Lowder had been a deliberate diversion, a means of avoiding something. However, the American girl still had no definitive answers. She only sensed that the truth, when revealed, would be significant, and she prided herself on being ready for whatever might come.

What she already knew, moreover, was filled with English culture, eccentric characters, and the style of Thackeray. Kate Croy had slowly become quite open about her circumstances, her past, her present, her general problems, and her limited success in satisfying her father, her sister, her aunt, and herself, all up to the present moment. Milly subtly guessed, and shared with her friend Susie, that the girl also had someone else, still unnamed, to satisfy. It was obvious that someone like Kate would.

Translation

Furthermore, what Milly already knew was saturated with English customs, unusual people, and the storytelling style of Thackeray. Kate Croy had gradually begun to speak candidly about her situation, her history, her current life, her general difficulties, and her failures in pleasing her father, her sister, her aunt, and herself, up to the present. Milly had a strong intuition, which she shared with her friend Susie, that Kate also had someone else, still unnamed, to keep happy. It was clear that someone like Kate would.

This someone was not perhaps designed to inspire passions, since that always suggested a degree of foolishness, but rather, as seen by her admiring friend, lived under the distinct influence of a man who was probably very important. The clear influence, from whatever source it originated, hung over Milly's friend the entire week. Kate Croy's attractive face smiled from within that influence, under soft skylights, both in the presence of the old masters, passive in their glory, and of the completely new artists, the newest ones, who nervously held pins and wielded scissors. It was meanwhile a pretty part of the intercourse of these young ladies that each thought the other more remarkable than herself—that each thought herself, or assured the other she did, a comparatively dusty object and the other a favourite of nature and of fortune.

Translation

This someone wasn’t likely meant to inspire grand passions, because that always hinted at a certain naiveté. Instead, as her admiring friend saw it, she lived under the obvious sway of a man who was probably very significant. This visible influence, whatever its origin, dominated Milly’s friend all week. Kate Croy’s appealing face smiled within that influence, beneath gentle skylights, among both the old masters, serene in their fame, and the very new artists, the latest ones, who nervously handled pins and wielded scissors. Meanwhile, a delightful element of these young ladies’ friendship was that each believed the other to be more remarkable than herself—that each considered herself, or told the other she did, a comparatively ordinary person while regarding the other as a favorite of fate and fortune.

Kate was amused, amazed at the way her friend insisted on "taking" her, and Milly wondered if Kate were sincere in finding her the most extraordinary—quite apart from her being the most charming—person she had come across. They had talked, in long drives, and quantities of history had not been wanting—in the light of which Mrs. Lowder's niece might superficially seem to have had the best of the argument. Her visitor's American references, with their bewildering immensities, their confounding moneyed New York, their excitements of high pressure, their opportunities of wild freedom, their record of used-up relatives, parents, clever, eager, fair, slim brothers—these the most loved—all engaged, as well as successive superseded guardians, in a high extravagance of speculation and dissipation that had left this exquisite being her black dress, her white face and her vivid hair as the mere last broken link: such a picture quite threw into the shade the brief biography, however sketchily amplified, of a mere middle-class nobody in Bayswater.

Translation

Kate was amused, and also astonished, by the way her friend insisted on “taking” her in. Milly wondered if Kate was sincere in finding her the most extraordinary person—quite aside from her being the most charming—that she’d ever met. They’d talked during long drives, and a great deal of history hadn’t been missing—in light of which Mrs. Lowder’s niece might superficially seem to have won the argument. Her visitor’s American references, with their bewildering immensities, their confounding, moneyed New York, their excitements of high pressure, their opportunities for wild freedom, their record of used-up relatives, parents, clever, eager, fair, slim brothers—these the most loved—all engaged, as well as successive superseded guardians, in a high extravagance of speculation and dissipation that had left this exquisite being with only her black dress, her white face, and her vivid hair as the mere last broken link. Such a picture quite threw into the shade the brief biography, however sketchily amplified, of a mere middle-class nobody in Bayswater.

And though that indeed might be but a Bayswater way of putting it, in addition to which Milly was in the stage of interest in Bayswater ways, this critic so far prevailed that, like Mrs. Stringham herself, she fairly got her companion to accept from her that she was quite the nearest approach to a practical princess Bayswater could hope ever to know. It was a fact—it became one at the end of three days—that Milly actually began to borrow from the handsome girl a sort of view of her state; the handsome girl's impression of it was clearly so sincere. This impression was a tribute, a tribute positively to power, power the source of which was the last thing Kate treated as a mystery.

Translation

And though that might be just a Bayswater expression, and though Milly was currently fascinated by Bayswater ways, this critic's viewpoint eventually convinced Milly that Kate, just like Mrs. Stringham, accepted that she was the closest thing to a real princess that Bayswater would ever know. It was a fact—established after only three days—that Milly began to adopt Kate's view of her own situation; Kate's impression of it was clearly genuine. This impression was an acknowledgment of power, power whose source was something Kate never treated as a mystery.

There were passages, under all their skylights, the succession of their shops being large, in which the latter's easy, yet the least bit dry manner sufficiently gave out that if she had had so deep a pocket——! Their friendship was made all the more interesting by the fact that each young woman considered the other more remarkable than herself. Each believed—or at least told the other—that she herself was relatively ordinary, while the other was a favorite of both nature and good fortune. Kate was amused and astonished by how her friend saw her, and Milly wondered if Kate was sincere in thinking her the most extraordinary person she had ever met, aside from being the most charming.

Translation

There were moments, beneath all of their skylights, within the succession of their shops, which were extensive, when Kate’s easy, though slightly reserved manner, made it clear that if she possessed a greater fortune——! Their friendship was all the more intriguing because each young woman believed the other to be the more exceptional. Each thought—or at least claimed to the other—that she was rather ordinary, while the other was favored by both nature and good luck. Kate was both amused and astonished by her friend's perception of her, and Milly wondered if Kate truly believed her to be the most extraordinary person she had ever encountered, in addition to being the most delightful.

During long drives, they had shared many conversations. In these conversations, Mrs. Lowder's niece seemed to have the upper hand. Kate's references to America, with its vastness, its overwhelming wealth of New York, its excitement, its freedom, and its history of relatives—parents, clever, eager, attractive brothers, all loved—as well as successive guardians, all involved in reckless speculation and excessive spending, had left Kate with her black dress, her pale face, and her striking hair as the only remnants.

Translation

They’d talked a lot during those long drives. In these discussions, Mrs. Lowder's niece consistently held the advantage. Kate's allusions to America, with its immense scale, its overwhelming New York riches, its vibrancy, its liberty, and its familial past—parents, intelligent, enthusiastic, charming brothers, all adored—and the string of guardians, all consumed by risky investments and lavish expenditures, left Kate only with her black dress, her pallid complexion, and her arresting hair.

This image overshadowed the brief, though somewhat detailed, biography of a middle-class woman from Bayswater. Although it might have simply been a Bayswater way of looking at it, and although Milly was interested in the ways of Bayswater, Kate's judgment was so persuasive that, like Mrs. Stringham, she convinced her friend that she was the closest thing to a real princess that Bayswater could ever know. After three days, it was a fact that Milly began to adopt Kate's view of herself, which was clearly so sincere.

Translation

This image overshadowed the short, but fairly detailed, biography of a middle-class woman from Bayswater. Even if it was just Bayswater's perspective, and even though Milly was interested in Bayswater ways, Kate's judgment was so convincing that, like Mrs. Stringham, she convinced her friend that she was the closest thing to a real princess that Bayswater could ever know. After three days, it was a given that Milly began to see herself the way Kate did, which was clearly so genuine.

This perception was a tribute, a tribute to power, the source of which Kate made no secret of. There were moments, as they strolled under the skylights of the shops, where Kate’s casual, slightly reserved demeanor hinted that if she had had the same financial resources… It was not moreover by any means with not having the imagination of expenditure that she appeared to charge her friend, but with not having the imagination of terror, of thrift, the imagination or in any degree the habit of a conscious dependence on others. Such moments, when all Wigmore Street, for instance, seemed to rustle about and the pale girl herself to be facing the different rustlers, usually so undiscriminated, as individual Britons too, Britons personal, parties to a relation and perhaps even intrinsically remarkable—such moments in especial determined in Kate a perception of the high happiness of her companion's liberty.

Translation

This perception was an homage, a tribute to power, the source of which Kate didn’t try to hide. There were moments, as they strolled beneath the skylights of the shops, when Kate’s casual, slightly reserved manner suggested that if she had had the same financial resources… It wasn’t, moreover, that she lacked the imagination for spending that seemed to make her challenge her friend, but rather that she lacked the imagination for fear, for frugality, the imagination or the habit of consciously depending on others. Moments like those, when all of Wigmore Street, for example, seemed to rustle and the pale girl herself faced the different rustlers, usually undifferentiated, as individual Britons too, personal Britons, parties to a relationship and perhaps even intrinsically remarkable—these moments in particular determined in Kate a perception of the profound happiness of her companion's freedom.

Milly's range was thus immense; she had to ask nobody for anything, to refer nothing to any one; her freedom, her fortune and her fancy were her law; an obsequious world surrounded her, she could sniff up at every step its fumes. And Kate, in these days, was altogether in the phase of forgiving her so much bliss; in the phase moreover of believing that, should they continue to go on together, she would abide in that generosity. She had, at such a point as this, no suspicion of a rift within the lute—by which we mean not only none of anything's coming between them, but none of any definite flaw in so much clearness of quality. Yet, all the same, if Milly, at Mrs.

Translation

The scope of Milly’s life was thus immense; she needed to ask nothing of anyone, to defer nothing to any person; her freedom, her fortune, and her imagination were her law; an obsequious world surrounded her, and she could inhale its fumes at every step. And Kate, in these days, was altogether in the phase of forgiving her so much bliss; in the phase, moreover, of believing that, should they continue to go on together, she would abide in that generosity. At such a point as this, she had no suspicion of a rift within the lute—by which we mean not only that nothing would come between them, but that there was no definite flaw in so much clearness of quality. Yet, all the same, if Milly, at Mrs.

Lowder's banquet, had described herself to Lord Mark as kindly used by the young woman on the other side because of some faintly-felt special propriety in it, so there really did match with this, privately, on the young woman's part, a feeling not analysed but divided, a latent impression that Mildred Theale was not, after all, a person to change places, to change even chances with. Kate, verily, would perhaps not quite have known what she meant by this reservation, and she came near naming it only when she said to herself that, rich as Milly was, one probably wouldn't—which was singular—ever hate her for it. The handsome girl had, with herself, these felicities and crudities: it wasn't obscure to her that, without some very particular reason to help, it might have proved a test of one's philosophy not to be irritated by a mistress of millions, or whatever they were, who, as a girl, so easily might have been, like herself, only vague and fatally female. She was by no means sure of liking Aunt Maud as much as she deserved, and Aunt Maud's command of funds was obviously inferior to Milly's.

Translation

If Milly, at Mrs. Lowder's banquet, had presented herself to Lord Mark as being treated with kindness by the young woman on the other side, because of a subtly-perceived special rightness in it, then there truly did correspond to this, privately, on the young woman's part, a feeling unexamined but split, a hidden sense that Mildred Theale was not, after all, a person with whom one would trade places, or even chances. Kate, truly, might not have fully known what she meant by this reservation, and she nearly named it only when she said to herself that, rich as Milly was, one probably wouldn't—which was odd—ever hate her for it. The beautiful girl had, within herself, these blessings and imperfections: it wasn't a mystery to her that, without some very specific reason to assist, it could have tested one's philosophy not to be irritated by a mistress of millions, or whatever the sum was, who, as a girl, could so easily have been, like herself, merely vague and fatally female. She was by no means certain of liking Aunt Maud as much as she should, and Aunt Maud's control of money was clearly inferior to Milly's.

There was thus clearly, as pleading for the latter, some influence that would later on become distinct; and meanwhile, decidedly, it was enough that she was as charming as she was queer and as queer as she was charming—all of which was a rare amusement; as well, for that matter, as further sufficient that there were objects of value she had already pressed on Kate's acceptance. A week of her society in these conditions—conditions that Milly chose to sum up as ministering immensely, for a blind, vague pilgrim, to aid and comfort—announced itself from an early hour as likely to become a week of presents, acknowledgments, mementos, pledges of gratitude and admiration that were all on one side. Kate as promptly embraced the propriety of making it clear that she must forswear shops till she should receive some guarantee that the contents of each one she entered as a humble companion should not be placed at her feet; yet that was in truth not before she had found herself in possession, under whatever protests, of several precious ornaments and other minor conveniences. It wasn't that she felt her friend lacked the imagination for spending money, but rather that she lacked the imagination for feeling fear, for being frugal, for consciously depending on others.

Translation

Thus, there was a definite influence, working in Milly's favor, that would later become clear. For the moment, it was enough that she was as charming as she was odd, and as odd as she was charming—a rare delight. It was also enough that she had already showered Kate with valuable gifts. A week spent in Milly’s company, which Milly described as providing enormous aid and comfort to a blind, vague pilgrim, promised from the start to be a week of presents, acknowledgments, mementos, and expressions of gratitude and admiration—all flowing in one direction. Kate quickly made it clear that she would avoid shops until she could be certain that their contents wouldn’t be lavished upon her. But this was only after she had, despite her protests, acquired several precious ornaments and other small luxuries. It wasn’t that Kate thought her friend incapable of spending money, but rather that Milly lacked the imagination to feel fear, to be frugal, or to consciously rely on others.

Those moments, when all of Wigmore Street seemed to buzz around them, and when the pale girl herself was facing all the people, usually indistinct, as individual Britons, people in relationships, possibly even remarkable—those moments, especially, made Kate realize how happy her friend was to be free. Milly's options were vast; she didn't have to ask anyone for anything, she didn't have to answer to anyone. Her freedom, her wealth, and her desires were her rules. An obliging world surrounded her, and she could breathe in its influence at every step.

Translation

Those moments, when all of Wigmore Street seemed to hum around them, and when the pale girl herself was confronting all the people, usually indistinct, as individual Britons, people in relationships, possibly even remarkable—those moments, especially, made Kate realize how happy her friend was to be unburdened. Milly's options were endless; she didn't have to ask anyone for anything, she didn't have to answer to anyone. Her freedom, her wealth, and her desires were the law. An accommodating world surrounded her, and she could breathe in its influence at every step.

And Kate, at this time, was completely in the phase of accepting all that happiness; in the phase of believing that if they stayed together, she would continue to be generous. She had no suspicion of any trouble brewing between them—meaning not only that nothing would come between them, but that there wasn't anything wrong with their perfect relationship. Yet, even so, if Milly, at Mrs. Lowder's dinner, had told Lord Mark that the young woman beside her was treating her well because it was the proper thing to do, then, privately, the young woman had a feeling, unexamined but divided, a hidden impression that Mildred Theale was, after all, not a person to trade places with, to even trade opportunities with.

Translation

And at this time, Kate was completely consumed by accepting all of this happiness; by believing that if they remained together, she would continue to be generous. She had no inkling of any conflict between them—meaning not only that nothing would come between them, but that their perfect relationship was without fault. Still, if Milly, at Mrs. Lowder’s dinner, had told Lord Mark that the young woman beside her was treating her well because it was the expected thing to do, then, privately, the young woman had an unexamined but divided feeling, a hidden impression that Mildred Theale was, in the end, not a person to trade places with, to even trade opportunities with.

Kate wouldn't have known what she meant by this feeling, and she almost revealed it when she told herself that, rich as Milly was, you probably wouldn't—and this was strange—ever hate her for it. The beautiful girl had both advantages and disadvantages; it was clear to her that, without some very specific reason to help, it might have been a challenge to avoid being annoyed by a woman worth millions, or whatever, who, as a girl, could easily have been, like her, just vague and inevitably female. She wasn't sure of liking Aunt Maud as much as she deserved, and Aunt Maud's wealth was clearly less than Milly's. So, clearly, something was working in Milly's favor, which would later become obvious; and meanwhile, it was enough that Milly was as charming as she was strange and as strange as she was charming—which was all a rare amusement; as well, it was more than enough that there were valuable gifts she had already given to Kate.

Translation

Kate wouldn't have understood the source of this feeling, and it nearly surfaced when she thought that, despite Milly's wealth, you probably wouldn't—and this was odd—ever come to hate her for it. The beautiful girl had her pros and cons; Kate could see that, without a specific reason to be helpful, it might be tough not to be irritated by a woman worth millions, or whatever, who, as a girl, could have easily been, like herself, just aimless and inevitably female. She wasn't certain she liked Aunt Maud as much as she should, and Aunt Maud's money was obviously less than Milly's. So, obviously, something was working in Milly's favor, a fact that would become clear later; and for now, it was enough that Milly was as delightful as she was peculiar and as peculiar as she was delightful—which was all a delightful distraction; and it was also more than enough that there were valuable gifts Milly had already given Kate.

A week in her company in these circumstances—circumstances that Milly liked to describe as being a great help to a blind, vague traveler—was shaping up, from the very beginning, to be a week of presents, tokens of gratitude, mementos, and expressions of admiration, all coming from Milly. Kate promptly decided that she must avoid shops until she could be sure that the items in each shop she entered as a humble companion wouldn't be offered to her; yet that wasn't before she had, despite her protests, found herself in possession of several valuable ornaments and other small conveniences. Great was the absurdity, too, that there should have come a day, by the end of the week, when it appeared that all Milly would have asked in definite "return," as might be said, was to be told a little about Lord Mark and to be promised the privilege of a visit to Mrs. Condrip.

Translation

A week spent with her, under these conditions—which Milly liked to characterize as being of significant assistance to a clueless, directionless traveler—was already starting to look like a week of gifts, expressions of thanks, keepsakes, and declarations of affection, all courtesy of Milly. Kate quickly resolved to stay away from stores until she could be certain that nothing in the stores she entered as a humble companion would be offered to her. Even so, she had already, despite her efforts to decline, acquired several valuable trinkets and other small comforts. It was also absurd that, by the end of the week, it would seem that all Milly would ask in explicit “exchange,” you might say, was to hear a bit about Lord Mark and to be granted the chance to visit Mrs. Condrip.

Far other amusements had been offered her, but her eagerness was shamelessly human, and she seemed really to count more on the revelation of the anxious lady of Chelsea than on the best nights of the opera. Kate admired, and showed it, such an absence of fear: to the fear of being bored, in such a connection, she would have been so obviously entitled. Milly's answer to this was the plea of her curiosities—which left her friend wondering as to their odd direction. Some among them, no doubt, were rather more intelligible, and Kate had heard without wonder that she was blank about Lord Mark.

Translation

Other entertainments had been offered to her, but her enthusiasm was shamelessly human, and she seemed to value the opportunity to meet the anxious woman from Chelsea more than the best nights at the opera. Kate admired, and showed it, such a lack of fear: she would have been perfectly justified in fearing boredom within such a relationship. Milly’s response to this was to indulge her curiosity—which left her friend wondering about its unusual focus. Some of these curiosities were, without question, more understandable, and Kate had heard without surprise that she knew nothing about Lord Mark.

This young lady's account of him, at the same time, professed itself as frankly imperfect; for what they best knew him by at Lancaster Gate was a thing difficult to explain. One knew people in general by something they had to show, something that, either for them or against, could be touched or named or proved; and she could think of no other case of a value taken as so great and yet flourishing untested. His value was his future, which had somehow got itself as accepted by Aunt Maud as if it had been his good cook or his steam-launch. She, Kate, didn't mean she thought him a humbug; he might do great things—but they were all, as yet, so to speak, he had done.

Translation

At the same time, this young lady's description of him admitted its own incompleteness, because what they knew him for at Lancaster Gate was hard to pin down. People are usually known by something they can present, something tangible, something that can be named or proven. Kate couldn't think of another instance where someone's worth was so high but had never been tested. His value was his future, which had been accepted by Aunt Maud as though it were his good cook or his steam-launch. Kate didn't think he was a fake; he might achieve great things, but he hadn't done them yet.

On the other hand it was of course something of an achievement, and not open to every one, to have got one's self taken so seriously by Aunt Maud. The best thing about him, doubtless, on the whole, was that Aunt Maud believed in him. She was often fantastic, but she knew a humbug, and—no, Lord Mark wasn't that. He had been a short time in the House, on the Tory side, but had lost his seat on the first opportunity, and this was all he had to point to.

Translation

On the other hand, it was, of course, something of an achievement, and not one available to just anyone, to have been taken so seriously by Aunt Maud. The best thing about him, undoubtedly, was that Aunt Maud believed in him. She was often whimsical, but she could spot a fraud, and—no, Lord Mark was not that. He had spent a short time in the House, on the Tory side, but had lost his seat at the first chance, and this was all he had to show for himself.

However, he pointed to nothing; which was very possibly just a sign of his real cleverness, one of those that the really clever had in common with the really void. Even Aunt Maud frequently admitted that there was a good deal, for her view of him, to come up in the rear. And he wasn't meanwhile himself indifferent—indifferent to himself—for he was working Lancaster Gate for all it was worth: just as it was, no doubt, working him, and just as the working and the worked were in London, as one might explain, the parties to every relation. It was also absurd that by the end of the week, Milly’s only requests for compensation were to hear a little about Lord Mark and to be promised a visit to Mrs.

Translation

Nonetheless, he offered no accomplishments. This might have been a testament to his intelligence, a quality shared by both the exceptionally astute and the utterly empty. Even Aunt Maud often acknowledged that there was still much to be revealed about him, from her perspective. Moreover, he wasn't indifferent—not indifferent to himself, at any rate—for he was leveraging Lancaster Gate to its fullest extent. No doubt it was doing the same to him; the exploiter and the exploited in London, one might say, the inseparable aspects of every connection. It was also absurd that by the end of the week, Milly’s only requests for recompense were a few details about Lord Mark and the promise of a visit to Mrs.

Condrip. She had been offered other entertainment, but her enthusiasm was purely human. She seemed to value the information about the anxious woman in Chelsea more than the best nights at the opera. Kate was impressed and showed it.

Translation

Condrip. She'd been offered other diversions, but her interest was purely down-to-earth. She seemed to value the information about the worried woman in Chelsea more than the best nights at the opera. Kate was impressed, and she showed it.

Milly should have been afraid of being bored by this connection, but she wasn't. Milly said her curiosity drove her, leaving her friend to wonder why her curiosity was directed in such an odd way. Some of her curiosities were more understandable. Kate had already heard that Milly was completely in the dark about Lord Mark.

Translation

Milly expected to be bored by this link, but she wasn't. Milly said curiosity was her motivator, leaving her friend to wonder why her interest took such a strange path. Some of her fascinations were easier to grasp. Kate already knew Milly had no idea about Lord Mark.

Kate’s explanation of him was also incomplete, as it was difficult to explain what they knew of him at Lancaster Gate. One usually knew people by what they had to show—something that could be touched, named, or proven either for or against them. But Kate knew of no other instance of a person whose value was so great and yet untested. His value was his future, which Aunt Maud had somehow accepted as fact, just as she might have accepted his good cook or his steam-launch.

Translation

Kate’s description of him was also lacking, since it was hard to explain what they knew about him at Lancaster Gate. Typically, one understood people by their observable qualities—something tangible, defined, or verifiable as either good or bad. But Kate knew of no other example of someone whose worth was so substantial and yet unproven. His worth was based on his future, which Aunt Maud had somehow embraced as fact, much like she would have accepted his skilled cook or his motorboat.

Kate did not believe he was a fraud. He might do great things, but he hadn't yet done anything. On the other hand, it was an accomplishment to have Aunt Maud take him so seriously. The best thing about him was that Aunt Maud believed in him.

Translation

Kate didn't think he was a fake. He might achieve great things, but he hadn't done anything yet. On the other hand, it was an achievement to have Aunt Maud take him so seriously. The best thing about him was that Aunt Maud believed in him.

She was often strange, but she could spot a fraud, and Lord Mark was not that. He had served briefly in Parliament on the Tory side but had lost his seat immediately. However, he had nothing to show for it. Perhaps that was a sign of his cleverness, one that clever people share with those who are void of substance.

Translation

Aunt Maud was often a bit odd, but she was good at sniffing out phonies, and Lord Mark wasn't one. He'd done a short stint in Parliament as a Tory, but he'd lost his seat right away. Still, he hadn't actually accomplished anything. Maybe that was a sign of his intelligence, something that clever people have in common with people who are all flash and no substance.

Even Aunt Maud admitted that there was a lot, in her view, that was yet to come. And he wasn’t indifferent to himself. He was using Lancaster Gate for all it was worth, just as it was using him. This was how things worked in London, where those who worked and those who were worked were both participants in every relationship.

Translation

Even Aunt Maud conceded that, in her opinion, much remained to be seen. And he wasn't indifferent to himself. He was exploiting Lancaster Gate to its fullest extent, just as it was exploiting him. That's how things operated in London, where the users and the used were equally involved in every connection.

Kate did explain, for her listening friend: every one who had anything to give—it was true they were the fewest—made the sharpest possible bargain for it, got at least its value in return. The strangest thing, furthermore, was that this might be, in cases, a happy understanding. The worker in one connection was the worked in another; it was as broad as it was long—with the wheels of the system, as might be seen, wonderfully oiled. People could quite like each other in the midst of it, as Aunt Maud, by every appearance, quite liked Lord Mark, and as Lord Mark, it was to be hoped, liked Mrs.

Translation

Kate explained to her friend, who was listening: everyone who had something to give—and it was true that they were the fewest—struck the sharpest possible bargain for it, getting at least its value in return. The strangest thing was that, in some cases, this could be a happy understanding. The worker in one situation was the worked in another; it was as simple as that—the wheels of the system were wonderfully oiled. People could quite like each other in the midst of it, as Aunt Maud, from all appearances, quite liked Lord Mark, and as Lord Mark, one hoped, liked Mrs.

Lowder, since if he didn't he was a greater brute than one could believe. She, Kate, had not yet, it was true, made out what he was doing for her—besides which the dear woman needed him, even at the most he could do, much less than she imagined; so far as all of which went, moreover, there were plenty of things on every side she had not yet made out. She believed, on the whole, in any one Aunt Maud took up; and she gave it to Milly as worth thinking of that, whatever wonderful people this young lady might meet in the land, she would meet no more extraordinary woman. There were greater celebrities by the million, and of course greater swells, but a bigger person, by Kate's view, and a larger natural handful every way, would really be far to seek.

Translation

Lowder, because if he didn't, he was a worse brute than anyone could imagine. Kate hadn't figured out yet what he was doing for her—besides which the dear woman needed him, even at the most he could do, much less than she realized; as far as all of that went, there were plenty of things on every side she hadn't figured out. She believed, on the whole, in anyone Aunt Maud took up; and she offered to Milly that it was worth considering that, however wonderful people this young lady might meet in the land, she would meet no more extraordinary woman. There were greater celebrities by the million, and of course greater swells, but a bigger person, according to Kate, and a larger natural handful in every way, would really be hard to find.

When Milly inquired with interest if Kate's belief in her was primarily on the lines of what Mrs. Lowder "took up," her interlocutress could handsomely say yes, since by the same principle she believed in herself. Whom but Aunt Maud's niece, pre-eminently, had Aunt Maud taken up, and who was thus more in the current, with her, of working and of being worked? "You may ask," Kate said, "what in the world I have to give; and that indeed is just what I'm trying to learn.

Translation

When Milly asked with interest if Kate's belief in her was mainly based on the people Mrs. Lowder supported, her friend could readily say yes, because she believed in herself on the same principle. Who but Aunt Maud's niece, above all others, had Aunt Maud supported, and who was thus more connected to her in the process of acting and being acted upon? "You can ask," Kate said, "what I actually have to offer, and that's precisely what I'm trying to figure out."

There must be something, for her to think she can get it out of me. She will get it—trust her; and then I shall see what it is; which I beg you to believe I should never have found out for myself." She declined to treat any question of Milly's own "paying" power as discussable; that Milly would pay a hundred per cent.—and even to the end, doubtless, through the nose—was just the beautiful basis on which they found themselves. Kate explained to her friend who was listening: everyone who had something to offer—and admittedly, those people were few—demanded the best possible deal for it, at least getting its value in return. The strangest thing was that in certain instances, this arrangement could even be pleasant.

Translation

There must be something, or else she wouldn't think she could get it from me. She will—trust her—and then I’ll see what it is, which I swear I would never have figured out on my own.” She refused to discuss any question of Milly’s ability to "pay." That Milly would pay a hundred percent—and probably, in the end, overpay—was simply the wonderful foundation of their relationship. Kate told her listening friend: anyone who had something to offer—and those people were rare—demanded the best possible deal for it, at least its worth in exchange. The weirdest thing was that in certain cases, this arrangement could even be enjoyable.

The person being utilized in one scenario was also the user in another; it was a balanced system—with the mechanisms, as one could observe, running smoothly. People could actually like each other amidst all this, just as Aunt Maud, seemingly, quite liked Lord Mark, and as Lord Mark, it was hoped, liked Mrs. Lowder, because if he didn't, he was more cruel than anyone could imagine. Kate, in truth, hadn't yet figured out what he was doing for her—besides the fact that the dear woman needed him, even with what he could do, which was less than she realized.

Translation

The person being exploited in one situation was also the beneficiary in another; it was a reciprocal system, and one could see that the gears were turning without a hitch. People could actually feel affection for each other in the midst of it all, much as Aunt Maud appeared to like Lord Mark, and as Lord Mark, it was hoped, liked Mrs. Lowder, because if he didn't, he was more malicious than anyone knew. Kate, to be honest, hadn’t yet determined what he was doing for her—apart from the fact that the dear woman needed him, even with what he could provide, which was less than she appreciated.

However, on that front, there were many things all around that she hadn't yet figured out. Overall, she had faith in anyone Aunt Maud supported; and she suggested to Milly that it was worth considering that, no matter what remarkable people this young lady might encounter, she wouldn't meet a more extraordinary woman. There were countless more famous people, and certainly people of higher social standing, but a more significant person, in Kate's view, someone with a greater impact in every way, would be hard to find. When Milly asked if Kate's belief in her was mainly because Mrs.

Translation

Lowder, like a true guardian, had faith in her, Kate replied that it was more than that, though her aunt's judgment was enough to get her started. It was also due to the way Milly treated things, because she never failed to make everything interesting, and so it was natural to hope that good things would come her way. Kate continued by admitting that this was what she wanted to believe. And she was also curious, as a keen observer. Her mind was constantly at work, and she saw the world as a complex collection of stories, and she knew there were many questions that would be answered, as one chapter led to the next.

Lowder "supported" her, Kate could confidently reply yes, because she believed in herself based on the same principle. Who else, other than Aunt Maud's niece, had Aunt Maud championed, and who was therefore more involved with her in the system of using and being used? "You might wonder," Kate said, "what I have to offer; and that's precisely what I'm trying to figure out. There must be something for her to believe she can get from me.

Translation

Lowder backed her, Kate could readily confirm, because her own self-belief rested on the very same foundation. Besides Aunt Maud's niece, whom else had Aunt Maud taken up the cause of, and who else was as implicated with her in this game of utilizing and being utilized? "You might wonder," Kate posed, "what I bring to the table; and that is exactly what I'm striving to understand. There must be something she anticipates obtaining from me."

She will get it—trust me; and then I'll see what it is; which I assure you I would never have discovered on my own." She refused to discuss any question of Milly's own "paying" ability; that Milly would pay a hundred percent—and probably, in the end, very dearly—was simply the wonderful foundation of their relationship. These were fine facilities, pleasantries, ironies, all these luxuries of gossip and philosophies of London and of life, and they became quickly, between the pair, the common form of talk, Milly professing herself delighted to know that something was to be done with her. If the most remarkable woman in England was to do it, so much the better, and if the most remarkable woman in England had them both in hand together, why, what could be jollier for each? When she reflected indeed a little on the oddity of her wanting two at once, Kate had the natural reply that it was exactly what showed her sincerity.

Translation

She'll get it, I guarantee it. Then I'll figure out what it is, something I would never have figured out on my own, I assure you." She avoided any discussion of Milly's financial contribution. That Milly would pay in full—and probably, ultimately, at a very high price—was simply the extraordinary basis of their connection. These were fine arrangements, pleasantries, ironies; all these indulgences of London gossip and philosophies of life. They swiftly became the usual form of conversation between them, with Milly expressing her delight that something was going to be done with her. If the most remarkable woman in England was doing it, all the better; and if the most remarkable woman in England had them both involved, well, what could be more enjoyable for each of them? When Kate considered the peculiarity of Aunt Maud wanting them both, her natural response was that it was precisely what proved her sincerity.

She invariably gave way to feeling, and feeling had distinctly popped up in her on the advent of her girlhood's friend. The way the cat would jump was always, in presence of anything that moved her, interesting to see; visibly enough, moreover, for a long time, it hadn't jumped anything like so far. This, in fact, as we already know, remained the marvel for Milly Theale, who, on sight of Mrs. Lowder, found fifty links in respect to Susie absent from the chain of association.

Translation

She always surrendered to her emotions, and those emotions had clearly surfaced when her childhood friend arrived. It was always fascinating to observe how Kate would react when something touched her; it was also obvious that she hadn't reacted with such intensity in a long time. This, as we already know, was what amazed Milly Theale, who, upon seeing Mrs. Lowder, discovered that fifty associations relating to Susie were missing.

She knew so herself what she thought of Susie that she would have expected the lady of Lancaster Gate to think something quite different; the failure of which endlessly mystified her. But her mystification was the cause for her of another fine impression, inasmuch as when she went so far as to observe to Kate that Susan Shepherd—and especially Susan Shepherd emerging so uninvited from an irrelevant past—ought, by all the proprieties, simply to have bored Aunt Maud, her confidant agreed with her without a protest and abounded in the sense of her wonder. Susan Shepherd at least bored the niece—that was plain; this young woman saw nothing in her—nothing to account for anything, not even for Milly's own indulgence: which little fact became in turn to the latter's mind a fact of significance. It was a light on the handsome girl—representing more than merely showed—that poor Susie was simply as nought to her.

Translation

She knew, herself, how she felt about Susie, and she would have expected the woman from Lancaster Gate to feel quite differently; this failure endlessly baffled her. But her bewilderment produced another strong impression in her, because when she went so far as to remark to Kate that Susan Shepherd—and especially Susan Shepherd arriving uninvited from an irrelevant past—should, by all rights, simply have bored Aunt Maud, her confidante agreed without protest and shared her wonder. Susan Shepherd, at least, bored the niece—that was obvious; this young woman saw nothing in her—nothing that explained anything, not even Milly's own fondness: which small fact, in turn, became, to the latter's mind, a significant detail. It was a revelation about the beautiful girl—suggesting more than was apparent—that poor Susie meant absolutely nothing to her.

This was, in a manner too, a general admonition to poor Susie's companion, who seemed to see marked by it the direction in which she had best most look out. These were wonderful amenities, pleasantries, ironies; all these luxuries of London gossip and philosophies of life. Between the two women, they quickly became a regular topic of conversation. Milly declared herself thrilled to be involved in something.

Translation

This, in a way, was also a warning to poor Susie's friend, who seemed to understand that it indicated where she should be most cautious. These were wonderful niceties, pleasantries, ironies; all the luxuries of London gossip and life philosophies. Between the two women, they quickly became a regular conversation topic. Milly said she was thrilled to be involved in something.

If the most remarkable woman in England were managing it, so much the better. If that woman had them both in her care, well, what could be more enjoyable for each? When she considered the strangeness of Kate wanting both of them at once, Kate had the obvious response that it proved her sincerity. She always yielded to her feelings, and those feelings had certainly surfaced upon the arrival of her childhood friend.

Translation

Even better if the most extraordinary woman in England was running the show. And if that woman was looking after both of them? What could be more fun for either of them? When she thought about how odd it was that Kate wanted them both there together, Kate’s immediate answer was that it showed how genuine she was. Kate always followed her emotions, and those feelings had clearly come up when her childhood friend arrived.

The way the cat would react to anything that moved her was always interesting to observe. It was clear that, for quite some time, the cat hadn't reacted in such a dramatic way. This, as we already know, remained a marvel for Milly Theale, who, upon meeting Mrs. Lowder, found that fifty links in her association with Susie were missing.

Translation

The cat's reactions to anything that caught her attention were always fascinating to watch. It was obvious that the cat hadn't put on such a display in a while. This, as we already understand, was still a wonder to Milly Theale. Upon meeting Mrs. Lowder, Milly realized that fifty pieces of her connection to Susie were gone.

She knew what she thought of Susie and expected the lady of Lancaster Gate to feel quite differently. The fact that she didn’t endlessly mystified her. But this mystification caused another fine impression, because when she went so far as to tell Kate that Susan Shepherd—and especially Susan Shepherd appearing so uninvited from an irrelevant past—should, according to all proper behavior, have simply bored Aunt Maud, her confidante agreed without protest and shared her wonder. Susan Shepherd certainly bored the niece—that was clear.

Translation

Milly understood her own feelings about Susie and assumed that Mrs. Lowder, the lady of Lancaster Gate, would feel the opposite. The fact that she didn't endlessly puzzled Milly. But this mystification made another favorable impression. When Milly went so far as to tell Kate that Susan Shepherd—and especially Susan Shepherd, showing up uninvited from an irrelevant past—should, according to all proper behavior, have simply bored Aunt Maud, her confidante agreed without protest and shared her wonder. Susan Shepherd certainly bored the niece—that much was clear.

Kate saw nothing in her—nothing to explain anything, not even Milly’s own fondness. This little fact became, in turn, significant to Milly. It illuminated the attractive girl, who represented more than she revealed, that poor Susie was nothing to her. This was also, in a way, a general warning to poor Susie’s companion, who seemed to see in it the direction she should watch out for.

Translation

Kate saw nothing in her—nothing that explained anything, not even Milly's own affection. This detail, in turn, became significant to Milly. It illuminated the appealing girl, who represented more than she showed, that poor Susie meant nothing to her. This was also, in a way, a general warning to poor Susie's companion, who seemed to see in it the path she should avoid.

It just faintly rankled in her that a person who was good enough and to spare for Milly Theale shouldn't be good enough for another girl; though, oddly enough, she could easily have forgiven Mrs. Lowder herself the impatience. Mrs. Lowder didn't feel it, and Kate Croy felt it with ease; yet in the end, be it added, she grasped the reason, and the reason enriched her mind.

Translation

It bothered her a little that someone perfectly acceptable for Milly Theale wasn't considered good enough for another girl. Oddly, she could have easily overlooked Mrs. Lowder's impatience. Mrs. Lowder didn't feel it, but Kate Croy did, easily. Eventually, it must be said, she understood the reason, and that reason expanded her understanding.

Wasn't it sufficiently the reason that the handsome girl was, with twenty other splendid qualities, the least bit brutal too, and didn't she suggest, as no one yet had ever done for her new friend, that there might be a wild beauty in that, and even a strange grace? Kate wasn't brutally brutal—which Milly had hitherto benightedly supposed the only way; she wasn't even aggressively so, but rather indifferently, defensively and, as might be said, by the habit of anticipation. She simplified in advance, was beforehand with her doubts, and knew with singular quickness what she wasn't, as they said in New York, going to like. In that way at least people were clearly quicker in England than at home; and Milly could quite see, after a little, how such instincts might become usual in a world in which dangers abounded.

Translation

Wasn't it reason enough that the beautiful girl, possessing twenty other excellent qualities, was also a bit brutal? Didn't she imply, as no one had ever done for her new friend, that there might be a wild beauty in that, and even a strange grace? Kate wasn't brutally brutal—which Milly had, until then, cluelessly assumed was the only kind. She wasn't even aggressively so, but rather indifferently, defensively, and, you could say, out of habit. She simplified things in advance, was ready with her doubts, and knew with remarkable speed what she wasn't, as they said in New York, going to like. In that way, at least, people were clearly quicker in England than at home. Milly could understand, after a little while, how such instincts could become commonplace in a world filled with dangers.

There were more dangers, clearly, round about Lancaster Gate than one suspected in New York or could dream of in Boston. At all events, with more sense of them, there were more precautions, and it was a remarkable world altogether in which there could be precautions, on whatever ground, against Susie. It vaguely bothered her that someone considered perfect for Milly Theale wasn't considered good enough for another girl. However, she could easily overlook Mrs.

Translation

There were, obviously, more threats around Lancaster Gate than anyone in New York suspected or anyone in Boston could have imagined. At the very least, there was a greater awareness of them, and there were more precautions, and it was altogether a remarkable world in which precautions could be taken, for any reason, against Susie. It vaguely bothered her that someone considered perfect for Milly Theale wasn't considered good enough for another girl. However, she could easily overlook Mrs.

Lowder's impatience. Mrs. Lowder didn't feel it, and Kate Croy felt it without effort. But she eventually understood the reason, and that understanding broadened her perspective.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder's lack of patience didn't trouble her; Kate Croy experienced it without difficulty. But she came to comprehend the source of this, and that comprehension expanded her understanding.

Wasn't the reason clear enough: the attractive girl, possessing many other admirable qualities, was also a bit ruthless, and didn't she—in a way no one had before for her new friend—suggest a wild beauty, even a strange elegance in that ruthlessness? Kate wasn't brutally cruel, which Milly had naively thought was the only kind of cruelty. She wasn't even aggressively so, but rather casually, defensively, and, one could say, out of habit. She simplified things beforehand, anticipated doubts, and knew with remarkable speed what she wouldn't like.

Translation

The reason was obvious: the alluring woman, with her many other fine attributes, was also somewhat ruthless, and didn’t she, in a way that was new to her friend, hint at a savage beauty, even a peculiar grace within that ruthlessness? Kate wasn't violently cruel, which Milly had naively believed was the only form of cruelty. She wasn’t even overtly so, but instead, casually, defensively, and, one might say, habitually. She simplified matters in advance, anticipated objections, and understood with striking swiftness what she would disapprove of.

In that regard, people were clearly quicker in England than in America. After a while, Milly could see how such instincts might become common in a world filled with potential threats. There were clearly more dangers around Lancaster Gate than one suspected in New York or could imagine in Boston. At the very least, because of a greater awareness of them, there were more precautions.

Translation

Milly realized that, in this respect, the English were quicker on the uptake than Americans. After some time, she could see how such instincts might be cultivated in a world that seemed to be full of potential danger. There were, it seemed, more hidden threats in the vicinity of Lancaster Gate than she'd ever suspected in New York, or could even imagine in Boston. Or, at the very least, there were more precautions taken, owing to a greater awareness of peril.

It was a remarkable world indeed, where precautions could be taken, for any reason, against Susie.

Translation

It was a truly extraordinary world, one where precautions could be taken against Susie, regardless of the reason.

Chapter 9

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

During a late-night talk, Susan "Susie" Shepherd tells her companion, Milly, about an announcement. While on a drive in Battersea Park with Mrs. Lowder, it was revealed that Mrs. Lowder and her niece, Kate Croy, know Mr. Merton Densher, a man Milly met in New York. Susie acknowledged to Mrs. Lowder that Milly knew him but said they were not yet great friends. Susie then relays a message from Mrs. Lowder (Maud): Milly should not mention Mr. Densher to Kate unless Kate brings him up first. Milly says she and Kate have not spoken of him. Susie explains that Mrs. Lowder wants Kate to marry Lord Mark and is afraid of her liking Mr. Densher.

Later, Milly and Kate visit Kate’s sister, Mrs. Condrip, in Chelsea.

That night, Milly tells Susie about the visit. While Kate was out of the room, Mrs. Condrip told Milly that Mr. Densher is in love with Kate and asked for Milly’s help to stop it, calling the situation "dreadful." Mrs. Condrip explained that Densher is poor with no prospects and that Aunt Maud (Mrs. Lowder) also disapproves of him. Mrs. Condrip asked Milly not to tell Kate about their conversation. Susie corrects one point, stating that Mrs. Lowder actually likes Mr. Densher and thinks he is very able.

Susie asks if Milly told Mrs. Condrip that she knew Densher. Milly says she did not, remembering Mrs. Lowder's wish for silence. They discuss what will happen when Densher returns. Milly suggests she could either tell him not to acknowledge her or she could leave.

Milly then becomes emotional, speaking about her illness and feeling lost. Susie offers to go anywhere with her. Milly asks Susie to stay with her wherever she goes, even if they go abroad to Switzerland or Italy.

Returning to the subject, Milly clarifies her main concern: that Mrs. Condrip would use the fact that Milly knows Densher to portray him to Kate as unfaithful. When Susie asks if Densher made advances toward Milly, Milly says no. Milly explains that Mrs. Condrip does not think Kate is in love with Densher, but only fears that Densher will continue to pursue her. Susie asks if Milly questioned Mrs. Condrip about Kate's feelings for Densher, and Milly says she did not.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

This is an exemplary passage, likely from a work by Henry James, that showcases a dense and intricate exploration of social dynamics, psychological depth, and the subtleties of human relationships. The analysis will focus on the developing themes of perception versus reality, social manipulation, and mortality, as well as the significant character developments of Milly Theale and her companions.

### Literary Analysis

#### **Themes**

**1. The Labyrinth of Social Convention and Perception:**

The most dominant theme in the text is the complex, almost suffocating nature of high society, which Susie aptly describes as a "labyrinth." The characters navigate a world where direct communication is rare and meaning is constructed through hints, silences, and strategic revelations. The news of the connection to Merton Densher is not a simple fact but an "announcement" that "altered all proportions" and "had an effect on all values."

* **Secrets and Omissions:** The narrative is driven by what is *not* said. Mrs. Lowder requests that Densher's name not be mentioned to her niece, Kate. Kate, in turn, has never mentioned Densher to Milly, a silence that Milly now sees as a "great darkness." Milly's own decision to remain silent with Kate becomes a "new sort of fun," tinged with anxiety, transforming her from a passive observer into an active participant in this social game. This theme is crystallized when Milly realizes the quantity Kate has told her might be "smallest, beside the quantity she hadn't."

* **Interpretation as Action:** Characters are constantly interpreting each other's motives. Milly's perception of Kate is radically altered by the new information; she now sees her "in the light of the knowledge" of her connection to Densher, revealing an "other, the not wholly calculable" side. Susie, in turn, analyzes Milly’s reactions, seeing her complex explanations as the work of a "New England heroine" who can "see round several corners." The plot advances not through action, but through these shifts in perception and interpretation.

**2. The Power of Money, Class, and Social Position:**

The social labyrinth is built upon a foundation of wealth and class. The visit to Mrs. Condrip in Chelsea throws this into sharp relief. Milly observes the stark contrast between the sisters, Kate and "poor Marian," and how "the social situation of sisters could be opposed." This difference is attributed to a rigid "hierarchical, an aristocratic order."
