Translation

"That he'll never amount to anything?" "No—quite the opposite: that he's exceptionally talented." "Oh, yes; I know"—Milly echoed, referring to what her friend had already revealed about this, in the same tone she'd used earlier. "But Mrs.

Condrip's key point is that Aunt Maud won't even consider such a person. Mr. Densher, she believes—at least, that's how it was explained to me—will never be a public figure or a wealthy man. If he were a public figure, she would, as I understand it, be willing to support him; if he were rich—without any other qualities—she'd try her best to tolerate him.

Translation

Mrs. Condrip's central argument is that Aunt Maud won't give someone like that a second thought. Mr. Densher, according to her—or at least that's how it was described to me—will never be a public figure, nor will he be rich. If he were a public figure, she would, as far as I can tell, be inclined to assist him; if he were rich—regardless of any other attributes—she would do her best to put up with him.

As it is, she rejects him." "In short," said Mrs. Stringham as with a private purpose, "she told you, the sister, all about it. But Mrs.

Translation

Stringham didn't consider the situation important enough to speak further on it. "That's how things are," she said. "In essence," Mrs. Stringham added with a private intent, "she, the sister, told you everything. But Mrs…"

Lowder likes him," she added. "Mrs. Condrip didn't tell me that." "Well, she does, all the same, my dear, extremely."

Translation

Lowder likes him," she added. "Mrs. Condrip didn't tell me that." "Well, she does, my dear, very much."

"Then there it is!" On which, with a drop and one of those sudden, slightly sighing surrenders to a vague reflux and a general fatigue that had recently more than once marked themselves for her companion, Milly turned away. Yet the matter was not left so, that night, between them, albeit neither perhaps could afterwards have said which had first come back to it. Milly's own nearest approach, at least, for a little, to doing so, was to remark that they appeared all—every one they saw—to think tremendously of money. This prompted in Susie a laugh, not untender, the innocent meaning of which was that it came, as a subject for indifference, money did, easier to some people than to others: she made the point in fairness, however, that you couldn't have told, by any too crude transparency of air, what place it held for Maud Manningham.

Translation

"There you have it!" With that, and a slump, a sudden, sighing surrender to a vague weariness and general fatigue—something that had lately become noticeable to her companion—Milly turned away. Yet the issue wasn’t dropped that night, though neither of them could later have said who had first brought it up again. Milly's closest approach, at least for a while, was to observe that everyone they saw seemed to think about money an awful lot. Susie responded with a laugh that wasn't unkind, implying that money, as a matter of indifference, was easier for some than others. Fairly though, she pointed out that you couldn’t tell what place money held for Maud Manningham, based on any obvious appearance.

She did her worldliness with grand proper silences—if it mightn't better be put perhaps that she did her detachment with grand occasional pushes. However Susie put it, in truth, she was really, in justice to herself, thinking of the difference, as favourites of fortune, between her old friend and her new. Aunt Maud sat somehow in the midst of her money, founded on it and surrounded by it, even if with a clever high manner about it, her manner of looking, hard and bright, as if it weren't there. Milly, about hers, had no manner at all—which was possibly, from a point of view, a fault: she was at any rate far away on the edge of it, and you hadn't, as might be said, in order to get at her nature, to traverse, by whatever avenue, any piece of her property.

Translation

She conducted her worldly affairs with grand, proper silences—or perhaps, it would be more accurate to say that she performed her detachment with grand, occasional pushes. However Susie phrased it, in reality, she was considering the difference between her old friend and her new one, as they were favored by fortune. Aunt Maud sat somehow in the middle of her money, founded upon it and surrounded by it, even if she did so with a clever, lofty demeanor, her manner of looking hard and bright, as if it weren’t there. Milly, concerning her own affairs, had no particular manner at all—which was possibly, from a certain perspective, a flaw: she was, at any rate, far removed on the fringes of it, and in order to understand her character, you wouldn’t have to traverse any part of her property, regardless of the path.

It was clear, on the other hand, that Mrs. Lowder was keeping her wealth as for purposes, imaginations, ambitions, that would figure as large, as honourably unselfish, on the day they should take effect. She would impose her will, but her will would be only that a person or two shouldn't lose a benefit by not submitting if they could be made to submit. To Milly, as so much younger, such far views couldn't be imputed: there was nobody she was supposable as interested for.

Translation

On the other hand, it was obvious that Mrs. Lowder was managing her wealth for goals, dreams, and ambitions that would appear as grand and honorably altruistic when they came to fruition. She would impose her will, but her will would only ensure that one or two individuals wouldn't miss out on an advantage by failing to comply, if they could be persuaded to comply. Milly, being so much younger, couldn't be suspected of such ambitious plans; there was no one she was believed to be looking out for.

It was too soon, since she wasn't interested for herself. Even the richest woman, at her age, lacked motive, and Milly's motive doubtless had plenty of time to arrive. She was meanwhile beautiful, simple, sublime without it—whether missing it and vaguely reaching out for it or not; and with it, for that matter, in the event, would really be these things just as much. Only then she might very well have, like Aunt Maud, a manner.

Translation

It was premature, given she had no personal stake. Even the wealthiest woman, at her age, had no driving force, and Milly's would likely develop in time. In the meantime, she was beautiful, straightforward, and sublime without it—whether she yearned for it or not; and with it, for that matter, she would still be these things just as much. Only then might she very well have, like Aunt Maud, a certain affectation.

Such were the connections, at all events, in which the colloquy of our two ladies freshly flickered up—in which it came round that the elder asked the younger if she had herself, in the afternoon, named Mr. Densher as an acquaintance. In short," Mrs. Stringham said, with a private purpose, "she, the sister, told you everything about it.

Translation

Such were the circumstances in which the conversation between the two women resumed—the conversation that led to the older woman asking the younger if she had, that afternoon, presented Mr. Densher as someone she knew. In short, Mrs. Stringham said, with a hidden motive, "she, the sister, told you everything about it."

But Mrs. Lowder likes him," she added. "Mrs. Condrip didn't tell me that."

Translation

"But Mrs. Lowder likes him," she added. "Mrs. Condrip didn't tell me that."

"Well, she does, it's a fact, my dear, very much so." "Then there you have it!" After which, with a decline and a sudden, slightly sighing surrender to a vague weariness and general fatigue that her companion had recently noticed more than once, Milly turned away. Yet the subject wasn't dropped that night between them, even though neither perhaps could later say who brought it up first. Milly's own closest approach, at least for a little while, was to observe that everyone they saw seemed to think a great deal about money.

Translation

"Well, she does, it's a fact, my dear, very much so." "Then there you have it!" After which, with a decline and a sudden, slightly sighing surrender to a vague weariness and general fatigue that her companion had recently noticed more than once, Milly turned away. Yet the subject wasn't dropped that night between them, even though neither perhaps could later say who brought it up first. Milly's own closest approach, at least for a little while, was to observe that everyone they saw seemed to think a great deal about money.

This prompted a tender laugh from Susie, meaning it came more easily to some people than to others to be indifferent to money: she pointed out in fairness, however, that you couldn't tell from any too obvious signs how much it mattered to Maud Manningham. She presented her worldliness with grand, proper silences—or perhaps it would be better to say she presented her detachment with grand, occasional efforts. However Susie put it, in truth, she was really thinking about the difference, as fortunate people, between her old friend and her new one. Aunt Maud seemed to sit in the midst of her money, founded on it and surrounded by it, even if with a clever, proud manner about it, her way of looking, hard and bright, as if it weren't there.

Translation

Susie chuckled gently, implying that for some, indifference to money came more naturally. She then fairly noted that you couldn't easily tell how much it mattered to Maud Manningham. Maud displayed her worldliness with impressive, controlled silences—or perhaps it was more accurate to say she showed her detachment with occasional, grand gestures. However Susie phrased it, the truth was she was contemplating the contrast between her old friend and her new one, both of whom were privileged. Aunt Maud seemed to exist in the heart of her wealth, built upon it and surrounded by it, although with a clever, proud demeanor, her gaze sharp and bright, as if the money wasn't even there.

Milly, regarding her own money, had no manner at all—which was possibly, from a certain perspective, a fault: at any rate, she was far away from the edge of it, and you didn't have to navigate any part of her property to understand her nature. It was clear, on the other hand, that Mrs. Lowder was keeping her wealth for purposes, ambitions, and plans that would seem as grand and honorably unselfish on the day they took effect. She would impose her will, but her will would only be that a person or two shouldn't lose a benefit by not submitting if they could be made to.

Translation

Milly, when it came to her own finances, lacked any discernible style. This, arguably, could be seen as a flaw. At the very least, she was far removed from the constraints of her wealth, and you didn't have to experience her possessions to understand what she was like. It was obvious, however, that Mrs. Lowder was managing her fortune with a certain purpose in mind, driven by ambitions and schemes that would, when realized, seem both significant and altruistic. She would exert her influence, but only to ensure that individuals wouldn't miss out on something beneficial if they could be persuaded to comply.

Such distant goals couldn't be expected of Milly, who was much younger: there was no one she could be imagined as being interested in. It was too soon, since she wasn't interested in herself. Even the richest woman, at her age, lacked a motive, and Milly's motive would undoubtedly arrive in time. Meanwhile, she was beautiful, simple, and sublime without money—whether missing it and vaguely reaching for it or not; and with it, for that matter, she would really be these things just as much.

Translation

Such long-term objectives were beyond Milly, considering her youth: there was no specific person she could be envisioned as caring about. It was premature, as she lacked self-interest. Even the wealthiest woman, at her age, wouldn't have a clear goal, and Milly's would certainly develop eventually. In the meantime, she was naturally lovely, unpretentious, and admirable, regardless of her finances—whether she was wanting for money and somewhat pursuing it, or not; and, for that matter, she would possess these same qualities regardless.

Only then she might very well have a manner, like Aunt Maud. Such were the connections, at any rate, in which the conversation of our two ladies newly re-emerged—in which the older woman asked the younger if she herself had mentioned Mr. Densher as an acquaintance that afternoon. "Oh no—I said nothing of having seen him.

I remembered," the girl explained, "Mrs. Lowder's wish." "But that," her friend observed after a moment, "was for silence to Kate." "Yes—but Mrs.

Translation

Lowder, for everything." The elder woman considered. "That's how you interpret it?" "Isn't it how you do?" the girl enquired. Her friend thought again. "I'm not sure. But it's very possible." "And do you think," the girl went on, "that she'll have spoken?" "Ah, that's what I'm wondering." The girl's eyes reflected. "I don't see what she could have said." "No—but that's just the danger," the elder woman returned. "She may have said too much by saying nothing." The girl followed this with a certain intensity. "By being clever?" "By being clever."

Condrip would immediately have told Kate." "Why so?—since she must dislike to talk about him." "Mrs. Condrip must?" Milly thought.

Translation

Condrip would have told Kate right away." "Why's that? She hates talking about him." "Mrs. Condrip does?" Milly wondered.

"What she would like most is that her sister should be brought to think ill of him; and if anything she can tell her will help that—" But Milly dropped suddenly here, as if her companion would see. Her companion's interest, however, was all for what she herself saw. "You mean she'll immediately speak?" Mrs. Stringham gathered that this was what Milly meant, but it left still a question.

Translation

"What she'd like most is for her sister to think badly of him. And if anything she can say will help that—" But Milly stopped, as if her friend would understand. Her friend, however, was focused on what she herself was seeing. "You mean she'll tell her right away?" Mrs. Stringham gathered that this was Milly's point, though a question remained.

"How will it be against him that you know him?" "Oh, no—I didn't say I'd seen him. I remembered," the girl explained, "Mrs. Lowder's request."

Translation

"What's it going to do to him, you knowing him?" "Oh, no—I didn't say I'd met him. I remembered," the girl clarified, "Mrs. Lowder's asking me to."

"But that," her friend pointed out after a moment, "was to be silent to Kate." "Yes—but Mrs. Condrip would tell Kate right away." "Why would she?—since she must not want to talk about him."

Translation

"But that," her friend pointed out after a moment, "was to be silent to Kate." "Yes—but Mrs. Condrip would tell Kate right away." "Why would she?—since she must not want to talk about him."

"Mrs. Condrip must not?" Milly thought. "What she'd most want is for her sister to think badly of him; and if anything she can tell her will help that—" But Milly stopped short, as if her friend would understand. Her friend's focus, however, was on what she herself understood.

Translation

"Mrs. Condrip must not?" Milly wondered. "What she'd really want is for her sister to think poorly of him; and if anything she can tell her will help that—" But Milly cut herself off, as if her friend would comprehend. Her friend, however, was occupied with what she herself comprehended.

"You mean she'll speak right away?" Mrs. Stringham realized that this was Milly's point, but it still raised a question. "How will it be a problem for him that you know him?" "Oh, I don't know.

Translation

"You mean she'll tell her immediately?" Mrs. Stringham understood this was Milly's concern, but it still didn't make sense. "How will it affect him that you know him?" "Oh, I don't know.

It won't be so much one's knowing him as one's having kept it out of sight." "Ah," said Mrs. Stringham, as if for comfort, "you haven't kept it out of sight. Isn't it much rather Miss Croy herself who has?"

Translation

"It won't be about one's knowing him, but about having kept it hidden." "Ah," said Mrs. Stringham, as if to console, "you haven't kept it hidden. Isn't it really Miss Croy herself who has?"

"It isn't my acquaintance with him," Milly smiled, "that she has dissimulated." "She has dissimulated only her own? Well then, the responsibility's hers." "Ah but," said the girl, not perhaps with marked consequence, "she has a right to do as she likes."

Translation

"It's not my relationship with him," Milly smiled, "that she's been hiding." "She's only been hiding her own? Well then, the responsibility falls to her." "Oh but," the girl said, perhaps not with any great significance, "she's entitled to do as she chooses."

"Then so, my dear, have you!" smiled Susan Shepherd. Milly looked at her as if she were almost venerably simple, but also as if this were what one loved her for. "We're not quarrelling about it, Kate and I, yet." "Oh, I'm not sure.

Translation

"And you, my dear, have as well!" Susan Shepherd smiled. Milly looked at her, almost as if she were venerably simple, but also as if this was why one loved her. "Kate and I, we're not fighting about it, yet." "Oh, I wouldn't be so sure."

It's not about whether you know him, but whether you've kept it hidden." "Ah," Mrs. Stringham said, seemingly trying to be reassuring, "You haven't kept it hidden. Isn't it really Miss Croy who has?"

Translation

"It's not about your relationship with him, but about your secrecy," she said. "Oh," Mrs. Stringham replied, apparently trying to calm her, "You haven't been secretive. Isn't it really Miss Croy who has?"

"It's not my relationship with him," Milly smiled, "that she's been concealing." "She's only concealed her own involvement? Well then, it's her problem." "But," the girl said, perhaps without much emphasis, "she's entitled to do what she wants."

Translation

"It's not my connection to him," Milly smiled, "that she's been hiding." "So she's only hidden her own part in this? Well, then, that's her issue." "But," the girl said, perhaps a little flatly, "she's allowed to do what she wants."

"Then so are you, dear!" Susan Shepherd smiled. Milly looked at her as if she were almost charmingly naive, but also as if that was why she loved her. "Kate and I aren't fighting about it yet." "I only meant," Mrs.

Translation

"Then so are you, dear!" Susan Shepherd smiled. Milly looked at her as if she were almost charmingly naive, but also as if that was why she loved her. "Kate and I aren't fighting about it yet." "I only meant," Mrs.

Stringham explained, "that I don't see what Mrs. Condrip would gain." "By her being able to tell Kate?" Milly thought. "I only meant that I don't see what I myself should gain."

Translation

Stringham explained, "that I don't see what Mrs. Condrip would gain." "By her being able to tell Kate?" Milly thought. "I only meant that I don't see what I myself should gain."

"But it will have to come out—that he knows you both—some time." Milly scarce assented. "Do you mean when he comes back?" "He'll find you both here, and he can hardly be looked to, I take it, to 'cut' either of you for the sake of the other."

Translation

"But it's inevitable—that he knows you both—eventually." Milly barely agreed. "Do you mean when he returns?" "He'll find you both here, and I don't think he's likely to shun either of you for the other's sake."

This placed the question at last on a basis more distinctly cheerful. "I might get at him somehow beforehand," the girl suggested; "I might give him what they call here the tip—that he's not to know me when we meet. Or, better still, I mightn't be here at all." "I simply meant," Mrs.

Translation

This finally shifted the question to a brighter angle. "I could try to get to him first," the girl proposed, "I could give him the heads-up—that he shouldn't recognize me when we run into each other. Or, even better, I could just not be here." "I simply meant," Mrs.

Stringham clarified, "that I don't understand what Mrs. Condrip would achieve." "By her informing Kate?" Milly wondered. "I only meant that I don't see what I myself would gain."

Translation

Stringham clarified, "that I don't understand what Mrs. Condrip hopes to accomplish." "By informing Kate?" Milly wondered. "I only meant that I don't see what I, personally, would gain."

"But it will inevitably come to light – that he's acquainted with both of you – eventually." Milly barely agreed. "Do you mean when he returns?" "He'll find you both here, and he's unlikely, I assume, to 'ignore' either of you for the other's benefit."

Translation

"However, it's bound to surface – the fact that he knows you both – sooner or later." Milly conceded, albeit reluctantly. "You mean when he gets back?" "He'll discover you're both here, and I don't imagine he'll simply 'disregard' one of you to accommodate the other."

This finally made the situation seem more optimistic. "I could perhaps contact him beforehand," the girl suggested; "I could give him, as they say here, the heads-up – that he shouldn't acknowledge me when we meet. Or, even better, I might not be present at all." "Do you want to run away from him?"

Translation

This new possibility made things appear less bleak. "Maybe I could reach out to him first," the girl offered. "I could, you know, give him a heads-up, as they say – tell him not to acknowledge me when we see each other. Or, even better, I could just not be there at all." "So, you want to avoid him?"

It was, oddly enough, an idea Milly seemed half to accept. "I don't know what I want to run away from!" It dispelled, on the spot—something, to the elder woman's ear, in the sad, sweet sound of it—any ghost of any need of explaining. The sense was constant for her that their relation was as if afloat, like some island of the south, in a great warm sea that made, for every conceivable chance, a margin, an outer sphere of general emotion; and the effect of the occurrence of anything in particular was to make the sea submerge the island, the margin flood the text.

Translation

Milly seemed to partially embrace the idea, strangely enough. "I don't even know what I want to escape!" In that moment, something disappeared—something that sounded sad and sweet to the older woman, and that needed no explanation. She always felt that their relationship was like an island in the South, floating in a vast, warm sea. The sea provided a margin, an outer sphere of general emotion, for every possible situation. And when something specific happened, the sea would submerge the island, the margin would flood the text.

The great wave now for a moment swept over. "I'll go anywhere else in the world you like." Milly seemed to almost agree with the idea. "I don't even know what I'm trying to escape!"

Translation

The enormous wave swept over them for a moment. "I'll go anywhere in the world you want." Milly seemed almost in agreement. "I don't even know what I'm trying to escape!"

In that moment, the other woman understood—the sadness and sweetness in Milly's voice made any further explanation unnecessary. She always felt that their relationship existed in a space like a floating island in a warm ocean, a place where many possibilities existed. Whatever happened was like a wave that would wash over the island, the general feelings would overtake the specifics. The large wave had now momentarily crashed over them.

Translation

In that instant, the other woman understood. The sadness and sweetness in Milly's voice rendered any further explanation pointless. She always felt their relationship existed in a space like a floating island in a warm ocean, a place brimming with possibilities. Whatever occurred was like a wave that would wash over the island, the general emotions overshadowing the specifics. The enormous wave had just now crashed over them.

"I'll take you anywhere in the world." But Milly came up through it. "Dear old Susie—how I do work you!" "Oh, this is nothing yet."

Translation

"I'll take you anywhere in the world," the first woman offered. But Milly surfaced, speaking from a depth of emotion. "Dear old Susie—how I wear you out!" "Oh, this is nothing yet," Susie replied.

"No indeed—to what it will be." "You're not—and it's vain to pretend," said dear old Susie, who had been taking her in, "as sound and strong as I insist on having you." "Insist, insist—the more the better. But the day I look as sound and strong as that, you know," Milly went on—"on that day I shall be just sound and strong enough to take leave of you sweetly for ever.

Translation

"No, definitely not—to what it's going to become." "You're not—and it's pointless to pretend," said dear old Susie, who had been listening to her, "as healthy and strong as I demand you to be." "Demand, demand—the more the merrier. But the day I look as healthy and strong as that, you know," Milly continued—"on that day I will be just healthy and strong enough to say goodbye to you sweetly, forever."

That's where one is," she continued thus agreeably to embroider, "when even one's most 'beaux moments' aren't such as to qualify, so far as appearance goes, for anything gayer than a handsome cemetery. Since I've lived all these years as if I were dead, I shall die, no doubt, as if I were alive—which will happen to be as you want me. So, you see," she wound up, "you'll never really know where I am. Except indeed when I'm gone; and then you'll only know where I'm not."

Translation

"That's the situation," she continued, in a pleasant tone, to elaborate, "when even one's best moments don't appear lively enough to be anything other than a handsome cemetery. Since I've spent all these years as if I were dead, I'll probably die as if I were alive—which will be according to your wishes. So, you see," she concluded, "you'll never really know where I am. Except, of course, when I'm gone; and then you'll only know where I'm not."

Milly struggled through her illness. "Sweet Susie, I really wear you out." "Oh, this isn't anything yet." "No, it isn't—compared to what's coming."

Translation

Milly persevered through her illness. "Sweet Susie, I'm exhausting you." "Oh, it's nothing yet." "No, it's not—compared to what's to come."

"You're not—and it's pointless to deny it," said sweet Susie, who had been studying Milly, "as healthy and strong as I keep telling myself you are." "Insist, insist—the more the better. But the day I look as healthy and strong as that, you know," Milly continued, "on that day I'll be just healthy and strong enough to say goodbye to you forever. That's the reality," she continued in her pleasant way, "when even one's best moments don't appear to be worth anything more exciting than a beautiful cemetery.

Translation

"You aren't—and there's no use pretending," said sweet Susie, who had been studying Milly, "as healthy and strong as I keep telling myself you are." "Insist, insist—the more the better. But the day I look as healthy and strong as that," Milly continued, "on that day I'll be just healthy and strong enough to say goodbye to you forever. That's the reality," she continued in her pleasant way, "when even one's best moments don't appear to be worth anything more exciting than a beautiful cemetery."

Since I've lived all these years as if I were dead, I'll probably die as if I were alive—which will be just what you want. So, you see," she concluded, "you'll never really know where I am. Except, of course, when I'm gone; then you'll only know where I'm not." "I'd die for you," said Susan Shepherd after a moment.

Translation

"Because I've spent all this time pretending I was gone, I'll likely die acting like I'm here—which, I imagine, is precisely what you're hoping for. So you see," she finished, "you'll never truly know my whereabouts. Except, naturally, when I'm no longer around; then you'll only know where I'm absent." "I'd die for you," Susan Shepherd said after a pause.

"'Thanks awfully'! Then stay here for me." "But we can't be in London for August, nor for many of all these next weeks." "Then we'll go back."

Translation

"Thanks so much," she said. "Then stay here for me."

"But we can't be in London in August, or during the weeks that follow."

"Then we'll go back."

Susie blenched. "Back to America?" "No, abroad—to Switzerland, Italy, anywhere. I mean by your staying here for me," Milly pursued, "your staying with me wherever I may be, even though we may neither of us know at the time where it is.

Translation

Susie paled. "Back to America?" "No, abroad—to Switzerland, Italy, anywhere. What I mean by your staying here for me," Milly continued, "is your staying with me wherever I might be, even if neither of us knows where that will be at the moment."

No," she insisted, "I don't know where I am, and you never will, and it doesn't matter—and I dare say it's quite true," she broke off, "that everything will have to come out." Her friend would have felt of her that she joked about it now, had not her scale from grave to gay been a thing of such unnamable shades that her contrasts were never sharp. She made up for failures of gravity by failures of mirth; if she hadn't, that is, been at times as earnest as might have been liked, so she was certain not to be at other times as easy as she would like herself. Translation

"No," she insisted, "I don't know where I am, and you never will, and it doesn't matter—and I dare say it's quite true," she broke off, "that everything will have to come out." Her friend would have felt she was joking about it now, had not her range from serious to lighthearted been a thing of such indescribable nuances that her contrasts were never stark. She compensated for her seriousness with instances of levity; if she hadn't been at times as earnest as one might have wished, she certainly wouldn't be at other times as relaxed as she would have liked. Condrip would put the fact before her to his injury." "I would give my life for you," Susan Shepherd said after a moment of thought. "That's very kind of you! Then stay here with me."

Translation

Condrip would present the truth to her, to his own detriment. "I would give my life for you," Susan Shepherd said after a moment's consideration. "That's very kind of you! Then stay here with me."

Translation

"But we can't stay in London in August, or for most of the next few weeks." "Then we'll go back." Susie looked alarmed. "Back to America?"

"No, abroad—to Switzerland, Italy, anywhere. When I say you'll stay here with me," Milly continued, "I mean you'll stay with me wherever I am, even if neither of us knows where that will be. No," she insisted, "I don't know where I am, and you never will, and it doesn't matter—and I suppose it's true," she added abruptly, "that everything will eventually be revealed." Her friend might have thought she was joking about it now, except that her range of moods was so nuanced that her shifts of feeling were never clear-cut. She made up for her serious moments with moments of levity; if she hadn't been as earnest as she could be at times, she certainly wouldn't be as casual as she wished at others.

Translation

"No, abroad—to Switzerland, Italy, anywhere. When I say you'll stay here with me," Milly continued, "I mean you'll stay with me wherever I am, even if neither of us knows where that will be. No," she insisted, "I don't know where I am, and you never will, and it doesn't matter—and I suppose it's true," she added abruptly, "that everything will eventually be revealed." Her friend might have thought she was kidding, except that her moods were so complex that her feelings never felt simple. She balanced her serious times with lighthearted ones; if she wasn't as sincere as she could be at times, she certainly wouldn't be as carefree as she wanted to be at others.

"I have to accept what's coming. It isn't just about 'revealing' it," she added; "it's that Mrs. Condrip would use the information to harm him." Her companion wondered.

Translation

"I must face what's about to happen. It's not simply a matter of the truth 'coming out'," she added. "Mrs. Condrip would weaponize the knowledge to hurt him." Her friend considered this.

"But how to his?" "Why, if he pretends to love her——!" "And does he only 'pretend'?" "I mean if, trusted by her in strange countries, he forgets her so far as to make up to other people."

Translation

"But how would that affect him?" "Well, if he pretends to love her——!" "And is that all he does, 'pretend'?" "I mean if, trusted by her in foreign places, he forgets about her enough to flirt with other people."

The amendment, however, brought Susie in, as if with gaiety, for a comfortable end. "Did he make up, the false creature, to you?" "No—but the question isn't of that. It's of what Kate might be made to believe."

Translation

The amendment, however, brought Susie into the conversation, as if cheerfully, for a satisfying conclusion. "Did he lie to you, the deceitful man?" "No—but that's not the issue. The issue is what Kate might be made to believe."

"That, given the fact that he evidently more or less followed up his acquaintance with you, to say nothing of your obvious weird charm, he must have been all ready if you had at all led him on?" Milly neither accepted nor qualified this; she only said, after a moment, as with a conscious excess of the pensive: "No, I don't think she'd quite wish to suggest that I made up to him; for that I should have had to do so would only bring out his constancy. All I mean is," she added—and now at last, as with a supreme impatience "that her being able to make him out a little a person who could give cause for jealousy would evidently help her, since she's afraid of him, to do him in her sister's mind a useful ill turn." Her friend was puzzled.

Translation

"Given that he clearly pursued his acquaintance with you, not to mention your obvious weird charm, wasn't he prepared to be led on if you'd given him the slightest encouragement?"

Milly neither agreed nor disagreed; after a moment, she said, with a deliberately thoughtful air, "No, I don't think she'd quite want to suggest that I pursued him; because if I had, it would only prove his devotion. All I mean," she added—and now with a final burst of impatience—"is that if she could portray him as someone who could provoke jealousy, that would clearly help her, since she's afraid of him, to make him look bad in her sister's eyes."

Her friend was puzzled.

"But how does that affect him?" "Well, if he's pretending to love her——!" "And is that all it is, just 'pretending'?" "I mean, if, after she trusts him in unfamiliar places, he forgets about her enough to flirt with other women."

Translation

"But how does that impact him?" "Well, if he's pretending to love her——!" "And is that all it is, just 'pretending'?" "I mean, if, after she trusts him in unfamiliar places, he forgets about her enough to flirt with other women."

That change of direction brought Susie in, as if cheerfully, for a satisfying conclusion. "Did the lying man flirt with you?" "No—but that's not the point. The question is what Kate might be led to believe."

Translation

The shift in focus brought Susie into the conversation, as if eager to provide a neat resolution. "Did the lying man flirt with you?" "No, but that's not what matters. The real issue is what Kate might be led to believe."

"That, given that he clearly more or less pursued you, not to mention your obvious, irresistible charm, he would have been ready to make a move if you had encouraged him at all?" Milly neither agreed nor disagreed with that. She just said, after a moment, in a thoughtful way: "No, I don't think she'd actually want to suggest that I made a move on him; because the only result of that would be to highlight his loyalty. All I mean is," she added—and now, finally, with an air of immense irritation—"that if she could portray him as someone who could inspire jealousy, that would clearly help her to damage his reputation in her sister's eyes, since she's afraid of him."

Translation

"So, since he basically came after you, and let's face it, you're incredibly charming, he would have jumped at the chance if you'd given him the slightest encouragement?" Milly neither confirmed nor denied it. After a beat, she said thoughtfully, "No, I don't think she'd actually try to say I came on to him. That would just make him look loyal. What I'm saying," she added, her voice now edged with irritation, "is that if she can paint him as someone who could make someone jealous, it would help her trash his reputation with her sister, because she's afraid of him."

Susan Shepherd perceived in this explanation such signs of an appetite for motive as would have sat gracefully even on one of her own New England heroines. It was seeing round several corners; but that was what New England heroines did, and it was moreover interesting for the moment to make out how many really her young friend had undertaken to see round. Finally, too, weren't they braving the deeps? They got their amusement where they could.

Translation

Susan Shepherd detected in this explanation a hunger for hidden motivations that would have suited even one of her own New England heroines. It was a matter of seeing multiple steps ahead, but that was precisely what New England heroines did, and furthermore, it was engaging for the time being to determine just how many steps her young friend had set out to foresee. Ultimately, weren't they both facing the unknown? They found their entertainment wherever they could.

"Isn't it only," she asked, "rather probable she'd see that Kate's knowing him as (what's the pretty old word?) volage——?" "Well?" She hadn't filled out her idea, but neither, it seemed, could Milly. "Well, might but do what that often does—by all our blessed little laws and arrangements at least; excite Kate's own sentiment instead of depressing it." Susan Shepherd found in this explanation such a clear desire to understand motives that it would have suited even one of her own New England heroines.

Translation

"Isn't it only," she asked, "rather probable she'd see that Kate's knowing him as (what's the pretty old word?) flighty——?" "Well?" She hadn't finished her thought, but neither, it seemed, could Milly. "Well, it might but do what that often does—by all our blessed little laws and arrangements at least; excite Kate's own feelings instead of discouraging them." Susan Shepherd detected in this explanation such a clear desire to understand motives that would have suited even one of her own New England heroines.

It was a matter of looking at things from several angles, but that was something New England heroines did. Furthermore, it was interesting to try to figure out just how many angles her young friend had taken the time to consider. In the end, weren't they both facing uncertainty? They got their entertainment where they could.

Translation

It involved examining the situation from multiple perspectives, a common practice among New England heroines. Moreover, it was intriguing to determine the extent to which her young friend had actually contemplated these different angles. Ultimately, weren't they both grappling with ambiguity? They found their amusement wherever possible.

"Isn't it likely," she asked, "that she would recognize Kate's awareness of him as, (what's that old-fashioned word?) a flirt?" "Well?" She hadn't fully explained her point, but it seemed Milly couldn't either. "Well, maybe that could do what it often does—at least according to all our carefully constructed rules and expectations—and instead of discouraging Kate's feelings, would actually intensify them." The idea was bright, yet the girl but beautifully stared.

Translation

"Wouldn't it be likely," she asked, "that she'd see Kate's interest in him as, (what's that old-fashioned word?) a flirtation?" "Well?" She hadn't finished making her point, but it appeared Milly couldn't either. "Well, maybe that could do what it often does—at least according to all our carefully constructed rules and expectations—and instead of putting Kate off, would actually make her feelings stronger." The idea was vivid, but the girl only stared, beautifully.

"Kate's own sentiment? Oh, she didn't speak of that. I don't think," she added as if she had been unconsciously giving a wrong impression, "I don't think Mrs. Condrip imagines she's in love."

Translation

"Kate's feelings? Oh, she didn't mention them. I don't believe," she added, as if she had inadvertently misled, "I don't believe Mrs. Condrip thinks she's in love."

It made Mrs. Stringham stare in turn. "Then what's her fear?" "Well, only the fact of Mr.

Densher's possibly keeping it up himself—the fear of some final consequence from that. "Oh," said Susie, intellectually a bit disconcerted—"she looks far ahead!" Stringham's question seemed to make her think. "What's she scared of?" "Well, the possibility of Mr.

Densher continuing things—the fear of how it might all end." "Oh," Susie replied, a bit intellectually thrown—"she's thinking far ahead!" At this, Milly presented another of her abrupt, indistinct pronouncements. "No—it's only we who are."

Translation

Densher going on with things—the fear of how it might all turn out." "Oh," Susie said, a little intellectually taken aback—"she's thinking far ahead!" At this, Milly offered another of her sudden, unclear statements. "No—it's just us who do."

"Well, let's not be more concerned for them than they are for themselves!" "Certainly not"—the girl readily agreed. Yet a degree of interest lingered; she seemed eager for clarity. "It wasn't about anything Kate herself felt that she was talking."

Translation

"Well, let's not worry about them more than they worry about themselves!" "Of course not," the girl agreed easily. Still, some curiosity remained; she seemed to want a clear answer. "Kate wasn't even talking about anything she felt personally."

"You mean she thinks her sister does not care for him?" It was still as if, for an instant, Milly had to be sure of what she meant; but there it presently was. "If she did care Mrs. Condrip would have told me."

Translation

"You think she believes her sister isn't interested in him?" For a moment, it was as if Milly needed to confirm her own understanding, but then it became clear. "If she cared, Mrs. Condrip would have told me."

What Susan Shepherd seemed hereupon for a little to wonder was why then they had been talking so. "But did you ask her?" "Ah, no!" "Oh!" said Susan Shepherd.

Translation

Susan Shepherd appeared to briefly consider why they had been speaking in the first place. "But did you ask her?" "Oh, no!" "Oh!" said Susan Shepherd.

Milly, however, easily explained that she wouldn't have asked her for the world.

Translation

Milly, on the other hand, clarified without difficulty that she wouldn't have asked her, not for anything.

Chapter 10

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

Lord Mark visited a woman and Susan Shepherd at their hotel. He visited once and found them home, visited a second time and missed them, and visited a third time, finding them again.

Later, at a gathering in a large historic house, Milly is introduced to new people and walks through various rooms. She accepts and drinks a cup of iced coffee. A servant takes her empty plate. Milly and Susan Shepherd have a brief conversation about whether Milly asked a Mrs. Condrip a question.

Milly talks with Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud). Milly tells Mrs. Lowder that Kate Croy is the most beautiful person present, and Mrs. Lowder responds. During their conversation, Milly observes Lord Mark walking back and forth nearby. Mrs. Lowder tells Milly she must stay and make her home with them, that she can have any position she wants, and that she must help with Kate because their friendship is important.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

Excellent. This is a rich and complex excerpt, characteristic of the style of Henry James (this text is from his novel *The Wings of the Dove*). The introductory paragraph you've provided, while modern in tone, serves as an excellent thematic overture to the analysis of the original text. It captures the sense of inevitability and a carefully orchestrated conclusion, which is precisely what the Jamesian passage explores in intricate detail.

Here is a literary analysis focusing on themes, character developments, and major literary ideas.

---

### Literary Analysis of the Text

This passage is a masterful exercise in psychological realism, immersing the reader in the intricate consciousness of its protagonist, Milly Theale. It depicts a moment of apparent social triumph that is simultaneously a climax of understanding, revealing the delicate and often ruthless machinery of high society. The text is built on a foundation of observation versus reality, artifice versus genuine emotion, and the subtle interplay of power among its characters.

#### **Major Themes**

**1. The Social World as a Work of Art and Artifice:** The most dominant theme is the framing of social life as a carefully constructed artistic composition. The grand house and its gathering are described as an "almost extravagantly grand Watteau-composition," immediately associating the scene with the idealized, picturesque, and slightly melancholic paintings of the Rococo artist Antoine Watteau. This is not a raw, authentic experience; it is curated and aestheticized.

This theme is reinforced through a dense web of artistic metaphors: * **Lord Mark as a Tool:** He is a "suspended skein of silk within reach of the broiderer's hand," and Aunt Maud's mind is a "free-moving shuttle" that "worked [him] in." This reduces a person to a beautiful but passive material to be used in a larger design. * **Kate as an Object of Curiosity:** Milly sees Kate as a "beautiful stranger," a "figure to be waited for, named and fitted." Kate loses her personal identity and becomes an aesthetic object, someone whose primary function is to be whatever "the occasion... demanded when its demand was highest." She is made for "great social uses," implying she is a beautiful, valuable piece to be strategically deployed.

**2. The Tension Between Protection and Suffocation:** Milly, a "poor shaky maiden," is the object of intense attention and, ostensibly, protection. Mrs. Lowder's speech is a cascade of comforting assurances: "You must stay... let us all think for you a little, take care of you and watch over you." Milly feels the "enveloping flap of a protective mantle."

However, this protection is double-edged. The mantle has the "weight of an eastern carpet," and Milly astutely notes that a magic carpet "was a thing to be on rather than under." This powerful image suggests that the offered shelter could easily become a trap, a weight that smothers her autonomy. The constant social management, while appearing benevolent, threatens to suffocate her.

**3. Manipulation and the Unspoken Language of Power:** The true currency of this world is not what is said, but what is understood without words. The narrative is driven by subtext and tacit agreements. Lord Mark seems to communicate with Milly at Mrs. Lowder's expense, a silent understanding "which she would have none of." He places her under "no obligation whatever," but this very lack of demand is its own form of sophisticated social maneuvering.

Mrs. Lowder's impassioned speech, while seemingly sincere in its affection, is also a strategic move. Milly understands that her aunt is primarily "planning for Kate," and that Milly's own "prosperity" is now required for this larger plan to succeed. Affection and strategy are inextricably linked.

#### **Character Developments**

**Milly Theale:** Milly is the central consciousness, and her development is one of dawning, and troubling, awareness. She arrives at the scene in a state of charmed wonder, seeing the experience as a "splendid cluster, an offering like an armful of the rarest flowers." However, as the passage progresses, her perception sharpens. She sips her iced coffee—a small, grounding detail amid the grandeur—and begins to dissect the scene with a "sharp doubt of her wisdom." She understands that she herself is "the matter," the focal point around which these complex social gears are turning. She is both a participant and a detached analyst, a combination of American innocence and a deeply perceptive intellect.

**Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud):** Characterized as a "natural force," Mrs. Lowder is the architect of the scene. Her happiness stems from the perfect alignment of her "affections and her views." She is not simply a cold manipulator; she genuinely seems to love the people she is arranging. However, her love is pragmatic and directorial. Her entire speech to Milly is an act of absorption, an attempt to fold Milly into her grand design for Kate. She is a powerful, formidable woman whose benevolence is inseparable from her will to control.

**Kate Croy:** Viewed entirely through Milly's fascinated and slightly wary eyes, Kate is an enigma. Her defining quality is her social malleability—the ability to become a "beautiful stranger," an object perfectly suited to its frame. This makes her both alluring and unsettling. She is the ultimate social creature, whose identity is fluid and performative. Milly's observation that Kate appears more "objective" after her connection to Merton Densher is revealed suggests that Kate's emotional detachment is a key part of her power and her tragedy.

**Lord Mark:** He is a connoisseur of the social game. He is aware he is being "worked in" to Mrs. Lowder's plan and seems to consent to it, yet he also establishes a separate, silent rapport with Milly. He represents the sophisticated, slightly world-weary insider who understands all the rules and can play his part with effortless grace.

#### **Major Literary Ideas and Techniques**

**1. The Jamesian Sentence and Psychological Depth:** The style is the substance. The long, subordinate-clause-laden sentences are not merely complex; they mirror the process of human consciousness. They track Milly's thoughts as they twist, qualify, and build upon one another, capturing the nuances of her perception in real-time. A simple observation blooms into a complex analysis of motive and meaning, all within a single, flowing sentence.

**2. The Central Consciousness:** By filtering the entire event through Milly's perspective, James creates a sense of profound subjectivity. We don't get an objective account of a party; we get Milly's *experience* of it. This technique makes the emotional and psychological stakes feel incredibly high, as the reader is locked into her struggle to interpret a world that is both dazzling and threatening.

**3. Symbolism and Metaphor:** As discussed in the themes, the passage is laden with symbolic language. The "parenthesis" that is about to close signifies the end of a brief, magical period and a return to a harsher reality. The "iced coffee" serves as a moment of cool clarity amidst the "spiritual ebriety" of the day. These metaphors elevate the narrative from a simple social scene into a rich tapestry of meaning.

### **Conclusion**

This excerpt is a microcosm of Henry James's broader literary project. It demonstrates how a seemingly pleasant social gathering can be a battleground of wills, a theater of performance, and a complex moral landscape. Through the sensitive and intelligent consciousness of Milly Theale, the reader is made to see the "admirable picture" of high society for what it is: a beautiful, meticulously crafted, and potentially suffocating work of art. The initial paragraph's foreshadowing of a "final act" is perfectly realized in the text, as Milly's dawning comprehension feels like the turning of a key, locking her into a destiny that has been elegantly, and relentlessly, arranged for her.

Now, it was almost over. The weight had become familiar. It settled in her chest, a dull ache that she had learned to ignore. Like a forgotten bruise. She'd known for a long time this would happen, even before she'd allowed herself to admit it. She remembered the first time she'd thought it, a fleeting, rebellious whisper. Then the thought had bloomed. It took root, spread, until it choked out everything else. And now, everything was arranged. The final act was imminent. The script was written, the stage set. The actors were in place, waiting for their cues.

Lord Mark looked at her to-day in particular as if to wring from her a confession that she had originally done him injustice; and he was entitled to whatever there might be in it of advantage or merit that his intention really in a manner took effect: he cared about something, that is, after all, sufficiently to make her feel absurdly as if she were confessing—all the while it was quite the case that neither justice nor injustice was what had been in question between them. He had presented himself at the hotel, had found her and had found Susan Shepherd at home, had been "civil" to Susan—it was just that shade, and Susan's fancy had fondly caught it; and then had come again and missed them, and then had come and found them once more: besides letting them easily see that if it hadn't by this time been the end of everything—which they could feel in the exhausted air, that of the season at its last gasp—the places they might have liked to go to were such as they would have had only to mention. Their feeling was—or at any rate their modest general plea—that there was no place they would have liked to go to; there was only the sense of finding they liked, wherever they were, the place to which they had been brought. Such was highly the case as to their current consciousness—which could be indeed, in an equally eminent degree, but a matter of course; impressions this afternoon having by a happy turn of their wheel been gathered for them into a splendid cluster, an offering like an armful of the rarest flowers.

Translation

Lord Mark scrutinized her today, as if trying to extract a confession that she’d wronged him initially. He seemed to believe he deserved some reward or recognition, as though his plans had actually worked out. He cared enough about something to make her feel ridiculous, as though she were confessing—though in reality, justice or injustice had never been the issue between them. He'd shown up at the hotel, found her and Susan Shepherd in, and been politely cordial to Susan—it was a subtle thing, and Susan had latched onto it eagerly. Then he’d returned and missed them, then come again and found them: and it was also clear that if everything wasn't already ending—which they could sense in the stale atmosphere, the final days of the season—the places they might have wanted to go were places they only had to name. They felt—or at least their modest, general preference was—that there was no place they wanted to go; they only liked where they were, wherever they’d been brought. This was particularly true of their present experience—which could just as easily have been inevitable; this afternoon's impressions having, by a fortunate turn of events, come together for them in a glorious collection, like a bouquet of the rarest flowers.

They were in presence of the offering—they had been led up to it; and if it had been still their habit to look at each other across distances for increase of unanimity his hand would have been silently named between them as the hand applied to the wheel. He had administered the touch that, under light analysis, made the difference—the difference of their not having lost, as Susie on the spot and at the hour phrased it again and again, both for herself and for such others as the question might concern, so beautiful and interesting an experience; the difference also, in fact, of Mrs. Lowder's not having lost it either, though it was with Mrs. Lowder, superficially, they had come, and though it was further with that lady that our young woman was directly engaged during the half-hour or so of her most agreeably inward response to the scene.

Translation

They were confronted with the offering—they’d been brought to it; and if they were still in the habit of seeking each other’s agreement from afar, his hand would have been silently identified between them as the hand that turned the wheel. He had applied the touch that, upon closer inspection, made all the difference—the difference of their not having lost, as Susie repeatedly put it, there and then, both for herself and anyone else who might care, such a beautiful and interesting experience; the difference also, in fact, of Mrs. Lowder not having lost it either, though it was with Mrs. Lowder, superficially, that they’d come, and though it was further with that lady that our young woman was directly occupied during the half-hour or so of her most pleasant inward response to the scene.

"You mean she thinks her sister doesn't care about him?" Milly hesitated for a moment, as if she needed to be certain of her own meaning, but then the idea became clear. "If she cared, Mrs. Condrip would have told me."

Translation

"You mean, she believes her sister doesn't have any feelings for him?" Milly paused, as though she had to verify her own understanding, but then the thought solidified. "If she did, Mrs. Condrip would have shared that with me."

Susan Shepherd seemed momentarily puzzled by why they had been discussing this. "But did you ask her?" "Oh, no!" "Oh!" said Susan Shepherd.

Translation

Susan Shepherd appeared briefly confused about the reason for their conversation. "But did you ask her?" "Oh, no!" "Oh!" said Susan Shepherd.

However, Milly readily explained that she wouldn't have asked her for anything. BOOK FIVE X Lord Mark seemed to be trying, today in particular, to make her admit that she had initially misjudged him.

Translation

Milly, though, was quick to clarify that she wouldn't have gone to her for anything. *BOOK FIVE X* Lord Mark appeared especially keen, today, on making her concede that she'd formed a mistaken first impression of him.

He acted as though he deserved any benefit or recognition that might come from his actions actually achieving their intended effect. He cared about something, enough to make her feel absurdly like she was confessing something, even though neither fairness nor unfairness was the actual issue between them. He had visited the hotel, found her and Susan Shepherd at home, and been "polite" to Susan—that precise shade of politeness, which had captured Susan's attention. Then he had come again and missed them, then come again and found them once more.

Translation

He behaved as if he was owed whatever good or praise might result from his actions working out the way he wanted. He seemed to care, and it made her feel as though she was admitting to something, though fairness or unfairness wasn't what they were really talking about. He had gone to the hotel, found her and Susan Shepherd there, and been "polite" to Susan—that particular brand of politeness that had gotten Susan's attention. Then he'd come back and missed them, then come back again and found them once more.

Moreover, he let them easily understand that if the season weren't ending—which they could sense in the exhausted atmosphere, as the season's last breath—they could have suggested places they wanted to visit, but only with a word. Their feeling was—or at least their modest general defense—that there was no place they particularly wished to go. They only felt they enjoyed wherever they happened to be. This was very much the case with their current experience, which could indeed, and to an equal extent, have been a matter of course.

Translation

Furthermore, he made it clear to them that, if the season weren't winding down—which they could feel in the weariness, like the season's final breath—they could have simply named places they wanted to go. Their position—or at least their quiet, overall defense—was that there was no specific place they desired. They simply felt content where they were. This was certainly true of their present situation, which, in fact, could just as easily have been commonplace.

This afternoon, by a fortunate twist, their experiences had gathered into a beautiful collection, an offering like a bouquet of the rarest flowers. They were in the presence of this offering, they had been led to it. If they still communicated with each other across distances to confirm their agreement, his name, in silence, would have been mentioned as the person who had set the process in motion. He had been the one who had made the difference, a difference which, under close examination, was that they hadn't lost—as Susie immediately and repeatedly declared, for herself and others concerned—such a beautiful and interesting experience.

Translation

This afternoon, by a stroke of luck, their experiences had coalesced into a stunning whole, a gift like a gathering of the rarest blossoms. They were present for this gift, they had been brought to it. If they still communicated with each other at a distance to confirm their shared understanding, his name, in silence, would have been invoked as the one who initiated the process. He was the one who had made the difference, a difference which, upon close inspection, was that they hadn't lost—as Susie immediately and repeatedly asserted, for herself and others involved—such a beautiful and engaging experience.

Also, Mrs. Lowder hadn't lost it either, although they had come with her, and although our young woman was directly occupied with Mrs. Lowder during the half-hour or so of her most pleasant inward response to the scene. The great historic house had, for Milly, beyond terrace and garden, as the centre of an almost extravagantly grand Watteau-composition, a tone as of old gold kept "down" by the quality of the air, summer full-flushed, but attuned to the general perfect taste.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder hadn’t lost it either, even though they had come with her. The young woman was directly occupied with Mrs. Lowder during the half hour or so of her most pleasant inward response to the scene. For Milly, the great historic house was, beyond terrace and garden, the center of an almost extravagantly grand Watteau-composition. It had a tone of old gold that was kept "down" by the quality of the air, summer full-flushed, but attuned to the general perfect taste.

Much, by her measure, for the previous hour, appeared, in connection with this revelation of it, to have happened to her—a quantity expressed in introductions of charming new people, in walks through halls of armour, of pictures, of cabinets, of tapestry, of tea-tables, in an assault of reminders that this largeness of style was the sign of appointed felicity. The largeness of style was the great containing vessel, while everything else, the pleasant personal affluence, the easy, murmurous welcome, the honoured age of illustrious host and hostess, all at once so distinguished and so plain, so public and so shy, became but this or that element of the infusion. The elements melted together and seasoned the draught, the essence of which might have struck the girl as distilled into the small cup of iced coffee she had vaguely accepted from somebody, while a fuller flood, somehow, kept bearing her up—all the freshness of response of her young life the freshness of the first and only prime. What had perhaps brought on just now a kind of climax was the fact of her appearing to make out, through Aunt Maud, what was really the matter.

Translation

By her estimation, a great deal had occurred in the past hour, connected to this revelation. It was measured in the form of charming new people being introduced, walks through rooms filled with armor, paintings, cabinets, tapestries, and tea tables, and an onslaught of reminders that this grand style was the sign of promised happiness. This grand style was the vast container, while everything else—the pleasant personal wealth, the easy, murmuring welcome, the honored age of the illustrious host and hostess, so distinguished yet so unassuming, so public and so shy—became merely elements of the mixture. These elements dissolved together, seasoning the drink. The essence of this drink might have struck the girl as having been distilled into the small cup of iced coffee she had vaguely accepted from someone, while a fuller flood somehow kept her afloat, all the freshness of her young life, the freshness of its only prime. What had perhaps just now brought on a kind of climax was the fact that she seemed to understand, through Aunt Maud, what was truly the issue.

It couldn't be less than a climax for a poor shaky maiden to find it put to her of a sudden that she herself was the matter—for that was positively what, on Mrs. Lowder's part, it came to. Everything was great, of course, in great pictures, and it was doubtless precisely a part of the brilliant life—since the brilliant life, as one had faintly figured it, clearly was humanly led—that all impressions within its area partook of its brilliancy; still, letting that pass, it fairly stamped an hour as with the official seal for one to be able to take in so comfortably one's companion's broad blandness. "You must stay among us—you must stay; anything else is impossible and ridiculous; you don't know yet, no doubt—you can't; but you will soon enough: you can stay in any position." It had been as the murmurous consecration to follow the murmurous welcome; and even if it were but part of Aunt Maud's own spiritual ebriety—for the dear woman, one could see, was spiritually "keeping" the day—it served to Milly, then and afterwards, as a high-water mark of the imagination.

Translation

It couldn't be less than a climax for a poor, shaky maiden to suddenly realize that she herself was the issue—because that was exactly what it came down to, on Mrs. Lowder's part. Everything was grand, of course, in the grand scheme of things, and it was undoubtedly part of this brilliant life—since the brilliant life, as one had vaguely imagined it, was clearly a human experience—that all impressions within it took on its brilliance. Still, putting that aside, it truly stamped an hour as official, to be able to take in so comfortably one's companion's broad blandness. "You must stay among us—you must stay; anything else is impossible and ridiculous; you don't know yet, no doubt—you can't; but you will soon enough: you can stay in any position." It was the murmurous consecration that followed the murmurous welcome; and even if it was just part of Aunt Maud's own spiritual intoxication—for the dear woman, one could see, was spiritually "keeping" the day—it served Milly, then and afterwards, as a high-water mark of the imagination.

For Milly, the great historic house, beyond its terrace and garden, was the focal point of an almost excessively grand scene reminiscent of a Watteau painting. It had a certain quality, like old gold muted by the atmosphere, a summer at its peak, yet perfectly in tune with the refined taste of everything around. Much had seemed to occur to her in the past hour regarding this place—a quantity expressed in the introductions to charming new people, walks through halls filled with armor, paintings, cabinets, tapestries, and tea tables. The whole experience was a barrage of reminders that this grand style was a symbol of her destined happiness.

Translation

For Milly, beyond the terrace and garden, the grand, historic house was the central element of an almost unbearably extravagant scene, like something out of a Watteau painting. It possessed a quality, like antique gold mellowed by the air, a summer at its zenith, perfectly in keeping with the surrounding elegance. Much had occurred to her in the last hour relating to this place—a volume of experience expressed through introductions to charming new acquaintances, strolls through halls filled with armor, paintings, cabinets, tapestries, and tea tables. The whole experience served to remind her that this grand style was a symbol of her impending happiness.

This grand style was the overarching element, while everything else—the pleasant personal wealth, the welcoming atmosphere, the respected age of the distinguished hosts, who were at once so distinguished and so ordinary, so public and so reserved—became simply another component of the mix. These components blended together and flavored the experience. Its essence may have crystallized for her in the small cup of iced coffee she vaguely accepted, while a larger current seemed to buoy her up—all the fresh responses of her young life, at its freshest, most vital stage. What may have brought this to a head was the realization, through her Aunt Maud, of what was truly happening.

Translation

This grandeur defined the experience, and everything else—the comfortable fortune, the friendly ambiance, the venerable age of the esteemed hosts, who were both so distinguished and so ordinary, so open and so private—became just another aspect. These elements merged, adding flavor to the moment. Its essence may have crystallized for her in the small cup of iced coffee she barely noticed, while a larger force lifted her up—all the youthful reactions of her young life, at its most vibrant. What may have brought this to a head was the realization, through her Aunt Maud, of what was really occurring.

It could be nothing less than a climax for a fragile young woman to suddenly realize that she herself was the focus—because that was positively what Mrs. Lowder’s words amounted to. Everything was grand, of course, like the great paintings, and it was surely part of the brilliant life—since the brilliant life, as Milly had vaguely imagined it, was clearly a human one—that all impressions within it shared its brilliance. Nonetheless, it certainly marked the hour when she could comfortably understand her companion's broad, placid manner.

Translation

The whole thing must have felt like a turning point for a young woman who was easily overwhelmed. To suddenly realize she was the main attraction—that’s what Mrs. Lowder’s words undeniably suggested. Everything was extravagant, just like the important paintings, and it clearly belonged to that dazzling world. In Milly's hazy imaginings, that meant a brilliant life—since the brilliant life was, without question, a human one—where all experiences shared that brilliance. All the same, it definitely marked the moment she could finally understand her companion's relaxed, calm demeanor.

"You must stay with us—you must; anything else is impossible and ridiculous. You don't know it yet, no doubt—you can’t; but you will soon enough: you can stay in any position.” These were the words of approval that followed the welcoming murmur. And even if it was only part of Aunt Maud's own spiritual exuberance—for the dear woman, one could see, was spiritually “celebrating” the day—it served Milly, then and later, as a high point for her imagination. It was to be the end of the short parenthesis which had begun but the other day at Lancaster Gate with Lord Mark's informing her that she was a "success"—the key thus again struck; and though no distinct, no numbered revelations had crowded in, there had, as we have seen, been plenty of incident for the space and the time.

Translation

"You absolutely must stay with us, it's essential, any other option is out of the question, and frankly, ridiculous. You probably don't realize this yet—how could you?—but you will soon enough: you can be anything here." This was the official blessing that followed the initial greetings. Even if it was just Aunt Maud's own effusive spirit at play—because, as anyone could see, the dear woman was "celebrating" the day in her own way—it still became a pivotal moment in Milly's mind, both then and later. It was the conclusion of that brief period that had started the other day at Lancaster Gate, when Lord Mark had informed her that she was a "success"—the key had been turned once more. And though no clear, distinct revelations had flooded in, as we've already seen, there had been more than enough going on for the time allowed.

There had been thrice as much, and all gratuitous and genial—if, in portions, not exactly hitherto the revelation—as three unprepared weeks could have been expected to produce. Mrs. Lowder had improvised a "rush" for them, but out of elements, as Milly was now a little more freely aware, somewhat roughly combined. Therefore if at this very instant she had her reasons for thinking of the parenthesis as about to close—reasons completely personal—she had on behalf of her companion a divination almost as deep.

Translation

There had been three times as much, all unearned and friendly, even if, at times, it hadn’t quite been the revelation it should have been—not that three weeks could reasonably have been expected to produce that. Mrs. Lowder had arranged a whirlwind, but with ingredients that, as Milly was now somewhat more aware, hadn't been fully refined. Therefore, if at that very moment she had her own personal reasons for thinking the parenthesis was about to close, she had almost as strong a sense of what was coming for her friend.

The parenthesis would close with this admirable picture, but the admirable picture still would show Aunt Maud as not absolutely sure either if she herself were destined to remain in it. What she was doing, Milly might even not have escaped seeming to see, was to talk herself into a sublimer serenity while she ostensibly talked Milly. It was fine, the girl fully felt, the way she did talk her, little as, at bottom, our young woman needed it or found other persuasions at fault. It was in particular during the minutes of her grateful absorption of iced coffee—qualified by a sharp doubt of her wisdom—that she most had in view Lord Mark's relation to her being there, or at least to the question of her being amused at it.

Translation

The parenthesis would close with this admirable picture, but the admirable picture still wouldn't entirely reflect Aunt Maud's certainty about her own place within it. Milly might even seem to see that what Aunt Maud was doing was talking herself into a more elevated sense of calm, ostensibly while talking to Milly. The girl found her aunt's way of talking to her to be excellent, even though, deep down, the young woman didn't need it or believe other forms of persuasion were failing. It was especially during the moments when she was gratefully absorbing iced coffee—tinged with a sharp doubt about her own good sense—that she most considered Lord Mark's connection to her presence, or at least to the question of her enjoyment of it.

It wouldn't have taken much by the end of five minutes quite to make her feel that this relation was charming. It might, once more, simply have been that everything, anything, was charming when one was so justly and completely charmed; but, frankly, she had not supposed anything so serenely sociable could define itself between them as the friendly understanding that was at present somehow in the air. They were, many of them together, near the marquee that had been erected on a stretch of sward as a temple of refreshment and that happened to have the property—which was all to the good of making Milly think of a "durbar"; her iced coffee had been a consequence of this connection, in which, further, the bright company scattered about fell thoroughly into place. Certain of its members might have represented the contingent of "native princes"—familiar, but scarce the less grandly gregarious term!—and Lord Mark would have done for one of these even though for choice he but presented himself as a supervisory friend of the family.

Translation

By the end of five minutes, it wouldn't have taken much to make her feel this relationship was charming. It might have been, once again, that anything and everything was charming when she was so justifiably and completely charmed. But frankly, she hadn't anticipated something so serenely sociable could define itself between them, like the friendly understanding currently in the air. They were, many of them together, near the marquee erected on a stretch of lawn as a refreshment temple, which happened to have the effect—which was all to the good—of making Milly think of a “durbar.” Her iced coffee was a consequence of this association, and the bright company scattered about fit in perfectly. Some of its members could have represented the contingent of “native princes”—familiar, but still grandly gregarious! And Lord Mark could have passed for one of these, even though, by choice, he presented himself as a supervisory friend of the family.

The Lancaster Gate family, he clearly intended, in which he included its American recruits, and included above all Kate Croy—a young person blessedly easy to take care of. She knew people, and people knew her, and she was the handsomest thing there—this last a declaration made by Milly, in a sort of soft mid-summer madness, a straight skylark-flight of charity, to Aunt Maud. It was time for the brief interlude that had begun recently at Lancaster Gate, when Lord Mark told her she was a "success" to end. The revelation was again brought to light.

Translation

He clearly intended to include the Lancaster Gate family, which meant the American additions as well, and most of all, Kate Croy—a young woman who was blessedly easy to care for. She knew people, and people knew her, and she was the most beautiful person present—this last being a declaration Milly made to Aunt Maud in a kind of gentle, midsummer madness, an act of sheer generosity. The brief interlude that had begun recently at Lancaster Gate, when Lord Mark told her she was a "success," was now over. The revelation was brought to light once more.

Although no specific revelations had crowded in, there had, as we know, been plenty of activity in that time. There had been three times as much, all pleasant and spontaneous, although not entirely revelatory, as could have been expected in those three weeks. Mrs. Lowder had arranged a "rush" for them, though, as Milly was now starting to understand, the pieces were somewhat haphazardly put together.

Translation

Even though nothing concrete had come to light, a great deal had been happening in the interim, as we know. There had been a flurry of activity, three times what one might have predicted for those three weeks, and it was all enjoyable and unplanned, if not exactly earth-shattering. Mrs. Lowder had organized things for them at a frantic pace, even if, as Milly was beginning to realize, the arrangements were rather loosely conceived.

Therefore, at that very moment, if she had her reasons for thinking the interlude was about to close—personal reasons—she had a near-equal intuition for her companion. The interlude would end with this lovely scene, but the lovely scene would still show Aunt Maud unsure if she herself was meant to stay in it. Milly might have even appeared to see that what she was doing was talking herself into a more peaceful calm while she was ostensibly talking to Milly. It was wonderful, the girl fully recognized, the way she spoke to her, even though the young woman, at heart, didn't need it or find the other persuasive arguments lacking.

Translation

So, at that moment, if she felt the break was ending—and she had her own reasons for that—she also had a nearly identical feeling about her aunt. The break would end with this beautiful moment, but the beautiful moment would still show Aunt Maud unsure if she belonged.
