Milly might have even seen that what she was doing was calming herself down while she was supposedly talking to Milly. It was wonderful, Milly knew, the way her aunt spoke to her, even though, deep down, the younger woman didn't need it and didn't think the other arguments were very convincing.

It was particularly during the moments of her grateful enjoyment of iced coffee—tempered by a sharp doubt of her wisdom—that she most considered Lord Mark's relationship to her being there, or at least to the question of her being amused by it. It wouldn't have taken much, by the end of five minutes, to make her feel that this relationship was delightful. It might, again, have simply been that everything, anything, was delightful when one was so rightfully and completely charmed; but, frankly, she hadn't supposed anything so peacefully sociable could define itself between them as the friendly understanding that was somehow present. Many of them were together, near the tent erected on a stretch of grass as a place of refreshment, which happened to have the property—which was beneficial—of making Milly think of a "durbar"; her iced coffee had been a result of this connection, where, further, the bright company scattered about fit in perfectly.

Translation

It was especially when she was gratefully enjoying her iced coffee—though she was also sharply doubting her judgment—that she most thought about Lord Mark's connection to her being there, or at least to whether she found it amusing. It wouldn't have taken long, within five minutes, for her to feel that their connection was delightful. It could have been that everything, anything, was delightful when she was so rightly and completely charmed; but, honestly, she hadn't expected them to settle into such peacefully social, friendly understanding. Many of them were together, near the refreshment tent set up on the grass, which—helpfully—made Milly think of a "durbar"; her iced coffee had come about because of this association, where the cheerful company scattered about fit in perfectly.

Some of its members could have represented the group of "native princes"—a familiar, but no less grandly sociable term!—and Lord Mark would have been one of them even if he only presented himself as a supervising friend of the family. The Lancaster Gate family, he clearly intended, which he included its American recruits, and especially Kate Croy—a young woman thankfully easy to take care of. She knew people, and people knew her, and she was the most beautiful person there—this was a statement Milly made, in a kind of soft, mid-summer delirium, a straightforward, soaring act of kindness, to Aunt Maud. Kate had, for her new friend's eyes, the extraordinary and attaching property of appearing at a given moment to show as a beautiful stranger, to cut her connections and lose her identity, letting the imagination for the time make what it would of them—make her merely a person striking from afar, more and more pleasing as one watched, but who was above all a subject for curiosity.

Translation

Some of them could have stood in for the "native princes"—a familiar, yet still grandly social phrase!—and Lord Mark would have been among them, even if he was simply presenting himself as a friendly supervisor to the family. He was clearly including the Lancaster Gate family, which meant also the American recruits, especially Kate Croy—a young woman that was, thankfully, easy to care for. She knew people, and people knew her, and she was the most beautiful person there—this was something Milly said to Aunt Maud in a kind of soft, mid-summer delirium, a straightforward, soaring act of kindness. Kate had, for her new friend's eyes, the extraordinary and captivating quality of appearing at a given moment as a beautiful stranger, cutting her ties and losing her identity, allowing the imagination, for the time, to create whatever it wished—making her merely someone striking from afar, increasingly pleasing as one watched, but who was, above all, a subject for curiosity.

Nothing could have given her, as a party to a relation, a greater freshness than this sense—which sprang up at its own hours—of being as curious about her as if one hadn't known her. It had sprung up, we have gathered, as soon as Milly had seen her after hearing from Mrs. Stringham of her knowledge of Merton Densher; she had looked then other and, as Milly knew the real critical mind would call it, more objective; and our young woman had foreseen it of her, on the spot, that she would often look so again. It was exactly what she was doing this afternoon; and Milly, who had amusements of thought that were like the secrecies of a little girl playing with dolls when conventionally "too big," could almost settle to the game of what one would suppose her, how one would place her, if one didn't know her.

Translation

Nothing could have given her, as a participant in their relationship, greater invigoration than this feeling—that arose spontaneously—of being as fascinated by her as if she were a complete unknown. As we have seen, it appeared the instant Milly saw her after Mrs. Stringham told her of Kate's connection to Merton Densher. At that moment, Kate appeared different, more objective, as a truly critical mind would say. Our young woman had known immediately that Kate would often appear this way. It was precisely what she was doing this afternoon. And Milly, whose private thoughts were like the secrets of a little girl playing with dolls when she was supposedly "too old," could almost surrender to the game of guessing what she was like, how one would categorize her, if one didn't know her.

She became thus, intermittently, a figure conditioned only by the great facts of aspect, a figure to be waited for, named and fitted. This was doubtless but a way of feeling that it was of her essence to be peculiarly what the occasion, whatever it might be, demanded when its demand was highest. There were probably ways enough, on these lines, for such a consciousness; another of them would be, for instance, to say that she was made for great social uses. Milly was not wholly sure that she herself knew what great social uses might be—unless, as a good example, exerting just that sort of glamour in just that sort of frame were one of them: she would have fallen back on knowing sufficiently that they existed at all events for her friend.

Translation

Thus, at times, Kate became a figure defined solely by her outward appearance, a figure to be anticipated, labeled, and categorized. This was likely just a way of feeling that it was her essential nature to be whatever the situation, no matter what it was, required when that requirement was most intense. There were probably enough paths for such a consciousness to follow; another would be, for instance, to say that she was made for significant social purposes. Milly wasn't entirely sure what those significant social purposes might be—unless, as a prime example, exerting precisely that kind of glamour within precisely that kind of setting was one of them: she would have been satisfied knowing that, at the very least, they existed for her friend.

It imputed a primness, all round, to be reduced but to saying, by way of a translation of one's amusement, that she was always so right—since that, too often, was what the insupportables themselves were; yet it was, in overflow to Aunt Maud, what she had to content herself withal—save for the lame enhancement of saying she was lovely. It served, all the same, the purpose, strengthened the bond that for the time held the two ladies together, distilled in short its drop of rose-colour for Mrs. Lowder's own view. That was really the view Milly had, for most of the rest of the occasion, to give herself to immediately taking in; but it didn't prevent the continued play of those swift cross-lights, odd beguilements of the mind, at which we have already glanced.

Translation

It suggested a certain primness, all around, to be reduced to simply saying, as a way of expressing one's amusement, that she was always so right—since that, too often, was how the insufferable ones themselves behaved; yet it was, in addition to Aunt Maud, what she had to settle for—except for the weak satisfaction of saying she was lovely. It served, all the same, the purpose, strengthening the bond that for the moment held the two ladies together, and in short, distilled its drop of rose-tinted hue for Mrs. Lowder's own perception. That was really the perspective Milly had, for most of the remainder of the occasion, to immediately devote herself to; but it didn't prevent the continued play of those swift, shifting perspectives, the odd mental seductions, which we have already touched upon.

For her new friend, Kate possessed the remarkable and captivating ability to present herself as a beautiful stranger, severing her ties and obscuring her identity at will. This allowed the imagination to freely construct her, transforming her into a striking figure, increasingly alluring the more she was observed, and above all, a source of intrigue. This quality gave their relationship an incredible freshness – the sense, which arose unexpectedly, of being as curious about her as if they had just met. This feeling had emerged, we understand, immediately after Milly saw Kate again after Mrs.

Translation

For Milly's new friend, Kate had the striking and charming gift of appearing as a beautiful enigma, able to cut ties and conceal her identity whenever she chose. This allowed the imagination to run wild, crafting her into a compelling figure, more and more captivating the more one looked at her, and above all, a source of mystery. This trait lent their relationship a remarkable vitality – the sudden feeling of being as intrigued by her as if they'd just been introduced. This feeling, we know, arose the moment Milly saw Kate again after Mrs.

Stringham had told her about her connection to Merton Densher. Kate had appeared different then, and – as Milly knew the truly discerning mind would recognize – more objective. Milly had immediately anticipated that Kate would often look this way again. That was precisely what she was doing that afternoon.

Translation

Stringham's mention of Kate's connection to Merton Densher had changed things. Kate seemed altered then, and—as Milly understood a keen mind would—more impartial. Milly had known right away that Kate would adopt this demeanor often. And that was exactly what she was doing that afternoon.

And Milly, whose thoughts were her private amusement, like a little girl playing with dolls when she was supposedly "too old," could almost immerse herself in the game of speculating about Kate, wondering how she might be perceived if they were strangers. Thus, Kate became, from time to time, a figure defined solely by her appearance, someone to be anticipated, labeled, and understood. This was likely just a way of sensing that her very essence was to be exactly what the situation, whatever it may be, required at its most demanding. There were likely many avenues for such an awareness.

Translation

And Milly, who kept her thoughts to herself as a private pleasure, much like a young girl playing with dolls when she was supposedly “grown up,” could almost lose herself in the game of thinking about Kate, wondering how she might be seen if they were strangers. So, from time to time, Kate became a figure defined entirely by how she looked, someone to be anticipated, categorized, and understood. This was probably just a way of sensing that her deepest self was to be precisely what any given circumstance, however difficult, demanded. There were likely many ways to become aware of this.

Another, for example, would be to say that she was destined for significant social purposes. Milly wasn't entirely certain what those great social purposes could be – unless, as a good example, exerting that particular kind of charm in that particular setting was one of them. She would have relied on knowing well enough that, at any rate, her friend possessed them. It seemed a bit stuffy to simply say, as a way of expressing her delight, that Kate was always so "right" – because that was often what the insufferable people themselves were like.

Translation

Another way to put it, for instance, would be to say that Kate was meant for important things in the world. Milly didn't have a clear picture of what those things were—unless, for example, the ability to work her particular charm in a specific situation counted. She would have trusted that, regardless, her friend had those qualities. It felt a little boring to just say, in admiration, that Kate was always so "correct"—because that was often how the most irritating people behaved.

Yet, that was the sentiment she had to offer Aunt Maud, except for the feeble attempt of calling her lovely. Even so, it fulfilled its purpose, strengthening the bond between the two women and adding a touch of rose-tint to Mrs. Lowder's perception. That was the primary perception Milly had to adopt for most of the occasion, but it didn't prevent the continuous interplay of those swift, shifting thoughts, the strange mental distractions that we've already hinted at.

Translation

And yet, that was the extent of what she could offer Aunt Maud, aside from the weak gesture of calling her lovely. Even that served its function, fortifying the connection between them and infusing Mrs. Lowder's view with a rosy hue. This was the dominant impression Milly had to maintain throughout the gathering, but it didn't halt the ceaseless activity of those quick, fluctuating thoughts, the unsettling mental diversions we've already mentioned.

Mrs. Lowder herself found it enough simply to reply, in respect to Kate, that she was indeed a luxury to take about the world: she expressed no more surprise than that at her "rightness" to-day. Wasn't it by this time sufficiently manifest that it was precisely as the very luxury she was proving that she had, from far back, been appraised and waited for? Crude elation, however, might be kept at bay, and the circumstance none the less demonstrated that they were all swimming together in the blue.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder merely responded, regarding Kate, that she was, in fact, a luxury to be enjoyed in the world. She displayed no greater astonishment at Kate's "perfection" on that day. Hadn't it become clear by now that Kate had been valued and awaited precisely for the luxury she now represented? Even so, any overt excitement could be suppressed, while the situation continued to demonstrate that they were all united and thriving.

It came back to Lord Mark again, as he seemed slowly to pass and repass and conveniently to linger before them; he was personally the note of the blue—like a suspended skein of silk within reach of the broiderer's hand. Aunt Maud's free-moving shuttle took a length of him at rhythmic intervals; and one of the intermixed truths that flickered across to Milly was that he ever so consentingly knew he was being worked in. This was almost like an understanding with her at Mrs. Lowder's expense, which she would have none of; she wouldn't for the world have had him make any such point as that he wouldn't have launched them at Matcham—or whatever it was he had done—only for Aunt Maud's beaux yeux.

Translation

The thought returned to Lord Mark, as he seemed to slowly pass, then pass again, and conveniently linger before them. He was personally the shade of blue, like a suspended skein of silk within reach of the embroiderer's hand. Aunt Maud's freely moving shuttle took up a length of him at rhythmic intervals. One of the truths that flickered across to Milly was that he ever so willingly knew he was being used. This was almost like an understanding with her, at Mrs. Lowder's expense, which she would not have. She wouldn't for the world have had him make any such point, as that he wouldn't have launched them at Matcham—or whatever it was he had done—only for Aunt Maud's benefit.

What he had done, it would have been guessable, was something he had for some time been desired in vain to do; and what they were all now profiting by was a change comparatively sudden, the cessation of hope delayed. What had caused the cessation easily showed itself as none of Milly's business; and she was luckily, for that matter, in no real danger of hearing from him directly that her individual weight had been felt in the scale. Why then indeed was it an effect of his diffused but subdued participation that he might absolutely have been saying to her "Yes, let the dear woman take her own tone? Since she's here she may stay," he might have been adding—"for whatever she can make of it.

Translation

What he had done, it was easy to imagine, was something he'd wanted to do for a while but couldn't. And what they were all benefiting from now was a relatively sudden shift, the end of hope that had been postponed. What caused the end of that hope wasn't any of Milly's concern, and fortunately, she wasn't actually at risk of him telling her directly that her personal influence had mattered. So why was it that his understated but widespread involvement created the impression that he could have been saying to her, "Yes, let the dear woman take charge? Since she's here, she can stay," he might have added—"and do with it what she will."

But you and I are different." Milly knew she was different in truth—his own difference was his own affair; but also she knew that, after all, even at their distinctest, Lord Mark's "tips" in this line would be tacit. He practically placed her—it came round again to that—under no obligation whatever. It was a matter of equal ease, moreover, her letting Mrs. Lowder take a tone.

Translation

"But you and I are different." Milly knew she was different in truth—his own difference was his own affair; but she also knew that, after all, even at their most distinct, Lord Mark's "tips" in this area would be tacit. He practically placed her—it came back to that—under no obligation whatsoever. Moreover, it was equally easy for her to let Mrs. Lowder take a tone.

She might have taken twenty—they would have spoiled nothing. Mrs. Lowder's only response regarding Kate was that she was, indeed, a luxury to have around the world. She showed no more surprise than that about Kate's perfect behavior that day.

Translation

Milly could have taken twenty of them—they wouldn't have ruined anything. Mrs. Lowder's only comment about Kate was that she was, in fact, a luxury to have in the world. She displayed no more surprise than that about Kate's impeccable conduct that day.

Wasn't it clear by now that Kate was valued and expected precisely as the very luxury she was proving to be? Still, they could avoid expressing crude excitement, and that didn't change the fact that they were all thriving. Lord Mark seemed to circle them, pausing and lingering conveniently nearby. He was the embodiment of their good fortune, like a length of silk ready for the embroiderer's needle.

Translation

By this point, wasn't it obvious that Kate was appreciated and anticipated exactly for the luxury she represented? Even so, they could refrain from displaying vulgar enthusiasm, which didn't alter the reality that they were all prospering. Lord Mark seemed to orbit them, stopping and lingering within easy reach. He was the personification of their good fortune, like a bolt of silk awaiting the embroiderer's needle.

Aunt Maud's quick mind seemed to use him periodically, and one of the truths Milly realized was that he willingly knew he was being manipulated. This was almost an understanding with Milly that came at Mrs. Lowder's expense, and Milly wanted none of it. She wouldn't want him to imply that he only launched them at Matcham—or whatever he'd done—because Aunt Maud was so attractive.

Translation

Aunt Maud's sharp intellect appeared to utilize him from time to time, and Milly understood that he knew he was being manipulated. This felt like an unspoken agreement between them, at Mrs. Lowder's cost, which Milly didn't want. She didn't want him to imply he'd only introduced them to Matcham—or whatever he had done—because Aunt Maud was so captivating.

What he'd done, it seemed, was something he'd been asked to do for a while without success; and what they were all benefiting from now was a relatively sudden shift, the end of a delay. What caused the change was clearly none of Milly's concern. Luckily, she wasn't truly at risk of him telling her directly that her influence had been a factor. Still, his subtle involvement gave the impression that he was saying to her, "Yes, let the dear woman set her own tone.

Translation

What he'd done, it appeared, was something he’d been unsuccessfully tasked with for some time. They were all now reaping the rewards of a relatively abrupt shift, the end of a protracted wait. The cause of this change was, obviously, none of Milly’s business. Fortunately, she wasn't in danger of him explicitly claiming that her influence had played a role. Yet, his subtle participation conveyed the impression that he was, in essence, saying to her, "Yes, let the dear woman establish her own atmosphere."

Since she's here, she can stay," he might have added, "for whatever she can get out of it. But you and I are different." Milly knew she was different, but his specific differences were his own. Also, she knew that even when they were most separate, Lord Mark's hints would be unspoken. He put her—it came back to that—under no obligation.

Translation

He might as well have said, "She's here, so she can stay. Let her take what she can. But you and I are different." Milly knew she was different, but his particular distinctions were his own concern. Moreover, she knew that even when they were most apart, Lord Mark's implications would remain unstated. He placed her—it always came back to that—under no requirement.

Moreover, it was just as easy for her to allow Mrs. Lowder to set a tone. She could have set twenty tones—they wouldn't have ruined anything. "You must stay on with us; you can, you know, in any position you like; any, any, any, my dear child"—and her emphasis went deep.

Translation

Furthermore, it was as easy for her to let Mrs. Lowder dictate the atmosphere. Mrs. Lowder could have set twenty atmospheres—none of it would have mattered. "You simply must stay with us; you can, you know, in whatever capacity you desire; any, any, any, my dear child"—and her emphasis was sincere.

"You must make your home with us; and it's really open to you to make the most beautiful one in the world. You mustn't be under a mistake—under any of any sort; and you must let us all think for you a little, take care of you and watch over you. Above all you must help me with Kate, and you must stay a little for her; nothing for a long time has happened to me so good as that you and she should have become friends. It's beautiful; it's great; it's everything.

Translation

"You absolutely must make your home with us, and it's truly open to you to create the most beautiful one imaginable. Don't be mistaken—under any circumstances—and you must let us all think for you a little, take care of you, and watch over you. Above all, you must help me with Kate, and you must stay a while for her; nothing in a long time has pleased me as much as your friendship with her. It's beautiful, it's wonderful, it's everything."

What makes it perfect is that it should have come about through our dear delightful Susie, restored to me, after so many years, by such a miracle. No—that's more charming to me than even your hitting it off with Kate. God has been good to one—positively; for I couldn't, at my age, have made a new friend—undertaken, I mean, out of whole cloth, the real thing. It's like changing one's bankers—after fifty: one doesn't do that.

Translation

What makes it perfect is that it happened because of our dear, delightful Susie, returned to me after so many years, by such a miracle. No—that's more charming to me than even you and Kate getting along. God has been good to me—absolutely; because I couldn't, at my age, have made a new friend—started one from scratch, I mean, the real thing. It's like changing one's bankers—after fifty: one doesn't do that.

That's why Susie has been kept for me, as you seem to keep people in your wonderful country, in lavender and pink paper—coming back at last as straight as out of a fairy-tale and with you as an attendant fairy." Milly hereupon replied appreciatively that such a description of herself made her feel as if pink paper were her dress and lavender its trimming; but Aunt Maud was not to be deterred by a weak joke from keeping it up. Her interlocutress could feel besides that she kept it up in perfect sincerity. She was somehow at this hour a very happy woman, and a part of her happiness might precisely have been that her affections and her views were moving as never before in concert. Unquestionably she loved Susie; but she also loved Kate and loved Lord Mark, loved their funny old host and hostess, loved every one within range, down to the very servant who came to receive Milly's empty iceplate—down, for that matter, to Milly herself, who was, while she talked, really conscious of the enveloping flap of a protective mantle, a shelter with the weight of an eastern carpet.

Translation

That’s why Susie has been preserved for me, just as you seem to keep people in your wonderful country, wrapped in lavender and pink paper—coming back at last, as if out of a fairy tale, with you as an attendant fairy.” Milly then replied appreciatively that this description of herself made her feel as if pink paper were her dress and lavender its trimming; but Aunt Maud wasn't going to be deterred by a weak joke from continuing. Her interlocutor could also feel that she was sincere. She was somehow, at this moment, a very happy woman, and part of her happiness might precisely have been that her affections and her views were moving in concert as never before. She undoubtedly loved Susie, but she also loved Kate and loved Lord Mark, loved their funny old host and hostess, loved everyone within reach, even the servant who came to take Milly's empty ice plate—even, for that matter, Milly herself, who, as she talked, was truly conscious of the enveloping flap of a protective mantle, a shelter with the weight of an eastern carpet.

An eastern carpet, for wishing-purposes of one's own, was a thing to be on rather than under; still, however, if the girl should fail of breath it wouldn't be, she could feel, by Mrs. Lowder's fault. One of the last things she was afterwards to recall of this was Aunt Maud's going on to say that she and Kate must stand together because together they could do anything. It was for Kate of course she was essentially planning; but the plan, enlarged and uplifted now, somehow required Milly's prosperity too for its full operation, just as Milly's prosperity at the same time involved Kate's.

Translation

An eastern carpet, for one's own purposes, was something to be on rather than under. Still, if the girl should fail, it wouldn't be, she could feel, Mrs. Lowder's fault. One of the last things she would afterwards recall was Aunt Maud's continuing on to say that she and Kate must stand together because together they could do anything. It was for Kate, of course, that she was essentially planning. But the plan, enlarged and uplifted now, somehow required Milly's prosperity too for its full operation, just as Milly's prosperity at the same time involved Kate's.

It was nebulous yet, it was slightly confused, but it was unmistakably free and genial, and it made our young woman understand things Kate had said of her aunt's possibilities as well as characterisations that had fallen from Susan Shepherd. One of the most frequent on the lips of the latter had been that dear Maud was a natural force. "You absolutely must stay with us. You can, you know, in any capacity you want.

Translation

It was hazy, a little unclear, but undeniably unrestrained and warm, and it helped our young woman comprehend things Kate had said about her aunt's capabilities, as well as characterizations that had come from Susan Shepherd. One of the latter's most frequent pronouncements had been that dear Maud was a force of nature. "You absolutely must stay with us. You can, you know, in any capacity you wish."

Any, any, any, my dear," she emphasized, her words carrying real weight. "You must make this your home, and you genuinely have the opportunity to make it the most wonderful home imaginable. You mustn't misunderstand—not at all. You must let us all think for you a little, take care of you, and watch over you.

Translation

"Any way, any way, any way, my dear," she stressed, her words carrying real weight. "You must make this your home, and you genuinely have the opportunity to make it the most wonderful home imaginable. You mustn't misunderstand—not at all. You must let us all think for you a little, take care of you, and watch over you.

Above all, you must help me with Kate, and you must stay a while for her. Nothing in recent memory has pleased me as much as your friendship with her. It's beautiful; it's wonderful; it's everything. What makes it perfect is that it happened because of our dear, delightful Susie, returned to me after so many years, by a miracle.

Translation

Above all, you have to help me with Kate, and you have to stay for her sake. Nothing lately has made me so happy as your friendship with her. It's beautiful, it's wonderful, it's everything. What makes it perfect is that it happened because of our dear, delightful Susie, returned to me after so many years, by a miracle.

No—that pleases me even more than your friendship with Kate. God has been good to me, truly. At my age, I couldn't have made a new friend—I mean, a genuine friend from scratch. It's like changing banks after fifty—you just don't do it.

Translation

No, that delights me even more than your friendship with Kate. God has been kind to me, truly. At my age, I wouldn't have been able to make a new friend—I mean, a real friend from the beginning. It's like changing banks after fifty—you just don't do it.

That's why Susie was kept for me, like how you seem to preserve things in your amazing country, wrapped in lavender and pink paper. She's come back, as fresh as a fairy tale, and you're her attendant fairy." Milly responded appreciatively that such a description made her feel as though pink paper was her dress and lavender its trim, but Aunt Maud wouldn't let a small joke stop her. Her listener could also sense that she was being completely sincere. She was, at that moment, a very happy woman, and part of her happiness might have been that her feelings and her thoughts were finally aligned.

Translation

"That's why Susie was kept for me," Aunt Maud said, "the way you seem to preserve things in your remarkable country, wrapped in lavender and pink paper. She's returned, fresh as a fairytale, and you're her attendant angel." Milly replied with a smile, saying it made her feel as though pink paper was her dress and lavender its trim, but Aunt Maud didn't allow the little joke to distract her. Milly could also sense that Aunt Maud was being completely genuine. At that moment, she was a very happy woman, and part of her happiness might have stemmed from the fact that her feelings and thoughts had finally converged.

Without a doubt, she loved Susie, but she also loved Kate and Lord Mark, loved their amusing hosts, and loved everyone within reach, down to the servant who took Milly's empty ice cream plate—even, for that matter, to Milly herself, who was, while she listened, truly aware of the enveloping feeling of a protective cloak, a shelter with the weight of an expensive rug. An expensive rug, for one's own wishes, was something you'd prefer to be on rather than under; yet, if the girl were to struggle, it wouldn't be Mrs. Lowder's fault. One of the last things she would later remember was Aunt Maud continuing to say that she and Kate had to stand together because together they could do anything.

Translation

Undoubtedly, she loved Susie, but she also loved Kate and Lord Mark, loved their entertaining hosts, and loved everyone nearby, down to the servant who cleared Milly's empty ice cream dish—even, for that matter, to Milly herself, who, while listening, felt the encompassing sensation of a protective cloak, a shelter with the weight of an expensive rug. An expensive rug, for one's own desires, was something you'd rather be on than under; still, should the girl struggle, it wouldn't be Mrs. Lowder's fault. One of the last things she would recall later was Aunt Maud continuing to say that she and Kate had to support each other because together they could achieve anything.

She was clearly planning for Kate, of course, but the plan, expanded and elevated now, needed Milly's success to fully work, just as Milly's success at the same time depended on Kate's. It was unclear, a bit confusing, but it was undeniably open and friendly, and it made our young woman understand things Kate had said about her aunt's capabilities, as well as the descriptions Susan Shepherd had offered. One of the most frequent phrases on Susan's lips was that dear Maud was a force of nature."

Translation

Mrs. Lowder's plan, it was obvious, revolved around Kate. But the plan, amplified and refined as it was, required Milly to succeed in order to fully come to fruition. In the same way, Milly's own success was, at this moment, interwoven with Kate's. It was all a bit obscure, a bit bewildering, but undeniably candid and amiable. It helped the young woman to grasp things Kate had said about her aunt's abilities, along with Susan Shepherd's portrayals of her. One of Susan's most common remarks was that dear Maud was a force of nature.

Chapter 11

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

Lord Mark approaches Milly and tells her she resembles a beautiful picture in the house. He leads her away to see the portrait, a Bronzino. On their way through the house, they are repeatedly stopped by other guests who know and greet Lord Mark.

When they reach the painting, Milly looks at it through tears and says, "I shall never be better than this." Lord Mark responds by comparing her favorably to the woman in the portrait. Milly clarifies she meant the afternoon was too beautiful to be repeated. She then turns to the portrait and jokes about the resemblance.

Kate Croy arrives with a lady and a gentleman (Lord and Lady Aldershaw). Kate and the others also comment on Milly's resemblance to the portrait. Lady Aldershaw begins to invite Milly somewhere, but Lord Mark interrupts and stops the invitation. He then walks off with Lady Aldershaw, and Lord Aldershaw follows them, leaving Milly alone with Kate.

Milly sits down and tells Kate she must leave soon. Kate asks her if she is feeling unwell. Milly asks Kate to do her a secret favor: to accompany her to an appointment with a doctor, Sir Luke Strett, the next day. She explains that she wants to deceive her companion, Susan Shepherd, who would worry too much.

Kate asks Milly what is wrong with her, and Milly says that is what she wants to find out. Milly asks Kate to promise absolute silence, stating she believes she "could die without its being noticed." Kate agrees to help and accompany her to the doctor.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

Excellent. This is a rich and psychologically dense passage, characteristic of Henry James, likely from his novel *The Wings of the Dove*. The analysis will proceed by examining the development of the central character, Milly Theale, and then exploring the major themes and literary ideas that emerge through her consciousness and interactions.

### Literary Analysis

This excerpt is a masterclass in psychological realism, capturing a pivotal moment of self-realization for its protagonist, Milly Theale. Set against the backdrop of a grand English social gathering, the passage charts Milly’s journey from a passive object of observation to an active agent confronting her own mortality. Through symbolism, nuanced character interactions, and a deep dive into Milly’s consciousness, the text explores themes of perception versus reality, the intersection of art and life, and the profound isolation of the individual.

---

### Character Development: Milly Theale

The passage meticulously develops Milly’s character on two distinct levels: how she is perceived by others and how she experiences her own reality.

1. **Milly as an Object of Perception:** From the outset, Milly is presented as a spectacle. She is the subject of what has "gone round" about her—the "awfully rich young American who was so queer to behold." Lord Mark approaches her not just for conversation, but to frame her against a piece of art, the Bronzino portrait, effectively turning her into a living exhibit. He suggests letting the other guests "have the benefit of her," positioning her as a public commodity. Kate Croy and the Aldershaws reinforce this, treating her resemblance to the portrait as a fascinating social curiosity. To them, especially to Kate, Milly is a figure of immense power and potential: "There's nothing you can't have. There's nothing you can't do." This external perception defines Milly by her wealth and her novel American status, creating a gilded cage of expectations.

2. **Milly’s Internal Journey and Self-Realization:** The narrative's true power lies in its deep focus on Milly’s internal state, which stands in stark contrast to her public image. Initially, her impressions are muted, "not to be fully present to the girl till later on." She moves through the social scene like a "vaguely afloat" stroller, absorbing the "friendly, empty words and kind, lingering eyes" of a society that feels both pleasant and hollow.

The turning point is the encounter with the Bronzino portrait. This is not merely a social compliment for Milly; it is an existential confrontation. She sees in the portrait a "very great personage—only unaccompanied by a joy." The final, devastating observation—"And she was dead, dead, dead"—is a projection of her own deepest fears. The portrait becomes a mirror not of her beauty, but of her suspected fate: a magnificent, wealthy, but ultimately tragic and lifeless figure. Her tearful, cryptic statement, **"I shall never be better than this,"** is a moment of profound insight. She is not speaking of her beauty or social standing, but of a peak moment of experience—a "magnificent maximum"—that she intuits will be fleeting. She recognizes that this perfect, beautiful afternoon is the zenith, and the only way forward is down.

3. **The Shift to Agency:** In the final section, Milly transitions from passive observer to active protagonist. Haunted by her premonition, she decides to seek the truth about her health. Her decision to ask Kate to accompany her to a doctor is a complex act. On one level, it is a practical necessity. On another, it is an attempt to overcome her own internal "perversity"—her unspoken unease about Kate's connection to another man (Merton Densher). By placing this "special confidence" in Kate, Milly actively tries to prove her own trust and generosity, turning a moment of supreme vulnerability into an assertion of friendship. This act is her first step in taking control of her own tragic narrative.

---

### Themes and Major Literary Ideas

1. **Appearance vs. Reality:** This theme permeates the entire passage. The social world is a "mild common carnival of good-nature," but its inhabitants are "a little battered," sustained by old momentum. Their pleasantries are "empty," and their civility is a practiced "bland stare." Lord Mark's gallantry masks an unspoken proposal to "take care of" a wealthy heiress. Kate's exclamation, "Let us do something bad," frames Milly’s desperate search for medical truth as a thrilling, romantic escapade, completely missing its gravity. The most poignant contrast is Milly herself: perceived as a woman who can have anything, she is in reality confronting the one thing her wealth cannot conquer: mortality.

2. **The Symbolism of the Bronzino Portrait:** The portrait is the central and most powerful literary device. It functions as a "doppelgänger" or a ghostly double for Milly, embodying the intersection of life, art, and death. * **Art and Immortality:** The portrait offers a kind of immortality, preserving the woman's beauty for centuries. However, it is a cold, joyless preservation. * **Foreshadowing:** By identifying with the "pale personage," Milly intuits her own fate. The woman in the painting is rich, beautiful, and "unaccompanied by a joy," just as Milly fears she will be. The repeated word "dead" tolls like a funeral bell, sealing this symbolic connection. * **A Catalyst for Truth:** The portrait forces Milly to confront what she has only suspected. It is the catalyst that moves her from vague anxiety to decisive action, prompting her secret visit to the doctor.

3. **Perception and Misunderstanding:** The passage is a study in the failure of empathy. No one truly understands Milly. Lord Mark hears her cry of existential despair—"I shall never be better than this"—and interprets it as a simple comparison of beauty, replying, "You are, one feels, as it happens, better." His inability to grasp her meaning underscores her profound isolation. Milly recognizes this as "probably as good a moment as she should ever have with him," a poignant acknowledgment that even in moments of intimacy, she remains fundamentally alone. Kate's misreading of the situation is equally stark, highlighting the chasm between her worldly pragmatism and Milly's spiritual crisis.

4. **The Old World and the New:** Milly, the rich American, is a creature of the New World, defined by freedom, wealth, and a certain innocence. She is thrust into the ancient, complex, and subtly decaying world of the European aristocracy. The house itself, with its "patches of old colour" and "gilded historic chamber," represents this tradition. Milly is both captivated by its "mystic circle" and an alien within it. Her direct, earnest nature clashes with the practiced artifice and coded language of this society, making her both a fascination and a figure of tragedy.

### Conclusion

In this dense and moving passage, Henry James establishes the central tragedy of his protagonist. Milly Theale is defined, objectified, and ultimately misunderstood by the world she inhabits. Through the powerful symbol of the Bronzino portrait, she is forced to confront her own mortality, a reality that renders her immense wealth and social success meaningless. The scene brilliantly captures her transition from a passive, observed "dove" into a woman who, with quiet determination, seeks to understand her own fate, even if she must do so alone, surrounded by the "kind, lingering eyes" of friends who cannot see the truth.

A prime reason, we must add, why sundry impressions were not to be fully present to the girl till later on was that they yielded at this stage, with an effect of sharp supersession, to a detached quarter of an hour—her only one—with Lord Mark. "Have you seen the picture in the house, the beautiful one that's so like you?"—he was asking that as he stood before her; having come up at last with his smooth intimation that any wire he had pulled and yet wanted not to remind her of wasn't quite a reason for his having no joy at all. "I've been through rooms and I've seen pictures. But if I'm 'like' anything so beautiful as most of them seemed to me——!" It needed in short for Milly some evidence, which he only wanted to supply.

Translation

A primary reason, we should note, that various impressions didn't fully register with the girl until later was that they gave way at this point, abruptly and decisively, to a separate fifteen minutes—her only time—with Lord Mark. “Have you seen the picture in the house, the beautiful one that’s so like you?”—he was asking this as he stood before her; having finally arrived with his subtle suggestion that any strings he’d pulled, which he preferred not to mention, weren’t the real reason he was so unhappy. “I’ve gone through the rooms and seen pictures. But if I’m ‘like’ anything as beautiful as most of them appeared to me——!” In short, Milly needed some proof, which he was eager to provide.

She was the image of the wonderful Bronzino, which she must have a look at on every ground. He had thus called her off and led her away; the more easily that the house within was above all what had already drawn round her its mystic circle. Their progress, meanwhile, was not of the straightest; it was an advance, without haste, through innumerable natural pauses and soft concussions, determined for the most part by the appearance before them of ladies and gentlemen, singly, in couples, in groups, who brought them to a stand with an inveterate "I say, Mark." What they said she never quite made out; it was their all so domestically knowing him, and his knowing them, that mainly struck her, while her impression, for the rest, was but of fellow-strollers more vaguely afloat than themselves, supernumeraries mostly a little battered, whether as jaunty males or as ostensibly elegant women. They might have been moving a good deal by a momentum that had begun far back, but they were still brave and personable, still warranted for continuance as long again, and they gave her, in especial collectively, a sense of pleasant voices, pleasanter than those of actors, of friendly, empty words and kind, lingering eyes.

Translation

She was the spitting image of that gorgeous Bronzino, which she absolutely had to see for herself, no matter what. He’d lured her away, and it was easy, because the house itself was the primary thing that had already wrapped her in its mysterious spell. Their walk, though, wasn’t a straight shot. It was a slow, unhurried advance, filled with countless natural stops and starts, mostly determined by the appearance of other people—ladies and gentlemen, alone, in pairs, in groups—who brought them to a halt with an insistent, “I say, Mark.” She never quite caught what they were saying. What really stood out was how well they all knew him, and how he knew them, while her impression of the others was just of fellow wanderers, more adrift than they were, mostly extras who looked a little worn, whether they were the jaunty men or the supposedly elegant women. They might have been propelled by a momentum that started long ago, but they were still brave and personable, still guaranteed to last as long again, and they gave her, as a whole, a sense of pleasant voices, even more pleasant than actors’ voices, of friendly, empty words, and kind, lingering eyes.

The lingering eyes looked her over, the lingering eyes were what went, in almost confessed simplicity, with the pointless "I say, Mark "; and what was really most sensible of all was that, as a pleasant matter of course, if she didn't mind, he seemed to suggest their letting people, poor dear things, have the benefit of her. XI One major reason why various details wouldn't fully register with the girl until later was that they were immediately overshadowed by a brief encounter—her only one—with Lord Mark. "Have you seen the portrait in the house, the stunning one that looks so much like you?" he asked, standing before her.

Translation

The lingering eyes examined her, the lingering eyes accompanied, with almost confessed simplicity, the pointless "I say, Mark"; and what was truly most sensible was that, as a pleasant matter of course, if she didn't mind, he seemed to suggest letting people, poor dear things, have the benefit of her. One major reason why various details wouldn't fully register with the girl until later was that they were immediately overshadowed by a brief encounter—her only one—with Lord Mark. "Have you seen the portrait in the house, the stunning one that looks so much like you?" he asked, standing before her.

He had finally approached her, vaguely suggesting that any previous actions of his were not the reason he was so unhappy. "I've been through the rooms and seen the paintings. But if I resemble anything as beautiful as most of them seemed to me—!" Essentially, Milly needed proof, which he was eager to provide. She was the spitting image of the magnificent Bronzino portrait, which she absolutely had to see.

Translation

He'd finally come over, hinting that whatever he’d done before wasn’t the cause of his distress. "I’ve walked through the rooms, seen the paintings. But if I resemble anything as lovely as most of them appeared to me—!" Milly needed something more concrete, which he was keen to supply. She was the very image of the stunning Bronzino portrait, which she simply had to see.

He had thus diverted her and led her away, particularly since the house itself had already cast its enchanting spell around her. Their path, however, wasn't direct. They advanced slowly, pausing frequently amidst soft encounters, often dictated by the arrival of individuals or groups who would halt them with a persistent "Hello, Mark." She never quite understood what they said. It was their familiar knowledge of him, and his of them, that primarily struck her.

Translation

He'd distracted her that way, leading her away, especially because the house itself had already started to work its magic. But their way wasn't straightforward. They moved slowly, stopping frequently amidst gentle exchanges, often because individuals or groups would interrupt them with a persistent, "Hello, Mark." She never really understood what they were saying. It was their familiarity with him, and his with them, that most impressed her.

Her impression, otherwise, was of other wanderers, more adrift than they were, mostly somewhat worn-down extras, whether as cheerful men or ostensibly elegant women. They might have been propelled by a momentum that began long ago, but they remained spirited and presentable, seemingly capable of continuing for an equal length of time. Collectively, they gave her a feeling of pleasant voices, even more agreeable than those of actors, filled with friendly, meaningless words and kind, lingering glances. The lingering glances examined her.

Translation

She got the impression of other wanderers, more lost than they were, mostly a bit used up—extras in the guise of cheerful men or ostensibly elegant women. They could have been driven by a momentum that began long ago, but they were still lively and presentable, seemingly able to keep it up for just as long. As a group, they gave her a feeling of pleasant voices, even more agreeable than actors', filled with friendly, meaningless words and kind, lingering glances. The lingering glances examined her.

The lingering glances accompanied the almost transparently simple "Hello, Mark." Most notable was that, as a natural and pleasant gesture, if she didn't mind, he seemed to be suggesting they allow these people to appreciate her. The odd part was that he made her herself believe, for amusement, in the benefit, measured by him in mere manner—for wonderful, of a truth, was, as a means of expression, his slightness of emphasis—that her present good-nature conferred. It was, as she could easily see, a mild common carnival of good-nature—a mass of London people together, of sorts and sorts, but who mainly knew each other and who, in their way, did, no doubt, confess to curiosity. It had gone round that she was there; questions about her would be passing; the easiest thing was to run the gauntlet with him—just as the easiest thing was in fact to trust him generally.

Translation

The lingering glances were followed by a nearly transparently simple, "Hello, Mark." Most significant was that, as a natural and pleasant gesture, if she didn't mind, he seemed to be suggesting they let these people appreciate her. The odd thing was that he made her, for amusement, believe in the benefit, measured by him in mere manner—because wonderful, truly, was, as a means of expression, his slight emphasis—that her current good nature bestowed. It was, she could easily see, a mild, common carnival of good nature—a mass of London people together, of sorts and sorts, but who mostly knew each other and who, in their way, did, no doubt, admit to curiosity. Word had spread that she was there; questions about her would be circulating; the easiest thing was to face it with him—just as the easiest thing was, in fact, to trust him generally.

Couldn't she know for herself, passively, how little harm they meant her?—to that extent that it made no difference whether or not he introduced them. The strangest thing of all for Milly was perhaps the uplifted assurance and indifference with which she could simply give back the particular bland stare that appeared in such cases to mark civilisation at its highest. It was so little her fault, this oddity of what had "gone round" about her, that to accept it without question might be as good a way as another of feeling life. It was inevitable to supply the probable description—that of the awfully rich young American who was so queer to behold, but nice, by all accounts, to know; and she had really but one instant of speculation as to fables or fantasies perchance originally launched.

Translation

Couldn't she passively understand for herself how little harm they intended her? It made no difference whether or not he introduced them. The most peculiar aspect for Milly was the uplifting confidence and detachment with which she could simply return the same blank stare that seemed to signify civilization at its peak. It was hardly her fault that these odd rumors had spread about her, so accepting them without question might be as good a way as any to experience life. The likely description was unavoidable: the terribly rich young American, peculiar to look at, but pleasant, by all accounts, to know. She only briefly considered the fables or fantasies that might have started it all.

She asked herself once only if Susie could, inconceivably, have been blatant about her; for the question, on the spot, was really blown away for ever. She knew in fact on the spot and with sharpness just why she had "elected" Susan Shepherd: she had had from the first hour the conviction of her being precisely the person in the world least possibly a trumpeter. So it wasn't their fault, it wasn't their fault, and anything might happen that would, and everything now again melted together, and kind eyes were always kind eyes—if it were never to be worse than that! She got with her companion into the house; they brushed, beneficently, past all their accidents.

Translation

She only wondered briefly if Susie could have, impossibly, been obvious regarding her. But this question was instantly and completely dismissed. She knew immediately and with certainty why she had "chosen" Susan Shepherd: from the very beginning, she was convinced that Susan was the least likely person in the world to be a gossip. So, it wasn't their fault, it wasn't their fault, and anything could happen, and everything was once again merging together. Kind eyes were always kind eyes—if things never got worse than that! She entered the house with her friend; they moved through all of their problems, with good intentions.

The Bronzino was, it appeared, deep within, and the long afternoon light lingered for them on patches of old colour and waylaid them, as they went, in nooks and opening vistas. The peculiar thing was that he made her believe, just for fun, in the advantage she received, which he measured only by his behavior—because, truly, his subtle emphasis was a remarkable form of expression. He made her believe that her current good mood was beneficial. She could easily see it was a gentle, common celebration of good cheer—a large gathering of Londoners, of all kinds, who mostly knew each other and, in their own way, were undoubtedly curious.

Translation

The Bronzino, it seemed, was deep within, and the long afternoon light lingered for them on patches of old color and waylaid them as they went, in nooks and opening vistas. The peculiar thing was that he made her believe, just for fun, in the advantage she received, which he measured only by his behavior—because, truly, his subtle emphasis was a remarkable form of expression. He made her believe that her current good mood was beneficial. She could easily see it was a gentle, common celebration of good cheer—a large gathering of Londoners, of all kinds, who mostly knew each other and, in their own way, were undoubtedly curious.

Word had spread that she was there; questions about her would be circulating. The easiest thing was to go along with him—just as the easiest thing was, in fact, to trust him in general. Couldn't she understand for herself, without reacting, how little harm they intended her? It reached a point where it didn't matter whether or not he introduced them.

Translation

News of her presence had circulated, and inquiries concerning her would be making the rounds. The path of least resistance was to comply with him, just as, in reality, the simplest thing was to generally trust him. Couldn't she intuitively grasp, without overreacting, the minimal harm they posed to her? It reached a stage where it was irrelevant whether or not he made introductions.

The strangest thing of all for Milly was perhaps the confident assurance and indifference with which she could simply return the specific polite stare that, in such situations, seemed to represent the highest level of civilization. It was so little her fault, this oddity of the things that "had gone round" about her, that accepting it without question might be as good a way as any to experience life. It was inevitable that they would describe her—as the incredibly wealthy young American who was strange to look at, but, by all accounts, pleasant to know; and she only briefly considered any potential stories or fantasies that might have started the rumor. She only asked herself once if Susie could, unbelievably, have spread rumors about her; but the question was immediately dismissed.

Translation

Perhaps the oddest thing for Milly was the self-assured, indifferent ease with which she could simply meet the polite stare, the kind that always felt like the height of civilization. It wasn’t really her fault, this bizarre situation created by the whispers that “had gone round” about her. Accepting it without protest might be as good a way to live as any other. They would inevitably describe her—the incredibly rich young American, odd to look at, but, by all accounts, pleasant to know. She only briefly considered what stories or fantasies might have started the rumor. She only asked herself once if Susie, impossibly, could have spread rumors about her; then, she dismissed the question.

She knew immediately and with certainty why she had "chosen" Susan Shepherd: from the very beginning, she had believed that Susan was precisely the person in the world least likely to gossip. So it wasn't their fault, it wasn't their fault, and anything could happen that would, and everything now blended together again, and kind eyes were always kind eyes—if it would never get any worse than that! She entered the house with her companion; they moved past all these challenges with goodwill. The Bronzino painting was, apparently, located far inside, and the long afternoon light lingered for them on patches of faded color, catching them as they went, in hidden corners and open views.

Translation

She knew instantly why she had "picked" Susan Shepherd: from the start, she had thought Susan was the person least likely to spread rumors. So it wasn't their fault, it wasn't their fault, and anything could happen, and everything was blending together again, and kind eyes were always kind eyes—if it couldn't get any worse! She went into the house with her friend; they navigated everything with good intentions. The Bronzino painting was, it seemed, located deep inside, and the long afternoon light lingered for them on patches of faded color, catching them as they walked, in hidden corners and open spaces.

It was all the while for Milly as if Lord Mark had really had something other than this spoken pretext in view; as if there were something he wanted to say to her and were only—consciously yet not awkwardly, just delicately—hanging fire. At the same time it was as if the thing had practically been said by the moment they came in sight of the picture; since what it appeared to amount to was "Do let a fellow who isn't a fool take care of you a little." The thing somehow, with the aid of the Bronzino, was done; it hadn't seemed to matter to her before if he were a fool or no; but now, just where they were, she liked his not being; and it was all moreover none the worse for coming back to something of the same sound as Mrs. Lowder's so recent reminder. She too wished to take care of her—and wasn't it, à peu près, what all the people with the kind eyes were wishing?

Translation

For Milly, it was as if Lord Mark actually had something beyond his stated reason in mind. It was as if he wanted to tell her something and was just—deliberately but not clumsily, only with great care—hesitating. At the same time, it was as though the matter had practically been settled by the time they looked at the painting. What it came down to was, "Let a man who isn't a fool look after you a little." Somehow, with the Bronzino's help, it was accomplished. It hadn't seemed important to her before whether he was a fool or not, but now, where they were, she liked that he wasn't. And it was all the better for echoing Mrs. Lowder's recent reminder. She, too, wanted to take care of her—and wasn't that, more or less, what all those kind-eyed people wanted?

Once more things melted together—the beauty and the history and the facility and the splendid midsummer glow: it was a sort of magnificent maximum, the pink dawn of an apotheosis, coming so curiously soon. What in fact befell was that, as she afterwards made out, it was Lord Mark who said nothing in particular—it was she herself who said all. She couldn't help that—it came; and the reason it came was that she found herself, for the first moment, looking at the mysterious portrait through tears. Perhaps it was her tears that made it just then so strange and fair—as wonderful as he had said: the face of a young woman, all magnificently drawn, down to the hands, and magnificently dressed; a face almost livid in hue, yet handsome in sadness and crowned with a mass of hair rolled back and high, that must, before fading with time, have had a family resemblance to her own.

Translation

Again, everything blurred together: the beauty, the history, the ease, and the glorious summer light. It was a kind of magnificent peak, the rosy dawn of a transformation, arriving surprisingly quickly. What happened, as she later realized, was that Lord Mark didn't say anything specific—she was the one who spoke. She couldn't help it; it just came out. The reason it came out was that, for the first time, she found herself looking at the enigmatic portrait through her tears. Maybe it was her tears that made it seem so strange and lovely then, as wonderful as he had said. The face of a young woman, flawlessly rendered, down to her hands, and magnificently dressed; a face almost pale, yet handsome in its sadness, framed by a cascade of hair swept up and back, which, before it faded with age, must have resembled her own.

The lady in question, at all events, with her slightly Michaelangelesque squareness, her eyes of other days, her full lips, her long neck, her recorded jewels, her brocaded and wasted reds, was a very great personage—only unaccompanied by a joy. And she was dead, dead, dead. Milly recognised her exactly in words that had nothing to do with her. "I shall never be better than this."

Translation

The woman in the portrait, at any rate, with her somewhat Michelangelo-esque solidity, her antique eyes, her full lips, her long neck, her documented jewelry, her crimson brocade faded with time, was clearly a woman of great importance—but without any happiness. And she was dead, dead, dead. Milly understood her perfectly, in words that were unrelated to her own situation. "I'll never be any better than this."

Throughout their time together, Milly felt as though Lord Mark had a hidden agenda beyond his stated reasons for being there. It seemed he wanted to tell her something but was delaying—purposefully, yet with grace. Simultaneously, the unspoken message was clear when they stood before the painting, as if he was saying, "Allow someone who isn't a fool to look after you." The sentiment, somehow enhanced by the Bronzino, had been communicated. It hadn't seemed to matter before whether he was foolish or not, but now, in that moment, she appreciated that he wasn't.

Translation

During their time, Milly sensed Lord Mark had an ulterior motive beyond his surface reasons. He appeared to want to tell her something but was postponing—deliberately, yet with finesse. At the same time, the subtext was obvious when they were in front of the painting, as if he were saying, "Let someone who isn't a fool take care of you." The feeling, somehow amplified by the Bronzino, had been conveyed. It hadn't mattered previously if he was foolish or not, but now, in that moment, she was grateful that he wasn't.

Moreover, it echoed Mrs. Lowder's recent words. She, too, wanted to care for her—and wasn't that, more or less, what everyone with kind intentions wanted? Once more, everything blended together—the beauty, the history, the ease, and the radiant summer light.

Translation

Furthermore, it resonated with Mrs. Lowder's recent remarks. She also wanted to look after her—and wasn't that, essentially, what anyone with good intentions desired? Again, everything harmonized—the aesthetic, the past, the tranquility, and the vibrant summer sunshine.

It was a kind of overwhelming peak, the start of a glorious moment, arriving surprisingly soon. What actually happened, as she later realized, was that Lord Mark said nothing specific. It was she who spoke everything. She couldn't help it—it just came.

Translation

It was a moment of intense climax, the beginning of something wonderful, arriving with unexpected swiftness. What she realized later was that Lord Mark hadn't actually said anything concrete. She had voiced everything herself. She couldn't stop it; the words just poured out.

The reason it came was that, for the first time, she found herself looking at the mysterious portrait through tears. Perhaps her tears were what made it seem so strange and beautiful—as wonderful as he had said. It was the face of a young woman, magnificently detailed, even down to her hands, and dressed in splendid clothes. The face was almost pale, yet beautiful in its sadness, framed by a mass of hair, rolled back and high, which must, before time faded it, have looked similar to her own.

Translation

The reason it happened was that, for the first time, she was looking at the mysterious portrait through her tears. Maybe her tears were what made it seem so strange and beautiful—as wonderful as he had claimed. It was the face of a young woman, exquisitely detailed, even down to her hands, and dressed in lavish clothing. The face was almost white, yet lovely in its sadness, framed by a mass of hair, rolled back and up, which must have looked, before time had taken its toll, similar to her own.

The woman in the painting, with her slightly angular features, her eyes of another era, her full lips, her long neck, her jewels, her faded, brocaded reds, was a great person—but without joy. And she was dead, dead, dead. Milly understood her completely, in words that had nothing to do with her. "I'll never be better than this."

Translation

The woman in the portrait, with her slightly sharp features, her eyes belonging to another age, her full lips, her long neck, her jewels, her faded, brocaded reds, was a great person—but without happiness. And she was dead, dead, dead. Milly understood her perfectly, in words that had nothing to do with herself. "I'll never be better than this."

He smiled for her at the portrait. "Than she? You'd scarce need to be better, for surely that's well enough. But you are, one feels, as it happens, better; because, splendid as she is, one doubts if she was good."

Translation

He smiled at the portrait for her. "Than her? You hardly need to be better, because surely that's good enough. But you are, one feels, better, as it happens; because, splendid as she is, one doubts if she was good."

He hadn't understood. She was before the picture, but she had turned to him, and she didn't care if, for the minute, he noticed her tears. It was probably as good a moment as she should ever have with him. It was perhaps as good a moment as she should have with any one, or have in any connection whatever.

Translation

He hadn't understood. She was in front of the picture, but she had turned towards him, and she didn't care if, for the moment, he noticed her tears. It was probably as good a moment as she would ever have with him. It was perhaps as good a moment as she would have with anyone, or have in any connection whatsoever.

"I mean that everything this afternoon has been too beautiful, and that perhaps everything together will never be so right again. I'm very glad therefore you've been a part of it." He looked at the portrait and smiled. "Than the woman in the picture?

Translation

"What I'm trying to say is that everything this afternoon has been too beautiful, and maybe everything, as a whole, will never be this perfect again. So I'm very glad you were a part of it." He looked at the portrait and smiled. "More than the woman in the picture?"

You hardly need to be superior, since she's certainly lovely enough. But you are, one senses, better than her; because, as magnificent as she is, one wonders if she was a good person." He hadn't grasped the meaning. She stood in front of the picture, but she had turned to him, and she didn't mind if he saw her tears for a moment.

Translation

You don't have to act all high and mighty, because she's clearly beautiful enough. Still, you are, I think, better than her. As stunning as she is, you can't help but wonder if she was a good person. He didn't understand. She was facing the portrait, but she had turned towards him, and she didn't care if he saw her tears for a moment.

This was probably the best moment she would ever have with him. It was perhaps the best moment she would ever have with anyone, or have in any circumstance. "I mean that everything this afternoon has been too beautiful, and that perhaps everything combined will never be so perfect again. So, I am very glad you've been a part of it."

Translation

It was likely the most perfect moment she would ever share with him. Perhaps, the most perfect moment she would ever experience, period. "I just mean that everything about this afternoon has been too beautiful. Maybe it can never be this perfect again. So, I am very glad you've been here for it."

Though he still didn't understand her he was as nice as if he had; he didn't ask for insistence, and that was just a part of his looking after her. He simply protected her now from herself, and there was a world of practice in it. "Oh, we must talk about these things!" Ah, they had already done that, she knew, as much as she ever would; and she was shaking her head at her pale sister the next moment with a world, on her side, of slowness.

Translation

Even though he still didn't get what she meant, he acted as though he did. He didn't press her for details, which was just one way he looked out for her. He simply kept her safe from herself at that moment, and it was clear he'd had plenty of practice. "Oh, we have to talk about this!" She knew they already had, as much as they ever would. The next moment, she shook her head at her pale sister with a great deal of hesitation.

"I wish I could see the resemblance. Of course her complexion's green," she laughed; "but mine's several shades greener." "It's down to the very hands," said Lord Mark. "Her hands are large," Milly went on, "but mine are larger.

Translation

"I wish I could see the family resemblance. Sure, her skin is green," she laughed, "but mine is a few shades greener."

"It's in the hands," said Lord Mark.

"Her hands are big," Milly continued, "but mine are bigger."

Mine are huge." Even though he didn't grasp what she meant, he was just as considerate as if he did. He didn't press her, which was just one way he looked out for her. He simply kept her from doing things she shouldn't, and he was quite skilled at it.

Translation

"Mine are enormous." Even though he didn't understand what she meant, he was just as thoughtful as if he did. He didn't push her, which was only one of the ways he took care of her. He just kept her from doing things she shouldn't, and he was very good at it.

"Oh, we need to discuss these matters!" Ah, she already knew they'd talked about it as much as they ever would. She turned to her pale sister and shook her head slowly. "I wish I could see the likeness.

Translation

"Oh, we need to talk about this!" She knew, of course, that they'd already exhausted the topic. She faced her wan sister and slowly shook her head. "I wish I could understand how they're alike."

Her skin is green, of course," she laughed, "but mine is even greener." "It's true even of her hands," said Lord Mark. "Her hands are big," Milly continued, "but mine are bigger. Mine are enormous."

Translation

"Of course, her skin is green," she laughed, "but mine is even greener."

"That's true of her hands, too," Lord Mark said.

"Her hands are large," Milly continued, "but mine are larger. Mine are gigantic."

"Oh, you go her, all round, 'one better'—which is just what I said. But you're a pair. You must surely catch it," he added as if it were important to his character as a serious man not to appear to have invented his plea. "I don't know one never knows one's self.

Translation

"Oh, you one-up her at every turn—that’s exactly what I said. But you two are a pair. You'll get yours," he added, as if it were essential to his image as a serious man not to seem as if he'd fabricated his argument. "I don’t know—one never knows oneself."

It's a funny fancy, and I don't imagine it would have occurred——" "I see it has occurred"—he has already taken her up. She had her back, as she faced the picture, to one of the doors of the room, which was open, and on her turning, as he spoke, she saw that they were in the presence of three other persons, also, as appeared, interested inquirers. Kate Croy was one of these; Lord Mark had just become aware of her, and she, all arrested, had immediately seen, and made the best of it, that she was far from being first in the field.

Translation

"It's a strange idea, and I don't think it would have come to me—" "I see it has come to you," he interrupted. She was facing a picture with her back to one of the room's open doors. When she turned at his words, she saw three other people, also seemingly curious. Kate Croy was one of them; Lord Mark had just noticed her, and she, frozen, immediately understood and accepted that she wasn't the first to arrive.

She had brought a lady and a gentleman to whom she wished to show what Lord Mark was showing Milly, and he took her straightway as a reinforcement. Kate herself had spoken, however, before he had had time to tell her so. "Oh, you've outdone her, completely—that's exactly what I said. But you're two of a kind.

Translation

She had brought a woman and a man, intending to show them what Lord Mark was showing Milly. He immediately seized upon them as backup. But Kate spoke before he could even say anything. "Oh, you've completely outdone her—that's exactly what I thought. But you two are alike."

You're bound to get it," he added, as if it were essential to his credibility as a serious person not to seem like he'd just made up his argument. "I don't know – one never truly knows oneself. It's a strange notion, and I doubt it would have occurred—" "I see it has occurred," he interrupted her.

Translation

"You'll understand," he added, as if it were critical to his being taken seriously that he not appear to be winging it. "I don't know—one can never truly know oneself. It's a bizarre idea, and I doubt it would have occurred—" "I see it has occurred," he cut her off.

She was facing the painting with her back to one of the room's doors, which was open. When she turned around, as he spoke, she realized that three other people were there, also seemingly curious. Kate Croy was among them. Lord Mark had just noticed her, and she, taken aback, immediately understood, and accepted it, that she was far from being the first one there.

Translation

She stood before the painting, her back to one of the open doors. When she pivoted, as he was speaking, she saw three other people in the room, seemingly just as curious. Kate Croy was among them. Lord Mark had just noticed her, and she, surprised, immediately understood and accepted that she was not the first to arrive.

She had brought a lady and a gentleman whom she wanted to show what Lord Mark was showing Milly, and he promptly used her as support. However, Kate herself had spoken before he could even tell her anything. "You had noticed too?"—she smiled at him without looking at Milly. "Then I'm not original—which one always hopes one has been.

Translation

She had brought a woman and a man with her, intending to show them what Lord Mark was showing Milly, and he immediately used her as a prop. But Kate spoke before he could say anything at all. "You noticed it too?" She smiled at him, not looking at Milly. "Then I haven't been original—which is what you always hope, isn't it?"

But the likeness is so great." And now she looked at Milly—for whom again it was, all round indeed, kind, kind eyes. "Yes, there you are, my dear, if you want to know. And you're superb." She took now but a glance at the picture, though it was enough to make her question to her friends not too straight. "Isn't she superb?"

Translation

"But the resemblance is so strong." And now she looked at Milly—for whom, all things considered, her eyes were kind, so very kind. "Yes, there you are, my dear, if you want to know. And you're superb." She glanced at the picture, which was enough to make her question to her friends less than straightforward. "Isn't she superb?"

"I brought Miss Theale," Lord Mark explained to the latter, "quite off my own bat." "I wanted Lady Aldershaw," Kate continued to Milly, "to see for herself." "Les grands esprits se rencontrent!" laughed her attendant gentleman, a high, but slightly stooping, shambling and wavering person, who represented urbanity by the liberal aid of certain prominent front teeth and whom Milly vaguely took for some sort of great man. "You noticed it too?" she asked, smiling at him without looking at Milly.

Translation

"I brought Miss Theale," Lord Mark explained to the latter, "entirely on my own initiative." "I wanted Lady Aldershaw," Kate continued to Milly, "to see for herself." "Great minds think alike!" laughed her attendant gentleman, a tall, but slightly stooped, shambling and wavering person, who represented urbanity with the generous assistance of certain prominent front teeth and whom Milly vaguely assumed was some sort of important person. "You noticed it too?" she asked, smiling at him without looking at Milly.
