"Then I'm not original—which one always hopes one is. But the resemblance is so strong." And now she looked at Milly—for whom she seemed to have kind eyes. Translation

"So, I'm not original—which is a disappointment. But the similarity is striking." Now she turned her gaze to Milly—and seemed to regard her kindly. "Yes, there you are, my dear, if you're curious. And you're magnificent." She glanced at the painting, which prompted her to probe her companions, though not too overtly.

Translation

"Isn't she superb?" Lord Mark clarified to the newcomer, "I brought Miss Theale; I made the arrangements." "I wanted Lady Aldershaw," Kate said to Milly, "to see for herself." "Birds of a feather!" laughed her male companion, a tall, slightly stooped, shambling, and hesitant man, who conveyed urbanity through his prominent front teeth.

Milly vaguely thought he was some kind of important person. Lady Aldershaw meanwhile looked at Milly quite as if Milly had been the Bronzino and the Bronzino only Milly. "Superb, superb. Of course I had noticed you.

Translation

Milly vaguely assumed he was someone of consequence. Lady Aldershaw, meanwhile, gazed at Milly as if Milly were the Bronzino painting and the Bronzino were merely Milly. "Superb, superb. Naturally, I had taken note of you."

It is wonderful," she went on with her back to the picture, but with some other eagerness which Milly felt gathering, directing her motions now. It was enough—they were introduced, and she was saying "I wonder if you could give us the pleasure of coming——" She was not fresh, for she was not young, even though she denied at every pore that she was old; but she was vivid and much bejewelled for the midsummer daylight; and she was all in the palest pinks and blues. She didn't think, at this pass, that she could "come" anywhere—Milly didn't; and she already knew that somehow Lord Mark was saving her from the question. He had interposed, taking the words out of the lady's mouth and not caring at all if the lady minded.

Translation

"It's wonderful," she continued, her back to the painting, but with a different kind of excitement, one that Milly could sense building and now guiding her movements. It was enough—they had been introduced, and she was saying, "I wonder if you could give us the pleasure of coming—" She wasn't youthful, because she wasn't young, despite denying her age with every inch of her; but she was vibrant and heavily bejeweled for the summer daylight, and she was dressed entirely in the palest pinks and blues. She didn't think, at this point, that she could "come" anywhere—Milly didn't; and she already knew that somehow Lord Mark was rescuing her from the question. He had stepped in, taking the words right out of the lady's mouth and not caring in the least if the lady was annoyed.

That was clearly the right way to treat her—at least for him; as she had only dropped, smiling, and then turned away with him. She had been dealt with—it would have done an enemy good. The gentleman still stood, a little helpless, addressing himself to the intention of urbanity as if it were a large loud whistle; he had been signing sympathy, in his way, while the lady made her overture; and Milly had, in this light, soon arrived at their identity. They were Lord and Lady Aldershaw, and the wife was the clever one.

Translation

That was clearly the right approach, at least for him. She had just smiled and then turned away with him. She had been handled—it would have served an enemy well. The gentleman still stood there, a bit lost, directing himself toward the pretense of politeness as if it were a loud whistle. He had been telegraphing sympathy in his own way while the lady was making her offer, and Milly had quickly grasped their identities. They were Lord and Lady Aldershaw, and the wife was the smart one.

A minute or two later the situation had changed, and she knew it afterwards to have been by the subtle operation of Kate. She was herself saying that she was afraid she must go now if Susie could be found; but she was sitting down on the nearest seat to say it. The prospect, through opened doors, stretched before her into other rooms, down the vista of which Lord Mark was strolling with Lady Aldershaw, who, close to him and much intent, seemed to show from behind as peculiarly expert. Lord Aldershaw, for his part, had been left in the middle of the room, while Kate, with her back to him, was standing before her with much sweetness of manner.

Translation

A minute or two later, the situation had shifted. She later realized this was due to Kate's subtle maneuvering. She was saying she feared she must leave now if Susie could be located, but she remained seated on the nearest bench as she spoke. Through the open doorways, the view extended into other rooms, down a vista where Lord Mark strolled with Lady Aldershaw. The lady, close beside him and deeply focused, appeared remarkably skilled from behind. Meanwhile, Lord Aldershaw was left in the middle of the room, while Kate, with her back to him, stood before her with a most agreeable demeanor.

The sweetness was all for her; she had the sense of the poor gentleman's having somehow been handled as Lord Mark had handled his wife. He dangled there, he shambled a little; then he bethought himself of the Bronzino, before which, with his eyeglass, he hovered. It drew from him an odd, vague sound, not wholly distinct from a grunt, and a "Humph—most remarkable!" which lighted Kate's face with amusement. The next moment he had creaked away, over polished floors, after the others, and Milly was feeling as if she had been rude.

Translation

The sweetness was all for her; she felt as though the poor gentleman had been manipulated, just as Lord Mark had handled his wife. He seemed lost, he shuffled a bit, then remembered the Bronzino, and he hovered before it with his eyeglass. It drew from him an odd, vague sound, not quite a grunt, and a "Humph—most remarkable!" which made Kate's face light up with amusement. The next moment, he had creaked away, over the polished floors, after the others, and Milly felt as if she had been impolite.

But Lord Aldershaw was in every way a detail, and Kate was saying to her that she hoped she wasn't ill. Meanwhile, Lady Aldershaw was looking at Milly as if Milly was the Bronzino painting, and the painting was just Milly. "Superb, superb. Of course, I've noticed you.

Translation

But Lord Aldershaw was, in every respect, an afterthought, and Kate was asking her if she hoped she wasn't ill. In the meantime, Lady Aldershaw was looking at Milly as if Milly was the Bronzino painting, and the painting was just Milly. "Superb, superb. Of course, I've noticed you."

It's wonderful," she continued, her back to the painting, but with a different kind of enthusiasm that Milly sensed, directing her actions. He had intervened, taking the words out of the lady's mouth and not caring at all if the lady was annoyed.

Translation

"It's wonderful," she went on, her back to the painting, but with a different sort of excitement that Milly could feel, guiding her. That was enough—they had been introduced, and she was saying, "I wonder if you could do us the pleasure of coming—" She wasn't new, because she wasn't young, even though she refused to admit she was old; but she was animated and heavily adorned with jewels for the summer day; and she was dressed in the palest pinks and blues. Milly didn't think, under the circumstances, that she could "come" anywhere; and she already knew that Lord Mark was somehow saving her from the question. He had stepped in, taking the words out of the lady's mouth and not caring in the least if the lady was put out.

That was clearly the right way to treat her—at least for him; as she had just smiled and then turned away with him. She had been handled—it would have pleased an enemy. The gentleman still stood, a little helpless, attempting to be polite as if it were a loud whistle; he had been silently showing sympathy while the lady made her offer; and Milly had, in this way, quickly understood who they were. They were Lord and Lady Aldershaw, and the wife was the clever one.

Translation

That was definitely the correct approach, at least as far as he was concerned. She had simply smiled and then walked away with him. She had been managed—it would have delighted an adversary. The man remained, looking somewhat lost, trying to be polite as if it were a shrill signal. He had silently offered commiseration while the woman had made her invitation, and Milly had immediately grasped the situation. They were Lord and Lady Aldershaw, and the wife was the shrewd one.

A few minutes later, the situation had changed, and she later realized it had happened due to Kate's subtle actions. Milly herself was saying that she was afraid she had to leave now if Susie could be found; but she was sitting down on the closest seat while saying it. The view, through open doors, stretched out before her into other rooms, down a long hallway where Lord Mark was walking with Lady Aldershaw, who, close to him and very focused, seemed from behind to be particularly skilled. Lord Aldershaw, meanwhile, had been left in the middle of the room, while Kate, with her back to him, was standing in front of Milly with great sweetness of manner.

Translation

A few minutes passed, and the situation had shifted, a change Milly later attributed to Kate’s deft maneuvering. Milly was claiming she had to leave, hoping to find Susie, but she remained seated on the nearest chair as she spoke. Through the open doors, the view extended into other rooms, down a long hallway where Lord Mark strolled with Lady Aldershaw. She appeared, from her back, to be intensely engaged and rather accomplished as she walked beside him. Lord Aldershaw, in the meantime, had been left alone in the middle of the room. Kate, with her back to him, stood before Milly, her manner remarkably pleasant.

The sweetness was all for Milly; she felt the poor gentleman had been treated in the same way Lord Mark had treated his wife. He lingered there, he shuffled a little; then he turned his attention to the Bronzino, which he examined with his eyeglass. It drew from him an odd, vague sound, not quite a grunt, and a "Humph—most remarkable!" which lit up Kate's face with amusement. The next moment he had walked away, across the polished floors, after the others, and Milly was feeling as if she had been rude.

Translation

The charm was all for Milly. She felt the unfortunate man had been dealt with in the same way Lord Mark treated his wife. He lingered, shuffling his feet a little, and then turned to the Bronzino. He examined it with his monocle, which elicited a strange, indistinct sound, something like a grunt, and a "Humph—most remarkable!" which amused Kate. Then, he walked away, across the gleaming floor, after the others, and Milly felt as though she’d been impolite.

But Lord Aldershaw was unimportant, and Kate was asking her if she was feeling unwell. Thus it was that, aloft there in the great gilded historic chamber and the presence of the pale personage on the wall, whose eyes all the while seemed engaged with her own, she found herself suddenly sunk in something quite intimate and humble and to which these grandeurs were strange enough witnesses. It had come up, in the form in which she had had to accept it, all suddenly, and nothing about it, at the same time, was more marked than that she had in a manner plunged into it to escape from something else. Something else, from her first vision of her friend's appearance three minutes before, had been present to her even through the call made by the others on her attention; something that was perversely there, she was more and more uncomfortably finding, at least for the first moments and by some spring of its own, with every renewal of their meeting.

Translation

But Lord Aldershaw was unimportant, and Kate was asking her if she felt unwell. And so, up there in the great gilded, historic chamber, in the presence of the pale figure on the wall, whose eyes seemed all the while to be fixed on her, she found herself suddenly immersed in something quite intimate and humble, for which these grand surroundings were strange witnesses. It had come, in the form in which she had to accept it, all of a sudden, and nothing about it was more striking than that she had, in a way, plunged into it to escape something else. Something else, from the first moment she had seen her friend, three minutes before, had been present to her, even through the demands the others made on her attention; something that was perversely there, she was increasingly and uncomfortably discovering, at least for the first moments and by some means of its own, with every renewal of their meeting.

"Is it the way she looks to him?" she asked herself—the perversity being that she kept in remembrance that Kate was known to him. It wasn't a fault in Kate—nor in him assuredly; and she had a horror, being generous and tender, of treating either of them as if it had been. To Densher himself she couldn't make it up—he was too far away; but her secondary impulse was to make it up to Kate. She did so now with a strange soft energy—the impulse immediately acting.

Translation

"Is that how she appears to him?" she wondered, the unsettling aspect being that she knew Kate was acquainted with him. It wasn't Kate's fault—nor certainly his; and being kind and sensitive, she was horrified at the thought of treating either of them as if it were. She couldn't fix it with Densher—he was too distant; but her secondary urge was to make amends to Kate. She did so now with an odd, gentle vigor—the impulse acting instantly.

"Will you render me to-morrow a great service?" So, up there in the grand, gold-trimmed historical room, facing the portrait of the pale woman on the wall, whose eyes seemed to be fixed on hers, she found herself suddenly overwhelmed by something intensely personal and unassuming. These magnificent surroundings seemed to be a strange backdrop to it. It had appeared, in the form she had to accept, quite abruptly.

Translation

"Could you do me a huge favor tomorrow?" So, up in that opulent, gold-adorned historic room, facing the portrait of the pale woman on the wall, whose eyes seemed to be locked on hers, she was suddenly overcome by something deeply personal and unpretentious. These lavish surroundings seemed like an odd backdrop to it. It had appeared, in a form she had to accept, quite abruptly.

Yet, what was most striking was that she had, in a way, embraced it to flee from something else. That "something else" had been there, from the moment she first saw her friend, even while others were demanding her attention. It was stubbornly present, she realized with growing discomfort, at least at first, triggered by something within herself, every time they met. "Is this how she appears to him?" she wondered, the frustrating part being that Kate was, as she knew, familiar to him.

Translation

However, what truly stood out was that she had, in a sense, embraced it as an escape. That “something else” had been present from the moment she first met her friend, even as others vied for her attention. She understood with increasing unease that it had been stubbornly there, at first anyway, initiated by something within herself, every time they met. “Is this how she appears to him?” she wondered, the most frustrating part being that Kate was, as she knew, familiar to him.

It wasn't Kate's fault, or certainly not his. Being kind and compassionate, she refused to think of either of them that way. She couldn't fix it with Densher himself—he was too distant. But her immediate desire was to make amends to Kate.

Translation

It wasn't Kate's fault, and certainly not his. She wouldn't allow herself to think of either of them that way, given her inherent kindness and compassion. She couldn't repair the situation with Densher directly—he was too aloof. Instead, her immediate impulse was to make things right with Kate.

She did so now with a curious, gentle force, the impulse acting at once. "Could you do me a huge favor tomorrow?" "Any service, dear child, in the world." "But it's a secret one—nobody must know.

Translation

She acted, her impulse driving her with a strange, tender strength. "Could you do me a huge favor tomorrow?" "Anything, dear child, in the world." "But it's a secret—nobody must know."

I must be wicked and false about it." "Then I'm your woman," Kate smiled, "for that's the kind of thing I love. Do let us do something bad. You're impossibly without sin, you know."

Translation

"I must lie and be deceitful." "Then count me in," Kate grinned, "because I live for that sort of thing. Please, let's do something naughty. You're ridiculously pure, you know."

Milly's eyes, on this, remained a little with their companion's. "Ah, I shan't perhaps come up to your idea. It's only to deceive Susan Shepherd." "Oh!" said Kate as if this were indeed mild.

Translation

Milly kept her gaze on Kate. "Well, I might not be what you're hoping for. All I want is to mislead Susan Shepherd." "Oh!" Kate replied, as if that were hardly exciting at all.

"But thoroughly—as thoroughly as I can." "And for cheating," Kate asked, "my powers will contribute? Well, I'll do my best for you." In accordance with which it was presently settled between them that Milly should have the aid and comfort of her presence for a visit to Sir Luke Strett. Kate had needed a minute for enlightenment, and it was quite grand for her comrade that this name should have said nothing to her.

Translation

"But completely—as completely as I can." "And for the deception," Kate asked, "will my abilities be useful? Well, I'll do my best for you." With that settled between them, it was arranged that Milly would have Kate's company and support for a visit to Sir Luke Strett. Kate had needed a moment to understand, and it was quite fortunate for her friend that this name meant nothing to her.

To Milly herself it had for some days been secretly saying much. The personage in question was, as she explained, the greatest of medical lights if she had got hold, as she believed (and she had used to this end the wisdom of the serpent) of the right, the special man. She had written to him three days before, and he had named her an hour, eleven-twenty; only it had come to her, on the eve, that she couldn't go alone. Her maid, on the other hand, wasn't good enough, and Susie was too good.

Translation

For days, the matter had held a private significance for Milly. She clarified that the individual in question was a prominent figure in the medical field, provided she secured, as she suspected she had (employing cunning), the right, the perfect individual. Three days prior, she had written to him, and he had designated an appointment time, eleven-twenty. However, the day before, it had dawned on her that she couldn’t attend alone. Her maid, however, was inadequate, and Susie was too capable.

Kate had listened, above all, with high indulgence. "And I'm betwixt and between, happy thought! Too good for what?" "Anything at all, darling."

Translation

Kate had listened, above all, with great tolerance. "And I'm stuck, a good thing! Too good for what?" "Anything, darling."

"But it's a secret, nobody can know. I have to be dishonest and deceptive about it." "Then I'm your person," Kate said with a smile, "because that's what I love. Let's do something naughty.

Translation

"But it's a secret, nobody can know. I have to be dishonest and deceptive about it." "Then I'm your person," Kate said with a smile, "because that's what I love. Let's do something naughty.

You're ridiculously innocent, you know." Milly's eyes lingered on her friend. "Oh, I probably won't be as wicked as you'd like. It's just to mislead Susan Shepherd."

Translation

You're incredibly naive, you know that?" Milly's gaze lingered on her friend. "Oh, I probably won't be as bad as you want me to be. It's just to throw Susan Shepherd off the scent."

"Oh!" Kate exclaimed, as if this were rather tame. "But completely—as completely as I can." "And for this deception," Kate inquired, "will my abilities be helpful? Well, I'll do my best for you." With this agreed, it was decided between them that Milly would have Kate's company for a visit to Sir Luke Strett.

Translation

"Oh!" Kate exclaimed, as if this were rather underwhelming. "But completely—as completely as I can." "And for this deception," Kate asked, "will my abilities be useful? Well, I'll do my best for you." With that settled, it was agreed between them that Milly would have Kate's company for a visit to Sir Luke Strett.

Kate needed a moment to understand, and it was impressive to her that this name meant nothing to her friend. To Milly, however, it had been secretly significant for days. As she explained, the person in question was the foremost medical expert, and she believed she had secured the perfect, specialized man (using a bit of cunning). She had written to him three days earlier, and he had given her an appointment at eleven-twenty, but the previous day, she realized she couldn't go alone.

Translation

Kate needed a moment to process. She was surprised that the name meant nothing to Milly. For Milly, though, the name had secretly been a big deal for days. As she explained, the person was the most important medical specialist, and she thought she had gotten the right, specialized guy (using a little trickery). She had written to him three days before, and he'd given her an appointment for eleven-twenty, but the day before, she realized she couldn't go by herself.

Her maid wasn't suitable, and Susie was too good. Kate had listened with great amusement. "And I'm the perfect choice, what a thought! Too good for what?"

Translation

Her maid wouldn't do, and Susie was too capable. Kate had been listening, highly amused. "So I'm the ideal candidate? Fancy that! Too good for what, exactly?"

Milly thought. "Why, to be worried if it's nothing. And to be still more worried—I mean before she need be—if it isn't." Kate fixed her with deep eyes.

Translation

Milly considered. "Why, to fret over something that's nothing. And to worry even more—I mean, before she even has to—if it isn't." Kate locked eyes with her, her gaze intense.

"What in the world is the matter with you?" It had inevitably a sound of impatience, as if it had been a challenge really to produce something; so that Milly felt her for the moment only as a much older person, standing above her a little, doubting the imagined ailments, suspecting the easy complaints, of ignorant youth. It somewhat checked her, further, that the matter with her was what exactly as yet she wanted knowledge about; and she immediately declared, for conciliation, that if she were merely fanciful Kate would see her put to shame. Kate vividly uttered, in return, the hope that, since she could come out and be so charming, could so universally dazzle and interest, she wasn't all the while in distress or in anxiety—didn't believe herself, in short, to be in any degree seriously menaced. "Well, I want to make out—to make out!" was all that this consistently produced.

Translation

"What in the world is the matter with you?" The question inevitably carried a note of impatience, as if demanding she actually have something to present. Milly felt Kate, for a moment, as an older person, looking down, skeptical of imagined ailments, suspecting the easy complaints of youth. It somewhat stalled her, that the problem, exactly, was something she herself wanted to understand. She immediately declared, for the sake of reconciliation, that if she were simply imagining things, Kate would see her proven wrong. In response, Kate fervently expressed the hope that, since she was capable of being so charming, of universally dazzling and interesting others, she wasn't secretly in distress or anxiety—that she didn't believe herself, in short, to be seriously threatened. "Well, I want to make out—to make out!" was all this consistently produced.

To which Kate made clear answer: "Ah then, let us by all means!" Milly considered. "Why be concerned if it's nothing? And to be even more concerned—I mean, before I even need to be—if it isn't."

Translation

To which Kate responded with a clear affirmation:

"Oh, then by all means, let's!" Milly thought it over. "Why should I worry if it amounts to nothing? And it's even worse—I mean, I'd worry before I even needed to—if it isn't."

Kate stared at her intently. "What's wrong with you?" Her question sounded impatient, almost a challenge, as if daring Milly to reveal something. For a moment, Milly felt as though Kate, an older woman, was looking down on her, skeptical of imaginary illnesses and suspicious of the youthful tendency to complain. It also hindered Milly that she didn't yet know precisely what was wrong.

Translation

Kate fixed her with a long stare. "What's the matter with you?" Her tone was abrupt, almost confrontational, like she was goading Milly to confess something. For a second, Milly felt Kate, the elder, was looking down on her, dubious of imagined ailments and distrustful of the young's inclination to whine. It didn't help that Milly herself wasn't sure what the problem was.

She quickly added, to placate Kate, that if she was just being fanciful, Kate would witness her embarrassment. In response, Kate expressed the hope that since Milly could be so charming and captivating, and could so effortlessly dazzle and interest others, she wasn't secretly suffering distress or anxiety—that she didn't, in short, believe herself to be seriously threatened. "Well, I want to figure it out—to figure it out!" was all Milly would say. To which Kate responded, "Then let's do it!"

Translation

Milly, trying to smooth things over with Kate, quickly added that if she was just imagining things, Kate would have a right to be annoyed. Kate, in turn, hoped that since Milly was so charming and could easily captivate and fascinate others, she wasn’t secretly struggling with some kind of emotional turmoil—that, essentially, she didn’t think she was in serious danger. “Well, I want to figure it out—to figure it out!” was all Milly would say. To which Kate responded, “Then let’s do it!”

"I thought," Milly said, "you would like to help me. But I must ask you, please, for the promise of absolute silence." "And how, if you are ill, can your friends remain in ignorance?" "Well, if I am, it must of course finally come out.

Translation

"I thought," Milly said, "that you'd want to help. But I need to ask you, please, to promise me absolute silence." "And if you're sick, how can your friends not know?" "Well, if I am, it will inevitably come out eventually, of course."

But I can go for a long time." Milly spoke with her eyes again on her painted sister's—almost as if under their suggestion. She still sat there before Kate, yet not without a light in her face. "That will be one of my advantages. I think I could die without its being noticed."

Translation

But I can last a long time. Milly spoke with her eyes fixed once more on her painted sister's, almost as if under their influence. She remained there before Kate, though not without a certain brightness on her face. That will be one of my advantages. I believe I could die without anyone noticing.

"You're an extraordinary young woman," her friend, visibly held by her, declared at last. "What a remarkable time to talk of such things!" "I hoped," Milly said, "that you'd be willing to help me. But I must ask you, please, to promise me you won't tell anyone."

Translation

"You are an extraordinary young woman," her friend declared at last, clearly captivated. "What a remarkable moment to discuss such matters!" "I hoped," Milly said, "that you would be willing to assist me. But I must ask you, please, to promise me you won't tell anyone."

"And if you're sick, how can your friends not know?" "Well, eventually, of course, it will be discovered. But I can keep it a secret for a long time." Milly spoke, looking intently at her friend, almost as if under some unspoken command. She was still sitting in front of Kate, but there was a certain radiance in her expression.

Translation

"If you're ill, how can your friends not find out?"

"Well, eventually, they will, obviously. But I can keep it hidden for a while." Milly said this, staring directly at her friend, as if under some unspoken obligation. She remained seated in front of Kate, but her face held a certain glow.

"That will be one of my strengths. I think I could die without anyone noticing." "You're an amazing young woman," her friend, clearly captivated, finally said. "What a strange time to be discussing such things!"

Translation

"That will be one of my strengths. I think I could die without anyone noticing." "You're an amazing young woman," her friend, clearly captivated, finally said. "What a strange time to be discussing such things!"

"Well, we won't talk, precisely"—Milly got herself together again. "I only wanted to make sure of you." "Here in the midst of——!" But Kate could only sigh for wonder—almost visibly too for pity. It made a moment during which her companion waited on her word; partly as if from a yearning, shy but deep, to have her case put to her just as Kate was struck by it; partly as if the hint of pity were already giving a sense to her whimsical "shot," with Lord Mark, at Mrs.

Translation

"Well, we won't exactly talk," Milly composed herself again. "I just wanted to check on you." "Here in the midst of——!" But Kate could only sigh in amazement—almost visibly too, from pity. It made a moment during which her companion waited for her to speak; partly as if from a yearning, shy but deep, to have her situation explained to her in the same way Kate had been struck by it; partly as if the hint of pity were already giving meaning to her whimsical "shot" at Lord Mark, at Mrs.

Lowder's first dinner. Exactly this—the handsome girl's compassionate manner, her friendly descent from her own strength—was what she had then foretold. She took Kate up as if positively for the deeper taste of it. "Here in the midst of what?"

Translation

"Well," Kate began, struck anew, "right here, in the middle of all this!" The handsome girl's sympathetic demeanor, her gentle outreach from a position of confidence, was precisely what she'd predicted. She embraced Kate, as if to savor it all the more. "Here, in the midst of what?"

"Well, we won't exactly talk," Milly composed herself. "I just wanted to make sure about you." "Here in the middle of——!" But Kate could only sigh in amazement—almost visibly, also, with pity. It made a moment during which her companion waited for her to speak; partly as if she longed, shyly but deeply, to have Kate explain her situation to her; partly as if the hint of pity already gave meaning to her playful "shot" at Mrs.

Translation

"Well, we won't exactly talk," Milly collected herself. "I just wanted to check on you." "Here in the middle of——!" But Kate could only sigh in amazement—almost visibly, with pity, too. It made a moment during which her companion waited for her to speak; partly as if she longed, shyly but deeply, to have Kate explain her situation to her; partly as if the hint of pity already gave meaning to her playful "shot" at Mrs.

Lowder's first dinner with Lord Mark. Exactly this—the beautiful girl's compassionate manner, her friendly descent from her own position of strength—was what she had then predicted. She embraced Kate as if positively eager to savor it. "Here in the middle of what?"

Translation

Lowder's first dinner with Lord Mark. This was precisely the thing—the beautiful girl's sympathetic demeanor, her amicable outreach from a position of advantage—that Kate had anticipated. She embraced Kate as if genuinely keen to appreciate it. "Here in the middle of what?"

"Of everything. There's nothing you can't have. There's nothing you can't do." "So Mrs.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder can have anything and do anything? "

Lowder tells me." It just kept Kate's eyes fixed as possibly for more of that; then, however, without waiting, she went on. "We all adore you." "You're wonderful—you dear things!" Milly laughed.

Translation

"Lowder tells me." It just kept Kate's eyes fixed, as if waiting for more. Then, however, without waiting, she went on. "We all adore you." "You're wonderful—you dear things!" Milly laughed.

"No, it's you." And Kate seemed struck with the real interest of it. "In three weeks!" Milly kept it up. "Never were people on such terms!

Translation

"No, it's you," and Kate appeared genuinely intrigued. "In three weeks!" Milly persisted. "Nobody has ever been so close!"

All the more reason," she added, "that I shouldn't needlessly torment you." "But me? what becomes of me?" said Kate. "Well, you—" Milly thought—"if there's anything to bear, you'll bear it."

Translation

"That's all the more reason," she added, "that I shouldn't needlessly torment you."

"But me? What becomes of me?" said Kate.

"Well, you—" Milly thought—"if there's anything to bear, you'll bear it."

"But I won't bear it!" said Kate Croy. "Oh yes, you will: all the same! You'll pity me awfully, but you'll help me very much. And I absolutely trust you.

Translation

"But I won't bear it!" Kate Croy said. "Oh yes, you will: all the same! You'll pity me awfully, but you'll help me very much. And I absolutely trust you."

So there we are." There they were, then, since Kate had so to take it; but there, Milly felt, she herself in particular was; for it was just the point at which she had wished to arrive. She had wanted to prove to herself that she didn't horribly blame her friend for any reserve; and what better proof could there be than this quite special confidence? If she desired to show Kate that she really believed the latter liked her, how could she show it more than by asking her for help? "You can have anything.

Translation

So there we are.” There they were, then, since Kate was meant to understand it that way; but there, Milly felt, she in particular was; for it was just the point she had wished to arrive at. She had wanted to prove to herself that she didn’t horribly blame her friend for any reticence; and what better proof could there be than this quite special confidence? If she desired to show Kate that she really believed the latter liked her, how could she show it more than by asking her for help? “You can have anything.”

There's nothing you can't have. There's nothing you can't do." "That's what Mrs. Lowder tells me."

Translation

"You can have anything. You can do anything." "That's what Mrs. Lowder tells me."

Kate stared, hoping for more; then, without pause, she continued. "We all love you." "You're amazing—you dear people!" Milly laughed. "No, it's you." Kate seemed truly intrigued.

Translation

Kate looked intently, wanting more. Without a break, she kept going. "We all adore you." "You're wonderful, you sweet things!" Milly laughed. "No, it's you." Kate appeared genuinely interested.

"In three weeks!" Milly persisted. "Never have people been so close! All the more reason," she added, "that I shouldn't burden you unnecessarily."

Translation

"In three weeks!" Milly insisted. "We've never been this close! All the more reason," she added, "that I shouldn't bother you unnecessarily."

"But what about me? What happens to me?" asked Kate. "Well, you—" Milly considered—"if there's anything difficult, you'll handle it." "But I won't handle it!" said Kate Croy.

Translation

"And what about me? What's going to happen to me?" Kate asked. Milly paused, considering. "Well, you—" "If anything's difficult, you'll take care of it." "But I won't take care of it!" said Kate Croy.

"Oh yes, you will: it's inevitable! You'll feel terrible for me, but you'll help me a great deal. And I completely trust you. So, that's that." That was indeed the situation, since Kate had accepted it; but, Milly felt, that's where she, herself, especially was; for that was the precise point she'd wanted to reach.

Translation

"Oh, you absolutely will; it's unavoidable! You'll feel awful for me, but you'll be a huge help. And I have complete faith in you. So, that's settled." That was indeed how things stood, as Kate had accepted it; but, Milly thought, that's where she, herself, specifically, was; for that was the exact point she'd wanted to get to.

She wanted to prove to herself that she didn't harshly blame her friend for any reticence; and what better proof could there be than this special trust? If she wanted to show Kate that she truly believed Kate cared for her, how better to prove it than by asking for help?

Translation

She wanted to convince herself that she didn't fault her friend for any hesitation. And what stronger demonstration could there be than this exceptional confidence? If she wanted to show Kate she truly believed in her affection, what better way than to request assistance?

Chapter 12

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

A woman, accompanied by Kate, has a ten-minute consultation with a doctor, Sir Luke Strett. The doctor apologizes for the short meeting and schedules another appointment with her in a day or two. After the meeting, the woman, Milly, tells Kate that the doctor is a "dear," that she is to see him again, and that he told her not to worry. When Kate asks if the doctor says she is ill, Milly replies that she doesn't know or care, stating that he can "tell" without asking many questions.

While waiting for their carriage, Milly tells Kate she will go to the next appointment alone and asks for her discretion. Kate agrees to be silent if Milly promises to tell her the truth about her condition. Milly agrees, saying she is happy and feels "absolved." When Kate suggests the doctor must like her, Milly dismisses it. Kate asks her to bring a Mrs. Stringham to the next visit, but Milly declines, saying she wants to see him one more time first.

Two days later, Milly returns to the doctor alone. He asks if she was accompanied. She tells him everything, explaining that she lied to her friend to come by herself because her situation concerns only her. When asked, she tells him she has no living relations and is the last survivor of her family.

The doctor tells her not to bear more than she needs to and to accept happiness. After his examination, he instructs her to follow a few prescriptions and says he will visit her at home in a few days. He tells her to leave London soon and gives her permission to return to the continent, saying he will "follow you up." He advises her to "see all you can" and not worry. Milly asks if she will suffer, and he replies, "Not a bit." When she asks if she will live, he tells her that persuading her to live is what he is trying to do.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

This is an excellent excerpt for literary analysis, characteristic of the dense, psychologically rich prose of Henry James. The passage, taken from his novel *The Wings of the Dove*, focuses on the pivotal consultations between the protagonist, Milly Theale, and the eminent physician Sir Luke Strett. It masterfully explores the internal landscape of a character grappling with mortality, perception, and the nature of human connection.

### Literary Analysis

#### **Major Themes**

1. **The Search for Truth and Authentic Connection:** The central driving force of the passage is Milly's quest not for a cure, but for an unvarnished truth. She is weary of social niceties and superficial kindness. The "friendship" she imagines with Sir Luke is profound because it is "scientifically, ponderably, proveably—not just loosely and sociably." He offers her a "crystal-clean the great empty cup of attention," an image suggesting purity, focus, and a space free of pretense. This connection is a "special trophy," a private "possession" she carries away, signifying its immense personal value in a world of social performance.

2. **The Nature of Living in the Face of Death:** The consultation is less a medical appointment than an existential negotiation. Milly feels she has "loosely rattling" through life without anything "firm to stand on." Paradoxically, the confirmation of her doom provides this firmness. The process of "being let down" by a grim prognosis is what finally "held up" her sense of self. Sir Luke’s ultimate prescription is not medical but philosophical: to "live." He commands her, "You've the right to be happy. You must make up your mind to it." The passage transforms a diagnosis into a mandate for life, however limited it may be.

3. **Perception, Intuition, and Unspoken Knowledge:** A key Jamesian theme is the power of what is *not* said. The communication between Milly and Sir Luke transcends dialogue. He "can tell" her condition without asking "stupid" questions; he finds out "simply by his genius." Milly, in turn, intuits his pity, which she visualizes with the horrifyingly vivid metaphor of "a head on a pike, in a French revolution, bobbing before a window." This unspoken understanding forms the true basis of their relationship, a "sign of the eyes only" in their "brown old temple of truth." This contrasts sharply with her stilted, verbal exchanges with Kate, which are fraught with hidden meanings and transactional undertones.

4. **Isolation vs. Intimacy:** Milly describes herself as a "survivor of a general wreck," utterly alone in the world. She tells Sir Luke that the kindness of others is "delightful and useless. Nobody can really help." This profound isolation makes her connection with him all the more powerful. He is the one person who can "help," not by saving her life, but by validating her reality. She insists on seeing him alone because this is a journey she must take by herself, with only a true, objective guide.

#### **Character Development**

1. **Milly Theale:** Milly undergoes a significant internal transformation. She enters the consultation nervous ("stammer and pant") but leaves with a sense of triumph and clarity. * **From Patient to Equal:** Initially awed by "the great man," Milly quickly establishes a relationship of intellectual and emotional equality. She challenges him, asserts her needs, and feels she is giving him a "hint to him that she was as good as himself." This is not arrogance, but a claim to her own agency and dignity in the face of annihilation. * **Embracing Her Fate:** Milly finds a strange liberation in being "found out." The knowledge of her condition, however grim, provides the "orderly living" she has never known. Her relief is almost spiritual; she feels "confessed and... absolved." Her final questions—"Shall I, at any rate, suffer?" "And yet then live?"—are not those of a frightened patient but of a philosopher contemplating the terms of her existence. * **Social Concealment:** Her interaction with Kate Croy reveals her newfound depth and her need to protect it. She carries her new understanding "under her cloak, but dissimulated, invisibly carried." She smiles, but it is a mask for a profound inner experience that Kate, with her practical and slightly cynical worldview ("Is it out?"), cannot comprehend.

2. **Sir Luke Strett:** He is more than a doctor; he is a symbolic figure of authority, wisdom, and compassion. * **The General-Bishop:** The description of him as "half like a general and half like a bishop" is perfect. It captures his blend of commanding, scientific authority (the General who marshals facts) and gentle, moral guidance (the Bishop who tends to the soul). * **Master of Psychology:** His true skill is not just medical but psychological. He understands that Milly needs truth more than false hope. He "allows for" her romanticism, handling her with a delicacy that is both kind and clinical. His kindness is itself a "tell-tale face" of pity, revealing the gravity of the situation without a single word. He expertly manages her, giving her a sense of control ("You can do exactly what I like") while subtly directing her toward the only possible path: living fully.

3. **Kate Croy:** Kate serves as a crucial foil to Milly, representing the social, material world that Milly is beginning to transcend. * **Pragmatism and Superficiality:** Her immediate comparison of Milly's experience to having a tooth pulled highlights her inability to grasp its existential weight. Her questions are practical: "what does he say?" "does he allow then that you're ill?" * **Transactional Nature:** Her sharp question, "But don't you ask a good deal, darling, in proportion to what you give?" reveals an underlying tension and a transactional view of relationships, which stands in stark contrast to the pure, truth-based connection Milly forges with Sir Luke. She is grounded in a world of social maneuvering that Milly is leaving behind.

#### **Major Literary Ideas and Techniques**

* **Psychological Realism:** The narrative is a masterclass in psychological realism, delving deep into Milly's consciousness. The external plot is minimal; the real action is the shifting of perceptions, the formation of intuitions, and the internal struggle for meaning. * **The Jamesian Sentence:** The text is characterized by long, complex sentences with multiple subordinate clauses. This syntax mirrors the intricate and nuanced process of thought, forcing the reader to follow Milly's mind as it qualifies, reflects, and slowly arrives at a conclusion. For example: "The impression... was neither more nor less than that she might make, of a sudden, in quite another world, another straight friend..." * **Potent Metaphors:** James uses powerful, often unsettling metaphors to make abstract psychological states tangible. The "empty cup of attention," the "trophy" of understanding, and especially the "head on a pike" are not mere decorations but central to conveying the characters' inner realities. * **Focalization:** The story is told through a third-person narrator but is tightly focused through Milly's perspective. We see the world and the other characters through her eyes, making her subjective experience the primary reality of the text.

In conclusion, this passage is a microcosm of Henry James's mature style. It uses a seemingly simple event—a doctor's visit—to stage a profound drama of consciousness. Through intricate prose, rich symbolism, and deep character insight, it explores the struggle to find truth, meaning, and authentic connection in the face of ultimate isolation and mortality.

What it really came to, on the morrow, this first time—the time Kate went with her—was that the great man had, a little, to excuse himself; had, by a rare accident—for he kept his consulting-hours in general rigorously free—but ten minutes to give her; ten mere minutes which he yet placed at her service in a manner that she admired even more than she could meet it: so crystal-clean the great empty cup of attention that he set between them on the table. He was presently to jump into his carriage, but he promptly made the point that he must see her again, see her within a day or two; and he named for her at once another hour—easing her off beautifully too even then in respect to her possibly failing of justice to her errand. The minutes affected her in fact as ebbing more swiftly than her little army of items could muster, and they would probably have gone without her doing much more than secure another hearing, had it not been for her sense, at the last, that she had gained above all an impression. The impression—all the sharp growth of the final few moments—was neither more nor less than that she might make, of a sudden, in quite another world, another straight friend, and a friend who would moreover be, wonderfully, the most appointed, the most thoroughly adjusted of the whole collection, inasmuch as he would somehow wear the character scientifically, ponderably, proveably—not just loosely and sociably.

Translation

The next day, when Kate went with her for the first time, the reality was that the great man had to make a slight apology. By a rare stroke of luck—as he typically kept his consulting hours strictly clear—he had only ten minutes to spare for her, a mere ten minutes. He offered them to her in a way she found even more impressive than she could have anticipated. The way he set a completely clear, empty space of attention between them on the table was crystal-clear. He was about to rush off to his carriage, but he immediately insisted he see her again, within the next day or two. He even set another time for her, all while gracefully acknowledging that she might not have fully explained the purpose of her visit. The minutes seemed to slip away faster than her list of points could cover, and she probably would have left without doing much more than securing another meeting, had she not sensed, at the end, that she had gained an impression. The impression—the intense growth in those final moments—was, simply, that she might find, unexpectedly, a new true friend in a completely different world. Moreover, this friend would be, wonderfully, the most perfectly suited, the most meticulously prepared of all, as he would somehow embody the role scientifically, thoughtfully, and demonstrably, not just casually and sociably.

Literally, furthermore, it wouldn't really depend on herself, Sir Luke Strett's friendship, in the least; perhaps what made her most stammer and pant was its thus queerly coming over her that she might find she had interested him even beyond her intention, find she was in fact launched in some current that would lose itself in the sea of science. At the same time that she struggled, however, she also surrendered; there was a moment at which she almost dropped the form of stating, of explaining, and threw herself, without violence, only with a supreme pointless quaver that had turned, the next instant, to an intensity of interrogative stillness, upon his general goodwill. His large, settled face, though firm, was not, as she had thought at first, hard; he looked, in the oddest manner, to her fancy, half like a general and half like a bishop, and she was soon sure that, within some such handsome range, what it would show her would be what was good, what was best for her. She had established, in other words, in this time-saving way, a relation with it; and the relation was the special trophy that, for the hour, she bore off.

Translation

Moreover, in reality, it wouldn't hinge on her own initiative or desire for friendship with Sir Luke Strett, not at all. Perhaps what made her the most flustered and breathless was the strange sensation that she might have engaged his interest even further than she'd intended, that she was, in fact, caught in a current that would ultimately be absorbed into the vastness of scientific knowledge. However, as she grappled with this, she also yielded; there was a moment when she nearly abandoned the effort to articulate, to clarify, and instead cast herself, without any dramatic outburst but with an overwhelming, pointless tremor that immediately transformed into an intense, questioning stillness, upon his general benevolence. His large, composed face, although firm, wasn't, as she had initially thought, harsh; he appeared, in a peculiar way, to her imagination, a blend of a general and a bishop, and she quickly felt certain that, within that admirable combination, whatever he revealed to her would be beneficial, would be what was best for her. In other words, in this efficient exchange, she had forged a connection; and this connection was the unique prize that she carried with her for the moment.

It was like an absolute possession, a new resource altogether, something done up in the softest silk and tucked away under the arm of memory. She hadn't had it when she went in, and she had it when she came out; she had it there under her cloak, but dissimulated, invisibly carried, when smiling, smiling, she again faced Kate Croy. That young lady had of course awaited her in another room, where, as the great man was to absent himself, no one else was in attendance; and she rose for her with such a face of sympathy as might have graced the vestibule of a dentist. "Is it out?" she seemed to ask as if it had been a question of a tooth; and Milly indeed kept her in no suspense at all.

Translation

It was like a complete acquisition, a brand new asset, something wrapped in the softest silk and carefully stowed away in the arm of her memory. She hadn't possessed it when she entered, but it was hers when she left; she carried it beneath her cloak, concealed and invisible, as she smiled and smiled again at Kate Croy. That young woman had waited for her in another room, where, because the distinguished man was about to leave, no one else was present; and Kate rose to greet her with a sympathetic expression that might have been suitable for a dentist's waiting room. "Is it out?" she seemed to ask, as if the matter had concerned a tooth; and Milly indeed didn't keep her in suspense.

The next day, when Kate accompanied her, the great man had to make a slight apology. By a rare stroke of bad luck—he usually kept his consultation hours strictly open—he only had ten minutes to spare for her. He offered those ten minutes with a grace that she found even more impressive than she could have hoped for. The great, empty space of his attention sat between them on the table, crystal-clear.

Translation

The following day, when Kate was with her, the eminent man had to offer a small apology. By a cruel twist of fate—he generally stuck to his scheduled hours—he could give her only ten minutes. He offered those ten minutes with a charm that she found even more remarkable than she'd anticipated. The vast, unoccupied expanse of his attention rested between them on the table, perfectly transparent.

He was about to leave in his carriage, but he insisted he see her again within a day or two. He immediately suggested another time, even then smoothly easing her concerns about not fully expressing her purpose. The minutes seemed to slip away faster than she could present her ideas. She probably wouldn't have accomplished much more than scheduling another meeting if she hadn't realized, at the very end, that she had gained an impression.

Translation

He was on his way out in his carriage, but he made a point of seeing her again in a day or two. He suggested another time right away, assuaging her worries about not fully explaining what she'd come for. The minutes evaporated before she could present all her ideas. She probably wouldn't have gotten much further than setting up another meeting if she hadn't realized, at the very end, that she'd made an impression.

That impression, which grew intensely in those last few moments, was simply that she might suddenly gain a true friend in a completely different world. Moreover, this friend would be the most perfectly suited, the most perfectly adjusted of all, because he would embody the role scientifically and demonstrably, not just casually and socially. In fact, Sir Luke Strett's friendship wouldn't really depend on her at all. Perhaps what made her the most nervous was the strange realization that she might have captured his interest beyond what she intended, that she had been swept into a current that would dissolve into the ocean of science.

Translation

That impression, which had intensified in those last few moments, was simply that she might unexpectedly find a genuine friend in an entirely different world. Furthermore, this friend would be the most ideal, the most perfectly suited of all, because he would embody the role through scientific means and verifiable evidence, not just through casual social interaction. In reality, a friendship with Sir Luke Strett wouldn't necessarily rely on her at all. Perhaps what made her the most anxious was the strange realization that she might have captured his interest beyond her intentions, that she had been swept into a current destined to dissolve into the ocean of science.

At the same time, though, she surrendered. There was a moment when she almost abandoned trying to state or explain her case, instead throwing herself—without violence, only with a supreme, pointless trembling that instantly transformed into an intense, questioning stillness—upon his general kindness. His large, settled face, though firm, wasn't, as she'd first thought, harsh. He looked, in a peculiar way, both like a general and a bishop, and she soon believed that, within such a handsome range, he would show her what was good and best for her.

Translation

Simultaneously, she gave in. There was a moment when she nearly stopped trying to articulate or justify her position. Instead, she threw herself—without force, only with an extreme, meaningless trembling that immediately became an intense, probing stillness—upon his overall benevolence. His large, composed face, while resolute, wasn't severe as she had initially imagined. In a strange way, he resembled both a military leader and a clergyman, and she soon believed that, within such an attractive scope, he would reveal to her what was right and best for her.

In other words, in this time-saving manner, she had established a connection with him. This connection was the special prize she carried away for the moment. It was like an absolute possession, a brand-new resource, something wrapped in the softest silk and tucked away in her memory. She hadn't had it when she went in, but she had it when she came out.

Translation

In essence, she'd forged a bond with him, a shortcut to understanding. This connection was her immediate reward, a tangible prize. It was an absolute acquisition, a fresh asset, something delicate and carefully stored within her memory. She hadn't possessed it when she entered, but it was hers upon exiting.

She carried it under her cloak, hidden, unseen, as she smiled and smiled, facing Kate Croy again. The young woman had waited for her in another room, where, because the great man was leaving, no one else was present. Kate rose to meet her with a face of sympathy that might have been found in a dentist's waiting room. "Is it out?" she seemed to ask, as if it were a tooth.

Translation

She kept it concealed beneath her cloak, invisible. She kept smiling and smiling as she went back to Kate Croy. The younger woman had waited for her in a separate room, where, because the esteemed man was departing, no one else was there. Kate stood up to greet her, her expression sympathetic in a way that felt familiar from a dentist’s waiting room. "Is it out?" she appeared to ask, as though it were a tooth.

And indeed, Milly kept her in no suspense at all. "He's a dear. I'm to come again." "But what does he say?"

Translation

And truly, Milly wasted no time. "He's lovely. I can go back." "But what did he say?"

Milly was almost gay. "That I'm not to worry about anything in the world, and that if I'll be a good girl and do exactly what he tells me, he'll take care of me for ever and ever." Kate wondered as if things scarce fitted. "But does he allow then that you're ill?"

Translation

Milly was practically ecstatic. "That I shouldn't worry about anything in the world, and that if I'm a good girl and do exactly as he says, he'll take care of me forever and ever." Kate seemed puzzled, as if things weren't quite right. "But does he admit, then, that you're sick?"

"I don't know what he allows, and I don't care. I shall know, and whatever it is it will be enough. He knows all about me, and I like it. I don't hate it a bit."

Translation

"I don't know what he acknowledges, and I don't care. I will know, and whatever it is will be sufficient. He knows everything about me, and I like it. I don't resent it at all."

Still, however, Kate stared. "But could he, in so few minutes, ask you enough——?" "He asked me scarcely anything—he doesn't need to do anything so stupid," Milly said. "He can tell.

Translation

Nevertheless, Kate continued to stare. "But could he, in such a short amount of time, ask you enough——?" "He barely asked me anything—he doesn't need to do anything so foolish," Milly said. "He can just tell."

He knows," she repeated; "and when I go back—for he'll have thought me over a little—it will be all right." He's a sweetheart. He wants me to come back. "But what does he say?"

Translation

"He knows," she repeated. "And when I go back—because he'll have considered it a bit—it'll be fine." He's wonderful. He wants me to return. "But what does he say?"

Milly was almost giddy with joy. "That I shouldn't worry about anything, and that if I'm a good girl and do exactly as he says, he'll take care of me forever." Kate seemed to struggle with the situation. "But does he acknowledge that you're sick?"

Translation

Milly was practically beside herself with happiness. "That I shouldn't worry about a thing, and if I'm a good girl and do everything he tells me, he'll look after me always." Kate seemed to be grappling with it. "But does he even admit you're ill?"

"I don't know what he acknowledges, and I don't care. I will know, and whatever it is, it will be enough. He knows everything about me, and I like it. I don't mind it at all."

Translation

"I don't know what he admits, and I don't care. I will know, and whatever it is, it will be enough. He knows everything about me, and I like that. I don't mind it at all."

Translation

"He knows," she repeated; "and when I go back—because he'll have considered me a bit—it will be all right." Kate, after a moment, made the best of this. "Then when are we to come?" It just pulled her friend up, for even while they talked—at least it was one of the reasons—she stood there suddenly, irrelevantly, in the light of her other identity, the identity she would have for Mr.

Densher. This was always, from one instant to another, an incalculable light, which, though it might go off faster than it came on, necessarily disturbed. It sprang, with a perversity all its own, from the fact that, with the lapse of hours and days, the chances themselves that made for his being named continued so oddly to fail. There were twenty, there were fifty, but none of them turned up.

Translation

She said that he knew. And when she returned, because he’d have given her some thought, things would be alright. After a pause, Kate made the best of the situation. “So when are we supposed to come?” That stopped her friend cold because even while they spoke—at least one of the reasons they were talking—she stood there, suddenly, irrelevantly, in the light of her other identity, the identity she would have for Mr. Densher. This was always, from one moment to the next, an unpredictable light, which, though it might fade faster than it appeared, was inherently unsettling. It sprang, with a perversity all its own, from the fact that, with the passing of hours and days, the opportunities that might have led to his being named continued so strangely to disappear. There were twenty, there were fifty, but none of them materialized.

This, in particular, was of course not a juncture at which the least of them would naturally be present; but it would make, none the less, Milly saw, another day practically all stamped with avoidance. She saw in a quick glimmer, and with it all Kate's unconsciousness; and then she shook off the obsession. But it had lasted long enough to qualify her response. No, she had shown Kate how she trusted her; and that, for loyalty, would somehow do.

Translation

This, in particular, was obviously not a moment when any of them would be expected to be around. But it would, Milly realized, nonetheless mean another day almost entirely defined by avoidance. She saw it in a flash, and with it, all of Kate's obliviousness; and then she cast off the thought. But it had lasted long enough to impact her reaction. No, she had demonstrated to Kate how much she trusted her; and that, for the sake of loyalty, would have to suffice.

"Oh, dear thing, now that the ice is broken I shan't trouble you again." Kate, after a moment, decided to make the best of it. "So, when are we coming?" This question startled her friend, because, even as they spoke—or at least partly because of it—she was suddenly and unexpectedly seen in the light of her other self, the self she presented to Mr.

Translation

"Oh, darling, now that we've cleared the air, I won't bother you anymore." Kate, after a pause, decided to make the best of it. "So, when are we going?" Densher. This was always an unpredictable light, which, though it could vanish quickly, always caused her to feel uneasy. There were twenty, there were fifty, but none of them appeared.

Translation

Densher. It was a light that always shifted, one that, though it might fade fast, never failed to make her uncomfortable. Translation

Milly had demonstrated her trust in Kate; and, because of their loyalty, that would suffice. "Oh, darling, now that we've begun, I won't trouble you anymore." "You'll come by yourself?" "Without hesitation."

Only I shall ask you, please, for your absolute discretion still." Outside, before the door, on the wide pavement of the great square, they had to wait again while their carriage, which Milly had kept, completed a further turn of exercise, engaged in by the coachman for reasons of his own. The footman was there, and had indicated that he was making the circuit; so Kate went on while they stood. "But don't you ask a good deal, darling, in proportion to what you give?"

Translation

"I'll only ask one more thing of you, please: absolute discretion." Outside, before the door, on the wide pavement of the great square, they had to wait again while their carriage, which Milly had kept, completed another turn of exercise, engaged in by the coachman for reasons of his own. The footman was there and indicated he was making the circuit, so Kate went on while they stood. "But aren't you asking a great deal, darling, considering what you offer?"

This pulled Milly up still shorter—so short in fact that she yielded as soon as she had taken it in. But she continued to smile. "I see. Then you can tell."

Translation

This stopped Milly in her tracks, so abruptly, in fact, that she gave in the moment she understood. But she kept smiling. "I understand. Then you can tell."

"You'll come by yourself?" "No problem. But I'm going to need you to be completely discreet, as always." Outside, in front of the door, on the broad sidewalk of the large square, they had to wait again.

Translation

"Will you come alone?" "No problem. But I'll need you to be completely discreet, as always." Outside, in front of the door, on the wide sidewalk of the large square, they had to wait again.

Their carriage, which Milly had kept waiting, was going around the block once more. The coachman was doing it for his own reasons. The footman was there, and he'd signaled that he was making the circuit. So, Kate kept walking while they waited.

Translation

The carriage that Milly had instructed to wait was circling the block again. The coachman was doing this on his own accord. The footman remained present, and he had signaled that he was completing the loop. Kate continued to walk while they waited.

"But don't you demand a lot, darling, considering what you offer?" This stopped Milly in her tracks, so abruptly that she gave in as soon as she understood. But she kept smiling. "I see.

Translation

"But you're quite the high-maintenance type, aren't you, given what you bring to the table?" The remark brought Milly to a standstill, so suddenly that she conceded immediately once she understood. Still, she maintained her smile. "I see."

Then you can tell." "I don't want to 'tell,'" said Kate. "I'll be as silent as the tomb if I can only have the truth from you. All I want is that you shouldn't keep from me how you find out that you really are."

Translation

"Fine, then you can tell me."

"I don't want to 'tell,'" Kate said. "I'll keep quiet, absolutely silent, if only I can hear the truth from you. All I want is for you to share how you discover your true self."

"Well then, I won't, ever. But you see for yourself," Milly went on, "how I really am. I'm satisfied. I'm happy."

Translation

"Alright, I won't, then, not ever. But you can plainly see," Milly continued, "what I'm actually like. I'm content. I'm happy."

Kate looked at her long. "I believe you like it. The way things turn out for you——!" Milly met her look now without a thought of anything but the spoken.

Translation

Kate scrutinized her for a long moment. "I think you relish it. The way things always seem to go for you——!" Milly met her gaze, no other thought present, only the words themselves.

She had ceased to be Mr. Densher's image; she was all her own memento and she was none the less fine. Still, still, what had passed was a fair bargain, and it would do. "Of course I like it.

Translation

She was no longer Mr. Densher's reflection; she was her own remembrance, and none the less impressive for it. Yet, even so, what had occurred was a reasonable trade, and it would suffice. "Certainly I do."

I feel—I can't otherwise describe it—as if I had been, on my knees, to the priest. I've confessed and I've been absolved. It has been lifted off." "I don't want to explain," Kate said.

Translation

I feel—I can't describe it any other way—like I was on my knees before the priest. I've confessed and I've been absolved. It's been lifted off. "I don't want to explain," Kate said.

"I'll be completely quiet if you just tell me the truth. All I want is for you to be honest with me about how you feel about yourself." "Alright then, I will," Milly continued, "I will. But you can see how I really feel.

Translation

"I won't say a word if you just give me the truth. All I want is for you to be honest with me about how you feel about yourself." "Fine, then, I will," Milly said, continuing, "I will. But you can see how I really feel."

I'm content. I'm happy." Kate stared at her for a long time. "I believe you're enjoying this.

Translation

"I'm content. I'm happy." Kate stared at her for a long time. "I believe you're enjoying this."

The way things are working out for you—!" Milly looked back at her without thinking about anything other than what was being said. She was no longer Mr. Densher's idea of her; she was entirely her own memory, and she was no less remarkable.

Translation

"The way things are working out for you!" Milly turned, unconcerned with anything but the words. She was no longer defined by Mr. Densher's perception of her; she was solely her own recollection, and no less extraordinary for it.

Even so, what had happened was a fair exchange, and it would suffice. "Of course I enjoy it. I feel—I can't describe it any other way—like I've knelt before a priest. I've confessed and I've been forgiven.

Translation

Even so, the events constituted a just transaction, and that would do. "Of course I enjoy it. I feel—I can't express it any differently—like I've knelt before a priest. I've confessed and I've been forgiven."

It's been lifted from me." Kate's eyes never quitted her. "He must have liked you." "Oh—doctors!" Milly said.

Translation

"It's been lifted from me." Kate never took her eyes off her. "He must have liked you." "Oh—doctors!" Milly said.

"But I hope," she added, "he didn't like me too much." Then as if to escape a little from her friend's deeper sounding, or as impatient for the carriage, not yet in sight, her eyes, turning away, took in the great stale square. As its staleness, however, was but that of London fairly fatigued, the late hot London with its dance all danced and its story all told, the air seemed a thing of blurred pictures and mixed echoes, and an impression met the sense—an impression that broke, the next moment, through the girl's tightened lips. "Oh, it's a beautiful big world, and everyone, yes, everyone——!" It presently brought her back to Kate, and she hoped she didn't actually look as much as if she were crying as she must have looked to Lord Mark among the portraits at Matcham. Kate never stopped watching her.

Translation

"But I hope," she added, "he didn't like me too much." Then, as if to escape a little from her friend's probing, or as if impatient for the carriage, not yet in sight, her eyes turned away, taking in the great, stale square. But since its staleness was just that of a London fairly exhausted, late, hot London with its dance all danced and its story all told, the air seemed a thing of blurred pictures and mixed echoes, and an impression met her senses—an impression that broke, the next moment, through the girl's tightened lips. "Oh, it's a beautiful, big world, and everyone, yes, everyone—!" It presently brought her back to Kate, and she hoped she didn't actually look as much as if she were crying as she must have looked to Lord Mark among the portraits at Matcham. Kate never stopped watching her.

"He must have been attracted to you." "Oh, doctors!" Milly said. "But I hope," she added, "he wasn't too fond of me." Then, as if trying to escape her friend's probing questions, or perhaps impatient for the carriage, which hadn't arrived, she looked away, taking in the large, tired square. But its tiredness was only that of a London worn out, the late summer London with its parties over and its stories told, and the atmosphere felt like a blur of images and a mixture of sounds.

Translation

"He must have been attracted to you." "Oh, doctors!" Milly said. "But I hope," she added, "he wasn't too fond of me." Then, as if trying to escape her friend's probing questions, or perhaps impatient for the carriage, which hadn't arrived, she looked away, taking in the large, tired square. But its tiredness was only that of a London worn out, the late summer London with its parties over and its stories told, and the atmosphere felt like a blur of images and a mixture of sounds.

An impression hit her—an impression that she couldn't help but reveal, the next moment, through her tightened lips. "Oh, it's a beautiful, huge world, and everyone, yes, everyone—!" It brought her back to Kate eventually, and she hoped she didn't look as though she was about to cry as she must have looked to Lord Mark among the portraits at Matcham. Kate at all events understood. "Everyone wants to be so nice?"

Translation

An idea struck her—an idea she couldn't help but show a second later, her lips compressing. "Oh, it's a beautiful, massive world, and everyone, yes, everyone—!" It brought her back to Kate eventually, and she hoped she didn't look like she was about to cry, the way she must have looked to Lord Mark among the portraits at Matcham. At any rate, Kate understood. "Everyone wants to be so kind?"

"So nice," said the grateful Milly. "Oh," Kate laughed, "we'll pull you through! And won't you now bring Mrs. Stringham?"

Translation

"So nice," said the grateful Milly. "Oh," Kate laughed, "we'll get you through! And won't you bring Mrs. Stringham along now?"

But Milly after an instant was again clear about that. "Not till I've seen him once more." She was to have found this preference, two days later, abundantly justified; and yet when, in prompt accordance with what had passed between them, she reappeared before her distinguished friend—that character having, for him, in the interval, built itself up still higher—the first thing he asked her was whether she had been accompanied. She told him, on this, straightway, everything; completely free at present from her first embarrassment, disposed even—as she felt she might become—to undue volubility, and conscious moreover of no alarm from his thus perhaps wishing that she had not come alone.

Translation

But Milly was certain about that again after a moment. "Not until I've seen him one more time." She would have found this preference fully validated two days later. Yet when she reappeared before her distinguished friend—a status that had only grown for him in the meantime—in prompt accordance with their conversation, the first thing he asked her was if she had brought anyone with her. She told him everything right away, entirely free now from her initial awkwardness, even inclined—as she felt she might become—to excessive talkativeness, and also feeling no alarm at his possibly wishing she hadn’t come alone.

It was exactly as if, in the forty-eight hours that had passed, her acquaintance with him had somehow increased, and his own knowledge in particular received mysterious additions. They had been together, before, scarce ten minutes; but the relation, the one the ten minutes had so beautifully created, was there to take straight up: and this not, on his own part, from mere professional heartiness, mere bedside manner, which she would have disliked—much rather from a quiet, pleasant air in him of having positively asked about her, asked here and there and found out. Of course he couldn't in the least have asked, or have wanted to; there was no source of information to his hand, and he had really needed none: he had found out simply by his genius—and found out, she meant, literally everything. Now she knew not only that she didn't dislike this—the state of being found out about; but that, on the contrary, it was truly what she had come for, and that, for the time at least, it would give her something firm to stand on.

Translation

It was as though, in the intervening forty-eight hours, her connection to him had somehow deepened, and his understanding of her had mysteriously grown. They'd spent scarcely ten minutes together before, but the connection, beautifully forged in those ten minutes, was immediately there to resume. This wasn’t due to any professional warmth on his part, any bedside manner, which she would have disliked—rather, it came from a calm, pleasant demeanor that suggested he'd specifically inquired about her, sought information, and learned things. Of course, he couldn't possibly have inquired or wanted to; he had no ready source of information, and in truth, he'd needed none: he'd discovered everything simply through his innate skill—and "everything," she meant, literally. Now, not only did she not dislike this—the state of being known; but on the contrary, it was truly what she had come for, and for the moment at least, it would provide her with something stable to rely on.

She struck herself as aware, aware as she had never been, of really not having had from the beginning anything firm. It would be strange for the firmness to come, after all, from her learning in these agreeable conditions that she was in some way doomed; but above all it would prove how little she had hitherto had to hold her up. If she was now to be held up by the mere process—since that was perhaps on the cards—of being let down, this would only testify in turn to her queer little history. That sense of loosely rattling had been no process at all; and it was ridiculously true that her thus sitting there to see her life put into the scales represented her first approach to the taste of orderly living.

Translation

She realized she was aware, as she'd never been before, that she'd never truly had anything solid from the start. It would be odd if this stability arose from discovering, in these pleasant circumstances, that she was somehow doomed. But above all, it would show how little she'd had to sustain her up to this point. If she was now to be held up by the simple act—since that was perhaps a possibility—of being let down, it would only further confirm her strange little history. That feeling of being loose and rattling had been no process at all. And it was ridiculously true that her sitting there to have her life weighed represented her first taste of orderly living.
