Such was Milly's romantic version—that her life, especially by the fact of this second interview, was put into the scales; and just the best part of the relation established might have been, for that matter, that the great grave charming man knew, had known at once, that it was romantic, and in that measure allowed for it. Her only doubt, her only fear, was whether he perhaps wouldn't even take advantage of her being a little romantic to treat her as romantic altogether. This doubtless was her danger with him; but she should see, and dangers in general meanwhile dropped and dropped. Kate understood everything.

Translation

Such was Milly's romantic idea: that her life, especially through this second meeting, was being assessed. The best thing about their relationship, for all she knew, might have been that the great, serious, charming man understood—had understood at once—that she was prone to romance, and adjusted his assessment accordingly. Her only worry, her only fear, was that he might take advantage of her romantic nature and treat her as a romantic character entirely. That was, without a doubt, her risk with him. But she would see, and in the meantime, her general anxieties diminished. Kate understood everything.

"Everyone wants to be so kind?" "So kind," Milly responded, grateful. "Oh," Kate laughed, "We'll get you through this! Won't you bring Mrs.

Translation

"Everyone wants to be so kind?"

"So kind," Milly answered, feeling grateful.

"Oh," Kate laughed, "We'll get you through this! Won't you bring Mrs. Lowder?"

Stringham?" But Milly knew immediately. "Not until I've seen him again." Two days later, she would find this preference completely validated.

Translation

Stringham?" But Milly knew immediately. "Not until I've seen him again." Two days later, she would find this preference completely validated.

When she returned to her distinguished friend, in accordance with their conversation—a character that, for him, had further developed in the meantime—the first thing he asked was whether she had company. She then explained everything to him, free from her initial nervousness and even prone to becoming overly talkative—and without any fear that he might have preferred she hadn't come alone. It was as though, in the past forty-eight hours, their acquaintance had deepened, and his understanding, in particular, had gained mysterious dimensions. They had been together for hardly ten minutes before, but the connection, beautifully formed in those ten minutes, was immediately re-established.

Translation

When she went back to her distinguished friend, as they had discussed—a character that, in the interim, had further developed for him—the first thing he asked was if she was with someone. She then explained everything, without her initial anxiety, and even tending towards garrulousness—and without any fear that he would have preferred her not to be alone. It was as if, in the past two days, their acquaintance had deepened, and his understanding, in particular, had gained mysterious dimensions. They had been together for hardly ten minutes before, but the connection, beautifully formed in those ten minutes, was immediately re-established.

It wasn't due to mere professional warmth or bedside manner, which she would have disliked, but a quiet, pleasant manner that suggested he'd asked about her, made inquiries, and learned things. Of course, he couldn't have asked or wanted to; there was no source of information, and he hadn't needed any. He'd simply found out through his extraordinary insight, meaning he understood literally everything. Now, she realized not only that she didn't dislike this—being understood—but that it was exactly what she had hoped for and would give her something stable to rely on, at least for now.

Translation

It wasn't just a matter of professional courtesy or a comforting demeanor, which she would have found off-putting. Instead, it was a calm, agreeable approach that implied he had thought about her, sought information, and become informed. Of course, he couldn't have done any of that; there were no avenues for gathering such information, and he hadn't needed them. He had simply discovered it through his exceptional intuition, signifying he understood everything, quite literally. Now, she realized that she not only didn't object to this—being understood—but that it was precisely what she had desired and would provide her with something reliable to lean on, at least for the time being.

She felt more aware than ever that she had never truly had anything solid. It would be strange if this stability came from discovering, in these pleasant circumstances, that she was somehow doomed. Above all, it would show how little she had had to support her. If she were now to be supported by the very process—since that was possible—of being let down, that would only confirm her unusual life.

Translation

She felt a sharpened sense of how little she'd ever truly possessed that was stable. It would be an odd twist if this sense of security originated in the realization—under these deceptively pleasant conditions—that she was, in some way, already doomed. More than anything, it would underscore how little she had to rely upon. If she were now to be supported by the very process—because it seemed possible—of being let down, it would only validate the extraordinary nature of her life.

That feeling of emptiness had been no process at all, and it was ridiculously true that sitting there, having her life assessed, was her first experience of a structured life. That was Milly's romantic interpretation: that her life, especially with this second meeting, was being assessed. Perhaps the best part of their relationship was that the impressive, serious, and charming man knew, had known from the start, that it was romantic, and had factored that in. Her only doubt, her only fear, was whether he might take advantage of her romanticism and treat her entirely as a romantic figure.

Translation

That emptiness had never been a process, and it was absurdly true that sitting there, having her life evaluated, was the first time she'd experienced a structured existence. That was Milly's romantic reading: that her life, especially with this second meeting, was under assessment. Perhaps the best thing about their relationship was that the impressive, serious, and charming man knew, had known from the beginning, that it was romantic, and had accounted for that. Her only doubt, her only fear, was whether he might exploit her romanticism and treat her exclusively as a romantic character.

That was likely her danger with him, but she would see, and dangers in general began to fade away. The very place, at the end of a few minutes, the commodious, "handsome" room, far back in the fine old house, soundless from position, somewhat sallow with years of celebrity, somewhat sombre even at midsummer—the very place put on for her a look of custom and use, squared itself solidly round her as with promises and certainties. She had come forth to see the world, and this then was to be the world's light, the rich dusk of a London "back," these the world's walls, those the world's curtains and carpet. She should be intimate with the great bronze clock and mantel-ornaments, conspicuously presented in gratitude and long ago; she should be as one of the circle of eminent contemporaries, photographed, engraved, signatured, and in particular framed and glazed, who made up the rest of the decoration, and made up as well so much of the human comfort; and while she thought of all the clean truths, unfringed, unfingered, that the listening stillness, strained into pauses and waits, would again and again, for years, have kept distinct, she also wondered what she would eventually decide upon to present in gratitude.

Translation

That was probably her risk with him, but she would find out, and the concept of danger in general was beginning to recede. Within a few minutes, the space itself, the comfortable, "handsome" room situated deep within the elegant old house, silent due to its location, a little faded from years of notoriety, somewhat gloomy even in midsummer—that very room took on for her the aspect of habit and familiarity, settling firmly around her as if with promises and certainties. She had set out to see the world, and this, then, was to be the world's illumination, the rich twilight of a London "back," these were the world's walls, those the world's curtains and carpet. She would become acquainted with the grand bronze clock and mantel ornaments, conspicuously displayed in gratitude from long ago; she would become one of the circle of distinguished contemporaries, photographed, engraved, autographed, and particularly framed and glazed, who comprised the rest of the decor, and also represented so much of the human comfort; and while she contemplated all the clear truths, unadorned, untouched, that the attentive stillness, strained into pauses and expectant moments, would repeatedly, for years, have preserved distinctly, she also wondered what she would ultimately choose to offer in return.

She would give something better at least than the brawny Victorian bronzes. This was precisely an instance of what she felt he knew of her before he had done with her: that she was secretly romancing at that rate, in the midst of so much else that was more urgent, all over the place. So much for her secrets with him, none of which really required to be phrased. It would have been, for example, a secret for her from any one else that without a dear lady she had picked up just before coming over she wouldn't have a decently near connection, of any sort, for such an appeal as she was making, to put forward: no one in the least, as it were, to produce for respectability.

Translation

She would at least give something better than those bulky Victorian bronzes. This was exactly what she thought he understood about her before he was done with her: that she was secretly indulging in fantasy, at that rate, amidst so much else that was more pressing, all over the place. So much for her secrets with him, none of which really needed to be articulated. It would have been, for instance, a secret from anyone else that without a dear lady she'd met just before coming, she wouldn't have a remotely close connection of any sort for the kind of appeal she was making, to present: no one, in effect, to produce for the sake of appearances.

But his seeing it she didn't mind a scrap, and not a scrap either his knowing how she had left the dear lady in the dark. She had come alone, putting her friend off with a fraud: giving a pretext of shops, of a whim, of she didn't know what—the amusement of being for once in the streets by herself. The streets by herself were new to her—she had always had in them a companion, or a maid; and he was never to believe, moreover, that she couldn't take full in the face anything he might have to say. He was softly amused at her account of her courage; though he yet showed it somehow without soothing her too grossly.

Translation

But that he saw through her didn't bother her in the least, nor did it bother her that he knew she'd left her dear friend in the dark. She had come alone, putting her friend off with a lie, giving an excuse of shopping, of a whim, of she didn't know what—the fun of being, for once, in the streets by herself. The streets by herself were new to her—she had always had a companion, or a maid; and he was never to believe, furthermore, that she couldn't take head-on whatever he had to say. He was gently amused by her story of her courage, though he still managed to show it somehow without overdoing the reassurance.

Still, he did want to know whom she had. Hadn't there been a lady with her on Wednesday? The room itself, after a few minutes, the spacious, "handsome" room, located at the back of the beautiful old house, silent due to its position, somewhat faded with years of fame, even a bit somber in the middle of summer—the room itself seemed familiar and well-used, solidifying around her with promises and certainties. She had come to experience the world, and this, then, was to be the world's light, the rich dimness of a London "back room," these the world's walls, those the world's curtains and carpet.

Translation

He still wanted to know about her company. Wasn’t there a woman with her on Wednesday? The room itself, after several minutes—a large, “handsome” room situated in the rear of the lovely old house, silent by its nature, somewhat faded with years of renown, even a little somber in the middle of summer—the room itself felt familiar and well-worn, settling around her with promises and certainties. She had come to experience the world, and this, then, was to be the world's light, the rich dimness of a London “back room,” these the world's walls, those the world's curtains and carpet.

She would become familiar with the large bronze clock and the ornaments on the mantelpiece, prominently displayed as gifts from long ago; she would become part of the group of famous contemporaries, photographed, engraved, with their signatures, and especially framed and glazed, who made up the rest of the decor and much of the human comfort. As she considered the clear, untouched truths, held in the listening stillness, strained into pauses and waits, which would again and again, for years, be kept separate, she also wondered what she would ultimately decide to give as a gift. She would provide something better than the bulky Victorian bronzes, at least. This was a perfect example of what she felt he already knew about her: that she was secretly imagining stories, even when surrounded by more pressing matters, all over the place.

Translation

She would become accustomed to the large bronze clock and the ornaments on the mantelpiece, proudly displayed as relics from the past. She would become a fixture among the gallery of celebrated contemporaries, immortalized in photographs, engravings, adorned with their signatures, meticulously framed and glazed—the very essence of the room's decor and much of its human warmth. As she contemplated the stark, untainted truths, preserved in the receptive silence, distilled into pauses and anticipations, which would, repeatedly, over the years, remain distinct, she also contemplated the gift she would ultimately offer. It would be something superior to those heavy Victorian bronzes, at the very least. This was a prime illustration of what she sensed he already understood about her: that she was secretly weaving narratives, even amidst more immediate concerns, in every conceivable corner of her mind.

So much for her secrets with him, none of which truly needed to be spoken. For example, it would have been a secret from anyone else that without a dear friend she had met just before coming over, she wouldn't have any kind of connection that was respectable for the visit she was making; no one she could really bring along to appear proper. But she didn't care at all that he knew, nor did she care that he knew how she had left the dear lady in the dark. She had come alone, deceiving her friend with a lie: claiming to be going shopping, a whim, she didn't know what—the fun of being alone in the streets for once.

Translation

As for her secrets shared with him, none of them required actual words. For instance, it would be a secret to anyone else that, absent a dear friend she'd met just prior, she’d have possessed no suitable connection to legitimize her visit; no one to properly chaperone her. But she held no concern that he knew, nor did it bother her that he knew how she'd misled the dear lady. She'd come alone, having deceived her friend with a lie: that she was off shopping, a spontaneous urge, she didn't know what—the novelty of being solitary on the streets for once.

Being alone in the streets was new to her—she had always had a companion or a maid; and, furthermore, he should never believe that she couldn't face anything he might say. He was subtly amused by her account of her bravery; though he somehow showed it without being too patronizing. Still, he wanted to know who she had with her. Hadn't there been a lady with her on Wednesday?

Translation

Being alone on the streets was a novel experience for her—she'd always had someone with her, either a friend or a maid. And, moreover, he shouldn't think for a moment that anything he could say would intimidate her. He found her recounting of her boldness amusing, though he managed to convey this without being condescending. Nonetheless, he wanted to know who she was with. Wasn't there a lady with her on Wednesday?

"Yes—a different one. Not the one who's travelling with me. I've told her." Distinctly he was amused, and it added to his air—the greatest charm of all—of giving her lots of time.

Translation

"Yes, a different one. Not the one who's traveling with me. I've told her." He was clearly amused, and it enhanced his appeal—his most captivating trait—of making her feel she had all the time in the world.

"You've told her what?" "Well," said Milly, "that I visit you in secret." "And how many persons will she tell?" "Oh, she's devoted.

Translation

"You told her what?" "Well," Milly said, "that I see you on the sly." "And how many people will she blab to?" "Oh, she's devoted.

Not one." "Well, if she's devoted doesn't that make another friend for you?" It didn't take much computation, but she nevertheless had to think a moment, conscious as she was that he distinctly would want to fill out his notion of her—even a little, as it were, to warm the air for her. That, however—and better early than late—he must accept as of no use; and she herself felt for an instant quite a competent certainty on the subject of any such warming.

Translation

"Not one," Milly said. "Well, if she's devoted, doesn't that make another friend for you?" It didn't take much thinking, but she still had to pause, aware that he clearly wanted to understand her better—even a little, as if to make things more comfortable for her. But that—and it was better to be clear about it sooner rather than later—he had to accept as pointless. And she herself felt a solid conviction about any such attempt to make things more comfortable.

The air, for Milly Theale, was, from the very nature of the case, destined never to rid itself of a considerable chill. This she could tell him with authority, if she could tell him nothing else; and she seemed to see now, in short, that it would importantly simplify. "Yes, it makes another; but they all together wouldn't make—well, I don't know what to call it but the difference. I mean when one is—really alone.

Translation

The air, for Milly Theale, was, by its very nature, never going to shake off a persistent chill. She could tell him this with certainty, even if she couldn’t tell him anything else; and it seemed clear to her now that this would significantly simplify things. "Yes, it adds one more; but they wouldn’t add up—well, I don’t know what to call it, but the essential difference. I mean, when one is—truly alone."

I've never seen anything like the kindness." She pulled up a minute while he waited—waited again as if with his reasons for letting her, for almost making her, talk. What she herself wanted was not, for the third time, to cry, as it were, in public. She had never seen anything like the kindness, and she wished to do it justice; but she knew what she was about, and justice was not wronged by her being able presently to stick to her point. "Only one's situation is what it is.

Translation

"I've never seen anything like the kindness." She paused for a moment while he waited—waited again as if he had his reasons for letting her, for almost making her, talk. What she herself wanted was not, for the third time, to cry, so to speak, in public. She had never seen anything like the kindness, and she wished to do it justice; but she knew what she was doing, and justice wouldn't be harmed by her being able to stick to her point presently. "One's situation is what it is, and that's all there is to it."

It's me it concerns. The rest is delightful and useless. Nobody can really help. That's why I'm by myself to-day.

Translation

It concerns me. The rest is lovely but pointless. No one can actually offer assistance. That's why I'm alone today.

I want to be—in spite of Miss Croy, who came with me last. If you can help, so much the better and also of course if one can, a little, one's self. Except for that—you and me doing our best—I like you to see me just as I am. Yes, I like it—and I don't exaggerate.

Translation

I want to be, despite Miss Croy, who was with me last time. If you can help, that's great, and also, of course, if one can, to some extent, help oneself. Aside from that, you and me doing our best, I want you to see me just as I am. Yes, I like that, and I'm not exaggerating.

Shouldn't one, at the start, show the worst—so that anything after that may be better? It wouldn't make any real difference—it won't make any, anything that may happen won't—to any one. Therefore I feel myself, this way, with you, just as I am; and—if you do in the least care to know—it quite positively bears me up." She put it as to his caring to know, because his manner seemed to give her all her chance, and the impression was there for her to take. It was strange and deep for her, this impression, and she did, accordingly, take it straight home.

Translation

Shouldn't one begin by revealing the worst—so that anything that follows might be better? It wouldn't really change anything—it won't change anything that might happen to anyone. Therefore, I present myself to you this way, just as I am; and—if you have the slightest interest in knowing—it quite definitively sustains me."

She phrased it as if his interest mattered, because his demeanor seemed to offer her every opportunity, and the implication was there for her to seize. It was strange and profound for her, this impression, and consequently, she embraced it completely.

It showed him—showed him in spite of himself—as allowing, somewhere far within, things comparatively remote, things in fact quite, as she would have said, outside, delicately to weigh with him; showed him as interested, on her behalf, in other questions beside the question of what was the matter with her. She accepted such an interest as regular in the highest type of scientific mind—his being the even highest, magnificently because otherwise, obviously, it wouldn't be there; but she could at the same time take it as a direct source of light upon herself, even though that might present her a little as pretending to equal him. Wanting to know more about a patient than how a patient was constructed or deranged couldn't be, even on the part of the greatest of doctors, anything but some form or other of the desire to let the patient down easily. When that was the case the reason, in turn, could only be, too manifestly, pity; and when pity held up its tell-tale face like a head on a pike, in a French revolution, bobbing before a window, what was the inference but that the patient was bad?

Translation

It revealed him—revealed him, despite himself—as someone who allowed remote things, things actually quite outside, as she would have put it, to delicately influence him from somewhere far within. It showed him as being interested, on her behalf, in things beyond the nature of her ailment. She accepted this sort of interest as typical of the most advanced scientific minds—and his was the most advanced of all, magnificently so, because otherwise, it simply wouldn't exist. At the same time, she could take it as a source of understanding about herself, even if that might make it seem like she was pretending to be his equal. Wanting to know more about a patient than their physical state or their mental state could only be, even for the greatest doctors, a way of softening the blow. When that was the case, the only possible reason was, quite obviously, pity. And when pity showed itself, like a head on a pike during the French Revolution, bobbing outside a window, the only conclusion to draw was that the patient was in a bad way.

He might say what he would now—she would always have seen the head at the window; and in fact from this moment she only wanted him to say what he would. He might say it too with the greater ease to himself as there wasn't one of her divinations that—as her own—he would in any way put himself out for. Finally, if he was making her talk she was talking; and what it could, at any rate, come to for him was that she wasn't afraid. If he wanted to do the dearest thing in the world for her he would show her he believed she wasn't; which undertaking of hers—not to have misled him—was what she counted at the moment as her presumptuous little hint to him that she was as good as himself.

Translation

No matter what he said now, she would always remember seeing that head in the window. From that point on, she only wanted him to speak his mind. He could express himself more freely because there was nothing she divined—that she considered her own—that he would take any pains over. Ultimately, if he was getting her to talk, then she was talking. And what that would mean for him was that she wasn't afraid. If he wanted to do the best thing for her, he would prove that he believed she wasn't. Her intention, which was not to mislead him, was, at that moment, her presumptuous way of implying that she was his equal.

It put forward the bold idea that he could really be misled; and there actually passed between them for some seconds a sign, a sign of the eyes only, that they knew together where they were. This made, in their brown old temple of truth, its momentary flicker; then what followed it was that he had her, all the same, in his pocket; and the whole thing wound up, for that consummation, with its kind dim smile. Such kindness was wonderful with such dimness; but brightness—that even of sharp steel—was of course for the other side of the business, and it would all come in for her in one way or another. "Do you mean," he asked, "that you've no relations at all?—not a parent, not a sister, not even a cousin nor an aunt?"

Translation

It proposed the audacious notion that he could actually be deceived. For a few seconds, a silent signal passed between them, a look exchanged that acknowledged their shared understanding of the situation. This created a brief spark in their time-worn sanctuary of truth. Then, what followed was that he still had her under his control. The entire situation concluded, as it was destined to, with a gentle, veiled smile. This kindness was remarkable considering its obscurity, but genuine clarity, even the sharpness of steel, was reserved for the other side of things, and it would all come into play for her eventually. "Do you mean," he inquired, "that you have no family at all? No parents, no siblings, not even a cousin or an aunt?"

"Yes, a different one. Not the one traveling with me. I've told her." He was clearly amused, and it added to his appeal—his most captivating quality was making her feel like she had all the time in the world.

Translation

"Yes, another one. Not the one I'm with. I already told her." He was clearly amused, and it made him more appealing; his most captivating quality was making her feel like time didn't exist.

"You told her what?" "Well," Milly said, "that I visit you secretly." "And how many people will she tell?" "Oh, she's devoted.

Translation

"You told her what?" "Well," Milly said, "that I visit you secretly." "And how many people will she tell?" "Oh, she's devoted. She won't."

Not a soul." "Well, if she's devoted, doesn't that make another friend for you?" It didn't take much thought, but she still had to pause, aware that he'd want to fully understand her—even a little, as if to make things more comfortable for her. However—and it was better to accept it sooner rather than later—she knew that wouldn't work, and she felt for a moment a distinct certainty about how things were.

Translation

"Not a soul." "Well, if she's devoted, doesn't that make another friend for you?" It didn't take much thought, but she still had to pause, aware that he'd want to fully understand her—even a little, as if to make things more comfortable for her. However—and it was better to accept it sooner rather than later—she knew that wouldn't work, and she felt for a moment a distinct certainty about how things were.

The air, for Milly Theale, was, by its very nature, destined to always be a bit cold. She could tell him this with authority, if she could tell him nothing else; and she seemed to see now, in short, that it would simplify things significantly. "Yes, it makes another; but they all together wouldn't make—well, I don't know what to call it—but the difference. I mean when someone is—truly alone.

Translation

The air, for Milly Theale, was inherently a bit chilly. She could state this with certainty, if she could state nothing else; and it seemed clear to her now that this would streamline matters considerably. "Yes, it adds another; but they all combined wouldn't make—well, I don't know the proper term—but the difference. I mean when someone is—truly alone."

I've never experienced such kindness." She paused for a moment while he waited—waiting again as if he had his reasons for letting her, almost encouraging her, to talk. What she really wanted was, for the third time, not to break down in public. She'd never experienced such kindness, and she wanted to do it justice; but she knew what she was doing, and justice wasn't hurt by her being able to stick to her point. "Only one's situation is what it is.

Translation

"I've never known such kindness." She hesitated, and he waited—waited again, as if he had his own reasons for allowing her, almost urging her, to speak. What she truly wished was, for the third time, not to fall apart in front of others. She'd never known such kindness, and she wanted to give it its due; but she knew what she was doing, and her ability to remain focused wasn't harming anything. "One's circumstances are what they are."

It's about me. The rest is lovely and doesn't matter. Nobody can truly help. That's why I'm here alone today.

Translation

It's all about me. The rest is beautiful, but it's irrelevant. No one can actually help. That's why I'm here, alone, today.

I want to be—despite Miss Croy, who came with me last time. If you can help, all the better, and also, of course, if one can, a little, on one's own. Except for that—you and me doing our best—I want you to see me just as I am. Yes, I like it—and I'm not exaggerating.

Translation

I want to exist—even though Miss Croy accompanied me previously. If you are able to assist, so much the better, and, naturally, if one can manage, even slightly, on one's own. Except for that—you and I giving it our all—I want you to perceive me exactly as I am. Yes, I enjoy this—and I'm not embellishing.

Shouldn't someone, at the start, show the worst—so that anything after that might be better? It wouldn't make any real difference—it won't make any difference—anything that may happen won't—to anyone. Therefore, I feel myself, this way, with you, just as I am; and—if you care at all to know—it absolutely gives me strength." She phrased it as if he cared to know, because his manner seemed to give her every chance, and she took the impression there for the taking. It was strange and profound for her, this feeling, and she took it straight to heart.

Translation

Wouldn't it be better for someone to reveal the worst first, so that anything that follows appears improved? It wouldn't matter anyway—nothing that could happen would matter to anyone. So I feel myself, here with you, exactly as I am; and—if you want to know—it gives me incredible strength." She said it as though he wanted to know, because his behavior suggested he did, and she felt certain she could. This feeling was strange and deep for her, and she took it completely to heart.

It showed him—showed him despite himself—as letting, somewhere deep down, things comparatively distant, things actually quite, as she would have said, external, subtly influence him; it showed him as interested, on her behalf, in questions beyond what was wrong with her. She accepted such an interest as typical of the highest level of scientific mind—his being the even highest, remarkably because otherwise, obviously, it wouldn't be there; but she could also see it as a direct source of understanding herself, even though that might present her a little as trying to be his equal. Wanting to know more about a patient than how a patient was constructed or broken couldn't be, even for the greatest doctors, anything other than some form of the desire to let the patient down easily. When that was the case, the reason, in turn, could only be, too obviously, pity; and when pity revealed itself like a head on a stake, in a French revolution, bobbing before a window, what was the conclusion except that the patient was in bad shape?

Translation

It revealed—even against his will—that he allowed relatively remote things, things that were, as she would have put it, external, to subtly affect him deep inside. It showed he was interested, on her behalf, in things that went beyond what was wrong with her. She saw this as typical of the most brilliant scientific minds, and his was the most brilliant of all, precisely because it otherwise wouldn't be present. But she could also see it as a direct path to understanding herself, even though it might make her seem as though she was trying to be his equal. Wanting to know more about a patient than their physical state could only mean—even for the greatest doctors—a desire to let the patient down gently. If that was the case, the reason, obviously, must be pity. And when pity showed itself, like a head on a stake from the French Revolution, bobbing in front of a window, the only conclusion was that the patient was in dire condition.

He could say what he liked now—she would always have seen the head at the window; and from this moment on, she only wanted him to speak. He could also speak more freely, knowing that there wasn't a single thing she divined that he would do anything to avoid. Finally, if he was making her talk, she was talking; and what it could mean for him was that she wasn't afraid. If he wanted to do the dearest thing in the world for her, he would show her he believed she wasn't; which undertaking of hers—not to have misled him—was what she considered at the moment her presumptuous little hint to him that she was as good as him.

Translation

He could say whatever he wanted now. She would always have seen the head in the window, and from that moment on, she only wanted him to speak. He could also speak more freely, knowing there wasn't a single thing she had figured out that he would try to avoid. Ultimately, if he was getting her to talk, she was talking, and what that could mean for him was that she wasn't afraid. If he wanted to do the dearest thing for her, he would show her he believed she wasn't. That endeavor of hers—not to have misled him—was, at that moment, what she considered her presumptuous little suggestion that she was his equal.

It put forward the bold idea that he could actually be misled; and for a few seconds, a look passed between them, a look only, that they knew together where they were. This created, in their old temple of truth, its momentary flicker; then what followed was that he had her, all the same, wrapped around his finger; and the whole thing concluded, with a kind, gentle smile. Such kindness was wonderful with such gentleness; but sharpness—even of bright steel—was of course for the other aspect of things, and it would all come into play for her in one way or another. "Do you mean," he asked, "that you have no family at all?—no parents, no siblings, not even a cousin or an aunt?"

Translation

The idea was audacious: that he could be deceived. For a fleeting moment, an unspoken understanding passed between them, a shared awareness of their position. This realization briefly illuminated their established truth; then, as before, she was entirely under his control. The scene concluded with a kind, gentle smile. That kindness and gentleness were beautiful; but a hard edge—the glint of steel—was reserved for other matters, and it would inevitably surface for her, in one form or another. "Do you mean," he asked, "that you have no family at all? No parents, no siblings, not even a cousin or an aunt?"

She shook her head as with the easy habit of an interviewed heroine or a freak of nature at a show. "Nobody whatever." But the last thing she had come for was to be dreary about it. "I'm a survivor—a survivor of a general wreck. You see," she added, "how that's to be taken into account—that everyone else has gone.

Translation

She shook her head, as easily as a heroine in an interview or a sideshow oddity. "No one at all." But she hadn't come to be morose about it. "I'm a survivor—a survivor of a total loss. You see," she added, "how that needs to be factored in—that everyone else is gone."

When I was ten years old there were, with my father and my mother, six of us. I'm all that's left. But they died," she went on, to be fair all round, "of different things. Still, there it is.

Translation

When I was ten, there were six of us, counting my father and mother. Now, I'm the only one left. But, in all fairness, they died of different causes," she continued. "Regardless, it is what it is."

And, as I told you before, I'm American. Not that I mean that makes me worse. However, you'll probably know what it makes me." She shook her head, as if she were a character in an interview or an oddity at a circus.

Translation

And, as I said, I'm American. Not that I'm suggesting that makes me a bad person. But, you probably already have an idea of what it means to you. She shook her head, as if she were being interviewed or was some kind of freak show attraction.

"Nobody." But she didn't want to be depressing. "I've survived—I'm a survivor of a catastrophe. You have to consider," she added, "that everyone else is gone. When I was ten, there were six of us, counting my parents.

Translation

"No one." But she didn't want to bring the mood down. "I've made it through—I'm a survivor of a disaster. You have to think about it," she added, "everybody else is dead. When I was ten, there were six of us, including my parents."

I'm the only one left. But they died," she continued, wanting to be clear, "of different causes. Still, that's the situation. And, as I mentioned, I'm American.

Translation

I’m the last one. But they died,” she clarified, wanting to be understood, “from different things. But that’s the reality of it. And, as I said, I'm American.

Not that I think that makes me bad. But you'll likely understand what it implies." "Yes," he discreetly indulged her; "I know perfectly what it makes you. It makes you, to begin with, a capital case."

Translation

It's not that I think that makes me a bad person. But you probably understand what that suggests." "Yes," he conceded tactfully; "I completely understand

what it makes you. To begin

with, it makes you a major player."

She sighed, though gratefully, as if again before the social scene. "Ah, there you are!" "Oh, no; there 'we' aren't at all. There I am only—but as much as you like.

Translation

She sighed, gratefully this time, as if she were once more in front of a social setting. "Ah, there you are!" "Oh, no; we are not there at all. I am only there—but as much as you like."

I've no end of American friends: there they are, if you please, and it's a fact that you couldn't very well be in a better place than in their company. It puts you with plenty of others—and that isn't pure solitude." Then he pursued: "I'm sure you've an excellent spirit; but don't try to bear more things than you need." Which after an instant he further explained. "Hard things have come to you in youth, but you mustn't think life will be for you all hard things. You've the right to be happy.

Translation

"I have tons of American friends. They're right here, if you want them, and honestly, you couldn't find a better place to be than with them. It puts you around other people—and that isn't just pure solitude." Then he continued, "I'm sure you have a great spirit, but don't try to carry more than you have to." After a moment, he elaborated. "You've had a tough time when you were young, but you can't think that life is always going to be like that. You deserve to be happy."

You must make up your mind to it. You must accept any form in which happiness may come." "Yes," he replied gently, "I understand exactly how this affects you. To begin, it makes you a fascinating person."

Translation

You need to commit to this. You must be willing to welcome happiness in whatever guise it appears." He responded softly, "Yes, I completely get how this impacts you. It starts with making you a captivating person."

She sighed in relief, as if she were once again facing society. "Oh, you're right!" "No, not at all. It's just me – but as much as you need.

Translation

Her relief was palpable, as though she were re-entering the world. "Oh, you're right!" "No, not at all. It's just me – but as much as you need."

I have a lot of American friends, and you couldn't be in better company than with them. You'll be with plenty of other people – and that's not pure loneliness." Then he added, "I'm sure you have a wonderful nature, but don't try to handle more than you have to." He elaborated after a moment: "You've experienced difficult things in your youth, but you can't assume that life will only be difficult for you. You have a right to be happy. You must decide to be happy.

Translation

I have many American friends, and you couldn't find better company. You'll be with lots of other people – and it won't be pure loneliness." Then he added, "I'm sure you're a wonderful person, but don't take on more than you need to." He elaborated after a moment: "You've been through hard times when you were young, but you can't assume that life will only be hard for you. You deserve to be happy. You have to choose to be happy.

You must embrace happiness in whatever form it appears." "Oh, I'll accept any whatever!" she almost gaily returned. "And it seems to me, for that matter, that I'm accepting a new one every day. Now this!" she smiled.

Translation

You need to welcome happiness in any way it shows up." "Oh, I'll take anything!" she replied, almost cheerfully. "And it seems to me, for that matter, I'm accepting a new one every day. Now this!" she smiled.

"This is very well so far as it goes. You can depend on me," the great man said, "for unlimited interest. But I'm only, after all, one element in fifty. We must gather in plenty of others.

Translation

"That's all well and good. You can count on me," the great man said, "to be as interested as possible. But I'm only one piece of the puzzle, one out of fifty. We need to find many more."

Don't mind who knows. Knows, I mean, that you and I are friends." "Ah, you do want to see some one!" she broke out. "You want to get at some one who cares for me." With which, however, as he simply met this spontaneity in a manner to show that he had often had it from young persons of her race, and that he was familiar even with the possibilities of their familiarity, she felt her freedom rendered vain by his silence, and she immediately tried to think of the most reasonable thing she could say.

Translation

It doesn't matter if anyone finds out. Knows, I mean, that you and I are friends."

"Oh, so you want to meet someone!" she exclaimed. "You're trying to get to someone who cares about me." Even so, because he simply met this outburst in a way that showed he'd often heard it from young women of her kind, and that he was even familiar with the possibilities of their familiarity, she felt her freedom rendered useless by his silence, and she immediately tried to think of the most sensible thing she could say.

This would be, precisely, on the subject of that freedom, which she now quickly spoke of as complete. "That's of course by itself a great boon; so please don't think I don't know it. I can do exactly what I like—anything in all the wide world. I haven't a creature to ask—there's not a finger to stop me.

Translation

This, specifically, concerned that freedom, which she quickly declared was absolute. "That's obviously a great advantage; please don't think I'm unaware of it. I can do whatever I want—anything in the whole world. I don't have anyone to ask—no one can stop me."

I can shake about till I'm black and blue. That perhaps isn't all joy; but lots of people, I know, would like to try it." He had appeared about to put a question, but then had let her go on, which she promptly did, for she understood him the next moment as having thus taken it from her that her means were as great as might be. She had simply given it to him so, and this was all that would ever pass between them on the odious head. Yet she couldn't help also knowing that an important effect, for his judgment, or at least for his amusement—which was his feeling, since, marvellously, he did have feeling—was produced by it.

Translation

I can flail around until I'm bruised. That might not be pure joy, but I know lots of people would want to try it."

He looked like he was going to ask something, but then he let her continue. She understood immediately that he'd accepted her implication that her resources were limitless. She'd simply implied as much to him, and that was all that would ever be said between them on that unpleasant subject. Still, she couldn't help but realize that it had a significant impact on him, for his judgment or at least for his amusement—which was his predominant feeling, since, remarkably, he did have feelings.

All her little pieces had now then fallen together for him like the morsels of coloured glass that used to make combinations, under the hand, in the depths of one of the polygonal peepshows of childhood. "So that if it's a question of my doing anything under the sun that will help——!" "Oh, I'll take anything!" she said almost cheerfully. "And it feels like I'm accepting something new every day.

Translation

All her fragmented parts had, at this moment, arranged themselves for him, much like the pieces of colored glass that formed patterns when manipulated in the depths of a childhood kaleidoscope. "So, if it involves me doing anything to help--" "Oh, I'll do anything!" she said, almost merrily. "And it feels like I'm taking on something new every single day."

Now this!" She smiled. "This is good so far. You can count on me," the great man said, "to be extremely interested. But I'm just one person out of many.

Translation

"Now this!" she smiled. "This is good so far. You can count on me," the great man said, "to be extremely interested. But I'm just one person out of many."

We need to get others involved. Don't worry about who knows. Knows, I mean, that you and I are friends." "Oh, you want to meet someone!" she exclaimed.

Translation

We have to bring in other people. Don't stress about who knows. Knows, I mean, that we're friends." "Oh, you want to meet someone!" she exclaimed.

"You want to find someone who cares about me." But as he responded to this outburst in a way that showed he was used to it from young women like her, and that he understood how they could be so open, she felt her freedom was pointless because of his silence. She immediately tried to think of the most sensible thing to say. This would be, exactly, about that freedom, which she quickly described as complete. "That's a huge advantage on its own; so please don't think I don't realize it.

Translation

"You want to find someone who cares about me." He responded in a way that suggested he was accustomed to these declarations from young women, and that he understood their candor. Her sense of liberation felt hollow in the face of his quiet. She immediately sought the most reasonable response, which was, naturally, about that freedom. She quickly clarified that her freedom was total. "That alone is a significant advantage. Please don't assume I'm unaware of that."

I can do whatever I want—anything at all. I don't have anyone to ask—no one can stop me. I can do whatever I please. That might not always be fun, but I know lots of people would want to try it."

Translation

I can do whatever I want. Anything. I don't need to ask anyone, and no one can stop me. I can do anything I feel like doing. It might not be fun all the time, but I know a lot of people would jump at the chance.

He looked like he was about to ask a question, but then let her continue, which she quickly did, because she understood that he was assuming that her financial resources were substantial. She'd essentially told him this, and that's all that would ever be said between them about that unpleasant matter. Still, she couldn't help but realize that this had a significant impact on his opinion, or at least on his amusement—which was his main feeling, since, surprisingly, he did have feelings—it amused him. All her little details had now come together for him, like the pieces of colored glass that used to create images under your hand, in the depths of a childhood kaleidoscope.

Translation

He seemed poised to ask something, but then he let her go on, which she immediately did, because she understood that he was concluding that she had a lot of money. She had essentially told him as much, and that was all that would ever be said between them about that distasteful subject. Still, she couldn’t help but see that it had a big effect on his opinion, or at least his amusement—which was his main feeling, because, surprisingly, he had feelings—it amused him. All of her little details had now come together for him, like the shards of colored glass that used to make images under your hand, in the depths of a childhood kaleidoscope.

"So if it's a question of me doing anything at all that will help——!" "You'll do anything under the sun? Good." He took that beautifully, ever so pleasantly, for what it was worth; but time was needed—ten minutes or so were needed on the spot—to deal even provisionally, with the substantive question. It was convenient, in its degree, that there was nothing she wouldn't do; but it seemed also highly and agreeably vague that she should have to do anything.

Translation

"So if it's a question of me doing anything at all that will help—!" "You'll do anything under the sun? Good." He received that sentiment beautifully, with utmost pleasure, for whatever it was worth; but time was needed—ten minutes or so were needed right then—to address even provisionally the real question. It was convenient, to a certain extent, that there was nothing she wouldn't do; but it also seemed highly and agreeably vague that she would actually have to do anything.

They thus appeared to be taking her, together, for the moment, and almost for sociability, as prepared to proceed to gratuitous extremities; the upshot of which was in turn, that after much interrogation, auscultation, exploration, much noting of his own sequences and neglecting of hers, had duly kept up the vagueness, they might have struck themselves, or may at least strike us, as coming back from an undeterred but useless voyage to the north pole. Milly was ready, under orders, for the north pole; which fact was doubtless what made a blinding anticlimax of her friend's actual abstention from orders. "No," she heard him again distinctly repeat it, "I don't want you for the present to do anything at all; anything, that is, but obey a small prescription or two that will be made clear to you, and let me within a few days come to see you at home." "You'll do anything?" He was pleased, of course, but it wasn't something to be taken at face value.

Translation

Thus, for the time being, they seemed to be including her in their plans, almost amicably, as someone prepared to go to any lengths for nothing; the consequence of which, after much questioning, listening, and investigating, after many observations of his own actions and a disregard for hers, had managed to preserve the ambiguity. They might have thought themselves, or at least we might think of them, as returning from an expedition to the North Pole that was undaunted but pointless. Milly was ready to go to the North Pole if ordered, which was probably what made her friend's actual refusal to give any orders such a crushing anticlimax. "No," she heard him repeat clearly, "I don't want you to do anything at all for the moment; nothing, that is, except follow a few simple instructions that I will explain, and let me come and visit you at your home in a few days." "You'll do anything?" He was pleased, of course, but it was not something to be taken seriously.

It took a few minutes to even begin to consider the real question. It was helpful that she was willing to do anything, but it also seemed pleasantly unclear what she might actually have to do. For the time being, it was as if they were simply enjoying the idea that she was prepared to go to any length for no particular reason. The result, after much questioning, observation, and analysis, with him mostly considering his own line of thought and ignoring hers, was that they preserved the ambiguity.

Translation

It took a few minutes to even get around to the real question. Her willingness to do anything was convenient, though what she might actually have to do remained delightfully vague. For the moment, it was as if they were simply savoring the fact that she was willing to go to any length without any clear purpose. The upshot, after much questioning, observation, and analysis, with him mostly preoccupied with his own thoughts and ignoring hers, was that the ambiguity was maintained.

They might have felt, or at least we might feel, that they had just returned from a pointless expedition to the North Pole, even though they had never been deterred. Milly was ready to go to the North Pole if asked, which was, ironically, why her friend's eventual decision to give her no specific instructions at all was so disappointing. "No," he repeated clearly, "I don't need you to do anything at the moment, nothing other than follow a few simple instructions that will be given to you. I'll come see you at your place in a few days."

Translation

It could be argued, or at least we could argue, that they'd just come back from a useless trip to the North Pole, despite never being discouraged. Milly was ready to go to the North Pole if asked, which, ironically, made her friend's ultimate choice to give her no specific directions at all so disappointing. "No," he said again, plainly, "I don't need you to do anything right now, nothing other than follow some basic instructions I'll give you. I'll come see you at your place in a few days."

It was at first heavenly. "Then you'll see Mrs. Stringham." But she didn't mind a bit now. "Well, I shan't be afraid of Mrs.

Translation

Stringham," she declared. "I've been in plenty of awkward situations before." It was the first time she had mentioned this woman, Mrs. Stringham, to me. I had to assume she was an important person in her life. Then, she seemed to grow a little tired. "I'll expect you to come here as soon as you can." Her smile was now fading. "We can leave immediately."

Stringham." And he said it once more as she asked once more: "Absolutely not; I 'send' you nowhere. England's all right—anywhere that's pleasant, convenient, decent, will be all right. You say you can do exactly as you like. Oblige me therefore by being so good as to do it.

Translation

Stringham.”

He repeated it as she repeated her question:

“Absolutely not; I won’t ‘send’ you anywhere. England’s fine—any place that’s pleasant, convenient, and decent will be fine. You say you can do whatever you want. Therefore, please, do it.”

There's only one thing: you ought of course, now, as soon as I've seen you again, to get out of London." Milly thought. "May I then go back to the continent?" "By all means back to the continent.

Translation

There's only one thing: you should, of course, now, as soon as I've seen you again, get out of London." Milly thought. "May I then go back to the continent?" "By all means, back to the continent.

Do go back to the continent." "Then how will you keep seeing me? But perhaps," she quickly added, "you won't want to keep seeing me." Initially, it was wonderful.

Translation

"Do go back to the continent." "Then how will you keep seeing me? But perhaps," she quickly added, "you won't want to keep seeing me." Initially, it was wonderful.

"Then you'll meet Mrs. Stringham." But she wasn't at all concerned anymore. "Well, I won't be intimidated by Mrs. Stringham."

Translation

"You'll meet Mrs. Stringham then." But she didn't care in the slightest. "I won't be intimidated by Mrs. Stringham, that's for sure."

And he repeated this as she repeated her question: "Absolutely not; I won't *send* you anywhere. England is fine—anywhere that's enjoyable, practical, and respectable will be fine. You've said you can do whatever you wish. So, please, be kind enough to do exactly that.

Translation

And he said it again, as she repeated her question: "Absolutely not; I'm not going to *ship* you off anywhere. England's the place—anywhere that's fun, useful, and decent will be fine. You've told me you can do whatever you want. So, please, be good enough to do just that."

There's just one thing: of course, after I see you again, you should leave London." Milly considered. "Can I go back to the continent then?" "Absolutely, go back to the continent.

Translation

There’s just one thing. Of course, after I see you again, you should leave London.” Milly considered this. “Can I go back to the Continent then?” “Absolutely, go back to the Continent.”

Please, go back to the continent." "Then how will you keep seeing me? But maybe," she quickly added, "you won't want to keep seeing me." He had it all ready; he had really everything all ready.

Translation

"Please, go back to the Continent." "Then how will you keep seeing me? But maybe," she quickly added, "you won't want to keep seeing me." He had it all ready; he really had everything all ready.

"I shall follow you up; though if you mean that I don't want you to keep seeing me——" "Well?" she asked. It was only just here that he struck her the least bit as stumbling. "Well, see all you can.

Translation

"I will come after you. Though, if you're saying you don't want me to keep seeing you—" "Well?" she prompted. It was only here that he seemed even slightly unsure of himself. "Well, look as much as you can."

That's what it comes to. Worry about nothing. You have at least no worries. It's a great, rare chance."

Translation

That's the crux of it. Don't worry about anything. At the very least, you have nothing to worry about. It's a great, rare opportunity.

She had got up, for she had had from him both that he would send her something and would advise her promptly of the date of his coming to her, by which she was virtually dismissed. Yet, for herself, one or two things kept her. "May I come back to England too?" He had everything prepared; truly, he had prepared everything.

Translation

She rose, because she'd received both assurances—that he would send something and that he would immediately inform her of his arrival. This was essentially her dismissal. Still, a couple of things held her back. "Can I come back to England too?" He had everything arranged; in fact, he'd prepared everything.

"I'll pursue this, although if you're suggesting you don't want me to visit—" "Well?" she inquired. It was precisely at this point that he seemed slightly uncertain. "Well, see as much as you can.

Translation

"I'll look into it," he said, "though if you're hinting that you don't want me to visit—" "And?" she prompted. He seemed to hesitate for a moment. "Well, take it all in."

That's the main idea. Don't fret about anything. You have nothing to worry about, at least. This is a marvelous, uncommon opportunity."

Translation

That's the gist of it. Don't stress. You're in the clear, at least for now. This is a fantastic, unique chance.

She rose to her feet, for he had promised to send her something and to promptly inform her of his arrival, which essentially signaled her departure. Yet, for her own purposes, a couple of questions lingered. "Might I also return to England?" "Rather!

Translation

She stood up, because he had promised to send something her way and to let her know when he arrived, which meant it was time for her to go. But she had a few questions of her own. "Will I also be able to go back to England?" "Of course!"

Whenever you like. But always, when you do come, immediately let me know." "Ah," said Milly, "it won't be a great going to and fro." "Then if you'll stay with us, so much the better."

Translation

"Whenever you wish. However, when you do come, please inform me right away."

"Ah," said Milly, "I won't be traveling back and forth very often."

"Then if you stay with us, so much the better."

It touched her, the way he controlled his impatience of her; and the fact itself affected her as so precious that she yielded to the wish to get more from it. "So you don't think I'm out of my mind?" "Perhaps that is," he smiled, "all that's the matter." She looked at him longer.

Translation

His restraint toward her moved her, and the very existence of it was so valuable that she gave in to the desire to experience more. "So, you don't think I'm crazy?" "Maybe that's," he smiled, "the whole problem." She looked at him for a long moment.

"No, that's too good. Shall I, at any rate, suffer?" "Not a bit." "And yet then live?"

Translation

"No, that's too much to hope for. Should I suffer, regardless?" "Not at all." "And still live?"

"My dear young lady," said her distinguished friend, "isn't to 'live' exactly what I'm trying to persuade you to take the trouble to do?" Of course! Anytime you'd like. But please, whenever you do come, let me know right away."

Translation

"My dear young lady," her distinguished friend said, "isn't 'living' precisely what I'm trying to convince you to make an effort to do?" Of course! Anytime you'd like. But please, whenever you do come, let me know immediately."

"Oh," said Milly, "I won't be traveling back and forth much." "Then if you stay with us, that's even better." It moved her, the way he masked his irritation with her. That quality itself was so valuable to her that she gave in to her desire to experience more of it.

Translation

"Oh," Milly said, "I won't be going back and forth a lot." "Well, if you're staying, that's even better." She was touched by how he hid his annoyance with her. That very trait was so precious to her that she surrendered to her urge to experience more of it.

"So you don't think I'm crazy?" "Maybe that's," he smiled, "the only problem." She looked at him for a longer time. "No, that's too simple.

Translation

"So, you don't think I'm insane?" "Perhaps that's," he smiled, "the only issue." She studied him for a while. "No, that's too easy."

Will I suffer, at least?" "Not at all." "And yet... live?"

Translation

"I will not." "And still... exist?"

"My dear young lady," said her distinguished friend, "isn't 'living' precisely what I'm trying to convince you to make an effort to do?"

Translation

"My dear," her esteemed friend said, "isn't 'living' exactly what I'm trying to persuade you to even attempt?"

Chapter 13

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

A woman goes into a square alone and begins walking through London. She wanders through unfamiliar streets, choosing her direction at corners but avoiding asking for her way. She accidentally arrives at Regent's Park and walks onto the grass. She sees other people who seem anxious and tired like herself. She looks for an empty bench and sits down to rest. After sitting for a long time, she stands up, looks at the people around her again, and decides to go home.

A day or two later at her hotel, her friend Kate Croy arrives in a hansom cab. Milly, who had been pacing in her room, hears the cab and goes out onto a balcony. She and Kate exchange smiles and nods as Kate pays the driver below.

Kate comes up to the room and asks Milly for news from her appointment with a doctor. Milly replies that everything is fine, there is nothing to worry about, and that she can do as she likes. Relieved, Kate embraces and kisses Milly. They talk about what Milly will do next. Milly says she plans to travel for pleasure and asks Kate to help her.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

This is an excellent excerpt for literary analysis, rich in psychological depth and stylistic complexity, characteristic of the work of Henry James (this text is from *The Wings of the Dove*). The passage captures a pivotal moment of transformation for its protagonist, Milly Theale, as she processes a life-altering medical consultation.

### Literary Analysis

#### **Themes**

The text is built around several interlocking themes, primarily focusing on the confrontation with mortality and the redefinition of life itself.

1. **The Paradox of Freedom and Fate:** The central theme is the harrowing freedom that comes with a potential death sentence. The "distinguished friend" (the doctor) gives Milly an ambiguous but profound injunction: "Be as active as you can and as you like." This advice treats her "as if it were in her power to live," yet she astutely understands that "one wasn't treated so—was one?—unless it came up, quite as much, that one might die." This creates a paradox: she is granted ultimate freedom and volition, but this freedom is only meaningful because her time may be limited. Life is no longer something to be passively experienced but a "great adventure, a big dim experiment or struggle" in which she must actively participate.

2. **Isolation and Impersonal Connection:** Milly’s immediate reaction is an overwhelming need for solitude. She feels that "No one in the world could have sufficiently entered into her state." The intimacy she shares with friends like Kate Croy and Susan Shepherd is suddenly insufficient. Instead, she finds a strange comfort in the "inspiringly impersonal" company of "the human race at large." This theme culminates in Regent's Park, where she identifies with the "scattered, melancholy comrades," recognizing their shared "great common anxiety" as "the practical question of life." Her connection shifts from the personal to the universal; she is alone, yet part of a collective human struggle.

3. **The Loss of Innocence and the Adoption of a Militant Identity:** The text powerfully dramatizes the shedding of a former self. Milly feels she must "pluck off her breast... some friendly ornament, a familiar flower, a little old jewel," symbols of her previous life of safety, femininity, and perhaps passive fragility. In its place, she must "take up and shoulder... some queer defensive weapon, a musket, a spear, a battle-axe." This military metaphor is central to her character development in this passage. She is no longer just a young woman; she is a "soldier on a march," and London’s "grey immensity" has become her battlefield. This new identity is defensive, demanding strength and a "military posture."

4. **Will vs. Circumstance:** The passage closes on a subtle but profound distinction. Milly observes the people in the park and re-evaluates the doctor's words. She contrasts two ideas: "one could live if one would" (an assertion of willpower) and "one would live if one could" (an acknowledgment of circumstance). While the former is "superficially more striking," she finds the latter "more appealing, insinuating, irresistible." This suggests her dawning realization that while she must exercise her will to its fullest, she is ultimately constrained by a reality she cannot control. The struggle is to live fully within the confines of what is possible.

#### **Character Development: Milly’s Transformation**

The entire text is a deep dive into Milly’s consciousness as she undergoes a rapid and profound internal shift.

* **From Impulse to Agency:** Initially, Milly is propelled by an "impulse received" from the doctor's words. It is an "excitement that carried her on," an almost involuntary forward motion. However, as she walks, this impulse transforms into conscious "option, [her] volition." She begins to actively "take personal possession of what surrounded her," choosing her direction at street corners and reveling in her newfound reason for being active.

* **From Patient to Warrior:** Her self-perception changes dramatically. She internalizes the military metaphor so completely that she feels the "instrument... already on her back." She embraces the role of a soldier on the "warpath," startling onlookers in the "slums" with her incongruous appearance and intense gaze. This is not madness, but a psychological armoring, a way of conceptualizing and bearing her new, heavy reality.

* **From Heiress to "Poor Girl":** In the park, her identity undergoes another critical reduction. As she contemplates the doctor's kindness, she realizes his compassion has the effect of "divesting, denuding, exposing." It strips away her social standing and wealth, reducing her to her "ultimate state, which was that of a poor girl with her rent to pay." This "rent" is metaphorical—the price for her future, for life itself. This realization democratizes her suffering, connecting her to the fundamental human condition.

* **From Naïveté to Performance:** The final section, her encounter with Kate Croy, marks the culmination of her development. She recognizes Kate's radiant health and strength as something alien to her own state. To confess her true situation would be a "surrender." Instead, she deploys her newly discovered "will-power" and performs the role of a healthy person, telling Kate everything is "all right." This lie is her first strategic "countermove," an act of seizing control over her own narrative and protecting the fragile, new identity she is building.

#### **Major Literary Ideas and Techniques**

1. **Stream of Consciousness:** The narrative is a masterful example of psychological realism, plunging the reader directly into the flow of Milly’s thoughts. The long, complex sentences with their subordinate clauses and self-interrogations ("hadn't she?", "was one?") perfectly mirror the process of a mind grappling with a complex, emotional, and intellectual crisis.

2. **Extended Metaphor:** The passage's power relies heavily on its central metaphors. The **soldier** metaphor provides the structure for Milly’s initial response, framing her journey as a heroic, if lonely, campaign. The metaphor of the **"poor girl with her rent to pay"** serves as a powerful symbol of existential reality, stripping away all artifice to reveal the basic, universal struggle for survival.

3. **Symbolism of Place:** The setting is not merely a backdrop but an active participant in Milly’s journey. The "great square" is a space of solitary contemplation. The "unknown streets" and "slums" represent her venture into a new, raw, and unfamiliar territory of experience. Finally, **Regent's Park** becomes a kind of public stage for the great human drama, a "grim breathing-space" where she finds a somber kinship with others facing the "practical question of life."

In conclusion, this text performs a profound literary and psychological dissection of a character at a moment of existential awakening. Through themes of freedom, isolation, and identity, and propelled by powerful metaphors and a deeply interior narrative style, the passage charts Milly's transformation from a passive individual into a self-aware, armed, and tragically heroic "soldier" in the battle to live.

She had gone out with these last words so in her ears that when once she was well away—back this time in the great square alone—it was as if some instant application of them had opened out there before her. It was positively, this effect, an excitement that carried her on; she went forward into space under the sense of an impulse received—an impulse simple and direct, easy above all to act upon. She was borne up for the hour, and now she knew why she had wanted to come by herself. No one in the world could have sufficiently entered into her state; no tie would have been close enough to enable a companion to walk beside her without some disparity.

Translation

She left with those words echoing in her ears, so that once she was well away—back in the great square alone—it was as if an immediate application of them had unfolded before her. This effect was, in fact, an excitement that carried her along; she moved forward into the open space, feeling an impulse—an impulse that was simple and direct, above all, easy to act upon. She was sustained for the moment, and now she understood why she had wanted to come alone. No one in the world could have truly understood her state; no bond would have been close enough to allow a companion to walk beside her without some disconnect.

She literally felt, in this first flush, that her only company must be the human race at large, present all round her, but inspiringly impersonal, and that her only field must be, then and there, the grey immensity of London. Grey immensity had somehow of a sudden become her element; grey immensity was what her distinguished friend had, for the moment, furnished her world with and what the question of "living," as he put it to her, living by option, by volition, inevitably took on for its immediate face. She went straight before her, without weakness, altogether with strength; and still as she went she was more glad to be alone, for nobody—not Kate Croy, not Susan Shepherd either—would have wished to rush with her as she rushed. She had asked him at the last whether, being on foot, she might go home so, or elsewhere, and he had replied as if almost amused again at her extravagance: "You're active, luckily, by nature—it's beautiful: therefore rejoice in it.

Translation

In this initial surge of feeling, she sensed that her only companion had to be humanity as a whole, present all around her, yet inspiringly impersonal. Her only arena had to be the immense grey expanse of London, right then and there. This grey immensity had somehow, all of a sudden, become her element; it was what her distinguished friend had, for the moment, provided for her world. The question of “living,” as he put it to her, of living by choice, by will, inevitably took on this immediate form. She walked straight ahead, without faltering, with a renewed strength. As she went, she felt gladder still to be alone, because nobody—not Kate Croy, not even Susan Shepherd—would have wanted to rush with her as she was rushing. She had asked him at the end if, since she was on foot, she could go home that way, or elsewhere, and he had replied, almost amused again by her extravagance, “You’re active, luckily, by nature—it’s beautiful: therefore rejoice in it.”

Be active, without folly—for you're not foolish: be as active as you can and as you like." That had been in fact the final push, as well as the touch that most made a mixture of her consciousness—a strange mixture that tasted at one and the same time of what she had lost and what had been given her. It was wonderful to her, while she took her random course, that these quantities felt so equal: she had been treated—hadn't she?—as if it were in her power to live; and yet one wasn't treated so—was one?—unless it came up, quite as much, that one might die. The beauty of the bloom had gone from the small old sense of safety—that was distinct: she had left it behind her there forever. But the beauty of the idea of a great adventure, a big dim experiment or struggle in which she might, more responsibly than ever before, take a hand, had been offered her instead.

Translation

"Be active, but not foolish—because you're not foolish. Be as active as you can and as you like." That had been, in fact, the final push, as well as the element that most thoroughly mixed her consciousness—a strange combination that tasted simultaneously of what she had lost and what she had been given. It was wonderful, as she continued her wandering, that these two aspects felt so evenly balanced. She had been treated—hadn't she?—as if living were within her power. And yet one wasn't treated that way—was one?—without also acknowledging, equally, that one might die. The beauty had faded from the small, old sense of security—that much was certain; she had left it behind her there forever. But the beauty of the idea of a great adventure, a vast, dim experiment or struggle in which she could, more responsibly than ever before, participate, had been offered to her instead.

It was as if she had had to pluck off her breast, to throw away, some friendly ornament, a familiar flower, a little old jewel, that was part of her daily dress; and to take up and shoulder as a substitute some queer defensive weapon, a musket, a spear, a battle-axe conducive possibly in a higher degree to a striking appearance, but demanding all the effort of the military posture. She felt this instrument, for that matter, already on her back, so that she proceeded now in very truth as a soldier on a march—proceeded as if, for her initiation, the first charge had been sounded. She passed along unknown streets, over dusty littery ways, between long rows of fronts not enhanced by the August light; she felt good for miles and only wanted to get lost; there were moments at corners, where she stopped and chose her direction, in which she quite lived up to his injunction to rejoice that she was active. It was like a new pleasure to have so new a reason; she would affirm, without delay, her option, her volition; taking this personal possession of what surrounded her was a fair affirmation to start with; and she really didn't care if she made it at the cost of alarms for Susie.

Translation

It was as though she had been forced to detach from her person, to discard, some comforting adornment, a familiar bloom, a worn trinket that was part of her everyday attire; and to take up and bear, as a replacement, some strange defensive weapon—a musket, a spear, a battle-axe—that was perhaps more conducive to a striking presence, but required the exertion of a military stance. She felt this instrument, for that matter, already on her back, so that she was now moving in the truest sense of a soldier on the march—moving as if, for her initiation, the first charge had been signaled. She traversed unfamiliar streets, across dusty, littered pathways, between long rows of facades unadorned by the August light; she felt invigorated for miles and only wanted to get lost; there were moments at corners, where she stopped and chose her direction, in which she fully embraced his directive to rejoice in her activity. It was like a novel pleasure to have so new a reason; she would assert, without hesitation, her choice, her will; claiming this personal ownership of what surrounded her was a fine declaration to begin with; and she truly didn't care if she caused worry for Susie.

Susie would wonder in due course "whatever," as they said at the hotel, had become of her; yet this would be nothing either, probably, to wonderments still in store. Wonderments in truth, Milly felt, even now attended her steps: it was quite as if she saw in people's eyes the reflection of her appearance and pace.
