She found herself moving at times in regions visibly not haunted by odd-looking girls from New York, duskily draped, sable-plumed, all but incongruously shod and gazing about them with extravagance; she might, from the curiosity she clearly excited in byways, in side-streets peopled with grimy children and costermongers carts, which she hoped were slums, literally have had her musket on her shoulder, have announced herself as freshly on the warpath. But for the fear of overdoing this character she would here and there have begun conversation, have asked her way; in spite of the fact that, as that would help the requirements of adventure, her way was exactly what she wanted not to know.

Translation

Susie would eventually wonder what had become of her, using the hotel's favorite expression. However, this would likely be nothing compared to the future uncertainties awaiting her. In fact, Milly felt that wonder already accompanied her: it was as if she saw her own image and rhythm reflected in the eyes of others. She found herself moving through areas not typically frequented by peculiar New York girls, cloaked in twilight, adorned with sable plumes, almost incongruously shod, and gazing around with exaggerated interest. Considering the curiosity she clearly aroused in the byways and side streets filled with grubby children and costermongers' carts—which she hoped were slums—she could have literally carried her musket on her shoulder, declaring herself as freshly arrived on the warpath. But, fearing she'd overdo the act, she would have started conversations and asked for directions. Yet, as this would have assisted her adventurous goals, she purposely avoided knowing her way.

The difficulty was that she at last accidentally found it; she had come out, she presently saw, at the Regent's Park, round which, on two or three occasions with Kate Croy, her public chariot had solemnly rolled. But she went into it further now; this was the real thing; the real thing was to be quite away from the pompous roads, well within the centre and on the stretches of shabby grass. Here were benches and smutty sheep; here were idle lads at games of ball, with their cries mild in the thick air; here were wanderers, anxious and tired like herself; here doubtless were hundreds of others just in the same box. Their box, their great common anxiety, what was it, in this grim breathing-space, but the practical question of life?

Translation

The trouble was that she stumbled upon it by accident. She emerged, as she soon realized, into Regent's Park, which her carriage had traversed a few times with Kate Croy. But now she ventured deeper; this was the real thing. The real thing was to be far from the imposing roads, deep within the heart of the park and upon the patches of worn grass. There were benches and dirty sheep; there were bored boys playing ball, their shouts muted by the heavy air; there were wanderers, anxious and weary like herself; and there, undoubtedly, were hundreds of others in the same predicament. Their predicament, their shared anxiety, what was it, in this grim respite, but the pressing question of survival?

They could live if they would; that is, like herself, they had been told so; she saw them all about her, on seats, digesting the information, feeling it altered, assimilated, recognising it again as something, in a slightly different shape, familiar enough, the blessed old truth that they would live if they could. All she thus shared with them made her wish to sit in their company; which she so far did that she looked for a bench that was empty, eschewing a still emptier chair that she saw hard by and for which she would have paid, with superiority, a fee. XIII She left with those last words echoing in her ears.

Translation

They could live if they wanted to; that is, like her, they had been told as much. She saw them all around her, on benches, processing the information, feeling it shift and settle, recognizing it again as something familiar, though slightly altered: the old, comforting truth that they would live if they could. Everything she shared with them made her want to sit among them. She went so far as to search for an empty bench, avoiding a chair nearby, which was even emptier and for which she would have paid a fee, acting superior. She departed with those final words echoing in her ears.

Once she was alone, back in the large square, it felt as though the impact of those words had immediately revealed itself to her. It was, without a doubt, a feeling of excitement that propelled her forward. She entered the open space, driven by a clear impulse, a simple and direct motivation that was easy to act upon. She felt invigorated for the moment, and now she understood why she had wanted to come alone.

Translation

Once alone again in the vast square, the weight of those words seemed to immediately dawn on her. Without a doubt, it was a surge of excitement that pushed her onward. She moved into the open space, guided by a clear impulse, a simple and direct motivation, easy to follow. She felt energized in that moment, and now she understood why she had wanted to be alone.

No one could have truly understood her situation; no bond would have been strong enough to allow a companion to walk beside her without some disconnect. She felt, in that initial rush of emotion, that her only company could be humanity itself, present all around her yet inspiringly impersonal, and that her only arena was, at that moment, the gray vastness of London. That gray immensity had suddenly become her element; it was what her distinguished friend had, for the moment, filled her world with, and it was the immediate context of the question of "living," as he put it, living by choice, by will. She walked straight ahead, without hesitation, with complete confidence.

Translation

No one could have grasped her circumstances; no connection would have been strong enough to allow another person to walk with her without some form of detachment. In that first surge of feeling, she sensed that her only companion could be humanity itself, ever-present, yet wonderfully impersonal, and that her only space was, for now, the gray expanse of London. That gray vastness had abruptly become her element; it was what her esteemed friend had, at this moment, filled her world with, and it was the immediate framework for the question of "living," as he had phrased it, living by choice, by will. She walked forward, without hesitation, with complete assurance.

As she walked, she found even greater pleasure in being alone, because no one—not Kate Croy, not Susan Shepherd—would have wanted to rush with her in the way she was rushing. She had asked him at the end if, since she was on foot, she could simply go home or somewhere else, and he had replied, as if amused by her impulsiveness: "You're naturally active, which is wonderful. So, embrace it. Be active, but not foolish—because you're not foolish.

Translation

As she walked, she found even more pleasure in her solitude, because no one – not Kate Croy, not Susan Shepherd – would have wanted to hurry along with her in the way she was hurrying. At the end, she had asked him if, since she was on foot, she could simply go home or somewhere else, and he had replied, as if amused by her impulsiveness: "You're naturally active, which is wonderful. So, embrace it. Be active, but not foolish – because you're not foolish."

Be as active as you can and as you want." That had been the final push, as well as the element that most contributed to the mixture of her consciousness—a strange mix that felt, at the same time, of what she had lost and what she had been given. It was extraordinary to her, as she wandered without direction, that these two aspects felt so balanced. She had been treated—hadn't she?—as if she had the power to live. Yet one wasn't treated like that—was one?—unless it also meant that one might die.

Translation

"Be as active as you can and as you want." That was the final push, the element that most contributed to the mixture within her consciousness—a strange mix that felt, simultaneously, of what she had lost and what she had been given. It was extraordinary, wandering without direction, that these two aspects felt so balanced. She had been treated—hadn't she?—as if she had the power to live. Yet one wasn't treated like that—was one?—unless it also meant that one might die.

The beauty of the security she had once known was gone—that was certain. She had left it behind her forever. But the beauty of the idea of a great adventure, a grand, shadowy experiment or struggle in which she could take part with more responsibility than ever before, had been offered to her instead. It was as though she had had to take off her breast, to throw away some friendly decoration, a familiar flower, a little old jewel, that had been part of her daily attire, and to pick up and carry instead some strange defensive weapon, a musket, a spear, a battle-axe, which might have made her look more impressive, but which required all the effort of a military posture.

Translation

The certainty was that the beauty of the security she had once known was gone. She had left it behind for good. But in its place, the beauty of the idea of a great adventure had been offered to her: a grand, shadowy experiment or struggle in which she could participate with more responsibility than ever before. It was as though she had to remove a breast, discard some friendly decoration, a familiar flower, a little old jewel, that had been part of her daily attire. She had to pick up and carry instead some strange defensive weapon, a musket, a spear, a battle-axe, which might have made her look more impressive, but which required all the effort of a military posture.

She felt this instrument, as a matter of fact, already on her back, so that she proceeded now as a soldier on a march, as if the first attack had already begun. She walked through unknown streets, along dusty, littered paths, between long rows of buildings not enhanced by the August light. She felt good for miles and simply wanted to get lost. At the corners of streets, when she stopped and chose a direction, she fully embraced his command to rejoice in her activity.

Translation

She felt this burden, in truth, already upon her, and she moved like a soldier on the move, as if the first assault had already begun. She walked through unfamiliar streets, along dusty, littered paths, between long rows of buildings diminished by the August light. She felt good for miles and simply wanted to disappear. At the street corners, when she stopped and chose a direction, she fully embraced his command to rejoice in her activity.

It was like a new pleasure to have such a new reason. She would immediately declare her choice, her will. Taking personal ownership of her surroundings was a good start. And she didn't care if it alarmed Susie.

Translation

It was as though a novel delight had presented itself in the form of this new cause. She would immediately and unequivocally voice her decision, her resolve. Claiming dominion over her immediate environment was a promising beginning. And she was indifferent to Susie's potential consternation.

Susie would eventually wonder "whatever," as they said at the hotel, had happened to her. Yet this would be nothing compared to the things that were still to come. Wonderments, Milly felt, were following her every step even now. It was as though she saw in people's eyes a reflection of her appearance and her pace.

Translation

Susie would eventually find herself asking, "whatever," as they said at the hotel, what had happened to her. But that wouldn't compare to what was still ahead. Milly felt that wonderings dogged her steps even then. It was as though she saw her image and tempo reflected in people's eyes.

She found herself moving at times in areas not normally frequented by peculiar-looking girls from New York, dressed in dark clothing, with sable plumes, whose shoes looked out of place, and who looked around with excess. She might have, considering the curiosity she clearly aroused in side streets filled with grimy children and vendors' carts, which she hoped were slums, literally had a musket on her shoulder, declaring herself as newly ready for battle. But for the fear of exaggerating the character she was portraying, she might have started conversations here and there, asking for directions. Yet, as that would assist the needs of adventure, her way was precisely what she wanted not to know.

Translation

She sometimes wandered into places not usually visited by strange girls from New York, wearing dark clothes, with sable feathers, and clunky shoes, who eyed everything with suspicion. Considering the obvious curiosity she stirred up in the back alleys filled with dirty kids and vendor carts, which she hoped were slums, she might as well have carried a musket on her shoulder, announcing her readiness for battle. If she weren't worried about overplaying her part, she would have started conversations, asking for directions. However, since that would have helped her sense of adventure, she was determined not to know the way.

The problem was that she eventually found it by accident. She had come out, she realized, at Regent's Park, which she had driven through with Kate Croy on several occasions in a public carriage. But now she went further into it. This was the real thing.

Translation

The trouble was that she stumbled upon it by accident. She'd emerged, she realized, in Regent's Park, which she'd ridden through with Kate Croy in a public carriage several times. But now she went deeper. This was the genuine article.

The real thing was to be far from the formal roads, deep within the center and on the stretches of worn grass. Here were benches and dirty sheep. Here were idle boys playing ball games, their cries softened by the dense air. Here were wanderers, anxious and tired like herself.

Translation

The authentic experience lay far from the manicured paths, deep within the heart of the park, along the stretches of trampled grass. Here, benches offered respite, and sheep grazed, stained with dirt. Here, carefree boys played games with a ball, their shouts muted by the heavy air. Here, too, were the aimless, the weary, the anxious, just like her.

Here, no doubt, were hundreds of others in the same situation. Their situation, their shared anxiety, what was it, in this solemn moment, but the practical question of life? They could live if they wanted to, which is to say, like herself, they had been told so. She saw them all around her, on benches, pondering the information, feeling it change, absorbing it, recognizing it again as something, in a slightly different form, familiar enough, the blessed old truth that they would live if they could.

Translation

Here, undoubtedly, were hundreds of others in the same predicament. Their predicament, their shared anxiety, what was it, at this somber moment, but the fundamental question of existence? They could live if they chose to, meaning, like herself, they'd been informed as much. She saw them everywhere, on benches, mulling over the information, feeling it transform, absorbing it, recognizing it again as something, in a slightly altered form, familiar enough, the enduring truth that they would live if they could.

Everything she shared with them made her want to sit in their company, which she did so far as to look for an empty bench, avoiding a still emptier chair that she saw nearby and for which she would have paid a fee, with a sense of superiority. The last scrap of superiority had soon enough left her, if only because she before long knew herself for more tired than she had proposed. This and the charm, after a fashion, of the situation in itself made her linger and rest; there was a sort of spell in the sense that nobody in the world knew where she was. It was the first time in her life that this had happened; somebody, everybody appeared to have known before, at every instant of it, where she was; so that she was now suddenly able to put it to herself that that hadn't been a life.

Translation

Everything she shared with them made her want to join them. She went so far as to search for an empty bench, avoiding an even emptier chair she saw nearby, which she would have had to pay to use. She felt a brief sense of superiority. That last bit of superiority was soon gone, mostly because she realized she was more tired than she had initially admitted. This, along with a certain, strange appeal to the situation itself, made her stay and rest. There was a kind of enchantment in the feeling that nobody in the world knew where she was. It was the first time in her life that this had happened. Before, it seemed that someone—everyone—had always known where she was every moment. Suddenly, she was able to think that that hadn't been a life.

This present kind of thing therefore might be—which was where precisely her distinguished friend seemed to be wishing her to come out. He wished her also, it was true, not to make, as she was perhaps doing now, too much of her isolation; at the same time however as he clearly desired to deny her no decent source of interest. He was interested—she arrived at that—in her appealing to as many sources as possible; and it fairly filtered into her, as she sat and sat, that he was essentially propping her up. Had she been doing it herself she would have called it bolstering—the bolstering that was simply for the weak; and she thought and thought as she put together the proofs that it was as one of the weak he was treating her.

Translation

This present situation, therefore, might be—and this was precisely what her distinguished friend seemed to want her to emerge into. He also wanted her, it was true, not to make too much of her isolation, as she might be doing now; yet he clearly desired to deny her no respectable source of interest. He was interested—she realized this—in her drawing upon as many sources as possible; and it gradually became clear to her, as she sat there, that he was essentially propping her up. Had she been doing it herself, she would have called it bolstering—the kind of bolstering that was only for the weak; and she thought and thought as she assembled the evidence that he was treating her as one of the weak.

It was of course as one of the weak that she had gone to him—but, oh, with how sneaking a hope that he might pronounce her, as to all indispensables, a veritable young lioness! What indeed she was really confronted with was the consciousness that he had not, after all, pronounced her anything: she nursed herself into the sense that he had beautifully got out of it. Did he think, however, she wondered, that he could keep out of it to the end?—though, as she weighed the question, she yet felt it a little unjust. Milly weighed, in this extraordinary hour, questions numerous and strange; but she had, happily, before she moved, worked round to a simplification.

Translation

Of course, she'd gone to him as one of the weak. But with what a hidden hope that he might declare her, regarding everything essential, a true young lioness! What she was really facing was the realization that he hadn't pronounced her anything. She fostered the feeling that he'd artfully avoided it. She wondered if he thought he could avoid it forever, but as she considered the question, she felt a twinge of unfairness. Milly, during this remarkable time, pondered many unusual questions. But, thankfully, before she moved, she'd arrived at a simplification.

Stranger than anything, for instance, was the effect of its rolling over her that, when one considered it, he might perhaps have "got out" by one door but to come in with a beautiful, beneficent dishonesty by another. It kept her more intensely motionless there that what he might fundamentally be "up to" was some disguised intention of standing by her as a friend. Wasn't that what women always said they wanted to do when they deprecated the addresses of gentlemen they couldn't more intimately go on with? It was what they, no doubt, sincerely fancied they could make of men of whom they couldn't make husbands.

Translation

More bizarre than anything, for instance, was the way it struck her that, if you thought about it, he might have slipped away through one door only to enter with a lovely, generous dishonesty through another. This kept her frozen in place, considering that his actual aim might be a masked plan to be a friend to her. Wasn't that exactly what women always said they wanted when they turned down the advances of men they couldn't pursue a more intimate relationship with? It was what they sincerely believed they could make of men they couldn't make into husbands.

And she didn't even reason that it was, by a similar law, the expedient of doctors in general for the invalids of whom they couldn't make patients: she was somehow so sufficiently aware that her doctor was—however fatuous it might sound—exceptionally moved. This was the damning little fact—if she could talk of damnation: that she could believe herself to have caught him in the act of irrelevantly liking her. She hadn't gone to him to be liked, she had gone to him to be judged; and he was quite a great enough man to be in the habit, as a rule, of observing the difference. She could like him, as she distinctly did—that was another matter; all the more that her doing so was now, so obviously for herself, compatible with judgment.

Translation

And she didn't even consider that, by a similar logic, this was the standard approach of doctors in general toward the sick people they couldn't turn into patients. She somehow knew enough to recognize that her doctor was—as ridiculous as it might seem—exceptionally affected. This was the damning little truth—if she could speak of being damned: that she could believe she'd caught him in the act of irrationally liking her. She hadn't gone to him to be liked; she had gone to him to be assessed. And he was, as a rule, a great enough man to know the difference. She could like him, which she certainly did—that was something else entirely; all the more so because her doing so was now, clearly to herself, consistent with being judged.

Yet it would have been all portentously mixed had not, as we say, a final, merciful wave, chilling rather, but washing clear, come to her assistance. Her sense of superiority quickly faded, mostly because she realized she was more exhausted than she'd intended to be. This, along with the captivating nature of the situation itself, made her stay and relax. There was something magical about knowing that no one in the world knew where she was.

Translation

But it would have been an ominous mess if a final, merciful wave hadn't come to her rescue. It was cold, but it washed everything clean. Her feeling of superiority vanished fast, mostly because she understood that she was more worn out than she thought. This, along with how captivating the situation was, made her stay and unwind. It was magical to know that nobody in the world knew where she was.

It was the first time in her life this had happened. Before, everyone seemed to know where she was at every moment, and she suddenly realized that perhaps that hadn't been a real life. This new experience, therefore, might be the point her distinguished friend wanted her to reach. He also, it was true, wished her not to dwell too much on her isolation, as she might be doing now, but he also clearly wanted to deny her no healthy source of interest.

Translation

This was a first. Previously, everyone had always seemed to know her whereabouts. She now understood that perhaps that hadn't been real life. This new experience might have been what her esteemed friend wanted her to achieve. Granted, he'd also hoped she wouldn't dwell on her isolation, as she might be doing now, but he certainly hadn't wanted to deny her any healthy sources of interest.

She concluded that he was interested in her exploring as many options as possible. It gradually dawned on her, as she sat there, that he was essentially supporting her. If she were doing it herself, she would have called it "bolstering," something done for the weak, and she thought and thought as she considered the evidence that he was treating her as one of the weak. Of course, she had gone to him because she felt weak, but, oh, with a secret hope that he might declare her a formidable young woman!

Translation

She decided that he wanted her to try everything. Sitting there, it slowly hit her that he was, at his core, backing her up. If she were the one doing it, she would've called it "propping up," something you did for people who were struggling. She thought and thought about the proof, considering whether he was seeing her as one of those people. She'd gone to him because she felt weak, of course, but, oh, with a secret wish that he would announce her as a strong young woman!

What she was really facing was the realization that he hadn't declared her anything. She began to suspect that he had skillfully avoided a definitive statement. She wondered, though, if he thought he could avoid it indefinitely, although, as she considered the question, she felt it was a little unfair. During this remarkable time, Milly contemplated many strange questions, but thankfully, before she moved, she had simplified things.

Translation

The truth she was grappling with was that he hadn't labeled her at all. She started to suspect he'd been carefully sidestepping any definitive pronouncements. She wondered, though, if he thought he could keep avoiding it, even though, upon reflection, she thought that was a bit unfair. During this odd period, Milly pondered many strange questions, but fortunately, before she acted, she'd clarified things.

Strangest of all, she realized that, perhaps, he might have avoided the issue in one way but approached it with a kind, dishonest intent in another. It kept her still, thinking that his underlying plan might be a disguised attempt to be her friend. Wasn't that what women always said they wanted when they rejected the advances of men they couldn't be more intimate with? It was what they sincerely imagined they could do with men they couldn't marry.

Translation

The most perplexing revelation was that he might have evaded the subject in one manner, yet in another, he'd approached it with a deceptive tenderness. This realization held her captive, as she considered the possibility that his true aim was a covert attempt to befriend her. Wasn't that the very thing women claimed to desire when they declined a man's romantic advances? It was what they genuinely believed they could manage with men they wouldn't marry.

She didn't even reason that it was, by a similar principle, the general tactic of doctors with patients they couldn't help, as she somehow knew enough that her doctor was—however foolish it might sound—exceptionally moved. This was the damning fact—if she could speak of damnation: she could believe she had caught him irrationally liking her. She hadn't gone to him to be liked; she had gone to be judged, and he was a great enough man to usually recognize the difference. She could like him, as she clearly did—that was something else, especially since her feelings now obviously had nothing to do with her judgment.

Translation

She didn't consider that, in a similar way, it could be the general approach of doctors with patients they couldn't save. She knew, somehow, that her doctor was—absurd as it seemed—deeply affected. That was the damning truth, if she could bring herself to use such a word: she could believe that she'd caught him liking her, irrationally. She hadn't gone to him to be liked; she'd gone to be assessed, and he was generally a man who understood the difference. She could like him, as she clearly did—that was something else entirely, especially since her feelings obviously had nothing to do with her judgment now.

Yet it would have become a tangled situation had a final, merciful wave not come to her rescue, chilling yet clarifying. It came, of a sudden, when all other thought was spent. She had been asking herself why, if her case was grave—and she knew what she meant by that—he should have talked to her at all about what she might with futility "do"; or why on the other hand, if it were light, he should attach an importance to the office of friendship. She had him, with her little lonely acuteness—as acuteness went during the dog-days in the Regent's Park—in a cleft stick: she either mattered, and then she was ill; or she didn't matter, and then she was well enough.

Translation

However, the situation would have become complicated had a final, merciful wave not arrived to save her, cold but clarifying. It came abruptly, when every other thought had been exhausted. She had been asking herself why, if her condition was serious—and she knew what she meant by that—he would have spoken to her at all about what she might pointlessly "do"; or why, on the other hand, if her case were minor, he would have placed such importance on the role of friendship. She had him, with her lonely perceptiveness—as much perceptiveness as one could muster during the dog days in Regent's Park—caught in a bind: either she mattered, and therefore she was ill; or she didn't matter, and therefore she was well enough.

Now he was "acting," as they said at home, as if she did matter—until he should prove the contrary. It was too evident that a person at his high pressure must keep his inconsistencies, which were probably his highest amusements, only for the very greatest occasions. Her prevision, in fine, of just where she should catch him furnished the light of that judgment in which we describe her as daring to indulge. And the judgment it was that made her sensation simple.

Translation

Now he was "acting," as they said at home, as if she did matter—until he should prove the opposite. It was too clear that someone under his kind of pressure must save his inconsistencies, which were probably his greatest sources of enjoyment, only for the most significant opportunities. Ultimately, her foresight of just where she would catch him provided the illumination for that judgment in which we describe her as daring to indulge. And it was that judgment that made her sensation simple.

He had distinguished her—that was the chill. He hadn't known—how could he?—that she was devilishly subtle, subtle exactly in the manner of the suspected, the suspicious, the condemned. He in fact confessed to it, in his way, as to an interest in her combinations, her funny race, her funny losses, her funny gains, her funny freedom, and, no doubt, above all, her funny manners—funny, like those of Americans at their best, without being vulgar, legitimating amiability and helping to pass it off. In his appreciation of these redundancies he dressed out for her the compassion he so signally permitted himself to waste; but its operation for herself was as directly divesting, denuding, exposing.

Translation

He had singled her out—that was the unsettling part. He hadn't known—how could he?—that she possessed a devilish subtlety, the very same kind that characterized those suspected, those suspicious, those condemned. He admitted as much, in his own way, as if fascinated by her complex nature, her odd background, her peculiar setbacks, her curious successes, her unusual independence, and, certainly, above all, her strange ways—strange, like the best of Americans, without being crude, justifying his friendliness and allowing him to feign it. In his admiration for these superfluous qualities, he conjured for her the sympathy he so readily allowed himself to squander; but for her, this action was utterly stripping, denuding, exposing.

It reduced her to her ultimate state, which was that of a poor girl with her rent to pay for example—staring before her in a great city. Milly had her rent to pay, her rent for her future; everything else but how to meet it fell away from her in pieces, in tatters. This was the sensation the great man had doubtless not purposed. Well, she must go home, like the poor girl, and see.

Translation

It reduced her to her essence, which was that of a poor girl with her rent to pay, for instance—staring blankly in a vast city. Milly had her rent to pay, her rent for her future; everything else, except how to manage it, crumbled away from her. This was the sensation the great man had likely not intended. Well, she must go home, like the poor girl, and see.

There might after all be ways; the poor girl too would be thinking. It came back for that matter perhaps to views already presented. She looked about her again, on her feet, at her scattered, melancholy comrades—some of them so melancholy as to be down on their stomachs in the grass, turned away, ignoring, burrowing; she saw once more, with them, those two faces of the question between which there was so little to choose for inspiration. It was perhaps superficially more striking that one could live if one would; but it was more appealing, insinuating, irresistible, in short, that one would live if one could.

Translation

Perhaps there were solutions after all; the poor girl would also be considering them. For that matter, it might come down to perspectives already shared. She looked around again, standing, at her scattered, dejected companions—some so morose they were lying face-down in the grass, turned away, ignoring everything, burrowing. Once more, she saw with them the two sides of the issue, between which there was so little to choose as a source of inspiration. It was perhaps more immediately striking that one could live if one chose to; but it was more enticing, suggestive, irresistible, in short, that one would live if one could.

It hit her suddenly, when she’d exhausted every other line of thought. She'd been wondering why, if her situation was serious—and she knew what she meant by that—he would have even spoken to her about what she might uselessly "do." Conversely, she'd wondered why, if her situation was not serious, he would put so much importance on their friendship. She'd cornered him, with her sharp mind—as sharp as it could be during the summer heat in Regent's Park—in a difficult position: either she mattered, in which case she was ill, or she didn’t matter, in which case she was well enough. Now, he was "acting," as they said back home, as if she did matter—until he proved the opposite.

Translation

It struck her, quite suddenly, after she’d exhausted every other possible line of thinking. She’d been trying to understand why, if her situation was dire—and she knew, she knew—he would have even spoken to her about what she might pointlessly "do." On the other hand, she’d been wondering why, if her situation was not so bad, he would place so much value on their friendship. She’d boxed him in, with her quick mind—as quick as it could be during the summer heat in Regent's Park—in a difficult place: either she mattered, in which case she was unwell, or she didn’t matter, in which case she was fine. Now, he was "acting," as they said back home, as if she did matter—until he proved otherwise.

It was clear that someone as busy as he was would only use his inconsistencies, which were probably his greatest form of entertainment, on the most important occasions. Her ability to predict what he'd do provided the clarity of judgment she was daring to have. And that judgment made her feeling simple. He had singled her out—that was the problem.

Translation

It was obvious that someone with his schedule would only deploy his inconsistencies—which were likely his favorite pastime—on the most significant occasions. Her capacity to anticipate his actions gave her the clarity of judgment she was beginning to trust. And that judgment simplified her feelings. The issue was that he had singled her out.

He hadn't known—how could he?—that she was incredibly perceptive, in exactly the way that someone suspicious and condemned would be. He basically admitted it, in his own way, by showing interest in her complex character, her quirky background, her strange setbacks and successes, her peculiar freedom, and, undoubtedly, above all, her odd behavior—odd, like the best of Americans, not crude, making friendliness acceptable and easier to accept. In his appreciation of these eccentricities, he presented her with the compassion he so readily showed; but for her, it had the effect of stripping her bare, exposing her. It reduced her to her core reality, that of a poor woman with her rent to pay—staring blankly in a big city.

Translation

He couldn't have known—how could he?—that she was incredibly perceptive, in the way a wary, ostracized person would be. He essentially admitted it, in his own way, by showing interest in her complex character, her unique origins, her strange failures and triumphs, her unusual freedom, and, without a doubt, above all, her odd behavior—odd, like the best of Americans, not vulgar, making amiability palatable and easier to reciprocate. In his appreciation of these eccentricities, he offered her the compassion he so freely dispensed; but for her, it had the effect of laying her bare, exposing her. It reduced her to her fundamental reality, that of a poor woman struggling to pay rent—staring blankly in a big city.

Milly had her rent to pay, her rent for her future; everything else, except how to meet it, fell away from her in pieces, in tatters. This was the feeling the great man had likely not intended to create. Well, she had to go home, like the poor woman, and figure things out. There might still be options; the poor woman would also be thinking.

Translation

Milly had to pay rent, the rent on her future. Everything else, except how she’d manage it, crumbled away, shredded to bits. This was probably not the effect the great man had intended. Well, she had to go home, like that poor woman, and work things out. There might still be possibilities; the poor woman would be thinking, too.

It came down, perhaps, to previously considered ideas. She looked around again, standing, at her scattered, miserable companions—some of them so dejected that they lay in the grass, turned away, ignoring everything, burying themselves in their thoughts; she saw once more, along with them, the two sides of the question, between which there was little difference in terms of inspiration. It was perhaps superficially more striking that one could live if one chose to; but it was more appealing, persuasive, irresistible, in short, that one would live if one could. She found after this, for the day or two, more amusement than she had ventured to count on in the fact, if it were not a mere fancy, of deceiving Susie; and she presently felt that what made the difference was the mere fancy—as this was one—of a countermove to her great man.

Translation

Perhaps it came down to things she'd considered before. She looked around again, standing there, at her scattered, miserable companions—some of them so dejected that they lay in the grass, turned away, ignoring everything, lost in their own thoughts. She saw again, along with them, the two sides of the question, between which there was little difference in terms of what motivated them. It was perhaps more immediately striking that one could live if one chose to, but it was more appealing, persuasive, irresistible, in short, that one would live if one could. She found, after this, for a day or two, more amusement than she had expected, in the fact—if it wasn't just a fantasy—of deceiving Susie. And she soon felt that what made the difference was the mere fantasy—like this one—of a countermove against her great man.

His taking on himself—should he do so—to get at her companion made her suddenly, she held, irresponsible, made any notion of her own all right for her; though indeed at the very moment she invited herself to enjoy this impunity she became aware of new matter for surprise, or at least for speculation. Her idea would rather have been that Mrs. Stringham would have looked at her hard—her sketch of the grounds of her long, independent excursion showing, she could feel, as almost cynically superficial. Yet the dear woman so failed, in the event, to avail herself of any right of criticism that it was sensibly tempting, for an hour, to wonder if Kate Croy had been playing perfectly fair.

Translation

His decision—should he decide—to pursue her companion suddenly made her feel, she thought, unconstrained, making any idea of her own acceptable; though in the very moment she allowed herself to enjoy this freedom, she became aware of a new reason for surprise, or at least for thought. Her expectation would have been that Mrs. Stringham would scrutinize her—her description of the reasons for her long, independent journey appearing, she could feel, almost cynically superficial. Yet the dear woman failed, in the end, to make use of any right to criticize, so that it was understandably tempting, for a time, to wonder if Kate Croy had been entirely honest.

Hadn't she possibly, from motives of the highest benevolence, promptings of the finest anxiety, just given poor Susie what she would have called the straight tip? It must immediately be mentioned, however, that, quite apart from a remembrance of the distinctness of Kate's promise, Milly, the next thing, found her explanation in a truth that had the merit of being general. If Susie, at this crisis, suspiciously spared her, it was really that Susie was always suspiciously sparing her—yet occasionally, too, with portentous and exceptional mercies. The girl was conscious of how she dropped at times into inscrutable, impenetrable deferences—attitudes that, though without at all intending it, made a difference for familiarity, for the ease of intimacy.

Translation

Hadn’t she possibly, out of the highest benevolence, driven by the finest anxieties, just given poor Susie what she would have called the straight tip? It must be mentioned right away, however, that, aside from remembering the clarity of Kate’s promise, Milly, next, found her explanation in a truth that had the virtue of being universal. If Susie, at this critical moment, suspiciously spared her, it was really because Susie always suspiciously spared her—though occasionally, too, with significant and unusual kindnesses. The girl was aware of how she sometimes fell into inscrutable, impenetrable deferrals—attitudes that, though entirely unintentional, changed familiarity, the ease of intimacy.

It was as if she recalled herself to manners, to the law of court-etiquette—which last note above all helped our young woman to a just appreciation. It was definite for her, even if not quite solid, that to treat her as a princess was a positive need of her companion's mind; wherefore she couldn't help it if this lady had her transcendent view of the way the class in question were treated. Susan had read history, had read Gibbon and Froude and Saint-Simon; she had high-lights as to the special allowances made for the class, and, since she saw them, when young, as effete and overtutored, inevitably ironic and infinitely refined, one must take it for amusing if she inclined to an indulgence verily Byzantine. If one could only be Byzantine!—wasn't that what she insidiously led one on to sigh?

Translation

It was as though she was reminding herself of her manners, of the rules of courtly conduct—which consideration, more than any other, aided our young woman in her comprehension. It was clear to her, though not entirely certain, that to treat her like royalty was a fundamental requirement of her companion's mindset. Consequently, she couldn't help but accept that this woman held an elevated perspective on how the social set in question ought to be treated. Susan had read history, had read Gibbon and Froude and Saint-Simon; she was keenly aware of the special privileges afforded to the upper class, and, because she had viewed them, when young, as decadent and overeducated, inherently sarcastic and exquisitely mannered, one should find it amusing if she leaned toward a truly Byzantine indulgence. If only one could be Byzantine!—wasn't that the unspoken invitation she slyly issued, causing one to sigh?

Milly tried to oblige her—for it really placed Susan herself so handsomely to be Byzantine now. The great ladies of that race—it would be somewhere in Gibbon—weren't, apparently, questioned about their mysteries. But oh, poor Milly and hers! Susan at all events proved scarce more inquisitive than if she had been a mosaic at Ravenna.

Translation

Milly tried to please her—because it really flattered Susan to adopt a Byzantine attitude. The great ladies of that era—it was probably in Gibbon somewhere—apparently, weren't questioned about their secrets. But oh, poor Milly and hers! Susan, at any rate, proved to be scarcely more curious than if she had been a mosaic in Ravenna.

Susan was a porcelain monument to the odd moral that consideration might, like cynicism, have abysses. Besides, the Puritan finally disencumbered——! What starved generations wasn't Mrs. Stringham, in fancy, going to make up for?

Translation

Susan was a porcelain monument to the strange moral that thoughtfulness, like cynicism, could also have dark depths. Moreover, the Puritan had finally loosened up! What Mrs. Stringham was going to compensate for, in her imagination, for all the generations who had suffered?

For a day or two after this, she found more entertainment than she had anticipated in the possibility, which might be imagined, of deceiving Susie. She quickly realized that the amusement stemmed from the very idea—this one in particular—of a strategic response to her "great man." If he were to try to manipulate her companion, she felt it would make her suddenly unaccountable, making any move of her own acceptable. Yet, as she allowed herself to enjoy this freedom, she became aware of something new to be surprised by, or at least to consider. Her expectation was that Mrs.

Translation

For a day or two after this, she discovered more amusement than she’d expected in the possibility, which could be imagined, of deceiving Susie. She quickly understood that the amusement came from the very idea—this one in particular—of a strategic response to her "great man." If he were to try to manipulate her companion, she felt it would make her suddenly free from responsibility, making any move of her own acceptable. Yet, as she allowed herself to enjoy this freedom, she became aware of something new to be surprised by, or at least to consider. Her expectation was that Mrs.

Stringham would scrutinize her intently, finding her explanation of her lengthy, independent journey to be almost cynically superficial. However, the dear woman failed to utilize any right to criticize, which tempted her to wonder, for a short while, if Kate Croy had been completely honest. Hadn't she, perhaps out of the best intentions, the strongest concern, given poor Susie what she might have considered the truth? However, it must be mentioned that, setting aside the clarity of Kate's promise, Milly soon found her answer in a universally applicable truth.

Translation

Stringham would study her closely, and would consider her explanation for her long, solitary travels to be almost cynically shallow. But the dear woman showed no inclination to criticize, which momentarily tempted her to wonder if Kate Croy had been entirely truthful. Hadn't she, maybe with the best intentions, the strongest care, offered poor Susie what she understood to be the truth? However, it must be said that, ignoring the exact details of Kate's promise, Milly quickly found her answer in a universally accepted truth.

If Susie was unusually lenient towards her during this time, it was because Susie always treated her with suspicion, yet occasionally, also with notable and exceptional kindness. The girl recognized how Susie sometimes adopted impenetrable, inscrutable attitudes—behavior that, though unintentional, changed the dynamics of their familiarity and intimacy. It was as if she were adhering to a code of conduct, a kind of court etiquette—which, above all, helped our young woman to a clear understanding. It became clear to her, though not entirely certain, that treating her like a princess was a necessity for her companion's mindset.

Translation

If Susie was lenient with her during this period, it was because Susie always eyed her with suspicion, even as she, on occasion, showed her remarkable and exceptional kindness. The girl knew how Susie sometimes assumed attitudes that were impenetrable and inscrutable—behavior that, though unintentional, altered the terms of their intimacy. It was as if she were bound by a strict code, a kind of courtly protocol—which, above all, gave our young woman clarity. It became clear to her, though not without lingering doubt, that treating her like a princess was a necessary function of her companion's disposition.

So, she couldn't help but accept that Susie had a high opinion of how such people should be treated. Susan had studied history, read Gibbon, Froude, and Saint-Simon. She was well-versed in the special privileges granted to this class. Since she viewed them, when young, as weak, overeducated, inherently ironic, and infinitely refined, it was amusing that she leaned towards a truly Byzantine level of indulgence.

Translation

Therefore, she had to accept that Susie had a very particular idea of how to treat these kinds of people. Susie had studied history, she'd read Gibbon, Froude, and Saint-Simon. She was well-versed in the advantages that came with their position. Because she'd seen them, in their youth, as fragile, over-educated, fundamentally cynical, and exquisitely polished, it was funny that she was so prone to a nearly Byzantine level of leniency.

If only one could be Byzantine!—wasn't that what she was subtly encouraging one to long for? Milly tried to accommodate her—since it made Susan herself look so good to be Byzantine now. The great ladies of that era—it would be somewhere in Gibbon—were apparently not questioned about their secrets. But oh, poor Milly and hers!

Translation

If only one could be like that! Wasn't that what Susie was subtly encouraging one to want? Milly tried to be understanding—since it made Susie look so good to be that way now. The great ladies of that era—it would be somewhere in Gibbon—apparently weren't questioned about their secrets. But oh, poor Milly and her secrets!

Susie, in any case, proved to be less inquisitive than if she were a mosaic in Ravenna. Susan was a porcelain example of the strange moral that consideration, like cynicism, could have hidden depths. Besides, the Puritan finally shed her burden! What deprived generations, Mrs.

Translation

Susie, at least, showed less curiosity than a mosaic in Ravenna might have. She was a porcelain example of the strange idea that consideration, much like cynicism, could possess hidden depths. And finally, the Puritan had cast off her shackles! Oh, the generations that had been deprived, Mrs.

Stringham was going to compensate for, in her imagination? Kate Croy came straight to the hotel—came that evening shortly before dinner; specifically and publicly moreover, in a hansom that, driven apparently very fast, pulled up beneath their windows almost with the clatter of an accident, a "smash." Milly, alone, as happened, in the great garnished void of their sitting-room, where, a little, really, like a caged Byzantine, she had been pacing through the queer, long-drawn, almost sinister delay of night, an effect she yet liked—Milly, at the sound, one of the French windows standing open, passed out to the balcony that overhung, with pretensions, the general entrance, and so was in time for the look that Kate, alighting, paying her cabman, happened to send up to the front. The visitor moreover had a shilling back to wait for, during which Milly, from the balcony, looked down at her, and a mute exchange, but with smiles and nods, took place between them on what had occurred in the morning. It was what Kate had called for, and the tone was thus, almost by accident, determined for Milly before her friend came up.

Translation

What Mrs. Stringham was going to make up for, in her imagination? Kate Croy went directly to the hotel—arrived that evening shortly before dinner; specifically and publicly, moreover, in a hansom cab that, driven seemingly very fast, pulled up beneath their windows almost with the sound of an accident, a "smash." Milly, alone, as it happened, in the vast, ornamented emptiness of their sitting-room, where, a little, really, like a caged Byzantine, she had been pacing through the strange, drawn-out, almost sinister delay of the night, an effect she still liked—Milly, at the sound, one of the French windows standing open, went out to the balcony that overlooked, with a certain flair, the main entrance, and so was in time to see the look that Kate, alighting and paying her cabman, happened to send up to the front. The visitor, moreover, had a shilling back to wait for, during which Milly, from the balcony, looked down at her, and a silent exchange, but with smiles and nods, took place between them about what had happened that morning. It was what Kate had come for, and the tone was thus, almost by accident, set for Milly before her friend came up.

What was also, however, determined for her was, again, yet irrepressibly again, that the image presented to her, the splendid young woman who looked so particularly handsome in impatience, with the fine freedom of her signal, was the peculiar property of somebody else's vision, that this fine freedom in short was the fine freedom she showed Mr. Densher. Just so was how she looked to him, and just so was how Milly was held by her—held as by the strange sense of seeing through that distant person's eyes. It lasted, as usual, the strange sense, but fifty seconds; yet in so lasting it produced an effect.

Translation

What was also predetermined for her, repeatedly and inevitably, was the fact that the image she saw, the radiant young woman who appeared especially striking in her impatience, with the elegant poise of her gesture, belonged specifically to someone else’s gaze. In short, this poise was the poise she presented to Mr. Densher. That was precisely how she looked to him, and it was precisely in this way that Milly was captivated by her—captured by the strange sensation of perceiving through that distant person’s eyes. It lasted, as usual, this odd feeling, but only for fifty seconds; yet, by persisting, it produced an effect.

It produced in fact more than one, and we take them in their order. The first was that it struck our young woman as absurd to say that a girl's looking so to a man could possibly be without connections; and the second was that by the time Kate had got into the room Milly was in mental possession of the main connection it must have for herself. Kate Croy went directly to the hotel, arriving that evening just before dinner. She arrived conspicuously and publicly in a hansom cab, which, driven at a rapid pace, screeched to a halt beneath their windows with the abruptness of a near accident.

Translation

It produced, in fact, more than one effect, and we shall consider them in order. The first was that it seemed absurd to our young woman that a girl's appearance to a man could possibly be without implications. The second was that by the time Kate had entered the room, Milly had mentally grasped the primary implication it must have for herself. Kate Croy went straight to the hotel, arriving that evening just before dinner. She arrived conspicuously and publicly in a hansom cab, which, driven at a rapid pace, screeched to a halt beneath their windows with the abruptness of a near accident.

Milly, alone in their spacious, decorated sitting room—where she had been pacing, feeling a bit like a caged exotic bird, through the peculiar, drawn-out, almost ominous delay of the evening, an atmosphere she actually enjoyed—Milly, at the sound, with one of the French windows open, stepped onto the balcony. The balcony overlooked the main entrance, and she was in time to see Kate, as she stepped out of the cab and paid the driver, glance upward. The visitor also had a shilling in change to wait for, during which Milly, from the balcony, watched her below. A silent communication, with smiles and nods, passed between them about the morning's events.

Translation

Milly, alone in their large, furnished sitting room—where she had been pacing, feeling like a caged exotic bird, through the strange, drawn-out, almost ominous wait of the evening, an atmosphere she actually enjoyed—Milly, at the sound, with one of the French windows open, stepped onto the balcony. The balcony looked out over the main entrance, and she was in time to see Kate, as she stepped out of the cab and paid the driver, glance upward. The visitor also had a shilling in change to wait for, during which Milly, from the balcony, watched her below. A silent communication, with smiles and nods, passed between them about the morning's events.

This was the news Kate had come to deliver, and the tone of the meeting was thus, almost unintentionally, established for Milly before her friend even came upstairs. What was also determined for her, again, and with an undeniable force, was that the image of the splendid young woman before her—who looked especially beautiful in her impatience, with the striking confidence of her signal—belonged to someone else's perception. That fine freedom, in short, was the same freedom she displayed to Mr. Densher.

Translation

This was the reason for Kate’s visit, and the atmosphere of the encounter was, almost by accident, set for Milly before her friend even reached the upper floors. What was also decided for her, once more, and with irrefutable power, was that the image of the impressive young woman before her—who appeared especially lovely in her eagerness, with the commanding assurance of her gesture—belonged to another’s point of view. That marvelous liberty, in short, was the very same freedom she showed to Mr. Densher.

This was exactly how she looked to him, and it was how Milly was affected by her—held by a strange sense of seeing through that distant person's eyes. This odd sensation lasted, as usual, for only about fifty seconds, but it left an impact. It produced more than one effect, and we'll consider them in order. First, it struck our young woman as absurd to think that a girl looking that way to a man could possibly be without implications.

Translation

That was precisely her appeal to him, and the way Milly was affected by her—captured by a strange sensation of seeing the world through that distant person’s eyes. This odd feeling lasted, as was the norm, for about fifty seconds, but it left a mark. It produced more than a single effect, and we'll address them in turn. Initially, it seemed absurd to our young woman to imagine that a girl who looked that way to a man could possibly be without implications.

The second was that by the time Kate entered the room, Milly had mentally grasped the primary implication it would have for herself. She produced this commodity on the spot—produced it, that is, in straight response to Kate's frank "Well, what?" The inquiry bore of course, with Kate's eagerness, on the issue of the morning's scene, the great man's latest wisdom, and it doubtless affected Milly a little as the cheerful demand for news is apt to affect troubled spirits when news is not, in one of the neater forms, prepared for delivery. She couldn't have said what it was exactly that, on the instant, determined her; the nearest description of it would perhaps have been as the more vivid impression of all her friend took for granted. The contrast between this free quantity and the maze of possibilities through which, for hours, she had herself been picking her way, put on, in short, for the moment, a grossness that even friendly forms scarce lightened: it helped forward in fact the revelation to herself that she absolutely had nothing to tell.

Translation

The second effect was that by the time Kate entered the room, Milly had already understood the primary implication it would have for her. She produced this realization immediately—produced it in direct response to Kate's blunt "Well, what?" The question, of course, with Kate’s eagerness, concerned the morning’s events, the great man’s latest insights, and it surely affected Milly a bit, the way a cheerful request for news can affect troubled people when news isn’t, in a convenient form, prepared for presentation. She couldn't have said exactly what it was that, in that instant, determined her; the closest description would perhaps be the more vivid impression of everything her friend took for granted. The difference between this ease and the maze of possibilities through which she, for hours, had been navigating, took on, in short, for the moment, a coarseness that even friendly forms barely softened: it, in fact, aided the revelation to herself that she absolutely had nothing to say.

Besides which, certainly, there was something else—an influence, at the particular juncture, still more obscure. Kate had lost, on the way upstairs, the look—the look—that made her young hostess so subtly think and one of the signs of which was that she never kept it for many moments at once; yet she stood there, none the less, so in her bloom and in her strength, so completely again the "handsome girl" beyond all others, the "handsome girl" for whom Milly had at first gratefully taken her, that to meet her now with the note of the plaintive would amount somehow to a surrender, to a confession. She would never in her life be ill; the greatest doctor would keep her, at the worst, the fewest minutes; and it was as if she had asked just with all this practical impeccability for all that was most mortal in her friend. These things, for Milly, inwardly danced their dance; but the vibration produced and the dust kicked up had lasted less than our account of them.

Translation

Moreover, there was something else, an influence that was even more elusive at that particular moment. On her way upstairs, Kate had lost that look—that certain look—that made her young hostess think so subtly, and one sign of which was that she never held it for long. Nevertheless, Kate stood there, vibrant and strong, entirely the "handsome girl," beyond all others, the "handsome girl" for whom Milly had initially been grateful. To meet her now with a note of plaintiveness would somehow be a surrender, a confession. Kate would never be ill. The greatest doctor would only keep her, at worst, for a few minutes. It was as if, with all this practical perfection, she had requested all that was most mortal in her friend. These things danced their dance within Milly, but the vibration and the resulting disturbance had lasted less time than it takes to describe them.

Almost before she knew it she was answering, and answering, beautifully, with no consciousness of fraud, only as with a sudden flare of the famous "will-power" she had heard about, read about, and which was what her medical adviser had mainly thrown her back on. "Oh, it's all right. He's lovely." She gave her response immediately—directly answering Kate's clear question, "Well, what?" Kate's eager question, of course, related to the morning's encounter and the great man's latest pronouncements.

Translation

Before she could think, she was replying, and replying beautifully, without any awareness of lying, but rather with a sudden display of the celebrated "willpower" she’d heard and read about, and which her doctor had mostly told her to rely on. "Oh, it’s all right. He’s lovely." She gave her answer right away—responding directly to Kate’s simple question, "Well, what?" Kate's eager question, of course, was about the morning's meeting and the great man's latest pronouncements.

It probably affected Milly the way cheerful demands for news often affect people when they have no easy answers. She couldn't say exactly what prompted her in that moment. Perhaps the best way to describe it was the strong feeling of all that her friend assumed. The contrast between Kate's freedom and the complex uncertainty Milly had been navigating for hours became, for a moment, overwhelming, which even friendly behavior couldn't ease.

Translation

Milly was likely reacting as people often do when they're asked for news and have none they can easily offer. She couldn't pinpoint her motivation in that instant. The most accurate description might be the forceful impression of her friend's assumptions. The difference between Kate's carefree life and the tangled ambiguity Milly had been dealing with for hours was, for a fleeting moment, too much, even for friendly behavior to alleviate.

It brought the realization that she had absolutely nothing to share. Also, something else was at play—something even more mysterious. On the way upstairs, Kate had lost the look—the look—that made her young hostess consider things so carefully, and which Kate could only hold for a brief time. But she stood there, nevertheless, in her youthful beauty and strength, completely the "handsome girl" above all others, the "handsome girl" for whom Milly had initially felt so grateful.

Translation

This brought the stark awareness that she had nothing to offer. And there was something else at work—something even more puzzling. On the way up the stairs, Kate had lost that look—the look—that had made her young hostess overthink things, and which Kate could only maintain for a moment. Yet, she stood there, in her youthful beauty and vigor, truly the "handsome girl" above all others, the "handsome girl" for whom Milly had first felt so much gratitude.

To respond with any hint of sadness would be a surrender, a confession. Kate would never be sick; the best doctor would barely see her. It was as if Kate's perfect health had somehow requested all the most vulnerable things about her friend. These thoughts danced around in Milly's mind, but the disturbance and confusion didn't last long.

Translation

To show any sign of sorrow would be to give up, to admit defeat. Kate would never be ill; the finest physician would hardly get a glimpse of her. It was as if Kate's flawless vitality had somehow claimed all of the most fragile aspects of her friend. These ideas whirled in Milly's head, but the unease and bewilderment didn't linger.

Almost before she knew it, she was answering, and answering beautifully, without any awareness of lying, but with a sudden surge of the famous "willpower" she'd heard and read about, and which her doctor had told her to rely on. "Oh, it's all right. He's lovely." Kate was splendid, and it would have been clear for Milly now, had the further presumption been needed, that she had said no word to Mrs.

Translation

Before she could think, she was responding, and doing so perfectly, without any sense of deceit, but with a sudden rush of that famed "willpower" she'd encountered in books and conversations, and that her doctor had advised her to trust. "Oh, it's fine. He's wonderful." Kate was magnificent, and it would have been evident to Milly by this point, if she'd needed any further confirmation, that Kate hadn't spoken a word to Mrs.

Stringham. "You mean you've been absurd?" "Absurd." It was a simple word to say, but the consequence of it, for our young woman, was that she felt it, as soon as spoken, to have done something for her safety. And Kate really hung on her lips.

Translation

"You mean you've been foolish?" "Foolish." It was an easy word to say, but the result of it, for our young woman, was that she felt it, as soon as it was spoken, to have done something for her protection. And Kate was truly hanging on her every word.

"There's nothing at all the matter?" "Nothing to worry about. I shall take a little watching, but I shan't have to do anything dreadful, or even, in the least, inconvenient. I can do in fact as I like." It was wonderful for Milly how just to put it so made all its pieces fall at present quite properly into places.

Translation

"You're not ill?" "Not at all. I'll need some observation, but there's nothing terrible, not even anything difficult, ahead. I can do whatever I please." It was amazing for Milly; saying it that way made everything fall perfectly into place.

Kate was marvelous, and it would have been obvious to Milly by now, as if further proof were required, that Kate hadn't spoken to Mrs. Stringham. "You mean you've been foolish?" "Foolish." It was a simple word to say, but the result of it, for our young woman, was that she felt, as soon as she said it, that it had somehow secured her.

Translation

Kate was wonderful, and it should have been clear to Milly at this point, as if more evidence were needed, that Kate hadn't talked to Mrs. Stringham. "You mean you've been a fool?" "A fool." It was easy to say the word, but the consequence of saying it, for our young woman, was that she felt, the moment it was out, that it had somehow made her safe.

And Kate was genuinely engrossed. "There's nothing wrong at all?" "Nothing to be concerned about. I'll need some observation, but I won't have to do anything terrible, or even, in the slightest, troublesome.

Translation

Kate was completely absorbed. "There's nothing amiss?" "Nothing to worry about. I'll need to monitor it, but I won't have to do anything awful, or even the least bit bothersome."

"I can do whatever I want." It was astonishing to Milly how simply saying those words made everything immediately click into place. Yet before the full impact could even register, Kate had grabbed her, kissed her, and blessed her. "My love, you're too sweet! It's too dear!"

But it's as I was sure." Then she grasped the full beauty. "You can do as you like?" "Quite. Isn't it charming?"

Translation

"But I knew it would be."

Then she understood the full beauty of it. "You can do whatever you want?"

"Exactly. Isn't that wonderful?"

"Ah, but catch you," Kate triumphed with gaiety, "not doing——! And what shall you do?" "For the moment simply enjoy it. Enjoy"—Milly was completely luminous—"having got out of my scrape."

Translation

"Oh, but you won't," Kate declared triumphantly, her voice light with humor. "Not doing! So, what will you do?"

"Learning, you mean, so easily, that you are well." It was as if Kate had but too conveniently put the words into her mouth. "Learning, I mean, so easily, that I am well." "Only, no one's of course well enough to stay in London now.

Translation

"But I knew it would be like this," she said. Then the magnitude of it all hit her. "You can do whatever you want?" "Absolutely. Isn't it wonderful?"

"Oh, but you," Kate rejoiced with a playful air, "you wouldn't just do nothing! And what will you do?" "Right now, I'll just enjoy it. Enjoy"—Milly's face was radiant—"having escaped my difficulty."

Translation

"Oh, but you," Kate rejoiced playfully, "you wouldn't just do nothing! And what will you do?" "Right now, I'll just enjoy it." Milly's face was radiant. "Enjoy"—she paused—"having escaped my difficulty."

"You mean, realizing so easily that you're healthy." It was as if Kate had perfectly anticipated her. "Realizing, so easily, that I am healthy." "Only, of course, no one is healthy enough to stay in London now.

"You mean, understanding so quickly that you're well." Kate seemed to know exactly what she was thinking. "Understanding, so quickly, that I am well." "Except, of course, no one is well enough to stay in London right now."

He can't," Kate continued, "want this for you." "Mercy, no—I'm to knock about. I'm to go to places." "But not beastly 'climates'—Engadines, Rivieras, boredoms?"
