Kate’s ceremonial embrace and kiss "seal" this identity onto Milly, marking her. * **The Rehearsal:** Frames the entire encounter as a prelude to a larger, more tragic performance, foreshadowing the novel’s central plot.

**3. Subtext and Foreshadowing:** Almost nothing is taken at face value. Kate's talk of Lord Mark is an "alibi," a distraction from unspoken realities. Aunt Maud's final compliment, "Oh, you exquisite thing!", lingers like an "oversweet fragrance," hinting at a cloying, suffocating form of appreciation that values Milly for her utility rather than her self. The repeated references to Sir Luke Strett and Milly's sense that people are rushing to "spare her the road" because she has "so little time to live" are heavy with the foreshadowing of her fatal illness, which becomes the engine of the novel's plot. Kate's declaration, "You may very well loathe me yet!", is a direct and chilling premonition of her eventual betrayal.

In conclusion, this passage is a masterful piece of literary craftsmanship. It functions as a microcosm of the larger novel, establishing the central conflict between innocence and experience, passivity and action. Through a dense tapestry of psychological insight, powerful symbolism, and intricate prose, it stages the critical moment where Milly Theale is both victimized and empowered by being named "the dove," an identity she will carry into the impending drama of her life and death.

It was doubtless because this queer form of directness had in itself, for the hour, seemed so sufficient that Milly was afterwards aware of having really, all the while—during the strange, indescribable session before the return of their companions—done nothing to intensify it. If she was most aware only afterwards, under the long, discurtained ordeal of the morrow's dawn, that was because she had really, till their evening's end came, ceased, after a little, to miss anything from their ostensible comfort. What was behind showed but in gleams and glimpses; what was in front never at all confessed to not holding the stage. Three minutes had not passed before Milly quite knew she should have done nothing Aunt Maud had just asked her.

Translation

It was probably because this odd type of forthrightness seemed self-contained, at the time, that Milly later realized she hadn't actually done anything to amplify it during their strange, indescribable meeting before their friends returned. If she was most aware of this afterward, during the long, drawn-out ordeal of the next morning, it was because she had truly stopped missing anything from their outward comfort until the evening concluded. What lay beneath the surface only flickered into view; what was on the surface never admitted to not dominating the scene. Three minutes hadn't passed before Milly knew she should have refused Aunt Maud's request.

She knew it moreover by much the same light that had acted for her with that lady and with Sir Luke Strett. It pressed upon her then and there that she was still in a current determined, through her indifference, timidity, bravery, generosity—she scarce could say which—by others; that not she but the current acted, and that somebody else, always, was the keeper of the lock or the dam. Kate for example had but to open the flood-gate: the current moved in its mass—the current, as it had been, of her doing as Kate wanted. What, somehow, in the most extraordinary way in the world, had Kate wanted but to be, of a sudden, more interesting than she had ever been?

Translation

She understood this, furthermore, through much the same lens that had informed her dealings with that woman and with Sir Luke Strett. It struck her then and there that she was still caught in a current, determined, through her indifference, timidity, bravery, or generosity—she could hardly say which—by others. It wasn't she who was acting, but the current, and someone else, always, held the key to the lock or the dam. Kate, for example, had only to open the floodgate: the current would move in its mass—the current, as it had been, of her doing as Kate wanted. What, somehow, in the most extraordinary way in the world, had Kate wanted but to be, of a sudden, more interesting than she had ever been?

Milly, for their evening then, quite held her breath with the appreciation of it. If she hadn't been sure her companion would have had nothing, from her moments with Mrs. Lowder, to go by, she would almost have seen the admirable creature "cutting in" to anticipate a danger. This fantasy indeed, while they sat together, dropped after a little; even if only because other fantasies multiplied and clustered, making fairly, for our young woman, the buoyant medium in which her friend talked and moved.

Translation

Milly, for that evening, held her breath in appreciation. If she hadn't been certain her companion lacked any basis for comparison, having spent no time with Mrs. Lowder, she might have imagined the admirable creature intervening to preempt some potential trouble. This particular fantasy dissipated after a time, though they continued to sit together; this was likely due to the proliferation of other fantasies that surrounded and multiplied, effectively creating a buoyant atmosphere in which her friend spoke and moved.

They sat together, I say, but Kate moved as much as she talked; she figured there, restless and charming, just perhaps a shade perfunctory, repeatedly quitting her place, taking slowly, to and fro, in the trailing folds of her light dress, the length of the room, and almost avowedly performing for the pleasure of her hostess. XV It was probably because this odd type of directness had seemed so adequate at the time that Milly later realized she hadn't done anything to enhance it during their unusual, indescribable time alone before their friends returned. If she became aware of this mostly afterward, during the long, difficult dawn of the next day, it was because she had, after a while, stopped missing anything from their outward comfort until the evening ended.

Translation

They sat together, as I've said, but Kate was in constant motion. She was there, restless and captivating, maybe a little bit too eager, frequently getting up from her seat and slowly pacing the room in her light dress, going back and forth, almost certainly putting on a show for the hostess. It was likely that because this strange, straightforward behavior had seemed sufficient at the time that Milly later understood she hadn't added anything to it during their strange, indescribable time alone before the others came back. If she realized this mostly afterwards, during the long, hard dawn of the next day, it was because she had, after a while, stopped wanting anything more from their superficial happiness until the evening was over.

What lay beneath the surface only appeared in brief flashes; what was on the surface never admitted to not being the main focus. Three minutes hadn't passed before Milly knew she shouldn't have done what Aunt Maud had asked. She realized this with the same understanding she'd had with that woman and Sir Luke Strett. It struck her then and there that she was still caught in a current, determined by others through her indifference, timidity, bravery, or generosity—she couldn't quite say which.

Translation

The depths revealed themselves only in fleeting glimpses; what was on display never acknowledged its secondary status. Three minutes hadn't elapsed before Milly knew she'd erred in acceding to Aunt Maud's request. This awareness dawned on her with the same clarity she'd experienced with that woman and Sir Luke Strett. It struck her then and there that she remained ensnared in a current, her course dictated by others through her indifference, her timidity, her courage, or her generosity—she couldn't quite name the driving force.

The current, not she, was in charge, and someone else was always the one controlling the flow, like a lock or a dam. For instance, Kate only had to open the floodgates, and the current moved in its mass—the current of her actions, as Kate desired. Somehow, in the most remarkable way, what Kate seemed to want was to suddenly become more interesting than she'd ever been. Milly, for their evening, held her breath in appreciation.

Translation

The current, not Milly, was in control. Someone else always determined the flow, like a lock or a dam. For example, all Kate had to do was unleash her desires, and the current surged forward—the current of her actions, just as Kate wished. Somehow, in the most remarkable way, Kate seemed to want to suddenly become more interesting than she'd ever been. Milly, for that evening, watched with breathless appreciation.

If she hadn't been sure her friend would have had nothing to go on from her time with Mrs. Lowder, she might have imagined the admirable woman "cutting in" to prevent a problem. This idea did fade after a bit, mainly because other ideas multiplied and gathered, forming a buoyant atmosphere in which her friend spoke and moved. They sat together, but Kate moved as much as she talked.

Translation

If Kate hadn’t been certain that her friend had gained nothing from her time with Mrs. Lowder, she might have imagined the admirable woman intervening to prevent a problem. This notion eventually faded, primarily because other ideas multiplied and took hold, creating a lively atmosphere as her friend spoke and moved. They were seated together, but Kate was as active in her movements as she was in her conversation.

She was there, restless and charming, perhaps a little superficial, frequently leaving her seat, pacing the room slowly in her light dress, and seemingly performing for her hostess's amusement. Mrs. Lowder had said to Milly at Matcham that she and her niece, as allies, could practically conquer the world; but though it was a speech about which there had even then been a vague, grand glamour, the girl read into it at present more of an approach to a meaning. Kate, for that matter, by herself, could conquer anything, and she, Milly Theale, was probably concerned with the "world" only as the small scrap of it that most impinged on her and that was therefore first to be dealt with.

Translation

She was there, restless and charming, maybe a little shallow, often getting up, slowly walking around the room in her light dress, and seemingly putting on a show for her hostess. Mrs. Lowder had told Milly at Matcham that she and her niece, as allies, could practically take over the world. Even though there had been a vague, grand glamour to those words back then, the girl now found more of a meaning in them. Kate, for that matter, could conquer anything on her own, and Milly Theale was probably only concerned with the “world” as the little piece of it that affected her the most, and therefore needed to be addressed first.

On this basis of being dealt with she would doubtless herself do her share of the conquering: she would have something to supply, Kate something to take—each of them thus, to that tune, something for squaring with Aunt Maud's ideal. This in short was what it came to now—that the occasion, in the quiet late lamplight, had the quality of a rough rehearsal of the possible big drama. Milly knew herself dealt with—handsomely, completely: she surrendered to the knowledge, for so it was, she felt, that she supplied her helpful force. And what Kate had to take Kate took as freely and, to all appearance, as gratefully; accepting afresh, with each of her long, slow walks, the relation between them so established and consecrating her companion's surrender simply by the interest she gave it.

Translation

Based on this premise of being handled, she would undoubtedly do her part in the conquering. She would have something to offer, and Kate something to take—both of them thus providing something that would align with Aunt Maud’s vision. In short, this was the situation now—that the occasion, in the quiet, late lamplight, had the quality of a rough rehearsal for the potential grand drama. Milly knew she was being handled—handsomely, completely. She surrendered to the knowledge, for she felt this was the way she provided her helpful force. And what Kate had to take, Kate took freely and, to all appearances, gratefully. She accepted anew, with each of her long, slow walks, the relationship between them, which had been so established, and consecrated her companion’s surrender simply by the interest she gave it.

The interest to Milly herself we naturally mean; the interest to Kate Milly felt as probably inferior. It easily and largely came for their present talk, for the quick flight of the hour before the breach of the spell—it all came, when considered, from the circumstance, not in the least abnormal, that the handsome girl was in extraordinary "form." Milly remembered her having said that she was at her best late at night; remembered it by its having, with its fine assurance, made her wonder when she was at her best and how happy people must be who had such a fixed time. She had no time at all; she was never at her best—unless indeed it were exactly, as now, in listening, watching, admiring, collapsing. If Kate moreover, quite mercilessly, had never been so good, the beauty and the marvel of it was that she had never really been so frank; being a person of such a calibre, as Milly would have said, that, even while "dealing" with you and thereby, as it were, picking her steps, she could let herself go, could, in irony, in confidence, in extravagance, tell you things she had never told before.

Translation

The interest for Milly, we mean, of course; the interest for Kate, Milly felt was probably less significant. It easily and largely arose from their current conversation, from the rapid passing of the hour before the spell was broken—when you consider it, it all came from the entirely ordinary fact that the beautiful girl was in exceptional "form." Milly remembered Kate saying she was at her best late at night; remembered it because its confident declaration had made her wonder when she herself was at her best and how fortunate those with such a fixed time must be. She had no fixed time; she was never at her best—unless, perhaps, exactly as now, in listening, watching, admiring, collapsing. Furthermore, if Kate, quite ruthlessly, had never been so good, the beauty and marvel of it was that she had never truly been so frank; being a person of such caliber, as Milly would have said, that, even while "dealing" with you and, in a way, carefully choosing her words, she could let herself go, could, with irony, with confidence, with extravagance, tell you things she'd never told anyone before.

That was the impression—that she was telling things, and quite conceivably for her own relief as well; almost as if the errors of vision, the mistakes of proportion, the residuary innocence of spirit still to be remedied on the part of her auditor had their moments of proving too much for her nerves. She went at them just now, these sources of irritation, with an amused energy that it would have been open to Milly to regard as cynical and that was nevertheless called for—as to this the other was distinct—by the way that in certain connections the American mind broke down. It seemed at least—the American mind as sitting there thrilled and dazzled in Milly—not to understand English society without a separate confrontation with all the cases. It couldn't proceed by—there was some technical term she lacked until Milly suggested both analogy and induction, and then, differently, instinct, none of which were right: it had to be led up and introduced to each aspect of the monster, enabled to walk all round it, whether for the consequent exaggerated ecstasy or for the still more as appeared to this critic disproportionate shock.

Translation

That was the impression—that she was confiding, possibly for her own comfort; almost as if the misperceptions, the inaccurate assessments, the remaining naivete that needed correction in her listener were, at times, overwhelming for her. She tackled these frustrations with an amused intensity, which Milly might have considered cynical, yet was required—of this the other was certain—by the way the American mind faltered in certain situations. It seemed, at least—the American mind as it sat there, thrilled and dazzled in Milly—incapable of understanding English society without a specific encounter with every case. It couldn't function by—there was a technical term she couldn't find until Milly proposed both analogy and induction, and then, differently, instinct, none of which were correct: it had to be guided and introduced to each facet of the subject, allowed to fully explore it, whether for the resulting exaggerated delight or for the, as it seemed to this critic, even more disproportionate shock.

It might, the monster, Kate conceded, loom large for those born amid forms less developed and therefore no doubt less amusing; it might on some sides be a strange and dreadful monster, calculated to devour the unwary, to abase the proud, to scandalize the good; but if one had to live with it one must, not to be for ever sitting up, learn how: which was virtually in short to-night what the handsome girl showed herself as teaching. At Matcham, Mrs. Lowder had told Milly that she and her niece, as allies, could practically rule the world. Though this statement had a vague, grand appeal at the time, Milly now understood it more deeply.

Translation

Kate conceded the monster might loom large for those born into less developed forms, which were no doubt less amusing. On some levels, it could be a strange and dreadful monster, designed to devour the unwary, humiliate the proud, and scandalize the virtuous. But if one had to live with it, one must learn how—and avoid being perpetually on edge. This was, in essence, what the beautiful girl was demonstrating she could teach. At Matcham, Mrs. Lowder had told Milly that she and her niece, as allies, could practically rule the world. While this statement had a vague, grand appeal at the time, Milly now understood it more profoundly.

Kate, on her own, could probably achieve anything. Milly Theale, on the other hand, was most concerned with the small part of the "world" that directly affected her, the part that needed her attention first. Based on this, she would also do her part in this conquering: she would provide something, Kate would take something. They would each contribute to Aunt Maud's ideal.

Translation

Kate, alone, was likely capable of anything. Milly Theale, however, was mostly preoccupied with the limited sphere of the "world" that directly influenced her, the portion that required her immediate focus. Accordingly, she would also play her role in this dominion: she would offer something, Kate would receive something. They would both contribute to Aunt Maud's vision.

This was the essence of their situation now. The quiet, late evening light felt like a rough practice for a major drama. Milly knew she was being taken care of—generously and completely. She accepted this knowledge, feeling that she was providing her helpful support.

Translation

That's what it all boiled down to, right now. The mellow, twilight glow felt like a dress rehearsal for something huge. Milly understood that she was being looked after—lavishly and without reservation. She embraced this awareness, sensing that she was also making her own helpful contribution.

Kate took what she needed just as freely and, seemingly, gratefully. Kate reaffirmed, with each of their slow walks, the established relationship, validating her friend's contribution simply through her interest in it. Naturally, we're talking about Milly's interest in herself. Milly thought Kate's interest was probably secondary.

Translation

Kate accepted what was offered with the same ease and, it seemed, appreciation. With every shared, unhurried walk, Kate reinforced the bond, acknowledging her friend's role simply by being engaged. Of course, this was about Milly's own self-regard. Milly suspected that Kate's interest was, at best, a secondary concern.

Their current conversations, the quick passage of time before the spell was broken—all stemmed from the fact that the beautiful girl was in extraordinary "form," as Milly noted. Milly remembered Kate saying she was at her best late at night. The statement, with its confidence, made Milly wonder when she herself was at her best, and how happy people must be to have a set time. She had no set time.

Translation

Their present exchanges, the swiftness with which they passed before the magic dissipated, all derived from the beautiful girl's remarkable "form," as Milly observed. Milly recalled Kate mentioning she was at her best late at night. That declaration, delivered with such assuredness, made Milly contemplate when she herself was at her best, and how fortunate some people must be to have a designated time. She had no such thing.

She was never at her best—unless, perhaps, it was in that moment, when she was listening, watching, admiring, and yielding. Furthermore, if Kate was, quite ruthlessly, in better form than ever before, the beauty and wonder of it was that she had never been so honest. Kate was a person of such character that, even while "managing" you and carefully choosing her words, she could be candid, trusting, and extravagant, telling you things she had never revealed before. That was the impression: she was sharing things, likely for her own relief as well.

Translation

Milly thought she was never at her best—unless, maybe, it was in that moment, when she was listening, watching, admiring, and giving in. And if Kate was, in a cruel way, more captivating than ever, the amazing thing was that she had never been so genuine. Kate possessed such a strong personality that, even while "working" you and carefully selecting her words, she could be frank, trusting, and generous, telling you things she had never said before. That was the feeling: she was sharing things, probably for her own peace of mind, too.

It was almost as though the misinterpretations, the misunderstandings, the remaining innocence of spirit still needing correction in her listener, became too much for her to bear at times. She addressed these sources of irritation with amused energy. Milly could have viewed it as cynical, but it was, as far as Milly could see, necessary because of the way the American mind occasionally struggled. It seemed to Kate, watching the American mind sitting there thrilled and dazzled in Milly, that it couldn't understand English society without a specific explanation of every case.

Translation

It was as if the misread signals, the ongoing confusion, and the lingering naiveté in her audience had become, at times, unbearable for Kate. She met these points of friction with a vibrant, amused intensity. Milly might have found it cynical, but, as far as Milly could tell, it was a necessity, given the American mind’s occasional struggles. Watching the American mind, enraptured and bewildered in Milly, Kate felt that it couldn’t possibly grasp English society without a precise explication of every instance.

It couldn't proceed by—there was a technical term she couldn't find until Milly suggested analogy, induction, and then, separately, instinct. None of which were correct. The American mind needed to be introduced to each aspect of the "monster" and allowed to examine it fully. Whether for the resulting exaggerated delight or for the, as Kate saw it, disproportionate shock.

Translation

It couldn’t continue with—there was a technical term that Kate couldn't recall until Milly offered “analogy,” “induction,” and then, separately, “instinct.” None of those were right. The American mind needed to be presented with each part of the “monster” and given the chance to thoroughly scrutinize it. Regardless of the excessive pleasure that might follow, or the, as Kate saw it, overly dramatic surprise.

The "monster," Kate admitted, might seem huge to those raised in less sophisticated environments and therefore probably less entertaining. It could be a strange and terrifying monster, designed to consume the careless, humble the proud, and scandalize the virtuous. But if one had to live with it, one had to learn how, to avoid being constantly overwhelmed, and that was essentially what the beautiful girl was demonstrating she was teaching that night. She gave away publicly, in this process, Lancaster Gate and everything it contained; she gave away, hand over hand, Milly's thrill continued to note, Aunt Maud and Aunt Maud's glories and Aunt Maud's complacencies; she gave herself away most of all, and it was naturally what most contributed to her candour.

Translation

The "monster," Kate conceded, might seem immense to those from less refined backgrounds, and thus, perhaps less amusing. It could be a bizarre, frightening monster, built to devour the unwary, humiliate the arrogant, and shock the righteous. But if one were compelled to coexist with it, one had to learn how, to avoid being constantly overcome, and that was essentially what the lovely girl was illustrating she was teaching that evening. In this process, she surrendered openly Lancaster Gate and everything it encompassed; she surrendered, bit by bit, Milly was still noting with delight, Aunt Maud and Aunt Maud's achievements and Aunt Maud's smugness; she surrendered herself most of all, and it was naturally what contributed most to her honesty.

She didn't speak to her friend once more, in Aunt Maud's strain, of how they could scale the skies; she spoke, by her bright, perverse preference on this occasion, of the need, in the first place, of being neither stupid nor vulgar. It might have been a lesson, for our young American, in the art of seeing things as they were—a lesson so various and so sustained that the pupil had, as we have shown, but receptively to gape. The odd thing furthermore was that it could serve its purpose while explicitly disavowing every personal bias. It wasn't that she disliked Aunt Maud, who was everything she had on other occasions declared; but the dear woman, ineffaceably stamped by inscrutable nature and a dreadful art, wasn't—how could she be?—what she wasn't.

Translation

She never again spoke to her friend in Aunt Maud's manner, about the possibility of reaching the heavens. Instead, she spoke—with a bright, perverse preference on this occasion—about the initial necessity of avoiding both stupidity and vulgarity. It could have been a lesson, for our young American, in the art of seeing things as they were—a lesson so varied and persistent that the student, as we have shown, could only stare in rapt attention. The strange thing, moreover, was that it could achieve its purpose while explicitly rejecting any personal bias. It wasn't that she disliked Aunt Maud, who embodied everything she had previously declared. However, the dear woman, indelibly marked by an inscrutable nature and a dreadful art, wasn't—how could she be?—what she wasn't.

She wasn't any one. She wasn't anything. She wasn't anywhere. Milly mustn't think it—one couldn't, as a good friend, let her.

Translation

She was nobody. She was nothing. She was nowhere. Milly shouldn't think that—one couldn't, as a good friend, allow it.

Those hours at Matcham were inespérées, were pure manna from heaven; or if not wholly that perhaps, with humbugging old Lord Mark as a backer, were vain as a ground for hopes and calculations. Lord Mark was very well, but he wasn't the cleverest creature in England, and even if he had been he still wouldn't have been the most obliging. He weighed it out in ounces, and indeed each of the pair was really waiting for what the other would put down. In this process, she publicly discarded Lancaster Gate and everything in it.

Translation

Those hours at Matcham were unexpected, were pure bliss; or if not entirely that perhaps, with the deceitful old Lord Mark as a supporter, were useless as a basis for hopes and plans. Lord Mark was fine, but he wasn't the brightest person in England, and even if he had been, he still wouldn't have been the most helpful. He measured things out carefully, and in truth, each of them was really waiting for what the other would offer. In the course of this, she publicly abandoned Lancaster Gate and everything it represented.

Milly was captivated, noting how she gradually gave away Aunt Maud, her achievements, and her self-satisfaction. Most of all, she gave herself away, which naturally enhanced her honesty. She no longer spoke to her friend in Aunt Maud's usual manner, about how they could achieve the impossible. Instead, on this occasion, she spoke, with a bright, contrary preference, about the necessity of avoiding both stupidity and vulgarity.

Translation

Milly was enthralled, observing how she slowly distanced herself from Aunt Maud, her accomplishments, and her self-regard. More than anything, she exposed herself, which paradoxically made her more genuine. She no longer addressed her friend as Aunt Maud would have, discussing their ability to achieve the impossible. Instead, on this particular occasion, she spoke, with a clear, contrarian inclination, about the need to steer clear of both foolishness and crudeness.

This might have been a lesson for our young American on how to see things as they truly were, a lesson so comprehensive and consistent that the pupil, as we've seen, could only absorb it with wide-eyed wonder. Furthermore, the odd thing was that this lesson served its purpose while explicitly rejecting any personal biases. It wasn't that she disliked Aunt Maud, who was everything she had previously described. However, the dear woman, indelibly marked by both her inscrutable nature and a dreadful art, wasn't—how could she be?—what she wasn't.

Translation

This might have been a lesson for our young American, showing her how to see things as they really were, a lesson so thorough and consistent that the student, as we've witnessed, could only receive it with open-mouthed astonishment. Moreover, the strange thing was that this lesson achieved its aim while expressly avoiding any personal prejudice. It wasn't that she had an aversion to Aunt Maud, who embodied everything she had previously described. However, the dear woman, indelibly shaped by her unknowable nature and a terrible kind of art, wasn't—how could she be?—what she wasn't.

She wasn't anyone. She was nothing. She was nowhere. Milly shouldn't believe it—as a good friend, she couldn't allow it.

Translation

She was a void. A nullity. A non-place. Milly shouldn't accept this – as a true friend, she couldn’t.

Those hours at Matcham were unexpected, like a gift from heaven. Or perhaps, with old Lord Mark's support, they were as fruitless as a foundation for hopes and plans. Lord Mark was fine, but he wasn't the most intelligent person in England, and even if he were, he still wouldn't be the most helpful. He measured everything carefully, and in truth, each of them was waiting to see what the other would contribute.

Translation

The time at Matcham was a surprise, a stroke of good fortune. Or, considering Lord Mark’s backing, they might be as unproductive as the basis for ambitions and schemes. Lord Mark was a decent man, but not the brightest in the country, and even if he were, he wouldn't be particularly useful. He was meticulous, and frankly, they were all waiting to see what the others would bring to the table.

"She has put down you." said Milly, attached to the subject still; "and I think what you mean is that, on the counter, she still keeps hold of you." "Lest"—Kate took it up—"he should suddenly grab me and run? Oh, as he isn't ready to run, he's much less ready, naturally, to grab. I am—you're so far right as that—on the counter, when I'm not in the shop-window; in and out of which I'm thus conveniently, commercially whisked: the essence, all of it, of my position, and the price, as properly, of my aunt's protection." "She's put you in your place," Milly said, still fixated on the subject. "And I think what you mean is that, on the shelf, she still controls you."

"Lest"—Kate continued—"he suddenly grabs me and runs off? Oh, since he's not ready to run, he's much less likely, naturally, to grab. I am—you're right about that—on the shelf when I'm not in the shop window, in and out of which I'm thus conveniently, commercially whisked: the essence of my position, and, appropriately, the price of my aunt's protection."

The odd effect had been that she consciously needed, as it were, an alibi—which, successfully, she acquired. She had exploited it fully, riding it back and forth across the path Aunt Maud had laid out for Milly, and now she had, so to speak, completely tamed it. Translation

for me—he's upset us all since you've arrived, by wanting someone else. I don't mean someone other than you." "She's dismissed you," Milly continued, still focused on the topic. "And I believe you're suggesting she still controls you."

"Lest"—Kate interjected—"he suddenly takes me and runs off? Since he's not prepared to run, he's certainly less inclined to grab. I am—you're correct about that—on the counter, when I'm not in the shop window; I'm moved in and out of it in a convenient, commercial way. That's the core of my situation and, essentially, the cost of my aunt's protection." Lord Mark was, for all intents and purposes, the subject she'd initiated as soon as they were alone.

Translation

"Lest," Kate interjected, "he suddenly just scoops me up and runs off? He's not exactly going to run, so he's even less likely to grab. I am—you're right—on display, when I'm not in the shop window; I'm moved around as it's commercially convenient. That's the crux of my situation, and essentially, the price I pay for my aunt's protection." Lord Mark was, as far as she was concerned, the topic she'd introduced the moment they were alone.

Milly still felt Kate had deliberately brought up his name, imposing it as a topic, directly countering the other name Mrs. Lowder had left unspoken, the one Kate's own expression had initially maintained for her friend. The immediate strange effect had been that she consciously seemed to need an alibi—which she found, and quite successfully. She had worked it through, used it to ride back and forth across the path Aunt Maud had set for Milly, and now, so to speak, she had broken it in.

Translation

Milly still believed Kate had intentionally steered the conversation to him, forcing his name into the discussion. This was, in effect, a direct response to the unspoken name Mrs. Lowder had introduced, the one Kate's expression had initially reserved for her friend. The strange immediate outcome was that Kate appeared to feel she needed an excuse, which she found, and quite effectively. She'd analyzed it, used it to navigate the course Aunt Maud had laid out for Milly, and now, so to speak, it was fully operational.

"The problem is that if she wants him so badly—wants him, heaven help her! for me—he's disrupted us all, since your arrival, by wanting someone else. I don't mean someone other than you." Milly threw off the charm sufficiently to shake her head.

Translation

"The trouble is that if she's so desperate for him—if, God help her, she wants him for me—then he's thrown us all off balance since you got here, because he wants someone else. I don't mean someone other than you." Milly shed the pretense enough to shake her head.

"Then I haven't made out who it is. If I'm any part of his alternative he had better stop where he is." "Truly, truly?—always, always?" Milly tried to insist with an equal gaiety.

Translation

"Then I haven't figured out who it is. If I'm any part of the person he's interested in, he'd better back off." "Really, really?—always, always?" Milly tried to emphasize with a matching cheerfulness.

"Would you like me to swear?" Kate appeared for a moment—though that was doubtless but gaiety too—to think. "Haven't we been swearing enough?" "You have perhaps, but I haven't, and I ought to give you the equivalent.

Translation

"Do you want me to swear?" Kate seemed to consider the question for a moment—though that was probably just a playful act, too. "Haven't we already sworn enough?" "Maybe you have, but I haven't, and I should offer you something equivalent."

At any rate there it is. Truly, truly as you say—'always, always.' So I'm not in the way." "Thanks," said Kate—"but that doesn't help me." "Oh, it's as simplifying for him that I speak of it."

Translation

At any rate, that's the situation. Truly, truly, as you say, "always, always." So I'm not in the way." "Thanks," said Kate, "but that doesn't help me." "Oh, it simplifies things for him that I mention it."

"The difficulty really is that he's a person with so many ideas that it's particularly hard to simplify for him. That's exactly of course what Aunt Maud has been trying. He won't," Kate firmly continued, "make up his mind about me." Milly shook her head, dismissing the allure.

Translation

"The real problem is that he's got so many ideas swirling around that it's tough to make things simple for him. That's precisely what Aunt Maud has been trying to do. He won't," Kate stated definitively, "make a decision about me." Milly shook her head, as if dismissing the whole thing as unimportant.

"So I haven't figured out who it is. If I'm an option for him, he should just stay away." "Really? Truly?

Translation

"So, I still don't know where I stand. If I'm on the table at all, he should just back off." "Seriously? You really mean that?"

Translation

"Always and forever?" Milly tried to sound casual. "Do you want me to swear on it?" Kate paused, as if thinking—but it was probably just for show.

"Haven't we sworn enough already?" "Maybe you have, but I haven't. I should offer you the same. Anyway, that's the truth.

Translation

"Haven't we sworn enough already?"

"Maybe you have, but I haven't. I should offer you the same. Anyway, that's the truth."

Truly, truly, as you said—'always, always.' So I'm not interfering." "Thanks," Kate said, "but that doesn't solve my problem." "Oh, it simplifies things for him that I'm being clear." "The real issue is that he has so many thoughts, it's hard to make things simple for him.

Translation

"Indeed, indeed, just as you said, 'always, always.' So I'm not getting involved." "Thanks," Kate said, "but that doesn't fix what's going on." "Well, it makes things clearer for him that I'm being direct." "The real problem is that he overthinks, and it's difficult to make things straightforward for him."

That's exactly what Aunt Maud has been trying to do, of course. He won't," Kate declared firmly, "make up his mind about me." "Well," Milly smiled, "give him time." Her friend met it in perfection.

Translation

Of course, that's precisely what Aunt Maud has been attempting. He won't commit to a decision about me," Kate stated resolutely. "Well," Milly smiled, "give him some time." Her friend understood perfectly.

"One is doing that—one is. But one remains, all the same, but one of his ideas." "There's no harm in that," Milly returned, "if you come out in the end as the best of them. What's a man," she pursued, "especially an ambitious one, without a variety of ideas?"

Translation

"One is doing that—one is. But one still remains, all the same, just one of his ideas." "There's no harm in that," Milly returned, "if you end up being the best of them. What's a man," she continued, "especially an ambitious one, without a variety of ideas?"

"No doubt. The more the merrier." And Kate looked at her grandly. "One can but hope to come out, and do nothing to prevent it." All of which made for the impression, fantastic or not, of the alibi.

Translation

"Undoubtedly. The more, the better." And Kate gave her a regal look. "One can only hope to emerge, and not do anything to stop it." All of which created the impression, fantastical or not, of an alibi.

The splendour, the grandeur were, for Milly, the bold ironic spirit behind it, so interesting too in itself. What, moreover, was not less interesting was the fact, as our young woman noted it, that Kate confined her point to the difficulties, so far as she was concerned, raised only by Lord Mark. She referred now to none that her own taste might present; which circumstance again played its little part. She was doing what she liked in respect to another person, but she was in no way committed to the other person, and her furthermore talking of Lord Mark as not young and not true were only the signs of her clear self-consciousness, were all in the line of her slightly hard, but scarce the less graceful extravagance.

Translation

The splendor, the grandeur—for Milly, the audacious, ironic spirit that underpinned it all—was fascinating in its own right. What was no less interesting was the fact, as our young woman observed, that Kate limited her remarks to the difficulties, as far as she was concerned, that Lord Mark presented. Kate didn't allude to the issues her own preferences might create; and this, too, had its significance. She was doing as she pleased with respect to another person, yet she wasn't obligated to that person in any way, and her assertion that Lord Mark wasn't young and wasn't genuine were merely signs of her self-awareness, all consistent with her slightly harsh, yet nonetheless graceful, extravagance.

She didn't wish to show too much her consent to be arranged for, but that was a different thing from not wishing sufficiently to give it. There was something moreover, on it all, that Milly still found occasion to say, "If your aunt has been, as you tell me, put out by me, I feel that she has remained remarkably kind." "Well," Milly smiled, "just be patient." Her friend responded perfectly.

Translation

She didn't want to appear too eager to be set up, but that was different from not wanting it enough. Furthermore, regarding the situation, Milly still felt compelled to say, "If your aunt has been, as you say, annoyed with me, I think she's remained remarkably kind." "Well," Milly smiled, "just be patient." Her friend understood perfectly.

"I am—I am being patient. But one remains, nonetheless, simply one of his ideas." "That's not bad," Milly replied, "if you eventually emerge as the best. What's a man," she continued, "especially an ambitious one, without a range of ideas?"

Translation

"I am—I am being patient. But I'm still just one of his ideas, even so."

"That's not so bad," Milly replied, "if you end up being the best one. What is a man," she continued, "especially an ambitious one, without a whole range of ideas?"

"No question. The more, the better." And Kate regarded her with a regal air. "One can only hope to come out on top, and do nothing to sabotage that." All of this created the impression, whether real or not, of an excuse.

Translation

"Absolutely. The more, the merrier." And Kate looked at her with a commanding demeanor. "One can only aim for the best possible outcome, and avoid any actions that would undermine that." All of this conveyed the impression, whether justified or not, of a justification.

The brilliance and elegance were, for Milly, the bold and ironic spirit behind it, so fascinating in itself. What was also interesting was the fact, as our young woman noticed, that Kate limited her concerns to the issues, as far as she was involved, raised solely by Lord Mark. She didn't mention any issues that her own preferences might create; and this detail was also significant. She was doing what she pleased in regard to another person, but she wasn't at all bound to the other person, and her speaking of Lord Mark as not young and not genuine only revealed her self-awareness.

Translation

For Milly, the brilliance and elegance were captivating because they revealed a bold, ironic spirit. What was also interesting was that Kate only seemed concerned with issues Lord Mark brought up. She didn’t acknowledge any problems her own choices might cause, and that detail was important. She was pursuing her own desires with respect to someone else, but she felt no obligation to that person. Her comments about Lord Mark not being young or genuine just revealed her own self-awareness.

It was all part of her slightly tough, but still graceful, extravagance. She didn't want to seem overly compliant, but that was different from not wanting to consent enough. There was something else, and Milly found an opportunity to say, "If your aunt has been, as you tell me, annoyed by me, I feel that she's been remarkably kind." "Oh, but she has—whatever might have happened in that respect—plenty of use for you!

Translation

It was all part of her slightly tough, yet graceful, extravagance. She didn't want to seem overly compliant, though that was different from not wanting to consent enough. There was something else, and Milly found an opportunity to say, "If your aunt has been, as you tell me, annoyed by me, I feel that she's been remarkably kind." "Oh, but she has—whatever might have happened in that respect—plenty of use for you!"

You put her in, my dear, more than you put her out. You don't half see it, but she has clutched your petticoat. You can do anything—you can do, I mean, lots that we can't. You're an outsider, independent and standing by yourself; you're not hideously relative to tiers and tiers of others." And Kate, facing in that direction, went further and further; wound up, while Milly gaped, with extraordinary words.

Translation

"You've helped her, my dear, more than you've hurt her. You don't realize it, but she's holding onto you. You can do anything—I mean, a lot of things that we can't. You're an outsider, independent and self-sufficient; you're not terribly connected to all sorts of other people." And Kate, speaking in that direction, went on and on; worked up, while Milly was astonished, with remarkable words.

"We're of no use to you—it's decent to tell you. You'd be of use to us, but that's a different matter. My honest advice to you would be—" she went indeed all lengths—"to drop us while you can. It would be funny if you didn't soon see how awfully better you can do.

Translation

"We're no good to you—it's only right to be honest. You'd be helpful to us, but that's beside the point. My real advice to you would be—" she went on at length—"to cut us loose while you still can. It would be funny if you didn't soon see how much better off you'd be."

We've not really done for you the least thing worth speaking of—nothing you mightn't easily have had in some other way. Therefore you're under no obligation. You won't want us next year; we shall only continue to want you. But that's no reason for you, and you mustn't pay too dreadfully for poor Mrs.

Translation

Stringham shouldn't have given you access. She's got the best moral compass imaginable; she's thrilled with her actions. But you shouldn't take your friends away from her. It's been terrible to watch you. "Oh, but she still absolutely needs you, regardless of what's happened!"

You help her more than you hinder her. You don't fully realize it, but she's depending on you. You have so much freedom—I mean, you can do things that we can't. You're an outsider, independent, and self-sufficient.

Translation

You're more of an asset than a liability to her. You don't see it, but she relies on you. You have so much leeway—I mean, you can do things we can't. You're an outsider, autonomous, and self-reliant.

You're not tied down to all these social circles." And Kate, facing towards Milly, continued even further, becoming increasingly animated, while Milly looked on in astonishment at the bold statements. "We can't help you—it's only fair to be honest. You could help us, but that's a different story. Honestly, my advice would be to—" she went so far as to say—"leave us while you still can.

Translation

You're not bound by these social groups." Kate, turning to Milly, continued, becoming more and more excited as Milly watched in astonishment. "We can't help you—it's the truth. You could help us, but that's a separate issue. Frankly, my advice would be to—" she went so far as to say—"get out of here while you still can.

It would be funny if you didn't soon realize how much better off you'd be. We haven't really done anything for you that's even worth mentioning—nothing you couldn't easily have gotten elsewhere. So, you don't owe us anything. You won't need us next year; we'll be the ones who still need you.

Translation

It would be laughable if you didn’t quickly understand how much better your life would be. We haven’t actually done anything for you that's even worth mentioning—nothing you couldn't have easily gotten somewhere else. So, you don’t owe us a thing. You won’t need us next year; we’ll be the ones who still need you.

But that's no reason for you to stay, and you shouldn't suffer too much because poor Mrs. Stringham brought you into this. She has the best intentions; she's thrilled with what she's done. But you shouldn't let her choose your companions.

Translation

However, there's no justification for remaining here, and you shouldn't feel burdened by Mrs. Stringham's role in this. Though she means well, and is delighted with the outcome, you shouldn't let her dictate your associations.

It's been truly awful to watch you do it." Milly tried to be amused, so as not—it was too absurd—to be fairly frightened. Strange enough indeed—if not natural enough—that, late at night thus, in a mere mercenary house, with Susie away, a want of confidence should possess her. She recalled, with all the rest of it, the next day, piecing things together in the dawn, that she had felt herself alone with a creature who paced like a panther.

Translation

"It's been awful to watch you go through this." Milly tried to sound amused, because she was too—it was ridiculous—too afraid. It was very strange indeed—though probably not that surprising—that she would feel this lack of confidence so late at night, in a cheap boarding house, with Susie gone. She remembered, along with everything else, the next day, putting the pieces together in the morning light, that she had felt like she was alone with a creature who stalked like a panther.

That was a violent image, but it made her a little less ashamed of having been scared. For all her scare, none the less, she had now the sense to find words. "And yet without Susie I shouldn't have had you." It had been at this point, however, that Kate flickered highest.

Translation

It was a brutal image, but it made her feel slightly less embarrassed about being frightened. Despite her fear, she at least now had the sense to speak. "And yet, without Susie, I wouldn't have met you." However, it was at this moment that Kate became most animated.

"Oh, you may very well loathe me yet!" Milly attempted to find the humor in the situation, so as not to become truly frightened, which would be ridiculous. It was undeniably odd, though perhaps not surprising, that she should feel uneasy at such a late hour in this rented house, with Susie absent. She remembered the next day, as she reflected on the previous night in the morning light, that she'd felt like she was alone with someone who moved about like a predator.

Translation

"Oh, you might end up hating me!" Milly tried to find the funny side of things, so she wouldn't freak out, which would be ridiculous. It was definitely strange, but maybe not surprising, that she was feeling uneasy at this hour in the rented house, with Susie gone. The next day, when she thought about the previous night in the morning light, she remembered feeling like she was alone with a predator.

It was a dramatic comparison, but it helped her feel less embarrassed by her fear. Despite her fear, she could now articulate her thoughts. "And yet, if Susie hadn't brought you, I wouldn't have met you." It was at this moment, however, that Kate's demeanor was at its most intense.

Translation

The theatrical nature of the comparison allowed Milly to feel less shame about her fear. Even with the fear, she could now express her thoughts. "And still, if Susie hadn't brought you, I wouldn't have met you." It was at this moment, however, that Kate's expression became its most serious.

"You might very well come to despise me!" Really at last, thus, it had been too much; as, with her own least feeble flare, after a wondering watch, Milly had shown. She hadn't cared; she had too much wanted to know; and, though a small solemnity of reproach, a sombre strain, had broken into her tone, it was to figure as her nearest approach to serving Mrs. Lowder.

Translation

"You could end up despising me!" Finally, it was too much, a consequence of Milly's slightest spark, after a long, thoughtful observation. She hadn't been deterred; she'd wanted to know too much. Though a hint of solemn reproach, a somber note, colored her voice, it was her closest attempt at helping Mrs. Lowder.

"Why do you say such things to me?" This unexpectedly had acted, by a sudden turn of Kate's attitude, as a happy speech. She had risen as she spoke, and Kate had stopped before her, shining at her instantly with a softer brightness. Poor Milly hereby enjoyed one of her views of how people, wincing oddly, were often touched by her.

Translation

"Why do you say such things to me?" The question unexpectedly brightened the moment, a shift in Kate's demeanor offering a welcome contrast. She stood up as she spoke, and Kate paused before her, immediately radiating a gentler warmth. Poor Milly, in that instant, observed yet another instance of how her presence, strangely, often moved people.

"Because you're a dove." With which she felt herself ever so delicately, so considerately, embraced; not with familiarity or as a liberty taken, but almost ceremonially and in the manner of an accolade; partly as if, though a dove who could perch on a finger, one were also a princess with whom forms were to be observed. It even came to her, through the touch of her companion's lips, that this form, this cool pressure, fairly sealed the sense of what Kate had just said. It was moreover, for the girl, like an inspiration: she found herself accepting as the right one, while she caught her breath with relief, the name so given her. She met it on the instant as she would have met the revealed truth; it lighted up the strange dusk in which she lately had walked.

Translation

"Because you're a dove." With that, she felt herself embraced, ever so gently, so thoughtfully; not familiarly, nor as a liberty taken, but almost ceremoniously and in the manner of an accolade. It was as if, though a dove capable of perching on a finger, one were also a princess, with whom formalities were to be observed. It even occurred to her, through the touch of her companion's lips, that this form, this cool pressure, fairly sealed the meaning of what Kate had just said. Moreover, for the girl, it was like an inspiration: she found herself accepting as the right one, while she caught her breath with relief, the name she’d been given. She embraced it on the instant, as she would have embraced a revealed truth; it illuminated the strange dusk in which she had lately walked.

That was what was the matter with her. She was a dove. Oh, wasn't she?—it echoed within her as she became aware of the sound, outside, of the return of their friends. There was, the next thing, little enough doubt about it after Aunt Maud had been two minutes in the room.

Translation

That was the problem. She was a dove. Oh, wasn't she? The idea echoed within her as she became aware of the sound outside, of their friends returning. There was little doubt about it after Aunt Maud had been in the room for two minutes.

She had come up, Mrs. Lowder, with Susan—which she needn't have done, at that hour, instead of letting Kate come down to her; so that Milly could be quite sure it was to catch hold, in some way, of the loose end they had left. Well, the way she did catch was simply to make the point that it didn't now in the least matter. She had mounted the stairs for this, and she had her moment again with her younger hostess while Kate, on the spot, as the latter at the time noted, gave Susan Shepherd unwonted opportunities.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder had ascended the stairs with Susan—which she didn't have to do, not at that hour, and instead of allowing Kate to come to her. Thus, Milly could be certain that the move was meant to seize upon the lingering thread they had abandoned. Well, the manner of this seizing was to merely highlight that it didn't matter at all anymore. She'd climbed the stairs for this purpose, and she had her moment alone with her younger hostess while Kate, right there, as Milly observed at the time, afforded Susan Shepherd unusual chances.

Kate was in other words, as Aunt Maud engaged her friend, listening with the handsomest response to Mrs. Stringham's impression of the scene they had just quitted. It was in the tone of the fondest indulgence—almost, really, that of dove cooing to dove—that Mrs. Lowder expressed to Milly the hope that it had all gone beautifully.

Translation

Kate was, in other words, as Aunt Maud spoke with her friend, listening with the most charming reaction to Mrs. Stringham's description of the scene they had just left. It was with the tone of the warmest affection—almost, truly, as though a dove were cooing to another—that Mrs. Lowder told Milly she hoped everything had gone perfectly.

Her "all" had an ample benevolence; it soothed and simplified; she spoke as if it were the two young women, not she and her comrade, who had been facing the town together. But Milly's answer had prepared itself while Aunt Maud was on the stair; she had felt in a rush all the reasons that would make it the most dovelike; and she gave it, while she was about it, as earnest, as candid. "I don't think, dear lady, he's here." Ultimately, it was simply too much.

Translation

Her “all” was generously benevolent; it soothed and simplified. She spoke as if it were the two young women, not she and her companion, who had been facing the town together. But Milly’s answer had been preparing itself while Aunt Maud was on the stair; she had felt in a rush all the reasons that would make it the most gentle. And she gave it, while she was at it, as earnestly, as candidly. “I don’t think, dear lady, he’s here.” Ultimately, it was simply too much.

Milly had shown this with her own subdued reaction after a period of silent observation. She hadn't been bothered; she'd just desperately wanted to understand. Even though a hint of gentle disapproval, a somber note, entered her voice, this was the closest she got to confronting Mrs. Lowder.

Translation

Milly's reaction, understated as it was, had made this clear, after she'd spent some time quietly watching. She hadn't been upset; she had only wanted, with all her being, to understand. Even though a trace of mild disapproval, a somber undertone, colored her tone, this was the most direct she would allow herself to be with Mrs. Lowder.

"Why do you say those things to me?" This unexpected question, as a result of a sudden shift in Kate's demeanor, turned out to be a good thing. Kate had stood up while Milly spoke, and stopped in front of her, immediately beaming at her with a softer glow. Poor Milly was getting another one of those glimpses into how her presence often touched people, even causing them to wince in a strange way.

Translation

"Why do you say those things to me?" The question, delivered without warning in a suddenly changed tone, was a positive development. Kate had risen while Milly spoke and now stood before her, her expression immediately softening into a beam. Poor Milly was experiencing another of those instances where her presence affected people, even causing them to react with a strange discomfort.

"Because you're a dove." With those words, she felt herself embraced, ever so gently and considerately. It wasn't an act of casual familiarity or a taking of liberties, but almost a formal gesture, like a ceremonial award. It was as if, though she was a dove who could perch on a finger, she was also a princess, requiring certain protocols. It even occurred to her, through the touch of her companion's lips, that this gesture, this cool pressure, effectively sealed the meaning of what Kate had just said.

Translation

"Because you're a dove." With those words, she felt herself embraced, gently and thoughtfully. It wasn't casual or presumptuous, but almost formal, like a ceremonial award. It was as if, though she was a dove who could perch on a finger, she was also a princess, requiring certain protocols. It even occurred to her, through the touch of her companion's lips, that this gesture, this cool pressure, effectively sealed the meaning of what Kate had just said.

Moreover, for the girl, it was like a moment of inspiration: she accepted the name given to her, welcoming it as the truth, while breathing a sigh of relief. It illuminated the strange darkness she'd been navigating lately. That was what was wrong with her. She was a dove.

Translation

And for the girl, it became a moment of revelation: she embraced the name bestowed upon her, receiving it as fact, and exhaling a breath of relief. It illuminated the bizarre darkness she’d been wandering through of late. That was it. That was the problem. She was a dove.

Oh, wasn't she?—it echoed within her as she heard the sound of their friends returning. Soon enough, there was little doubt about it after Aunt Maud entered the room. Mrs. Lowder came up, with Susan—which she didn't have to do, at that time, rather than letting Kate go to her.

So Milly was sure she was there to salvage something incomplete. Well, her approach was simply to declare that it was no longer relevant. She'd climbed the stairs for this, and had her moment again with her younger hostess while Kate, as Milly observed, gave Susan Shepherd a rare chance to speak. In other words, Kate, as Aunt Maud engaged her friend, was listening with rapt attention to Mrs.

Translation

Stringham's account of the event they'd just witnessed. With the most heartfelt fondness—almost like a cooing dove—Mrs. Lowder told Milly how much she hoped everything had gone perfectly. Her "everything" was all-encompassing; it was soothing and reductive.

She spoke as if it were the two young women, not she and her companion, who had been facing the town together. But Milly's response had prepared itself while Aunt Maud was on the stairs. She had felt a rush of all the reasons that would make her answer as dovelike as possible, and she gave it, as sincerely and candidly as she could. "I don't think, dear lady, he's here."

Translation

She spoke as if it were the two young women, not her and her companion, who had been facing the town together. But Milly's response had prepared itself while Aunt Maud was on the stairs. She had felt a rush of all the reasons that would make her answer as gentle as possible, and she gave it, as sincerely and candidly as she could. "I don't think, dear lady, he's here."

It gave her straightway the measure of the success she could have as a dove: that was recorded in the long look of deep criticism, a look without a word, that Mrs. Lowder poured forth. And the word, presently, bettered it still. "Oh, you exquisite thing!" The luscious innuendo of it, almost startling, lingered in the room, after the visitors had gone, like an oversweet fragrance.

Translation

It immediately showed her the extent of her potential as an innocent: that was the meaning of Mrs. Lowder's long, deeply critical gaze, a gaze that spoke volumes. And the words that followed only confirmed it. "Oh, you exquisite thing!" The suggestive flattery, almost shocking, hung in the air of the room after the guests departed, like an overly sweet perfume.

But left alone with Mrs. Stringham Milly continued to breathe it: she studied again the dovelike and so set her companion to mere rich reporting that she averted all inquiry into her own case. That, with the new day, was once more her law—though she saw before her, of course, as something of a complication, her need, each time, to decide. She should have to be clear as to how a dove would act.

Translation

But left alone with Mrs. Stringham, Milly continued to absorb it. She again examined the gentle, composed woman and thus directed her companion towards simple, detailed descriptions. Milly avoided all questions about her own situation. That, with the new day, was once more her rule—though she saw before her, of course, a complication: her need, each time, to decide. She would have to be certain about how a dove would behave.

She settled it, she thought, well enough this morning by quite readopting her plan in respect to Sir Luke Strett. That, she was pleased to reflect, had originally been pitched in the key of a merely iridescent drab; and although Mrs. Stringham, after breakfast, began by staring at it as if it had been a priceless Persian carpet suddenly unrolled at her feet, she had no scruple, at the end of five minutes, in leaving her to make the best of it. "Sir Luke Strett comes, by appointment, to see me at eleven, but I'm going out on purpose.

Translation

She handled it, she thought, well enough this morning by fully returning to her plan regarding Sir Luke Strett. That, she was glad to consider, had originally been set at a level of merely shimmering plainness; and though Mrs. Stringham, after breakfast, began by staring at it as if it were a priceless Persian carpet suddenly unfurled at her feet, she had no problem, after five minutes, in letting her sort it out. "Sir Luke Strett is coming, by appointment, to see me at eleven, but I'm going out on purpose."

He's to be told, please, deceptively, that I'm at home, and, you, as my representative, when he comes up, are to see him instead. He will like that, this time, better. So do be nice to him." It had taken, naturally, more explanation, and the mention, above all, of the fact that the visitor was the greatest of doctors; yet when once the key had been offered Susie slipped it on her bunch, and her young friend could again feel her lovely imagination operate. It operated in truth very much as Mrs.

Translation

He's to be told, please, deceptively, that I'm at home, and you, as my representative, are to see him instead when he arrives. He will like that better this time. So be nice to him." Naturally, it had required more explanation, and above all, the mention of the fact that the visitor was the greatest of doctors; yet once the key had been offered, Susie slipped it onto her bunch, and her young friend could again feel her lovely imagination at work. It truly operated much as Mrs.

Lowder's, at the last, had done the night before: it made the air heavy once more with the extravagance of assent. It might, afresh, almost have frightened our young woman to see how people rushed to meet her: had she then so little time to live that the road must always be spared her? It was as if they were helping her to take it out on the spot. Susie—she couldn't deny, and didn't pretend to—might, of a truth, on her side, have treated such news as a flash merely lurid; as to which, to do Susie justice, the pain of it was all there.

Translation

Lowder's had, at the end, the previous night: it once more thickened the atmosphere with excessive agreement. It might almost have scared our young woman to see how eager people were to accommodate her: did she really have so little time left that the path ahead must always be cleared? It was as if they were helping her to get it over with right then and there. Susie—she couldn't deny, and didn't pretend to—could have, truthfully, treated such news as nothing more than a lurid flash; as for that, to be fair to Susie, all the pain was there.

But, none the less, the margin always allowed her young friend was all there as well; and the proposal now made her what was it in short but Byzantine? The vision of Milly's perception of the propriety of the matter had, at any rate, quickly engulfed, so far as her attitude was concerned, any surprise and any shock; so that she only desired, the next thing, perfectly to possess the facts. Milly could easily speak, on this, as if there were only one: she made nothing of such another as that she had felt herself menaced. The great fact, in fine, was that she knew him to desire just now, more than anything else, to meet, quite apart, some one interested in her.

Translation

But, nonetheless, the latitude always afforded to her young friend was present as well; and the proposal now made her—what was it, in brief, but Byzantine? The vision of Milly's understanding of the propriety of the matter had, at any rate, quickly engulfed, so far as her attitude was concerned, any surprise and any shock; so that she only desired, the next thing, perfectly to possess the facts. Milly could easily speak, on this, as if there were only one: she made nothing of the fact that she had felt herself menaced. The great fact, in fine, was that she knew him to desire just now, more than anything else, to meet, quite apart, someone interested in her.

Who therefore so interested as her faithful Susan? The only other circumstance that, by the time she had quitted her friend, she had treated as worth mentioning was the circumstance of her having at first intended to keep quiet. She had originally best seen herself as sweetly secretive. As to that she had changed, and her present request was the result.

Translation

Who, then, was as interested as her devoted Susan? The only other thing she considered worth mentioning, by the time she'd left her friend, was that she'd originally intended to keep quiet. She'd initially envisioned herself as sweetly secretive. She'd changed her mind, and her current request was the consequence.

She didn't say why she had changed, but she trusted her faithful Susan. Their visitor would trust her not less, and she herself would adore their visitor. Moreover he wouldn't—the girl felt sure—tell her anything dreadful. The worst would be that he was in love and that he needed a confidant to work it.

Translation

She didn't explain her change of heart, but she had complete faith in her loyal Susan. Their visitor would trust Susan just as much, and she herself would adore their visitor. Furthermore, he wouldn't—the girl was certain—reveal anything awful. The worst-case scenario would be that he was in love and required someone to confide in.

And now she was going to the National Gallery. Mrs. Lowder's initial assessment gave her an immediate sense of the kind of success she could achieve, like a dove. That assessment was conveyed through a long, critical look, completely silent, that Mrs.

Translation

Lowder had directed at her. The success wouldn't be in the galleries, but the other direction, the social. She felt as though she could flap her wings, float, arrive somewhere. She felt at ease, she could do it. She hadn't been in the National Gallery for ages.

Lowder gave her. And soon, the words that followed improved the situation even more. "Oh, you are exquisite!" The suggestive meaning of that compliment, almost shocking, lingered in the room like an overly sweet perfume after the visitors had left. However, Milly, alone with Mrs.

Translation

Lowder gave her the words. And quickly, the subsequent words improved the situation even further. "Oh, you are exquisite!" The suggestive meaning of that compliment, almost shocking, hung in the air like a cloying perfume after the guests had departed. However, Milly, alone with Mrs.

Stringham, continued to absorb it. She again studied the "dove-like" qualities and encouraged her companion to simply report what she saw, thereby avoiding any direct questions about Milly's own circumstances. That, with the new day, became her guiding principle again – even though she recognized she needed to make decisions each time, which complicated things. She needed to be clear about how a dove would behave.

Translation

Stringham, alone, kept processing the compliment. She again examined the "dove-like" aspects and urged her friend to just describe what she observed, sidestepping any direct inquiries about Milly's own situation. That became her guiding rule again, as the new day arrived, even though she knew she had to make choices each time, which made everything more difficult. She needed to understand how a dove would act.

She decided that morning, by returning to her plan regarding Sir Luke Strett, that she understood well enough. That plan, she was pleased to recall, had initially been presented in a neutral, almost dull tone. And although Mrs. Stringham, after breakfast, seemed bewildered by it, as if a priceless Persian rug had been unexpectedly unrolled at her feet, Milly had no problem, after five minutes, in allowing her to make sense of it on her own.

Translation

She decided that morning, by revisiting her plan regarding Sir Luke Strett, that she understood it well enough. That plan, she was pleased to remember, had originally been presented in a neutral, almost unexciting way. And although Mrs. Stringham, after breakfast, seemed confused by it, as if a priceless Persian rug had been unexpectedly unrolled at her feet, Milly had no problem, after five minutes, allowing her to comprehend it herself.

"Sir Luke Strett has an appointment to see me at eleven, but I'm going out on purpose. He should be told, deceptively, that I'm at home, and, you, as my representative, will see him instead when he arrives. He will enjoy that more this time. So please, be kind to him." Naturally, it had required more explanation, especially mentioning that their visitor was the most renowned doctor.

Translation

"Sir Luke Strett has an appointment with me at eleven, but I'm going to be out. He should be told, falsely, that I'm here, and you, acting on my behalf, will see him when he arrives. He'll prefer that this time. So please, be nice to him." Of course, it required further explanation, particularly regarding their visitor's status as a celebrated doctor.

Yet once the key was offered, Susie quickly grasped it, and her young friend could again feel her captivating imagination at work. In truth, it worked very much like Mrs. Lowder's had the night before, making the atmosphere heavy again with excessive agreement. It might almost have frightened our young woman to see how eager people were to accommodate her.

Translation

Nevertheless, once the key was presented, Susie instantly understood. Her young friend could feel her alluring imagination taking over again. In reality, it operated much like Mrs. Lowder’s had the previous evening, re-establishing an atmosphere thick with overwhelming approval. It might have almost frightened our young woman to witness how desperately people wanted to please her.

Did she have so little time left to live that she would always be spared any effort? It was as if they were helping her use up all her energy at once. Susie – she couldn't deny it, nor did she attempt to – might truly have viewed such news as merely shocking. Regarding that, to be fair to Susie, the pain was definitely present.

Translation

Did she have so little time left that she would always be excused from doing anything? It was as if they were helping her expend all her energy at once. Susie – she couldn’t deny it, nor did she try to – may have genuinely found such news merely shocking. On that score, to be fair to Susie, the pain was definitely there.

But, nevertheless, the leeway her young friend was always granted was also still there. And the proposal now made to her, what was it, ultimately, but Byzantine? The vision of Milly's understanding of the situation had, at any rate, quickly swallowed up any surprise and any shock, as far as her attitude was concerned, so that the only thing she wanted was to completely understand the facts. Milly could easily speak, on this matter, as if there was only one fact: she didn't mention being threatened.

Translation

But the leniency always extended to her young friend persisted. And this proposal to her—what was it, fundamentally, if not Byzantine? The image Milly had of the situation had, at any rate, quickly erased surprise and shock from her demeanor, so that all she wanted was to fully grasp the details. Milly could easily speak, on this subject, as though there were only one fact: she made no mention of being threatened.

The most important fact, in short, was that she knew he wanted, more than anything else at that moment, to meet someone who was interested in her, completely separately. Who, therefore, was more interested than her loyal Susan? The only other thing she felt was worth mentioning, by the time she had left her friend, was that she had initially intended to keep things secret. She had initially envisioned herself as sweetly secretive.

Translation

The main thing, in other words, was that she understood he desperately wanted to meet someone solely because they were interested in her. Who could possibly be more interested than her devoted Susan? The only other thing she felt was worth mentioning, after leaving her friend, was that she had originally planned to keep it a secret. She'd pictured herself as charmingly discreet.

However, she had changed her mind, and her current request was the result of that. She didn't say why she had changed her mind, but she trusted her faithful Susan. Their visitor would trust her just as much, and she herself would adore their visitor. Moreover, she felt certain that he wouldn't tell her anything dreadful.

Translation

However, she'd changed her mind, and her request now stemmed from that. She didn't explain her reasoning, but she trusted her loyal Susan. Their visitor would trust her the same, and she herself would adore their visitor. Furthermore, she felt certain he wouldn't reveal anything awful.

The worst-case scenario would be that he was in love and needed a confidante to help him. And now she was going to the National Gallery.

Translation

The worst that could happen was that he was in love and required someone to confide in. And now she was going to the National Gallery.

Chapter 16

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)

A woman, later identified as Milly, goes to the National Gallery. She walks through the rooms and observes several lady-copyists at work before sitting down to rest. While seated, she watches other museum visitors, particularly a group of American tourists.

A mother and her two daughters pause nearby. The mother makes a comment about something being "handsome" and "in the English style," and then the three of them leave.

Milly stands up to go and turns around. She sees a man, whom she recognizes as Merton Densher. She then sees Kate Croy standing with him. Kate smiles at Milly, and Densher greets Milly with surprise.

Milly invites Kate and Densher to lunch at her hotel, and they accept. They take a carriage from the museum to the hotel. Milly then introduces them to her companion, Susie, who is waiting with lunch.

After the meal, Kate sits with Susie in one room, while Milly and Densher sit and talk in an adjacent room. Densher tells Milly about his travels in the United States.

Literary Analysis (Click to expand)

Excellent. This is a rich and complex excerpt, characteristic of the psychological realism of Henry James, from whose novel *The Wings of the Dove* this text is taken. The protagonist is Milly Theale, a wealthy young American heiress in London, who is secretly and seriously ill.
