And that was that she liked him, as she phrased it to herself, as much as ever. If that meant liking a new person, so much the better. The amusement would only be greater.

She had thought him at first very quiet, in spite of recovery from his original confusion; though even the shade of bewilderment, she yet perceived, had not been due to such vagueness on the subject of her reintensified identity as the probable sight, over there, of many thousands of her kind would sufficiently have justified. No, he was quiet, inevitably, for the first half of the time, because Milly's own lively line—the line of spontaneity—made everything else relative; and because too, so far as Kate was spontaneous, it was ever so finely in the air among them that the normal pitch must be kept. Afterwards, when they had got a little more used, as it were, to each other's separate felicity, he had begun to talk more, clearly bethought himself, at a given moment, of what his natural lively line would be. It would be to take for granted she must wish to hear of the States, and to give her, in its order, everything he had seen and done there.

Translation

She had initially thought him very reserved, even though he'd recovered from his initial confusion. She realized the lingering bewilderment wasn't caused by the vagueness of her renewed self, but perhaps from the sight of countless others like her, which would have been understandable. No, he was quiet, naturally, for the first half, because Milly’s own vivaciousness—her spontaneity—made everything else seem muted. And also, because Kate was spontaneous to a certain extent, it was understood that they must maintain a normal level of interaction. Later, once they’d become more accustomed to each other's separate happiness, he began to speak more, clearly remembering, at a particular moment, what his own natural disposition would be. It would be to assume she wanted to hear about the States, and to tell her, systematically, everything he had seen and done there.

He abounded, of a sudden he almost insisted; he returned, after breaks, to the charge; and the effect was perhaps the more odd as he gave no clue whatever to what he had admired, as he went, or to what he hadn't. He simply drenched her with his sociable story—especially during the time they were away from the others. She had stopped then being American—all to let him be English; a permission of which he took, she could feel, both immense and unconscious advantage. She had really never cared less for the "States" than at this moment; but that had nothing to do with the matter.

Translation

Suddenly, he was overflowing, almost insistent; he'd return to it again and again after a pause. Perhaps the effect was even stranger because he never gave any indication of what he'd found admirable during his travels, or what he hadn't. He simply overwhelmed her with his gregarious narrative—especially when they were alone. At that point, she'd stopped being American—allowing him to be English; a permission he was taking, she could sense, with both tremendous and unconscious ease. She'd truly never cared less about the "States" than at that moment, but that had nothing to do with the issue at hand.

It would have been the occasion of her life to learn about them, for nothing could put him off, and he ventured on no reference to what had happened for herself. It might have been almost as if he had known that the greatest of all these adventures was her doing just what she did then. Gradually, the reality of Kate's actions clarified things. Merton Densher was in love, and Kate couldn't prevent it—she could only be regretful and caring.

Translation

It should have been the moment for her to learn about them, because nothing could deter him, and he avoided any mention of what had happened to her. It was as though he knew the greatest of these adventures was her doing exactly what she was doing then. Gradually, the reality of Kate's actions became clear. Merton Densher was in love, and Kate could do nothing to stop it—she could only feel regret and care for him.

Wouldn't that, without causing a scene, explain everything? Milly, at least, tried to use that as a shield, attempting it with effort, pulling it around her, in the main room, bringing it up to her neck with determination. If it didn't completely protect her, it did enough that she could compensate. She made up for any deficiency with the captivating question of whether, seeing him again, with everything that had happened, her perception of him would be different from her initial impression from New York.

Translation

Wouldn't that, without causing a disturbance, account for everything? Milly, at least, tried to use that as a defense, laboring to do so, drawing it around her in the main room, pulling it up to her neck with determination. If it didn't completely protect her, it did enough that she could compensate. She made up for any shortfall with the compelling question of whether, seeing him again, with everything that had happened, her perception of him would be different from her first impression of him from New York.

That thought preoccupied her from their time at the museum; it remained with her during the carriage ride and lunch; and now that she was alone with him for fifteen minutes, it became urgent. She was to understand during this critical moment that no clear, simple answer, no direct satisfaction on this point, would come to her. She would witness her question itself simply disintegrate. She couldn't determine if he had changed or not, and she neither knew nor cared if she had.

Translation

The thought consumed her from the moment they left the museum. It lingered through the carriage ride, persisted through lunch, and now, alone with him for a quarter of an hour, it intensified. In this crucial moment, she realized that no straightforward answer, no direct resolution to her question, would be forthcoming. The question itself would simply dissolve. She couldn't tell if he had changed, and she neither knew nor cared if she had.

These considerations lost significance in light of the only thing she knew with certainty: she liked him, as she phrased it to herself, as much as ever. And if that meant liking a new person, the enjoyment would only be greater. She had initially found him very reserved, despite recovering from his initial awkwardness. Though she did notice that even the appearance of confusion wasn't due to uncertainty regarding her renewed identity, which seeing so many people like her there would have justified.

Translation

These thoughts faded in importance, eclipsed by the one sure thing: she liked him, as much as she ever had, as she put it to herself. And if that meant liking someone new, so much the better. She had first found him to be very guarded, though he had gotten over his initial discomfort. She realized the confusion she saw wasn't because he was unsure of her new self, which, given all the other women like her, might have been understandable.

No, he was quiet, naturally, for the first half of the time because Milly's own lively manner—her spontaneity—made everything else secondary. Also, because Kate's own spontaneity was so subtle among them that they had to maintain a controlled tone. Later, once they had become more comfortable with each other's individual happiness, he began to speak more, clearly realizing, at a particular moment, what his own natural, animated approach should be. It would be to assume she would want to hear about the States, and to provide her, in a structured way, everything he had seen and done there.

Translation

No, he was naturally reserved for the first while, because Milly’s own exuberance—her impulsiveness—overshadowed everything else. Also, because Kate’s own spontaneity was so understated that they were all forced to maintain a sense of restraint. Later, after they’d grown more accustomed to each other’s individual joy, he started speaking more, clearly understanding at some point what his own natural, lively approach should be. It would be to assume she’d want to hear about the States, and to provide her, in a methodical way, an account of everything he’d seen and done there.

Suddenly, he was full of stories, almost insistent; he would return, after pauses, to the subject. The effect was perhaps more peculiar because he gave no indication of what he had admired along the way or what he hadn't. He simply overwhelmed her with his friendly tales, especially when they were away from the others. She had stopped being American then—all to allow him to be English; a license of which he, she sensed, took both tremendous and unconscious advantage.

Translation

Suddenly, he was overflowing with stories, almost demanding to be heard; he kept circling back to the topic, even after hesitations. It was perhaps stranger because he didn’t reveal what he’d liked or disliked. He just swamped her with his amiable stories, particularly when they were alone. She had stopped being American then—all to let him be English; a privilege he, she felt, used both consciously and without realizing it.

She had never been less interested in the "States" than at that moment, but that had nothing to do with the issue. It would have been the perfect opportunity for her to learn about them, because nothing could deter him, and he avoided any reference to what had happened to her. It was almost as if he knew that the most significant of these events was her doing exactly what she was doing at that moment. It was at this point that she saw the smash of her great question as complete, saw that all she had to do with was the sense of being there with him.

Translation

She was utterly indifferent to America at that moment, but that wasn't the point. This would have been the perfect time to learn about it, because nothing could stop him, and he didn't mention anything that had happened to her. It was almost as if he knew the most important of these events was her being exactly where she was at that moment. At this point, she saw her great question as entirely answered, that all she had to do was be there with him.

And there was no chill for this in what she also presently saw—that, however he had begun, he was now acting from a particular desire, determined either by new facts or new fancies, to be like everyone else, simplifyingly "kind" to her. He had caught on already as to manner—fallen into line with everyone else; and if his spirits verily had gone up it might well be that he had thus felt himself lighting on the remedy for all awkwardness. Whatever he did or he didn't, Milly knew she should still like him—there was no alternative to that; but her heart could none the less sink a little on feeling how much his view of her was destined to have in common with—as she now sighed over it—the view. She could have dreamed of his not having the view, of his having something or other, if need be quite viewless, of his own; but he might have what he could with least trouble, and the view wouldn't be, after all, a positive bar to her seeing him.

Translation

And in what she presently observed, there was no coldness about this: however he had started, he was now acting out of a specific desire, dictated by either new facts or new fantasies, to be, in a simplified way, “kind” to her, just like everyone else. He had already grasped the necessary style, blending in with everyone; and if his spirits had genuinely lifted, perhaps he’d felt he’d stumbled upon the solution to all awkwardness. Regardless of his actions, Milly knew she would continue to like him—there was no other choice; but her heart still sank a little when she realized how much his perception of her was destined to resemble—as she sighed about it now—the general perception. She could have imagined him not having the same view, instead possessing something unique, even if it were without a view at all; but he could have whatever was easiest for him, and the common perception wouldn’t ultimately prevent her from seeing him.

The defect of it in general—if she might so ungraciously criticise—was that, by its sweet universality, it made relations rather prosaically a matter of course. It anticipated and superseded the—likewise sweet—operation of real affinities. It was this that was doubtless marked in her power to keep him now—this and her glassy lustre of attention to his pleasantness about the scenery in the Rockies. She was in truth a little measuring her success in detaining him by Kate's success in "standing" Susan.

Translation

The problem with it, in a general sense—if she could be so uncharitable as to criticize—was that its cloying universality turned relationships into something rather commonplace. It anticipated and took the place of—equally cloying—the function of actual connections. This, without a doubt, was evident in her ability to keep him now—this and her glassy, attentive focus on his enjoyment of the scenery in the Rockies. She was, in truth, measuring her own success in keeping him by how successful Kate had been in “standing up” to Susan.

It would not be, if she could help it, Mr. Densher who should first break down. Such at least was one of the forms of the girl's inward tension; but beneath even this deep reason was a motive still finer. What she had left at home on going out to give it a chance was meanwhile still, was more sharply and actively, there.

Translation

If she had any say, it would not be Mr. Densher who would crack. At least, that was one aspect of the girl's internal struggle. But beneath this significant rationale lay an even more delicate motivation. What she had left behind at home, when she left to give it a chance, was still there, more acutely and actively present than ever.

What had been at the top of her mind about it and then been violently pushed down—this quantity was again working up. As soon as their friends should go Susie would break out, and what she would break out upon wouldn't be—interested in that gentleman as she had more than once shown herself—the personal fact of Mr. Densher. Milly had found in her face at luncheon a feverish glitter, and it told what she was full of.

Translation

The thing that had been at the forefront of her thoughts, then violently suppressed, was resurfacing. As soon as their friends departed, Susie would explode. What she would explode about wouldn’t be, despite her previously demonstrated interest, the personal details of Mr. Densher. Milly had noticed a feverish glint in her eyes at lunch, and it revealed her inner turmoil.

She didn't care now for Mr. Densher's personal fact. Mr. Densher had risen before her only to find his proper place in her imagination already, of a sudden, occupied.

Translation

Susie no longer cared about Mr. Densher's personal life. He had only appeared in her thoughts so she could discover that her imagination was already preoccupied.

His personal fact failed, so far as she was concerned, to be personal, and her companion noted the failure. This could only mean that she was full to the brim, of Sir Luke Strett, and of what she had had from him. What had she had from him? It was indeed now working upward again that Milly would do well to know, though knowledge looked stiff in the light of Susie's glitter.

Translation

His personal details ceased to be relevant to her, and her companion noticed this. The only explanation was that she was completely absorbed with Sir Luke Strett, and with what he had given her. What exactly had he given her? It was that question, now resurfacing, which Milly would be wise to consider, even though such knowledge seemed rather rigid when contrasted with Susie's excitement.

It was therefore, on the whole, because Densher's young hostess was divided from it by so thin a partition that she continued to cling to the Rockies. At that moment, she realized her major question had been completely answered. All she had to focus on was the feeling of being present with him. This realization didn't feel cold, because she also understood that however he'd begun, he was now acting out of a specific desire.

Translation

Consequently, because Densher's young hostess was separated from it by so little, she continued to hold on to the Rockies. In that moment, she understood her most important question had been fully answered. All she had to concentrate on was the sensation of being with him. This realization wasn't unsettling, because she also understood that however it had started, he was now acting out of a specific want.

He was determined—possibly by new information or simply new ideas—to be like everyone else, to be simply "kind" to her. He had already adapted his behavior, falling in line with everyone else. If his spirits had truly improved, he may have felt he'd found a solution to any awkwardness. Regardless of his actions, Milly knew she would continue to like him—there was no other possibility.

Translation

He was resolved—perhaps because of new knowledge, or just new thoughts—to be ordinary, to be merely "kind" to her. His behavior had shifted, aligning with everyone else. If his mood had genuinely brightened, he might have believed he had resolved any unease. No matter what he did, Milly knew she would keep liking him—it was inevitable.

Yet, her heart still sank a little as she realized how much his perception of her would align with the general "view." She had imagined him not having this particular view, or having something unique and individual. However, he was probably choosing the easiest path, and the common view wouldn't entirely prevent her from seeing him. The issue with this view, if she could be so critical, was that its widespread sweetness made relationships rather ordinary. It pre-empted and replaced the—also sweet—development of genuine connections.

Translation

Even so, her heart still dipped a bit as she understood how much his perception of her would mirror the general "consensus." She had pictured him not holding this particular view, or having something unique and individual to offer. But he was likely choosing the simplest route, and the common view wouldn't entirely block her from seeing him. The problem with this view, if she could be critical, was that its pervasive sweetness made relationships rather ordinary. It preempted and replaced the—also sweet—development of genuine connections.

This was likely the reason she was managing to keep him there, along with her unwavering attentiveness to his compliments about the scenery in the Rockies. She was secretly assessing her success in keeping him by comparing it to Kate's success in "tolerating" Susan. If she could prevent it, Mr. Densher would not be the first to leave.

Translation

That was probably why she was still managing to hold onto him, along with her steadfast interest in his compliments about the Rocky Mountain scenery. She was privately measuring her success in keeping him against Kate's success in "tolerating" Susan. If she could help it, Mr. Densher wouldn't be the first to leave.

This was one aspect of the girl's internal tension. However, beneath even this strong motive was a more subtle one. What she had left behind at home when she came to give it a chance, was still, more intensely, present. What had been at the forefront of her mind, then forcefully suppressed, was resurfacing.

Translation

This was a facet of the girl’s inner conflict. Yet, underlying even this powerful drive was a more delicate one. What she'd abandoned at home when she'd arrived to try her luck was still, even more intensely, a presence. What had been foremost in her thoughts, then aggressively pushed down, was now rising again.

As soon as their friends left, Susie would react, and her reaction wouldn't be about—despite her previous interest in him—the personal fact of Mr. Densher. Milly had noticed a feverish excitement in her face at lunch, revealing what she was consumed with. She no longer cared about Mr.

Translation

As soon as their friends departed, Susie would respond, and her response wouldn't be about—despite her prior interest in him—the personal fact of Mr. Densher. Milly had detected a feverish excitement in her face at lunch, betraying what she was preoccupied with. She no longer cared about Mr.

Densher's personal situation. He had only appeared to find his place in her imagination already occupied. His personal fact, as far as she was concerned, was irrelevant, and her companion noticed this. This could only mean that Susie was completely focused on Sir Luke Strett, and what she had gained from him.

Translation

Susie's reaction came swiftly after their friends left, and it didn't involve Mr. Densher, despite her earlier interest. Milly had noticed a frenzied excitement in her face during lunch, revealing her true preoccupation. The details of Mr. Densher's life no longer held any importance for her. It was as if his presence in her thoughts had been preempted. As far as Susie was concerned, his personal circumstances were inconsequential, and Milly observed this change. This could only signify that Susie's attention was fully consumed by Sir Luke Strett, and what she'd acquired through him.

What had she gained from him? It was now becoming clear that Milly should know, even though that knowledge might be difficult, given Susie's excitement. Therefore, she continued to cling to the Rockies, because Densher's young hostess was separated from this issue by such a small barrier.

Translation

What had she gotten from him? Milly realized she should know, though it promised to be a challenge given Susie's fervor. Therefore, she continued to focus on the Rockies, because Densher's young hostess was so close to understanding the matter.
